div.p: A REPLIE TO M. CALFHILLS BLASPHEMOVS ANSWER MADE AGAINST THE TREATISE OF THE CROSSE; BY IOHN MARTIALL, BACHILER of Lawe, and ſtudient in Diuinitie.
READE AND REGARDE.
div.q: Yf any man teache otherwiſe, and doth not encline to the holſome woordes of our Lord Ieſus Chriſt, and to the doctrine which is according to godlynes, he is proude, and one that knoweth nothing, but beating his braynes aboute queſtōis, and ſtrife of woordes. 1. Timoth. 6.
div.p: Imprinted at Louaine by Iohn Bogard at the Golden Bible with the Kinges Maieſties priuilege. 1566.

REgiae Maieſtatis Priuilegio permiſſum eſt Ioanni Martiali in LL. Baccalaureo & ſacrae Theologiae Candidato, vt per aliquem Typographorum admiſſorum impunè ei liceat imprimi curare, & per omnes has ſuae ditionis regiones diſtrahere librum inſcriptū, A replie to M. Calfhills blaſphemous anſwer made againſt the treatiſe of the Croſſe, & omnibus aliis inhibitum ne eundem abſ
que eiuſdem Ioannis conſenſu imprimant vel alibi impreſſum diſtrahant, ſub poena in priuilegio contenta.

div.head: TO M. CALFHILL.
div.p: Non contradicas verbo veritatis vllo modo & de mendacio ineruditionis tuae confundere, Eccleſiaſtici 4.
Speake in no wiſe againſt the woord of truth, but be aſhamed of thyne owne ignorance.

div.head: TO THE CHRISTIAN READER.
div.p: Contradicunt linguae multae: diuerſae hereſes, diuerſa ſchiſmata ſonant: Multa linguae contradicunt veraci doctrinae 〈◊〉 curre ad tabernaculū Dei: Eccleſiā Catholicam tene, & protegeris •• tabernaculo a contradictione linguarum: Auguſt. in Pſalm. 30.

Many tongues do gayne ſay: diuerſe hereſies, diuerſe ſchiſmes do ſounde euery where. Many tongues ſpeake againſt the true doctrine. Runne thou to the tabernacle of God. Keepe the Catholique church, and thou ſhalt be defended in the tabernacle from contradiction of tongues.

div.head: A REQVEST TO MAISTER GRINDAL AND OTHER SVPERINTENDENTS OF THE NEVVE CHVRCHE OF ENGLAND.
div.p:
AMONGEST other godly counſells of the wiſeman this being one,Eccle. 19. that we ſhould not beleue all that is ſaid, I thought it not conueniēt to beleue the publick fame that reported vnto vs, that you M. Grindal did peruſe the anſwer made to the Treatiſe of the Croſſe, and allowe all the doctrine contayned in it, and priuiledge it to the printe, leſt for my light beleauing you might with the ſame wiſe mā accōpte me light of heart. VVherfor as euery one that is deſirous to lerne the truth, when rumors are ſpred inquireth of the authour as occaſion ſerueth for furder triall and better creditte of the thinge: Euen ſo I longing to heare whether the doctrine vttred in the ſaid booke, be the doctrine of all your church of Englād, or the fanſie only of one idle brayne, make this requeſt to you and the reſt of your bretherne, for furder certificate, and ſurer knowledg of this. For albeit the wynkīg at the ſetting forth of it, the permitting it to be ſold, the ſuffring the authour to triūphe of it at the Croſſe, and the not forewarning the people to be ware of it, and longe ſilence to maiſter Dormans requeſt,M. Dorma in the preface. haue miniſtred vehement preſumptiōs both of liking and allowing, yet haue I not adiuged it reaſon, to chardge the whole congregation with it, vnleſſe I haue ſome furder notice and certificate
from you. As you therfore tender the honour of God, truth of the Ghoſpell, and wealth of their ſoules, whome you pretend to bring to Chriſt: So let vs be aduertiſed whether you will iuſtifie all the doctrine vttred in that boke, as the receaued and approued doctrine of all your newe church of England or no. The requeſt is reaſonable: yf you refuſe it, we ſhall iudge of your ſilence accordingly.

Leſt you ſhould hafte in this cauſe, and finde ſome friuolous excuſe, as diſtemperature at the full of the mone, buſineſſe in miniſtring of othes, care in ſending promoters to the hauens, aegerneſſe in ſearching after bokes, and trouble in ſeeking after non communicants, and zeale to apeaſe the contētions amongeſt the brotherhoode for the weightie matters lately in hand, and pretend that you haue no leyſure to take a newe viewe of that old worke, I haue drawē out certayne of his poſitions, and quoted the places in the margent, where you ſhall finde them. And as I truly in effect repete them: So doe I moſt earneſtly require and challenge you and all the reſt of the ſuperintendents (that muſt be ready to geue an accompte of their doctrine to al that aſke) to geue notice and ſignification by ſome pamphlet in print, whether it be the receaued and approued doctrine of all the newe church of England able to be iuſtified by the playne and vndoubted word of God,M. Calfhills poſitions. and by the true and godly fathers of the church, and generall councells within ſix hundred yeres after Chriſt, or when the Ghoſpell was moſt ſincerely preched.
Fol. 3. aThat ſtraunge attire, difference of meate, refuſal of marriadge, ryſing at midnight, making of vowes, ſhutting vp in cloyſter, and moſt wilfull beggery, be ordinances of the diuell.
Fol. 32. bThat faith forceth ſynne vpon vs.
Fol. 35. aThat a naked faith is able to teache hym that neither did nor euer could heare, without any further information that a God there is.
Fol. 124. bThat Latin ſeruice, vowing of chaſtitie, communicating vnder one kinde, are direct contrary to the woorde.

Fol. 135. •
That God commaunded Chriſt only, no church, no councell,
no man to be heard.

That they made a good excuſe that denying the bodie of Polycarpe to the Chriſtians that ſued for it,Fol. 147. b ſaied it ſhould not be delyuered, leſt they would forſake Chriſt, and begynne to woorſhip hym.
That God ſaied of Behemoth and Leuiathan,Fol. 27. a none dare come neare them, none can reſiſte them.
That neuer God, nor good man deuiſed a croſſe.Fol. 170. a
That we hauing the material croſſe can not come to the knowledge of the crucified.Fol. 18. b
That croſsing bread ſuch inconueniēce that the externall actiō had ſtill in reuerence, the inward faith hath ben vntaught.Fol. 26. a

That wherſoeuer a ſigne of the croſſe was,Fol. 25. b we ſhould not thīk that there was a zeale of true deuotion, but as wel, or rather an heatheniſh obſeruāce, and ſuperſtition of them that neuer thought vpon Chriſt.
That the ſigne of the croſſe was made a magical inchauntemēt and cauſe of conqueſt againſt the Chriſtians.Ibidem. b.
That the croſſe was neuer receaued vpon good occaſion.Fol. 26. a
That the croſſe is not the ſigne peculiar to Chriſtians.Fol. 51. b.
That the croſſe is likened to the helmet of hel and coniurers mace.Fol. 29. b
That the diuel ſeemeth to tremble at the ſigne of the croſſe for no other purpoſe,Fol. 29. a. but that we ſhould leaue our confidence in Chriſt, and only repoſe it in a piece of wood.
That the diuel delited in the ſigne of the croſſe.Fol. 117. a.
That more witchcraft, ād ſorcery,Fol. 90. b was done by the ſigne of the croſſe, than with any thing in the world beſide.
That prayer for the dead is a thing of naught.Fol. 36. b
That ſuffrages, interceſsions to Sainctes,Fol. 94. a. and Maſſes are helps to hel.
That it is a generall precept, all men to iudge, al men to trie,Fol. 23. b what doctrine ethey receaue.
That Sainctes honoured with the honour of inuocation,Fol. 26. a are diuels.
That no ſpirite can be woorſe, than he, that hath no faith.Fol. 36. a.
Fol. 52. aThat to dedicate a church in the honour of a ſainct, is a derogation to Gods honour, and contrary to the vſe of the primitiue church.
Fol. 53. bThat it is a poynt moſt ſtrange and diſſonant from al godly lerning to ſay, that Mary mother of Chriſt did make a vowe of chaſtitie.
Fol. 103. bThat there be not ſeuen graces of the holy Ghoſt, mentioned in the 11. of Eſai: or that to gather a ſeuēfold grace out of that chapiter, is to abſurde.
Ibidem b.That the Papiſtes ſaying there be ſeuē graces of the holy Ghoſt, be falſifiers of the ſcriptures.
Fol. 106. aThat the Maſſe is nothing els but the ſacrifice of the diuel.
Fol. 113. b.That anoynting mentioned by S. Iames was temporal, and only touched the preſent ſtate.
Fol. 107. aThat to bleſſe and geue thankes is all one.
Fol. 105. bThat neither ſcripture nor any lerned father commendeth any bleſsing, but of prayer vnto vs.
Fol. 86. aThat Helena for going to Hieruſalem and ſeeking the croſſe, was ſuperſtitious.Fol. 132. a
Fol. 101. bThat S. Dioniſe and Fabian (both holy martyrs) were, the on ſuſpected, the other infamous.
Fol. 103. aThat S. Cyprians ſaying, vngi neceſſe eſt eum qui baptiſatus ſit, etc. It is neceſſary for hym that is baptiſed to be anoynted, was proude and blaſphemous.
Fol. 36. aThat it was blaſphemie for S. Gregorie to report howe a Iewe was preſerued from ſprites by the ſigne of the croſſe.

Fol. 68. aThat the ſeuenth general councell, was a doltiſh and proude Synode,Fol. 160. b an inſolent and doltiſh conſpiracie: A Nice councel, and the fathers a madde company,Ibidem a reuerend aſſes, Synodical men,Fol. 17. a Nice maſters, and their decrees idolatrous dedes and doctrines, and impudent vanities.
Fol. 141. bThat the councel of Elibery or Granata in Spayne was a general councel.
Fol. 145. bThat we making our prayers to ſainctes retayne the memorie of the dead, and call vpon the dead.

Fol. 3 aThat the Papiſtes haue the decrees and decretalls in as ſoueraigne
a price as the Bible.
That the bloud of Chriſt amongeſt the catholiques (whome he calleth a rable of Romiſh heretikes) is a thing of a thouſand leſt accompted of.Fol. 94. a
That ceremonies were vſed in dedication of churches,Fol. 95. a to bring in the diuell.
That within twoe hundred yeres after Chriſt the ſimplicitie of Gods ordinances was refuſed.Fol. 96. a
That the fathers in obſeruances and ceremonies ſcant agreing with them ſelues,Fol 2. 3. a declined all from the ſimplicitie of the Ghoſpel.

That ſithens Silueſters tyme (which was in the yere of our lord 309.Fol. 85. b) ſuch filth of idolatrie and ſuperſtition flowed into the moſt partes of all Chriſtendome, out of the ſynck of Rome, that he needed as many eies as Argus, that ſhould haue eſpied any piece of ſinceritie vntill the miſcreants, and heretikes, to witte Luther and Crammer, beganne to reſtore the decaied ſtate.Fol. 85. b
That Rome is the ſynagog of Satan, ſynke of idolatrie,Fol. 121. b and no membre of the church.Fol, 152. a
That the Pope is the greate Antichriſt of Rome.Fol. 87. b
That Popery is worſe idolatrie than the Iewes.Fol. 133. a.
That yf we light tapers in the day for the vſe and ſeruice of God, it is blaſphemous.Fol. 142. b.
That there is no lauful preſident of any miracle done by the ſigne of the croſſe.Fol. 151. a
That euery citie, euery monaſterie,Fol. 153. b euery priuate pariſh church in Chriſtendom, hath ſome piece of the holy croſſe.
That king Salomon was abuſed by images.Fol. 165. a.
That theſe woordes, Iacob ſummitatem virgae Ioſeph adorauit, Fol. 70. a Iacob woorſhipped the toppe of Ioſephs rodde, was coyned of a father in the coūcel of Nice, and not to be foūde in ſcripture.
That this woorde, Crux, ſignifieth a croſſe piller, a candelſtick,Fol. 79. a a ſtaffetorche, or a pole that carieth the creſſet.Fol. 139. b.
That the ordering of miniſtres is a ſacrament,Fol. 104. b. and yet no ſacrament of the church.
Fol. 99. a.That Impoſition of hādes (which he calleth a ſigne) ſhould not remayne.
Fol. 111. b.That it is blaſphemous and abhominable to call penaūce the ſeconde table or borde after ſhipwrack.
Ibidem b.That it is an horrible lawe not only impious to God, but alſo iniurious to man, that he that diuorceth an adulterous perſon, may not marry another.
Ibidem b.That it is an horrible lawe not only impious to God, but alſo iniurious to man, that youngefolke wilfully contracting them ſelues without their parents cōſent, may marry wel ynough.

Fol. 51. b.That it accordeth not with the doctrine of Chriſt, to ſay: Virtutū opes habere non poſſunt qui voluerint diuitias habere terrenas, they can not haue the ſubſtance of vertues, that will haue the ſubſtance of the earth.
Fol. 120. a.Or that the thing (which was the holy Ghoſt) geuen by impoſition of handes in the Apoſtles tyme, is nowe aboliſhed.
Fol. 99. a.Or that Chat Chriſt is not Legiſlator a lawemaker, and not catholique to call hym ſo.

Theſe with diuerſe other which I omitte to repete, are his poſitions and paradoxes, theſe are his reſolutions and ſayings, as you may ſee in the places quoted in the margent. Nowe yf you haue priuiledged and allowed them as the receaued and approued doctrine of all the newe church of England, for them and euery one of them we require proufe out of the playne and vndoubted worde of God, out of the true and godly fathers of the church, within ſix hundred yeres after Chriſt, and out of lauful councells, within the ſaid terme, or within theſe xiiij. hundred yeres. And that the world may ſee your playne dealing in this behalf, Ley downe the ſcriptures plainly without corruption, ley downe the fathers wordes truly without falſifying. Ley downe the canons of the councells ſimply without all clipping, chaunging and inuerting their wordes. Or yf you haue neither ſcriptures, nor fathers, nor councells for proufe of them, condemne them as blaſphemous, wicked, and vngodly, able to be mayntayned neither by ſcripture, councell, nor any
godly fathers of the church. Yf you ſuffer this doctrine to procede and haue increaſe, as it is ſowed, we may ſay vnto you, as the vertuous emperour Cōſtātine ſaied to the Arriās aſſembled at a Synode in Tyrus: Lib. 3. cap. 7. hiſtor. Tripart. Vos autem qui ſancta myſteria eius clementiae proferre videmini, non dicam cuſtodire, vos inquam nihil agitis niſi quae ad contentionem noſcuutur & odia pertinere, & vt abſolute dicam, quae ad humani generis tendere videntur interitum. You who ſeeme to bring foorth, I will not ſay keepe the myſteries of his mercie, you I ſay, doe nothing but that which is knowen to pertayne to contention and debate, and ſeme to tende, (that I may ſpeake fully and wholy as it is) to the deſtruction of all man kinde. Or yf you fanſie not Conſtantines ſaying, I will ſay vnto you as that valiaunt Emperour Charles the fyft ſayed of Luther in his edicte ſet forth at VVormes in this ſort: Lutherus ſcribit nihil ferè aliud, niſi quod ad ſeditionem, ſchiſma, bellum, caedes, rapinas, incendia, & ad defectionem vniuerſalem Chriſtiana fidei tendit atque ſubſeruit: Luther writeth almoſt nothing els, but that which tendeth and ſerueth to ſedition, ſchiſme, batail, ſlaughter, robberies, burnings, and to the generall reuolt and defection of the Chriſtiann faith. Or yf that like you not, we will ſay of you as our noble king, Henry of famous memorie ſpoke of the ſame friers faction. Nulla vnquam factio fuit ita ſeditioſa, Peſtilens, nepharia, Epiſt. ad duces Saxo. quae ſic religionem omnem tollere, leges omnes ob • ilere, mores omnes bonos corrumpere, res publicas omnes euertere, machinata fit, vt nunc iſta coniuratio Lutherana. There was neuer factiō ſo ſeditious, ſo peſtilēt, ſo wicked, which ſo endeuored to take away all religion, to oppreſſe all Lawes, to corrupt all good manners as this conſpiracie of the Lutherans doth nowe. The counſells of Chriſte in his Ghoſpel, to be called ordinances of the diuell, ſuffrages helpes to hel, The lawe of God and his church forbidding hym that diuorceth an adulterous ꝑſon to marry another whiles the partie lyueth, horrible and impious, the prayers of Chriſtians a ſacrifice of the diuel, Chriſt no lawe maker, and his Ghoſpel no Lawe, what is to endeuour to bring a generall reuolt and defection from all Chriſtian religion and faith, yf this be not Grindall? Conſider it, you were beſt. The matter is weightie, and the tyme perilous.
And whereby a figure called praeoccupatio, you chardge vs that our bokes are ſeditious, yf it may pleaſe you to examine them indifferently, it will eaſely be eſpied whether your diuines bokes breathe ſedition, or ours. Let the lerned iudge: prayſed be God, There is no blaſt blowen againſt the monſtruous regimēt of womē. There is no libel ſet foorth for order of ſucceſsiō: there is no word vttred agaīſt dewe obediēce to the ſoueraine.

As for corrupt gaynes which is another foule fault that you chardge vs withall, we are thankes be to God ſo farre from all iuſt reproufe in this behalf, that euer more we were content to geue the copies of our bokes and gaynes whatſoeuer it were, to him that would bare the chardges of the print, and conuey them into the realme. And as yet, yf it will pleaſe you either to ſend vs mony to bare ſuch neceſſarye charges, or apoynt ſome frend of yours that will faithfully print and trulye ſet them foorth to the ſight of the worlde, you and your factour ſhall haue all the gaynes, that may be made. At this preſent I haue gathered together maiſter Calfhils lies, contradictions, falſe tranſlations, falſifying the ſcriptures, corrupting the doctours, which will make a pretie volume, and becauſe I could not conueniently ſet them foorth together with this replie, I haue reſerued them to another tyme. Nowe yf it wil pleaſe you to trie whether I wil ſtād to the performāce of my promiſe, ſend your factour with your lettre and he ſhall be heard with the conditions afore mentioned. S. Auguſtine declaring certayne properties of the hartes in the foreſt,In Pſa. 41 ſaieth: They rūne very ſwift to the foūtaynes ād ryuers, they kil ſerpēts, and after the killing of thē are very thyrſtie, and when they will ſwymme ouer into any other cuntrie, they ley their hornes one vpon another: and applying that to vs, he ſaieth: Sic nos Chriſtiani debemus velociter currere ad fontes aquarum, & vitia, ſerpentes iniquitatis noſtrae interimere, vt amplius deſideremus fontes veritatis: Debemus inuicem onera portare & ſic adimplere legem Chriſti. So we Chriſten men ought to runne ſwiftely to the fountaynes of water, and kill ſynnes, the ſerpentes of our iniquitie, that we may the more deſire the fountaynes of truthe, we ought to beare one anothers burden, and
ſo fulfill the lawe of Chriſt. Nowe yf your zeale be ſuch as you pretend to the Chriſten religion, and furderance of truth geue vs leaue to runne to the fountaynes of water, to kill the ſerpents of iniquitie, to impugne your hereſies, to detect your miniſters lies, keepe not our bookes from them, that would come to the fountaynes of truthe, but as you loue the truth, ſo beare part of the burden with vs, and fulfill the lawe of Chriſt. God ſend you his grace, and ſpirite of truth.

div.head: TO THE NEVVE CLERGIE.

p.hi: Deponentes mendacium loquimini veritatem vnuſquiſque cum proximo ſuo, quia ſumus inuicem membra, Epheſ. 4.

div.p: Leying away all lying ſpeake the truth, euery man to his neighbour, for as much as we are membres one of another.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p:
HAuing reade and regarded the anſwer to the treatiſe of the croſſe, and finding the ſcriptures falſified, the councells diſauthoriſed, the fathers corrupted, the doctours miſcōſtrued, the ſacraments prophanelye reported, the churche diſcredited, the vertuous ſclaundered, S. Cyprian reiected asFol. 103 a blaſphemous, 101 b Fabianus an holy martir refuſed as infamous, S. Dionyſe Paules ſcholler condemned as ſuſpicious, 132 a Helena a bleſſed ſaincte neglected as ſuperſtitious. S. Gregory as fabulous, 6. b Paulinus as zelous without knowledge, the fathers of the Nicene councell called68. a Aſſes, Nice 68. a maiſters, and70. a Sinodicall men, their aſſemble an 182. a. inſolēt, doltiſhe cōſpiracie, diſſembling at Nice,
their decrees impudent Fol. 163. b Fol. 17. a. vanities and idolatrous dedes and doctrines, the doctours vnworthied of auctoritie, as mē that had Fol. 120. b errours, men that thought Fol. 29. b. better than they wrote, mē that Ibidem. borowed of the cōmon cuſtome impropre phraſes, ſuch as ſeeme to mayntayne an errour, men that were not ſo wel affectioned as they Fol. 89. a oughte, mē that in termes Fol. 175. b ouer ſhotte them ſelues, men that declined all, from the Fol. 23. a ſimplicitie of the Ghoſpell, To be ſhort finding the croſſe, which in the holy ſcriptures and auncient fathers is called,Apoca. 7. Signum Dei, Signum Matth. 24 filij hominis, Signum Caſsio. in Pſal. 4. coeleſtis Imperatoris, Theod. ca. 1. li 6. Trip. figura dominici trophaei, Chriſoſt. in demōſt. cont. gent. Argumentum multae benedictionis, Aug. ca 3. de viſit. in. venerabile monumentum, Salutare, Cyril. li. 6. cōt. Iulia. & Lactantius de paſsio. precioſum, venerabile lignum, Ephrē de poenit. viuificum ſignum, Cano. 73. Concil. Cō ſtā. in Trull. victoriae trophaeum, Lactā. li 4 c. 27. de vera ſapi. c. 26. coeleſtis nota, maximum ſublime & immortale ſignum, Aug ſer. de cruce & lat. res honoris, mortis deuictae Cyril. hie roſ. epiſt. ad Cōſt Impe. trophaeum, Lactā. ca. 27. lib. 4 de vera ſapiēt. & Aug. c 20 de cathe. ru. Signum paſsionis, Chriſ. ho. 55. 116. Mat. & Iuſti. Tit. de Monac. Nouel col 1 Signum ſalutis noſtrae, Chriſ ho 55. in 16. Mat. Signum communis libertatis, ſignum manſuetudinis & humilitatis domini, Amb li. 6 c. 4. de Sacr. Signum virtutis, & Paulinꝰ epi. 11 ad Seuer. pignus aeternae ſalutis, the ſigne of God, the ſigne of the ſonne of man, the ſigne of the heauenly Emperour, the figure of our lordes triumphe, a token of much bleſsing, an honorable monument, an healthfull, precious, and reuerend wood, a liuely ſigne, a triumphant banner of victorie, an heauenly marke, a moſt greate, high and immortall ſigne, a pearle of price, a ſigne of the conqueſt ouer death, a ſigne of Chriſtes paſsion, a ſigne of our ſaluation, a ſigne of the delyueraunce of all mankinde, a ſigne of the meekenes, and humilitie of Chriſt, a ſigne of vertue and pledge of eternall ſaluation, to be likened toFol. 44. b. gallowes, to the helmet29. b. of hell, to the coniurers mace, and called a magicall25. b. inchauntemēt, an heatheniſh117. a. obſeruance, a ſtumbling176. b ſtock, a128 a. ſtone of offence, a25. b. cauſe of ſicknes, a106. a. dumbe God, a94 a. dead diuell, a3. a counterfeict of Serapis, and120 a. conqueſt againſt the Chriſtians, and prayers of the church a ſacrifice of the diuel, ſuffrages helps to hel, our ſauiours counſels ordinances of the diuel, Chriſt no lawemaker and his Ghoſpell by conſequent no lawe
I thought it good to contemne it, as a famous libel, ful of lyes,M. dormā in his preface. ſclaunders, and blaſphemies, and let it lye obſcure with the authour, eſpecially ſeing the ſuperintendents, being demaunded, whether they would iuſtifie the ſaide booke, and all the doctrine contayned in it, haue geuen no ſignification nor notice of their liking, leſt yf vpon their generall lyking, it ſhoulde be confuted, the ignominie ſhould redounde vnto them, whereas nowe the whole ſhame lieth but in one pratīg Parrat,Prouer. 26 more woorthy to be contemned than anſwered.

But when I conſidered that ſaying of Salomō, Anſwer a foole accordinge to his fooliſhnes that he may not ſeme wyſe vnto him ſelfe, I thought it good to examine the forſaid anſwer, and diſcouer the folly of it, that bothe the authour ſeing his vanities layed before his eies, might be aſſhamed of his arrogancie, ād with the ꝓude peacocke, lookīg vpō his foule feete, caſt downe his braggīg tayle ād abhorre his ſerpētine voyce, ād alſo the ſimple reader poyſoned with the venemoꝰ drugges, of his gay coloured, ād ſweete ſugered wordes, might haue a remedy to expel that infectiō, ād preſeruatyue to beware of the like. VVherfore al his ſuperfluities caſt aſide, and impertinēts loted out, I will bringe the chiefeſt and moſt principalſt matters, that he treateth in his anſwer, to this examination. And that yow may the better vnderſtand which are the wordes that M. Calfhill vſeth either of ſcripture, Doctour, Councell, or his owne, I haue ſett them in a diſtincte letter, and noted the place in the Margent where you ſhall finde them in his booke, as they are in effect.

And to begynne with the preface, his longe diſcourſe there,M. Calf • intent in his preface. Fol 9. a tēdeth chiefly to proue that there ſhoulde be no images in churches. And for proufe of that, he brīgeth certayne places of ſcripture, as the 20. Exodus, where it is ſayde: Thou ſhalt haue none other Gods before me. Thou ſhalt make vnto thy ſelfe no grauen image, nor any ſimilitude that is in heauen aboue, or in the earthe beneath, or in the waters vnder the earth. Thou ſhalt not adore them, nor woorſhippe them, And the 19. of Leuiticus, where it is ſaide. Nolite conuerti ad idola, turne not to Idolls, nor make vnto yower ſelfes, Gods
of metall, VVhat is forbidden by this cō maundement. and ſuche like. VVhiche preceptes of God do onely inhibite the idolls of the gentils to be vſed amonge the Iewes who were ſo prone vnto the idolatrie, of the Gentills that they woorſhipped caul • es, ſtocks, ſtones, catts, apes, brute beaſtes, and the ſunne, moone, and ſtarrs, for God. VVherfore God being a iealous God, a god that would haue the glorie of his name geuen to no creature on earthe, did forbid them, to make any grauen idol, or likeneſſe of any thinge, becauſe they ſhould not adore it,Exod. 32. and worſhip it for God, as the children of Iſrael did, when they ſayd of the golden Caulfe, Hi ſunt dij tui Iſraell, Theſe are thy Gods o Iſraell. Yf it had bene his holy will, to haue forbidden abſolutely all kinde of images,Exod 25. the images of Angells made and ſet in the mercy ſeate by the apoyntmēt of God. 3 Reg 7. Images of oxen and Lions in Salomons temple. he would neuer haue willed Moyſes to make the twoe Cherubins vpon the mercy ſeate, in the Tabernacle. For he ſhould haue geuen a precept contrary to his firſte commaūdement. Neither would Salomon being in hye fauour with God at that time, haue made, and engraued the images of oxen, lyons, and Cherubins in the tēple which he made, to the honour and glorie of God. For in ſo doing he ſhould haue greuouſlye tranſgreſſed that lawe. For the Cherubins that Moyſes made, were ſcuptile, a grauen image, the images of a certayne order of Angells: the oxen and Lyons had Similitudinem, the likeneſſe of a thing in earth. But let vs not erre. There is no alteration, no chaunge, nor contradictiō in God: he is allwayes one. VVherfore when he did forbid the Iſraelites, to make any grauen image, he did forbidde them to make it, becauſe they ſhould not take them to be Gods, nor adore them and woorſhippe them for Gods. VVhen he willed Moyſes to make the tabernacle, he willed thoſe Cherubīs to be made,Paralip. 22 for a bewtie and furniture of his houſe, which that precepte did not inhibite: which Salomon vnderſtanding cauſed thoſe oxen,The ievves ſtamped Caeſars image in his coyne. Lyons, and Angells, to be engraued, and portraicted in his temple. And ſeing he making that temple by the prouidence and commaundement of God, willed thoſe images to be made in his temple, it is euident that the forſaide commaundement of God, did not inhibite all kinde of images, to be made, no not in the temple.

Beſides this, the Iewes them ſelues, being very ſkillfull in their lawe, and ſcrupulouſe in obſeruing it, according to the lettre, ſtamped the image of Caeſar in their coynes. And our Sauiour Chriſt ſeing it, did neuer reprehend them for it, which he woulde haue done, had it ben agaynſt the lawe. But when he ſawe the Coyne with the image of Caeſar, he ſaide no more, but Geue vnto Caeſar, Matt. 22. thoſe thinges which are Caeſars and to God thoſe thinges that are Gods. Furdermore all Chriſtian Emperours, princes, and gentle men would neuer haue engraued, nor ſett in their enſignes, and Armes, Egles, Lyons, Lylies, Greyhoundes, Draggons, Faukons, horſes, gotes, bulls, beares, Apes, and ſuch like. For ſculptile, is a grauen thing. And if all grauen thinges had ben by that precepte inhibited, they would neuer ſo generally haue practiſed it, nor with out feare of Gods indignation, hitherto haue cōtynued it. Ouer and aboue al this, Chriſt gaue an image of his countenāce to Veronica, and ſent an other to Abgarus, Damaſce. lib 4 cap. 17 de orthod. ſide. Euſeb. lib. 7. cap. 14. hiſtor. king of the Ediſſens. The Chriſtians euē frō the begynning payncted both his images and the Apoſtles alſo, which were ſculptile & ſimilitudo, a grauē image, and the lykenes of a thinge. VVherfore ſeing Moyſes at the commaundement of God, made the twoe Cherubins in the tabernacle, ſeing Salomon engraued in his tēple, oxen, lyons, and Cherubins, ſeing the Iewes ſtamped the image of Caeſar in their Coynes, and were not reproued of Chriſt for them, ſeing Chriſten Emperours, princes, and gentle men ſett Egles, Lyons, Lilies, dragons, greyhoundes, and ſuch like in their armes, and were neuer controlled for yt, Seing the Chriſtians, euen from the Apoſtles tyme, haue made the images of Chriſt and his Apoſtles, and thoughte to honour Chriſt and his Apoſtles by it, yt muſt nedes followe, that the precepte of God,VVhat images the L vve doth forbid. Non facies tibi ſculptile, Thow ſhalt not make vnto thy ſelfe any grauen image, doth not abſolutely forbid all kinde of images, but only ſuch as were adored and worſhipped, and that not ſimplye neither, but ſuch as were adored ād worſhipped for gods: ſuch the lawe doth inhibite, ſuch doth God forbid. And al ſuch doe we Catholiques deteſt, accurſe, and abhorre: and euer did.

VVe knowe our images to be but the worke of man: we
doe not worſhip, nor adore, nor honour the matter, wherof they are made. That which we adore and worſhip, is the thing repreſented by the image, which is either Chriſt him ſelfe, or ſome of his ſaynctes. And in honouring them as the frendes of God, we honour God, as the prince that honoureth an others prince his Ambaſſadour honoureth the prince in his Ambaſſadour.Heretikes calling the Chriſtians images Idols, or denie Chriſt to be come, or diſcredite the prophets. Sopho. 2. Al idols deſtroyed by Chriſtes coming. And if our newe Maiſters will nedes haue the Chriſtians images to be idolls, than either they muſt deny Chriſt with the Iewes to be come, or contemne the prophetts with the Samaritanes. For if Chriſt hath bē incarnate & redemed the worlde, then hath he according to the predictions of the prophetts deſtroyed all Idolls, and delyuered his church from them. For Sophonias ſaid of Chriſt, He ſhall deſtroye all the godds of the earthe. Zacharie ſayeth, I will deſtroy the names of Idolls out of the earthe, and they ſhalbe remembred no more. By the name of Idolls he vnderſtādethe here honour and worſhip done to Idolls. Nowe yf Chriſt according to this prophecy, by his cumning deſtroyed all Idolls, and worſhipps done vnto them, then will it followe, that the images of the Chriſtians, are not Idolls, nor the honour and reuerence done vnto them, an honour and reuerence done vnto Idolls. Or yf it be, that either Chriſt by his cumming, did not deſtroye the idolls of the Gentils, or that the prophetts were not true, in their ꝓphecies. And one of theſe twoe they muſt graunte, ſpite of their beardes, vnleſſe they wilbe worſe thā Iulian the apoſtata. For he being otherwiſe an enemy of Chriſte, and of all Chriſtians ſeing the deameanour of the faithfull beleauers,Lib. 6 cōt. Iulia. was forced to confeſſe that ceſſabant idola adorare, & colere as Cyrillus ſaieth: They ceaſed to adore and worſhip idols. But becauſe he deſpited their religiō, and knewe not the ſecret myſteries of it, he layde to their chardge, (as theſe men do to ours) that they adored the wood of the Croſſe. But howe fondly it was done, Cyrill ſheweth at lardge, as the learned knowe, and he that is deſirous to ſee and able to reade and vnderſtand, may turne the booke, and finde. For the ſimple, it may ſuffice them to knowe, howe that Chriſt, by his cumming deſtroyed al wicked idolls, and groſſe idolatrie of the Gentills, and taught vs a
true waye to worſhip God in ſpirite and truth, and that, the catholique church, hath euermore obſerued that manner of worſhipping of God, and euer taught that images, be deuoyd of all ſenſe of them ſelues, and therfore worthy of no honour in reſpecte of them ſelues, but in conſideration that they repreſent vnto vs Chriſte, and his ſainctes.

Out of the newe Teſtament he quoteth theſe places:Fol 9. a Acto. 7.48. But the higheſt dwelleth not in temples made of handes, heauen is my ſeate, and the earth is my foote ſtoole, Acto. 15 28. It hath ſemed good to the holy Ghoſt and vs, to put no burdeyne vpon you beſides theſe neceſſaries, that ye abſteyne from thinges offred vp to falſe images, and bloud and ſtrangled meate, and fornication. Rom. 1 And they changed the glorie of the vncorruptible God, into the likeneſſe of an image of a corruptible man, and of birdes, and foure footed, and creeping beaſtes.

p.hi: I wrote vnto you in an epiſtle that ye ſhould not company with fornicatours of this worlde, nor with the couetouſe,

nor with the extorcioners, nor with them that ſerue idolls. For thē muſt ye nedes haue gone out of this worlde, but nowe I write vnto you that you company not together. Yf he that is called a brother, be a fornicatour, or couetous,
p.note: Idolis ſeruiens. 1 Cor. 10 1 Cor. 14 Idolorum cultura 2 Cor. 6 14. Cōſenſus tēplo Dei cū idolis Galat. 5.20. 1. Ioan 21. Simula chris. Acto. 7.48.
p.hi: or a worſhipper of idolls or a rayler, or a drunckarde, or an extorcioner, with hym that is ſuch a one, ſee that ye doe not eate. Flee from the woorſhpping of idolls.

div.p: Drawe not the yoke with infidells, and a litle after that, what agreement hath a temple of God with idols? Be not druncke with wyne in which is ryott, but be filled with the holy Ghoſt, ſpeaking vnto yower ſelues in hymnes and Pſalmes and ſpirituall ſonges, ſinginge and making melodie to God in yower hartes, geuing thanckes allwayes for all, to God the father in the name of our lorde Ieſus Chriſte. Litle children keepe yower ſelues from falſe and fayned images.

And all theſe places make not one iote againſt images. For
albeit God dwelleth not ſo in temples made with handes,Acto. 15.28. but that his power alſo is euery where without ſcripture, yet hath he bene worſhipped, adored and honored in tēples made with handes. And as in the old Teſtament he commaunded the tabernacle to be made, and images of Cherubins in it, and Salomons temple, where both the Cherubins, and images of oxen liōs and ſuch like were paynted: So hath he in the tyme of grace, by ſecret inſpirations, and viſions, commaunded churches to be builded, that the faithfull might reſort vnto them, to honour prayſe, and ſerue hym. And in thoſe he hath willed the ſigne of our redemption, and croſſe of Chriſte and images of ſainctes to be erected and ſet vp. And yf yow aſke me where this will, and commaundement of God is to be ſeene, I anſwere, it is to be ſene in the decrees of the catholique church which is one body with Chriſte, directed and taughte by the holy Ghoſte. It is to be ſene in the holy fathers, by whome God ſpeaketh vnto vs,In Pſal. 46 as S. Auguſtine declareth, ſaying: God hath ſpokē many wayes, he hath ſpoken by Angells, by prophetis, by his owne mouthe, by his Apoſtles, by his faithfull ſeruantes, he ſpeaketh: by ſo meane a man as I am he ſpeaketh, when I ſpeake any thing that is true. Ipſe ſonat vbique tangendo, modificando, inſpirando, he ſowndeth euery where, by touching, gouerning, and inſpiring the hearte.

Furthermore albeit God hath forbidden vs to eate of thinges offred to idolls, yet hath he not forbidden vs to eate that which is offred vpon the aulter.1. Cor. 9. But prouided that he that ſerueth the aulter, ſhall take parte of the aulter. Or yf he had not, what reaſon hath this our proteſtants argument? VVe muſt not eate thinges offred to idolls, ergo we muſt haue no images? Conſider it by a lyke. VVe muſt abſtaine from fornication, ergo we muſt not haue the ſounday kept holyday. As for the antecedent, it is a commaundemēt of God as well as the abſtaining from thinges offred to idolls, and the conſequent followeth as well as the firſt. Concerning the thing it ſelfe, as the church, notwithſtanding God gaue a ſpeciall precept to kepe holy the ſabaoth day, aduētred to turne it into the ſunday, becauſe they woulde haue nothing common with the Iewes: So the ſame church, ſeing no
precepte of God forbidding the image of Chriſte and his Sainctes, to be had amongeſt Chriſten men, hath not only permitted, but alſo cōmaunded the ſaid images, to be had in churches, and oratories. And ſeing it is ſo, we are as much bounde to obey the church in one, as in the other. To procede, what argument will he make, againſt images, of the wordes of S. Paule, either to the Romaines, Corinthians, or Galathians? Yf he ſay:Rom, 1. 1. Cor. 5. Galat. 6. M. Calfs argumēts. Some chaunged the glorie of the vncorruptible God into the likenes of an image, of a corruptible man, ergo all men did: we muſt not company with idolatours, ergo we muſt haue no images: we muſt flee from the woorſhipping of Idolls: ergo we muſt worſhip no images, The temple of God hath no agrement with idolls, ergo the church hath no agrement with images: we muſt not be drunck with wyne, in which there is ryot, ergo we muſt not haue any images of ſainctes, Keepe your ſelfes, from counterfettes: ergo haue no images, VVe will ſend hym to ſchole to learne Logicke agayne: For this is ſtarke naughte, as euery yoūge puine that hath read his firſt principles may ſee.

But peraduenture M. Calf. truſting to the Engliſh doctours tranſlation, who where he founde the worde Idolum in Latin,1. Cor. 5. idolis ſeruiens. Falſe trā ſlation. tranſlated it image, in Engliſhe, as where the Latin and Greke both ſaye: I wrote vnto you that you ſhould not company with him that is a worſhipper of idolls, he ſaide: I wrote vnto you, that you ſhould not cōpany with hym that is a woorſhipper of images, And where the Apoſtle ſaide: Fugite ab idolorum cultura, Flee from the worſhipping of idolls, and agayne: Quis conſenſus templo Dei cum idolis? VVhat agrement hath the church of God with idolls, he ſaid, howe agreeth the temple of God with images, M. Calf. I ſay, thought he might be bold to bringe the ſaid places againſt images: but that warrant is inſufficient, and auctoritie vnworthie ſo famous a reader: and argueth that he paſſeth not howe ſhamefully he corrupteth the ſcripture to deceaue the ſimple people. VVherfore to make him vnderſtande his folly,The difference betvvene an Idol and an image. I will declare for his furder inſtruction, what difference there is betwene an idoll, and an image. The word idol is deryued of the
Greke nowne 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ſpecies, Cice. libr. 15. epiſt. Fa. Caſsia. becauſe it ſheweth and pretendeth a bare ſhape and voyde figure of a thinge, wheras in dede there is no ſuch thinge at all. VVherupon that which the Greekes called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 idol, the Latins called, Spectrum, and it is taken for thoſe pillers, counterfeicts and images, which were erected to repreſent that which is falſely beleaued to be a God.Lib. 7. queſt. ſuꝑ Iudic. ca. 41. Idolum. 1. Cor. 8. Sonnius Demonſt. lib. 2. ca. 5. VVherfore S. Auguſt calleth, idolum falſi Dei ſimulachrum, an idol the forged image of a falſe and fayned God. In which there is no power, no vertue, nor any thing but mere vanitie, as apeareth by S. Paule, where he ſayeth: Idolum nihil eſt, the idoll is nothing. That is to ſay: Nihil habet in ſe eius quod creditur numinis et veritatis. It hath nothing in it of the power and truth which it is beleaued to be. And in this ſenſe, it is taken in the ſcriptures, that M. Calf. alleadgeth, and in all the fathers which write againſt the groſſe ſuperſtition, and wicked impietie of the Gentills for worſhipping of idolls.

The Chriſtians images cā not be called idols.As for our images they can neither be called Simulachra, feyned counterfeites, nor idolls. For firſt they are not erected to repreſent vnto vs any thing, as God, nor beleaued to haue any vertue or power in them as God. Thirdly they repreſent, no falſe nor lying thing, but that which they repreſent vnto vs is true. As the image of Chriſte vpon the croſſe in the forme of man, repreſenteth vnto vs, that he was a mortall man, and put to death for our redemption. The image of our ladie repreſenteth vnto vs the mother of Chriſt, in whome he was incarnate, and made man. And ſo likewiſe of other ſainctes, wherupon an image either paincted or engraued in wood, Vide Quī tinū Heduū in Synod. Gang impreſſam Pariſ. 1560. Imago. Actio. 4. 2. Nicae. ſtone, or metall, is a true repreſentation of a thinge: or a figure, likeneſſe, and ſhape of him that is portraicted either in the picture, or in the engraued worke. It is as Germanus an holy patriarke of Conſtantinople declareth, a deſcription of the ſtoutenes of holy men, who reſiſted ſynne vnto deathe. It is a repreſentation of holy vertue, and diſpenſation of grace, geuen vnto them. It is an admonition and inſtruction to glorifie God, whome they ſerued in this life. And this hath nothing that reſembleth the nature of the Iewes idols, or gentills counterfeites, as is declared before.

VVe Chriſten men call not ower images Gods, we geue thē no diuine honour, we thinck no power, nor heauenly thing to
conſiſt in them. VVe haue no hope, nor affiance of helpe and ſuccour from them, as the Iewes had of their golden Calfe, and gentills of the Counterfeictes of Iuppiter, Mars, Apollo, Venus, and ſuch like. Our truſt is in God, and hope in the mightines of his power, who made both heauen and earth.Pſal. 95. Hī we acknowledg to be our lord ād God, and none but him. Oēs dii gentiū, daemonia, Al the Gods of the gētils are diuels. VVherfore to al that thīke other wiſe of the catholikes ād take their images to be Idolls, we will cry Anathema, with the fathers of Nice.Act. 6. Nicae. 2. And to al that thīcke we worſhip thē as God, or geue honour vnto thē, due only to god, we wil ſay with the good father Epiphanius, O inſanientē linguā. O mad and raging tōgue, edged like a ſharpe ſworde full of poyſon. It is but a fable of the gētils, ād inuentiō of the diuel, and worke of Sathā. No Chriſten man geueth Latriam, Acto. 6. Nicae. 2. diuine honour and ſeruice to any creature on earth. Latria noſtra eſt in ſpiritu & veritate. Our honour and ſeruice dewe vnto God, is in ſpirite, and truth.What adoratiō and vvorſhip is geuen to images Geneſ. 23. Geneſ. 33. Geneſ. 42.43. Exod. 18 2. Reg ca. vlti. The adoration, worſhip and honour, that we geue vnto images is but aulia, that is a ſeruice, which one creature oweth vnto an other, and is expreſſed by doing reuerence and honour vnto a man, or ſome other earthly thinge, either by putting of the cappe, bowinge the knee, humbling the bodie, kiſsing the hād, or ſuch like. In this ſort Abrahā adored the people of Heth, Iacob adored his brother Eſawe, Ioſephs brothers adored hī, lying flat on the groūde. Moyſes adored Iethro his father ī lawe. Areuma Iebu ſeus adored Dauid with his face flatt vpō the grounde, Iacob adored the toppe of Ioſephs rod. And after like ſorte doe we Chriſten men, reuerence, honour, and woorſhip one other.

VVhen we meete together we put of the cap, we bowe the knee, we humble the bodie, we offer to kiſſe the hand. In like manner when we receaue the kinges letters, we put of our capps. VVhen we come into the chamber of preſence, and ſee the cloth of eſtate, we ſhewe a kinde of reuerence and honour vnto it, not reſpecting the paꝑ and waxe, nor ſilken clothe, or golden chaire, but the prince that wrote it, and kinge that ſate vnder that cloth of eſtate. Right ſo when we ſee the image of Chriſte, or any Sayncte, we put of our cappes,Haeb. 11. we make courteſy,
we bowe,Why vve bovve to the croſſe and image of Chriſt we cappe, we kneele, and ſhewe ſuch external reuerence, and honour, not becauſe it is made of ſiluer and gold, or curiouſlye wroughte, or ſette with pearle, or fynely paynted, but becauſe it repreſenteth vnto me Chriſt and his paſsion, his ſainctes and theyr patience, conſtancy and martirdome. And yf it be idolatrie for me or any Chriſtiā man, to do this, thē it is idolatrie to reuerence my princes image, to vaile my bonnet when I receaue her lettre, to ſhewe reuerence when I come in ſighte of her clothe of eſtate. For both haue one reſpecte. The one to the firſt Sampler repreſented by the image, the other to the prince that occupieth that ſeate, and gaue out that ſeale. And yf heretikes do not vnderſtand this to be the doctrine of the Catholike churche, they ſhewe them ſelues very ignoraunte and vnſkilfull in the Councells. For the fathers haue approued it. And of many to recite a fewe,

Images made in remembrance of Saincts. Stephanus B. Boſtro writeth thus. God hath caſt away and condemned the idolatrie of the Gentills, becauſe they were counterfeictes of of diuells, we make images in remembraunce of Saynctes. Of whom yow ſaye? Forſoth of Abraham, Moyſes, Elias, Eſay, Zacharie, and other prophets, Apoſtles, and holy Martirs, who were perſequuted for chriſtes ſake, that euery man that beholdeth them in the image may remembre them, and glorifie God, who honoured them. For honour and worſhip is ſitting for them, for their righteouſnes, that euery one, who ſeeth them, may be drawne to an imitatiō, of their good workes. But what honour of adoratiō is this? Images paincted and vvorſhipped. Lib. 5. Apolo pro Chriſtia. cont Iudeos habet. act. 4 Nicae. 2. Ezech. 40 & 41. 3. Reg. 6. & 7. verely no other thē ſuche as we vſe, amōgeſt our ſelues, ſaluting one an other for honour ād loue. And a litle after, reaſonnīg the matter he cōcludeth ād ſayeth. By this it is very manifeſt, that the images of ſaītes who are the ſeruantes of God, are payncted, worſhipped and adored.

Leontins biſshop of Neapolis in Cypres, prouing out of the old Teſtament, that God commaunded images to be made, as the Cherubins, which were images of Angells, Lyons oxen, palme trees, men, and ſuch like, ſayeth vnto the Iewe: Yf thou doſt reproue me for images, reproue God him ſelfe, who commaunded theſe to be made, in remembrance of thoſe thinges which we haue. And when the Iewe replied and ſaid. The ſimilitudes or images were not adored as God, The Chriſtian awnſwered. Yow ſay well, for with vs the images, figures,
and pictures of Saynctes are not worſhipped as Gods. For if they worſhipped Gods in the wood of the images, they would not burne the image, when the forme, and printe of it were gone. For my parte (ſaietn he) as twoe pieces of wood hauing the figure of the croſſe are ioyned together, I adore the figure for chriſtes ſake: The figure of the croſſe vvorſhipped for Chriſtes ſake, and not the vvood nor metal when thoſe pieces are ſeparated, I caſt them away and burne them. And as he that receaueth a commiſsion or placket frō the Emperour, by kiſsing the ſeale worſhippeth not the waxe, letters, or lead, but geueth that honour and reuerence to the Emperour: So we that are children of chriſten men, adoring the figure of the croſſe, do not not adore the nature of the wood, but we looking vpon the ſeale, ringe, figure, and Chriſt him ſelfe, ſalute and adore him by this figure, who was crucified vpon it. Thus much Leontins, and much more in the ſame ſenſe worthy of all men to be noted and read.Libr. 7. epiſt. 53. S. Gregorie wrting to Secundinus who deſired to haue the images of Chriſt, S. Peter, and S. Paule, ſent him, ſayeth: I knowe, yow deſire not the image of our Sauiour for that intent, that you will woorſhip it as a God, but that by remembraunce of it, yow may be feruent in the loue of God. And we do not fall downe before it, as before God, but we adore him, whome by the image we remē bre either borne, either to haue ſuffred, or ſitting in his throne. Lib. 4 ca. 12. de orthod fide. Damaſcene ſayeth, we adore the figure of the pretiouſe and lyuely croſſe, albeit it be made of an other matter, not worſhipping the matter (for God forbid that). But the figure, as the ſigne of Chriſt. To be ſhorte, to declare the doctrine of the churche in this poynte, Gratian, (whome yow ſo much ſpite and malice) reciteth this Canon out of the ſyxt Synode. The Chriſtians call not the reuerend images Gods,
De cōſec. diſt. 3. cap. venerabiles.
The ſixth Synode. The 7 general coū cel.
Actio. 7. Images cōmaunded to be ſet in churches.
nor ſerue them as God, nor put hope of ſaluation in them, nor looke for the iudgement that is to come of them, but they worſhip and adore them, for the memory and reuerence of the originals and firſt ſamplers, but they ſerue them not with diuine honour, nor any other creature. The ſeauenth geneall councell ſayeth. VVe conclude that images be had and ſet vp in churches &c. that by this beholding and ſeing of images, all that looke vpon them may come to the memory, remembraunce, and deſire of the firſt ſamplers, and geue vnto them a gentle ſalutation and courtiouſe kinde of adoration, not adoration dewe vnto God, according to our faithe, but ſuch as we geue to the figure of the reuerend and lyuely croſſe, and Ghoſpells of
Christ &c. for the honour of the image redoundeth to the firſt ſampler, and he that adoreth an image, adoreth the thing deſcribed in the image.

VVherfore ſeing it is ſo? what honeſtie is in this man, that bringeth the places of ſcriptures and fathers, that ſpeake againſt the idolls which the ſeduced Iewes and Gentills worſhipped and adored as Gods, and toke for Gods, againſt the images of the Chriſtians which we profeſſe to be no Gods, nor of any diuine ād heauēly power? Yea what Chriſtian charitie is in his hearte that ceaſeth not to vpbraie vs with groſſe idolatrie that are redemed with the death of Chriſt, and brought out of thraldome of the diuell, and ſuch abhomination, as the gentills vſe, by his paſsion, and haue learned to adore him in ſpirite and truth, and defye all idolls, and accurſed idolatours? The diuel hī ſelfe could ſay no more. But let it be their Euangelicall charitie, what reaſon is there in this ſaying?

Fol. 15. b Calf. An image can not be made of Chriſt except it be a lying image: for Chriſt is god and man. And ſince of the Godhead which is the moſt excellent part, no image can be made, it is falſely called the image of Chriſt: and they that do any honour vnto it, are mere Idolatours, making Chriſte therby inferiour to his father, cleauīg only to his humanitie, wheras we ſhould ſo honour the ſonne as they honour the father? Ioan. 5. Mart. VVould any be ſides a ſcourer of old errours, and reuyuer of canckred hereſies haue made the like? This was one of the greateſt reaſons, that the image breakers made in their conuenticle and conſpiracy of Conſtantinople. And ſeing M. Calf. boroweth it of them, I might condemne him as an heretike with them. But that the worlde may ſee, what fooliſh fanſies they haue that impugne images,Actio 6 Nicae. 2. The heretickes obiections I will lay forthe the anſwers that Epiphanius made for whole councell of Nice to like obiections, and then frame one to this. The heretikes obiected this in effecte as M. Calf. doth, and ſaid: Chriſte is God and mā: Therfore yf you make an image of Chriſte, it muſt be an image of God and man. And yf that be true, then muſt either his deitie be circumſcribed, or his vnitie be confounded. Epiphanius anſwered.

This worde Chriſte doth ſignifie the deitie and humanitie (that is) both the perfecte natures of Chriſt. Epiphaniꝰ anſvver. According to that nature in which he was ſeene, Chriſten men haue learned to paincte his image, and not according to that nature in which he was inuiſible: for that can not be deſcribed. For we haue heard out of the Goſpell, that no man euer ſawe God. Ioan 1. 1. Ioan. 4. Therfore when Chriſt is paincted in his humaine nature, as the truth of the thing ſheweth, Chriſten men profeſſe and acknowledge that they ſhape the image that they ſee, to the firſt ſampler according to the name, and not according to eſſence, or ſubſtance, The image of Chriſt paincted as he vvas man. that is (to make it playner) they profeſſe to payncte Chriſt, as man only, and not as God and man. Theſe lighte loſells teache that there is no difference betwene the image, and the firſt ſampler, that is betwene the bare image, and the thing repreſented by the image, et in diuerſis ſubstātijs idētitatē ſubstātiae indicāt and in diuerſe ſubſtances, ſhewe an idenditie of ſubſtance. Agayne he ſayeth: No man is ſo madde that ſaying the humaine nature may be circumſcribed goethe about by that, to circumſcribe the nature which can by no meanes be circumſcribed. Chriſt as he was man, was in Iury, and Galile. As he was God, he is in euery place, and contynueth, not able by any meanes to be circumſcribed. Yf when he lay wrapte in ſwadeling clothes in the manger, his diuinitie was enwrapped by the nature of his humanitie, then ſhall his diuinitie, that is vncircumſcriptible, be circumſcribed in a coloured image, but yf his diuinitie was not enwrapped there, in the clothes, nor can his diuinitie be circumſcribed here in the image. I would they would acknowledg and call to rememaraunce that ſaying of holy S. Dionyſe, in his Hierarcihe. VVhere he ſaieth:S. Dyoniſe. Non eſt exacta ſimilitudo cauſatis & cauſis, habent enim cauſata cauſarum contingentes imagines. Ipſae vero cauſae ſecundū proprij principij rationē exemptae ſunt & ſupereminēt. There is no exacte or perfect likeneſſe betwene thinges that are cauſed, and the cauſes them ſelues. For the thinges cauſed haue the accident images or likeneſſe of the cauſes. The cauſes them ſelues, are exempte and doe ouerpaſſe all, according to the nature of their owne firſt beginning. And by this we may ſee, that Chriſt being God and man, may be payncted, as man, albeit he cā not be payncted as God, becauſe euery image is made to the imitation of the name, and not according to the nature and ſubſtance of the repreſented.

Another obiection of theirs with which M. Calfhill alſo chardgeth the catholiques was this: To make an image af Chriſte in his humaine nature, as he walked here in earthe etc. is wicked and ſauoring of the hereſie of Neſtorius.
Anſvver To this Epiphanius anſwered: The Chriſtians knowing Chriſt to be God, paynte him as he was made man, and beſides reiecte and caſt from them all idle fanſies. And receauing playnly, and ſimply, all thinges that are delyuered of the church, and beholding pictures or images, they conceaue nothing in their minde, but that which is ſignified by them. For when they behold in the picture that the virgin hath brought forthe a ſonne, The meditations of true Chriſtiās vvhē they ſee the image of Chriſt. and the angell and ſheapeardes ſtanding by, they thincke with them ſelues, that God is made man, and borne for our ſaluation. And that they acknowledg ſaying: He that is without fleſhe, is nowe incarnate and borne in fleſhe, he that is vnable to be touched, is nowe touched and felt. And ſo they acknowledge and confeſſe him to be one, perfecte in his humanitie and deitie. As for Neſtorius, Neſtorius hereſie. he made two ſonnes, vnum verbum patris, alterum Filium virginis. One the worde of the father, an other the ſonne of the virgin. But true Chriſtians confeſſe Chriſt their lorde, They do vvel that pay act the image of Chriſt. and God, to be but one ſonne. And when they paynte his image as he was incarnate and made mā, they are knownē to doe very well and godly. For God the ſonne bing made man, was conuerſant with vs in fleeſhe. The deitie is not cōſidered payncted: for no man euer ſawe God. For he can not be paincted, ſene, or compriſed, but only his humanitie. For we knowe Chriſte to be of twoe natures, and in twoe natures, that is of humaine and diuine, ioyntly without diuiſion. One of them is vnable to be payncted, the other able to be payncted, is conſidered in one Chriſte.
In vvhat an image muſt be like the firſt ſampler.
The ſoule of a man not of any ſought in his image
And the image is not like the firſt ſampler according to his ſubſtā ce, but only in reſpecte of name and diſpoſition of lyneaments expreſſed by the partes of the bodie. For when a paynter, paynteth the image of a man, no man requireth or ſeeketh the ſoule in the image. And verily the difference of the ſoule of man, and the diuine nature is ſeuered. The diuine nature is vncreated, and without all tyme. The ſoule of man is created, made in tyme, and framed by the diuine nature. Furder: No man that is wyſe, ſeing the image of man, euer thought that the man was ſeuered from his ſoule by the paincter. For the image is not only depriued of the ſoule, but of the ſubſtāce of the bodie, as fleeſhe, muſculles, ſynowes, bones, bloud, fleame, choler, and humours, the mixture wherof can not be ſene in the image. For
yf it could be ſene in the image, we would call it a man, and not an image.

As for the deniyng or cōfounding of bothe natures, by paynting Chriſt as man, he ſayeth thus in effecte. The talke which they haue of denying and cōſounding the diuine and humayne nature, hath no truth. For the image is one thing, and the proportion and originall another. What is to be loked for in an image. Nor any man that wiſe is, will ſeeke the properties of the originall in the image. For true reaſon ſeeketh nothing ells in an image, but a communitie of the name, whoſe image it is. It knoweth not the ſubſtāce of the original. Thus much Epiphanius. Nowe to come to M. Calfhills reaſon. VVe deny his principle, and require him to proue, according to his promiſſe, by ſcripture, councell, and auncient father, that becauſe Chriſt is both God and man, Fol. 1 • . b an image can not be made of him, except it be a lying image. For Chriſt may be payncted in the forme and ſhape of a man, as he walked here in earth, and died on the croſſe, albeit his godhead which is the moſt excellēt part, can not be compriſed in any image. Neither are they lyers, that call any ſuch picture the image of Chriſte, Fol 15. b They are not liere nor idolaters that call the image made to repreſent chriſt, the image of Chriſt. neither they mere idolaters that woorſhip it. For it is not neceſſarie in an image, that there be an exacte ſimilitude in all proportions. Nor it is required, that the image be like the originall and firſt ſampler, according to the ſubſtance, but only in reſpecte of name and diſpoſition of the partes of the bodie. VVherfor yf Chriſte be payncted in the habite of man, either as he waulked here on earth, or as he died on the croſſe, or as be rooſe from the dead and aſcended to heauen, it may welbe ſaid this is the image of Chriſte, although the true forme and proportion of his body be not knowne to vs.

As for his ſentence adiudging them mere idolaters, that honour that image, it is but raſhe, fooliſh, and ignorant, and argueth that he knoweth not, who be idolaters.VVho are idolaters. Lib. 10. ca. 6. de Trin. Therfore for his furder inſtruction, I will tell him. S. Auguſtine ſayeth: Idololatrae dicuntur qui ſimulachris eam ſeruitutem exhibent quae debetur Deo. They are called idolaters, who geue that ſeruice to falſe images which is dewe to God.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . The ſeruice dewe to God (called of the Greciās 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) conſiſteth principallie in thre thinges, to wit, in acknowledging
him to be lorde of all lordes, maker and creatour of all thinges, and geuer of all goodneſſe to man. Next in louing him with all our heartes with all our ſoules, and with al our power. Then in offerīg vnto him ſacrifice of prayer, thāckes geuing, and the pretious bodie, and bloud of his ſonne, Ieſus Chriſt. This honour and ſeruice was neuer geuen by Chriſten man to images. The honour and worſhip which the churche alloweth to images, is no other, but a reuerent putting of the cap, bowing, kneeling, kiſsing, or ſuch like, which, ſeing it hath bene done, and may be done to creatures, we are no more idolaters, for vſing the like to any image, than you are for kneeling to the prince, for putting of yower cap to the cloth of eſtate, for kiſsing the Quenes ſeale, or bowing to yower frend when you meete him.

Fol 15. b Fol. 16. a A ſclaūderaus cauil Chriſt not made inferiour to his father by any Paynting of imagesVVhere he ſayeth: that we by making an image of Chriſte, make him inferiour to his father, and cleaue only to his humanitie, it is but a mere ſclanderouſe cauill. For the making of an image, is the worke of mās hand, and by ſuch worke Chriſt can not be made inferiour to his father. VVhen Chriſt walked here on earth, the diſciples honoured him, and wayted vpō him, and ſerued him as man, his mother attended vpon him, the Maries and other holy woemen followed him as man. Mathaeus and Zachaeus receaued him into their houſes as mā: and becauſe they did ſerue him, honour him, and followe him as man, did they therfore deny him to be God? and make him inferiour to the father, or cleaue only to his humanitie? No ſir: In like manner when we payncte him as man, engraue his image as man, or portraicte him vpon the croſſe crucified as man, doe we deny him to be God, or make him inferiour, to the father or cleaue only to his humanitie? VVhat extreame folly is in this folliſhe fantaſie?A queſtiō to M. Calf. Let me aſke M. Calf. this queſtion. VVhen you made and penned yower laſt ſermō, did you write the name of Chriſte in it or no? Yf you did, you did it in paper and yncke, and becauſe paper and yncke can not conteyne the power of God,Vvhether he that vvriteth the name of Ieſus in ynck paper maketh hym inferiour to his father. nor diuinitie of Chriſte, did you deny Chriſt to be God, or make him inferiour to his father, and cleaue only to his humanitie? Anſwer M. Calf. And yf you by writing his name in yncke and paper,
do not deny him to be God, nor make him inferiour to his father, no cleaue only to his humanitie, no more doe we by making his image in colours, or in any kīde of metal. But as you by writīg his name in yncke, ād paper, doe by reading or pronoū cing of it trāſmitte him by the eare into the minde, and there cō ceaue him to be bothe God ad mā: Euē ſo we by payncting him as man, doe by the eie tranſmitte him into the hearte, and there adore and worſhip hym as God, and mā, of equal ſubſtāce with the father, and neuer ſeparate his diuine and humaine nature.

But put caſe in paynting Chriſt as man, we did make hym inferiour to the father? Are we therefor idolaters M. Calf? Did not Chriſt ſay, Pater maior me eſt? My father is greter than I am? Doth not the Catholique church ſing in the crede made by Athanaſius, Ioan. 14. Minor patre ſecundum humanitatem? In Symbolo Athanaſij. Chriſt is leſſer than the father according to his humanitie? And if Chriſt be inferiour to his father as he was man, is it not lawfull for vs to thincke ſo of him? And if it be lawfull to thincke ſo of him, is it not laufull to paynte him ſo, and ſet hym foorth in a picture as man and yet committe no idolatrie? Anſwer directly ſir. Vnleſſe you quitte your ſelf the better, either yow muſt recant with greate ſhame, or denie the goſpel of Chriſt, and doctrine of the church with impudent arrogancie. For they manifeſtly teache that Chriſt according to his humanitie is inferiour to his father. And that being true, it is no idolatrie nor to thincke hym nor make hym in that ſenſe inferiour to his father.

Thus for that obiection, wherin yf I haue bene ſomewhat longe, pardon me (gentle reader). It is all to make the matter playne to thy capacitie. Yf I had to doe with M. Calf. alone in the ſchooles, I would haue denied his argument, and required his miniſterſhippe to haue made theſe conſequēts good. Chriſt is God, and man, ergo there can be no image made of hym as man. There can be no image of the godhead, ergo there can be true image of Chriſt, as man, ergo they that honour it, are mere idolatours, making Chriſte therby inferiour to his father, and cleauing only to his humanitie. And when he had iuſtified
them by ſcripture, councell, or auncient father, or any good reaſon, I would haue geuen him the victorie, and ſo will I yet, vnleſſe I cōuince and impugne his reaſon with better. In the meane tyme we will beleaue the ordinaunces of the Catholique church, and boldly affirme that as man conſiſting of body and ſoule,An image of man may be paynted although the ſoule cā not be expreſſed. Fol. 16. a may be payncted, albeit the ſoule which is the chifeſt part can by no arte be expreſſed: Euen ſo our Sauiour Chriſt may be paynted, engraued, and repreſented by an image in the forme and ſhape of man, albeit the diuinitie which is the cheifeſt parte be vncircumſcriptible, indiuiſible, incomprehēſible and vnable by any meanes to be expreſſed. But the reaſon is nothing like, quoth M. Calf. For the ſoule may be ſeuered from the bodye as daily by death we ſee by experience. Nor is it impietie to thincke vpon, or behold the ſhape of a man without a ſoule, but the diuinity of Chriſt can not be ſeparated from his humanitye. Nether is it lawfull to imagine an humanitye without a diuinitie leſt we fall into the hereſy of Neſtorius. To reproue that he varieth farre from all good reaſon, aſke him firſt (good readers) whether our ſauiour Chriſt died not for vs, as man, and whether he gaue not vp the ghoſt, and lay in the gaue as mā?The ſoule of Chriſt ſeuered from his bodie at his death. and if he cōfeſſe it, (as he muſt) yf he be a Chriſten man, then aſke him whether the ſoule of Chriſt was not ſeuered at that tyme from the bodie, and yf he acknowledge it, then aſke him whether it be impietie for vs to thincke that the ſoule of Chriſt was ſeuered from his body? Yf he accompte it none, then muſt he ſeeke for a newe reaſon to proue, that albeit man conſiſting of body and ſoule may paynted, yet Chriſt conſiſting of his humane and diuine nature, can not be paynted as man, for this will not ſerue.

Agayne whereas we talke of paynting, aſke him why he chaungeth the ſtate of queſtion,M Calf fleeth frō the queſtion. and runneth to thinckīge, and where we ſpeake of engrauing, why doth he runne to ymagining, and from the hande why doth he flee to the heart? ower cōtrouerſie is not whether the minde may thincke, or the heart imagine the humanitye of Chriſt, without the diuinitye, but
whether the hand may paynte him, as man, not withſtanding it is not able to paynt his diuinitie. And to this he ſayeth nothing, worthy the hearing, nor can yf he would. For looke howe lawful it is for him to haue his wiues image or coūterfeicte of his frende, in his houſe: So lawfull it is for vs, to haue the image of our ſauiour Chriſt in the ſhape of mā, both in the church and houſe. Nor doe we Chriſten men,Chriſten mē neuer ſeparate the diuinitie of Chriſt frō his humanitie. when we behold that image ſeparate in hearte and thoughte, the diuinitie, from the humanitie, nor thincke of Chriſt as only man, but we beleaue him, we acknowledg him, we confeſſe him to be God and man, equall with his father in ſubſtāce, and euerlaſting in diuyne Maieſtie with him. This with heart we beleaue, and this with mouthe we confeſſe, and worſhip him in ſpirite, and truthe, whome we knowe to be rep̄ſented by that image. Nor was there euer Chriſten man, allowed of the church, that thoughte contrary. VVherfore M. Calf. may ſeeke other, whome he may vpbraide with the hereſie Neſtorius, for paynting the image of Chriſte as man. For that ſclaunder can not light vpon the Catholiques.

His other twoe reaſons that followe are witleſſe.Fol. 16 a M. Calfs reaſons. For who would ſay as he dothe, Chriſte caried his fleſhe vp vnto heauē with him, no more to be knowne according to fleſhe, ergo we fleaſhly creatures do fall from his will, when we make a counterfeict of his mortall fleſhe, whereas his is glorified? Agayne vnknowne it is what was the forme and countenaunce of Chriſt. Therfore as ſone as an image of Chriſt is paīted by and by a lye is made? I aſſure you no ſimple logiſoner,The proꝑties of the original not to be ſought in an image. The properties of the example not to beſought in the image much leſſe a ſolemne reader of Poules owght to vſe ſuche baggage for very ſhame. It is but paultry. For it is not neceſſarie (as I ſaid before out of Epiphanius) that the image be like the originall, and firſt ſampler in ſubſtance: nor any man that wiſe is, will ſeeke the properties of the originall, in the image. For true reaſon ſeekethe nothing in an image, but the communitie of the name, and diſpoſition of lyneamentes expreſſed by the partes of the bodie. Yf it ſhould haue all the ꝓperties and qualities of the originall, then ſhould it be no image, but the thinge it ſelf. As if the
picture which the payncter draweth, ſhould haue fleaſh, bloud muſculls, ſynowes, life and other properties, and qualities that reſt in the originall, we would no longer accompte it an image but a man. VVherefor we tell M. Calf. that in this caſe he is lurdely deceaued, and that vnleſſe he proue by ſcriptures, councels and fathers, that all the properties of Chriſte and his bleſſed fleaſhe, muſt be expreſſed in his image, he ſhalbe a lyer for ſaying, It is a lying image, and not the image of Chriſt.

Nowe touching his authorities brought out of Epiphanius, Irenaeus, and S. Auguſtine, ye ſhall vnderſtand that he belyeth Epiphanius and Irenaeus, and falſifieth S. Auguſtine. For neither did Epiphanius rent a paynted clothe wherin was the picture of Chriſt or ſome ſaincte,Fol. 141. b as ſhall apeare hereafter, in the 5. Article: Neither did Irenaeꝰ reproue the heretikes called Gnoſtici, for that they caried about the image of Chriſte. Irenaeus writeth thus of thoſe accurſed heretikes.Irenaeus lib. 1. c. 14. The Gnoſticks. They cal thēſelues Gnoſtickes, they haue alſo certayne payncted images, and certayne made of other matter, ſayīg that it was the ſhape ād ꝓportiō of Chriſt made of Pilat, at what tyme Ieſꝰ was cōuerſant here with mē, ād thoſe images they crowned with garlādes, ād ſet thē foorthe with the images of the Heathē Philoſophers (that is to ſay with the image of Pythagoras, Plato, Ariſtotle, ād others) ād did other ſolemnities aboute them as the Gentills doe. Thus much Irenaeus of that matter. And where is there in all this, any one woorde which reproueth the Gnoſticks, for that they caried about the image of Chriſt? Irenaeus doth but only declare the facte, and addeth no wordes of reproufe, nor can it be gathered of his wordes or any circumſtances that he reproued them for that. The cauſe why he reproued them,VVhat Irenaeus reproued in thoſe heretiks. was becauſe they placed the image of Chriſt with the image of Pithagoras, Plato, Ariſtotle and other heathen Philoſophers, and vſed ſuch ſolemnities and obſeruatiōs aboute them as the Gentills did. And this was the thinge that Irenaeus reproued, and not the hauing and carying aboute the image of Chriſte.

S. Auguſt. falſified.VVhere he ſayeth, that S. Auguſtine alloweth M. Varro, affirming that relligion is moſt pure without images, and citeth
for his credit in the margent, De ciuitate Dei lib. 4. cap. 3, Ye ſhall vnderſtand that in all that chapiter S. Auguſtine doth no ſo much as mētion M. Varro. That which he meaneth is in the 31. chapiter of the ſaide booke. There he talketh of M. Varro, and commendeth him for a wiſe man, but theſe very wordes, that religion is moſt pure without images, VVordes attributed to S. Auguſtine not ſoūde in hym. are not to be founde in the whole chapiter: he ſayeth: The Romaines contynued more then an hundred and ſeuentie yeares, ſ • ne ſimulachro, without an idoll, without a falſe and fayned images and yf that had contynued, he ſayeth: Caſtius dij obſerua ••• . The Gods had bē better honoured. Agayne he thought, caſtius obſeruari ſine ſimulachris religionē, that religion would haue bene more reuerently and better obſerued without idolls, or fayned images. That is to ſay, he thought that yf they had had no idolls, nor falſe images of Gods, they would haue thought better of God, and not haue beleaued their idolls, their ſtockes, and ſtones to haue ben Gods. But what is this to that which M. Calf. maketh S. Auguſtine father vpon M. Varro, that religion is moſt pure without images? Can the hauing of images make religiō worſe, and the not hauing of them make it better? That were worthy the learning of ſo fyne a fanſier. VViſe mē thincke that religion, which (as S. Auguſtine ſayeth) is cultus diuinitati, Religion. Lib. 10. ca. 1. de ciuit. Dei. vel deitati debitus, a worſhip dewe vnto the diuinitie, or godhead, contynueth alwayes one, and as the logiſioners ſay, non ſuſcipit magis & minus, is no more a worſhip this day, then it was yeſterday, no more purer this day, then it was yeſterday. And whether we haue images, or no images, religion ſhalbe moſt pure alwayes.

All that M. Varro ſayde, and S. Auguſtine reported in the forſaide place is,The effect of M varro his ſaying. that yf the Romaines had had no idolls nor fayned images, men would haue thought better of God, and haue ſerued him better, men would haue kept religion better. Men that knewe not God, nor could lifte vp their eies to heauen, and conceaue that there was a God, would haue quickly learned that there had bene a God, yf they had had no earthly idolls, which they might haue honoured, ād worſhipped as God. But what is this to vs, that knowe God, worſhip God, and are deliuered frō ſuch ignorāce, ſuperſtition,
and idolatrie by our ſauiour Chriſte throughe the great mercy of God? howe dare you crake M. Calfhil that our religion is corrupted with them which we vſe not? The Chriſtians when the Iewes would not geue them the body of S. Polycarpe, thinking they would forſake Chriſt and worſhip him, ſaid:Euſeb. lib. 4. cap. 15. The miſerable wretches knowe not, that we can not forſake Chriſt that ſuffred death for the ſaluation of the world, nor worſhip any other, becauſe we knowe the true God that muſt be worſhipped. So ſay we to theſe proteſtantes that thincke we committe idolatrie, forſake Chriſte, and corrupte his religion with images. And in deede they ſhewe them ſelues very wretches, that haue ſo vyle imaginations of any Chriſten man.

There is none vnleſſe he be madde, but cā tell a differēce betwene a dead and ſenſeleſſe thinge, and that which hath both life and ſoule. Euery childe yea euery beaſt knoweth, that it is not God, whome they ſee, as M. Calf. alleadgeth out of S. Auguſtine:In Pſal. 36 & 113. which wordes although in parte they be true, yet are they not all S. Auguſtines wordes, nor theſe that followe, neither in ſuch ſort as they be alledged. Marke and you ſhall ſe. M. Calf. putteth them downe thus. Euery child, yea euery beaſt knoweth that it is not God that they ſee. Fol. 15. a VVherfore then doth the holy Ghoſt ſo oftē warne vs of that which all men knowe? he anſwereth thus. For when the images, are placed in temples in honorable ſublimitie, and begynne once to be worſhipped, forth with breadeth the moſt vile affection of errour. S. Auguſtine talking there of the Gentills idolls, and declaring, that the God which they worſhipped, was blinde, deafe, dumbe, immoueable, vnſenſible, deade, and worſe than the dead, ſayeth: O my dearly beloued brethren, what is more manifeſt than this? what is more euidēt? what childe being aſked, is not able to anſwere, that it is certayne that the images of the Gentills haue mouthes, and will not ſpeake, eies and will not ſee, and the reſt which the word of God hathe adioyned? VVhy then doth the holy Ghoſt ſo earneſtly prouide to inſinuate and inculcate thoſe thinges, as it were to ignorants? as though they were not moſt open and well knowne to men, but becauſe he ſignifieth by the
ſhape and proportion of the membres, which we haue bene accuſtomed naturally to ſee in other, and ſee in our ſelues. Albeit as they affirme in ſome ſigne made cunningly, and ſet vp in an hye place, when it begynneth to be adored and honoured of the multitude, it breadeth the moſt filthieſt affection of errour, that becauſe he findeth not in the fayned image, a lyuely mouing, he beleueth that there is ſome diuine power in it, yet for all that being deceaued with the ſhape, and moued with the auctoritie of wiſe maſters, and obedient people, he thincketh the image, that is like a lyue bodie, is not without ſome lyuely inhabitour: vpon this, ſuch like affection of men inuiteth wicked diuells to poſſeſſe the Gentills idolls, by whoſe manifeſt deceites reſting there, diuerſe manifeſt errours are ſowed and multiplied.

Therfore in other places alſo the holy ſcripture doth watche diligently againſt theſe idolls, nor let any man ſay, The ſcripture agaīſt idols. when theſe forged images are irrided, I woorſhip not this viſible thinge that we ſee, but the power that lieth ſecret within. But thoſe powers the ſcriptures condemne: Quoniam dij gentium, daemonia, becauſe the Gods of the Gentills are diuells. And a litle after he ſayeth: They ſeme vnto them ſelues to be of a more purer religion, which ſay, I worſhip not the image, nor the diuell, but by the bodely ſhape, I ſee the ſigne of that thing which I muſt worſhip. What the Gētils vnderſtode by their idols. So in good ſoothe they take and vnderſtande their images, that by one they ſay, the earthe is ſignified, wherupon they are wont to call the temple of the earthe, by an other they ſignifie the ſea, as by the image of Neptune, by another the fyre, as by the image of Vulcane, by another the day ſtarre, as by the image of Venus, by another the ſunne, by another the moone, to whoſe images they geue names, as they did to the image of the earth. By another they ſignifie this ſtarre, and that ſtarre, this creature, and that creature, for we are not able to expreſſe all. VVordes not in S. Auguſtine. Thus farre S. Auguſtine touching that which maiſter Calf. alleageth. And in all this, where are thoſe wordes. For when images are placed in temples, which he fathereth vpon S. Auguſtine? They are not there, nor any one woorde againſt the images of the Chriſtians.

All his diſcourſe in that place is againſt the falſe images of Neptune, Vulcane, Iuno, Venus, and the creatures which they did worſhip as gods, as the ſunne, the moone, the ſtarres, the earthe the ſea, and ſuch like. VVhich being ſo, what honeſty is there in
this miniſter to falſifie S. Auguſtine, and turne that to the Chriſtians, which he ſpoke of the Gentils, and to alleage that againſt their images which was ſpokē againſt idolls? S. Auguſtine him ſelfe, beſt interpreter of his owne wordes, geueth vs to vnderſtand, in that place rehearſed, that the preſent Pſalme which he handled, and other places of ſcripture ſpoke againſt thoſe fayned and forged counterfeites of the Gentills, and idolls, which they worſhipped. Yet notwithſtanding he is ſo impudent, that he ſayeth:Fol. 15. a An impudent lye. Thus all the doctours haue thoughte the commaundement to extende to vs, and that ower images are forbidden by it. And of all the doctours, in this place, he hath recited, but thre, and thoſe thre make nothing for him, as in parte you ſee, and ſhall ſee furder hereafter. But to oppoſe him a litle better,The doctours allovve images. tell vs ſir, were not Paulinus, Gregorius, Damaſcenus, Euthymius, Athanaſius, Ambroſius, Iſidorus, Hieronymus, Gregorius Niſſenus, and S. Baſile, doctours of the churche? And haue you not read that Paulinus paynted images in his church, that S. Gregory rebuked him that broke them, that Damaſcene made a booke of them, that Athanaſius accounted them amongeſt thinges appartayning to the church, and the adourning and ſetting foorthe of our faith, that Euthymius told the Emperour, that our ſauiour Chriſt euer ſithens his incarnation haue ben woorſhipped in images? Haue you not read, that S. Ambroſe thoughte it lawfull to worſhip an image, that Hierome had the croſſe in Bethlem, and licked it, and kiſſed it? Haue you not read that Sainct Gregorie liked the image of Abraham ſleying his ſonne Iſaac? that S.
