Baſill counted it Apoſtolicum, a commaundement or tradition of the Apoſtles to ſet vp images in the churches?

Yf yow haue, then can yow not ſay, all the doctours haue thought the commaundement to extend to vs, and that our images are forbidden by it. For all theſe doctours, and the whole Catholique church beſides haue allwayes allowed images, and neuer thought this commaundement to inhibite our images. Yf yow haue not read ſo farre in the ſaid fathers, but haue truſted youer engliſhe doctours, youer Magdeburgenſes, youer
M. Caluine, and ſuch Apoſtatats, begynne nowe to take them in hand. And yf it be too combrouſe or longue to ouerrunne them all, then reade the diſcourſe of the ſeuenth generall Councell kept at Nice: or if that be lotheſome and tediouſe, reade the fourthe and fift dialogue of M. Alane Cope lately ſett foorthe, and this replie of myne. There and here ſhall yow ſee that it was neuer inhibited Chriſtē mē by any commaūdemēt of God, in the whole ſcriptures, to make images and worſhip them, in ſuch ſotte as I declared before.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Fol. 15. a

Nor thinke M. Calfhill, that you haue any aduantage by the Iewes, to whome the lawe was firſt geuen, and who of congruence ſhould haue the true ſenſe and meaninge of it, becauſe they had no images publiquely in their temples. M. Calfs running to the Ievves and Turkes helpeth hym not. It furdereth yower cauſe nothīg. They had the lawe, the ꝓphetts, ād Chriſt him ſelf amōges thē: Yet did not al their ſkill in the lawe, and prophetts, and miracles of Chriſte, ꝑſwade thē that he was the Meſsias that was the expectation of the gentills, and redemer of the worlde. They did not thinck that he was king of the Iewes, and ſauiour of Iſraell. They did not beleaue that a virgin ſhould bring foorthe a ſonne with out breache of her virginitie. They did not vnderſtād the myſteries of our faith, their mindes were ſo addicted to the bare and literall ſenſe of the lawe.
What cō ſequution is this M. Calf.
The ievves and Turkes haue no images ī their tēple, ergo Chriſten men ſhould haue none their churches Lykewiſe the Turkes vntill this day do not beleaue that the Meſsias is come. they beleaue not that Chriſt hath died for the redemption of many: They haue no faith in his paſsion, no truſt in his reſurrection, nor hope of his mercy. They haue no ſacrament, no baptiſme, no ſupper of our lorde, nor goſpell, nor Chriſt. And becauſe they haue none, ſhall we haue none? what a ſleight of Sathan is this? To bring in more abſurdititie, ſee howe madlie this miniſter reaſoneth. The Iewes and turkes haue no images in their temples, ergo Chriſten men ſhould haue none in their churches? Yf he might wynne ſo muche of him, as to thincke, that a ſufficient and good argument, then would he haue other in ſtore, as for example. The Iewes and Turkes do not beleaue that the Meſsias is come, ergo the Chriſtians ſhould
not. The Iewes and Turkes haue no baptiſme, ergo the Chriſtiās ſhould haue none. The Iewes and Turkes haue no Sacraments ergo the Chriſtians ſhould haue none. The Iewes keepe not holy the ſundaye, ergo the Chriſtians ſhould not. The Iewes and Turkes haue no Goſpell nor Chriſte, ergo the Chriſtians ſhould haue nor Goſpell nor Chriſte. By like reaſon as M. Calf. concludeth negatiuely, that we muſt haue no images in our churches, becauſe the Turkes and Iewes had none in their temples, he wil negatyuely conclude al the other, and vpon the graunting of of the firſt infer the reſt, and ſo bring his diſciples a litle and litle to Atheiſme.

VVherfor I much maruell that M. Calf. would vſe that reaſon of the Iewes, and alleadge that of the Turkes. It conuinceth him of inexcuſable follye, and declareth that he, ād his fellowe proteſtantes, in this poynt reſemble the Iewes and Turkes, as nigh as can be. For as the Iewes and Turkes deteſted and abhorred images,Heretikes reſemble the Ievves and Turkes. ſo do they. As the Iewes and turkes counted images to be idolls, ſo do they. As the Iewes and Turkes called the chriſtians idolaters, for hauing and worſhipping of images, ſo doe they. As the Iewes and Turkes thincke it laufull to put away their wyues in caſe of fornicatiō, and marry another. So would M. Calf. and the proteſtātes haue it laufull for them. The Iewes and Turkes marry according to Moyſes lawe in the degrees of affinitie.Melanch. in locis com 52. So M. Calf. and his fellowes thinke it good that Chriſtians ſhould marry, for he findeth faute with the order of the churche prohibiting mariage within the degrees of affinitie. The Iewes and Turkes haue their Canon of ſcripture,Melanch. Ibidem. diuerſe from the Chriſtians, and reiecte diuerſe partes of the old teſtament, ſo haue M. Calf. and his fellowes one diuerſe from the catholique churche, and reiecte the Machabees, Eccleſiaſt. and other partes. The Iewes and Turkes doe no penaunce, nor vſe any confeſsion of their ſynnes, no more doth M. Calf. nor his. The Iewes and Turkes deteſt the croſſe as a ſigne of maledictiō. M. Calf. abhorreth it as a magicall inchauntemēt, as a ſorcerous mace, and as a ſigne of conqueſt againſt the Chriſtians. And vnleſſe God of his goodneſſe, ſtaye the rage of hereſie, they will
agre in the other poyntes. As Dauid George beganne,Trinitaries. and the Trinitaries, Anabaptiſtes, and ſuch as circumcide them ſelues practiſſe apace in Polonia. VVherfore ſeing the commaundemēt of God in Exodus, and other places of ſcriptures make nothing againſt images amongeſt Chriſten men, ſeing the doctours teache that the precept of God doth not inhibite our images, but declare the contrary, ſeing the reaſon that M. Calf. boroweth of the Iewes and Turkes, is but Iewiſh and Turkiſh, and as meate to infringe all the myſteries of our faith and redemption, as to conuince that there ſhould be no images in churches, it is euident that all his babling proueth nothing againſt the vſe of images.

His other poſition that images doe not teache, is a thinge more boldly auouched, than wyſely proued. To euery good Chriſtian,Li. 9 epiſt. 9, ad Sere. Actio. 4 Nicae. 2. Oratio. in laudes Theodo. martir. Ser. de 40. mart. the auctoritie of the church ſhalbe a ſufficient warrant. And ſeing S. Gregory calleth them: Lay mens bookes which ſerue the ignorant in ſteade of writinges, And Germanus taketh them to be a repreſentation of the ſtoutneſſe of ſainctes, and an inſtruction to teache vs to glorifie God. And Gregorius Niſſenus ſayeth: Solet etiam pictura tacens in pariete loqui, maxime
que prodeſſe. A ſtill picture alſo in the walle is wounte to ſpeake, and profitte very much: and S. Baſile termeth them a ſtill poetrie, and affirmeth, the profitte of pictures and writing to be one, and ſayeth: That drawing of thinges lyuely in a table hath ſtirred many to valiaunt courage, I truſt with all indifferēt men. S. Gregorie, Germanus, Gregorius Niſſenus, and S. Baſill ſhal more preuayle than the fanſie of this proteſtant, who as he ranne to the Iewes and Turkes euen nowe to proue that we ſhould haue no images in churches: So for proufe of this,Fol. 11. b Amadys. he fleeth to one Amadys a gold ſmithe of Lōdō, lying in his bed, at the poynt of deathe, when cōmonlye mens ſenſes and wittes fayle them, to proue that images can not teache. And becauſe he tormented with the agonies and panges of death, hauing the croſſe preſented vnto him to put him in remembraunce of his maker, aſked what is the price of an ounce, This wiſe marchaunte ſhutteth vp the matter, as thoughe it could not put other in remembrance of Chriſte, and ſayeth.

Fol. 12. a Such is the fruicte that the vnlearned receaue by images, yea though they be of the beſt ſorte. But that you may better vnderſtand the weakneſſe of his reaſon, conſider his argument: thus in effecte, he ſayeth, or muſt ſay yf he will proue that images doe not teache.M. Calfs argument that images do not teache. Amadys lying at the poynt of death, when mens witts and ſenſes commonly faile them, was not put in remembrance of Chriſte by the croſſe preſented vnto him by his perſon, ergo men that are whole, and in no ſuch extremitie, can not be put in remembrance by it. And yf this be not, in the iudgement of ſome whote proteſtant, a doltiſhe kinde of reaſoning, let him conſider it by the like. Some that are almoſt dead in the lewde luſtes of ſynne, take no commoditie by the worde of God preached by their perſon: Ergo no man doth. The ſcholler who hath neither witte nor capacitie, taketh no profitte by his maiſters leſſons. Ergo none of the reſt can. The mā that is deſperately ſicke of a phrenſie can haue no helpe by phiſicke, Ergo no other may. And yf theſe be vayne, and fonde, ſo thincke of his. For as diuerſe take commoditie by the worde of God when it is preached, albeit euery ſinful man whoſe heart is obdurated, doth not, and diuerſe ſchollers receaue, profitte of their maiſters leſſons, albeit the dullard can not, and many haue helpe by phiſick allthough the prontike foole hath not: So albeit Amadys the gold ſmithe lying at the poynt of death was not put in remembrance of Chriſte, by the croſſe, yet diuerſe other are, and ſtirred to deuotion, and contemplation of the merittes of his paſsion. For yf Gregorius Niſſenus a famous doctour, Lib 22. ca. 73 contra Fauſt. Manich. Actio. 4 Nicae 2. and lerned biſshope ſeing the image of Abrahā and his ſonne Iſaac, tot locis pictū, payncted in ſo many places, as S. Auguſtine ſayeth, wept when he ſawe it, and neuer paſſed by it, without teares, howe much more will the whole diſcourſe of our ſauiour Chriſtes life here incarnate vpon earth being ſeene of vs, moue all that behold it, to teares, and other furder commoditie? Certes, nowe where charitie is cold, and faithe not feruent, although mē ſeeing the croſſe and image of Chriſt crucified, doe not weepe, as Gregorius Niſſenus did, when he ſawe the image of Abraham, offring his ſonne, yet no doubte, euery
well diſpoſed man hath ſome good motion and meditation of the mercy of our ſauiour Chriſte, by the ſight of it.

As for that which he obiecteth, againſt Stephen Gardiner, Fol. 11. b Stephen Gardiner. that he was fowly abuſed by an image, and founde S. George on horſeback in the kinges brode ſeale, where the kinge him ſelfe was ſet on both ſides, it is but a mere cauil. The wiſdome, learning, grauitie, and experience of that reuerend father and honorable counſeller was not to ſeeke, to knowe S. George on horſe backe in batayle, from kinge Henry in peace. But of that hereafter, when I talke of his ſclaunderous lies. In the meane tyme conſider good readers vpon what groundes this man buildeth his newe doctrine, and as you finde them weake, ſo imagine of al that is builded.Fol. 19. b To drawe towardes an end of this preface, where he ſayeth: that yf the Louaniſtes had but a mā gled piece of ſuch a preſident for the Pope, as they haue for euery prince, founde in the auncient recordes of London, remayning in the Guild hall, lorde howe would they triumphe? they would deſiphire, Fol. 20. a and by Rhethorique reſolue euery letter of it, I beſeeke you that haue experience of his fyne witte, examine the woordes, which he citeth out of an epiſtle of
• le •
therius the Pope ſent to
• ucius king of England. The woordes that he buildeth vpō, are theſe.Fol. 19. b A ſentence forte out of the Guild hall in Londō. You haue both teſtaments in youer realme. Take out of them by the grace of God and aduiſe of youer ſubiectes, a lawe, and by that lawe through Gods ſufferance, rule youer realme, but be you Gods vicar in that kingdome. Here becauſe Eleutherius Pope of Rome willed Lucius king of England (that ſent vnto him for lawes to gouerne his people) to take lawes out of the old and newe Teſtament, and apoynted him to be the vicar of God in that realme, M. Calf. thincketh his owne deſperate cauſe, to be greatly aduauntaged againſt the Pope. But I pray yow, aſke his wiſdome, who is of greater authoritie, The man that apoynteth the lawe, or he that receaueth the lawe? The commiſsioner, or he that geueth the commiſsion? The Lieutenant, or the prince
that apoynteth the Lieutenante? The Viceroye, or the kinge that maketh the viceroy? Yf he acknowledge him that apoynteth the lawe to be of greater authoritie, than the man that receaueth the lawe, and the prince that geueth a commiſsion, to be of higher dignitie,M. Calf. condēnēd by his ovvne ſentence brought out of Guild hall in Londō. then the commiſsioner that receaueth the commiſsion, then muſt he nedes condemne him ſelf. For by the auncient recordes, remayning in Guild hall in London, it is euident that Eleutherius pope of Rome, apoynted lawes for Lucius kinge of England, and gaue hym authoritie, and commiſsion to be Vicarium Dei, Gods vicar, in that land. And looke howe hier in dignitie he is, that apoynteth the lawe, than he is that receaueth the lawe, he that geueth the commiſsion, than he that receaueth the commiſsion, ſo higher was Eleutherius then Lucius, and the pope thē the prince. VVhich being ſo, Lorde howe hath M. Calf. deceaued him ſelf, with a piece of a ſentence, brought out of the auncient recordes of Londō, remayning in the Guild hall? howe hath he opened his owne ignorance, and reſolued a great piece of his folly? Is it not great pittie for ſo learned a reader to be ſo groſſely deceaued in ſo plaīe a matter? Lorde what ouerſighte was this of thoſe that had the ouerſighte and viewe of his booke before it came to printe with out priuiledge? Muſt all ſyphre, and none diſiphre, nor by rhetorique reſolue euery lettre o •
• his, and by logike proue, that it would make againſt him? Lorde what a ſcape was that?

Any of thoſe whome it pleaſeth his worſhip to call the famouſe writers of Louayne, Fol. 19. b could haue better aduiſed his clarkſhip in this cauſe, yf he had but once mentioned the matter vnto them: yea the meaneſt of them all, (that as he ſayeth be greate Clearkes, Fol. 19. b bachilers of diuinitye, and ſtudentes of the ſame, as ſoone as they taſt the good lyquor of Louayne, could haue ſignified that the ſentēce borowed out of the Guild hal of Lōdon would make againſt him. And (be it ſpoken with out pride,) the meaneſt of them all could teache him, and al his moore true diuinitye in one daye, than he or his haue taught the people in ſundrie poyntes, theſe ſeuen yeares. And albeit
amongeſt them, we be no more knowē than contemned, yet ſhal our doings not lacke eſtimation with the wiſe, nor intent leeſe his rewarde with the higheſt, when he and his ſhalbe vnknowē, and contemned with the loweſt, yf they amend not by tyme.

VVe knowe it to be an olde practiſe with heretikes,None lerned in the iudgemēt of heretiques but ſuch as ſauour thē. to contemne all that fauour not their hereſie, and thincke all vnlearned that fanſie not their faction. But he that was but yeſterday a Cobler, ſhalbe within fewe monethes, a profounde miniſter, and great Rabbi, nor vnknowne nor contemned, yf Apollo caſt his courtayne aboute him and the ſpirite inſpire him to fauour the procedinges. Yea he ſhalbe ſuche a docterlike man, that yf the beſt of all the papiſtes were matched wih him, Fol. 19. a The beſt of the papiſts not to be matched vvith the ſimpleſt proteſtāt. Lib. 1. cap. 14. Trip. being but the ſimpleſt of their ſide, they ſhould haue great wronge.

For which exceſsiue pride wel may we with Alexander biſshop of Alexandria, hauing to do with arrogant heretikes crie, O wicked arrogācie, O vnmeaſurable madneſſe, O rage of vayne logrie, O wiſdome of Sathan vehemently inuading their wicked ſoules. But redreſſe it we can not. Nor lett them ſwell like hills in pride, nor be witleſſe like Caulfes, nor be full of lyes like lorrels, nor be •• atting like paratts, nor prating like pies, nor clipping like cutte purſes, nor ſcolding like queanes. It is a naturall deſeaſe paſsing with the inheritance. VVherfore yf we will do them good, the only remedy muſt be to pray vnto allmightie God to geue thē the ſpirite of humilitie and grace to knowe thē ſelues. So may it come to paſſe, that they ſhall miſlike ſingularitie, and miſtruſt they owne wiſdome, and ſo by conference with the other, attayne to the knowledge of the truth, which God of his goodneſſe graunte.

Yf any willfull proteſtant, or hotte hereticke myſlyke my writing, for that I dippe my penne ſometymes ing all, and vſe certayne termes, inflamed (as it may ſeme) with choler,In the epiſtle. I deſire them to conſider charitably whoſe woordes theſe are. VVillfull wanderer, young ſcholler, pelting pedler, Synon, Fol. 18. b Ape, ſeruant to the diuel, Ib • . •• b ſtuīmblg lade, 40. b haſty hounde,
Fol. 32. b Tapſter, Tynker, oſtler, lewde poticarie, Cooke ruffian, Fol 90 a puine, ſir boy, Fol. 91 b ſolemne ſyr, 113. a bold, blinde, bayard, 36. a Spyder, Iohn 119 b Taberer, a 48. b foole that walketh in a nett, 10 9. a dolt, dawkin, and 116. a clowter of a patche of truthe vpon a whole cloke of lyes, with ſuch like, which are applied to me in this anſwer to my treatiſe. Againe I deſire them to conſider charitably whoſe wordes theſe are, willfullnes, ignorance, vayne deuiſes, In the epiſtle. dotages, drunken frenſie, fonde, ſenſeleſſe, vnſounde proufes, ſtale ieſtes, idle tales, Fol. 32. b vnſauory ſoppes, profeſſed 127. a impudencye, ſhameleſſe deſeruing, 135. b beaſtlyneſſe and vanitie, 160. b ignorant allegations, impudent vntruthes, applied to my writinges. Furder yf it be not tediouſe for them, I deſire them to conſider charitably whoſe woordes theſe are,78. a. b Iezabell, Athalia, inſolēt, madde, ſauage, wild beaſt, applied to Irene, in the epiſtle. Ruffian to Staphilus, diſguiſed geſt, ſodayne conuert, Apoſtata, to M.D. Harding, dowghtye to M. Dorman, Raſcall, to M. Raſtell, Dogges eloquēce, pieuiſh fanſies, colledge of conſpiracie, willfull, wittleſſe, peruerſe confederates, out Iaw • s, lewde Fol. 52. b lyers, image Fol. 13 b mungers, 94. a Romiſh heretikes, 19 b aduerſaries of truthe, 121. a enemies of God, reuerend 68. b aſſes, Nice 69. a maiſters, popiſh 19. a chaplīs, blinde 94. a beaſtes, ſenſeleſſe hipocrites, ſauſy 36 a mouthes, Apiſhe 95. b imitatours, 105. b Greaſy marchantes, bluddy Ibidē. a coniurers, 18. a Antichriſtiās, and other ſuche applied to the Catholiques. And yf they finde them to be their owne propre miniſters woordes, iſſued from the plenifull ſpōge, and ſcolding ſpring of M. Calfs. ſprite, lett him graūte vs the ſame libertye, which they accounte euangelicall in their propre holy preacher, and geue vs, leaue to vſe his owne figure of Regeſtiō, that is to returne backe vpon him, either his owne termes, or the like, and in imitation of his owne Rhetorique, vſe his owne figures and phraſes of ſpeache, or ſome equiualent with thē worthely applied to his perſon, which he vnworthely would lay vpō me. It is reaſon that they allowe that in another, which they commend in them ſelues.

Yf any cold Catholique thinck this to hotte, lett him remē bre with what heate the auncient fathers haue written againſt old heretikes. And yf he fynde theſe phraſes that I vſe, or the like in their writinges, lett him beare with me, that in a more perilouſe tyme, haue to do with more blaſphemouſe heretikes. As the phiſition by ſharpe medicines thincketh to cure longe feſtred ſoores: So doe we truſt by this kinde of writing to purge the venemouſe infection, which this canker of hereſie hath bredde, and lodged in mens myndes. S. Auguſtine declaring, howe one may reproue an other of his faulte, ſaieth, dilige & dic quod voles. Nullo modo maledictum erit quod ſpecie maledicti ſonuerit, In expoſi. cap 6 ad Galath. ſi memineris ſenſeriſque te in gladio verbi Dei liberatorem hominis eſſe velle, ab obſidione vitiorum. I oue and ſaye what thou wilte. It ſhall be, by no meanes a taunte that ſoundeth after the manner of a taunte, yf thou wilt be a delyuerer of a man from the ſeidge of vice, in the ſworde of Gods worde. And certes ſeing I loue M. Calfhills perſon, and hate his hereſie, as euery Chriſten man ſhould, I haue vſed that liberty which he hī ſelf tooke, hopinge that as I miniſter hī occaſion to ſee his errour, ſo he will gather vnderſtandinge, and miſlike it, wiſdome and deteſte it, grace, and deſire the mercy of God to pardonne it. Qui attendit contemptores vt corrigat, Auguſtin. in Pſal. 50 neſ •• ntes vt doceat, confitentes vt ignoſcat, who marketh the contemptuouſe that he may puniſhe them, the ignorant, that he may teache them the bū ble that confeſſe their faultes that he may pardonne them. But yf God hath ſo geuen him ouer to his ſelf will, that for ſhame of the worlde he wil not chāge his peruerſe turkiſhe faithe, and with the Catholique churche followe the righte faithe, but for eger zeale of contention will followe his blinde guides, he may be well aſſured that fyer ſhall come vpon fyer,Idem in Pſal. 54. ſuper ardorem diſſenſionis ardor conſumptionis, the flame of conſumption vpon the heate of diſſenſion, prepared for all rebellious heretikes with Core, Dathan, and Abiron, by the iuſt and mercifull iudge, whoſe name be bleſſed for euer.

div.head: FAVLTES ESCAPED IN PRINTING.
div.p: VVhatſoeuer is eſcaped beſides, I truſt the gentle reader will by his owne iudgment amend it, and conſider where, and by whome this was printed.

div.head:
Jesus
A REPLIE TO M. CALFHILS BLASPHEMOVS ANSWER MADE AGAINST THE TREATISE OF THE CROSSE. THE FIRST ARTICLE.
div.p:
MAruel not (good readers (that M. Calfhil laboreth buſelye in the beginning of this article to plante this poſition, that the auncient fathers decrees, writings, and traditions are not to be credited. He doth nought ells but that which his progenitours the curſed, and canckered heretickes, haue done in all ages.Baſil. cap. 10. de ſpi. ſancto. The Eunomians reiected the teſtimonies of the father, as thinges of naught: and with great clamours exacted proufes out of ſcripture. The Arrians would not admitte the fathers, nor the woorde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that expreſſed the conſubſtantialitie of Chriſt with god his father,Lib. 2. ca. 7 & lib. 4. c. 5. hiſtoriae Tripart. Lib. 1. cōt. Maximū. Actioner. Concilj Chalced. Becauſe it was not foūde in ſcripture. Maximus ſaid to ſaint Auguſtine, The woordes that are not in ſcripture, are in no caſe receaued of vs. The Eutychians cried, In qua ſcriptura iacēt duae naturae? In what ſcripture lie the twoe natures. And ſo likewiſe other heretickes, as M. Calfhil doth nowe. But as ſaint Baſile vrged the decrees and traditions of the Apoſtels, and the fathers againſt Eunomius: So did the fathers of Nice againſt the Arrians, Saint Auguſtine againſt Maximus, and the whole councell of Chalcedon againſt Eutyches: not that the Chatholiques lacked ſcripture, but becauſe the heretikes did peruert the true ſenſe of ſcripture to the maintenaunce
of their erroneous fanſies, and blaſphemous hereſies: and forced the Catholiques to ſticke to that meaning and ſenſe of ſcripture, which the learned woorkes of the fathers, traditions of the Apoſtels, and authoritie of the church, had taught them. They knewe that if euerie hereticke might haue the interpretation which him ſelfe deuiſed vpon the woordes of ſcripture, admitted as good, ther ſhould be as many hereſies as there were ſingular fantaſtical heades, able to deviſe ſuch fonde interpretations.Libro de praeſcrip. And therefore they thought with Tertullian, (who was well acquainted with the ſhiftes and ſleights of heretickes) that we ſhould not appeale to ſcripture nor make our conflicte and bickering in them, in which either ther is no victorie or doubtful, or not verie certaine. And this reſon is giuē for it. This hereſie admitteth not certaine ſcriptures: or if it doth admitte them, yet with additions, and detractions it turneth them vp and downe, to the maintenance of their owne purpoſe. And if this hereſie fortune to admitte ſcriptures, ſhe admitteth them not ful and whole as they are: or if ſhe admitte them ful and whole, yet by deuiſing diuerſe expoſitions, ſhe turneth them to a quite contrarie ſenſe. Therfore Tertullian would haue old traditions and cuſtomes reſpected, and all doctrine that Chriſt reueled to his Apoſtels, not to be allowed otherwiſe thē by the ſame churches, which the Apostels them ſelues did build by preaching vnto thē, as well by their liuelie voices, as by their epistels afterward. Further he affirmeth that all doctrine,The doctrine which agreeth not with the Apoſtolike churches is to be cōdēned of lying and falſitie. whiche agreeth with theſe Apoſ •• cal churches Matricibus & originalibus fidei, The mothers and originals of faith, is to be reputed for truth, retayning without all doubt, that which the church toke of the Apostels, the Apoſtles of Chriſt: and Chriſt of god. And that al other beſides, what ſoeuer it be, is to be cōdemned of falſitie, ſuch as ſauoreth againſt the truth of the Churches of the Apostels, and of Christ, and of God. VVherfore ſith the malice of heretickes is ſuch, that they admitte not ſome parte of ſcripture, as in our dayes, Luther would not admitte the epiſtle of S. Paule to the Hebrues, the Apocalypſe of S. Iohn, and epiſtels of S. Iames and Iude, vſed additions, and diuers interpretations to make them ſerue his purpoſe, as al heretikes euer did before, and do at this preſent, the catholikes after the example of their forefathers, thinke the onlie ſcripture
to be not ſufficient way to decide controuerſies in religion, but euer appealed to the expoſitions of the fathers, traditions of the Apoſtels, and authoritie of the churche: who as it deliuered the goſpell of S. Matthew, and others for ſcripture, ſo hath it deliuered a true ſenſe, meaning, and vnderſtanding of ſcripture: which euerie man muſt followe, that wil not be an authour of hereſie, as Eunomius, Arrius, Eutiches, Vigilātius, and diuerſe other were. For the ſame holie Ghoſt that ſpoke in them that wrote the ••••
ture, ſpeaketh in the church, that vttereth the true meaning 〈◊〉 ſcripture.

S. Auguſtine ſaieth, Chriſt is the bridegrome, In Pſal. 30 the Church 〈◊〉 is his ſpouſe, and vvhy is Chriſt • te bridegrome and the Churche his ſpouſe? Niſi quia duo in carne vna? ſi duo in carne vna, quare non in voce vna? Loquatur ergo Chriſtus, quia in Chriſto loquitur Eccleſia, & in Eccleſia loquitur Chriſtus, & corpus in capite, et caput in corpore. But becauſe they are twoe in one fleſhe? if they be twoe in one fleſhe, why not in one voice? Let Christ therfore ſpeake becauſe the Church ſpeaketh in Chriſt, and Chriſt ſpeaketh in the Church, and the bodie in the head, and the heade in the bodie. For the head and the bodie is but one Chriſt. Yf then the true ſenſe, and menīg of ſcripture be in the Churche, and what ſoeuer the Church ſpeaketh, Chriſt ſpeaketh as the head of the church, we muſt repaire to the church, and not to the ſcriptures, for the true vnderſtanding, and interpretation of ſcripture.

In the old teſtament, when any controuerſie roſe aboute the lawe, the people were not ſent to Moiſes tables, not written letters of the Bible: but to the prieſtes, and cōmaunded to enquire of them, and they ſhould ſhewe, iudicij veritatem: Deut. 17. the truth of iudgement: God ſaied not, the inke and paper and letters of the Bible keepe the knoweleadg of my will. But he ſaied:Malac. 2. Labia ſacerdotis cuſtodiunt ſcientiam: The lippes of the prieſt kepe knowleadg. He ſaid not, they ſhould require and ſeeke, the lawe out of the naked elemēts, But, exore eius, out of the prieſt his mouth, becauſe he is the Angel of the lord God of hoſtes. Our ſauiour Chriſt ſent not his diſciples and hearers alwaies to the ſcriptures: he ſent ſome to the figg three, ſome to the flowers in the field,Matth. 24. Matth. 6. ſome to the foules of the aire, ſometimes he vſed examples, ſometimes ſimilitudes,
ſometimes parables,Tit. 1. 1 Cor. 11. 2. Theſſ. 2. ſometimes natural reaſon. His Apoſtel S. Paule vſed both the ſentēce of Epimenides an heathen poet, and alſo cuſtome and tradition, they ſaid not alwaies, ſcriptum eſt: It is writen. Chriſt commaunded vs in no place of al the goſpell, to goe to the ſcriptures only. wherfore it is manifeſt that it was not his bleſſed will, that we ſhuld haue ſcriptures onlie to be iudges in controuerſies and matters of religion. If the hereti
•• s obiect againſt vs,Ioan. 5. that ſaying of his: Scrutamini ſcripturas: Searche the ſcriptures, we tell them, that the ſame Chriſt, the ſame holie Ghooſt, and the ſame God the father, ſaied: State, & tenete traditiones, 2. Theſſ. 2. Stand ye ſtoute, and kepe traditions. Yf they preſſe vs with that ſaying of God the father,Matt. 17. Ipſum audite, heare him: we wil preſſe them with that ſaying of God the ſonne: Qui vos audit, Luc. 10. 1. Ioan. 4. Matt. 18. me audit: Qui nouit Deum, audit nos: Si Eccleſiam non áudierit, ſit tibi tanqûam Ethnicus & Publicanus. He that heareth yow, heareth me, he that knoweth God, heareth vs: He that heareth not the Church, let him be vnto the as an Heathē and Publicā. If they alleage that ſaying of Chriſt:Ioan. 4. Illae ſunt quae teſtimonium perhibent de me: It be the ſcriptures which geue witnes of me, we wil returne vnto them the ſaying of God,Exod. 10. Ioel. 1. by his ſeruant Moyſes, and Prophet Ioel, Our fathers ſhal tel vs, our aunceters ſhal ſhewe vs, and our elders ſhal beare witnes vnto vs, of the miracles and mightie power of God: And ſo conuince that we muſt not haue cōtrouerſies determined by ſcriptures onlie, but alſo by traditions, cuſtomes, and interpretations of the fathers, whome God hath placed, ſome Apostels, ſome Prophetes, Ephe. 4. ſome Euangeliſtes, Paſtours and Doctours to the conſummation of the holie ones, into the woorke of miniſterie, to the edifyīg of the bodie of Christ vntil we come al together into the vnitie of faith, and knowleadge of the ſonne of God. And ſeing traditions and cuſtomes generally obſerued through out al Chriſtendome, and interpretations of the fathers agreed vpon with one vniforme cōſent, varie not from the playne and euident ſcripture, taken in the true ſenſe that the holy Ghoſt wrote, and the catholike churche receaueth, there is no inconueniēce, but that they ſhould preuayle, where there is no expreſſe ſcripture, and the interpretations of the fathers agreing in one vniforme conſent be admitted for the better
ſearching out of the ſenſe and meaning of ſcripture.

There be many things in the ſcriptures of God, which may be drawen to that ſenſe which euerie man preſumeth and imagineth to him ſelfe, ſayeth S. Clement.Libro 1. recog. wherfore we muſt ſeeke the vnderſtanding of ſcripture of him who kepeth it acording to the trueth deliuered of his forefathers. VVhich Chriſt hath layed vp in the lappe of his church, as in a rich treaſure houſe, and taught that we ſhould not ſeeke it any where out of that church. And if any doubtes of this, what doth he els but doubt whether God, (who doubtleſe ſpeaketh by the mouth of his church) be true. S. Baſile and Gregorie Naziāzene his brother for ſaking the ſtudie of Rhetorike, Philoſophie, and other prophane ſtudies,Euſeb. lib. 11. cap. 9. hiſto. and applying their paynes to the ſtudie of the bookes of holy ſcriptures, Eorū intelligentiā non ex propria praeſumptione, ſed ex maiorum ſcriptis & authoritate ſequebantur, etc. Folloed or rather ſought the vnderſtanding of thē, not of their owne preſumption, but out of the writings and authoritie of their forefathers, and eſpecially thoſe whom they knewe to haue taken the rule of vnderſtanding the ſcriptures, of the Apoſtolicall ſucceſsion, that is the ſee Apoſtolike.

S. Hierome ſaieth of him ſelfe,Prefat in Paralip. ad Rogat. that in the ſcripture he neuer truſted his owne opinion, but was wounte to aſke for the vnderſtanding of thoſe thinges which he thought him ſelfe to knowe, howe much more then did he in thoſe thinges of which he doubted? writing to Paulinus, Epiſt. ad Paulinū. he told him, that in ſcripturis ſacris ſine praeuio & monſtrante non poſsit ingredi. In the holy ſcriptures he could not goe without a guide, and one to ſhewe him the waye.Epiſt 59. quaeſt. 5. S. Auguſtine taketh the general cuſtome of the church to be a good way to expounde the ſcripture, and therfore him ſelfe expounding thoſe woordes of S. Paule, I deſire obſecrations, prayers, ſupplicatiōs, and thankes geuing to be had for al mē, expoundeth thē by the maner and cuſtome of the church. If there had ben any contention or reſoning aboute ſome meane and trifling queſtiō, Irenaeus thought,Lib 3 cōt. haere. ca. 4. that we ought to haue recourſe to the moſt auncient churches in which the Apostels liued and lerne of them the plaine and euident truth of the matter in controuerſie, and followe the tradition, Serm. de paſs. & cru ce dom. which they deliuered to thoſe to whom they committed their churches. Athanaſius repeting a piece of ſcripture, ſaieth, For the expounding of this, it ſhalbe good to haue recourſe to the holie fathers,
and of them to take the meaning of theſe woordes. But to followe this councell, and do as S. Clement, S. Baſile, S. Gregorie, S. Hierome, S. Auguſtine, Ireneus and Athanaſius thought moſt beſt to do, M. Calfhil ſuppoſeth it, to be, To build vpon an euil ground, Fol. 21. A. a loſſe of coſte, and trauail, and commending and ſetting to ſale of a ruinous or infectious thing, in ſteede of a ſtrōge defence, and holſome place to reſt vpon, and would haue nothing but ſcripture, but how doth he proue it? Forſohe: S. Paule ſaieth: Gal. 1. Si angelus è coelo, If an angel from heauē teach otherwiſe than the Apoſtels haue preched vnto vs, let him be accurſed. Looke better to yowr text ſir Iames, where finde yow there thoſe woordes, Than the Apostles preched to vs. wil yow be alwayes like yower ſelfe, and vſe your owne additions, detractions, and gloſes vpon the woorde of God? were not the diſciples prechers of the ghoſpell? Did not Chriſt geue them authoritie and commiſsion to preache his ghoſpel? VVhy then doe you not tranſlate Euangelizauimus, the diſciples preached, as well as the Apoſtles preached? Muſt not we receaue and followe that which the diſciples preached, as well as that which the Apoſtles preached? Had not the diſciples authoritie from the ſame holy Ghoſt that the Apoſtles had? Howe ſaye you M. Calf? Yf they had, they are to be credited on like. Paule ſaied not: Yf an angel from heauen teach otherwiſe than the Apoſtles haue preached to vs, let hym be accurſed: But he ſaied: Yf an angel from heauen preache otherwiſe than we haue preached, let hym be accurſed: ſignifiing that yf any preached other doctrine beſides, or contrary to that which the Apoſtles and diſciples authoriſed by Chriſt had taught, he ſhuld be accurſed. And therefor he ſaieth furder (which you ſuppreſſe) Yf any preache vnto you other doctrine, beſides that which you haue receaued, let hym be accurſed. He diſanulleth not by this ſaying, the traditions of the church, and ſayings of the fathers, that varie not from the ghoſpel:Tract. 98. in Ioan. as you may ſee by S. Auguſtine, who ſaieth: Si quis vobis euangelizauerit praeterquam quod accepistis, anathema ſit. Non ait pluſquam accepistis, ſed praeterquam accepistis, etc. Yf any preache vnto you otherwiſe
than that which ye haue receaued, let him be accurſed. He ſaieth not, yf any may preache vnto you more, than that which you haue receaued, but yf he preache vnto you otherwiſe, thā that which you haue receaued, let hym be accurſed. For yf he ſhould ſay ſo, he ſhould preiudice hym ſelf, Theſſa. 3. who coueted to come to the Theſſalonians to ſupply thoſe thinges which wanted to their faith. But he that ſupplieth that which was leſſe, addeth, and doth not take away that which was before. He that goeth beyond the rule of faith, cometh not in the way, but goeth out of the way. Thus much S. Auguſtine. And by this (ſir) you may lerne howe that piece of ſcripture is to be vnderſtode. Yf S. Paule ſhould be takē, as you meane, both the ghoſpel of s. Iohn, and his reuelatiōs ſhould be cōdēned. For they were written after this epiſtle was ſent to the Galathiās. VVherfor deceaue not your ſelf and your readers. S. Paule willeth the Galathians to flee ſuch teachers, as ſhould teache that which was contrary and repugnant to the doctrine of Chriſt, as they did, who at that tyme preached that circumciſiō, and the lawe of Moyſes was neceſſary to be obſerued. And yf you would haue delt faithfully, and applied that place of the Apoſtle fittely, without all ſhift of falſyfying, you ſhould haue proued, that the traditions, and writinges of the fathers generally receaued, and allowed of the catholique church in one vniforme cōſent, had ben repugnant to the ſcripture, and cōtrary to the ghoſpel, and preaching of the Apoſtels, and then haue ſaied againſt them, Si angelus è caelo. Yf an angel frō heauen teach otherwiſe than the Apoſtels haue preached to vs, let him be accurſed. But that was to heauy for your head, and therefor as though you ſhould not be eſpied, you ranne it ouer ſlightly, euē as you doe the next of S. Iohn, ſaying:1. Ioan. 2. Fol. 21 A Vos quod audiſtis ab initio, in vobis ꝑmaneat. Let that abyde in you which you heard frō the begynning. This playnly condēneth all your noueltie. For yf it be euident (as Tertulliā ſaieth) id verius quod prius, Lib 4 cōt. Marcio. id prius quod ab initio, ab initio, quod ab Apoſtolis, pariter vtique conſtabit id eſſe ab Apostolis traditum, quod apud Eccleſias Apoſtolorum fuerit ſacroſanctū. That that is truer which was firſt, and that that was firſt which was frō the begynning, and that that was frō the begynnīg which came frō
the Apostles it ſhal be euidēt with all, that that was deliured of the Apoſtels, which was holy in their churches. And ſeing you doe not obſerue that which is, ſacroſanctum apud Apostolorum eccleſias, most holy in the Apostles churches, and eſpecially in the church of Rome, where the chiefeſt Apoſtles S. Peter, and S. Paule had their churches, and ſuffred martirdome, you do not abyde in that which you heard from the begynning: and ſo neither continewe in the father, nor in the ſonne. You haue forſaken the faith of your forefathers, and the faith in which you were baptiſed, and the faith of the viſible, catholique and knowen church, for theſe xv. hundred yeres. Exijstis, diſceſsistis: ye haue gone out, ye haue departed away: And ye acknowledge it in your Apologie. And that going out, and diſceſsion is a token of Antichriſts coming, as S. Paule ſaieth.2. Theſſ. 2. 1. Ioan. 2. Yea it is a manifeſt argument that ye haue not God. For as S. Iohn ſaieth: Omnis qui recedit, & non permanet in doctrina Chriſti, Deum non habet. Euery one that goeth away and continueth not in the doctrine of Chriſt, hath not God. You haue gone away, and not taried in the doctrine of Chriſt (for you haue not taried in the doctrine of the Catholike and Apoſtolike Church, which is one bodie with Chriſt) wherfore that ſaying of the Apoſtle may be verified vpon you. As for the Catholiques, they continewe in the faith of their forefathers, in the faith in which they were baptiſed: in the faith of the Catholique, viſible, and knowen church. They acknowledg no diſceſsion as you doe. They abyde in that which they heard ab initio, from the begynning, that is, in in that, which is ſacroſanctum apud Apostolorum eccleſias, moſt holy in the Apoſtles churches. The high myſteries, and chief poynts of our religion and faith are al one with theirs in euery reſpect touching the ſubſtance. As for you, howe you alter, vary, chaunge, and differ one from another, and flitte from the Apoſtles, and that which you heard frō the begynning, the worlde may ſee, and thereupon proue vnuinciblie againſt you, that your doctrine is wicked, and naught.

2. Ioan. 1.That ſaying of S. Iohn, Yf any man do not bring this doctrine with hym, do not ſo much as ſalute him, nor receaue hym into your houſe, maketh againſt you. For if (as S, Auguſtine ſayeth) He denieth Chriſt
to be come in fleſh, that breaketh the church: Then doe ye heretikes,Tract. in 1. Epiſt. Ioan. that breake the ordināces, traditiōs, and cuſtomes of the church, and diuide it, and teare it by ſchiſme, denie Chriſt to be come in fleſhe, and bring not with you the doctrine that S. Iohn mentioneth, albeit your tongues clatter neuer ſo much of it.

That ſaying of Chriſt: He that loueth God, heareth his voyce, (for the which you ſend vs in the quotation of your margent to the 14. of S. Iohn, where that is not to be founde, but this:Ioan. 14. If any man loue me, he wil keepe my ſayings,) maketh nothing for your only ſcripture, againſt traditiōs and cuſtomes, and expoſitions of the fathers: but rather much for them. For ſeing the voyce of the Catholique Church, and prelates whome the father hath ordayned ſome Apoſtles, ſome Prophetes, Epheſ. 4. ſome Paſtours and Doctours into the woorke of miniſterie, to the edifying of the body of Chriſt, vntill we meete all in the vnitie of faith, and knowledg of the ſonne of God, is the voyce of God, who ſaied: Qui vos audit, me audit: Luc 10. He that heareth you, heareth me, it muſt nedes followe, that whoſouer heareth the voyce of his catholique church, and prelates of the ſame, heareth the voyce of God ſpeaking vnto vs many wayes beſides the ſcripture. But quoth M. Calf.Matt. 15. Fol. 21. B. They in vayne do woorſhip Chriſt, that teache the doctrine and precepts of men. And veril • e, yf he meane it, as Chriſt ſpoke it, they doe ſo. But what? Doe not they that teache the traditions of the Apoſtles, and general cuſtomes of the catholique church, and interprete the ſcripture after the minde and vniforme conſent of the fathers teſtified in their lerned commentaries, woorſhippe Chriſt? Reade the ſcriptures, ſearch the woorde of God, conferre the writings of the fathers, and you ſhall finde that the traditions of the Apoſtles are the traditions of the holy Ghoſt, and the general cuſtomes of the Catholique church, the doctrine of Chriſt, who is the head of the church, and that the voyce of the fathers agreing in one vniforme doctrine, is the voyce of God, ſpeaking by the fathers, whome he ordayned Paſtours, Doctours, and Biſſhops to rule, gouerne, and edifie his Church.

Furdermore you ſhall finde, that, this ſaying of Chriſt, is meant of the Scribes and Phariſees, who rebuked the diſciples,
for eating with vnwaſhed hādes, and keeping certaine curious, and friuolous traditions of their owne, contemned the commaundemēt of God. VVherevpon Chriſt to rebuke their wicked arrogācie,Eſa 29. ſaied, Eſai prophecied wel of you, hipocrites, as it is written: This people honoreth me with their lippes, but their heart is farre from me: And ſtreitwayes addeth theſe woordes: They woorſhippe me without cauſe, Marc. 7. teaching the doctrine and precepts of men. And that you may ſee it more euidently, reade further, where it is ſaied: Ye forſaking the commaundements of God, keepe the traditions of men, the waſſhing of pottes, and cruſes, and many ſuch other like things ye doe. And if ſeing this, you cā not ſee M. Calf. that our ſauiour Chriſt ſpooke thoſe woordes, of the fonde and vnprofitable traditions of the Scribes, and Phariſees, and not of the Catholique and Apoſtolique traditions of the church, and commaundements of the fathers, by whome the church is gouerned and directed, your ſight is very dymme, and needeth either ſome clere ſpectacle, or ſome fyne horne.Tract. 18. in Euang. Ioan. S. Auguſtine was wont to ſay, That hereſies and certayne peruerſe opinions did not riſe, but whiles the good ſcriptures are not wel vnderſtode, and that which is not wel vnderſtoode, is raſhly and boldely affirmed. And in this you may ſee a greate piece of your owne faulle in to hereſie. You vnderſtād not the ſcriptures, but frame vnto your ſelf a ſenſe contrary to that which the fathers teache and the church alloweth, and that you auouche, that you affirme, and of the ſcriptures not vnderſtoode make a ſnare as the diuel doth for the faithfull. Ambroſ. lib. 4 cō ment. in Luc: And as you deale falſely in alleaging the ſcriptures: ſo woorke you guilfully in alleaging the fathers and doctours. S. Auguſtine (you ſay) framing a perfect preacher willeth him to cōfer the places of ſcripture together. Let it be ſo what cōclude you of it? Forſoth, that he ſends hym not to the doctours diſtinctions, nor to the cenſure of the church, Fol. 21. B. Fol. 22. A. nor canons of the Popes, nor traditiōs of the fathers, but only to quiet and cōtent hym ſelf with the woord of God. Is not this a woorthy and profunde reaſon? You might as wel ſay: Chriſt commaunded the iewes to ſearche the ſcriptures: ergo he did not ſend them to his Apoſtles, and diſciples, and
traditions that they taught. Or this: M. Grindal commaunded a younge miniſter to ſtudie Gods booke: ergo he did not ſend hym to the vniuerſitie to lerne Latin, Greke or Hebrue, nor any of the liberall ſciences. Or if you will haue a more familiar example, you might as wel haue ſaied: The old cooke of diſtaffe lane ſent his wife to the ſhambles, to bye a calfs head and content her ſelf with that, ergo he did not ſend her to the Sermon at the Croſſe, leſſon in Paules, prophecying in Cornehil, nor goſsip in yuy lane. There is as good reaſon and ſequele in theſe as in yours. Did you not reade S. Auguſtines prologue before his firſt booke, De doctr. Chriſt? And founde you not there that he ſayeth: The condition of man ſhould be very abiect and baſe, yf God ſhould ſeeme not to be willing, to geue and miniſter his woorde by men to men? Founde you not that he ſaied: Howe ſhould it be true that is ſaid, The temple of God is holy, which temple ye are, yf God ſhould not geue anſwers out of this humaine temple, but ſounde into our eares frō heauē and by angells all that he would haue deliured to men? Founde you not that he ſaied: Charitie which bindeth men in the knott of vnitie together, ſhould haue no way, occaſion or entree to vtter and communicate the ſecret of mindes, yf men ſhould lerne nothing by men? Founde you noth that both he reproueth their fonde fanſie, who thought they might haue the vnderſtanding of ſcripture from heauē without any knowledg in tongues, and precepts and inſtructiōs frō men? As you thinke we may haue ſufficiently by conference of one place with another, and alſo accompteth it à ſnare of the diuel, and a moſt proude and perilous temptation, to refuſe to goe into the church, to reade the booke to heare a man reading and preaching, and to looke to be taken vp into heauen, and there to heare the myſteries of Gods woorde, and vnderſtanding of it? Act. 9. Act. 10. Exod. 18. Founde you not that he declareth howe Paule was ſent to a man, Cornelius to a mā, and that Moyſes tooke counſel and the eunuche inſtruction of a man? And if you founde all this, why make you the ſimple beleaue, that S. Auguſt. would not haue vs goe to men to lerne the true vnderſtāding of Gods woorde? why ſay your that he ſends vs not to the doctours diſtinctiōs, nor cenſure of the church, nor canōs of the Popes,
nor traditions of the fathers? Yf your memorie had ben ſo ſlipper, that reading his ſecond booke De Doctrina Chriſtiana, you forgotte the contents of the firſt, yet you ſhould not haue forgotten that which he ſpooke in the eight chapiter of the ſame booke, immediatly following that which your ſelf alleage. There he ſaieth, ſpeaking of his preacher, or rather young ſtudient in diuinitie: Eccleſiarum catholicarum quàm plurium ſequatur authoritatem, etc. Let hym followe the authoritie of the moſt catholique churches, amongeſt which they are, which deſerued to haue the Apoſtles ſees, and receaue their epistles. Nowe ſir yf S. Auguſtine ſend his ſcholler to the catholique churches where the Apoſtles had their ſees (of which Rome was the chiefeſt) to knowe which was the Canonicall ſcripture, is it credible that he did not ſend hym to the cenſure of the ſame church to knowe the true ſenſe and vnderſtanding of the ſcripture? No M. Calf. He that beleaueth this to be the ghoſpel and ſcripture, becauſe the church telleth hym, it is ſo, beleaueth alſo that this is the true meaning and vnderſtanding of ſcripture, becauſe the church telleth him it is ſo.Cōt. epiſt. Manich. cap 5. And ſoo did S. Auguſtine doubteleſſe, who ſaid, that he would not beleue the ghoſpel, vnleſſe the authoritie of the catholique church moued hym ſo to doe. Did you euer reade his bookes againſt Iulian the Pelagian, where he allegeth the autoritie of Ireneus, Cyprianus, Reticius, Olympius, Hilarius, Ambroſius, Innocentius and others? or his epiſtle to S. Hierome where he ſaieth:Epiſt. 28. Nemo cōtra fundatiſsimum morem Eccleſiae ſentiat? Let no man thinke againſt the moſt ſure and grownded cuſtome of the church? Or his epiſtle to Ianuarius where it is ſaied:Epiſt. 118. Thoſe thinges which wee keepe, not written, but delyured, which are obſerued through out the whole worlde, are geuen vs to vnderſtande, that they are retayned, as commended, and ordayned either of the Apoſtles thē ſelues, or of full generall councells, whoſe authoritie is moſt holſome in the church? Did you not reade that he ſaieth: Yf the catholique church through out the worlde vſeth any like thing, it is moſt inſolent madnes to diſpute whether it ſhould be done in ſuch ſort or no? Yf you did, what folly forced you to ſay, that S. Auguſtine ſends vs not to the doctours diſtinctiōs, nor cenſure of the church, nor canons of the popes, nor traditions
of the fathers? Is it not euident that he hym ſelf vſed the authoritie and ſayings of the fathers, and kept the traditions of the church, and thought it a madneſſe to diſpute againſt them? Yf you did not reade ſo much in S. Auguſtine, was your witt ſo barren, and your ſkill ſo ſimple that you knewe not this to be an euill argument, S. Auguſtine ſends vs not to the doctours diſtinctions, nor cenſure of the church, nor traditions of the fathers, in that place, ergo he ſends vs to thē in no other place, nor no other father beſides? Forgot you that it is no ſounde nor ſubſtantial reaſoning vppon the authoritie of any man negatiuely? Yf you did, to ſchole like a ſir Iames, to ſchole, for ſhame, and lerne your logique and diuinitie better, this will not ſerue yourne turne. Albeit S. Auguſtine did not commaunde this, yet other holy men might, and be of no leſſe creditte,S. Auguſtine corrupted. than yf S. Auguſtine had geuen it in expreſſe cōmaundemēt. But (ſir) where you ſay, that S. Auguſtine willed his ſcholler only to quiet and content hym ſelf with the woord of God, where finde you that in the 9. chap. & ſequentibus, of his ſeconde boke De Doctrina Chriſtiana? VVill you neuer leaue your falſifying the doctours? we can finde no ſuch thing in the ſaid booke and chapters. VVherfore to ſaue your creditte, bring foorth his woordes,Fol. 22. A as yet they can not appeare. That in the primitiue church before the newe teſtamēt was written all thinges were examined according to the ſermons and woordes of the Apostles, and that he that is of God heareth the Apoſtles, we graunte,1. Ioan. 4. what inferre you vppon it M. Calf? Yf you make this argument: All thinges were examined in the primitiue church by the woordes and ſermons of the Apostles, ergo nothing ſhould be examined nowe, but by the woordes, and ſermons of the Apoſtes, we will denie the conſequēt, and auouche the reaſon to be ſtarke naught, and deſire your woorſhip to proue a neceſsitie in it, and make euident declaration that all the woordes and ſermons of the Apoſtles are written and come to our handes.

S. Auguſtine is of this opinion, that we haue many thinges of the
tradition of the Apostles, Lib. 5. cap. 23. de Baptiſmo. Epiſt. 118. Ad Pāma. cōt. erro. Ioā. Hier. Cōt. Apoſtolicos. lib. 2. hereſ. 61. 1. Cor. 11. which are not written, and becauſe the Catholike church doth keepe them, he thinketh it, an inſolent madneſſe to diſpute whether they ſhuld be obſerued. S. Hierome writeth that: Symbolum fidei & ſpei noſtrae etc. Our creede and articles of our faith and hope, was delyured of the Apoſtles, and not written in ynck and paper, but in the tables of mens heartes. Epiphanius ſaieth: we moſt vſe tradition. For al can not be fotte out of holy ſcriptures. Therefore the bleſſed Apoſtles delyured certayne thinges in writing, and certaine thinges in tradition not written, as S. Paule ſaieth: Sicut tradidi vobis: As I haue delyured vnto you, ſo I teache, and ſo I haue delyured in the churches. By this you may lerne that the Apoſtles left many thinges vnwrittē, which came from the holy Ghoſt, as wel as the written ſcripture. You may lerne that the xij.The Articles of our Creede not writtē in ſcripture. Articles of our creede were neuer written in the ſcripture: and ſeing they are neceſſarie to be beleaued, although they be not written in ſcripture, you may ſee that ſome thinges neceſſarie to ſaluatiō, are not written in ſcripture, and ſo proue vnto your ſelf, that there is ſomewhat vnwritten whereby controuerſies ſhould be examined, beſides the writtē ſcripture. Furder out of Epiphanius you may note two thinges, one is, that the Apoſtles left not all thinges in writing that they would haue obſerued of the faithful. The other that all doubtes and controuerſies, touching matters of faith, are not to be tried by ſcripture only, becauſe all can not be fotte out of ſcripture, and by this you may lerne to haue the aunciēt fathers and vnwritten traditions in better creditt.

But ſaye you, So farre as men accorde with the holy ſcripture, and ſhape there writings after the patterne that Chriſt hath left, I wil not only my ſelf eſteme them, but wiſhe them to be had in moſt renoune, and reuerēce. Suerly they are much beholding vnto you, that without derogation to your perſon, can thinke them woorthy of ſuch renoune, and reuerēce with ſo gentle a condition. I beſeeke you, is there any that reuerence them otherwiſe? Is there any that eſteme theyr writtings whē they write any thing that is repugnant or contrary to the ſcripture? Is there any that followe theyr writtinges when they be not ſhaped after the patterne that Chriſt left? If there be, name
hym, and blame hym. No Catholique will be offended with you for it. VVhereſoeuer any of the fathers vary frō the receaued and approued doctrine of the Catholique chuche, in that he is nor followed, nor reuerēced, nor abſolutely truſted vnto. we gather not out of theyr writinges whatſoeuer was witneſſe of theyr imperfection. That which we gather out of them, and allowe to be followed, in maters of religiō and faith, is the doctrine of the catholique Church, in which they were by the prouidēce of God as apoſtles, euāgeliſtes doctours and paſtours. If there be any imperfections in ſome, not agreinge withal the reſt, we reiect them, and vtterly condemne them, and muche maruell what moueth you and other heretikes to condemne thoſe thinges for imperfections in the fathers, which with one vniforme conſent both they haue euer taught, and the Catholique church gouerned by the holy Ghoſt hath alwayes allowed. Furthermore we maruel, that to proue that in no age any man was ſo perfet that a certayne truth was to be builded on hym, you bring only the example of Aaron and Peter, and in your induction, adde not, & ſic de ſingulis. If you would haue it a general rule, you ſhould haue done ſo. But you knewe that for Aaron in the old lawe, we could make inſtance of Abel, Abraham, Moyſes and Samuel, and for Peter in the newe lawe, bring S. Iohn Baptiſt, S. Iohn the Euangeliſt, S. Paule, and other who neuer erred in faith, and therefore you did ſuppreſſe it, and as though you had made a ſure grownde, march forward, and alleage another place of S. Auguſtine to proue your purpoſe,Proem. lib. 3. de Trinit. Fol. 22. A your woordes are theſe. Truſt me not ſaieth S. Auguſtine, nor creditte my writinges, as though they were Canonical ſcripture, but what ſoeuer thou findeſt in the woorde, although thou didſt not beleaue it before, yet grownde thy faith on it nowe. And what ſo euer thou readeſt of mine, vnleſſe thou knoweſt it certaynly true, geue no aſſent vnto it. Epiſt. 48. And in another place, reprouing ſuch as will bring foorth cauills out of mens writings thereby to confirme an errour, he ſaieth that
a difference ſhould be made betwene ther aſſertions, and mindes of men, were they either Hilarie, Cyprian Agrippine, or other, and the canon of the ſcripture.

But ô merciful God what a miſerable ſhyft is this to impayre the eſtimation of the Fathers? VVhat a corruption to deceaue the readers? S. Auguſtne in al that ꝓeme hath not thoſe wordes, Truſt me not. And ſeing he hath them not, what a vile falſifier are you to tel the ſimple people,S. Auguſt. corrupted that S. Auguſtine ſaieth of hym ſelf in that place, Truſt me not. That which he ſaieth to to your purpoſe is this. Noli meis literis quaſi ſcripturis Canonicis in ſeruire. doe not addict thy ſelfe to my writinges as to the Canonical ſcriptures. But what is this againſt the writinges of the auncient fathers? Dyd euer man eſteme S. Auguſtines wordes as highly as the ſcripture?Diſtin. 9. cap. Noli. or ſo addict hym ſelfe vnto them as though they were ſcripture? No M. Calf. Gratian hym ſelfe (whome your ſect malitiouſly ſclaunder) hath put this ſayng of S. Auguſtine amōgeſt the decrees, to proue that the ſayinges of the interpreters ſhoud yeld to the ſcriptures. And certes there was neuer Catholique that thought otherwiſe. Nowe becauſe we muſte not addicte your ſelues to the fathers as to the ſcriptures, will it followe that we muſte not credite the fathers at all? No forſothe, no more than if one would ſay, I muſt geue an high and peareleſſe honour vnto my ſouerayne Ladie, and Princeſſe, ergo I muſt geue no honour to the lordes of the Councell,Epiſt. 48. iuſtices of peace, ad ſhriues of the ſheere. As for the other place of S. Auguſtine it maketh againſt you and yours M. Calf. You are they that bring cauills and half mangled ſentences out of the fathers writings to confirme your errous. Your are they that preſſe their autoritie to confirme your hereſie. VVe vſe them but as witneſſes to proue that this is the true meaning of ſcripture, and truth in matters of faith, and religion agreed vpon in their dayes, and allowed by the catholique church And if they agree with the ſcripture and determinatiō of the church we admitte them, yf they varie, we refuſe them in that, were they either, Hilarie, Cyprian, Agrippine or Baſile, whoſe authoritie I maruel
much, howe you dare ſo vilye abuſe, and ſay:Fol. 22. b S. Baſile ſetteth foorth by à proper ſimilitude with what iudgement the fathers of the church ought to be read, and quote for your creditte in the margent. Concio. ad Adoleſcē. S Baſile abuſed. Suerly in all that ſermon S. Baſile ſpeaketh no one woorde of the fathers of the church. All his diſcourſe is to teache youngemen, howe to behaue them ſelues in the ſtudie of prophane writers, as poetes, hiſtoriographers, oratours, philoſophers, and ſuch like. VVherefore vnleſſe, Heſiode, Homer, Virgil, Ouide, Horace, Eſchines, Plautus, Terence, Lyuie, Saluſte, Plutarche, Demoſthenes, Cicero, Quintilian, Varro, Macrobius, Suetonius, Pythagoras, Ariſtotell, and Diogenes are accompted in your lerned iudgemēt fathers of the church, you can not ſay, that he ſpeaketh of the fathers of the church. Of ſuch he ſpeaketh, and not of the fathers of the church. Thoſe he thinketh expediēt and neceſſarie for younge men to reade in their tendre yeres, to whette their wittes, and increaſe their iudgments, that afterwarde with more facilitie they might vnderſtande the myſteries of Chriſtian religion. VVhich thing the very title of the booke might haue geuen you to vnderſtand, yf there had ben nothing els. But I perceaue Momus will be Momus, heretikes will be heretikes, and falſify the fathers continually at their pleaſure.

VVhere you ſay that we are aduerſaries to you, Fol. 22. b and to the truth, and that all the fathers had their errours, and in ceremonies declined al, from the ſimplicitie of the ghoſpel, Fol 23. a and that you are onely burdened with the name of fathers, and therefore deſyre leue to vſe a Regeſtiō, and to haue the libertie towardes other that Hierome graunteth to hym ſelf, VVe tell you that you take vpon you foure pretie perſons, that is, a ſclaunderer, a lyer, a curſed Cham, and a poore ſuppliant. A ſclaunderer, in that you ſay, we are aduerſaries to the truth. For we ſet not our ſelues againſt the truth, but defende it, and mayntayne it againſt the aſſaultes and vilanie of heretkies. we continewe and • ide in that which we receaued ab initio. From the begynning, we tread after our holy fathers ſteppes. Communicamus
cum Eccleſiis Apostolicis, Tertul. de preſcrip. quòd nulla doctrina diuerſa, hoc est testimonium veritatis. VVe cōmunicate with the Apostolike churches. That there is no diuerſe, nor contrary doctrine amongeſt vs (touching principall poynts of religion and faith) it is a teſtimonie of truth. This parologiſme petitio Principij, taking that to be graunted which remayneth to be proued is ofte yn your booke: before you had ſclaundered vs as aduerſaries to truth, you ſhuld haue proued it: that your ſelues are ſuch in deede you may ſee by theſe places of Tertullian. Ye communicate not with the Apoſtolique churches, and therefore hold not that wich you heard from the begynning. You haue diuerſe and contrary doctrine, in ſome of the chiefeſt poynts of your faith, and therfore haue not teſtimonium veritatis, the teſtimonie of truth: for there is: Et ſcripturarum & expoſitionum adulteratio, Tertul. de preſcrip. vbi diuerſitas inuenitur doctrinae: A corruption of the ſcripture, and expoſitions of them, where there is founde a diuerſitie of doctrine. Agayne in ſaying that the fathers declined al frō the ſimplicitie of the ghoſpel, Fol. 23 you ſclaunder them. For if Chriſt according to his promiſe is with the church alwayes to the end of the worlde, and yf the holy Ghoſt teacher of al truthe hath ben preſidēt in it as God promiſed, then haue they not ſuffred al the fathers to decline from the ſimplicitie of the ghoſpel, but hath preſerued ſome to mayntayne his truth, leſt hel gates ſhuld preuayle againſt it.

A lyer you are for ſaiynge that ye are onely burdened with the name of fathers: for beſides their names you are burdened with their expreſſe woordes, and plaine ſentences. The places where you ſhal finde thē are leyed before your eyes. Furder we burdē you with the ſcriptures, and authority of the church, that authoriſeth thoſe ſcriptures, and geueth the true vnderſtāding and ſenſe of the ſcriptures. VVe burden you with the traditions of the Apoſtles, and general councels, and lawes of emperours, beſides the names of fathers. A curſed Chā you are, hauing a wicked minde to detecte the imꝑfectiōs and errours of the fathers to the worlde and for lacke of imperfectiōs, and errours obiecting moſt vndoubted truthes to ſome, as ſhall apere hereafter. And albeit you pretend an holynes here not to followe Cham
Noes ſonne, yet in your anſwer you do it ſo oftē, that you ſhew in what forge you were framed. A pore ſupplicāt you are in deſirīg leaue to vſe a Regeſtiō and the ſame liberty towards other which S. Hierome graunted againſt hym ſelf. And becauſe the requeſt is reaſonable, we graunte it. Vſe you Regeſtiō on Gods name. Take the libertie that S. Hierome tooke, mary with this condition that you abuſe it not, nor falſifie S. Hierome. Goe to what ſaied S. Hierome? Forſoth, Certe vbicun
que ſcripturas nō interpretor, & libere meo ſenſu loquor, arguat me qui volet. Fol. 23. a Truly whereſoeuer I expounde the ſcripture, but freely ſpeake of myne owne ſenſe, let hym reproue me that lyſte. VVhy ſir, haue you ſo ſone forgotten the condition that was ioyned to your lycence? VVe told you that you ſhould not falſifie S. Hierome? Howe falleth it out that you ſo wickedly abuſe him?Apol. cōt. Iouinia. VVil it neuer be otherwiſe? S. Hierome in deede ſaieth: Truly whereſoeuer I expounde not the ſcriptures, but ſpeake freely of myne owne ſenſe, let hym reproue me that lyſte? VVhat followeth immediatly without any diſtinction or poynt? Nothing M. Calf? Reade it ones againe, and you ſhall ſee theſe wordes there, me durum quid dixiſſe contra nuptias: ſo that the whole ſentence it this: Certe vbicun
que ſcripturas non interpretor, & liberè de meo ſenſu loquor, 8. Hierom not truly alleaged. arguat me cui libet, me durum quid dixiſſe contra nuptias. Truly wherſoeuer I do not interprete the ſcripture, but ſpeake freely of my owne ſenſe, let hym reproue me that liſte, that I ſpooke any hard or ſeuere thing againſt mariage. In this place he talketh of an īterpreter, and ſheweth what his dutie is. And ſaieth for him ſelf that if he ſpoke any thing ſeuerely, or rigorouſly, againſt mariage, after his owne opiniō, and not as interpreting holy ſcripture, euerie man ſhould reproue hym. But if they could finde no ſuch thinge in hym, then he willed them rather to attribute it, to the authoritie of the writer, thā to the fault of the interpreter. He gaue not all men licence to reproue hym: when he interpreteth the ſcripture, he willeth no man to reproue hym. But when he ſpeaketh any thinge of his owne fanſie, any thing contrary to the ſcripture, any thing contrary to the receaued, and approued doctrine of the church, thē
he geueth licence, and libertie to all men to reproue hym, and by good and ſufficient reaſon to conuince hym. And if he dyd not graunt it, we would take it, and reproue him, and al others. For we admitte them, and receaue them no otherwiſe, than as they agree with the ſcriptures, and determinations of the catholique church:Apolog. cont. Iou • nia. Epiſt. 85. and ſo do all catholiques. Nor is it the practiſe of this age to alleage the fathers when occaſion ſerueth. S. Auguſtine alleageth S. Cyprian, S. Hierome alleageth S. Ambroſe, and Leo diuerſe fathers ſentences in his epiſtell to Leo the Emperour againſt the blaſphemies of Neſtorius and Eutiches: ſo that if our newe maſter find fault with vs, for alleaging the fathers, and vrging their authoritie, and preſsing thē with the traditiōs of their forefathers, we wil deſire them, to reade S. Hierome, Ambroſe, Auguſtine and Leo, and either with them to accuſe vs, or with them and others to licence vs to do as we doe.

VVe aſſure your ſelues vpon the tender mercie of our ſauiour Chriſt,Mat. vlt. that promiſed to be with his church alwaies to the end of the world, Ephe. 4. and gaue ſome Apoſtles, ſome Euangeliſtes, ſome Prophets, ſome Paſtours, ſome Doctours, to the edefying of his bodie, that we ſhould not be litle ones, wauering and caried away with euerie winde of doctrine, in the wickednes of men, in craftines, to the circumuention of errour, we I ſay, do aſſure your ſelues, that God neuer ſuffred al the fathers to decline from the ſimplicitie of the ghoſpell, and to fall to ſuch errours, as ſhould be contrarie to his faith and religion. But yf any one did, he raiſed ſome other that controlled him for it: as when S. Ciprian erred, Cornelius biſſhop of Rome controlled him. S. Hierome, S. Auguſtine, and other that came after, found fault with him for it, as diuerſe did before with Tertulliā, and Origen, in that they taught repugnant to the church. But what ſoeuer Tertullian, Origen or S. Cyprian ſaie, if Cornelius or the biſſhop of Rome for the time did allowe it, S. Hierome approue it, S. Ambroſe confirme it, S. Auguſtine embrace it, Hilarius accept it, Proſper ratifie it, S. Gregorie receaue it, Fulgentius admitte it, S. Bede like it, and S. Bernard credite it, and others whome God apointed Doctours, and Paſtours in his church, ſubſcribe vnto it, we may be well aſſured, that the ſaying of
Tertullian, Origen, and S. Cyprian, is the determination of the holy catholique church, ſuch as no man ought to gaine ſay. VVherfore let vs, (geuing the firſt and higheſt place to the ſcripture) nothing imperiſh the eſtimation of the aunciēt fathers. Let vs not wilfullie abrogate the decrees of the doctours, where they agree with the catholike church.Oratio dicta in praeſent f • atr. Gregor. But with the bleſſed biſſhop Gregorie Nazianzene, let vs as long as we haue a day to lyue, confeſſe with a ſtoute heart and free tongue: Sanctorum patrum depoſitum, that which our holy fathers which were nearer to Chriſt, left vnto vs. Let vs keepe, Primae fidei confeſsionem, the confeſsion of our firſt faith. which was nourriſhed in vs from our tender yeres: So ſhall we, no doubte, remayne obedient and faithful children in Chriſt.

As for the twoe iudges of controuerſies, which maſter Calfhill apoynteth, the woord, and the ſpirite, Fol. 22. a let vs (embracing the woorde and honouring the ſpirite) inquire of his wiſdome, howe the woord and the ſpirite can be iudges of cōtrouerſies? A iudge muſt be ſenſible, the woorde is ſenſeleſſe. A iudge muſt ſpeake. The woorde is dumbe. A iudge muſt heare, the woorde is deafe.the vvord no iudge in cōtrouerſies. A iudge muſt examine things brought in controuerſie. The woorde, that is, the bare letter of the Bible (as heretikes take it) written in incke and paper, conſidered as it lieth, nor reade, nor pronunced of any man, is deafe, and not able to proue it ſelfe to be the worde of God, and holie ſcripture of Chriſt. Yf one ſhould require the beſt rabby, and profoundeſt maſter amonge al the proteſtants, that exacte proufes out of ſcripture only, for matters in controuerſie, to proue and iuſtifie out of ſcripture, that this woorde, (which they crake and bragge of) is the woorde of God, he would neuer do it, ſo long as he liueth. Al his refuge muſt be, to the catholick church, that hath adiudged, and declared this be the ſcripture, and woorde of God. VVherfore ſeing it hath thoſe defectes, it cā not be iudg of matters in controuerſie in the church, eſpeciallie, ſeing al our contention, debate, and controuerſie is, of the ſenſe and vnderſtāding of ſcripture, which they receaued of the catholiques.

And whereas the Catholiques ſay: This is the true meaning
of this place of ſcripture, and the heretickes for theyr part denie it, and ſay: Nay: This is this the true meaning of this place of ſcripture, and ſo contēd ſtoutely aboute it, howe ſhall the ſcripture be iudge, and decide this controuerſie? It hath no tongue to ſpeake and geue ſentence. Shall we conferre place to place, and ſo trie out the truth? That is a way of greater contention: For when other places be alleaged, the Catholiques may ſay: This is the right ſenſe of that ſcripture. And the heretikes denie it, and ſo procede infinitely in contention. VVherefore is it not poſsible that the ſcripture only, taken in any other ſenſe than the Catholique church alloweth, ſhould be iudge, which is the true ſenſe of ſcripture and ſo decide matters in controuerſie. But peraduēture ſome cauilling heretike, will ſcāderouſly reporte of me, and ſay, I ſpeake much to the derogatiō of holy ſcripture. If any ſuch opē his mouth, I wil him to vnderſtand that I honour, reuerēce, and eſteeme the holy ſcripture, as wel, or rather better than he.Heb. 4. I acknowledge with S. Paule, that it is lyuely, effectuous, and more pearcing than any two edged ſworde. I confeſſe that it is, as it were, Eſa 23. a fyer, and hammer waſting the rock, a lanterne to guide our ſteppes, ſweete br •• d to feede our hungry ſoules, Pſal. 118. Ioan. 6. Ioan. 4. Eſa. 55. and pleaſant water to quench our heates and luſtes: to be ſhorte, I confeſſe that it is, the ſweete ſhoore of rayne and ſnowe, that cōmeth from heauen, and moyſteth the earth, and maketh it bring foorth her frute and doe whatſoeuer God wil haue done, and proſper in all thinges, for which he ſends it. But notwithſtandinge it hath all theſe vertues, and effectes by the mighty power of God, yet in al the ſcripture can you not finde that it hath this vertue, and power to be a iudge, and decide controuerſies. No more than the greate booke of ſtatutes, and writtē lawes, haue to put on my Lord chief Iuſtices robes, and come to the kinges bench, or common place, and geue ſentence. For ſeynge as S. Hyerome ſaieth:Contra Luciferia. The ſcriptures conſiſte not in reading, but in vnderſtanding, and the Goſpell is not in the letre which killeth, but in the ſpirite that quickeneth, not in the outward ryne, but ī the īward pith, not in the leaues of paper, but in the roote of reaſon, there muſt be ſome man that muſt informe vs of the vnderſtandinge, and inſtructe vs in the ſenſe of it, and picke out the pyth, and
rule vs in the reaſon of it, as there muſte be a iudge to informe men of the minde and vnderſtanding of the lawe, and decide their cauſes as reaſon and equitie do require.

Nowe as for the ſpirite, that it can not be a iugde, eſpecially ſuch a iugde, as we muſt haue, reaſon tells you.The ſpirite no ſuch iudge as vve muſt haue in matters of religion. Our iugde muſte be viſible, the ſpirite is inuiſible. Our iugde muſt be ſo in the light of the world, that euery man may knowe where he dwelleth. The ſpirite is ſo ſecret, that no man can truly ſay, out of the Catholique church, here he dwelleth, here he abideth, here is his reſting place. No man can ſay in this later age of the world, I am ſure the holy Ghoſte dwelleth in me, I am ſure the holy Ghoſt ſpeaketh in me, vnleſſe he ſpeaketh that which the Catholique church, hath taught hym to ſpeake. VVhich being ſo, the ſpirite cā not be ſuch a iugde of cōtrouerſies, as we muſte haue. VVherefore it remayneth that we ſearch, who may be iugde ī matters of cōtrouerſie. For neither the word neither the ſpirite can be iudges as M. Calf. ſaieth, vnleſſe we wil haue a iudge that is ſenſeleſſe, dumbe, deafe, inuiſible, ſecret, vnknowen, and vnable to be gone vnto. Or if either of them bothe might be iugdes, let our good miniſter tel vs, howe it came to paſſe that when a controuerſie aroſe for the obſeruation of the lawe of Moyſes,Actuū 15.8. Paule and Barnabee, vvent, to the Apoſtles and prieſtes in Hieru alē for deciſion of a matter in controuerſie. S. Paule and Barnabe Chriſtes Apoſtles went to Hieruſalem about that queſtion, ad Apoſtolos & Preſbiteros, to the Apoſtles, and Prieſtes? They had the ſpirite (that is the holy Ghoſte) geuen of Chriſte hym ſelfe from heauen. They had the worde, that was preached before of Chriſte. They had the traditions and preceptes of the Apoſtles, and ſcripture whatſoeuer was then written, and yet they decided not that queſtion neither by the worde, neither by the ſpirite. But went vp to Hieruſalem to the Apoſtles and Prieſtes: which they would not haue done, if they had ſuppoſed the word or the ſpirite to be ſufficiēt iugdes in controuerſies.

Our ſauiour Chriſt redemīg the church with his death vpō the croſſe, that he might make it glorious, and without wringle in his ſight would not leaue it in worſe caſe, then the Synagog of the Iewes was in the old lawe. And ſeing for thē he prouided a
iudge that could heare and ſpeake, a iudge that was viſible, a iudge that had a certayne dwelling place, to which the people might reſort for iudgemēt,Cap. 17. as it apeareth in Deuteromie, where it is ſaied, If thou perceaue the iudgement which is before thee to be hard, and doubtefull, betwene bloud and bloud, cauſe, and cauſe, lepre, and lepre, and ſeeſt the iudges wordes within thy gates to varie, ariſe and goe vp to the place which the Lord thy God hath choſen, and come to the Prieſtes of the ſorte of Leuy, and to the iudge that ſhalbe at that tyme, and thou ſhalt ſeeke of them, who ſhall ſhewe vnto thee, the truth of iudgment, and thou ſhalt doe whatſoeuer they ſay, who are preſidentes in the place, whiche God hath choſen, and teach thee according to his lawe, It can not be, but that he foreknowing that there ſhoud be hereſies, ſchiſmes, and controuerſies in his church, prouided of his tender mercy a like a iudge to determine ſuch controuerſies, and apoynted a viſible place whether men might reſort to ſeeke that determination. For he loueth vs as tenderly as he loued them. As then he choſe a place for the Iewes in the Synagog, where controuerſies ſhould be decided: So hath he choſen a place for the Chriſtians in this newe Hieruſalem to ende and determine all cauſes and controuerſies, and that place is his catholike church. VVhich is Locus ſanctificationis, Eſa. 60. Chryſoſt. hom. 36. in 1. Cor. Matth. 15. Pſal. 18. Matth. 18. 1. Tim 3. Eſa. 62. locus angelorum, locus archangelorum, regia Dei: The place of ſanctification, the place of God, the citie ſet vpon the hill, the tabernacle placed in the ſunne, loued of God aboue all the tabernacles of Iacob. To this God biddeth vs goe, ſaying: Dic Eccleſiae. Tell it to the church. This is the piller and fure foundation of truth, & voluntas mea in ea, and my will in it, ſaieth God: In this place ſhall we haue controuerſies truly and faithfully decided. And no where beſides.

Agayne, as he apoynted the Iewes: Sacerdotes Leuitici generis, Priestes of the order of Leui to be their iudges: So for vs he hath apoynted Apoſtles, Prophetes, Euangeliſtes, Paſtours and doctours to the edifying of his bodie. To them he hath ſaid: Attendite vobis & vniuerſo gregi, Act 20. etc. Take heede to your ſelues, and to the whole flocke, in which the holy Ghoſt hath placed you, biſſhops to rule the church of God. 1. Pet. 5. To them he hath ſaid: Feede the flock of our lord, which is in you, taking the ouerſight of them willingly without compulſion. And
if God hath apoynted Apoſtles, Prophetes, Euāgeliſtes, Paſtours and Doctours, to edifie and builde his church, and the holy Ghoſt hath geuen them auctoritie, and commiſsion to rule his ſheepe, then they muſt rule, they muſt gouerne, they muſt feede Chriſtes flock, and trie what paſture is beſt for thē. And if they muſt do it, and none but they (for the commiſsion of the holy Ghoſt ſtretcheth to none, but to ſuch as they are,) thē is it not, A precept generall all men to iudge, al men to trie, Fol. 23. a. what doctrine they receaue, as you ſay M. Calf. For all are not Apostles, all are not Prophetes, all are not Euangeliſtes, 1. Cor. 12. all are not Paſtours and Doctours. The holy Ghoſt placed not all to rule the church of God, but vos poſuit epiſcopos, He placed you, that is to ſay, Apoſtles,God apoynted one chief iudg in the old lavve and another in the nevve lavve Matt. 16. Luc. 22. Ioan. 21. and ſuch like, biſſhops to rule the church of God. And as in the old lawe, to auoyde ſchiſme and diuiſion, he ordayned one of the prieſts, to be chief iudge for the tyme: So in the newe lawe, he ordayned one to be chief iudg, head, and ruler, of all the reſt. And that one was S. Peter, to whome Chriſt ſaid: Thowe art Peter, and vpon this rock, I will build my church. To thee will I geue the keyes of the kingdome of heauē. Thou being turned, confirme thy breetherne. Feede my lambes, feede my ſheepe. For by theſe woordes, Chriſt gaue hym a ſinguler preeminence, and ſuperioritie ouer al the reſt, and as the fathers ſay builded his church vpon Peter. VVhoſe ſayings becauſe M. Calfhill ſeemeth not to haue reade, I will breefely repete thē, for his furder inſtructiō, let him refell thē if he cā. Tertullian hath theſe wordes:De preſcrip. Latuit aliquid Petrū adificādae eccleſiae petram dictum? VVas any thinge vnknowen to Peter called the rock of the church, that was to be builded? By this he may vnderſtād, that S. Peter was aedificādae Eccleſiae Petra dictus: called of Chriſt the rock of the church, that was to be builded. In another place he hath theſe wordes: Qualis es euertens atque commutans Domini intentionem, perſonaliter hoc Petro conferentem? Superte, De pudicitia. Orat. de conſum. mundi. Libro 1. epiſt 3. inquit aedificabo eccleſiā meam? VVhat arte thowe turning vpſidowne, and altering the intention of our lord geuing this perſonally to Peter?
