Vpon the he ſaid, I will build my church? The bleſſed martyr Hippolitus, ſaieth: Princeps Petrus, fidei petra, &c: docuit nos, Peter the chief of all, and rock of faith, hath taught vs. S. Cyprian ſaieth: Petrus ſuper quem aedificata fuit
à domino eccleſia, Libro 4. epiſt. 9. Ser. de habitu virg. dicit: Domine ad quem ibimus? Petrus loquitur, ſuper quem aedificāda fuerat eccleſia. Petrus ſuper quem dominus poſuit & fundauit Eccleſiam, aurum ſibi & argētum eſſe negat. Peter vpon whome the church was builded of our lord, ſaieth: Lord to whome ſhall we goe? Peter vpon whome the church was to be builded ſpeaketh. Peter vpon whome our lord founded, Lib. 1. cō menta in Matth. vide Euſe. lib 6 cap. 18. hiſtor. Homi. 5. ſuꝑ exod. and builded his church, ſaieth, he hath no gold. Origen hath theſe words: Petrus ſuper quē domini fundatur Eccleſia, duas tantummodo epiſtolas ſcribit. Peter vpon whome, the church of our lord is builded, writeth two epiſtles onlye. In another place he writeth thus: Magno illi eccleſiae fundamento, petrae
que ſolidiſsimae ſuper quam Chriſtus fundauit eccleſiam, vide quid dicatur à domino: Modicae fidei quare dubitaſti? See what is ſaid of our lord to that greate foundation, and moſt ſure rock of the church, vpon which Chriſt builded his church:Lib. 2 cōt. Eunomiū O thowe of litle faith, why didſt thowe doubte? S Baſile talking, of S. Peter ſaieth: Propter fidei excellētiam, eccleſiae in ſeipſum aedificationem ſuſcepit. For the excellence of his faith,In Ancor. he tooke the building of the church vnto him ſelf: Epiphanius hath theſe wordes: Ipſe dominus conſtituit Petrum primum Apoſtolorum, petram firmam ſuper quam eccleſia Dei aedificata eſt. Our lord him ſelf made Peter chiefe of the Apoſtles the firme and ſure rock, vpon which the church of God was builded. S. Chriſoſtome ſaieth:Homi. 55. in Matth. Chriſtus Petrum vniuerſo terrarum orbi praepoſuit: Chriſt made Peter chiefe ruler ouer all the worlde, and ſaied vnto him: Thowe art Peter, & ſuper te aedificabo eccleſiam meam, and vpon the I will build my church.in Pſal. 103 S. Auguſtine ſaieth: Manducat Petrus, quia Petrus petra, petra eccleſia. Peter eateth becauſe, Peter is the rock,Serm. 26. de ſanctis. and the rock is the church. In another place, he ſaieth: Ye haue heard Peter called, Petram rock oftentymes of our lord, as he hym ſelf ſaieth: Lib. 2. de voca gēt. cap. 9. In cap 16. Matth. Serm de aniuer. Pō tif. aſſum. die. Thoue art Peter and vpon this rock, I will build my church. S. Ambroſe calleth him: Firmiſsimam Petram, the moſt firme and ſure rock, that toke from Chriſt, the principal rock, communion both of vertue, and name. S. Hilarie calleth him, Foelix Eccleſiae fundamentum, the happy foundation of the church: To be ſhort: Leo ſpeaking of S. Peter ſaieth: Tu quoque petra es, thou art alſo a rock which art made ſtronge by my vertue and ſtrenght. S. Hierome ſaieth: Dominus domus Petrus Apoſtolus eſt: Peter the Apoſtle is maſter of the houſe, to
whome God committed his houſe. In cap. Marc. 16. By which it is eaſy to be ſeene that S. Peter was choſen of Chriſt, to be iudg and ruler in his church. Yf any man will argue out of S. Auguſtine as M. Nowel doth, that Chriſt is the rock: and therefore Peter is no rock. I will referre them to M. Dormans diſproufe of M. Nowells reproufe, fol. 189. A, where S. Auguſtines woordes are alleaged to proue that he leaueth the matter indifferēt to the reader and thinketh both opinions true, that Chriſt is the rock, and Peter the rock, ſo apoynted by Chriſt.

Nowe becauſe Chriſte would haue his church continewe for euer, vntil his comming againe, the ſame authoritie and pre-eminence which he gaue to S. Peter,Lib. 2. de ſacerdo. he geueth to S. Peters ſucceſſours as Chriſoſtome witneſſeth: which being moſt vndoubtedly true, it is euident, that neither the word, nor the ſpirite can be iudges in cōtrouerſies as M. Calf. fanſieth, but men that reade the word, men that preache the word, men that vnderſtand the word, and not all men neither, but Apoſtles, Prophetes, Euangeliſtes, Paſtours, and Doctours,Chriſoſt. hom. 44. 23. Matth. whome the holy Ghoſt hath placed, Epiſcopos regere Eccleſiam Dei, Byſſhops to rule the church of God. They muſt be iudges. For they be Clauiculaij, quibus credi tum eſt verbum docendi, & interpretandi ſcripturas. The keybeares, to whome authoritie is geuen to teach the word, and expounde the ſcriptures. They muſt decide controuerſies, but not in euery place, but in the place which God hath choſen, that is in the Catholique church, where the ſpirite ſpeaketh, ruleth, and gouerneth, and out of the which the ſpirite of God doth nor ſpeake, nor rule, nor gouerne, but the ſpirite of errours, and hereſie, the ſpirite of malice, and blaſphemie. wherefor if you will haue M. Calf. the true place where controuerſies muſt be tried, and the true iudges, that muſt iudge thē and determine thē, come to the Catholique church, and to the Biſſhops whome the holy Ghoſt hath apoynted to gouerne his church. And amongeſt them reſort to the higheſt Biſſop that is choſen for the tyme. Remember that S. Cyprian ſaieth: Hereſies haue not ryſen, nor ſchiſmes ſproung of any other occaſion, than of that, that the Prieſt of God is not obeyed, Libro 1. epiſt. 3. nec vnus in eccleſia ad tempus ſacerdos, & ad tempus iudex vice Chriſti cogitatur,
and one Prieſt, for the tyme, and one iudge for the tyme, is not thought vpon in the church in the ſtede of Chriſt. Remember that God ſaieth to you,Mat. 23. doe all whatſoeuer they commande you, as he ſayed to the Iſraelites: Thou ſhalt doe whatſoeuer they ſhal ſay vnto thee, Deut. 17. who rule in the place whome God hath choſen. Remembre that he ſaieth to you: Obey your gouerners, and ſubmitte your ſelues to them, as he ſaied to the Iſraelites: Thou ſhalt followe theyr ſentence and iudgement, thou ſhalt not bowe to the right hand, Hebr. 13. nor to the left hand. Remembre that he ſaieth to you: He that heareth not the church is an heathen, and a Publican, Matt. 18. as he ſaied to them: He that obeyeth not the commaundement of the iudge for the tyme, ſhal dye: And if you haue any grace, obey the order that God hath apoynted in his church, hearken to the voyce of your Lord God, and forſake your priuat examination of doctrine in matters of controuerſies:Fol. 22. b and come to the publique, Fol. 23. a which you memtion, (that is) the cōmō conſent of the church. That muſt be your ankorhold, that muſt be your refuge: The priuate examination is dangerous. Euery one, as he is ful of pride, and ſingularitie, ſo wil he haue his owne way, and his priuate fanſie and ſole opinion to reſte vpon, and falle into diuerſe abſurdities, as you haue done in this anſwer. And to come to the inſtances. Marke good readers.

VVhereas in the very beginning of the firſt Article of my treatiſe, I brefely declared that the woorde (croſſe) ſignified foure thinges in ſcripture, to witte, tribulation, the paſſion of Chriſt, the Croſſe whereon he died, and the material and myſtical ſigne of the Croſſe, and for the firſt referred the readers to the tenth of S. Mathew, ninth of S. Luke, the 8. of S. Marke, for the ſecōd to the firſt of S. Paule, to the Corinthiās and firſt chapiter, and ſixth to the Galathians, for the thirde to the common ſtory of the goſpel, where mention is made howe the Iewes forced Chriſt, and Simon of Cyrene to carry a croſſe to the mounte of Caluarie, for the fourth to the 49. of Eſaie, 4. of Ieremie 9. of Ezechiel, 24. of S. Mathewe, and 7. of S. Iohn in his Apocalipſe,Fol. 24. b. Calf. in commeth this freaſh feloe lyke a luſtie launce-knight, and telleth me that I haue but fewe mē, and in muſtering
thē haue nūbred one ſouldier more then I haue, and like a couetous capitaine intended for a dead paye. Mart. Faine would he ſeeme to haue ſome ſkill in warly affaires, and although he neuer ſtrooke ſtroke in bataill, nor heard the ſounde of trumpet in fielde, yet he talketh like a politicke capitaine that had longe ſerued vnder ſome greate Solymans Baſſa in warre. But if trial be takē of his experiēce, and ſkill in this behalfe, ye ſhall finde hī neither politike capitaine, nor faithful ſouldier. For no man that hath any meane knowledge, or practiſſe in feates of warre, wil ſay vnto his enemie, ſir you haue to fewe men to encounter, leſt he ſend for freaſh ſouldiers and more ayde, and make hym ſelf more ſtrōger. Againe no man wil ſignifie to his enemie that for couetouſnes he retaineth fewer ſouldiers than he ought to doe, or for his owne gayne indenteth for a dead paye, leſt vppon this warnynge he furniſh hym ſelfe better, and prouide that he ſhal haue no aduātage againſt hym. Agayne no faithful ſouldier wil ſtreeke out of his maſters checker booke, any one that ſerueth ſtoutely againſt the enemie, or be aggreued to haue his maſters enſigne, and bannerborne in the fielde: yet ſuch is the wiſdome of this doubty knight, that he hath betrayed hym ſelf in both, declaring his ignorance in the one, and malice in the other Ignorance for that he telleth me, that am his aduerſarie, that I haue fewe men and number one ſouldier more thā I haue, and indent for a dead pay: malice for that he ſtreaketh out of his maſters boke, one truſtie and valiant ſouldier, recorded longe ſithens in the checker rolle. It is an old ſaid ſawe, a litle money is ſone told, the leſſer the nūber, the eaſier is the tale. A fewe ſouldiers are ſone viewed, and the cōpte quicklie kept. VVherefor if (as you ſay) my ſouldiers were fewe, the tale could not be lōg, yf the nūber were but ſmale, the accompt could not be greate.

VVhere you ſay that I indent like a couetous capitaine, for a dead pay (that is) aſke allowaūce for a ſouldier that is not a liue, I muſt tell you, that you miſreporte me like an vncourteous companion. As for my honeſtie, that al my ſouldiers are a liue, my checker boke ſhal beare recorde, and your infidelitie in
denying any ſuch to be extant, ſhal both by the ſame and other ſufficient witnes be controlled. You ſay, neither the materiall nor myſtical croſſe in that ſenſe I take them, Calf. Fol 24 B. Mart. to that end, that I applie them, be once mentioned in ſcripture. Alas ſir what haue the Prophetes, Eſaie, Ieremie, and Ezechiel deſerued, now after ſo manye hundred yeares to be reiected out of the canon? Be not their prophecies ſcripture? Can not you and your companions be content to take away S. Iames epiſtle, the epiſtle to the Hebrues and S. Iudes epiſtle, but will you alſo put thes (the principall and chiefeſt of all the prophetes) in the ſame predicament? ſhall they nowe be compelled to ſeeke a newe harber and be no longer in the canon of ſcripture? yeas ſay you, we admitt them for canonicall ſcripture, Calf. but they make nothing at all for your purpoſe. Mart. Cap. 49. Cap. 4. No ſir? hath not Eſai theſe wordes, Exaltabo ad populos ſignum meum: I will ſet out my ſigne on high to the people? doth not Ieremie ſay, Leuate ſignum in Sion? Lyft vp a ſigne in Sion? Cap. 9. Doth not Ezechiel ſay, or God by the mouthe of Ezechiel: Paſſe through the midſt of the citie, in the midſt of Hieruſalem and ſigne Tau vppon the mens forheads, that moorne, and be ſorie for all the abhominations that are done in the midſt of it? Calf. yeas? Mart. And doth not God by the ſigne that he will exalt to his people, and haue lyfted vp in Sion, meane the ſigne of the croſſe? Calf. no Mart. yeas ſir. And why not my yea, as good as your nay? why may not the ſenſe that I conceaue of theſe places, ſtand as well as that which yow ymagine? Is it not as lawfull for me to abounde in my ſenſe, as it is for you in yours? I ſee no cauſe to the contrarie. I haue to ſupporte me S. Hierome an auncient father, more expert in the ſcripture, and tongues wherein it was written than any of this age. His wordes becauſe the people ſhould not thinke that I ſpoke after my owne fanſie, I recited out of his learned commentaries vppon the ſaied prophetes: you alleage no authoritie but your ymagination, and cite vs a text out of the prophet Eſai, which is not to be founde in ſuch ſort, as you turne it, neither in the Greeke, nor in the Hebrue text adnexed to S. Hieromes commentaries, but in Robert
Steuens, after the tranſlatiō of the Tygurines, allowed by none, but by ſuch ſchiſmatikes as they are. And withall you ioyne a piece of your owne fanſie vnto it, which although as farre as it repugneth not to the rules of faith, it may ſtand, yet not withſtanding, it letteth not, but that the other may be true. For be it, That God anſwering his church cōplayning of ſterilitie, Fol. 38. A and barrēneſſe, ſaied, behold I will lift vp my hand and ſet vp my ſtandard vnto the people, and meant therby, that not only the Iewes, but alſo the gentils ſhould be brought to Chriſt? VVil it followe (as you ſaye) That it was the preaching of the woord that cōuerted the gentils frō errours and ſuperſtitiō? And nothing (ſir) but preaching? were there no miracles done? no ſtraunge ſignes wrought? no extraordinarie vertues and power ſhewed, beſides the word? did not Chriſte hym ſelf ſay of ſome: Vnleſſe ye ſee ſignes and wounders, Cap. 4. Cap. 3. Cap. 6. you will not beleue? Doth not S. Iohn ſay: Many beleaued in his name ſeing his ſignes which he wrought? Doth not the ſame Euangeliſt ſay: A great multitude followed him becauſe they ſawe the ſignes which he did vpon thoſe that were ſicke? did not the Iewes ſay vnto our ſauiour, what ſigne doeſt thow then, that we may ſee, and beleue, what woorkeſt thou? Ibidem. I thinke you being maſter reader haue read theſe textes: And if you haue reade them, I truſt you ſee, there was an other meane to conuert the gentils, beſides the preching of the word.Cap. 6. Againe doth not Salomon ſend vs to the emmot, and Chriſt to the fig tree to learne? I truſt your wiſdome wil not denie it.Mat. 24. Marc. 13. If then Chriſt willed vs to lerne of them, there be other meanes for a man to lerne beſides preaching. And if emonge thoſe, it hath pleaſed the holy Ghoſt to make the ſigne of the croſſe to be one,Fol. 38. A then am not I a falſifier, of the worde, but you a falſe lier before the lorde, ſo to report of me.

Furder where you bid me lerne of you, that preching is the hand of God, that he ſaied he would lyft vp to the gentils, Ibidem. and that the ſtandard which he ſet vp to his people is preching, whereby we are brought to truth, frō blindnes and ignorāce, I tell you in playne termes, that I refuſe ſuch an ignorant maſter.
And preferre S. Hierome before tē hūdred ſuch newe vpſtartes and arrogant heretikes.Eſai. 11. He ſaieth, This hand lyfted vp to the gentils, is the ſame of which this ſelfe ſame Prophete ſpeaketh: There ſhalbe a rote of leſſe, which ſhal riſe vp, that he may be prince of all nations, in him natiōs ſhal hope. And he wil not only lift vp his hand, but alſo exalt, and ſet vp his ſigne. Pſal. 8. there is no doubt, but it is the ſigne of the Croſſe, that it may be fulfilled, which is writen. The earth is ful of his praiſe. Nowe ſir which is the better ſcholemaſter, S. Hierome, or maſter Calfhil? S. Hierome that telleth me, that the hand, that is lifted vp to the gentils, is the rote of leſſe, euen Chriſt hym ſelf, that is preached, or M. Calf. that teacheth that it is preaching. S. Hierome that teacheth that, the ſtādard that God will exalte and ſet vp, is the ſigne or bā ner of the Croſſe, or maſter Calf. that ſaieth it is the preching of the worde, S. Hierome that telleth vs that God of his mercy will ſend vs two thinges, Chriſt ayd his croſſe, or M. Calf. that by a feate of his Arithmetike will make of two but one, and Chriſte and his croſſe, but a bare preaching?

Suerly (ſire) whatſoeuer opinion of lerning, the Alebaſtards, tākerdberers, porters, coblers, and other your auditours haue conceaued of you, I will not acknowledge you for a maſter, more worthy of credit than S. Hierome, nor attribute that to preaching, thereby to exclude the croſſe as you doe, which the prophet, by the iudgement of that learned father, attributed to Chriſt, and his croſſe. VVherefor learne of S. Hierom M. Calf. to make one thīg of the hand, that the Prophet mētioneth, and another thing of the ſtandard: Chriſt of the hand, the Croſſe of the ſtandard,Calf. Fol. 38. a for ſo he teacheth you: but ſay you. The Prophet Eſai in the text before teacheth, that Gods mouth is a ſharpe ſwearde, and that preachinge is a choſen ſhaft, had in the quiuer of the almightie, ād becauſe you thought I would take ſkorne to lerne of you, Mart. you willed me to lerne of God. It is gētly done of you (ſire) you haue preferred me to a good ſcholemaſter. I thanke you for it. I will dayly pray, that I may haue grace to lerne, and faith to beleaue al that he teacheth. But is it true that you ſay, that in the 49. chapiter of Eſay, God ſaieth:
his mouth is a ſharpeſword, and preaching is a choſen ſhaft. In what text ſhal we finde it? In the ſeptuagintes, and tranſlatiō of S. Hierome, ther is no ſuch thing. The woordes that you harpe vppon, I ſuppoſe, are theſe. Ye Ilandes harken vnto me, and take heede ye people that are farre of. The lord hath called me from my byrth and hath remembred my name, euen from my mothers wombe. He hath made my mouth as it were, like a ſharpe ſworde, vnder the ſhadowe of his hande he hath defended me, and hath put me as a choſen arrowe. In his quiuer he hath hid me. Thus farre the prophete. But what is this to preaching? VVhat woord haue you here to ſignifie, that Eſai ſhould meane as you pretēd? Is it ſagitta electa? a choſen arrowe? Suerly if it be ſo, S. Hiero. deceaueth vs. For he ſaieth:In 49. Eſai. Chriſt verelie of many arrowes and many ſonnes, is the only choſen arrowe, and the only begottē ſonne, which he hath hid in his quiuer, that is to ſay, in an humane bodie, that the fulnes of diuinitie might corporallie dwell in him. By which woordes we may lerne, that Chriſt is the choſen arrowe that the ꝓphet ſpeaketh of, and not p̄aching, his humanitie the
qui uer, wherin he was hid in this world, ād not the ſcripture. And if ſaint Hierome had ſaied nothing, the circūſtance of the place dulie examined might haue told yow, that God ſpake there, of the incarnation of Chriſt, and ſending his ſonne into the world to redeme man. But we muſt pardon your ouerſigth, and albeit you haue falſified the ſcripture, in ſaying that to be there which is not there, and vniuſtlie accuſed me for falſe alleaging authorities which are in the places which I quoted, yet will I not deale cruelly with yow here, nor note your errous, ſo deſpite fullye to the world, as you would do myne if yow had like occaſion. But let me frendly aſke you this one queſtion. Did you euer reade S. Hierome vppon this chapiter of Eſaie? If you did euer reade him, then can you not be excuſed of gret ſingularitie and pride, who ſeing the wordes of the prophet to deſcribe the coming of Chriſt, and reading the woordes of that auncient father, expounding Sagittam electam, to be Chriſte, and pharetram, his humaine bodie, would not withſtāding write, and ſet forth in printe to exclude the croſſe, that preaching is a choſen ſhaft, mentioned there, by the prophet, where he ſaieth nothing leſſe.
If the choſen ſhaft be Chriſt as S. Hierome ſaieth, thē can it not be preaching, as you ſay. For Chriſt is one thing, and preaching is another.1. Cor. 1. Chriſt is the thing that is preached (for as ſaint Paule ſaieth: VVe preache Chriſt crucified, preaching the act of man that preacheth, directed by God, yf he preach in the vnitie of his church. If you did neuer reade theſe commentaries (as I beleue you did not) then were you not well adui • ed when vppon ſo ſlipper a grounde, you would build, and proue that S. Hierome did not ſpeake of the ſigne of the croſſe. For ſay you.

p.hi: S. Hierom meaneth there by the enſigne of the croſſe, the ſetting forth of the praiſe of God, which is not by ſetting à croſſe vppon the aulter, but by preaching the crucified.

div.p:
Mart.Mart. You harpe much vppon preachinge, which in deede is an excellent way to ſet foort the praiſe of God, and I truſt it ſhalbe better vſed to his honour and glorie hereafter.Luther. Act. 36. In cōmē. in epiſ. ad Rom Melanel in locis cō. & annot. in Ioan. But as it is vſed amongeſte you, who make hym the authour of euill, ſaying that the traiſon àf Iudas was as well the worke of God, as the conuerſion of Paule, falſe in performing his promiſe, ſayinge that he gaue a piece of bread, when he promiſed his fleaſh: vniuſt in ſaying that he exacteth the obſeruāce, and keeping of his cōmaundemētes which you ſay, are vnpoſsible: not carefull of his church: ſaying it may erre, wheras he promiſed the holy Ghoſt to it, to gouerne • it, to comforte it, and teach it all truth, with many thinges mo, which I may not ſpeake of, beſide your blaſphemies againſt his ſacraments, ſlaunders againſt his vicare on earth: malice againſt his members, and deſire of vengeaunce vttered almoſt in euery ſermon, contradictions among your ſelues in the high myſteries of the faith: thus I ſay as it is vſed amongeſt you, is nothing to ſet forth the praiſe of God. But what? Is there no other meane to ſet forthe praiſe of God, but preaching? Muſt euetie one that wil praiſe God, be a preacher? Then let the huſbandman forſake his plowgh, and bye hym a bible: Let the merchaunt leaue of his trafficke, and leppe vp to the pulpet. Let women geue ouer their buſines, and read leſsōs of diuinitie. May not al the mineſterie ioye in you, ād
thinke that they are ſped of profoūde clearke who can reaſon fo depely againſt the croſſe, and ſay:Fol. 38. b. The ſetting forth of the praiſe of God is by preaching the crucified. Ergo it is not by ſettig the croſſe vppon the aulter? May not we reaſon in like ſorte and ſay: The ſtate of the cōmō weale is preſerued by miniſtring of iuſtice: ergo it is not preſerued by tilling of the grounde? The Citie of London is enriched by merchauntes: ergo it is not enriched by reſorte of gentilmen, ſtraungers and lawyers? Clothing is a relief for the poore: ergo the deuotion and almes of the welthy is no relief for the pore? The honour of the prince is ſette foorth by worthy exploictes in warres abrode: ergo it is not ſet forth by good gouerment in peace at home, with a number as fonde as theſe? Yeas M. Calf. therefor deceaue not your ſelfe. There be many waies to ſet forth the praiſe and glorie of God beſides preaching.Matth. 5.

Chriſt ſpeaketh of good workes in S. Mathewe, and biddeth vs let our light ſo ſhyne before men that they may ſee our good workes, 1. Corin. 6 and glorifie our father which is in heauen. S. Paule biddeth vs glorifie and carye God in our bodies: by which we vnderſtād that the praiſe and glorie of God is ſet forth by external actes, as vertuous life, charitable almes, deuout praier, viſitation of the ſicke, intertayning of ſtraungers, waſhing holy mens feete, chaſt life, pouertie of ſpirite, humilitie of minde, chaſtening of bodie, and ſuch lyke which al men may doe beſides thoſe that preach. Nowe then, ſeing there be more waies to ſet forth the praiſe of God than preaching, amongeſt which it hath pleaſed the auncient fathers to apoynte, and ordaine the ſigne of croſſe to be one, as a meane to excite and ſtire vp that heauy lūpe of earth, that aggreaueth the ſoule, and bring vs to remēber the paſsion of Chriſt, maſter Calf. doth no more ouerthrowe the authoritie of S. Hierome, affirming that it is the ſigne of the croſse, that God ſaied he would exalt and ſet vp to his people, thē he that maketh the reaſons before mē tioned, or any like vnto the ſame, doth ouerthrowe the ſtate of the cōmō weale. For the reaſon is as good in the one as in the other. The next place of ſcripture that he ipugneth and ſaieth maketh no more for the croſſe than for a candelſticke, Fol. 38. b.
is, leuate ſignum in Sion, lyft ye vp a ſigne in Sion. that is as S. Hierome ſaieth: lift vp the ſigne of the croſſe in the toppe of the churche, and what ſhift vſeth this impugner here (thinke you) to ſhift away this place of the prophet and interpretation of S. Hierome?Fol. 39. a. In good ſooth, one as like an heretike as euer you ſawe. God ſaieth he, ſpoke there by an Ironie, that is to ſay, God mockt his people: Agayne, There was no cauſe why S. Hierome ſhould rune to an allegorie: which howe foliſh it is, I had rather other mē ſhuld conceaue, than I declare: for his cōtrolling of S. Hieromes iudgement, for going to an allegorie, he geueth no reaſon why. Such is his inſolencie, and pride to controlle the fathers, and ſet them to ſchole againe. Here would I ſay ſom what of the difference that is betwene S. Hierome, and maſter Calfhil, ſauing I nothing doubt but euerie ſimple ſoule ſeeth, that an old oxe is to be preferred and better eſtemed then a younge calf. But maſter Calfhil ſaieth:Calf. Fol. 39. a. Yf S. Hieromes allegorie ſhould take place, it maketh nothing for your purpoſe, becauſe he talketh there of heretikes, that make battaill againſt the church, and we muſt not fight againſt thē with a croſſe in our hādes. VVherfore the ſigne that he would haue ſet vp in the toppe of the church, is no croſſe, but preachīg of the worde by the prelates.

Mart.In deede if heretikes had that grace and humilitie of ſpirite that they would gladly harken to the prelates of Chriſtes Church, and gently imbrace the truth when it is told them, this impugner had ſaied ſomewhat. But if heretikes are ſo obſtinate and proude, that they contemne al other beſides them ſelues, if they will admitte no other ſenſe, no other interpretation, no other meaning of the ſcripture, than that which they haue conceaued, if they contemne al the auncient fathers, and generall councels, as Arius contemned the fathers of Nice preaching vnto him Iheſus Chriſt to be God, of equal ſubſtance with the father, Macedonius contemned the fathers of Conſtantinople, preaching vnto him the holy Ghoſt to be God, and other heretikes contemne other councells in effect as you do the general councel kept at Nice againſt image breakers, and
that of Florence, and this of Trent now in our daies, preaching vnto you that ther is one ſupreme gouernour in Chriſtes church, and that there be ſeuen ſacraments ordayned of God, for our comfort in this his militant church on earth, if S. Paule willed vs not to contend with heretikes, if the holy fathers not to diſpute with them, becauſe they haue ſuch ſingular cōceites of their wiſdome, that they wil yeld to none, preache he Chriſt and the Ghoſpell neuer ſo much, if it be any thing contrarie to their fanſie, if S. Hierome knewe preaching to be no way to conuince an heretike, (as vndoubtedly he did) then al that maſter Calfhil hath ſaied is not woorth a blewe pointe, and S. Hieromes allegorie, interpreting the ſigne that God would haue lifted vp in Sion, to be the ſigne of the croſſe to be ſet vp in the top of the church, ſtandeth in as good force as it did before.

From thes places he goeth to xxiiii. of S. Mathewe:Fol. 39. b. and to proue that the ſigne of the ſonne of man that ſhal appeare in the cloudes at the later day, is not the croſſe, he brīgeth in a place out of Chriſoſtome in his ſecond expoſition vpon S. Mathewes Ghoſpell. VVhere I beſeeke you note, howe theſe heretikes, for their aduātage father this woorke vpon Chryſoſtom: and when the catholike alleageth any thing out of the ſaied woorke, they denie it vtterly to be his, and for proufe of their allegation bring the cenſure of Eraſ. ſet before the ſaid woorke: which is no indifferēt dealing. For if they wil haue it to be Chriſoſtomes woorke, when they alleage it for their purpoſe, there is no reſon why they ſhould denie it to be Chryſoſtomes, when we alleadge it for ours. If I were diſpoſed to followe their vayne in denying of authours, I could ſay, that were not Chryſoſtomes worke, and bringe his plaine wordes for my purpoſe out of his commētaries vpon S. Mathew which neuer man denied to be his,Homi. 77 where he ſayeth vppon thoſe woordes of the Ghoſpel: Tunc apparebit ſignum filij hominis in coelo: Matt 24 Then the ſigne of the ſonne of man ſhal appeare in the element. Hoc eſt ipſa crux. That is the verie croſſe it ſelf. For the croſſe ſhal be ſeene more brighter than the ſunne. For the ſunne ſhalbe darkened. The croſſe ſhal
appeare. But for what cauſe doth the ſigne appeare, forſooth that the Iewes impudencie may be abundantlie ouerpreſſed, and conuinced. He will come into iudgement hauing his croſſe with him, for declaration of his owne iuſtice and righteouſnes: I coulde repete his wordes in his homilies de Cruce & Latrone, where talking of the ſecōd coming of Chriſt, and inquiring whether, He ſhal come with the croſſe or no, he ſaieth: Heare: Then when he ſhal come, the ſunne ſhal be darkened, then the ſtarres ſhall falle, and the ſigne of the ſonne of man ſhall be ſeene in the element. Thou haſt ſeene the glorie of the ſigne, that is of the croſſe. The light of the ſunne ſhal be made darke. The mone ſhal not haue her bewtie, nor grace, but that light ſhal glitter and ſhine. And like as the prī celie pompe goeth before an Emperour, and the ſouldiers, as they goe before, carrie his flagges and enſeignes vppon their ſhoulders, ſo when our lord ſhal come from heauē, a cōpanie of angels and multitude of archangels ſhal cary that ſigne vpon their ſhoulders, and denounce vnto vs, his royal and princelie comīg. But I wil not vſe that heretical ſhift, and proteſtantes refuge. I will rather examine the authoritie, and conuince him by the ſame.Fol. 39. b. Chryſoſtom as you alleage him (ſir) ſaieth: Some thinke that the croſſe ſhalbe ſhewed in heauen, but it is truer that Chriſt himſelfe ſhal appeare hauing in his bodie the teſtimonies of his paſsion, Hom 49. in Mar. 24 and ſo forth: Theſe be Chriſoſtomes wordes, let it be the truer opiniō (as it is in deede) that Chriſt ſhal come at the later day hauīg in his bodie the ſignes of his paſsiō, what will you inferre vpon it? ergo is the other opiniō falſe? ergo ſhal not the croſſe, the ſigne of the ſonne man appeare at al? Yf yower Logick ſerue you to make ſuch reaſons, then I beſech you tel me, howe holde theſe argumēts? It is truer that the citie of London is welthier than the citie of Briſtowe, ergo the citie of Briſtowe is not welthi. It is truer that M. Ieuel is wiſer than M. Calf. ergo M. Calf. is not wiſe, or if yow wil haue a more familier example. It is truer that an old oxe hath longer hornes than a younge Calf. of xij. moneths old, ergo a younge Calfe of twel moneths old hath no hornes at all? And if yower mymiſtralitie find this but vaine ſophiſtrie, ſo may you think that to be no veritie which you would inferre falſlie, vppon Chryſoſtomes authoritie. If you had remembred yower
Logique rules, you might haue concluded thus: This is truer than that, ergo this is true, and not falſe. As for the other, loke al Ariſtotell, and your Raphe ploweman if ye liſt, yow ſhal neuer be able to make that conſequent good. VVherfore yow had more neede to ſeke yower old Logique rules than I for a fifth ſignification of the croſſe.

Saint Hierome might haue taught yow that either the paſſiō of Chriſt, either the ſigne of the croſſe,In 24. Matth. might be ſignified by thoſe woordes of the Euangeliſte: Tunc apparebit ſignum filij hominis: Then ſhal the ſigne of the ſonne of man appeare. For he ſayeth: Signum hic aut crucis intelligamus, vt iuxta Zachariam videant Iudaei, Cap. 22. quem compunxerunt, aut vexillum victoriae triumphantis. Here we may vnderſtand either the ſigne of the croſſe, that according to Zacharie the Iewes may ſee whome they haue pricked, either the banner of the triumphant victorie. But you would not vouchſafe to reade him. His graue authoritie was to hard meate for your queſie ſtomake. It liketh nothing but woodcocks and capons.

Origen in like manner expounding that place of S. Mathew ſaieth: Then ſhal the ſigne of the ſonne of man appeare, that is to ſay, Homi. 30. in Mat. 24 the vertue whiche the ſonne of man wrought vppon the croſſe, and ſpeciallie his ſigne ſhal glitter in the element, that men of al tribes which before did not beleue Chriſtianitie, that was preached, but ſpoke euil of all, may at that time cumming to knowledg of it, Per ſignum illud manifeſtatum, by that ſigne made manifeſt and open, lament for their ignorance and ſinne, becauſe they did not receaue the woord of God. Here alſo you ſee (ſir) that at that day bothe the vertue of the paſsion, and ſigne alſo ſhal appeare. This notwithſtanding if you cauil, and ſay that this ſigne is Chriſt him ſelfe hauing the ſigne of his paſsion, yet can you not exclude the croſſe, becauſe that was one ſigne, and inſtrument vpon which the other were made. Againe here is mention made but of a ſigne in the ſingular number, Chriſt had may ſignes and woundes, and fyue more notable thā al the reſt, in his handes, in his feete, in his ſide. Then of likeliehoode if the Euangeliſt had ment onlie the ſignes of Chriſtes bodie wounded, he would haue ſaied: Apparebunt ſigna filij hominis, and not, ſignum, the ſignes of the ſonne of man ſhal appeare, and not
the ſigne. Beſides to make Chriſt, the ſonne of God, that then ſhall come in maieſtie, and infinite glorie, a ſigne of the ſonne of man, and not the ſonne of man him ſelfe, is to vile, and baſe a thought for a Chriſtian, and meete for ſuch ſignifiers as ſacramentaries are. But that the ſigne of the croſſe alſo ſhal then appeare,Cap. 3. reade Hippolitus in his oration de cōſummatione mundi. Ephrē in his booke of penance. reade Cirill. Hieroſ oration ad Conſtantium, reade Damaſcen lib. 4. cap. 12. de fide, reade S. Hilarie vppon the 24. of S. Mathewes Ghoſpell, and Theophilact vppon the ſame. VVhoſe woordes to the intent the readers may ſee, that the Euangeliſt ſpoke of the ſigne of the croſſe, I wil recite. In Engliſh they are theſe: Then ſhall the croſſe apeare in the element ſhining aboue the ſunne, to conuince the Iewes. For Chriſt ſhal come againſt the Iewes hauing his croſſe, as a grete matter and teſtimonie to iuſtifie hī ſelfe. As if a mā be ſtrokē with a ſtone, he ſheweth the ſtone with which he was ſtroken: The ſigne he calleth the croſſe, as it were the triumphant banner, and princely ſtandard.

Thus M. Calf. yow ſee by the iudgement of thes auncient fathers, that the ſigne of the ſonne of mā, is the ſigne of the croſſe, that ſhal appeare at the terrible day of iudgment, and that I neede not ſeeke, (as you fondely fanſie) a fyfte ſignification of this woord croſſe. For it may be a material croſſe, and the very ſame that Chriſt died on, yf it pleaſe God. VVe are not ſure of the contrarie. Of what matter his Maieſtie will haue it made, it is vncertayne to vs, but a croſſe he will haue it to be, that is moſt certayne. Diſpute you as long as ye liſt of the one, we wil beleaue the other.

As for that, which you prate againſt the ſigne of Tau, mentioned in Ezechiel, and reuelations of S. Iohn, it is ſo childiſh, that I thinke, the very foole of the midle temple (made miniſter by M. Grindal) would neuer haue preached it on a benche, at an ale bankett, much leſſe haue left it in writing to be ſene. But becauſe euerie merie man maketh much of his bable, and thinketh it a precious thing, I wil vnrippe it, that yow may ſee what baggadge is within it, and be wiſer hereafter.

To proue that the ſigne of Tau with which the people of God
were ſealed in Hieruſalē, did not ſignifie nor expreſſe the croſſe you brīg three reaſons, that ſhal make me bluſh you ſay. But take heede M. Calf. that they caſt not milke in your white weariſh face, and make yow aſhamed. The firſt is this:Calf. Fol. 40. a. The ſpirite of life, and liuelie faith is not inſpired as ſone as a croſſe is figured, ergo the letter Tau of which Ezechiell ſpoke, and ſeale which S. Iohn mētioneth, do not expreſſe the croſſe. The ſecond not much vnlike to the firſt. The ſigne of the croſſe is not ſufficient to diſcerne the good from the bad, the faithful from the infidels, ergo the letter Tau and ſeale that S. Iohn mentioneth doe not expreſſe the croſſe. The third is as bad, as the woorſt of the other. It is this. None were ſealed with Tau but ſuch as moorned for the abhominatiōs of Hieruſalē, none were ſigned but the ſeruantes of God, but all men indifferētly haue the ſigne of the croſſe, many more than be greued with the ſight of ſynne: Therfore the ſeale that in thoſe places is ſpoken of is not the ſigne of the croſſe. Mart. Yow may ſee (good readers) that Logique was harde with him, and euell to be gotten, when he aduiſed to make ſuch conſequentes. But of them hereafter. Nowe to his diuinitie, where he ſayeth that the ſpirite of life, and liuely faith is not inſpired, as ſoone as a croſſe, is figured, vnderſtande ye, that God, who knoweth the ſecretes of mens heartes, and can not be deceaued, comaunded the ſigne Tau (expreſsing playnly the croſſe) to be printed in the foreheades of thoſe that were godly, and lamented the abhominations of Hieruſalem. not purpoſing by that marke ex opere operato, to make men good, that before were badd, (as M. Calf. miſtaketh the matter) or to inſpire a lyuely faith by the nature of that marke into an infidell, without any godly inwarde motion of the perſon, but to the intent that thoſe that were good, and godly in Hieruſalem, before they receaued any ſuch marke in their foreheades, might be knowen by that make to be good and godly, and therby eſcape the plagues that ſhould fall on the citie. So that they were firſt good as the texte is playne, and becauſe
they were good, Tau was figured in their foreheades, and not (as M. Calf. imagineth) to make thē that were before badd to be good.

Baptiſme by the very nature of the ſacrament, is a full, perfet, and ſufficient cauſe, wherby the infante is made from the childe of wrathe, the childe of God, without hauing any propre faith of his owne, or godly motion to haue the ſacrament. VVe neuer taught ſo of the ſigne of the croſſe, that it is able to make euell men good, without they haue godly inwarde motions with faith, hope, and charitie. Marry that it geueth men occaſiō to be good, by calling to remembraunce our ſauiours bitter paſſion, I declared in the ninth article, where I tolde you, what commoditie euery Chriſtian hath, or may haue by the ſigne of the Croſſe.

Matt. 9.16 Mar. 6. Luc. 8.Some men there were that were healed as ſoone as they touched fimbriam veſtimenti eius, the hem of Chriſte his garmēt, ande yet many touched his whole garment, that had no good thereby.Act. 18. S. Paules Napkins did many men good in his abſence, ande yet there were many that tooke no good by them in his preſence.Pſal. 18. Coeli enarrant gloriam Dei. The heauens ſhewe foorth the glorie of God, yet howe many philoſophers were there that denied, ſome God him ſelfe, ſome his prouidence? Chriſt him ſelfe came to ſaue that which was loſte, Matth. 18. 1. Pet. 2. not with ſtanding, he was called the ſtumbling ſtone, ande rocke of offence. Miracles were alſo done, bothe to the confirmation of the faithfull, ande conuerſion of the Gētilles, yet Chriſte vpbrayed certaine cities,Matth. 11. Luc. 10. ande tolde thē, that if miracles had bene wrought in Tyre and Sidon, they would haue done pertaunce. And why did not al theſe worke the vertue for which they were ordayned? The faulte was not in them, but in the lacke of godly motions in the perſons that muſt neceſſarily cōcurre, that the effecte may, by ordinarie courſe be brought to paſſe. They geue great prouocatiōs to men of any good nature to come to a godlie life, but they bring not the thing fullie to paſſe without the cōſent and godly motions of the perſonnes. VVhat then? ſhall we ſaye as M. Calf. ſayeth: That theſe heauens are not of his creation, becauſe
diuerſe looke not vp and conſider the power of God in their creatiō? Shall we denye that Chriſte had any coate, S. Paule any napkinnes, Chriſtes incarnation, the Apoſtles miracles, becauſe they woorke not in all men alyke? The ſcripture it ſelfe worketh not his effecte ſtreighte in all mēnes hartes. Some beleaue, ſome do not. Shall the ſcripture therfore be no longer taken for Gods holy woorde? as M. Calf. denieth the ſigne of Tau, to be the croſſe, becauſe as ſoone as it is figured, it worketh not the ſpirite of life, and lyuely faithe in all perſonnes a like? God forbidd. Many preache the worde of God, and albeit the ſeede taketh no roote, nor any ſpirite or lyuely faithe be inſpired as ſoone as it is ſpokē, yet is it the worde of God. Yf it might haue pleaſed the worſhippe of this profoūde clearcke, to haue looked vpon the prophete, he might haue ſeene, that Tau in that place, made not euel people in the nature of an efficient and ſufficient perfecte cauſe, to be good, but was ſigned in good folkes foreheades, becauſe they were good before. And notwithſtanding there is no mention made in that place of the prophet that the ſigne of the Croſſe (figured by Tau) wrought any godlynes at all in mennes hartes, but was onely commaunded to be ſigned in their foreheades that were good before, yet for as much as it doth continuallie ſet before our eies the memorie of Chriſte, that died vpon the croſſe, it worketh in all heartes a diſpoſition of grace, and as the ſkye dothe, make vs conſider Gods glorie, and all his workes. And wheras God gaue, when Iulianus was feared with ſpirites ſuch force to the ſigne of the croſſe, that the euell ſpirites at the fighte therof departed in haſte, and he might haue had good occaſion to forſake his Apoſtaſie if any grace in the worlde might haue taken place in him, it geueth vs to vnderſtande that albeit the ſpirite of life and liuely faithe is not inſpired, as ſoone as a croſſe is figured, yet is the croſſe of Chriſte, an heauēly marke, and will worke the effectes of grace in vs, if we be otherwiſe apte and meete veſſells to receaue it.

VVhere he ſaieth in his ſeconde reaſon, that the ſigne of the croſſe is not ſufficient to diſcerne the good frome the badd, the
faithfull from the infidells, I will firſt examine the ſufficiencie of this marke Tau, and ſee howe his reaſon hangeth. That Tau imprinted in the foreheades of the people in Hieruſalem was ſufficient to diſcerne the good from the badd, I truſt M. Calf. will not be ſo raſhe as to deny the ſcripture. God gaue it for a ſufficient ſigne at that time to the angell that ſhould ſtrike the citie, to knowe the good from the badd: if it was not ſufficient, then God that tooke it to be ſufficient, was both deceaued him ſelfe, and alſo deceaued the angell. VVheruppon it followeth that the angell ſtroke with the plague as many good as badd. Yf M. Calfs. diſcretion be ſuch that he will driue vs to confeſſe, ſpite of our teathe, that as the ſigne of Tau, at that time in Hieruſalem was a ſufficient marke to diſcerne the good frome the badd, euen ſo that ſame ſigne of Tau muſt be taken for a ſufficient ſigne, to knowe the good frome the badd, at all tymes, in all places, amonge all nations, wheras the ſcripture talketh but of the ſufficiencie of the ſigne, at that ſpeciall tyme, in that ſpeciall place, amonge that ſpeciall people, I muſt be ſo bold as tell M. Calf. that he muſt haue a bell rounge at his eares, to wake him out of his drowſie dreame, that he may learne, that we vſe not to allowe argumētes, from particulars to generalls, nor him ſelfe neither when he is fullie awaked. Yf he do, aſke him howe this argumēt holdethe? M. Calfhill is apointed to reade in Poules, ergo he muſt reade, at all tymes, in all places of the worlde: and with all, deſire him to conferre his owne follie with this, and ſee whether it be not like. I will not preſſe him yet with the doctours that take the ſigne Tau mentioned there to be the ſigne of the croſſe. Let it remayne as it is, to be but the ſigne of Tau. VVill he graunte that as the ſigne of Tau was ſufficient at that time, to diſcerne the good and badd in Hieruſalem, euen ſo that it being marked in mennes foreheades ſhoul be a ſufficient ſigne to knowe the good? Yf not, I muſt knowe why. His anſwere can be no other (if he anſwere wiſely) but that it was a ſufficient ſigne then, at that tyme, place, and amonge that people, becauſe God ſo apointed it, and that it is not a ſufficiēt ſigne in all other places of the worlde to knowe the good, becauſe it
is apointed ſo no where by God. Yf he anſwere thus, as of force he muſte, then hath he anſwered fullie for me, why the croſſe, (meant by Tau (is no ſufficiēt ſigne to knowe the good, becauſe God no where ſo apointed it. For the which I thancke him, and ſignifie with all, that it is a ſufficient ſigne to knowe the bad in all places, in all ages, amonges all nations, if they do but contemne it. For they may well be called inimici crucis Chriſti, Philip. 3. ennemies of the croſſe of Chriſte, and becauſe they refuſe that heauenly marke, ſhalbe in perill of deathe when the deſtroyer cometh.

As for the dependence and ſequele of his argument, it holdeth much after this ſort. The working of miracles is not ſufficient to diſcerne the true Apoſtle frome the falſe, the faithful from the faithleſſe, ergo the working of miracles is not the vertue of the holy Ghoſte, that Chriſte ſpoke of in the Ghoſpell. The laſt argument is ſo fooliſhe that I maruell much that euer M. Calf. would ſuffer it to paſſe his penne. It hathe neither rime nor reaſon, nor mode, nor figure, nor faith, nor truthe. The argument runneth thus: The ſeruātes of God were ſealed which Tau, but many more then be good haue the ſine of Tau, ergo the ſeale that is ſpoken of in this place, is not the ſigne of Tau. Doth not this concluſiō followe as well out of yower premiſſes, as that the ſigne of Tau is not the ſigne of the croſſe? looke well vpon it, and yow ſhall finde them all one. Or if that doe not pleaſe you, take this. Such as are ſaued,M. Calf. by his ovvne reaſon dri • en to foule abſurdities. are ſaued by the death of Chriſte, but Chriſte died for many more then ſhalbe ſaued: ergo it is not Chriſtes deathe by which men be ſaued. So euery way by yower owne reaſon, yow ſhall fall into foule abſurdities, by the firſte to to deny the ſcripture, by the ſeconde the paſſion and death of Chriſte, and yet yow are not aſhamed of it. But yow will I doubte not hereafter, when ye cōſider it better.

Nowe becauſe yow maruell why I cite the ſeuenth chapiter of S. Iohns reuelations, where it is ſaide. Hurte not the lande and ſea, The ſeuenth of the Apoc. examined nor the trees vntill we ſigne the ſeruantes of our lorde God in their foreheades, I will take paynes to examine it for yower furder inſtruction. They are the wordes of the Angell, (that is to ſaye) of our ſauiour Chriſte, to the diuelles, commaunding them not
to hurte, neither the lande, ſea, nor trees, vntill they had ſigned the ſeruantes of God in their foreheades.The land and ſea ſignifie ſynners. By the lande and ſea, ſynners are ſignified, which are vile in cōſideration of their ſynnes cōmitted, and inconſtant and waueringe, in reſpecte of that which they haue done, and will doe. The lande, becauſe it is drye, ſignifieth the couetous, the ſea, becauſe it is moiſte and fometh, expreſſeth the riotous. By the trees, good men are meant,The trees good mē. becauſe they are fruictfull by good workes, and allwayes readie to bringe foorth good fruicte. The euell mē that muſt not be hurte, are thoſe that ſhould conuerte and turne to Chriſte, and perſeuere to the end, albeit at that tyme, they were in darkeneſſe of infidelitie and other wickedneſſe. The hurte inhibited to be done, was both vehement temptations in ſpirite,The hurt inhibited to be done, to the euil. and to the good. and alſo externall dāmage in bodie, which mighte haue bene done, by procuring death, or ſtirring vp hatred and malice proceding to murder. The good men were ſuch as were conuerted allreadie to Chriſte, and cleaued faſt vnto him by faith, loue, and hope, and imitation of his croſſe. The hurte inhibited to be done to theſe, is the mightines of ſpirituall temptatiōs, and perſecutions.The tyme Apoc. 7. The tyme apointed is the tyme vntill they be ſigned, as S. Iohn ſayeth: doe not hurte vntill we ſigne, that is to ſaye, both I my ſelfe, by framing within, the ſigne of faith with the affection of mercye, and power to followe the croſſe, and my miniſtres, by diſpoſing outwardly by doctrine and ſacramentes, by which the ſoule is diſpoſed to the impreſsion of the ſigne of faithe and grace, which is the ſigne of the croſſe, becauſe it cometh frome the croſse, and ſheweth them to be ſeruantes of the croſſe. The place The place where the ſigne muſt be made is the forheade, which is the ſeate of ſhamefaſtnes, and boldnes, and conſtancie, and is taken bothe for the inwarde minde, and externall parte of the bodie. Tvvo kindes of ſealing. VVherfore the ſealing alſo is internall and externall. Internall whē faith and loue in the paſsiō of Chriſte is imprinted in the hearte, and deſire to followe it, and boldneſſe to confeſſe it, and conſtancie to perſeuere in it, is ingraffed in the nimde. The externall printing of this ſeale, is by the Sacramentes, and eſpecially by baptiſme, by which God dothe woorke, and commaundeth to be diſpenſed owtwardlye. In this ſacrament the ſoule is not onely ſealed, but alſo the bodie, becauſe the whole bodie by baptiſme is
dedicated to God, for which cōſideration, the mā is anoynted in the ſhoulders, in the heade and in the breaſt in baptiſme. And on the forehead by the biſſhoppe in confirmation, with Chriſme, and ſigne of the croſſe. Theſe two ſignes are required, becauſe to make a man holde to confeſſe the name of Chriſte, and conſtant to ſuffer aduerſitie, the diſpenſatiō of the ſacramentes by the miniſtres outwardly, is not ſufficient, vnleſſe God inwardly dothe infuſe grace, but whē bothe concurre and meete together, thē is the ſealing perfited. After which ſealing by vertue of the ſigne, which is faith, and grace, and loue of the croſſe in the ſoule, with imitation, and imprintinge of the croſſe in the bodie, the faithfull are more defended from the diuel, than they were before.

Thus yow ſee ſir howe that ſigne which the Euangeliſte mentioneth and ſealinge which he ſpeaketh of, in his reuelatiōs is not onely faith in Chriſte, and loue of the paſsion, but alſo the outwarde ſigne of the croſſe, not onely an impreſsion of grace in the hearte inwardly, but alſo a printing of the croſſe in the bodie owtwardlye. And this is not myne interpretatiō, or opinion. It is his, whome all good men reuerence,8. Tho in Apocalip. whome all learned men wonder at, to whome yf all the proteſtantes in the worlde were compared and laied in a balance, for profounde diuinitie they would apeare lighter then a feather. VVherfore ſeing euery one of theſe fiue places doe ſignifie ād expreſſe the ſigne of the croſſe, and yow in denying thē ſo to doe, denie both the ſcriptures them ſelues, the very propre worde of God, wherof yow vaunte yower ſelfe as peart as a pere munger, and alſo contemne the hoy fathers, Origen, Ephrem, Chryſoſtom, Hilarie, Theophilactus, and Hierome, that be of that minde, what ſhall we thincke not of yower cōtemning the witneſſes of mē, but of yower deniyng the worde of God, not of yower miſreporting the ſayinges of the fathers, but of yower wreaſtinge of the 〈◊〉 ſcripture, not of yower cauilling againſt doctours, but of yower wranglinge againſt the Prophetes, Apoſtles, and Euangeliſtes? Are yow worthie to be taken for a cunnīge M. Carpenter, or a vile botcher, an experte free maſon, or a durtie morter maker? My ſelfe will geue no ſentence, let wiſe men iudge, to them I appeale, to them I call, to their cenſure I
ſubmit my cauſe. Nowe let vs heare what you ſay againſt the fathers. Chriſoſtome liketh yow not: His golden mouth you ſay:Fol. 14. a. Had ledden woordes, and for ſpeaking honorably of the croſſe to the gētils you chardg hī with running to an extreame cō trary. Chryſoſtome. But howe vnmete a goldſmith you are to iudge of Chriſoſtomes golden mouthe, your coper teath and ledden tongue declare. As for running to an extreme contrary, we tell you, that albeit it be a true rule, that Contraria contrarijs curantur: Contraries are cured with their cōtraries, yet as the expert phiſition in tempering his mixtures, vſeth ſuch diſcretiō, that no extreame ſhall diſtēper the bodye: So although that vertuous father, and heauenly phiſitiō Chriſoſtome vſed (as yow ſaye (one contrary to cure an other (that is) highlye commended the ſigne of the croſſe, Fol. 25. a. becauſe the Gentilles reproued it: and thought that he could be no God that woulde ſuffer ſo vile a deathe vpon the Croſſe, to make them embrace Chriſte and his croſſe, yet you muſte not ſuppoſe, that he ſo tempered his talke, that he gaue them ſuch wordes as ſhould infecte their ſoules: and for true relligion (which he profeſſed to teache thē) gaue them euen at the beginning ſuch leſſons as might bring them to errour and ſuperſtition, and by one euill, remedie an other. Let me reaſon with yow after this ſorte. Either it was euill of it ſelfe to commende • the ſigne of the croſſe in ſuch ſorte to the gentills, or it was not. Yf it were euill of it ſelfe, no circumſtāce cā make it good.Rom. 3. N • ither as S. Paule ſayeth: VVe muſt doe euil, that good may come. VVhich S. Chriſoſtome knewe right wel and woulde not a • uenture to fall into the handes God, in ſuch a caſe, hauing other meanes to perſuade, vnleſſe ye will enrolle him amongeſt thoſe of whome the poet ſayde: Stulti dum vitant vitia in contraria currunt. Fooles whiles they auoyde faultes, faulle in to the contrary. Yf it were not euill of it ſelfe, but for circumſtances and conſideratiōs tolerable, then are yow much to blame, for condemning ſo auncient and lerned a father, as Chryſoſtome was, of follye in ſaying that he ranne to an extreame contrary as far in one ſyde, Fol. 25. a as the gentils were on the other.
Yf yower ſpirite had ben Euangelicall, or any thing like vnto theirs who preached Chriſte crucified, and his relligiō and faith vnto vs, you might haue lerned to haue borne with that which you your ſelf graunt to be in ſome reſpecte tollerable. But he that looketh to finde a ſparkle of their mekenes in yow, is as much deceaued, as he that loketh to finde a droppe of water in the flint ſtone. For if there had ben either token of humilitie, ſparkel of honeſtie, or ſigne of Chriſtianitie in yow, that venemous tōgue of yowers would neuer haue ſaid, that the ſigne of the croſſe,Fol. 25. b vpon which it pleaſed Chriſte to worke our redemption, is a magicall inchauntement, a conqueſt againſt Chriſtians, an heathniſhe obſeruance, and ſuperſtition of thē that neuer thought vpon Chriſte: For they be wordes more meeter for a Lucian, a Celſus, a Iulian, an Apoſtata, and enemye of Chriſte, than for one that is redemed with his death vpō the croſſe.Matt. 24. And neuer reade to haue ben vſed of any, but of heathens, turkes, Iewes, or heretikes in theſe our miſerable dayes.

The holy ſcriptures called it, the ſigne of the ſonne of man, the fathers (as I proued it my treatiſe) call it, the ſigne of theCaſsiod. in Pſal. 4. Emperour of heauen, aChriſo. demonſt. ad verſ. gent token of much bleſsing, anPaulinus epiſt. 11 ad Seuer. pledge of eternall ſaluation, a triumphantDamaſc. lib. 4. cap. 12. de fide Chriſoſt. homi. 55. in Matth. banner of victorye, a ſigne ofAmbro. li. 6. ca. 4. de Sacra. vertue, an honorableAuguſt. de viſita. infir. ca. 3. monument, a heauenlyLact. de vera ſapient lib. 4. cap. 27. marke, and immortall ſigne. And nowe in ſteppeth a Iulianiſte, and cō trary to the ſcriptures of God, cōtrary to the teſtimonies of the aunciēt fathers, in deſpite of all Chriſtiās reuileth it, as ye heard before, and which is moſte abhominable of al, in other places of his booke, calleth it, an idoll, a dumbe God, dead diuell, a ſcholemaſter of errour, and impietie. And as though this were not blaſphemous ynough, he likeneth it, to the Gallowes, to the helmet of hell, and coniurers mace. Lyke hearte, like thoughtes, like tongue, like woordes: he that once hath forſaken the vnitie of Chriſtes church, will neuer ſpeake well of his miniſters, croſſe, and ſacramentes. Examples we haue to many in theſe our miſerable dayes, and one to many by this pieuiſhe Iulianiſte: who beſides thes blaſphemies againſte the croſſe, hath not ſpared
as in proceſſe ſhall appeare, the ſainctes in heauen, the Sacraments on earth, and miniſters ordayned of Chriſt to be diſpenſers of his myſteries, vntill his coming againe: whome we had neede to pitie rather thā to hate, ſeing ſo haynouſly he abuſeth the gyftes which he receaued of God, to bleſſe, and not to curſe: to our inſtructiō, that we maye beware of ſuch: to his owne condemnation, vnleſſe he repente.

But be it M. Calf. that yower imagination (which is blaſphemous for any Chriſtiā man to thincke) were true, touching the ſigne of the croſſe. VVas it ſitting for ſuch a ſincere profeſſour of the Ghoſpell, ſuch an experte father in the ſcriptures, ſuch a profounde Bachiler in Diuinitye, as yow pretend yower ſelfe to be, ſo to reuile and raile at it? VVhat ſcripture taught you that? Doe you not reade, that nothing is worſe than the diuell, and yet not with ſtādīg doth not? S. Iude • he Apoſtle tell you, that whē Michael the Archāgell did cōtēd with hī aboute the body of Moyſes, he durſt not, inferre iudiciū blaſphemiae, inferr the iudgement of blaſphemy? But ſaid: Imperet tibi Deus. Let God commaunde the? Doth not the VViſe man tell yow, that: Dum maledicit impius diabolum, Eccle. 21. maledicit ipſe animam ſuam? The vngodly curſeth his owne ſoule while he curſeth the diuell? And could neither the example of the Angel ſparing to curſe, and blaſpheme the diuel, being as fearce as a lyon, and cruell as the dragon againſt vs, teache yow, as it teacheth other men, to beware of blaſpheming? neither the care of yower owne ſoule, ſtaye yow frome railing at the Croſſe, which Procopius callethNiceph. lib 4 cap. 26. hiſto. Eccle. precious, IuſtinianDe ſanctiff. Epiſ. cap. cap. 32. coll. 9. honorable and holye, ConſtantineEuſeb. lib. 3. de vita Cōſt. healthfull, and S. Auguſtine aSer. de cruce & latro. thinge of honour? Is the worde of God forceable to pearce into mens heartes, when you preache, and can it not ſincke into yower owe minde when yow reade it? Yf it be ſo, than may you thincke yow haue a ſtony hearte, and crooked ſoule. But what proofe haue yow for all that which you haue ſaid? In ſo weightie a matter as this is, ſome ſcripture, ſome father, ſome councell, ſome example, ſome auctoritie ſhoulde haue bene alleadged. Shal we beleue yow vpon yower bare worde, or truſte yow vpon yower ſimple credit? Nay ſir, not ſo,
we will haue better triall of yower honeſtie firſte. And albeit in ſome poinctes peraduēture you woulde be a Pythagoras, and credited vpon your bare woorde, yet ſhall yow not haue ſilēce for fyue yeares ſpace, as he had of his ſchollers.

But what if we did graunte yow, that ſome diueliſh and euill diſpoſed perſon abuſed that holy ſigne, in practiſe of witch crafte, ought it therfore of any to be called a Magicall inchantemēt? a Coniurers mace: or ſuch lik? Yf yower wiſdome wil ſerue yow to thincke ſo, by like reaſon ſuch as yow are, may cauill againſte the holy name of God, ſcriptures of Chriſte, and Supper of our lorde, and Pater noſter that we vſe. For that woemen abvſed the name of God to ſorcery, the diuell ſcriptures to euil purpoſe, the Corinthians the ſupper of our lorde,Homil. 21. Cap. 4. other, their Pater noſter to witchecrafte, S. Chryſoſtome declareth in an homelie to the peolpe of Antioche. S. Mathew in his Goſpell. S. Paule in his Epiſtle,1. Cor. 11. and yow yower ſelfe in this anſwere where yow tell vs of a witche,Fol. 2. b. that with her Pater noſter made her payle goe a milking. VVherfore if there be any grace in you, reuoke this, for ſhame, and learne a newe leſſon, that a thing good of it ſelfe, ſhoulde not be ſclandered or taken awaye for the abuſe of a fewe.

Furder that the croſſe was no heathniſh obſeruance,The croſſe no heatheniſh obſeruāce Lib. 2. ad vx. learne of Iulian the Apoſtata your Coſyn, who exꝓbrated the Criſtians, and not the Gētills with hauīg and making of Croſſes, which he would neuer haue done, if the Gentills had had any like cuſtome. Or if you diſdayne to learne of him, learne of Tertullian who tolde his wife, that ſhe ſhoulde geue almes with out trooble, goe to the ſacrifice with out ſcrupule, do her buſines without ſuſpition, ſerue God boldlye, reioyce merilye, and bleſſe her ſelf openlye, if ſhe maried with a Chriſtian after his deathe, but if ſhe maried with an heathe ſhe coulde not do it ſo frelye, which Tertullian woulde neuer haue ſaid, if that practiſe of bleſsing, croſsing, or ſigning had ben practiſed amōge the heathens.Euſeb. lib. 1. de vita Conſtan. Moreouer that is was no conqueſt againſte the Chriſtians learne of Conſtātine the great, who ſaid: By this healthfull ſigne a true token of vertue, I haue deliuered our citie, from the yoke
of the tirant, and made it free, or if yow will diſdaine for the nobilitie of yower perſon to learne of ſo meane an Emperour as Cō ſtantine was, learne of the higheſt, that is lorde of lordes, and kinge of kinges, yea God him ſelfe, who ſhewed that ſigne frome heauen, and ſaid to Conſtantine: In hoc ſigno vince: Ouercome in this ſigne. Lerne of Chriſt who the next night after apeared vnto him, and willed him to make a ſigne like vnto that which he had ſeene, and vſe it in warres. And cōſider with yower ſelfe that God ſhewinge that ſigne frome heauē, woulde neuer haue cauſed the Angell to ſaye: Ouercome in this ſigne, Nor Chriſt apearing to him in a viſion, would haue willed him to make and vſe the like, if it ſhould be a conqueſt againſte vs. For he loueth vs more tenderlye, than that he will ſuffer that ſigne, vpon which he cōquered hell, deathe, and ſynne, to make vs his coheires, to be a cōqueſt againſt vs, and make vs no inheritours. VVith all, learne that the lawes puniſhe ſuch blaſphemers, gladio, fuſte, & cathena, with ſworde, clubb, and chayne. And if you thincke yower ſelfe to ſtande in ſuch ſecuritie, in this world that yow neede not to feare them, yet feare the indignatiō of God, who will puniſhe all iniquitie and ſinne. And if he puniſhed Iulian the Apoſtatats vncle called alſo Iulianus, in the ſecret partes,Socrates lib. 6. c. 10 Tripart. ſo that they rotted, and had woormes engendring in them, and made his mouthe that vſed to blaſpheme God, to be the way and inſtrument of his naturall egeſtion, and excrements, for caſting on the grounde the holy veſſells and palles dedicated to God, and ſitting vpon thē, and piſsinge againſte the holy aulter, and reuiling at Chriſt as it pleaſed him, Yf all his vaynes opened, and bloud iſſued out of his bodye for ſaing ſkornfullye, Beholde in what veſſells the ſonne of Mary is ſerued, Nicep. li. 14. cap. 36 Yf Neſtorius tonge was eaten with wormes, for blaſpheming againſte Chriſt and the virgin Mary, thincke that ſome horrible plague hangeth ouer yower head, either in this worlde to repentance, to ſett yow in ſtate of ſaluation, yf you haue grace to acknowledge it, either to the greater heape of puniſhment into euerlaſting damnation, yf yow continewe and die in it. VVherfore repent in tyme, and do penaunce for this abhominable blaſphemye.Act. 8 Yf perhappes this thoughte of thy hearte may be remitted the.

Yower fanſye in ſaying that the croſſe was a ceremony amō geſt the prieſtes of Serapis: I will differ as yet:Fol. 25. b In the meane ſeaſon I wil diſſcuſſe ij rules that yow bring and procede to the other auctorities that you ſeeme to oppugne,M. Calfs. Rules. Calf. Fol 26. a. Mart. and conferr yower anſwers. The firſte is this: VVhatſoeuer is brought in vnder cloke of good intēt, is not ſtreight waies alloweable. To this I anſwer. Some thinges are brought in by the deuotion of priuate men, in particuler churches, and not auctoriſed generally by the high biſſhope. VVhat ſoeuer they are, they binde not generally, nor are ſtreight waies to be allowed of all men.Concil. 2. Aurel. c. 9 As for example it was brought in, by the biſſhops of Fraunce vpon good intent and deuotion, that none of the clergie ſhould preſume to dwell with the laye people, without the licence of his biſſhop. Itē that none ſhould departe frō Maſſe,Concil. 3. Aure. c. 22 Conc. To let. 4. c. 17 before the lordes prayer had ben ended, and bleſsing geuen of the biſſhop, yf he were there. In Spayne likewiſe the biſſhops brought in vpon good intent and deuotion, that the deacons ſhould communicate before the aulter, the other clerks in the quier, and the people without the quier. Beſides they brought in, that euerie yere, from the Ides of December, they ſhould haue the Litanie, ſounge or ſaid, three dayes together. And diuerſe cuntries haue diuerſe like vnto thes. But becauſe they receaued them, they are not ſtreitwayes allowable. In your churches, you haue brought in the Paraphraſis of Eraſmus, Caluins inſtitutions, to be read as homilies, you haue made and iniunctiō, that prieſtes ſhall not marry vnleſſe the iuſtices of peace take trial of their wyues honeſties before, and ſee whether they be meete woemē for ſuch religious perſons. Theſe nor any ſuch are allowable, as generally receaued, not amongeſt the Swinglians them ſelues. Some thinges are brought in by a common conſent of all Chriſtendome, expreſſed and concluded in generall councells repreſenting the vniuerſall bodye of Chriſtes militant church on earthe. VVhatſoeuer is ordayned, whatſoeuer is determined, and brought in by them, with the cōſent and aſſent of the head biſhop, Chriſtes vicar in earth, that ſtreight wayes is alloweable, that is to be followed of all the humble, and obedient children
of God.Lucae 10. VVhoſoeuer gayneſayeth their decrees deſpiſeth Chriſte, who ſaid, he that deſpiſeth yow deſpiſeth me. VVhoſoeuer heareth not them, muſt be vnto vs, as an Heathen and Publicane. Some thinges haue bene brought in by tradition and cuſtome,Matth. 18 and neuer altered in the Catholike church. As that in conſecrating the bodye and bloude of Chriſt,Clemēs li. 8. ca 17 Apoſt. Inſtitution. Iuſt. Mar. Apol. 2. Cyprian. lib. 2. epi. 3 Ambrol. lib. 5. ca. 1. de Sacra. water ſhould be mingled with wine, that at theChriſo. Ho. 69. ad popul. Antio. dreadfull myſteries, commemoration ſhould be had of the dead, that theBaſil. ca 27. de ſpirit. ſanct. Tertul. de coromil. Fol. 26 a Chriſme and olye be conſecrated, that we ſigne thoſe that are Chriſtened with the ſigne of the croſſe, that we praye towards the eaſte, and bleſſe our ſelues. Theſe are to be allowed becauſe they were neuer altered. Some other haue bene brought in by tradition and cuſtome, yet not generally receaued, as that infantes after baptiſme ſhoulde receaue honye and milke, that children ſhould receaue the ſacrament, and ſuch like, which haue either ben altered by auctoritie of ſuch as Chriſte apointed to be miniſters and gouernours to rule his church, or ſuffred to growe out of vſe by a ſecret diſſent, and lack of vſe. Theſe are not to be allowed, and followed. But the croſſe is none of theſe.

Yower ſeconde rule is this. VVhatſoeuer hath ben vpon good occaſiō receaued once, muſt not neceſſarilye be retayned ſtill. For proufe of this, you bring a decre of pope Stephen, mā gled at yower pleaſure.Diſtin. 63. ca. Quia But of that hereafter when I come to declare youre falſitie in abuſing the fathers: your rule and authoritie we admitt. VVhat will you inferre vpon it? Becauſe thinges once receaued vpon good occaſion may be altered, ſhall it be lawfull for euery iacke ſtrawe, to alter and change, whē and what pleaſeth him? Learne you that by the authoritie that ye alledge out of the decrees? To ſchoole ſir Iames, to ſchoole, and ſpell it a litle better. The wordes of the decrees be theſe. Si nonnulli ex praedeceſſoribus & maioribus noſtris fecerūt aliqua. etc. Yf ſome of our predeceſſours, and elders haue done any thing which at any time coulde be with out offence, and afterwarde be turned into errour and ſuperſtition, lett them with out any more delaye, and with greate authoritie be deſtroyed of them that come after. Here is authoritie geuen to aftercūmers, to abrogate that which their predeceſſours
made, if it growe to errour and ſuperſtition: but who be theſe aftercūmers ſir Iames? Euery pieuiſhe proteſtant? euery laye man that cometh after? VVil yower wit ſerue you to ſay ſo? as you muſt nedes yf you will inferre any thing vpon this for yower purpoſe? then by youer iudgement euery man that cūmeth after, yea the very Tinkers, Coblers poticaries, and pedlers (for you can not exempte them frome the name of after cū mers,) may alter and chāge what ſoeuer their p̄deceſſours haue done. And ſhoulde we not haue a goodlye commō weale if it mighte be lawfull for all men to alter thinges at their pleaſure? But tell me ſir Iames, what was that Stephanus that made the decree which yow recited before? VVas he not pope of Rome? VVere not the predeceſſours and ſorefathers that he ſpeaketh of, the biſhopps that were before him in that ſee? Yf it be ſo,Calf. condēned by the decree vvhich him ſelf allegeth. as (if you deny it,) the decre ſhall controlle yow, and reaſon conuynce you of follye, then muſt it nedes followe, that the aftercūmers, that he ſpeaketh of, were the biſhopes that ſhoulde ordinarilye ſuccede him in that ſee. And not in generall euery one that ſhoulde come after him. So that it is the biſhope of Rome, M. Calf. that muſt abrogate and take awaye whatſoeuer abuſe is crepte into the church, it is he that muſt alter the decrees and Canons of his predeceſſours, if any be growen into errour and ſuperſtition.

Call to yower remembrāce the rule of the lawe that ſayeth,ff. de Reg. Iuris. Nihil tam naturale quàm eodē genere quod
que diſſoluere, quo eſt colligatū. There is nothing ſo naturall as to diſſolue euery thing by the ſame ſorte and kinde as it was knit together: and with all conſider, that as with vs England, when a lawe is eſtabliſhed by a parliament in one kinges dayes, and to be repealed after his death by his ſucceſſours, it can not be done but by an other acte of parliamēt, ſo in like caſe, when a decree is made by a biſhope of Rome, it cā not be altered but by an other biſhope, that ſuccedeth him in the ſame ſee. VVherefore M. Calf. ſeing it hathe bene eſtabliſhed by generall Councells and decrees of the biſhop of Rome that the ſigne of the croſſe ſhould be in churches, and theſe canons and decrees haue neuer bene abrogated
by any of them, it followeth that it ſhoulde be retayned ſtill, vntill the B. of Rome his ſucceſſours, that Pope Stephen meaneth, abrogate it, as erroneous and ſuperſtitious.

VVhere you ſay, that the makīg the ſigne of the croſſe hath bredd ſuch inconuenience that the inwarde faith hath ben vntaughte, Calf. Fol. 26. a. and that the vertue hath bene attributed to the ſigne, which only procedeth frome him which is ſignified, I muſt plainly tell yow,Mart. that yow malitiouſly ſclaunder the catholicke church and affirme more than you ſhal euer be able to proue. For neither hath the faith bē vntaught theſe xv. hundred yeres in Chriſtendome, nor almoſt theſe thouſande yeares in Englande. Nor yet if there hath bene any inconuenience or negligence in the prelates for not preaching, that hath not proceded (as you diſdainfully ſay) of Croſsing. Fol. 26. a. You tell me that, I do putt cauſam pro non cauſa, VVhere I wiſſe, You haue litle cauſe, but howe well you haue kepte your ſhipp frome that rocke and putte, non cauſam pro cauſa lett the worlde iudge. See good people M. Calf. ſaieth:Fol. 26. a. Chriſten men haue vſed to bleſſe and croſſe them ſelues, ergo the inwarde faith hath bē vntaught. In Tertullians tyme the inward faith was vntaught, and why M. Calf? Forſooth Croſsing was ſo much vſed amongeſt Chriſtians, that whenſoeuer they went out, whenſoeuer they came in, whenſoeuer they ſate downe, or did any other thing, they made the ſigne of the croſſe in their forheads.In 9. Ezechiel. In S. Hieromes time, the inward faith was vntaught. For croſsing was ſo much vſed, that the figure of it was printed in mens forheds: Frequenti manus inſcriptione, Ad Euſto. with often inſcription of the hand. Yea S. Hierome him ſelf commaunded, that: ad omnem actum manus pingat crucem. At euery action of ours the hand ſhould make a croſſe: And ſo likewiſe in other ages. O fyne logitioner and profoūde diuine.An imitation of M. Calfs Rhethorique. Fol. 28. a O cūninge argumēt worthie that all the ſchollers may hiſſe out of the ſcholes? VVould a mā haue thought that a Bacchiler of Diuinitie and woorſhipful reader in Paules, could haue made ſo woorſhipful a reaſon? Yf croſsing bred ſuch inconuenience, that it hindred the teaching of inward faith, then
was the faulte in the people, not in the prieſtes, in the laitie, not in the cleargie. For the greater nūber of ſuch Chriſtiās, the more croſsing, the more croſsing, the greater lett to preaching as you ſaye: So ſir, haue you not beſtirred yower ſefe like a pretie clearke? You geue vs as good a reaſon for the hindering of of the inwarde faith, as the old ſage father foole did the gentlemen in Kent for the ſtopping of Sandwiche hauen, ſaying that the hauen neuer proſpered ſithens yonder Tinderden Steeple was builded. May not yower ſuperintendēt M. Grindall much reioyſe, that he hath ſo fine a piece nighe his palace, and geue you leaue to ſett forthe a newe booke without the old priuiledge? But this is nothing to yonder Tynderden ſteple. It is a greate blot in yower eye: I dare ſay yow woulde wiſhe it a fiſhe poole.

VVhere you chardge vs that we attribute to the ſigne, Fol. 26. a Calf. Mart. the vertue which procedeth frome him, which it ſignified, I muſt tell yow that you haue eares and will not heare, eies and will not ſee, a litle wit and wil not vnderſtāde. For if youer eares had not bene deafe, eies blinde, and witte willfull, yow mighte haue hearde, ſeene, and vnderſtode, that nothing is attributed, to the ſigne without ſpeciall relation to the merites of Chriſtes paſsion, no effecte mentioned to haue bene done by the croſſe, but in the vertue of Chriſtes death ſuffred full bitterlye vpon the croſſe. VVhich clauſe I did purpoſly put in at the latter end of the firſt article, to take awaye occaſion of cauilling frome all ſuch wranglers as yow ſhewe yower ſelfe, to be.M. Calf. but a vvragler. And ſurely if you did reade that clauſe before, you can not eſcape the blemiſh of willfull malice, for chardging me with that errour, ſaying that I left out that ſentence of Chriſoſtome, vellē ſcire a pagano etc. I woulde heare of the pagane howe it cometh to paſſe that the ſigne of ſo curſed deathe is ſo to be deſired, niſi magna crucifixi virtus, Fol. 26. b. if it be not the greate power of him that was crucified, becauſe I would proue the ſigne it ſelfe, without relation to the merites and vertue of Chriſtes paſs • on, to be a token of much bleſsing. The contrary, to conuince yow,
is there to be ſeene, Euery one that hath eies to ſee, and cūning to reade, may perceaue it. Yf you did not reade that clauſe before you framed this anſwer, then ranne yow as far on the other ſide in to the note of ignorance and folly, for aduentring to make anſwer before you vnderſtande what is the queſtion, and meaning of him that doth propounde it. For as the VViſe man ſaieth:Prouer. 18 He that anſwereth before he heareth, ſheweth himſelfe to be a foole and woorthie of confuſion.

Calf. Fol. 40. bBut you aſke me, why I bring the example of Iulian the Apoſtata and ſaye, that man vſing only the ſigne of the Croſſe, putteth away all the crafte and ſubtiltye of the diuell, yf I attribute nothing to the ſigne but by relatiō to the merites of Chriſtes paſsion? Mart. Here belike yower wit was a wolle gathering, when you deuiſed to moue this queſtion, or youer capacitie eſtranged with ſome fonde fanſie when you conceaued it. For anſwer, I might referre you to the hiſtorie, but ſeeing a thing once tolde can not ſincke into ſuch a witteleſſe head, I will tell it you once againe. I brought that ſtory, to expreſſe the great and mightie vertue of the croſſe, which being made by the wicked Tyrant, and Apoſtata, of it ſelfe, through the power and force, that Chriſt by his paſsion gaue vnto it, put the wicked ſpirites to flight. There was no vertue, no merite, nor faith in Iulian, yet he draue the diuells away by the ſigne of the croſſe,Chriſoſt. de monſt. contra gentil. and why by the ſigne of the croſſe? Niſi quia magna crucifixi virtus, but becauſe the power of the crucified is greate? And that triumphant banner of his victory terrible vnto them, and the very printing of it in the forheade, ſuch a terrour, that they durſt not abide, which argueth that it hath vertue ſpecially of the merites of Chriſtes death. And if I had omitted the latter clauſe in my firſt article, yet the gentle, and charitable reader might haue cō ceaued ſo much of this hiſtorie, if not of this, yet of the other ſentence that I alleaged out of Athanaſius, where I ſignifie that Athanaſius, declaring how before the cumming of Chriſte, diuells miſerablie afflicted men, and how when Chriſte was come, they were diſcomfited and ouerthrowne, ſaid, Signo crucis
tantum vtens homo omnes horum fallacias pellit. Atha. de humanit. ver • i. Man vſing only the ſigne of the croſſe, putteth away all their ſubtiltie and crafte. For I declared there out of Athanaſius (whoſe name M. Calf. ſuppreſſeth, leaſt the reader ſhould reuerence his authoritie) that the ſubtility of the diuell is driuen away by the ſigne of the croſſe, after the death of Chriſt, which argueth, that there is a relation made to Chriſtes cumming and death, vpon the croſſe. And becauſe it ſhould moſt manifeſtly apeare, I cited an other ſentence out of Athanaſius in the ſame place, where it is ſaid: that if one vſe the ſigne of the croſſe, Chriſtum ſolummodo nominans, naming only Chriſte, all the diuells be put to flighte. VVhich alſo might haue geuen yow to vnderſtand that nothing is attributed to the ſigne but by relation to the vertue and power of the crucified.

VVherfore ſeing croſsing hath bredd no ſuch inconuenience, that the inwarde faith hath bene left vntaught, ſeeing the vertue proper to the crucified, hath neuer bene atttibuted to the ſigne, the ſigne may remaine ſtill, and Chriſte that is ſignified, may be ſimply preached not withſtanding, as he hath euer bene amongeſt the Catholikes.

VVhere you ſaye, that thes wordes of Chriſoſtom, Calf. Fol. 26. b hoc mortē ſuſtulit, hoc inferni oereas portas cōfregit, This tooke away death, this broke the braſen gates of hell, conuince, that Chryſoſtome meaneth not, that Chriſte, who hāged vpon the Croſſe, made the croſſe and ſigne therof to be of more vertue, becauſe no materiall thinge, no piece of wood nor ſigne did worke that effecte, nor conquer death and hell, Mart.

VVe muſt deſire yow to make a Comment vpon theſe wordes, and at the next edition with priuiledg, according to the Quenes Maieſties iniunctions, expounde to whome this worde of the comparatyue degree (more) hath his relation & what you meane by it. Ad as (more) muſt inferre a than, ſo whē yow tell vs, what that (thā) is, then ſhall you haue an awnſwer to yower than. In the meane ſeaſon, the worlde may ſee that you meane deceithfullye that will not vtter yower mīde plainlye. You take much paynes, & bringe certaine places of ſcripture
to proue that it was Chriſte, Calf. Fol 26. b Mart. and not the Croſſe that redemed and ſaued vs. I pray you what waltams caulfe did euer denye that, or thincke the contrarye?
