And yet what wiſe man did euer ſay, that Chriſt did redeeme vs otherwiſe thē by his death vpon the Croſſe, o • r vſed that as an inſtrument other wiſe, than to worke our ſaluation, or made that ſigne healthfull and comfortable, otherwiſe than by the merite of his paſſion? Yf you haue any mathematicall imagination in youer idle brayne, or melancholie fanſie in yower wauering head, conſult with ſome aſtronomers, that may reſolue the one, and drincke ſome Elleborum that may expell the other. For I thincke there was neuer man that had more nede.

Now to your anſwer againſt the authoritie of Martialis. Firſt you will haue him to be none of the 72. Fol. 27. a Calf. diſciples, one reaſon which you bringe, is becauſe Euſebius ſaieth, the regeſter of 72. diſciples is founde in no place, An other, that Hieronimus Gēnadius, and Iſidorus neuer made mētion of him▪ which had bene a greate ouerſight, if his auncientie had ben ſuch as I pretend. Mart. M. Calfs reaſons againſt the authoritie of Martialis ſoluted. To the firſt I reply, that Euſebius in the place which you quote, that is, lib. 1. cap. 12. hath no ſuch thinge. And if he had, yet doth it make nothing for youer purpoſe. For Euſebius in the proheme declareth that he gathered his hiſtorie out of diuerſe mēs workes, wich were confuſely written, ſome in this cuntrey, ſo me in that, and thought that he ſhould ſufficiently pleaſe, and gratifie his proſteritie, if he gathered together and regeſtred in order, the ſucceſſours of the cheifeſt Apoſtles of our ſauiour Chriſte in the moſte famous churches, if he did not ſhewe forth all. VVherby it is playne that albeit he compiled his ſtorye out of diuerſe Chronicles, yet he had not all the writinges, all the monumentes, all the Chronicles of all men, and all cuntries, and all thinges that were written and done in all ages, to his tyme, fithens Chriſte was incarnate. Many thinges might righte well eſcape his handes, and paſſe his knowledg as well appeareth by his wordes rehearſed before. To the ſeconde I anſwer in like manner, that albeit S. Hierome, Gennadius, and Iſidorus made bookes
of Eccleſiaſticall writers, yet this might paſſe their knowledge, and yet no ouerſighte cōmitted. For it is not poſsible for euery man to ſee euery thing, nor to haue information, or by mouth or by monument of all that was done before, ſearche he neuer ſo narrowly. Many bookes and monumentes of the fathers are brought to light nowe, that then were hidden, and many hiddē nowe that then were knowen, as all that be expert in the eccleſiaſticall hiſtories may righte well ſee. VVherfor it is a childiſh parte of you M. Calf. to deny ſo auncient an author and inferre vpon the authoritie of Euſebius and S. Hierome and others negatiuely, as (if you inferr any thinge againſt the forſaide authour) you muſte of neceſsitie inferre this, Euſebius ſaieth the regeſter of the 72. diſciples is founde in non place, ergo Martialis was none of the 72. diſciples: and ſo cōſequently there were no ſuch diſciples. S. Hierome, Gennadius, and Iſidorus writing the liues of eccleſiaſticall writers, make no mention of the foreſaide authour, ergo there was none ſuch. Certes if yower diuinitie ſhould chaunce to faile, and you fortune to become a portpannier, or pedler, and ſell Sophiſtrie, the verieſt idiote in the cuntrey that knoweth a B frō a beetle, will not geue twoe lepps of an olde dogg, for x. ounces of the beſt that you carye in al your panniers. Nowe to his wordes.

VVheere that holy father ſayeth,Calf. Fol. 27. a The croſſe of our lorde is an invincible armour againſt Sathan etc. it pleaſeth his maiſterſhip to ſay that if this may be rightly vnderſtande according to the letter, we neede not greatly ſtand in dreade of Sathan, he is eaſely vanquiſſhed, we neede no furder armour, thā the croſſe. Let Chriſt alone. This Mars ſhal ſuffice. Mart. But Alas (ſir) where is youer witt become, where is your profounde ſight in diuinitie? Is all gone? It ſhould ſeme ſo by yower clerkly anſwers. For no man that hath witt and comon ſenſe, would reaſon as you do. To ſhewe youre fondneſſe plainlye, Tell me I beſeche you,Marc. 16. Is it not true according to the letter that Chriſte ouercame the worlde and the diuell, and that whoſoeuer beleueth and is baptized, ſhalbe ſaued? Is it not true according to the letter, that whoſoeuer
eateth the fleſhe of the ſonne of man, Ioan 6. according to Chriſtes inſtitution, ſhall haue life euerlaſtinge? Is not all this true according to the letter? And this not withſtanding haue we not neede to feare, and fighte againſte the diuel? Doth not S. Paule ſaye vnto vs,Ephe. 6. Be ſtronge in our lorde, and in the mightines of his power, put on the armour of God, that you may be able to ſtand againſt the aſſaultes and priuie waightes of the diuel? 1. Cap. 5. Doth not S. Peter bidde vs to be ſobre and watch becauſe our aduerſarye the diuell goeth aboute like a roring lion ſeeking whome he may deuoure, and reſiſt him being ſtronge in faith? Luc. 21. Doth not our ſauiour him ſelfe commaunde vs to take heede to our ſelues, and to be ware of ſurfeting, and drunckennes, and cares of this worlde? Dothe he no • bidd vs watch and praye allwayes, that we may be worthy to auoyde the thinges that are to come, and ſtande before the ſonne of man? I truſte yower Maiſterſhip will not deny it. As then ſir, by thes places of ſcripture, not withſtāding it be true according to the letter, that Chriſte hath cōquered Sathā, that baptiſme waſſheth away our ſynnes, that the fleſh of the ſonne of man geueth vs life, we haue cōmaundement to putt on the armour of God, to be ſtronge in faith, to be ſober, to be ware of ſurfeting, and drunckenneſſe, and cares of the worlde, to watche and praye, and fighte ſtoutelye againſt the diuell, Niſi enim quis legitimè certauerit non coronabitur, 2. Tim. 2. for vnleſſe a man fighte luſtely, he ſhall not be crowned: Euen ſo albeit according to the letter it be true, that as Martialis ſaieth, The croſſe of our lorde is an inuincible armour againſt Sathan etc. and by the mightie poure of Chriſte and merites of his paſsion, a ſworde not ſuffring iniquitie ād ghoſtly aſſaultes of peruerſe power to approche vnto vs, Yet haue we neede to feare the diuel, and vſe againſt him all the meanes we cā to auoyde his aſſaultes, and priuie waightes. For he is a mightie enemye, and of greate power, and when we fighte againſt him,Ephe. 6. Iob 7. we fighte not againſte fleſhe and bloude, nor againſte one only, but againſt powers. Beſides our life is a warrfare vpon earth, and as longe as we are militantes, ſo longe haue we neede to playe the valiant ſouldiers, and exerciſe our ſelues to fight, that whē the enemye inuadeth, we may put on the armour of God, ſpread our lordes banner, againſte him, and encounter māfully.
And if in fighte we fortune to take a foile, or vtterly be ouercū med, the faulte is in our daſterdnes, and not in our weapon. For as S. Paule ſaieth. The weapons of our warfare are not carnall, 2. Cor. 10. But mightie in God, to the deſtruction and ouerthrowing of all munition and defence, made againſte them.

Furder conſider howe the authour calleth it, the croſſe of our lorde, which wordes geue vs to vnderſtande, that we muſt be Chriſtes ſeruantes in holynes of life, and not bonde ſlaues in vilenes of ſynne, lyuely membres of his myſticall bodye, and not rotten bowes ſeuered from the vnitie of his church, Children ſeruing him in ſpirite and truth, and not ſtrāgers following our owne appetite, in ſenſualitie and hereſie: Otherwiſe neither this croſſe that is here mentioned, nor the paſsion of Chriſt it ſelfe, ſhall ſaue vs frome the terrible thraldome of the diuell, not that either the croſſe through the vertue of Chriſte his paſsiō, either the death of our ſauiour it ſelfe is vnable to ſaue vs, but becauſe we throughe our iniquitie and ſynne are not worthy of ſo greate grace, and benefite.

But quoth M. Calf. Behemoth and Leuiathan (that is the diuells againſt whome we muſt fight) are of an other manner of force, none dare come nere them, none can reſiſte them, Calf. Fol. 27. a the ſworde ſhall neuer touche them, the ſpeare yealdeth to thē.

But beleue him good people no furder then yow ſee him.Mart. The ſcripture falſified. For in the 40. chapiter of Iob which he alleageth for his ꝓofe, there is no ſuch thing in the texte of S. Hieroms tranſlation, but the contrarie rather is there to be ſeene. For God ſayeth, pone manum tuam ſuper eum, lay thy hande vpon him. To lay hande vpō him, is as S. Gregorie there ſayeth, virtutis poteſtate ſuperare, to ouer come him with poure of vertue, not of thy owne, but of God, who repreſſing his crueltye, ſuffreth him to rage no more than is expedient, and turneth his fearcenes into the commoditie of the electe and choſen. And if M. Calf. vrge his owne ſaying to be true,Mat 12 Marc. 7 aſke him whether our ſauiour Chriſte, when he commanded dumbe and deafe diuells to departe from the bodies which they poſſeſſed, and expelled whole legions, and made them go into the piggs,Matth. 8. when
he ſpoiled the pouers of the ayre,Matt. 8. Luc. 8. Coloſſ 2. and brought them foorth in opē ſhewe, aſke him I ſay, whether he did not, or durſt not come nigh the diuell? Aſke him againe whether S. Paule came not nigh the diuell when he expelled him out of a mayden at Philippis a citie in Macedonia? Acto. 16. Aſke him whether Chriſtes diſciples came not nigh the diuells, when they expelled them, and ſaied:Luc. 10. O lorde yea the diuells are ſubiect vnto vs in thy name? And if he deny it, tell him he denieth Chriſte, and his Goſpell.

Fol. 27. aAgaine where he ſaieth: that no man can reſiſt them, that is the diuels. Aſke him whether Chriſte gaue not his Apoſtles vertue and power to caſt out diuells? Mar 3. Luc 9. Aſke him whether Chriſt ſaied not, that they that beleue, in my name ſhall caſt out diuells? and if he tell yow that Chriſte gaue his Apoſtles, and faithfull beleuers ſuch authoritie, and power, then tell him againe that the diuell is not ſo terrible,Cap. 4. but that he maye be reſiſted. For S. Iames ſaieth: Reſiſt the diuell and he will flee away frome yow: VVithal tell him I beſeche you, that it is a great ſhame for him, and a foule ſclaunder for the Goſpell, to bringe in any ſuch opinion, and falſifie the worde of God, to mainteine ſuch a newe and wicked hereſie. The next wordes that followe, as M. Calf. alleageth are theſe:Fol. 27. a They eſteme yron as ſtrawe. and braſſe as rotten wood: But reade as longe as ye liſte, ye ſhall neuer finde them in the 40. chapiter of Iob, as it is quoted in the margent of his booke, wherfore deſire him to amend it, at the nexte impreſſion. In dede ſuch like wordes are readd in the 41. chapiter of Iob. But nott altogether as M. Calf. citeth them. S. Hieroms tranſlation hath it thus: Reputabit enim quaſi paleas ferrum, & quaſi lignum putridum as. For he ſhall eſteme yron as ſtrawe, and braſſe as rotten wood. And as S. Gregorie interpreteth them, they are ſpoken of the diuell that ſhall beare the ſweay when Antichriſte cummeth: His force ſhalbe ſuch, that he ſhall eſteme yron as ſtrawe, that is, He ſhall conſume with the fire of his wickednes, the poure and ſtrenght of thoſe that preache, vnleſſe the grace of God doth aſsiſt them. He ſhall repute braſſe as rottē woodde, that is to ſaye, he ſhall bringe into duſt the conſtancye of the patient and long ſuffring, vnleſſe God doth defend thē.
The other ſenſe, that M. Calf. like an euill gloſer ſaieth, that none ſhall dare come nere him, or that none can reſiſte hym, Fol. 27. a is contrary to the ſaying of S. Iames, contrary to the Ghoſpell, and Chriſte him ſelfe. VVherfore iudge of him (good readers) accordinglye, and thincke whether he be worthy to be a preacher amongeſt the people of God, who is ſo good a proctour for the deuil. My ſelfe will ſay nothing, but wiſhe him grace to repent for his fondnes, in tyme.

Nowe to his anſwer againſt the place brought out of Damaſcene,Damaſc. Fol. 27. b Calf. whome like a graue iuſticer he will not diſcredite but excuſe, although he be not ſo ſounde in all pointes as was to be wiſſhed. But marke I pray yow haue wiſely he doth it,Mart. theſe are his wordes: He lyued in the tyme of Leo Iſauricus, Calf. when the blouddye bickering was for images: then Sathan be ſtirred him ſelfe. Then was it no maruell if a man learned and godly other wiſe were caried away with the common errour. Here is his excuſe, Damaſcene was lerned, but he yealded to errour, and that not obſcure or doubtfull, but cōmō, Mart. ſuch as all men knewe, he was godly, but he was caried awaye with the worlde, learning yealded to errour, godlines to vnſtableneſſe, which is not likely to be true. For the learned mā, being a godly man (as Damaſcene was) will neuer yeld to an errour, if he knowe it to be an errour, nor the godly man if his hearte be fixed in the lawe of God,Epheſ. 4. Rom. 8. wilbe caried away with euery winde, of newe doctrine, that maketh againſt his glorye. For what ſaieth S. Paule, Shall ſeparate vs frome the loue of God? Shall tribulation perſecution, or the ſworde do it? No: VVherfore if Damaſcene yealded to a common errour, he was not learned, and godly, if he was lerned and godly he yelded not to a cōmon errour. Againe if he was caried awaye with the ſwea of the worlde, he was not godly, and if he were godly, he was not caried away with the ſwea of the worlde. So that M. Calf. muſte graunte his owne excuſe to be fonde, and imploye a kinde of cōtradiction, or acknowledge that either Damaſcene was not lerned and godly otherwiſe, or that he neither yealded nor was caried
away with a common errour. For both can not ſtande. Yet he pleaſeth him ſelfe well with this cōceite, and ſhifteth away his reaſon with as vnreaſonable talke, as euer mā hearde. For wheras that father ſaid: that the croſſe is geuen vs as a ſigne vpon our foreheads, like as circūciſion was to the Iſraelites, by this we Chriſten men differ, and are diſcerned frome infidels, This is our ſheilde, our weapō, our bā ner and victory agaīſt the diuell, this is the marke that the deſtroyer touche vs not, nay it cā not be ſo (quoth M. Calf.) for Lactātius ſayeth: The bloud of a beaſte had not ſuch power in it as to ſaue men: Calf. Fol. 28. a therfore the ſigne of the croſſe is neither ſheilde, nor weapon, nor victorie of ours. Mart. This is as good reaſon as if ſome royſter had ſaid, my mans ſhadowe can not kepe a knawe from my heade, ergo my mans buckler or ſworde is no defence of myne. For that the bloud of the lambe ſpringled vpō the poſtes of the children of Iſraells dores,Lib. 4 cap. 26. de vera Sapient. was but a ſhadowe, Lactantius in the place that M. Calf. alleageth, doth plainly ſhewe. But it liked not his lerning to tell vs ſo much, nor yet howe he tooke the midle of a ſentēce, and left out the beginnīg, and ending, which is no vnwonted thing with birdes of that fether.

Lactant. not truly alleaged. Lactantius there, treateth of the myſterye and pouer of our lordes croſſe, and of the ſignificatiō of thoſe thinges which Chriſt did, or ſuffred, and how he was prefigured by the paſcall lambe. And amongeſt the reſt he declareth why he ſtreacht out his handes, and ſaieth. Chriſte therfore ſtreacth out his handes in his paſsion and meaſured the worlde, that he might thē declare that a mightie people ſhoulde come vnder his winges, and receaue in their foreheades, ſignum illud maximum & ſublime, that moſte greate and honorable ſigne, The figure of which, the Iewes do nowe repreſent, when they ſpringle their doore poſtes with the bloud of the lambe. For whē God was ready to plague the Egiptians, that he might preſerue the children of Iſraell from that plague, Exod. 12. he commaūded them to kill a lambe with out ſpott, and ſett a ſigne with the bloud of that, vpon their dore poſtes, whervpon when all the firſt begotten of the Aegiptians were deſtroyed in one night, Haebrei ſolo ſigno ſanguinis tuti fuerunt, non quia cruor pecudis tantam in ſe vim gerebat vt hominibus ſaluti eſſet, ſed imago fuerat rerum futurarum, etc. The Iſraelittis onlye were ſafe, hy the ſigne of the bloud, not becauſe the
bloud of a beaſt had ſuch force, in it that it could be a ſafegarde to mē, but it was a ſhadowe of thinges, to come. For the white lambe with out ſpott was Chriſte, that is to ſay innocent, and iuſt and holy, which being offred vp in ſacrifice of the ſame iewes, is a ſafegard and ſaluation to all which haue written the ſigne of bloud, that is the ſigne of the Croſſe vpon which he ſhedd his bloud, in their foreheades. For the forheade is the hieſt dore poſte of man, and the wood which was ſprinckled with bloud is a ſignificatiō of the Croſſe. Thus muche Lactantius, by which yow ſee that the bloud of the lābe ſpringled vpon the dore poſtes in Aegipt, was a ſhadowe, and that it ſignified the croſſe of Chriſte, and not his paſsion only, but the croſſe, qua ſanguinem fudit, vpon which he ſhedd his bloud, the ſigne of which Croſſe, all men that come vnder the winges of Chriſte muſt receaue in their foreheades. The bloud of the lambe ſpringled at that tyme vpon the dore poſtes was vaileable in a figure, to keepe all that had it, frome daunger of the deſtroyer, not of it ſelfe, but becauſe God did ſo ordaine it, that it might apeare how much the truth it, ſelfe ſhoulde auaile to defend the people of God, in the latter and extreame neceſsitie of the worlde. This alſo Lactantius writeth in the foreſaid place, and in the nexte chapiter treateth of the power of the ſigne of the Croſſe, and declareth how terrible it is vnto diuells, which M. Calf. omitteth. But that men may ſee how he taketh a piece of an authour and ſnatcheth all morſells to ſerue his hungrie appetite, and letteth the reſt goe, and neuer dothe reſpect the mīde of the authour, I wil repeate you ſome of his wordes that followe in the very next chapiter. Thus he ſaiethe.Lib. 4. ca. 27. de vera ſapien. Nowe it is ſufficient to declare the power of this ſigne what it is albe to doe. VVhat a great terrour this ſigne is vnto the diuells, he ſhall knowe, who ſeeth howe when they are coniured by Chriſte, they flee out of the bodies which they poſſeſſed. Lactant. iudgment of the croſſe. For as our ſauiour hīſelfe when he lyued amongeſt men, did putt all diuells to flight with his worde, and did quiet mens mindes that were diſtracted, and ſett in rage by their wicked incurſions: Euen ſo at this preſent, thoſe that followe him, dryue out of men the ſame wicked ſpirittes, & nomine magiſtri ſui, & ſigno paſsionis, both with the name of their maiſter, and ſigne of the paſsion, of the which thinge there is eaſy proofe. For when the gentills offer ſacrifice to their Gods, if any man ſtande by, that hath his forehead ſigned, they
offer vp no ſacrifice. Againe when certayne of our ſeruantes ſtoode by their maiſters, while they were ſacrificing, by making of the Croſſe vpon their foreheades, they put the diuells to flight, ſo that they could not deſcribe in the bowells of their beaſtes, what thinges were to come: Thus yow ſee what Lactantius minde was of the croſſe, and that the ſigne is ſuch a terrour to wicked ſpirites, that they vaniſhe awaye as ſoone as they ſee the figure of it. VVherfore not withſtandinge M. Calfhills halfe mangled ſentēce alleadged out of Lactantius, it is true that Damaſcene writeth, that the croſſe is our ſheilde, our weapon, our banner, and victorie againſt the diuell, and that his anſwer to Damaſcene, is not worthe a rotten Damſon, although he much reioyſeth in it, as maye appeare by the great triumphe and exclamation which he maketh by and by vpon it, becauſe I ſaid that the effectes afore rehearſed were done by the death of Chriſte eſpecially, and by the ſigne of the croſſe as an external meane, and vſed for proofe of it, this ſimilitude: As mē not withſtanding the merites of Chriſtes paſsion muſt receaue the ſacramentes: So fighters againſt the violent aſſaultes, of Sathan, muſt vſe beſides the faith in Chriſtes paſsion, the outwarde ſigne of the croſſe. In which ſimilitude, I make my proportion and likenes betwene the paſsion of Chriſte redeming and ſauing vs, and the ſacramentes concurring as external meanes in the one ſide, and betwene the faithe of a Chriſtian man to fight againſt temptations, and the ſigne of the croſſe, concurring as an owtwarde ayde in the other ſide, that as the ſoule fighteth on her parte, ſo the bodie which is but a lumpe of earth, and hath no faith may alſo fighte with a bodely armour, and doe his endeuour on his parte, as the minde prayeth, the tongue ſpeaketh, the hearte beleueth, the mouth confeſſeth, the ſoule laboreth in heauen, the hande worketh in earthe. Nowe cometh M. Calf. inuerting my wordes and manner of ſpeache, and maketh me ſay thus:Fol. 28. a Calf. The ſacramentes muſt concurre with faith, ergo the ſigne of the croſſe with Chriſte. VVhich is quite contrary to that I ſaid,Mart. and not to be gathered of my wordes. For I am not ignorant, that infantes although they haue no actuall faith, be ſaued by the ſacrament of baptiſme, nor that Chriſt is vnable
to ſaue vs without the Croſſe:M. Calf. dealeth vvith vs as Celſus did vvith the Chriſtians. • i 7 cōt. Celſum. Fol. 1 • b VVherfore this wrangler may well be compared to Celſus that Origen had to do with all, who woulde attribute thoſe woordes to the Chriſtians which they neuer ſpake, as apeareth by his woordes where he ſayeth, after this: Celſus ſhewinge forthe in many woordes thoſe thinges which we neuer ſpake, yet for all that he bringeth them forthe as though we had ſpokē them. VVhich is a ſory ſhifte, but conſider his argumēt, this it is.

Notwithſtanding God his power that geueth encreaſe I muſt eate my meate, ergo notwithſtanding my labour, wherby I may ſustayne my ſelfe, I muſt couet my neighbours goods: here be iiij. partes, as in mine rehearſed before, Chriſtes power geuing encreaſe, meate nouriſhing, labour purchaſing, couetouſnes deſiring other mens goods: But the proportion is not like, eſpecially betwene labour and couetouſnes, and faith and the croſſe: For labour is commaunded, couetouſnes contrary to the precept, but faith and the croſſe are bothe commaunded: faith by the expreſſe worde of Chriſt, the croſſe by tradition,2. Theſſ. 2. Cap. 17. de Spir. ſan. Epheſ. 6. which S. Paule commaundeth vs to kepe, and S. Baſil doth in a ſorte equalle with the ſcripture. Beſides I am commaunded by S. Paule to be ſtronge in the mightines of Gods power? Yf thē gods power be not tied to this, or that, but is infinite, and ſhewed many and ſundry waies (of the which the ſigne of the Croſſe through the merite of Chriſtes paſsion is one) as apeareth by the ſtrange and greate miracles, which it pleaſed his maieſtie to worke by it, why may not euery Chriſten man vpon affiance of Gods mercye and goodnes, accompte him ſelfſtronge againſt the diuell, with this ſigne, as one of the inſtruments, wherby the mightynes of Gods power is ſhewed? Chriſt ſaide to Conſtātine:Euſebius lib de vita Conſtan. Chriſoſt. demonſt. ad verſus gent. In hoc ſigno vince, ouercome in this ſigne. The holy Ghoſt by the holy fathers and prelates of the churche, tell vs that this ſigne is a terrour to wicked ſpirits, and bridle to contrarye powers. The ſtories of antiquitie and practiſe of this p̄ſent time, declare the ſame. And why ſhould we not beleue them? Marry it is forbidde quoth M. Calf. As couetouſnes and luſting after other mens goods is. Fol. 28. b. Yf it be ſo ſir, ſhewe vs that negatiue commaundement, or
ſome ſentence, ſome clauſe of the expreſſe worde of God, that doth prohibite mē, to croſſe them ſelues, as we can ſhewe you, many places, in which the other is expreſſly forbidden. Yf you can not doe it, (as I am ſure yow can not,) vnleſſe yow haue ſome texte newly forged at Geneua or framed at Tygurie, which our forefathers neuer knewe, then reuoke yower raſhe ſentence, in ſaying that it is forbidden in the expreſſe worde of God. For it is no where to be ſeene. VVithal be aſhamed of yower blaſphemy in ſetting the croſſe againſt couetouſnes, and luſting after other mens goods: and bluſhe at yower lurde and Calfehiſh ignoraunce in making my wordes to be ſpoken by way of compariſon, which are ſpooken by a ſimilitude.

My ſelfe becauſe yow haue not learned yet, what difference there is betwene a compariſon and a ſimilitude, would haue taken paynes to haue expreſt it vnto yow, but that I perceaue, yow haue conceaued ſuch a maieſtie of yower owne perſon, ſuch truſt in yower vntruthes that you will diſdayne to be taught of an olde vſher of VVincheſter. Therfere I remitte you to youer Doctour Radolphe.Li. 1. ca. 24 Lerne of him whether yow haue done well in calling that a compariſon. Yf a man ſhould ſaye. As euery ſcholler that is deſirous to profite in ſtudie, muſt haue beſides the benefit of capacitie, memorie, and witt, a maſter to inſtructe him, and bookes to occupye him ſelfe with all: Euen ſo euery ſouldier that will gladly gett the victorye of his enemy, muſt haue beſides ſtoutnes of hearte, actiuitie of body, and ſkill of warre, harnes to defende him, victualls to nourriſhe him, and weapon to inuade his enemye, would yow make of it a compariſon or a ſimilitude? Yf according to yower rules of logicke, and Rh •• orike, yow finde it a ſimilitude, rather than a com ••
〈…〉
• ry out like a Calf. againſt yower ſelfe and vſe yower 〈◊〉
••• clamatiō. O blinde ignorāce that coul, de not knowe a ſimilitude from a compariſon. VVoulde a man-haue thoughte that a M. of Arte,M. Calfs Rhetorique. Fol 28. a Fol. 18. b a bacheler of diuinitye, a reader of Poules, coulde with hereſie haue forgotten logicke, Rhetoricke, and humanitie? You, blame me as though: I compared thinges vtterly vnlike, of the which the one can not inferre
the other. But I tell yow that it is ſome Melancholy fanſie, or phrenetike paſsion in yow, to thincke ſo. For the wordes of which you gather that, importe no ſuch thinge.

VVhere you tell me,Fol 28 b that ſacramentes haue a promiſſe annexed vnto them, I praye yow be ſo good maſter vnto vs as finde out by yower Geneuian doctrine, where in all the ſcripture, there is any promiſſe made, to bread and wyne. Yf yow cā ſhewe vs none, what ſhall we thincke of yower ſchiſmaticall communion miniſtred by your diſordred miniſtres, which is nothing ells but bread and wine according to your doctrine? Sacrament it can be none, becauſe it hath no promiſſe annexed vnto it. And if it be no ſacrament, what impudencye is there in yow, to force men vnto it vnder the name of a ſacrament, and to publiſhe to the worlde in yower Apologie, that you haue twoe ſacramentes in yower church, baptiſme and the Euchariſte? VVheras euery ſacrament hauing a ꝓmiſe, and bread and wyne (which is yower communion) hauing no promiſe,The communiō no ſacramēt by M. Calfs doctrine. it muſt nedes followe by yower owne rule, that it is no ſacramēt at all, and that you haue but one only ſacrament. VVherfore if you be rigorous to condemne the croſſe becauſe it hath no promiſſe in expreſſe ſcripture, we will condemne yower communion of bread and wine, for the ſame defaulte.

As for the rock which yow ſay yow paſſe ouer like an vnſkilfull mariner ſtriking yower helme againſte it, that Sacraments are no cauſe of grace, I would likewiſe paſſe it ouer,Fol. 28. b but that it is too dangerouſe for all that paſſe, through this ſea. For that Sacramentes are no cauſe of grace, neither ſcripture, nor auncient father taught, neither Chriſten man beleaued.ſacramēts cauſes of grace. Iudge yower ſelfe. Is it not a greete grace to haue remiſsion of our ſynnes? to be iuſtified, and to haue Chriſt with in vs? be not all theſe greate graces, and is not the ſacramēt of baptiſme cauſe of all this? Reade the ſcriptures, doth not S. Peter ſaye: Doe penance, and let euery one be baptiſed in remiſsiō of ſynnes? Dot not Chriſt ſaye VVhoſoeuer beleueth and is baptiſed ſhalbe ſaued? Doth not S. Paule tell vs, that: All ye that are baptiſed in Chriſte, haue put on Chriſte? Againe is it not a greate grace to haue the holie Ghoſte? And
read yow not in the Actes of the Apoſtles,Act. 8. that they by impoſition of handes gaue the holie Ghoſte? Doth not S. Paule ſaye vnto Timothe For which cauſe I exhorte thee that thou reſuſcitate and ſtirre vp the grace which is in thee by the impoſition of my handes? 2. Tim. 1. Doth he not ſaye to him in his other epiſtle. Deſpiſe not the grace which is in the, which is geuen thee by prophecy with the impoſition of handes of prieſthoode? And what other true cōſtruction can you make of this, but that the holy Ghoſte (which is no ſmalle grace) is geuen by impoſitiō of handes, bothe in the Sacrament of Confirmation, and orders? Examine the wordes of the Actes, and S. Paule in his epiſtle. In the Actes it is ſaide: The holy Ghoſt was geuen by the impoſition of handes: In S. Paule, reſuſcitate and ſtirre vp the grace which is in the, by the impoſition of my hādes: neglect not the grace which is in the, Cap. 4. which is geuen thee by prophecie, by the impoſition of handes? VVhat plainer woordes can you haue? See you not that one ſayeth, that the holy Ghoſte, and the other that grace was geuē by impoſition of handes? And yet will you ſaye that Sacramētes are no cauſe of grace? VVhat colour or gloſe haue yow to illude thes wordes of the ſcriptures? VVill yow ſaye (as yow doe by the fathers) that the Apoſtles and Euangeliſtes, yea and our Sauiour him ſelfe:Fol. 29. b meant better than they wrote, and borrowed impropre phraſes of the common ſpeache ſuch as ſeemed to mayntayne an errour, and ouerſhot thē ſelues in their termes? And where they ſaid, by baptiſme, Chriſte is put on vs, remiſſion of ſynnes is geuen vs, and the holy Ghoſte and grace is geuen by impoſition of handes, will you corrupte the texte, and ſay: By baptiſme Chriſte is ſignified to be put on vs, Remiſsion of ſynnes is ſignified to be geuen vs? The holy Ghoſte and graces are ſignified to be beſtowed vpon vs: And for a truth will yow geue vs a figure? Yf this be lawfull by yower newe Ghoſpell, what aſſurance ſhall we haue of our Chriſtianitie? what hope, but that, when thinges ſhalbe ripe according to yower owne appetite,2. Cor. 4. Coll 1. yow will not ſaye with S. Paule: Chriſt is the image of God, nor with S. Iohn: Verbum caro factum eſt: The worde is made fleſh: But Chriſte ſignifieth the image of God, the worde is ſignified to be made fleſhe? You haue begonne pretely allredy, by
interpreting thoſe wordes of Chriſte: Hoc eſt corpus meum: Matt. 26. This doth ſignifie my body. For this is my bodie, and certes great doubte leſt you will procede furder. For in hereſy there is no ſtay.

VVhere yow ſaye,Calf. Fol. 28. That in the ſacramentes the only promiſes of God by Chriſte, bothe by worde and ſigne are exhibited vnto vs, which promiſes yf we apprehend by faith, then is the grace encreaſed in vs, and the gifte of God by faith receaued, is by the ſacrament ſealed in vs: I beſeke you tell vs,Martial. whē the thing it ſelf, (that is to ſaye) remiſsiō of ſynnes, and other graces are geuen vs, if the only promiſes of Chriſte are exhibited in the ſacramentes? and lett vs vnderſtande in what tyme of our life we ſhall receue them? For it is a neceſſarie matter for vs, and worthy to be knowen. For if we apprehende the promiſes of God neuer ſo much by faith, and lacke the thing by our owne follye, there ſhall no grace effectuallye encreaſe in vs, to euerlaſtinge life, as Chriſte him ſelfe ſayeth.

Vnleſſe a man be borne againe of water and the holy ghoſte, he can not enter into the kingedome of heauen. Againe if grace doth not increaſe,Ioan. 3. nor the gifte of God (which is ſpecially remiſsion of ſynnes) be not ſealed in vs, before we apprehēde the promiſes of God by faith, in what caſe will you putt infantes, that haue no actuail faith? In what caſe will you putt the ignorantes, that haue nether witt, nor vnderſtanding to apprehende the promiſes of God? Shall they be exempted frome the kingedome of heauen? Shall they be imbarred of the merites of Chriſtes paſsion? And where as all that are baptiſed in Chriſte, haue put on Chriſte, and by baptiſme receaue remiſsion of ſynnes, and ſo are made the children of God into euerlaſting life, will you take vpō you to eſtrange them frome the mercy of Chriſte, becauſe, for lacke of age, witt, and vnderſtanding, they can not by faith apprehēde the promiſes of God by Chriſte? It is to vnmercifull.Fol 28. b Calf. Yet ſo you doe, for you ſaye, that when we haue apprehended the promiſes of God by faithe, then is the grace increaſed in vs, Mart. then the gift of God by faithe receaued, is ſealed by the ſacramēt in vs? Yf it be then receaued and ſealed in vs, M. Calf, and not before,
then you exclude all infantes frome eternall ſaluation in Chriſte. Yf it be ſigned and ſealed before, then are yow very ignorant in ſaying, that the only promiſes of God are exhibited vnto vs in the ſacramentes, and that they be no cauſes of grace: And while yow profeſſe to teach me true doctrine, by the way, yow runne lyke a wanton Calfe out of the waye, and fall into an olde hereſie of our newe frendes the wicked Anabaptiſtes, lately ſcoured by yower doctor that died (as the fame goeth) of the lowſy euell at Geneua:Caluine. for which fondnes I will wiſhe yow, neither wringe by the eares, nor wincheſter rode, nor butchers beetle, but a criſtall glaſſe to ſee yower errours and hereſies, and grace to reuoke them and amend.

VVhen you had done with this digreſsion and wittely talked (as you conceaue) of ſignes and ſeales, and promiſes, exhibited in the ſacraments, yow returne to the croſſe, and tell vs, that if there were ſuch neceſsitie in the croſſe to fighte agaīſt Sathan, Fol. 28 b Calf. Peter and Paule were fooles: Peter for not ſaying, reſistite crucis ſigno, reſiſte withe the ſigne of the croſſe, but fide ſolida, with a ſtrong faith, when he gaue aduiſe to reſiſte the aduerſarie. Paule for forgetting that piece of defence, whē he furniſhed a Chriſtian man with his complete harneſſe.

Mart.Here you are to be noted of much ignorance and follye, both for not vnderſtanding that which yow take vpon yow to confute: And alſo for iudging ſo raſhly and fondly of the bleſſed Apoſtles. Touching the firſt that there is any abſolute neceſsitie, to vſe a croſſe in fight againſt the diuell, I neuer taughte in all my booke, nor do I teache, that the auncient fathers commaunded, but counſeled men to vſe the ſigne of the croſſe, in their conflicte againſt the diuell. Reade the fifte Article and ſee whether you be not lurdely deceaued, in thincking that the Catholikes do make it a matter of neceſsitie, as you would ſeme to make the ſimple and ignorante beleaue: and call to remembraunce that lawe of Iuſtinian the Emperour, Inciuile eſt niſi tota lege perſpecta, de aliqua parte reſpondere It is an vncourteous pointe to anſwer vnleſſe all the whole lawe be well conſidered. Concerning
the ſecōde. Yf it had bene a matter of neceſsitie, yet had there bene no follye in S. Peter, nor ouerſight in S. Paule in omitting it. For bothe S. Peter writing twoe epiſtles, and S. Paule diuerſe, to the Romaynes, to the Galathians, to the Epheſians, to the Philippians, to the Coloſsians, to the Theſſalonians, to Timothie, to Tite, and Philemon, omitted a more neceſſarie matter then a croſſe. For in all thoſe epiſtles, there is no commaū dement, nor counſell geuen to celebrate the ſupper of our lorde in remembrance of his death, there is no mētion made that the ſonne is of equall ſubſtance with the father, nor of the proceding of the holy Ghoſte, which are matters of importance, and neceſſarie to ſaluation, not withſtanding they were no fooles as M. Calf. woulde make thē, for omittīge of it. They had the holy Ghoſt teacher of all truth to guide their hartes, and direct their pennes. They knewe what was expedient to be tolde at that time, and to thoſe men.

Our ſauiour being here on earth did not ſhewe his Apoſtles all that was behoofull for thē to knowe, at that tyme, but ſaide: I haue many thinges to ſaye vnto you, but you can not beare them nowe, Ioan. 16. you ſhall knowe them hereafter. Nowe becauſe our ſauiour Chriſt being preſent with his diſciples, and opeaning the ſcriptures and ſecret myſteries vnto them, did not tell them all at ones, will M. Calfs. wit ſerue hī to thincke, that, a folly in Chriſt? I doubte much: he is ſo fotted in follye, and infatuated with hereſie, that to maintayne his fooliſhe fantaſye, and to make ſome reſemblance to the worlde, he paſſeth not to ſtreatche a poynt. It is a ſmale matter with him to corrupte and falſifie the ſcriptures, he repeated but iij. wordes out of S. Peters epiſtle,1. Pet. 5. and one of the thre is falſified. For whereas S. Peter teaching vs to reſiſte the diuell, ſaid (as the olde tranſlation hathe) Reſiſte ſortes in fide, and as Eraſmus tranſlateth it: Reſiſtite 〈◊〉 fide ſolidi: 1. Pet. 5. Doe ye reſiſte being ſtronge in faith: Maiſter Calfhill ſaieth: Reſiſtite fide ſolida: Reſiſt with ſtedfaſt faith,M. Calf. altereth the vvoordes of S. Peter. turning the nominatiue caſe into the ablatiue, and alteringe the ſubſtantiue to the adiectiue. Contrary to the common texte of the Greke copye, and contrarye to the common edition, and tranſlation of Eraſmus, who was ten hundred
degrees better ſeene in greeke than this prating parrat. S. Peter willed vs to be ſtronge in faith, and to ioyne vnto our faith ſobrietie, which cōtayneth faſting, and to vſe watchinge, which includeth prayer (as apeareth by his wordes going immediatly before,) for that he knewe our aduerſarie to be ſtrōge as a lyon, and diuerſe of that ſorte, that they can not be caſt out and conquered,Marc 9. Niſi in oratione et ieiunio, but in prayer ād fasting: Diuerſe may haue a ſtedfaſt faith, yet not be ſtronge in faith. For to be ſtrōge in faithe is to beleue vnfainedlye, in the ſonne of God, to loue him aboue all thinges, and ſo to cleue vnto him, that no aduerſitie, no tribulation, nor feare of death may alienate our mindes from him, which grace euery mā hath not, that hath a ſtedfaſte faith.1. Cor. 13. For (as it apeareth by S. Paule,) ſome may haue ſo ſtedfaſte a faith, that they may transfer moūtaynes, diſtribute their goods vnto the poore, and geue their bodies to the fire to be burned, and yet haue no charitie, which is the moſt cheifeſt and neceſſarie thing, that is required in him that wilbe ſtronge in faith.

VVherfore ſeing he ſticketh not to alter the woordes of ſcripture and falſifie them, to forge ſuch a ſenſe as liketh his fooliſh fantaſie, there is no great doubte to be made, but that he will venture vpon higher matters if time ripe thinges according to his imagination.

The bleſſed Martir Hippolitus in his oration made de conſummatione mundi, ſaieth that Antichriſte ſhall geue vnto all thē that will followe him, a character, or marke in the right hande, and forehead, that no man may printe with his hande, that preciouſe croſſe in his forehead: frome which time forwarde he ſhalbe albe to ſigne no parte of his bodye, In 13. Apocal. but ſhall cleaue faſte to the deceauer. In which ſenſe S. Ambroſe alſo writeth theſe wordes, It may be that as we haue a character or marke of Chriſte, (that is the croſſe, with which we are ſigned: So Antichriſte may haue a peculier character and Marke, with which they that beleue in him ſhalbe marked. The marke and ſeale which he ſhall geue in their righte handes and foreheades is Calculus a Coūter with thes letters,Antichriſtes Mark.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . and this worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Id eſt nego, I denye, (as Hippolitus ſuppoſeth). And as the diuell, by his miniſters cried vnto the bleſſed martirs, Negato Deū
tuū crucifixū, deny thy God crucified, ſo euery one that hath this ſeale, and marke of Antichriſte ſhall ſay. I deny the creatour of heauen and earthe, I deny my baptiſme, I deny the adoratiō and honour whih I was wonte to geue vnto God, which wordes I repeate here for this purpoſe, that you (good readers) may conſider, whether Sathan by the doinges of heretikes and practiſes of proteſtantes, in theſe latter dayes, and declination of the worlde, beginne not to prepare a waye for Antichriſte. Doe yow not ſee how they ſtand vpon the negatiue and cry all, Nego, I deny:Heretikes reſemble Antichriſt by their Negatiues. That is to ſaye, I deny that there is any externall ſacrifice, in the churche, I deny that Chriſtes body and bloud is really and ſubſtantially in the ſacramēt? I deny that there be ſeuen ſacraments? I deny that there is any prieſthoode? I deny that there is any prayer for the deade? I deny that Sainctes are to be called vpon? I deny that good workes are meritorious? I deny that a man may ſay Maſſe vnleſſe he haue ſome to cōmunicate with hī? I deny that there is any power in earth to remitte ſynnes? VVith a great many thinges moe? Doe you not ſee M. Calf. as though he had Antichriſtes counter and marke in his hande, and foreheade alredy, denyīg all that is mētioned befor? and ſayīg furder? I denye that the ſigne of the croſſe is mētioned in ſcripture? I deny that Chriſten men ſhoulde make it in their foreheades? I deny that they ſhoulde haue it in churches? I deny that it is able in a Chriſten mā to reſiſte temptations? I deny that the ſinceritie of Gods worde was preached thes xiiij. hundred yeares before Luther and Caluins tyme? I deny that the auncient fathers mente as they wrote? I deny that they vnderſtoode the worde of God? I deny that the generall Councells had the holy ghoſte? with many thinges beſides, as ſhall apeare in proceſſe? And to what end is all this denied? See the ſubtilitie of the diuell, he knoweth that if he ſhoulde plainly ſaye vnto men, deny God: they woulde defye him. Againe if the externall ſacrifice and ſacraments ſhoulde continewe in their force, and prieſtes be ſuffred to offer that holy ſacrifice vnto God the father, and the olde relligion be ſuffred to remayne, he knoweth (I ſaye) that God ſhoulde be honoured, and acknowledged in the power of his maieſtie, and
his owne kingedome be diminiſhed. VVherfore he goeth craftely to worke, and like a ſubtill ſophiſter kepeth priuie his concluſion, that when he hath made men deny the externall ſacrifice, ſacramēts, and prieſthood, and ſuch like, he may vrge them by their owne grauntes to conclude, ergo there is no God. For if there be a God, he is to be honoured, as he him ſelfe ſayethe, Yf I be your father where is my honour? Mala. 1. Yf he muſt be honoured, it muſt be chiefely with an externall ſacrifice, as Abel, Abraham, Melchiſedech, and Iob and the children of Iſraell did, and as he him ſelfe by thoſe wordes of the prophet Malachie:Malac. 1. A cleane ſacrifice ſhalbe offred to my name, ſaide it ſhould be frome the Eaſt to the weſt. VVhich ſacrifice can not be vnderſtode properly and principallie of prayer, or of the the ſacrifice of the hearte, becauſe no man can ſaye:Prouer. 20 My hearte is cleane, I am pure frome ſynne. And if there be no ſacrifice there can be no God. So vpon one inconueniēce graunted, he inferreth many and triumpheth ouer men, when he hath ſeduced them.

VVhen he hath thus made them deny God the father, then he practiſeth an other way to make them deny God the ſonne, and that is,Tract. in 1. Ioa. Ser. 33 de verbis Apoſt. (as S. Auguſtine ſayeth) by breaking of vnitie, by tearing the body of Chriſte, by ſchiſme, by renting and ſwelling againſt his ſpouſe the church: An other is by taking awaye the externall ſignes, that may printe the memorie of his death and paſsion, in our heartes, and continewe the memory of it in our mindes by often ſeing of it, and bringing men to contempte of that vnder pretence of Idolatrie. Amōgeſt which the ſigne of the croſſe is one, as the auncient fathers recorde. VVherfore beware of him, yeld not to his ſuggeſtion, but knocke his heade againſt the rocke, VVhich is Chriſte Ieſus, who by his death vpō the croſſe, gotte the victorie ouer him, and made that ſigne ſo terrible vnto thē,Quaeſt. 38. ad Antio. that whenſoeuer they ſee it: they tremble and flee away, and are miſerably tormēted, as Athanaſius writeth in his xxx. and eight queſtion to Antiochus. In quoting of which place if the printers hande failed, miſtaking one figure for an other, and ſet 9. for 8. it was not ſuch a matter of importance, that required a reprehenſion with a marginall note. A gentle reader if he could not finde
in it one place, would haue ſought it in in an other, and haue aſcribed the errour to the negligence of the printer, not to any ouerſight of the authour. But you may ſee that M. Calf. had rather playe ſmale game than ſit out. And whereas he can ſay nothing iuſtly agaīſt the doctrine, he cauilleth chilediſhlye againſt the miſſe quoting of the place. In which tripp if I take him hereafter, and note howe falſely he quoteth his places, beare with me gentle reader, and impute it to his folly who miniſtred occaſion, and vpbrayed me firſte with ouerſight in that, wherin he him ſelfe hath, full often fayled, as ſhall apeare in the chapiter of his falſe quotations. In the meane ſeaſon, heare his wiſe anſweres to the place of Athanaſius, one is this:Fol 29 a Calf. VVe haue no more the croſſe on which our ſaluation was wrought, then we haue the aſſe on which Chriſt rode, therfore the diuells be not afrayed of the ſigne of the croſſe:

And is not this a farre fett concluſion, fondly deuiſed,Mart. Argumēts like M Calfhils of Chriſtes Aſſe. and euill fauoredly compariſed? and good for nothinge? Myght he not as well haue ſaid, we haue no more the tables that God gaue to Moyſes, than we haue the fyre wherin he apeared: ergo they be not the lawes of God that men be afraied to breake.

VVe haue no more the copies of Dauid pſalmes written with his owne hande, than we haue his ſlinge wherewith he killed Goliath, ergo the diuells be not afrayde of the wordes of the pſalmes. VVe haue no more the melodie that Dauid made before Saule, then we haue the harpe that he played on, ergo melodie is not good againſte melancholye. VVe haue no more the epiſtles that S. Paule wrote with his hand to the Romaines, then we haue his horſe that he rode vpon to Damaſcus: ergo the diuells coniured with wordes of that epiſtle, be not dryuen awaye? The conſequent is like, and followeth euen as well as the firſte, (that is) ſtarke ſtaring noughte. For as we haue not the notes of Dauid pſalmes ſonge before Saule, nor the firſt copies or the originals of S. Paules epiſtles ſent to the Romaynes, but the like melodye as good as that was againſt Melancholye paſſions, and ap •• terne of Dauids pſalmes, which being reade,Homi. 20. in Ioſue. yea of them that do not vnderſtande them as Origen ſayeth, make
the diuells afrayde, and the copies of S. Paules epiſtles, the wordes wherof haue as much force nowe as they had then, being vſed of a Chriſtiā with faith and callīg vpō the name of chriſte: Euē ſo albeit we haue not the croſſe in all places, on which our ſaluation was wrought, yet haue we the type, the figure and likenes of the ſame croſſe, which by the merites of Chriſtes paſſion, is as terrible at this preſent to all wicked ſpirits, as it was then.Euthymiꝰ Titul 19. part. 2. Panopliae Ea gratia quae ſemel in prototypo fuit efficax etc. The ſame grace which was ones effectuous in the firſt ſampler proceding alſo with like efficacie to very figures and ſignes of the croſſe. Nor Athanaſius talketh of that ſpeciall croſſe on which Chriſte died, but of a croſſe in generall.

Fol. 29 a Calf.The ſecond reaſon is this: As the charmer doth not caſt out Sathan, but Sathan of his owne accorde goeth out to deceaue mē, and that they may not goe to Chriſte, perſuadeth them to go to ſorcerers: On lik ſorte the diuell may ſeeme to tremble and quake, when he ſeeth a croſſe, but it is for no other purpoſe, but that we ſhoulde leaue onr confidence in Chriſte, and repoſe it in a piece of wood. Mart. The diuell is craftye I confeſſe, and becauſe men ſhoulde not goe to Chriſte, he will rather yelde at the incantation of a charmer for a time, than loſe the poſſeſſion of his ſeruantes for euer. But that he trēbleth and quaketh when he ſeeth the croſſe, to make men leaue their confidence in Chriſte, and put it in a piece of wood, how knowe you that M. Calf? who made yow of his priuy counſell? and ſecretary of his ſecrets? Haue yow any ſuch inſpiration of the ſpirite? any ſuch nightly viſion? any ſuch priuy practiſes? or any ſuch ſecret aquaintance with him, as yower forefather Luther had, that yow can tell vs ſo much of his intent and meaning? You make vs miſtruſte it ſhrewdly, becauſe you auouche it ſo earneſtly, without ſcripture, councell or auncient father. It had ben expedient for you to haue added ſome weight vnto that yower aſſertion. As longe as you ſimply aſſeuere it, as a poſitiō of yower owne, without proofe, no VViſeman will beleaue it. For yow may well conceaue that the diuell vſeth no temptation, nor
ſlighte to deceaue man, but ſuch as he ſuppoſeth is moſt forceable to ouerthrowe him. And wheras he knoweth euery Chriſten man to repoſe his faith and truſt in the merites of Chriſtes paſsion, he will not immediatly attempte to bring him frome that, to haue affiance in ſome piece of wood. For ſo he ſhoulde betray him ſelfe. For the errour is ſo groſſe and ſenſible, that the ſimpleſt man that knoweth Chriſte crucified, and is learned to beleaue in God, would deteſt it, and defie all that ſhoulde labour to induce hym vnto it. His deuiſes are more ſubtile, his practiſes more pollitike, his waightes more weightie. That was an errour of the gentills too much diſcloſed, to deceaue any Chriſtian nowe in thes latter dayes. Yf you haue ſo vile and baſe an imagination of yower euen Chriſtiā brethren, that they will forſake Chriſte, and repoſe their hope in a piece of wood, you may aſſure yower ſelfe, that it is more vile, than is ſittinge for one that profeſſeth Chriſte.

The Iewes miſtruſting that the Chriſtians would forſake Chriſte, and woorſhippe Policarpe thē martired, as you do leſt we will renounce Chriſte,Euſeb. lib. 4. cap. 15. Eccleſia. hiſto. The deuill ſeemeth not to feare the croſſe, but feareth it in deede. Athanaſ. de verb. incar. Signo crucis etc. Lib. 3. cap. 2. eccleſia. hiſto. & lib. 6. cap. 1. Tripart. and repoſe our confidence in a piece of wood or metall figured, were counted ignorante, and moſt wretched men for that ſurmiſe: The Chriſtians ſaide then of them ſelues we can neuer forſake Chriſt who ſuffred death for the ſaluation of the whole worlde nor worſhip any other, becauſe we knowe the true God and him who is to be woorſhipped. The like we may returne to yow. VVith all yow may aſſure your ſelfe, that it is too euident by the teſtimonies of the auncient fathers, that the diuell doth not pretend and diſſemble a feate at the ſighte of the croſſe, but feareth it in dede, and trembleth and quaketh at it, and can not abide it. To beginne with Athanaſius. Conſider that ſaying of his alleadged before. He ſaied not, that the diuells ſeme to tremble, but they trēble in dede, they ſeme not to flee awaye, but they flee away in dede, they ſeme not to be tormented, but are tormented in dede, yea they ſuffer perſecution: Man vſing the ſigne of the croſſe, dryueth them away in dede, and dothe noth only ſeme to dryue them awaye. Theodoretus ſaieth: The diuells when they ſawe the figure of our lordes banner remembred the ſlaughter and
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
foile, which they had taken, & mox euanuerunt, and by, and by they vaniſhed awaye. Orat. pri. cōt. Iulia. Gregory Nazianzene ſayeth, that with the ſighte of the croſſe which Iulian made, daemones compeſcuntur, ſuperantur, the diuells were quayled, the diuells were ouercomed. He ſaide not they ſemed to be quailed,Titu. 19. part. 3. Panopl. they ſemed to be ouercomed. Euthymius ſaieth by vertue of the croſſe cōpanies of deuils are expelled, he ſaid not. They ſeemed to be expelled. Neither are you able M. Calf. to alleage one aunciēt doctour, that maketh for that fonde opiniō of yowers, or if you can, let vs haue his wordes truly alleadged, and you ſhall haue an anſwer according. In the meane time this vndoubted doctrine of the fathers, that the ſigne of the croſſe is a bit ād bridle to the diuel, and terrour to all wicked ſpirites ſhall ſuffice vs, and I truſt, all true Chriſtians beſides.

Fol. 29. aAs for yower ſuſpitious head ſuſpecting the counſell geuen to the relligious, that they ſhould arme them ſelues and their houſes with the ſigne of the croſſe, when the diuell doth aſſault and attempte them,M. Calf. ſuſpecteth S. Anthony his counſel as inſufficient. as inſufficient, we take far inſufficiēt to be credited before S. Anthony that gaue that coūſel. He was a holy man geuen to contemplation, you ſeeme to be an hipocrite geuen to diſsimulation, he lyued in wildernes with great abſtinence, yow lyue in the citie with great delicatnes, he was renommed through all the worlde, for ſanctitie, you infamous through out all England for blaſphemie, he a frend to Chriſt, you an enemy to his church, he a worker of miracles, you becauſe you can do none, a thincker that they are illuſions, he a vertuous heremite, you a wicked heretike. And certes vnleſſe Lucifers proude ſpirite had pricked you forward, you woulde neuer ſo preſumptuouſlye haue ſuſpected that counſell as inſufficient, Fol 29. a which S. Anthony an holy, vertuous, and godly father, altogether occupied in contemplation and prayer, with whome it pleaſed God to talke by viſions, and reuelations, and by whome it pleaſed him to worke ſundry miracles,vide Athana • de vita S. Antonij. and great cures, gaue to the relligious, and which Athanaſius writeth and teſtifieth to be true. But o lorde what will not heretikes reiecte? whome will not they cōtemne beſides them ſelues? There was neuer man yet ſo holy, neuer doctour ſo lerned, neuer father ſo
auncient, but they haue ſet him at naught, where he wrote or ſpake any thing againſt their newe doctrine. Yea they haue not ſpared the very ſcriptures, and epiſtles of the bleſſed Apoſtles, ſuch is their zeale to promote their Ghoſpel. As for this caſe that is nowe in hande, whome ſhall we credit? S. Anthony that gaue counſell to the religions to arme them ſelues with the ſigne of the croſſe, when Sathan did attempte them, or M. Calf. that forbiddeth it? S. Anthony that counſelled it as good and godly, or M. Calfe that ſayeth, it is inſufficiēt, and vngodly? S. Anthony that taketh the Croſſe vpon which as an inſtrument Chriſte ſpoiled the powers of the ayre, to be the triūphāt bāner of victory or M. Calf. that ſemeth to take the death to be the bā ner of his victorie, and not the victory it ſelfe, not farre vnlike the heretikes that thought Chriſte not to haue died in dede but in a fantaſie? I would refer it to yower iudgement (good readers) but it is not harde to iudge, nor vneaſy to define, vnles ſome wilbe ſo madde as to prefer a young diuell before an old ſaincte. Nowe to his anſwer againſt the place of Chriſoſtome.

VVhere that holy father ſaide.Homi. 55. in 16. Mat. Crucem non ſimpliciter digito in corpore, etc. Thou muſt not ſimply with thy finger make a Croſſe in thy body, but firſt of all thou muſt make it with greate faith in thy minde, Chryſoſt. For if thou printe it in thy face after this māner, none of all the wicked ſpirites when they ſee the ſpeare with which they receaued a deadly wounde, will dare to encounter with the, Fol 30. a Calf. This is neither materiall nor myſticall croſſe, quoth M. Calf. for neither of them can be printed in the hearte. Therfore it is the faith in Chriſtes paſsion, which the finger can not impreſſe in the forehead, but grace can engraffe in the minde of man. Mart. To cōuince his folly in this point, lett vs examine the place. Chriſoſtome telleth vs here, that if we do twoe thinges, the diuell will not dare to encounter with vs. The firſte is to printe the paſsion of Chriſte with greate faith in our mindes. The ſecond to make the ſigne of the croſſe with the hāde in our bodies, his wordes be plaine for bothe. And as he maketh mention of body and ſoule, ſo doth he apointe ij inſtruments to imprint the paſsion of Chriſte in thē,
faith for the ſoule, and the figure of the croſſe for the body. Yf perchāce M. Calf. being in ſome drowſy dreame,Tel vs M. Calf, vvhat croſſes. Chryſoſt. vvould haue made vvith the finger? ſawe not this, nor yet will cōceaue it, aſke him what Croſſe it was, that Chriſoſtome woulde haue made in the body, with the finger, if it were not a myſticall croſſe? Yf he ſay Chryſoſtome meaneth no • roſſe made with the finger, becauſe it can, Not be printed in the hearte, aſke his worſhip what Chriſoſtome meneth by thoſe wordes, Crucem non ſimpliciter digito in corpore etc. Thou muſt not ſimply prīte a Croſſe in thy body, with thy finger, but firſt of all thou muſt printe it with great faith in the minde? Is not digitus Latine for a finger, and corpus Latine for a body, Crux, Latine for a Croſſe, and Formare, Latine to frame, ſhape, forme, and make? I truſte his cunning ſerueth him to thincke ſo. And doth not he that telleth his ſeruante twoe thinges, and ſaieth, ſirra, doe this firſte, meane that he ſhould doe the other afterwarde? In like ſorte doth not Chriſoſtome bidding vs in this place print the paſsion of Chriſte firſt of all in our heartes, with faith, meane that afterward we ſhould printe the croſſe in our bodies with the hande? Looke well to his wordes. It followeth: Si hoc modo faciei tuae impreſſeris. If thou printe it after this mā ner in thy face? VVhat manner, M. Calf? ſpeake man, be not aſhamed? tell truth and ſhame the diuell. VVhat manner was it? any other than that which he mentioned before? Firſte by faith in the ſoule, afterwarde with the finger in the body? No no: Yower gloſes are too groſſe to gloſe ſuch an euident matter as this is.Fol. 30. a Yower reaſon in ſaying: it can be no myſticall Croſſe, becauſe it cā not be printed in the hearte, is not worthe three lepps of an olde dogg. For albeit it can not be printed in the hearte by mans finger or hand, yet may it be imprinted with preaching, meditation, and faith as Chriſoſtome ſayeth.

VVhere yow ſaie that the croſſe which Chriſoſtome there mentioneth is faith in Chriſtes paſsion, etc. You betray your owne ignorance, and geue vs to vnderſtande that your capacitie conceaueth, not what Chriſoſtome meaneth: his woordes be thes: Crucem magna profecto fide in mēte prius formare oportet. You
muſt firſte printe the croſſe with greate faith in yower minde, the croſſe that he ſpeaketh of in this latter clauſe, is the paſsion it ſelfe, and affiance in the vertue and power of it. VVhich muſt be printed in our mindes: faith is the gyft of God by meanes where of the paſsiō muſt be printed with in vs.M. Calf. confoundeth the paſsion and faith in the paſsion And wil youer pregnant wit ſerue you to confounde the meane, with which men muſt printe, and the thing that muſt be printed? Is there no difference betwene the conduicte pipe, and the water? the wine and the tunnell, by which as meanes the water is cōueyed into the citie, and the wine to the veſſel? Acknowledg, youre folly for ſhame, and learne to take the doctours ſayinges in their true meaning. Learne that the paſsion of Chriſte is one thing,The paſs on and faith in the paſſion not all one faith in the paſsion of Chriſte an other. The paſsion is the paynes, torments, and death that Chriſte ſuffred for vs, faith is a grace ingraffed in vs to beleue it. The paſsiō is the Ranſome and price that was paid on the croſſe for our redēption, faith is the meane that maketh vs partakers of the vertue and merite purchaſed by it. The paſsion is the acceptable ſacrifice that Chriſte made for our iuſtificatiō, faith a gifte of the holy Ghoſte, that by pouer of that maketh vs a ſwete ſacrifice to God the father. VVhen you haue lerned this and cōſidered the wordes of Chriſoſtome, I truſt you will neither affirme that the croſſe mentioned in that place is taken for faith in the paſsion, nor thincke that the collectiō which I made out of that fathers wordes for printing the merites of Chriſtes paſsiō firſt in the minde, and afterwarde in the body, is indirectly gathered, Fol. 30. b nor to be ſhifted awaye with this Sophiſtication: Fruſtra fit per plura quod fieri potest per pauciora. In vaine it is done by moe, which may be done by fewer. M. Calfs. Sophiſtrie A ſtraunge rule of newe Sophiſtrie practiſed moſt about the impugning of definitions and diuiſions, not to be admitted amonge diuines, for by that ſame rule, you may illude al the myſteries of our religion.

Our Saluation mighte haue bene wrought by the abſolute pouer of God, ergo the incarnation, and paſsion of Chriſte was in vayne, we might be taught the goſpell from heauen with
out miniſtres, ergo the apointing of prechers was in vayne. The Engliſhe cōmunion might be in fewer wordes, ergo the ſaying of ſo many words is in vayne. Some may be ſaued by faith, ergo it is vayne to doe good workes, and ſo illude all the miſteries of our faith, and religiō. But keepe yower ſophiſtical rules for the Sophiſters, it is not to be admitted amonge diuines. Chriſte ſaide.Luc. 17. VVhen yee haue done all that ye can, ſay ye are vnprofitable ſeruantes, but by yower iudgment (M. Calf.) Yf we may be ſaued with doing as litle as the theſe vpon the Croſſe, it is in vayne to do all that we can. For fruſtra fit per plura quod fieri poteſt, per pauciora. In vayne it is done by more, which may be done by fewer. This is yower profounde lerninge this is yower new diuinitie,The nevve doctrine. this is yower Euangelicall doctrine inuented by Sathan to deſtroy all that the forefathers builded, contented with as fewe prayers, and ceremonies, as litle faſtinge and watching, as ſimple almes and deuotion, as litle modeſtye frome lying, and rayling, as meane care of ſclaundering and blaſpheming, as poſſible may be: Quia fruſtra fit per plura quod fieri potest per pauciora.

Origen.Frome Chriſoſtome you goe to Origen, and many matters you laye foorthe, to infringe his autoritie and diminiſhe his credit. But howe fonde ſome of them are, it ſhal apeare hereafter. Nowe let vs ſee how wiſely you ſhift to auoyde that place.Calf. Fol 31. a b. Origen (ſay yow) aſking a queſtiō how it is poſsible to auoyde, that ſinne raygne not in our bodies, Coll 3. anſwereth, and ſayeth. It is poſsible to auoyde it if we doe as the Apoſtle ſayeth. Mortifie your members which are vpō earth, and yf we cary aboute allwayes in our bodies the death of Chriſte. For it is certaine that where the death of Chriſte is caried aboute, ſynne can not raygne. Eſt enim tanta vis crucis. For the power of the croſſe is ſo greate, wherby it is euidēt, that he ſpeaketh of the death of Chriſt, and that is the croſſe that be commendeth.

Mart.Very true it is (M. Calf.) that the way to prouide that ſinne raigne not in our bodies, is to mortifie our mēbers vpon earthe,
and to cary the death of Chriſte allwayes in our bodies: Neuer man denyed it, but licentious heretikes which plainly affirme that men can not mortifie their membres on earthe,Free vvil proued by Origen. In epiſt. ad Rom. lib. 6. Fol. 30. a or lyue chaſte, and vtterly take awaye free will, which Origen plainly proueth by thoſe wordes of the Apoſtle, the very nexte ſentence before, but you could not ſee that, neither when yow anſwered the place of Chriſoſtome howe he taketh the croſſe to be the death of Chriſte, and not faith in the paſsion, as yow fondly imagined before. Neither could yow ſee by what meanes he would haue the deathe of Chriſte to be continued and caried in our bodies, and becauſe other ſhould not ſee it, yow ſtayd in the middeſt of a ſentēce and vttered not Origens wordes, as he ſpake them. He ſaid not, the power of the croſſe is ſo greate, and made a full pointe there, (as you doe) but he ſaid: It is ſo greate, that if it be ſett before a mans eies, and kepte faithfully in his minde, ſo that he looke with ſtedfaſte eies of the minde, vpon the very death of Chriſte, no concupiſcēce, no ſenſualitie, nor enuy is able to ouercome him. This (ſir) ſaid Origen: And you might haue ſeene if yower ſhaking head ſuffred your gogling eies to be ſteadye, that as Chriſoſtome would haue the croſſe to be printed in the body and ſoule, So Origen would haue it ſet before the eies of the bodie and ſoule: that by outwarde ſight with the eye, the inwarde minde might conceaue a full impreſsion of the death, and paſſiō of Chriſte. Cōſider his wordes.Origen vvould haue the croſſe ſet before our eies. In the firſte clauſe he would haue it ſet before our eies. In the ſeconde to be kepte faithfully in the minde. And is there any way ſo conuenient, either to ſet the death of Chriſte before our corporal eies, as the ſigne of the croſſe, wherō Chriſte ſuffred? Let vs haue yower deuiſe & if you deuiſe a better, let vs heare of it, and we will thancke you for it: But al the politike wit in yower pieuiſhe heade cā not: neither is there any thinge able to be leyd before the eies, that can moue vehemēter affections to the minde, or make deper impreſsiōs of Chriſtes death in a hearte meeke and gentle, than the croſſe which is ſeene by the corporall eye, as I haue proued in the eighte Article of my Treatiſe. VVherfore vntill yower better deuiſe be deuiſed, we will ſay that Origen willing the death of
Chriſte to be ſet before our eies, and kepte faithfully in the minde, would haue it ſet before the eies with a crucifixe, and kepte in the minde with vertuous meditation and godlye preachinge.

Yf yow ſaye that Origen by the eies and minde which he ſpeaketh of, meant but one thing, howe will you excuſe him from that foule figure Tautologia in ſo fewe wordes in one ſentence? what ſhall become of yower owne rule, fruſtra fit per plura quod fieri poteſt per pauciora? will you make him that in his time was counted the flower of the worlde, ſo ignorant in matters of diuinitye, that he knewe not what he wrote? So vnſkillfull in diting his ſtile that he could not auoide Tautologiam, in twoe clauſes ſeparated, but with one comma? So rude in logicke that he knewe not your rule fruſtra fit per plura? No I dare ſaye yow will not, if it were for nothīg ells but that he deſtroyeth Imagery, as you ſaye. But of that in another place. In the meane while you ſee that all though the croſſe be the deathe of Chriſte that Origen ſpeaketh of, yet is it the ſigne by which he willeth that deathe to be ſett before our eies, becauſe it can not be ſo cōueniently and effectually done by any one viſible thing beſides.

Yower extrauagantes and impertinent digreſsions made againſte prieſtes and nunnes, I willingly omitt, becauſe they be ſclaunderous.Fol 31 b Yower tauntes and ſcoffes againſt me I wittingly contemne, becauſe they be ridiculous. Myne intent is onlye to examine yower anſwers, and not to dallie with you in trifles. The nexte auctoritie then that you labour to infringe is that of Caſsiodorus, Caſsiodorus. a learned father and graue Senatour, alleadged out his commētaries vpon the 4. Pſalme, where he ſayeth. Lyke as the Coyne beareth the image of the Emperour: Euen ſo are the ſignes of the faithfull, etc. But you ſaye neuer a wiſe worde to it, but, what thoughte, Fol. 32. b M. Calf. anſvvereth like a cooke Ruffian. muche like to a Cooke Ruffian, who chidden ones for making his maiſter vnſauorye ſoppes, ſaide, in his fuſtiā fumes, what thought, ād for anger woulde ſpeake neuer a good worde beſides, for his owne excuſe. In which pointe if his wiſdome be weighed with yowers, it will counterpeiſe it a greate deale. For he by ſilēce did leſſen his faulte, for euill cokerie, you
by multiplying of wordes diſcloſe yower vnſkill in not knowing the markes of Chriſtianitie. The effect of yower anſwer is this:Fol. 32. b Fol. 33. a Calf. Though the ſignes of the heauenly Emperour be printed vpon the faithfull, as the image of the Emperour is in his coyne, yet is a roode, or a crucifixe, or wagging of a finger not able to ſhewe whoſe men we are, as the printe in the money dothe ſhewe whoſe the coyne is. For whereſoeuer that image and ſuperſcription is ſtamped there is it certaine, who hath right to the coyne. But whoſoeuer hath the ſigne or ſtampe of the croſſe, ſhewe not therby whoſe ſeruantes they are. Marc.

Here is much ſaid, but nought proued. Belike you haue purchaſed ſome protection, and priuiledge to ſay what ye liſte and proue what you pleaſe. Yf it be ſo, we will reſemble you to the banckroutes in London, and for a Ladde of Ludlowe take you for a Lacker of Ludgate. Their propertie is to require payment of others and to make none them ſelues, and ſoo do you here. Reaſon woulde that as you deny it conſtantly, ſo yow ſhould proue it ſubſtantially. For no VViſeman hath you in ſuch admiration and credit that he will beleaue it, becauſe you deny it.

The croſſe hath euermore ben an eſpeciall ſigne of Chriſtianitie, and whereſoeuer the faith was preached, the ſigne of the croſſe was had, and reuerenced, as I proue in the 3. and firſte article of my of my treatiſe.Euſeb. lib. 6 cap. 5. hiſt. eccle. In the beginning when any were cō uerted to the faith they that were in auctoritie gaue them, ſignum dominicum, our lordes ſigne, which was the croſſe, and by that they were knowne to be Chriſtians. Damaſcene ſayeth: By the croſſe the faithfull are diſcerned frome the infidells. Lib. 4. ca. 12. de ſide. In Pſal. 4. Caſsiodorus (whome we haue nowe in hande) ſayeth, that the ſigne of the heauenly Emperour is printed vpon the faithfull, as the image of the earthlye Emperour is prīted in the coyne, and to what other purpoſe, or reaſon is it, but as the Emperour his coyne is diſcerned by his image, ſo the faithfull Chriſtians ſhould be knowen by that ſigne (which is the croſſe) only peculier, and proper to the Chriſtians. Ells: VVhy doe you in your communion booke commaunde it to be imprinted and made in childrens forheads in baptiſme? The
gentills did euer deteſt it: the Chriſtians alwayes eſteeme it: The Iewes abhorre it: The Chriſtians honour it. The Turkes defye it. The Chriſtians deſire it: Heretikes blaſpheme it malitiouſly: The Chriſtians worſhippe it reuerētly, heretikes reiecte it with much vilaine: The Catholiques ſette it vp with great pietie.

They rayle at it with much blaſphemy. The Chriſtians wherſoeuer Chriſte was preached, in teſtimonie that they beleaued in the crucified, did ſett vp his croſſe as a bāner and recogniſance honorably to be knowen for Chriſtes ſouldiers. For teſtimony whereof, if any will ſee proofe of it, I referr him to the 3. and 5. article of my booke. There notwithſtanding all M. Calfs. cauills he may be ſatisfied. And albeit we can not enter into other mens conſciences, and iudge the Pope, and Prelates to be the beſt Chriſtians, for hanging Croſſes aboute them, yet by that may we iudge them to be Chriſtians, and men that haue affiance in the merites of his paſsion, becauſe none but Chriſtians commonly vſe, that bleſſed ſigne. The Gentills, Iewes, Turkes and heretikes (as I ſaide before) hate it, and what they hate they do not willinglye vſe. Yf thē the vſing and not vſing of a thing maketh one man to be knowen, externally from an other, why may not the hauing and not hauing of a croſſe, diſcerne a Chriſtian outwardly frō an infidell? In London a gentle mans ſeruāt is knowen from others by the badge on his ſleaue. The Lawier by his Coyfe,Some mē knovven frō other by their habite. the Citizene by his gowne, the miniſter by his hat, and euery man of experience that ſeeth them, can ſaye, he is a gentlemans ſeruant, he is a lawier, he is a Londiner, and he is a miniſter. And ſhall not the croſſe of Chriſte be a ſigne ſufficient, outwardly to diſcerne this or that man to be a Chriſtian? I referre it to the iudgemēt of the wiſer, out of which numbre, if M. Calf. will exempte him ſelfe by his profounde knowledge,Fol. 33. a Knowing the moſt croſſers (as he ſaieth) not to be the beſt Chriſtians, I can not be againſte his ſinguler head, and ſelfe will, ſine viuat ineptus, Let him lyue like a VViſe mā by him, ſelfe alone.

In the latter day whē all the ſecrets of darkenes ſhalbe reuealed mēs thoughtes diſcouered and doinges rewarded, he ſhall finde
that the enemies of the croſſe, and no croſſers ſhall haue no parte with Chriſte. But as all that had not the bloud of the lambe ſprinckled vpō their dore poſtes in Egipte,Exod. 12. nor the ſigne of Tau ſigned in their foreheads in Hieruſalem,Ezech. 9. were killed by the deſtroyer: So at that dreadfull daye, they that haue not the bloude of Ieſus Chriſte ſprinckled in their heartes, and the ſigne of the croſſe in their foreheades, ſhalbe in woful caſe. For then the croſſe which they hated ſhall apeare (ſaieth Ephrē) and vexe them and trooble them: Cap. 3. de poenitent. Homi. 55. in 16 Mat. Then will Chriſte (ſaith S. Chriſoſtome) be aſhamed of them, becauſe they were aſhamed of ſo greate a treaſure. But if a man ſhould come to a pointe of lawe with M. Calf. and aſke him, howe he knoweth that the moſt croſſers be not beſt Chriſtians, and demaūde cauſes of his knowledge, quia ſcire eſt ꝑ cauſas cognoſcere, to knowe is to knowe by cauſes, I thīcke he would aſke a very longe terme ad ꝓponendū omnia, and in the end lett fal his ſuite, and frome knowing leape to ſuppoſing. For be it that he knoweth ſome that vſe the ſigne of the croſſe, to be of euill conuerſation, and very lewde, for their vitious life, will it followe that he knoweth all to be ſuch? No, vnleſſe he were a younge God, or nere Coſyn to Dauid George that would be Chriſte. Let me reaſon with him a while. Howe ſaye yow M. Calf. be not the Dominicans, Obſeruantes, Carthuſians, and other religious mē, and women, moſt croſſers (as you terme them)?Fol. 33. a Doe they not renoūce the worlde, forſake all that they haue, and diſtribute their goods to the poore, and binde thē ſelues from the pleaſures of the worlde? Are they not content to fare euill, to haue harde lodging, and ſimple apparell? Doe they not faſte muche, watche long, riſe at midnight, and ſpend moſt parte of the daye in ſtudie and cōtemplation? Is it not ſo? Howe ſay you man? Yf you deny it, the worlde ſhall conuince yow of impudency. And will yow ſay that theſe men be not the beſt Chriſtians? VVhere is yower wit? Chriſte counſeled him that would be perfecte, to ſell al that he had, and geue it to the poore, Mat. 19. Mat. 26. Coloſſ. 3. Philip. 3. 2. Pet. 3. and followe him, he counſeled men to watche, to faſte, to praye, to abandone the pleaſures of the worlde, to mortifie their membres vpon earthe, and to haue their conuerſation in heauen, and come as nighe as they can to
imitation of him, wherupon I may make this argument, Al that followe theſe, and other counſells of Chriſte moſt neareſt, be beſt Chriſtians (for Chriſte ſaide of Marie that woulde not incumber her ſelfe with worldlye cares, but lyue in contemplation.Luc. 10. Marie hath choſen the beſt parte, But thes relligious men and woemē to the outwarde ſhewe, (beionde which we may not iudge) obſerue theſe and other, counſells of Chriſte, tending to perfection,The moſt croſſers the beſt Chriſtiās. moſt neareſt of all other and ſhewe nothing to the contrarye. Ergo of all other they be the beſt Chriſtians ſo farre as man can iudge, and ſo conſequently the moſt croſſers the beſt Chriſtians. VVhere is nowe yower knowledge become M. Calf.? Hath it not confounded it ſelfe? Muſt it not come (as I ſaid) frome a knowing to a ſuppoſinge, and that ſuppoſition in time be founde vayne, and vnſittinge for a chriſtian? Trye it and yow ſhall finde it, and knowe yower ſelfe better.

Calf. Fol. 33. aYower wordes that followe, That the ſigne of God, is beleife in Chriſte, and grace to doe thereafter, and the merites of his paſsiō our ſuccour, Mart. our refuge, and defence, we acknoweldg to be true in a ſenſe, and ſo true, that whoſoeuer denieth thē denyeth the miſtery of our redemption. But what neede (they) in that place? VVas there euer Catholike that did gaine ſay it? And becauſe Caſsiodorus, In Pſal. 4. and other ſay, The Croſſe is our ſuccour, our refuge and defence, thincke yow that they exclude the death of Chriſt, and merites of his paſsion?Gregor. li. 5. cap 11. in Iob. One truth not be deſtroyed by another. The paſſion of Chriſt and ſigne of the croſſe our defence. and hovve. No: but yow would followe yower progenitours, whoſe propertie was to mingle good with euil, that they might creepe into creditt with their hearers, and by teaching one truthe deſtroye an other. But that is not commendable. Faithe is not ſo to be preeched, that good workes be cō temned, grace not ſo aduaunced, that free will be condemned, nor mercye ſo commended, that Iuſtice be not feared, libertie not ſo ſignified, that diſcipline be decayed. The omnipotencye not ſo declared, that the Sacramentes and other externall meanes be reiected.

Concerning the matter in hande, both the paſsion of Chriſte and ſigne of his croſſe, be our ſuccour, our refuge, and defence. The paſsion as principall, the ſigne as a meane, the paſsion as a
fountayne geuing vertue to all, the ſigne as a conduicte deriued frome that ſpring. The paſsion as a Caſtle, ſtronge inoughe of it ſelfe, the ſigne as an inſtrument taking force frome thence. For (as Caſsidorus ſayeth, and I alleadged in the end of the 6. article,In Pſal. 1.) ſpiritualis aqua ſignū crucis inūdat, ſpirituall water dothe flowe into ſigne of the Croſſe, that is to ſaye, heauēly grace dothe flowe in to the ſigne of the croſſe, which is knowē to be the ſaluation, of faithfull ſoules, and alſo the grace and vertue, which was once effectuouſe in the firſt patterne procedeth (ſayeth Euthimius) with like efficacye to the ſignes of the croſſe. Beſides Damaſcene telleth vs that,Libro 4. cap 12. de fide. vbi eſt ſignum Chriſti, ibi ipſe erit. VVhere the ſigne of Chriſte is, there he wilbe him ſelfe, Yf the partie be not vnworthy to receaue him. Thus you mighte haue vttred both theſe truthes, and not by vttringe one haue condemned the other, ſauing it liked you better to intermedle a fewe ſwete ſugered wordes, that the ignorāt might drincke of yower poyſoned cuppe, than ſimplie to vtter the truthe, that yowr falſetie mighte not be eſpeied.Vt ſupra. But it is ſayeth S. Gregorie a propertie of heretikes, ſo to doe. And you haue practiſed their properties ſo lōge, that nowe you can not leaue them nor theirs. Frome one yow flit to an other. And as Celſus, Lib 7. cōt. Celſ. (as I mentioned before, out of Origen) did attribute to the chriſtians thoſe wordes which they neuer ſpake:M. Calf. attributeth that to vs vvhich vve neuer ſpoke nor meant. ſo do yow inferr of my wordes that argumēt of which I neuer dreamed on, nor wiſe man coulde finde, if he ſought witht a lanterne, wherin you ſeeme, not to haue had yower common ſenſes at commaundement, but either in captiuitye to hereſye, or in thraldome to phreneſie, or in danger to bothe. For vnleſſe hatred to the truth, engendred by hereſy, and fooliſhe fantaſies conceaued by phrenſye, had eſtranged yower witts, yow woulde neuer haue forged ſo foliſhe an argument, and falſely impute it to to an other. But ſuch forgeries and fooliſhe ſhiftes they muſt haue, that will defend hereſies. To trye yowr honeſtie, I deſire no more of the gentle reader but to peruſe the ſimilitude, deduced from faith ioyned wirh charitie, to faith aſsiſted with the ſigne of the croſſe, by way of an anſwer to heretikes obiections, and note whether he can deduce and frame out of it this argument of
yowers,Fol. 33. a b. The ſigne of the croſſe is as neceſſarie to cōcurre with our beliefe, as charitie to be with faith: But faith without charitie, is a diuells faith, ergo beliefe without the ſigne of the croſſe is diueliſhe?
