I am ſure none but ſuch as are euil affected in cauſes of relligion, and daunce after ſuch miniſtrells pipes can picke out ſuch a ſenſe of my wordes. For here is no ſuch to be founde.Fol. 21 a of my treatiſe. Thus I ſaye: As not euery ſimple, bare, and naked faith, but ſuch as worketh by charitie, is the victorie that conquereth the worlde, the meane that maketh our ſoules meete habitations for the holy Ghoſte, the waye that leadeth vs to heauen: Euen ſo ſaye we, that faith worketh to man the foreſaide effectes, expelleth diuells, putteth out their fiery dartes, ād defendeth man frome all their fury and aſſaultes, Mary not euery faith, but ſuch as is ſtedfaſte, cōſtant, and ſtronge, ioyned with charitie, builded vpon hope, ſtrēgthened with prayer, augmented with faſting, and aſsiſted by the ſigne of the croſſe. And I beſeeke you what worde is there here that expreſſeth ſuch an abſolute neceſsitie betwene the ſigne of the holy croſſe, and faith as is betwene faith and charitie? Yea by what wordes may it be but probablie gathered? Is it this worde aſsiſted? if it be ſo, let vs ſee, by what reaſon they can make it good. To be aſsiſted by one is to be holpen by him, as in time of warre, for a prince to be aſſiſted by a garriſon ſent frome his frende, is to be holpē by that garriſon of his frende. Nowe as no VViſeman will ſaye, that the frende that helpeth the prince is greater than the prince in his realme, whome he helpeth, or that the aide which he ſendeth is of like neceſsitie, as the power which he leuied of his owne ſubiectes at home: Euen ſo none can ſaye that the ſigne of the croſſe is either of as greate power, or as neceſſarie as faith. Albeit in reſiſting and expulſing of diuells, it dothe aſsiſte and helpe faith.

That faith nedeth the helpes of faſting and prayer, and ſigne of the croſſe,17. Matt. Lib. 4. ca. 27. de vera ſapientia. I proued the firſt, by our ſauiours wordes, where he tolde his diſciples, that there is a kinde of diuells which is not caſt out but in faſtinge and prayer: the ſecōde out of Lactātius, where he ſayeth that as Chriſte by his wordes did expell wicked diuells, ſo nowe
the followers of Chriſte do caſte wicked ſpirites out of men, both with the name of their maiſter, and ſigne of the paſsion. And becauſe he talketh ſo plainlye of the name of Chriſte, and ſigne of the croſſe, M. Calfehills ſcoffinge witt diuiſed a newe taūte for him, and ſayde He tied two pointes together, the name of Chriſte, Fol. 33. b and ſigne of his paſsion, VVherein if I were diſpoſed to imitate his Rhethorike, I coulde more iuſtly ſaye, that he compareth the name of Chriſte, and ſigne of his croſſe to twoe pointes, then he can auouche that I compared the croſſe with charitie, and hope, faſting, and prayer. But I will not followe ſo lewde a preſident. My chiefeſt purpoſe is to diſcuſſe the pith of his anſwers to the authorities broughte out of the fathers.Fol 33. b Calf. To Lactantius euē nowe recited he ſayeth. The name of Chriſte is ſpoken of in many places of ſcriptures, and all thoſe places proue a true effecte, but in all thoſe places the ſigne of the Croſſe is not ſpoken of, wherfore the name of Chriſte alone woulde haue done as much as the name and ſigne together. Nor we muſte impute the vertue to the ſigne, though contrarye to the vſe, Mart. and example of Scripture it pleaſed ſome men to adde it. To ſo fooliſhe a reaſon, a breife anſwere ſhall ſuffice, and that is. Nego argumentum, I denie that argument. And when you iuſtifie it by good reaſon, I will diſproue it with better, vntill that come, ye and then too we will better creditt Lactantius than M. Calf. in this pointe, and more regard, the twoe pointes that he tieth together, the name of Chriſte, and ſigne of his croſſe, then all the pellfrey ware that he beareth in his pedlers pānier. VVhat? Nay ſofte quoth M. Miniſter, you do not well to likē hī to a pedler, for he ſuſtayneth a nobler perſonage, and is of late made a highe counſeler with God,Fol. 33. b ſo priuie to his will and ſoo well experienced in his power, that he can nowe aſſure vs that twelue hundred yeares agoe, the name of Chriſte alone woulde haue done as much as the name and ſigne of his paſsion together.

Yf it were ſo, for that reſpecte he oughte to be hadde in better reputation for his maſters ſake. In dede he talketh arrogantlye of his perſon in the end of his booke, and determinately like
a counſeller with God in this place. But the more higher he is in opinion of him ſelfe, the more viler ſhall he be in the ſighte of God, and eſtimation of the wiſer. It is an old rule in the lawe: Duo vincula ſortius ligant. 2. Tim 2. Twoe chaines binde faſter. The name of Chriſte is holy, mightie and greate, but if a mā will haue it ſtāde hī in ſteade, he muſte ioyne an other līcke vnto it, that is hatred of ſynne,Hovv the calling vpon the name of God helpeth vs. for as S. Paule ſayeth: Euery man that calleth vpon the name of God muſt go away from iniquitie. And (as S. Auguſtine ſaieth) he that calleth vpon the name of our lorde, muſt goe from iniquitie: if he wil haue the name of our lorde profitte him. The Apoſtles did many miracles in the name of Chriſte, yeat when a childe poſſeſſed with a ſpiritte was brought vnto them to be healed, they could not heale him by callinge vpon the name of Chriſte,Serm. 11. in Euang. Matth. which they practiſed as may be gathered by a ſtorie of the Bible, becauſe that kinde of diuells (as Chriſte ſaid) is not caſt out but with faſtinge and prayer. Mat 17. Mark 9. Luc. 9. Beholde the name of Chriſte alone called vpon of the Apoſtles (who had as ſtrong faith as euer any had) could not caſt out a diuell, and binde him to departe out of a childe. Chriſte beſides the callinge vpon his name, tolde that twoe other linckes were neceſſarie to binde that kinde of diuells, to witt,Matt 17. faſtinge and prayer. And ſhall we thincke that either there be no ſuch diuells raging like roring lions nowe, or that we are able to caſt them out by the name of Chriſte alone, VVheras the Apoſtles coulde not? No no: Yf we haue that fantaſie we doe deceaue our ſelues. Faithe being decayed in thes latter dayes, and charitie waxen colde, deuotion ſlaked, and prayers not very feruent, and yet the power of the enemye being as mightie as euer it was, it is reaſon that we ioyne all our force together, and call vpon the name of Chriſte, truſte in the merittes of his paſsion, faſte ſrome fleſhlye delightes, iniquitie and ſinne, praye without intermiſsion, and vſe all the helpes whatſoeuer they be, wherof the ſigne of the croſſe is one, taughte vndoubtelye of the holie Ghoſt, and practiſed of Chriſtes catholike churche, vniuerſallye througheout all the worlde, vntill this daye, and all wilbe litle ynough. VVherfore M. Calf. being no counſeller with God (for as S. Paule ſayeth: No
man is counſeller to him, Rom. 11. his wayes be inſearcheable) may be aſhamed to define ſo abſolutely without any reaſon, ſcripture, or doctour that the name of Chriſt alone would haue done as much, as the ſigne and the name together.

VVhere he ſaieth,Calf. Fol. 33. b Mart. that we muſt not impute the vertue to the ſigne, we tell him plainlye that we neuer did ſo, but referred all the vertue to the merittes of Chriſtes paſsion, and none to the ſigne, otherwiſe than to an inſtrument, by which the vertue is wrought, as remiſsion of ſynnes is by water in the ſacrament of baptiſme.

VVhere he ſayeth,Calf. Fol. 33. b Mart. that contrary to the vſe and example of Scriptures, it pleaſed ſome men to adde it, VVe deſire him to ſhewe one expreſſe texte in all the ſcripture, frome the firſte of Geneſis, to the laſt of the Apocalipſis, where it is inhibited, and where the vſe and example of ſcripture, is contrarie vnto it,No ſcripture forbiddeth and the ſigne of the croſſe. Calf. Mart. we woulde gladly learne it. If he cā ſhewe none (as I am ſure he cā not, let him be aſhamed of his impudent aſſertion. You ſay it is not commaunded in ſcripture, ergo it is not to be vſed.

VVe deny that conſequent, and and ſaye it is not forbidden in ſcripture, ergo it maye be vſed. Yf you admitte not this, tell vs by what ſcripture, you haue bene commaunded to vſe this and that collecte at yower cōmunion? to ſet the table in the quier? to put a cope vpō the miniſtres backe? to haue three at the leaſte to receaue at yower communion? or ſinge Gloria in excelſis, at the latter end? VVhat ſcripture haue you for all this? Yf you haue none at all, but vſe it becauſe you thinke it not inhibited, be not offended with other for vſing that licence laufully, that you take yower ſelfe, at your pleaſure.

Next to Lactantius I ioyned a ſentence out of S. Auguſtine to proue, that the ſigne of the croſſe,S. Auguſt. De Symb. ad Cathe. lib. 2. ca. 1. is a weapon and engine to fight againſt the diuell. The ſentence is this. VVe haue receaued the remedie of faith againſt the poyſon of the old ſerpent, that if our aduerſarie the diuell will at any time lye in waight for vs, the mā that is redemed, may knowe that he ought to meete with hī with a ſtedfaſt faith, Crucis vexillo. or (as M. Calf. will haue itt, with the Sacrament of faith and enſigne of the croſſe.
To ſhifte awaye this ſentence, a queſtion is propounded, and anſwere framed as it pleaſeth M. Calf. The queſtion is this.

Fol. 34. a. Calf. VVhat meaneth ſ. Auguſtine by that Metaphore? VVhat is that enſigne of the croſſe? The banner that is caried aboute the church yarde in proceſsion? The anſwer: No, but that which in the ſelfe ſame ſentence before he called Canticum ſalutis, the ſonge of Saluation. Mart. Fol. 25. b Fol. 29. b. A ſtraunge Metamorphoſis (good readers) M. Calf. that before vttered many blaſphemous wordes againſt the croſſe, can nowe ſaye, it is: Canticum ſalutis, A ſonge of Saluation. O that he woulde as gladly embrace the truth, when it is tolde him ſimply, as he cā finde ſtarting holes to ſhifte it away phantaſticallye. For in deede this is a mere fantaſie, and ſhifte of deſcant, clene beſides the playne ſonge. S. Auguſtine, (vpon whome he fathereth this his fantaſie) inſtructing in that place, Cathecumenos, younge Nouices as it were in the faith, declareth parte of the ceremonie vſed aboute thē, of the which this was one. They were brought frome certayne ſecrete places, where they had ben, into the face of the church, and there humbling them ſelues, with all humilitie, were examined, and prayed for. That the proude ſpirite mighte be expelled, Chriſte moſte higheſt of all, and yeat humble, was called vpon for them. They were humble, and meeke, they made their petitions, or ando, pſallendo atque dicendo: Pſal. 138. Proba me Deus & ſcito cor meum, praying, ſinging and ſaying: Trye me (o God) and knowe my hearte. God tried them, God examined them, God touched his ſeruants heartes with his feare. God by his power droue the diuell awaye frome them, and deliuered his familie frome the others poſſeſsion and thrauldome. But to our purpoſe: with in fewe lynes, after, it followeth: Our lordes familye therfore being purged, after that they had ſounge, the ſonge of Saluation, they receaued the remedie of faithe againſte the poyſon of the old ſerpent.

But was this ſonge of Saluation a banner of the croſſe (as M. Calf. fanſieth) No: S. Auguſtine ſayeth hī ſelfe. It was that verſe of the Pſalme:Pſal 138. Proba me Deus meus & ſcito cor meum, Try me o God and knowe my hearte. This ſonge they ſange after they came into the face of the church, and when they had ſounge this ſonge, then did God trye them, and examine them, and touche
their heartes with his feare, and deliuer them frō the ſeruitude of the diuell. And when they were thus purged and tried, and entring nowe by faith into the myſticall bodie of Chriſt, which is their health and ſaluation, and ſounge that verſe of Dauid, S. Auguſtine called it: Canticum ſalutis, the ſonge of ſaluation. This is S. Auguſtines minde. This mighte M. Calf. haue ſeene in the ſame place, if it woulde haue pleaſed him to haue marked al that S. Auguſtine ſayde. Furder he mighte haue ſeene with in xiij. lynes after the beginning, this ſaying of S. Auguſtine:Per ſacrū crucis ſignum. Ye are not yet borne agayne by holye baptiſme, but you are cōceaued in the wombe of yower holy mother the churche, by the holy ſigne of the croſſe.

By which he mighte haue learned, that according to the vſe of the primitiue church, of which Euſebius mentioneth,Lib. 6. c. 5 hiſt. eccle. Theodor. lib. 7. cap. 34. Tripar they that beganne to profeſſe Chriſte had the ſigne of the croſſe geuen them, and by that ſigne were as it were brought to Chriſte. But he would not ſee it, it was not for his purpoſe. But we muſt pardon him. A rollinge eye in a Calfes head, dothe not narrowlye marke al that lyeth before him. That which was nothing to the matter in hand, nor any one iote againſt that, which I alleadged for the ſigne of the croſſe, he eſpied to make a ſmoother, and nothing els: For what thought S. Auguſtine, biddeth vs vſe, The chaſte feare of God, and faith of praier, as twoe weapons againſt the twoe terrible engines, of the diuell, pleaſure and feare? VVill M. Calfhills Logike make it followe, that he doth forbid vs to vſe the ſigne of the croſſe? This is too ſtraunge, and newe triflinge follye.

S. Auguſtine in the very ſame place before, talked of the remedie of faith, and ſigne or banner of the croſſe, vt talibus armis indutus facile vincat Chriſtianus, that the Chriſtian being furniſhed with ſuch armour might eaſely ouercome, and becauſe he repeateth not the ſame againe in the other place, M. Calf. ſayeth he doth not bid vs make the ſigne of the croſſe in our forheades. VVhat triflīge folly is this? Howe holdeth this argumēt?Fol. 34. a. S. Auguſtine (in that place) doth not bidd vs vſe the ſigne of the croſſe: ergo he biddeth vs in no other place? S. Paule in ten of his epiſtles doth not bidde vs celebrate the ſupper of our lord, ergo he biddeth vs no where? Chriſte in the 1. Chapter of S. Matth. doth not bid vs
praye, ergo he biddeth vs no where. Yf you finde them ſtarke ſtarīg naughte (as in deede they are) then feare not to geue like ſentence of M. Calfhills. For they differ not the breadth of a nayle. For as S. Paule biddeth vs celebrate the ſupper of our lorde,1. Cor. 11. in his epiſtle to the Corinthians, although he did not in the other, and Chriſte commaunded vs oftentimes to praye, notwithſtandinge he did it not in the firſt of S. Mathewe: Euen ſo albeit S. Auguſtine did not bid vs expreſſelye in that ſentēce and clauſe, to make the ſigne of the croſſe in our foreheades, yet in the xxviij. lyne before, in the ſame chapiter he tolde vs that a Chriſtian man muſt vſe againſt the diuell, the remedie of faith and ſigne of the croſſe. And in diuerſe other places of his workes, biddeth vs vſe the ſame.

Thus you ſee (gentle readers), M. Calfhills anſwers to be no thinge but mere Cauilling and wranglinge. You ſee the authorities broughte for the vſe and vertue of the croſſe, ſtande in their force, and in the ſame ſenſe for which they were brought, and neuer an argument,Fol. 34. a either to halte downe righte, or to rū-, ne of vncertayne feete, as the aduerſaries doe. VVherfore lett truthe preuaile, and hereſy quayle, let the auncient fathers haue credite, and this newe vpſtarte his deſerte. As you finde him limping in this litle allredy examined, ſo ſhall you in all the reſt. Reade with indifferēcye, and ſee, there is nothing ſo abſurde but he will mainteyne it after his feble faſhion, rather than graunte that the ſigne of the Croſſe vſed of a Chriſtiā mā, is through the merites of Chriſtes paſsiō of vertue, or power againſt the diuel.

He telleth you that I preferr the bare ſigne of the croſſe before naked ſole and only faith. But there he maketh a lye ſir reuerēce. For I do not abſolutely prefer the bare ſigne before naked,Fol. 34. b ſole, and only faith: but declare an experimēt, and fact, where the bare ſigne of the croſſe wrought that in Pagan, which a naked, ſole, and only faith did neuer by any Chriſtian, and the declaring of a facte, is not a preferring of one thing before another. I knowe that a naked faith, which in tyme may growe to a perfection is better thā any externall ſigne. But what needed
all this bable aboute naked, ſole and only faith? It nothīg impugneth any thing that I ſaid. But for M. Calfhils pleaſure let vs heare the reaſons by which he proueth, that a naked and diuels faith is better than a Croſſe.

The firſt is this,Fol 34. b Calf. that the diuells faith dothe teache ſomewhat. The ſecond, that it taketh awaye the excuſe of ignorance. The thirde, that it forceth a ſynne vpon vs. The fourth, that a naked faithe is able with out furder information to inſtructe him, that nether did, nor euer coulde heare at all.

As for the firſte,Fol. 35. a Mart. M. Calfs firſt reaſon. in good ſoothe as we muſt confeſſe that as the naked and diuels faith teacheth all that haue it, ſome what, ſo may we not denie, but that the croſſe teacheth vs ſomwhat. But the teaching of ſome what doth not alwayes make a thing better. He that teacheth nothing, is ſome tymes better than he that teacheth ſome what, as the ignorant that holdeth his peace is better than the proteſtant that teacheth hereſie. That which we teache, is that as a naked and diuels faith auayleth nothing, vnleſſe it be clothed with charitie, ſo the bare figure of the croſſe, ordinarily profiteth nothing vnleſſe it concurre with faith. But this is nothing to the purpoſe. VVe ſee in heretikes, that haue this naked and diuels faith nowe a dayes,The fruictes of the naked and diuels faith. contempt of the Maieſtie of God, blaſphemie againſt Chriſt, diſobedience to his lawes, diſhonour to his gouernours on earth, rebellion againſt princes, ſpoyling of churches, ſacriledg of religious, malice againſt Catholiques, pride of heart, wantonneſſe of bodie, couetouſnes of money, with a great many ſuch of M. Calfs ſomwhatts. But in thoſe who hauīg faith clothed with charitie honour the croſſe, and are contented to haue it in their churches, we ſee no ſuch ſomwhats.

To ſee your folly, reaſon but this with your ſelfe M. Calf. That is better which worketh to man the leſſe harme, but the Croſſe worketh leſſe harme to man, than the diuells faith, contynuing ſtill a diuels faith (for it worketh none at all), ergo the croſſe in this reſpect is better than the diuels faith. Of the ſecōd
reaſon,The ſecōd that it taketh away the excuſe of ignoraunce, what can ye infer, but that it maketh mens ſynnes that haue it, more greuous,Luc. 12. and damnation more terrible. Doth not Chriſt ſaye that the ſeruante that knoweth his maiſters will, and hath not prepared him ſelfe, and done according to his maiſters will, ſhalbe beaten with many ſtripes, but he that doth not knowe it, and doth thinges worthie of puniſhment, ſhalbe beaten with fewe? And ſhall it nowe be better becauſe it taketh away the excuſe of ignorāce? Me thīcketh you might better haue ſaid: That is worſe which maketh mans damnation greater, but a naked and diuells faith, knowing God and not glorifying him as God, doth make our damnation greater than all the ſignes of the croſſe in the worlde, ergo a naked and diuels faith in this poynt is worſe than the croſſe.

The thirdCōcerning the third reaſon, where you ſay: that faith forceth a ſynne vpon vs, and alleage Chriſtes wordes for it, you ſhewe your ſelf neither ſkilful in the ſcriptures, nor true Chriſtian. For the place which you alleage out of S. Iohn proueth,Cap. 15. that the Iewes (of whome Chriſt ſpoke, had no excuſe of their ſynnes, becauſe Chriſt had preached vnto them, and they cōtinued ſtill in their incredulitie, and would not beleaue in hym, nor haue any faith of his incarnatiō, death, or reſurrectiō. Yf they would haue had faith,M. Calfs doctrine, that faith forceth ſynne vpon vs. they ſhould haue ben delyured from ſynne, for they ſhould haue ben iuſtified by the death of Chriſt in lauacro regenerationis, in thee bath of regeneration and baptiſme. Furthermore no true Chriſten man would euer ſay, that faith forceth ſynne vpon vs. For faith is the gift of God, and the giftes of God force not ſynne vpon vs. As he hym ſelf is holy, ſo are all his gyftes: and make vs holy, Yf we vſe them to ſuch effects as he gaue them vnto vs. Yf a man ſhould vrge you that crake vnto the people, that you teach nothing, but the ſincere Ghoſpell, where you finde this poſitiō, faith forceth ſynne vpon vs, in all the Ghoſpel of Ieſus Chriſt, what could you ſay M. Calf? Yf you haue any ſcripture, councell, or father, let it apeare, yf you haue none, then are you litle better than an Atheiſt, to ſay, that faith (which is the gyft of God) forceth ſynne vpon vs: But
yf your poſition were true, we might make this reaſon againſt you. VVhatſoeuer forceth ſynne vpon vs, is woorſe than that which forceth no ſynne vpon vs: but the naked and diuels faith forceth ſynne vpon vs (as you ſay) ergo it is worſe than that, which forceth no ſynne vpon vs. But the croſſe forceth no ſynne vs, ergo it is woorſe than the croſſe. That the croſſe forceth no ſynne vpon vs, it is manifeſt, for it hath no life, no ſenſe, nor power to vſe any force.Matth. 15. Marc 7. All that polluteth and defileth a mā cū meth from the heart. From thence, come euil thoughtes, murders, adulteries, fornications, theftes, falſe witneſſes, and ſuch like, theſe be they that defile man, and not croſſes M. Calf.

The fourth reaſon is ſo fonde,The iiij. that I thincke your brayne had ſome convulſion, and witte diſtraction, when you deuiſed to vtter it. For who but you, knowing that faith cometh by hearing, Rom. 10. and hearing by the worde of God, woulde ſaye, That a naked faith is able to teache him, that there is a God, that neither did, Fol 35. a not euer could heare at all? The man that did neuer heare, can haue no faith, quia fides ex auditu, for faith cometh of hearing. Yf he hath no faith, I woulde faine haue your deuiſe, howe faith can teache hī. The inſtincte of nature, viſible thīges of this worlde, as the mouīg of the heauēs, the encreaſe, of the earth, the face of man, and ſighte of others may inſtructe ſuch a one, that there is a God. And the ſight of the croſſe and crucifixe can expreſſe vnto his eie that one died vpon the croſſe: but that faith (which is not in him) becauſe he neuer had any ſenſe of hearing, can doe it, it were a prety deuiſe to le • ne.

The Philoſopher Ariſtotle taught, that,De ſenſu & ſenſibili. Auditus eſt via ad diſciplinam. Hearing is the waye to learning, lacke hearing, and the ſenſe of hearing, and lacke learning and all that muſt be learned by hearing. But M. Calf. had forgotten that principle of philophie, and no maruell for he beginneth pretelye to forget Chriſtianitie. As for the abſurditie, which he findeth in comparing the fained and diuells faith, which is a gifte of God, Fol. 35. a he ſayeth) and a qualitie of the minde, to the croſſe which is the worke of man, wil apeare none at al, yf he remēber howe S. Paule cō pared
the high prieſte who was in auctoritie,Acto. 23. ād had no doubte great giftes of God, and ſome kinde of faith, ſuch as M. Calfhills fayned diuells faithe is, to a paynted walle, which was the worke of man, full of rubble and durte. And nowe to his Coſen Iulian, and his iudgement of that experiment. Marke it well. It is profounde.

Fol. 35. b M. Calfs. Notes.Firſt he noteth, that wicked, reprobate and godleſſe perſons can vſe the ſigne of the croſſe, as well as other, which if they can doe, and notwithſtādinge haue neuer a whitte the more faith, it can not be (ſaieth he) that the croſſe dryueth out hereſies, that it conuerteth obſtinate ſynners, that it maketh wicked men thinck vpon God, or that it is cōfortable in deſperation. Mart. Is not this a proper note, and he a cunninge noter? Is it not to be noted as well that lechers, vſurers, heretikes, couetous men, and other lewde perſons can haue the Bibles in their houſes, reſort vnto ſermons, heare the worde of God, as wel as other that are vertuouſly diſpoſed, and not withſtāding haue neuer a whitte the more care to amend their lyues? Yeas verely, the more is the pitie: And becauſe all wicked mē do not take occaſion by reading of the Bible, and hearing of Sermons, to amend their liues, ſhal we ſay (as M. Calf. doth of the croſſe) that the worde of God can not make lecherers chaſte, vſurers honeſt, couetous mē liberall, heretikes catholiques, and naughtie men good?Haebr. 4. God forbidde. The worde of God is lyvely and effectuous, and more percing than any twoe edged ſworde? Eſa. 55. It ſhall doo all that God will haue done, and proſper in thoſe, for whome he ſent it. VVhē it falleth, it falleth like the ſowers ſeede, ſome by the high wayes ſide, ſome vpon the ſtones, ſome amongeſt thornes, and ſome vpon good grounde. Some heare with one eare, and let it out at the other. Some receaue it with ioye, but ſuffre it not to roote: and in tribulatiō be offended for it. Some heare it, but are ſo choked with riches and cares of the worlde,Matt. 13. that it doth not fructifie. Some haue humble gentle, and milde hartes, and they bringe forth fruicte in greate plentye. In like ſorte, Some ſeing the croſſe, goe by, and thincke not of it, but rather contemne it.
Some ſee it gladlye and thincke of it, but they are worldlye, and can not entre into any meditation of Chriſtes death, by often ſight of it. Some haue holy meditations of Chriſte, and his paſſion, by occaſion of it, and yeat do not fructifie. Some that haue remorſe and care of eternall ſaluation, by ſight of it fall into ſome heauenly contemplation of Chriſtes benefittes, and paſſing loue towardes vs, and fructifie an hundred folde. Nowe becauſe all that ſee it do not take like commoditie by it, ſhal we generally ſaye as M. Calf: ſayeth, that it driueth hereſies out of no man? It cōuerteth no obſtinate ſynners? It maketh no wicked men to thincke of God, nor is comfortable to none in deſperation? or ſaye as he noteth in the margent,Fol. 35. b that theſe are contradictions in Martiall? It were no pointe of wiſdome to builde ſuch an argument of ſo ſclender a reaſon. For that admitted, many other abſurdities will followe, eſpecially that which I declared before.

Now that the ſighte of the croſſe, beheld with earneſt meditation of Chriſte, humbling him ſelfe to deathe, to gather vs together, and bring vs into vnitie, expelleth hereſie, not I onely, but that holy father Ephrem, witneſſeth in theſe wordes:De poenit. cap. 3. Crux eſt haereſium expulſatrix: the croſſe is an expeller of hereſies, whoſe wordes M. Calf. that reproueth the vertue of the croſſe, ſhould rather haue anſwered wiſely, then condemned fooliſhlye. That ſome obſtinate ſynners are conuerted, or rather induced to conuerte by ſight of it, not I onely, but Athanaſius teacheth.De humanit. • erbi. And his auctoritie ſhould rather haue bene diligentlye weighed, than diſdainfully reiected. That it is comfortable in deſperation, diuerſe knowe that haue bene diſquieted by the diuell, and by Gods grace, through the cōtemplation of this, haue gotten the victorie, and triumphed ouer him. For examples ſake I could haue named ſome, but that I thought the gentle reader would credit it, and did not miſtruſte that any heretike woulde ſcoff at it: But I perceaue, vnder euery ſtone there lieth a Scorpion.The 2. Note. Fol. 35 b. Calf.

His ſeconde note is, that the diuell was not ſore hurte by the Croſſe, for notwithſtanding he retayned the poſſeſsion of
whole Iulian both in body and ſoule. Mart. Yf his note bookes at home, haue no better notes than this, there were a fooliſhe note booke God wot. You forget your ſelf (ſir). VVe ſpeake not of harme done vnto the diuel, but of his fleing away at the ſigne of the croſſe. VVhy vrge you not that? The diuel was not by coniuration called vp, to hurt Iulian, but to helpe hym. etc. For Iulian had to conſulte for an empire, and thereim the diuells counſell was required. But when Iulian ſawe that terrible and oughly ſight of ſo foule a fynde, he was in greate feare, & woefull agonie, and ſo vpon the ſodayne, hauing no other refuge, he made the ſigne of the Croſſe in his foreheade, as he commonly, vſed when he was a Chriſtian. The diuels were putte to flight, and driuē backe agayne. VVas this, after a ſort, no harme to the diuel as you terme it? Imagine M. Calf. that M. Gryndall ſendeth a Currier for you haſtely to beſtowe ſome fatte prebende vpon you, and ſome one by the way draweth his ſworde vpon you, and maketh you runne away for feare: haue you no harme by it? Yes verelye: for the infamie that ſhal redounde to ſuch a dowtye knight for cowardneſſe is harme ſufficiēt, if there be no more.Calf. Fol. 35. b M. Calfs. reaſon. Mart. But let vs heare what reaſon you haue, why the diuel had no harme. The diuell (you ſay) reteyned the poſſeſsiō of Iulian both bodye and ſoule, ergo he was not hurte by the Croſſe that he made. O that witt of yours howe fyne it is. VVhen you wēt to M. Grindall you kept poſſeſsion of your houſe, ergo when you ran awaye for feare, you had no harme. A pyrate robbed by another pyrate kepeth the poſſeſsion of his ſhippe, ergo he hathe no harme by the pyrate. Is not this ſubſtantiall geare? either get you better ſtuff, or holde youre peace for ſhame. The thirde note which you gather,Fol 35. b The 3. note. is that the diuell faineth him ſelfe, to be afraide of that which with al his hearte he would haue mē vſe. To this in part I anſwered before, and proued that the diuell ſeemeth not to feare the croſſe, but feareth it in dede. To ſay ſomewhat beſides I thincke it ſuꝑfluous, vnles M. Calf. wil tel vs by what ſecrete conference he hath lerned that the diuell did at that tyme feyne him ſelfe to be afraid of the croſſe that Iulian
made, or woulde haue men vſe the croſſe, and howe we ſhall knowe when the diuell is afaid. And what is the pointe which he woulde haue doobled, Yf he had bene afrayde in dede, whē Iulian and the coniurer were together? There was no cauſe why the diuell ſhould faine a feare to deceaue them. They were bothe his owne allready. Et quod ſuum eſt, amplius ſuum fieri non poteſt, ſayeth the lawe, that which is a mannes owne, can be no more his owne, than it is. There was no cauſe why he ſhould dooble a pointe. Iulian was his dearling, the coniurer his frende, and none vſe to doble with their frendes, for feare of breache of amitie. There was no cauſe why the diuell ſhould playe ſuch open playe, and runne awaye, excepte it were for feare of the ſigne of the croſſe: he was called vp by the coniurer to ſerue Iulian. Iulian was as glad to haue him as the coniurer, and the diuell would as gladlye ſerue them. There was no occaſion of feare otherwiſe miniſtred, and yeat to runne awaye vnder pretence of feare? Howe can this ſtande? It is a great torment to the diuell to be rayſed vp by coniuration, and the oftener he is cōiured, the oftener is his payne encreaſed. VVherby it apeareth that being called vp by the coniurer, he would not (as M. Calf. imagineth) playe open playe and make as though he were afraide, and runne awaye, and ſuffer newe torment by an other coniuration, onely to make ſporte. Nowe let vs haue a rule of M. Calf. to knowe whē the diuell feareth in dede, and whē he pretendeth to feare. He trēbleth at the name of Ieſus, he quaketh alſo at the ſigne of the croſſe, he fleeth whē he heareth his name, he runneth away when he ſeeth his ſigne. His tremblinge argueth feare, his runninge away cowardneſſe: Nowe to knowe which is for feare, and which is vnder pretēce of feare, were worthe the learning of ſo cunning a man as M. Calf. pretēdeth him ſelfe to be in the diuels policies. Yf it be by no other than running awaye, he may ſay, that he pretendeth feare at the name of Ieſus, as well as he doth at the ſighte of the croſſe. For he runneth away at bothe.

VVhere you note ſir contradictions in me, Fol. 35. b becauſe I ſaide
the ſigne of the croſſe muſt concurre with faith,That vvich M. Calf. auoucheth to be contradictiō, proued none. and faith, with the ſigne of the croſſe, and declared twoe experimentes, one of Iulian, and an other of a Iewe, in whome the ſigne of the croſſe wroughte great effectes, without faith, yow ſeme to be ſo deſyrous of quarrelinge, that you would rather fight with a ſhadowe, than ſit ſtill and not be counted a quarreler. You might ſee, that in the firſt, I had reſpecte to the ordinarie waye that God apointed vs to fighte with all againſt the diuell, and therfor ſaid that the ſigne of the croſſe muſt cōcurre with faith, and faith with the ſigne of the croſſe. And that they iontly concurring together haue dryuen out of men not only one ſpirire, but whole legions of diuells. In the ſecōd that I had reſpecte to an extraordinarie way, by the which it pleaſed god to declare the vertue of the croſſe, and what force it had, ex opere operato, by the worke wrought, yea by an Apoſtata and infidell, who had neither faith, neither hope in Chriſte. And theſe twoe diuerſe reſpectes conſidered, you might plainly haue ſeene, that there was no contradiction at all. For in Contraries there muſt allwayes be one reſpect. And if that reſpecte varie in tyme, place, manner, or other circumſtance, there can no contradiction be employed. Yf a phiſition ſhould ſaye vnto yow. Sir, this is the moſt common, and ordinarie medicine, that our arte preſcribeth to cure one ſicke of a phrenſie, and yet notwith ſtāding tell you that he knewe a man fallen into as deepe a phrenſye, as you, cured whith out that medicine, Or to vſe a more familer example, yf a man ſay vnto you, whoſoever will goe frome London to Lambeth by water, muſt haue a bardge, whirre, or ſome ſuch veſſell, and yeat tell you howe the laſt yeare, ſaue one a man mighte goe betwene Lōdon and Lambeth by water, with out any bridge, whirrie, bote, or Scullowe, will yower wiſdome ſay that either the phiſition in his wordes, or the other man in his ſaying imployeth a contradiction? I thincke not. And if you can finde none in theſe, looke well, and you ſhall finde none in the other. And maruel firſt at your owne ignorance, that vnderſtā de not that which you take in hande, to confute, Secondly at your owne follye, for wrangling and quarreling, where you
haue no iuſt cauſe. Thirdly at your owne diſobedience, who being a profeſſour of diuinitye and reader in Poules, and ſometimes a luſtly braue younker ſeruing man like with a badge on your ſleue, an earneſt fauorer, and quicke furderer of the ſuperintendentes iniunctions, woulde ſett forth a booke, nether peruſed by the lerned, nether priuiledged by the quene,M. Calfs booke printed vvithout priuiledg. nor allowed by order, commaūded by iniunctions, which you being a faithfull ſubiecte (as you ſaye) ſhould willinglye haue allowed, and not wittinglye contemned. But I ſee heretikes wilbe alwayes contemners of authoritie and rule, bolde, wilfull in there owne conceit, mē that feare not to bring in ſectes, mē that forſake the vnitie of Chriſtes, Catholique church, ād breake all good order.

div.head: THAT THE CROSSE OF CHRIST WAS PREFIGVRED IN THE LAVVE OF NATVRE FORESHEVVEN BY THE FIGVRES OF Moyſes Lawe, denonced by the Prophetes, and ſhewed from heauen in the tyme of grace. ARTICLE II.
div.p:
Fol. 41. AS THE Philoſopher whome M. Calf. mentioneth in the beginning of this article thought it not good to tell the foole that came vnto him, Fol. 41. a and aſked what was honeſtie, becauſe he had nothing to doe with it, ſo did I ones thinke it not expedient, for me, to anſwer this contentious quarreling of M. Calf. who profeſsing the ſinceritie of the Goſpell,Philip. 4. and commaunded ſo to behaue him ſelfe, that his modeſtie might be knowen to all mē, doth ſo reuile and raile in all his diſcourſe, that whoſoeuer fiftethe it, ſhall finde no pointe of honeſtie or modeſtie, frome the firſte leafe to the laſte: which in part he confeſſeth him ſelfe,In the preface to the reader ſayinge that he is more aſpre in his writing, than modeſtie requireth: But the truthe of the cauſe, ſo blaſphemouſlye reuiled, deſire to profitte my deare countrie ſo miſerably deceaued, and care to reduce him that ſo blindlye wandereth, haue made me take in hande the diſprouing of this his anſwere, which is more worthie to be cōdemned than remembred. Briefely therfore to ioyne iſſue with this
quareller that ſayeth:Fol. 41. b Calf. The ſigne of the croſſe was neither prefigured in the lawe of nature, nor foreſhewed, by the figures of Moyſes lawe, nor denounced by the prophetes, nor ſhewed from heauen in the time of grace, but the paſsion of Chriſt, and manner of his death was onlye prefigured, Mart. VVhat will he ſay to the fathers, and eſpecially to S. Auguſtine, that ſpeakīg of the widowe to whome Elias was ſent, and of the ſtickes that ſhe gathred ſayeth: Non hic ſolo ſigni nomine, Cōt. Fauſtum Manich li. 12. cap 34. ſed etiam numero lignorum, ſignum crucis exprimitur. In this place the ſigne of the croſſe is expreſſed, not with the only name of wood, but alſo with the number of the pieces of wood? VVhat will he ſay, to thoſe expreſſe woodes of his, Moyſes manus ad coelum extendit, iam tunc figuram crucis Chriſti oſtendens? Moyſes lifted vp his handes to heauen,De 5. Heraeſ ad quod vult Deū. ca. 2. Fol. 175. b Fol. 29 b ſhewing euē at that tyme the figure of Chriſtes croſſe? VVil he ſay: that they ouerſhotte them ſelues in their termes, and meant better than they wrote? Yf he doe, Let me aſke him this queſtion. Howe ſaye yow (ſir) was not the croſſe an inſtrumēt on which Chriſt ſhould be put to deathe? VVas it not one of the means, by which the māner of his paſsiō was wrought? VVhat ſaye you? was it? or was it not? Yf it were, then by yowr owne confeſsion,M. Calf. by his ovvne cōfeſsion cōu • nced a lyar. ſaying that the paſsion of Chriſt and māner of his death were prefigured, Yow are conuinced to be a liar. For if the manner of his paſsion, and meanes howe he ſhoulde come to his paſsion were prefigured, and the croſſe was one of thoſe meanes, then muſte it neceſſarilie followe, that the croſſe was prefigured: and that yowe haue done me greate iniurie in denying it.

Yf the croſſe were no inſtrument of his death, then was not Chriſt crucified, and ſo by your opinion the worlde not yet redemed. Your often confounding and taking the ſigne of the paſsion, for the paſsion of Chriſt it ſelfe, miniſtreth many occaſion to ſuſpecte, leaſte you be one of them, that intend to rayſe vp the Manichees hereſie, that Chriſte had but a fantaſticall bodie, and ſuffred here not in veritie, but in fantaſie: Take hede,vide Ambroſium ſerm. 55. de cruce & Auguſtinū ſer. 19 de ſanctis. you crepe apace towardes it. Againe, wheras Damaſcene, and
Cirillas, and diuerſe other do expreſſlye tell vs that the tree of life planted in the middeſt of paradiſe, did prefigure the ſigne of the Croſſe, dare you being but an vpſtarte, of no experience, nor lerning, in compariſon, controlle them of ignorance in the ſcriptures, and myſapplying the figures of the olde teſtament? or of ſeking allegories more then neded? VVere they men of ſuch meane lerning and cheuerill conſciences, that they woulde runne from a reueled truth, Fol 42. a to their owne fantaſies, and deuiſes: and ouerſhoote themſelues? No no: their vertue and lerning declare the contrarye, too well knowen, to be imperiſhed by ſuch a pelting pellferer, who falſely perſuaded, that he hath the beſt and fyneſt ware, that is in all the world, ſetteth vp a newe ſhoppe, and like a mountibanke prayſeth his owne confections,Lib. 4. ca. 12 de fide. and reproueth other mens? As for example, where Damaſcene reſembled the tre of life in paradiſe to the croſſe, this man (as though he had auctoritie to ſitt in iudgement ouer all,) ſaieth.Fol 42. a Calf. As in one ſenſe I condemne it not, ſo in an other ſenſe I like it not: the wordes that are inferred ſauour not of ſcripture: Mart. vvhy M. Calf liketh not Damaſc. He wilbe aboue all, he will like, and miſlike all, he will teache the fathers howe to interpret ſcriptures: Is not this exceſsiue pride? and Lucifers owne ſpirite? he likethe not Damaſcenes iudgement, and why? The thefe neuer liketh the iudges ſentēce be it neuer ſo true, if it be againſte him. Beſides wheras S. Ambroſe ſaide,Lib 1. de fide ad Gratia in prol. Lib. 8. ca. 17. in Euang. Ioā. Lib. 4. ca. 12. de fide. In 7. Exo. that the ſtandarde of Abraham when he foughte for his brother Loth, Cirillus, that the woodde layde vpon Iſaac when he ſhould be ſacrificed, Damaſcene that the bleſsing of Ioſephs twoe childrē by Iacob, Origen that the rodde of Aaron being all figures of the olde lawe, prefigured the croſſe, yet this man ſaieth, that it was not figured in anye at all. Lett the doctours dallie in figures as they fanſye, (ſaieth he) let not vs departe frome the veritie of the worde. Yf they ſpeake one thīge, and meane an other let vs take their meaning, Fol. 41. b Calf. Fol 43. Mart. and let their wordes goe.

As though ſuch lerned and vertuous fathers, woulde dallie in figures after their fanſie, and goe frome the veritie of Gods worde,
or ſpeake one thing and meane an other, and ſo voluntarilye erre them ſelues, and be occaſion of errour to other. This imagination is too vile, and thought too ſclanderous for a man to conceaue of ſuch noble lightes of the worlde, and nowe by the grace of God ſainctes in heauen.Fol. 23. a Fvl. 96. a Fol. 85. b But yet ſuch is M. Calfhills opinion of them, and not of them onlye, but of all the fathers that haue lyued theſe thirtene hundred yeares ſithens Chriſte.

A terrible matter, God commaundethe vs to aſke our forefathers, and they ſhall tell vs, and what ſhall they tell vs? the truth.Deut. 32. For orherwiſe God woulde not ſende vs vnto them, but to learne the truth, and nowe M. Calf. biddeth vs not goe the fathers, they runne frome a reueled truth to their owne deuiſes, Fol. 43. a. they dallie in figures as they fanſie, M. Calfs opinion of the fathers. they ſpeake one thinge and meane an other? Is not this to aduaunce him ſelfe againſte God? Lett the indifferent iudge. Yf any ſaye, the proteſtantes and ſuch as M. Calf. is, prefer the ſcriptures before the fathers, So doe the Catholiques too, and euer did, and yet neuer contemned their expoſition vpon the ſcriptures, where it is agreable to the doctrine of Chriſtes catholike churche, nor thought them to be ſo ignorant that they knewe not the meaninge of ſcripture, or ſo malitious that they woulde ſpeake one thinge, and meane an other to bringe men into errour, or ſo voyde of the grace of the holie Ghoſte, that making ſuch lerned cōmentaries, and expoſitions vpon the ſcriptures, ſuch godly ſermons, and deuote homilies to the people, ſuch treatiſes of faſting, prayer, and almes dedes, and ſuch like amountinge to greate volumes, they woulde varie frome the true ſenſe of Gods worde, and goe frome the ſinceritie of the Goſpell. Nor Damaſcene ſauoreth the leſſe of ſcripture becauſe, he ſaid: Seing deathe came in by the tree, it was conuenient that life and reſurrection ſhould be geuen againe by a tree, Yf it maye haue a gentle interpretation, and be taken as he meante, that is for the meane, and inſtrument by which death came, and life and reſurrection was geuen. For he was not ſo vnſkillfull in the ſcriptures, but that he knewe S. Paule ſayed: By one man ſynne entred in, and by one man reſurrection. 1. Cor. 15. Rom. 5. Nor ſo ignorant in the principles and groundes of the faith, but
that he knewe that our fall came by Adam, and our ſaluation by Chriſte, as the chiefe authour and woorker of it. VVherfore yow doe verye greate iniurye to ſo lerned a father to charge him with ignorance and not ſauoring of ſcripture. And albeit yow labour buſilie to diſcredite him, and Caſsiodorus and Cyrillus, for ſaying that the tree planted in the middeſt of paradiſe prefigured the croſſe,Fol. 42. a and bringe certaine places of S. Auguſtine to proue that it is called the wiſdome of God, and Chriſte hī ſelfe, yet ſhall yow haue no aduauntage againſt them, nor improue their interpretatiōs. The ſcripture is a greate deepe pole, it hathe many darke ſenſes, and ſecret myſteries, which may be diuerſlye taken, and ſignifie diuerſe thinges. As for example, the paradiſe that God planted for man,
VVhat paradiſe ſignifieth myſtically.
Lib. 13. ca. 21. de ciuitace Dei. Sapientiā. ſignifieth (ſayethe S. Auguſtine in the place which yow alledged before) the life of the bleſſed, the foure fluddes, the foure vertues, wiſdome, fortitude, temperance, and iuſtice, the trees ſignifie all good lerning, the fruictes of the trees, the manners of the vertuous, the tree of life, wiſdome, the mother of all goodnes, the tree of knowledg of good and euill, the experiment that the commaundemente of God was trāſgreſſed. This is one ſenſe. Beſides this it hathe an other ſignification. Paradiſe ſignifieth the church, the foure fluddes, the foure Ghoſpells, the trees holye men, their fruictes, their workes, the tree of life, Chriſte, Free vvill the tree of knoweledg of good and euill, proprium voluntatis arbitrium, mans owne free will. By which you may ſee that one thinge in the ſcripture maye haue diuerſe myſtical ſignifications, and neuer a one confounde the other. The tree of life ſignifieth Chriſte, and wiſdome the mother of all goodnes (as S. Auguſtine ſayeth,) we graunte. It ſignifieth alſo the croſſe of Chriſte, as Damaſcene,Lib. 13 de ciui • . Dei cap. 21. Caſsiodorus, and Cyrillus ſaye, no VViſe man can denye. For bothe maye ſtand, and one bring no confuſion to the other, as S. Auguſtine proueth by diuerſe examples of the olde teſtament. VVherfore (ſir) in prouing it to ſignifie Chriſte, and wiſdome, yow proue nothing, but that we graunte, and yet nothing improue that which we ſaye, that it ſignifieth (as thoſe fathers interprete it) the croſſe of Chriſte.Libro primo de moribus. But I perceaue the drunckarde will neuer lacke wine, nor the quarreler matter of contention. True it is that Seneca writeth. Euery man ſauoreth of that which he
hathe lerned. Yow haue lerned in Luther and Caluines ſchole, to be contentious againſt the church, and impugne one truth with an other, and that yow practiſe nowe, but howe wiſelye the euent ſhall trie.

The liftinge vp of Moyſes handes (yovv ſaye) ſignifieth prayer, ergo it ſignifieth not the croſſe, Calf. Fol. 43. a Mart. or els you ſay nothing againſt it. An argumēt lyke yower ſelfe. For if it were true, that the lifting vp of Moyſes handes did ſignifie praier, yet doth not yower reaſon holde in forme of a good conſequēt. For it maye ſignifie an other thing beſide prayer. That the lifting vp of Moyſes handes did ſignifie prayer, yow ſaye,Fol. 43 a it is euident by conſent of all men, and bringe but one, bothe euill quoted and nothing for yower purpoſe. Cōſider yower wordes: Chriſoſtome ſayeth libro primo de orando ad Deum, it is: Libro ſecundo de orando Deū, mende yower booke Sirra. Calf. Howe did Moyſes preſerue the people of Iſraell in the warres? Did he not deliuer vnto his ſcholler his armour, and hoſte, but he him ſelfe ſette his earneſt prayer againſt the multitude of his enemies? Therby teachīg vs that the prayer of the righteous is more auayleable, than armour, or horſe men? Thus much S. Chriſoſtome in deede.Mart. But where is there, in all this ſentence, one clauſe, yea one worde that ſayeth: The liftīge vp of Moyſes hādes did ſignifie prayer? Of the lyfting vp of Moyſes handes. There is none to be ſeene: All is ſpoken in the commendation and force of prayer: by which Moyſes conquered Amalech, yet not without the liftinge vp of his handes. For as the ſcripture ſayeth: VVhen Moyſes lifted vp his handes, the Iſraelites ouercome, Exod. 17. when he did let them falle Amalech had the victorye: There are twoe actiōs, liftinge vp of the handes, and prayer. Yf prayer onlye had bene neceſſarie, he mighte haue made it ſecretlye, and continued it without payne, and neuer needed Aaron and Hur to ſtand on bothe ſides to bolſter vp his handes. For prayer may be made without liftinge vp of handes, and greate wearines of the bodie. Nowe wheras Moyſes prayed with his hearte, and lifted vp his handes, M. Calf. can not well include thē in one. For if he make
them bothe one, and will haue the liftinge vp of Moſes handes to ſignifie prayer onely, then muſte he make one thinge in one reſpect to be a figure of it ſelfe, which is impoſsible. For thinges them ſelues can not be figures of them ſelues.

That he might haue made his prayer without lifting vp of his handes, and continued the ſame without payne, without Aaron and Hur on bothe ſides to bolſter them vp, no mā doubteth.Tertullia. li. 1 aduer. Marcio. & 2. Tertullian ſaieth: Nowe verilye why did Moyſes then only pray ſitting, with his hādes caſt abrode, whē Ieſus fought againſt Amalech, where as in ſuch perplexitie, he ſhould rather haue commended his prayer, by falling downe vpon his knees, with knocking his breaſte with his handes, and leying his face flatte vpon the grownde, except it were becauſe, where the name of Ieſus was mentioned, which ſhould fight in tyme to come, againſt the diuell, Habitus crucis erat neceſſarius. there the very forme, and habite of the croſſe was neceſſarye, by which Ieſus ſhuld carry away the victorie. Here Tertullian declareth that if nothing had ben to be ſignified in the lyfting of Moyſes handes, but prayer, it might better haue ben made with kneling and knocking of the breaſt, and proſtrating him ſelf vpon the grownde, but becauſe the holdīg vp of his hādes did prefigure the croſſe of Chriſt, who ſhould fight agaīſt the diuel, as he did then againſt Amalech, it was neceſſary for him to expreſſe the figure of the croſſe in ſuch manner, as he did. VVhere is nowe yower conſent of all ſir? Can yower number come but to one, and that one ſpeake neuer a worde at all of the liftinge vp of handes in either of the places which yow alledge? Alas I pitie yower caſe. There is great lacke, and euill ſtore, where one is all. Yow are ſuch a weakeling and in daunger of ſuch famyne, that I thincke yow will ſtarue before yow come to yower full groweth, and neuer proue a good oxe to tread out the true corne in Chriſtes flower, vnleſſe you make better prouiſion, but to the matter.

Fol 44. a Fol 28 a De 5. Heraeſ quod vult. Deū cap. 2.VVhat fonde toye came into yower idle brayne, when you ſaid, the lifting vp of Moyſes handes did not ſignifie the figure of the croſſe? Did yow not ſee in my booke, this ſaying of S. Auguſtine, Nobiſcum est Moyſes ille etc. VVith vs is that Moyſes, the greate frend of God: who to the ende he mighte ouerthrowe his enemies, helde vp
his handes to heauen, euen then ſhewing the figure of Chriſtes croſſe? Chriſtes croſſe prefigured by the lyftīg vp of Moyſes hands. Lib. 4. de Trinitate cap. 15. Calf. Did yow not ſee in the nexte ſide of the ſame leafe, this ſayinge out of the ſame father? Ille ſuperbiſsimus ſpiritus etc. That proude ſpirit is diſcomfited and ouerthrowen by the croſſe of our lorde which was prefigured by the handes of Moyſes? And if yow ſawe them, why did yow diſſemble them? VVhy did yow not frame an anſwer to them? Make they nothing to the purpoſe? Conſtrue them and ſee: Moyſes ille, that Moyſes, magnus amicus Dei, the greate frē de of God, eſt nobiſcum, is with vs, qui the which, vt, that, vinceret hoſtem praeliantem, he might ouercome his enemies warring againſte him, manus ad coelum extendit: Lifted vp his handes to heauē, iā tūc figurā crucis Chriſti oſtendēs, euen then ſhewing the figure of Chriſtes croſſe. Mart.

VVel done, howe ſaye yow nowe ſirra? Is not figura crucis Latine, for the figure of the croſſe? and oſtēdere Latine to ſhewe, and manus Moyſi, Moyſes handes? See yow not by this time, that the lyfting vp of Moyſes hādes did prefigure the croſſe of Chriſte? VVell done, to the nexte.

p.hi: Ille ſuperbiſsimus ſpiritus, that moſte proude ſpirite,
negās tranſitum, denying paſſage ad terrā promiſsionis to the lande of promiſſe, ſuperatur is ouercommed, per crucem domini, by the croſſe of our lorde, quae, the which, praefigurata eſt,
was prefigured, manibus Moyſi, with Moyſes handes.

div.p:
Howe ſaye yow nowe, is not figura caucis Latine, for the figure of the croſſe, and oſtendere Latine to ſhewe, and manus Moyſi Moyſes handes? VVhat ſay you to this? Did not Moyſes handes prefigure the croſſe, being lyfted in ſuch ſort as they were? VVhat will you haue playne • ? recante for ſhame, no ſhifte will ſerue yow. Yow can not ſaye that S. Auguſtine taketh figuram crucis, the figure of the croſſe, to be the deathe of Chriſte, for an externall figure of a thing cā not be one with the thing it ſelfe, and S. Auguſtine ſayeth not, Moyſes handes did ſhewe the croſſe, but figuram crucis, the figure of the croſſe, which argueth that you can not make the figure of the croſſe, and the croſſe, which is the deathe of Chriſte, to be all one, vnleſſe yow will
make. S. Auguſtine fall into the Manichees hereſye, and ſaye that Chriſtes paſsion was figuratiue, and not true, and in deede, which is too ſoone for Sathans purpoſe to beginne as yet. The harueſt is not ripe, nor the harueſt men framed to that Iewer, albeit ſome be more readier than ſome. Amonges whome take hede M. Calf. that he be not accompted one, that hath ſeparated him ſelfe frome the vnitie of Chriſtes church, and ſaieth that the ſinceritie of Gods ordinance was refuſed within twoo hundred yeres after Chriſt, Fol. 96 a Fol. 85 b and that ſythens Sylueſters time, in moſt partes of Chriſtendome a man could not haue eſpied any piece of ſinceritie, hauing as many eies as Argus, and counterfeting a newe religion, prophaneth the ſacraments of the church, breaketh the olde ordinaunces, and contemneth all the aunciēt fathers in compariſon of him ſelfe, and thincketh that he and his onelye haue the true meaning and ſenſe of Gods worde, ſuch as the holy Ghoſt neuer reueled before theſe latter dayes. For of ſuch factes a vehement preſumption is ſoone gathered.

Lib. 20. ca. 8. de ciui. Dei. Fol. 43. bYow finde faute whith me for interpreting thoſe wordes of S. Auguſtine, Manibus in figuram crucis extenſis, his handes helde vp a croſſe, and woulde haue it worde for worde interpreted, Manihus his handes, extenſis, ſtreached oute, in figuram crucis in the forme of a croſſe. That mē maye not thīcke that yow haue no iuſte cauſe to quarrell, I paſſe not a pointe to cōfeſſe an ouerſight in the interpretation of thoſe wordes: for if I did, yowe ſhoulde haue no aduantadge by it. For whether Moyſes handes were ſtretched out in the forme of a croſſe, or helde vp a croſſe, it maketh againſt yower aſſertion, and proueth playnly that it prefigured the ſigne of the croſſe, as is proued by the places of S. Auguſtine recited before.

Nor haue we as yow fooliſhlye ſurmiſe by that allegation bewrayed our ignorance: for a man maye holde vp his handes a croſſe,Fol 43. b and neuer neede to putte one hande ouer an other, and frame as yow ſaye a S. Andrewes croſſe, Nether neede we ſaye that Moyſes to repreſente the croſſe which we haue in the
church, put one of his handes vnder his other elbowe, which were a ſtrange thing to be done, and meete for ſome tumbler. For if he had but helde vp his handes, the very holdinge vp of them had prefigured, and repreſented the miſterye and ſigne of the croſſe. For as S. Ciprian ſayethe by liftinge vp the handes, S Cypriā de coena domini. Arnobius li. 8 aduerſus gentes. Fol. 43. b. the miſterye of the Croſſe is repreſented, vnto vs. And Arnobius ſayeth, Cum homo porrectis manibus orat, ſignū Crucis eſt. VVhen a man prayeth hauing his handes ſtretcht out it is a ſigne of the croſſe. But let me take yower owne interpretation and ſee what argument maye be builded of it, againſte yow. Yow ſay, the ſtretching fooorth of handes in the figure of a croſſe, (for ſo yow meane) is at the armes ende, as Chriſtes was on the croſſe, but the ſtretching foorth of Moyſes hādes, was in the figure of a croſſe, at the armes ende, ergo it was like the ſtretching of Chriſtes hā des on the croſſe, and ſo conſequentlye did prefigure the croſſe, as by yower owne interpretation it is playnlie conuinced. I woulde thancke yowe for it, but it was againſte yower will.

As for the greeke Υ Pithagoras letter,Fol. 44 a which yow ſaye was the olde figure of the croſſe, and haue no better proufe for it, than a glaſſe windowe in a gallery at Lambeth, I will leaue it to the painter, and glaſier, vntill yow can ſhewe more antiquitie for thatt, then we can for this. And ſeing yowe make yower ſelfe ſo ſkillfull an antiquarie, and lerned in olde monumentes, ſaue yower poore credite, and ſmale honeſtie, and bring foorth but one preſident of ſcripture, and antiquitie, contrarye to the forme of the croſſe which we vſe, and to inſtructe poore ſoules that woulde learne, recite but one place, or expreſſe texte of ſcripture,Fol. 44 a which is (as yow ſaye) againſt the hauing of the ſigne of the croſſe, Nō facies tibi ſculptile, thowe ſhalt make to the ſelf no grauen thing, VVil not ſerue for it. Hitherto againſt yower fonde awnſwers, to the authorites of the fathers broughte to proue that the ſigne of the croſſe was not foreſhewen by the figures of the lawe.

Nowe let vs heare whether yow had iuſte cauſe of laughter with indignation againſte my argument made,Fol 44 a vpon the place
of S. Auguſtine, and thence procede to yower replies againſte the predictions of the prophetts. S. Auguſtines wordes be thes. That moſte proude ſpirite mediatour to bringe men to hell etc is diſcomfited by the croſſe of our lorde, Lib. 4. de Trinitate cap. 15. which was prefigured by the hādes of Moyſes. To this maior propoſition of S. Auguſtines, I added this minor, and concluſion. But by Moyſes handes, the ſigne of the croſſe, was prefigured, ergo by the ſigne of the croſſe, diuells are ouercommed. Nowe ſir is there, nor witt, nor common ſenſe, (as yow ſaye) in this argument? Fol 44. a Or was S. Auguſtine, in yower iudgement, ſo wittleſſe and voyde of commō ſenſe, that he vnderſtoode not what he ſaid, when he made that maior propoſition? or is the minor, ſo farre out of ſquare, that it can not be ioyned with the maior? Or is the cōcluſion ſo abſurde that it can not followe of the premiſſes? Iudge by yower owne argumēt: yow woulde haue it thus.Fol 44. a Diuells are diſcōfited by that which Moyſes handes prefigured: but Moyſes handes prefigured the ſigne of the croſſe, ergo by the ſigne of the croſſe diuells are diſcomfited. Is not this all one in effecte? Haue yow not the ſame matter, and the ſame ſenſe, that I had in myne? And haue altered nothing, but added a terme, and lefte out certayne wordes, which I added to make it more playne, VVhich doth not infringe the ſubſtance and grounde of the argumēt, but the forme and faſhiō onelye? And wil you laughe with indignation at an argument all one in effecte with yower owne, becauſe it is not in mode and figure? Dothe not yower Logicke teache yow, that the argument that lacketh mode and figure is not to be reproued as euill, nor the former of it, voyde of witt and cō mon ſenſe, if it be reducible to any mode and figure? Haue you not hearde of manye ſuch in Logicke? And if yow haue forgotte this, maye we not laugh (not as yow doe with indignation (for that maye welbe called a dogges laughter) but with good reaſon at yower malepertneſſe in findīge faute with that, which to no man that hathe wit, or common ſenſe, ſeemeth reprehenſible? VVeighe it well M. Calf. and for proufe of the minor, which yow thincke worthie to be denyed, ſeeke to that which
I ſaied euen nowe of the lifting vp of Moyſes handes.

Nowe to his croſſe anſwers againſte the ſigne of Tau,The ſigne of Tau. Fol 44 b he profeſſeth him ſelfe to be a mā of greate learning, and to haue depe ſighte in manye ſciences, and yeat when it cometh to triall, he is proued to vtter nothing but idle fumes, and vayne toyes, to whome I am ſumwhat beholding. For where before, to inſtructe ſuch young ſchollers as I am, he ſaide nothing, nowe for my furder lerning, he will adde ſomewhat, which in the ende ſhalbe, for anye good reaſon or wiſdome, leſſe thā nothing. Heare it I beſeche yowe, for yower inſtruction as well as for myne. Tau (ſayeth he) which Ezechiell ſpoke of, Calf. did not figure our croſſe, for the prophets ſpake Hebrewe, and the Hebrewe character is a very paire of Gallowes. Here, it is to be noted,Mart. that either M. Calf. hath not charitably accōpained his bretherne, neither to Tiburne, nor to S. Thomas of VVaters, and taken a true viewe, and proportion of the Gallowes, either that he is not ſo good an Hebrewe, as by pronouncing his wordes Noah and Eliſsha, after the ſounde of that tongue, as the parrat dothe her 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he woulde make the poore prenteſes of London beleue. For albeit the Hebrewe character ſomewhat reſemblethe a payre of Gallowes, yet hath it not the verye figure of a Gallowes. A difference there is, for one lyne is longer, and not ſo ſmothelye drawē neither aboue, nor beneathe, as the Gallowe poſtes are. VVerfore vnleſſe the Gallowes that he ſawe laſte, was iointed, for ſome diſpleaſure done to the brotherhoode, in one poſt, and made ſhorter then an other like a Iambus, I maruell that M. Calf. woulde ſo definitiuely ſaye, that the Hebrewe character is a very Gallowes. He mighte haue had a trewer figure and proportion of a very gallowes in an other Hebrewe letter 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , if his ſight had bene good, but that he would nedes playe the gallowes, and to bringe men in hatred with the croſſe, terme it a verye gallowes, as ſome preachers aboute Cā terburye haue done. But howe fondlye he fayleth in this, and betrayeth his ignorance in the Hebrewe character, yowe ſhall heare.

The charecters which the olde Hebrwes vſed when Moyſes, and the prophetes wrote, were ſomewhat differing frome thoſe which we haue nowe, and eſpeciallie the laſte letter Tau, as it is euident by S. Hierome,In 9. Ezech. vpon the nīght of Ezechiell, where he ſayeth: Antiquis Hebraeorum literis quibus hodie vtuntur Samaritani extrema Tau litera crucis habet ſimilitudinem, The hebrue letter Tau hath the true foorme of our croſſe. quae in Chriſtianorum frontibus pingitur, & frequenti manus inſcriptione ſignatur. That is to ſaye. In the olde auncient letters of the Hebrewes, which the Samaritanes vſe at this preſent, the laſte letter Tau hath the likenes and forme of the croſſe, which is paynted in the foreheade of the Chriſtians, and ſigned with often impreſsion of the hande. Thus much S. Hierome: who with paynful trauail, lōge ſtudie, and greate chardge, attayned a great excellēcie in the Hebrewe tongue: where note firſte, that in calling them the olde letters of the Hebrewes, he declareth, that they which were vſed in his time, were newe and differīg frome the other. As if we would ſay, this was the olde faſhion, this was the olde coyne, this was the olde lawe, it is to be vnderſtāded, that nowe we haue a newe faſhiō, a newe coyne, and a newe lawe, differing frome the other. Secondarilie in ſaying that the Samaritanes vſe thoſe charecters at this preſent, he proueth not onlye a manifeſt differēce, but declareth that in his dayes they were vſed, yea and ſeene, no doubte of him ſelfe. VVherupon he boldelye pronounceth, that the Hebrewe letter Tau had the verye figure and forme of the croſſe, which is paynted in Chriſten mens forheades, and ſigned with the often impreſsion of the hande. VVherfore vnleſſe M. Calf. will ſay, that Chriſtē men heretofore, had a gallowes painted in their foreheades, and the figure of twoe poſtes with a beame ouerthwhart, ſigned with often impreſsion of the hand in their foreheades, he can not bringe to paſſe that the Hebrewe letter Tau, which Ezechiel writing in Hebrewe vſed, and at the commaundement of God ſigned in mens foreheades, is a very gallowes, nor any man ells, but ſuch as with M. Calf will make a quarell to the gallowes, or gallye poſtes.

Vpon this place of S. Hierome, euery ſimple ſoule maye reaſon thus with our greate Hebrewe man, that ſayeth,Fol. 45. a there is
no lickneſſe betwixte that Hebrewe letter Tau that Ezechiel vſed, and our croſſe. The laſte letter which the olde Hebrewes had, and Samaritanes vſe at this daye, hathe the likeneſſe and forme of the croſſe which is printed with the hāde, in Chriſten mens foreheades, but Tau is the laſte letter, which the olde Hebrewes had, and Samaritanes vſe at this daye, ergo Tau hathe the likneſſe and forme of the croſſe that is printed in Chriſten mens foreheades. And that is the true ſigne of our croſſe, ergo the olde Hebrewe lettre Tau hath the true ſigne of our croſſe. VVhich parte of this argumente will M. Calf. denie? the maior is S. Hieromes,Anſvver directly M. Calf. a man much better lerned in the Hebrewe tonge then he is. The minor can not be denied it is alſo S. Hieroms, the premiſſes then being true, and the forme of the argument good the concluſion muſt nedes followe. VVhere is nowe the greate lerning of our profounde clerke become, that will teache other that which he hath not him ſelfe? Is this the addition that he will geue for our furder lerning: Fol. 44. b this and no other? Awaye with it for ſhame. It is meeter for Coblers of quene hyue, and drūckardes at S. Katherins, and others that are well ſene in ciathis ebriorum, than for thoſe which profeſſe then ſelues maiſter readers in characteribus Hebraeorum.

VVe are taught an other leſſon for our furder learning, and truer inſtruction of the bleſſed father S. Hierome, more ſounde and ſtronge, than can be remoued with the fantaſie of ſo yoūge an Hebrewe. Yoūge for his ſkill, and olde for his malice. For vnleſſe he woulde haue willingelye erred, and malitiouſlye deceaued, he coulde not choſe but ſee this place that I haue alledged. For it followeth in the very nexte worde to the ſentē ce that he him ſelfe recited oute of S. Hierome, in the ſame chapiter. VVherfore truſte him as yow finde him. Yow haue S. Hieromes workes, yow I meane that be learned, confer the place, and ſee his ſubtilitie, & warne yower frēdes of it. Nor deaceaue, nor be deceaued any lōger. You that haue no ſighte in the latin • tongue, deſire ſome to peruſe the place, and when yow haue tried the truth crye Vae to him for deceauinge you, and ſhame to yower ſelues that being wiſe men beleue ſo fooliſhe a caulfe.

Homi. 14.Yf any wil not beleue this, for furder inſtruction he maye adde the wordes of S. Chriſoſtome vpon S. Marke, where he ſayeth, The myſterye of the croſſe, is ſhewed in the number of thre hundred. The letter Tau is a note of three hundred, whervpon it is ſaide in Ezechiel. Cap. 9. And thou ſhalt write Tau, in the foreheades of them, that moorne. And whoſoeuer hath that written vpon him ſhall not be killed. For whoſoeuer hath the ſigne of the croſſe in his forehead he can not be ſtrooken of the diuell: And if that will not content him, take Tertullian more auncient wel nigh by ij. hundred yeares, he ſayeth: God did foretell that Chriſte ſhoulde ſuffer perſecution, and his Apoſtles in like ſorte and all faithfull men ſigned, Illa ſcilicet nota de qua Ezechiel, etc. with that marke of which Ezechiel ſpeaketh, The ſigne Tau. in Ezechiel ſignifieth our croſſe. our lorde ſaid vnto me paſſe in the midſt of the gate in the midſt of Hieruſalē, and geue the ſignes of Tau in the forheads of mē. Tau is a lettre of the Greekes, and our Tau is a ſigne of the croſſe, which he did portēd or foreſhewe, that it ſhould be in our forheads in the true and Catholike Hieruſalē. This cōſidered, I truſt you will better creditte the authoririe of theſe fathers, declaring manifeſtly that the olde letter Tau which Ezechiell mentioneth hath the likenes of the croſſe of Chriſt, printed in Chriſten mens foreheades, than the follye of M. Calf. that ſaieth it is a very gallowes,Fol. 44. b and biddeth, vs goe to the idol Serapis, Yf we will haue any figure of olde time for the croſſe, which we haue in expreſſe ſignification and foorme ſhewed of God him ſelfe, by his holy prophete Ezechiel. But if we had no preſident of antiquitie for the ſigne of the croſſe, as M. Calfehill full calviſhlye cauilleth, what ſhame were it to take a paterne there? May we not take ſalutem ex inimicis? Helth of our enemies? and inſtructiō out of the gentills writings? The olde fathers thinke it laufull. Yf there were a Iewe in Englande M. Calf. that wrote the Hebrewe characteres ſo faire and fyne as no man in the worlde could counterfeate the like, I ſuppoſe yow woulde thincke it no ſhame to yower worſhippe, nor diſhonour to yower perſon, to go vnto him, and purchaſe a copie of his charecters. But to inſtructe ſo longe a reader at Paules, ſo olde a M. of arte, and ſo cunning a Bacheler of Diuinitie as you are, I will declare for yower furder learning, and better inſtruction, becauſe I perceaue
yow content yower ſelfe with Engliſhe Doctors, and doe but ſkimme ouer the eccleſiaſticall hiſtories, and auncient fathers, I, I ſaye, being ſometimes vſher of VVincheſter will declare that this ſigne was not in the idol of Serapis, by any knowledge of the Egiptians, but by the ſecret diſpoſition and eternal prouidence of God. Socrates an auncient hiſtoriographer, talking of the idol Serapis, amonges other thinges, ſayethe thus. But I doe not thīcke that the prieſtes of the Egiptians foreknewe the cumming of Chriſte, and made the ſigne of the croſſe. The croſſe ſet in Serapis by the prouidence of Coll 1. For if the myſterie of the cumming of our lorde was hidde (as the Apoſtle ſayeth) and kepte priuie frome the prince of naughtines the deuill, howe much more was it kepte priuie frome his ſeruantes the Egyptian prieſtes? but the prouidence of God did make this before, that that might be done in queſtioning aboute thoſe letters, which was ſhewed in the Apoſtle S. Paule. Act 17. For he enriched with the holy Ghoſte, brought many of the Athenians to the faith, at what time, as he expounded thoſe thinges which were written in the aulter, as he in his owne opinion thought beſte: except peraduenture ſome man will ſaye that God wrought, in the Egiptians prieſtes, as he did in Balaam and Caiphas. For they alſo are ſaid to haue prophecied. Thus farre Socrates: where note (good readers) that if we had to go to Serapis, M. Calf. by ſendīg vs to Serapis, for a patterne of the croſſe, ſendeth vs to the prouidence of God. for a patterne of our croſſe, as M. Calf. woulde haue vs, we ſhoulde go to that which God him ſelfe foremade, to that which God by his prouidence ordeyned, to that which in thoſe letters he woulde ha-prophecied, and ſo directlye to Gods ordinance, and haue in Serapis that bleſſed ſigne, which according to the olde traditiō and interpretation of their holy letters, ſignified vitam futuram, the life to come.

Nowe a worde of his greate marueling, and my wondering to ſhut vp this chapiter.Fol 45. a b Calf. I maruell quoth M. Calf. what • oye came into yower idle heade, when for a proofe of the vndoubted ſigne of the croſſe, yow bringe foorthe the woordes of the Pſalme, O lorde the lighte of thy countenaunce is ſealed on vs. Mart. And I wonder what braineſicke paſsion pearced yower witte, when yow deuiſed to chardge me with that which I neuer ſaid, nor any indifferent man can gather of my wordes. To declare
that yow deuiſe matter of marueling as a vice doth of laughter on a ſcaffolde, when he hath noughte to ſaye, I will repete my wordes of which yow take occaſion to maruell. In the xxx. leafe and ſeconde page, which according to yower promiſſe you quote not after yower apointed order, becauſe belike the reader ſhould not confer the place,Eſa 49. and ſee yower falſe iuggingle, I ſay thus. Againe by his ſaide prophet, he ſayeth: Beholde I will lifte vp my handes to all nations, and ſet vp my ſigne on high to all people. That ſigne ſayeth: S. Hierome is vndoubtedly the ſigne of the croſſe, which God alſo ſignified in the ſame prophet,Eſa 66. and put (as S. Hierome there declareth) in our foreheades, that we may freely and franklye ſaye: Pſal. 4. Signatum eſt ſuper nos, lumen vultus tui domine. O lorde the light of thy countenaunce is ſigned and ſealed vpon vs: Thes are my wordes repeted orderlye as they lye in the booke: Nowe ſir in all this where finde yow that the wordes of the Pſalme are brought for an vndoubted proufe of the ſigne of the croſſe? Is yower ſkill ſo ſmall, that yow can not conceaue what is meāt by ſo ſmale a ſentēce ſet out in Engliſh? Is yower eye ſight ſo dimme that yow can neither ſee the name of Eſaye and S. Hierome in the texte, neither the 66. chapiter quoted in the margent? But when I bringe a ſentēce to one purpoſe, muſt yow wreaſte it to an other, when I ſpeake out of Eſaye, muſt you anſwer out of Ezechiell? when I cite S. Hierome in one place, muſt yow take his wordes ſpoken in an other place? I am ſorye for it, and wiſhe yow a guide to directe yower ſtepps, and ſome Collirium to purge yower eies, leaſte if yow continewe in ſuch blindenes, yow fall into the ditche, and drawe to the increaſinge of yower owne damnation diuerſe ſeely ſoules with you. Did you not ſee that firſt I brought the ſaying of the prophete Eſai, in the 24. chapiter, and S. Hieroms interpretatiō vpō that place for the croſſe, and afterward for furder euidence of the ſame noted the 66. chapiter of the ſaied prophete, and S. Hierome declaring that God did putte that ſigne in our forheads, that when we had receued that ſigne in our forheads, at baptiſme, and lerned the faith of Chriſt, we might freely and franckely ſay, Signatū eſt ſuper nos lumen vultus tui Domine? O lord the light
of thy countynance is ſigned and ſealed vpon vs? And if you did ſee it, why did you diſſemble it? Is it not euident ynough that the woordes of the pſalme vſed in that place by S. Hierome declare the end why God would haue that ſigne to be printed in men foreheads? and that the end was nothing els, but that when they had receaued that ſigne at baptiſme, and were nowe made children of inheritāce and lightned with the light of faith and grace, they might reioyſe in God, and ſing that ioyful ſonge. O lord the light of thy countynāce as ſigned and ſealed vpō vs, we are ſure of thy fauour, and certayne of thy grace, for we haue thy ſignet, we haue thy ſeale, we haue that marke which thou wouldeſt to be ſet in the forheads of all thy faithfull? And if this be not playne ynough what is playne? Certes whē I wroteit, I toke it to be playne ynough for all that had witte to conceaue, or eies to ſee. Howe ſoeuer it be, yower ſhiftīg vayne was very barrayne, when this was deuiſed, and yower copye far ſpēt, when this refuge was ſought to put it in the readers eares, that we are ſo inſenſible, as to thincke, that either the wood in the roode lofte, Fol. 45. b. or Crucifixe on the aulter is the lighte of Gods continaunce, or that it can be printed in the fleaſhly foreheades with a finger.

Such imaginations are to groſſe, and heatheniſhe, vnfitte, either to be vttred in mouth, or conceaued in hearte of one Chriſtiā againſt an other. And certes M. Calf. if there were any ſuch euangelicall charitie in yow as Chriſte requireth, ſuch a ſurmiſe ſhould neuer haue entred into yower hearte, much leſſe haue bene ſpoken with tōgue and vttered in printe to yower perpetuall infamye. Take heede: Qui amat periculum, peribit in eo. Eccleſi. 3. M. Calfs. braule about the ſhevving of the croſſe frō heauen to Conſtantine. He that loueth danger ſhall periſh in it.

Yower braule made aboute the ſhewinge of the ſigne of the croſſe frome heauen to Cōſtantine, the greate maye welbe compared to an angrye and cholericke ruffians fighte. For as he in his vehemēt paſsion, werieth him ſelfe with vayne blowes, and openeth his body to the enemies ſworde: righte ſo by yower triffling talke, yow haue opened yower groſſe ignorance, and
geuē the aduerſarie greate aduātage to trippe yow. Firſte yow confeſſe it to be true that a croſſe in the fourthe ſignification, ſuch as I ſpake of, was ſhewed frome heauen in the time of grace, wherein yow are cōtrarye to yower ſelfe, and iniurious to me: for yow ſaide in the beginning of this article, that this ſigne was not ſhewed frome heauē in the time of grace, Fol. 41 b and that if either of thoſe ſignes was prefigured in the lawe of nature, foreſhewen by the ſignes of Moyſes lawe, etc. Yow did me wronge in reprouing of me.

Fol. 45 bSecondly yow ſaye I haue good teſtimonye for this, wherin yow are a lyar in ſaying that there is no lauful preſident of the ſigne of the croſſe, Fol. 151. a but call it an idle deuiſe of man.

Fol. 45.Thirdlye that God commaūded him to make that ſigne, and carye it in his ſtandarde, wherin yow are contrary to yower ſelfe,Fol. 44. a for yow ſay a litle before that it is againſte Gods worde, to haue and occupie the ſigne of the croſſe.

Fol. 46. bFourthly yow confeſſe that Conſtantine ſett vp his croſſe in the markett place to the ende it might there remayne as a teſtimonye of the pouer of God, wherin yow are contrary to yower ſelfe,Fol. 26 a for in the firſte article yow ſaye that the croſſe was neuer receaued vpon good occaſion.

Fol. 46 aFiftelye yow ſaye, that whoſoeuer did beholde that ſigne of the croſſe, might by and by conceaue, of whoſe relligion this Emperour was, and in whoſe name he ouercame his foes, wherin yow are contrarye to yower ſelfe, for in the firſte article yow ſaye that a roode, or crucifixe are not able to ſhewe whoſe men we are: Fol. 33. a as the printe in the money dothe ſhewe whoſe the coyne is. VVherſoeuer that image and ſuperſcription is ſtamped, there is it certaine, who hathe right to the coyne. But who ſo euer hath the figure or ſtampe of a croſſe vpon them, ſhewe not therby whoſe ſeruantes they are.

Sixthlye that at the firſt gathering of the church together newelye come frome the gentils, Fol. 46. a the viſible ſigne of the croſſe was thought very neceſſarie. VVherin yow are contrarye to yower ſelfe, for the firſte gathering of the church together frome the gentillls, was by Chriſte and his Apoſtles. And if at that tyme it was thought very neceſſarye to haue the viſible ſigne of the croſſe, then was there either ſome precept or counſell geuen by Chriſte and his Apoſtles to haue that ſigne, but yow ſay, Chriſte lefte no precepte of his croſſe, amongeſt vs. Fol. 34. a b The Apoſtles neuer vſed the ſigne of the Croſſe, nor gaue any counſell, or commaundement for it.

Seuenthly yow graunte that by the croſſe, as an outwarde meane, mē mighte be broughte by a litle and a litle to thincke better of Chriſte and ſerue him. Fol. 7. a Fol. 11. a VVhich is bothe contrarye to yower doctrine in our preface, where yow call Images dū be doctors, which take out nothing ells but leſſons of lyes, and bringe no knowledge, but blinde in ignorance: and alſo to all your diſcourſe in the ninthe Article, where yow ſaye, that no croſſe can tell you (that is a Chriſten man, as I thincke) for ſo yow ſpeake in yower owne perſon,Fol 167. a Six cōtradictionum opeaning of one ſtorie. that Chriſte came once into the worlde, and ſo forthe. And is not this a greate foile for yow. Six contradictiōs ſo manifeſte, ſo euidēt, ſo open, in ſo litle rome in the opening of one ſtorie, without ſhame, of the worlde and feare, to deceaue the ſimple, beſides lies and other ſmothering ſmokes? O M. Calf: where were the twoe functions of yower ſoule, ſenſus & memoria, ſenſe and memorye? are they bothe loſte, and yet yow take vpon you to goe about like a peddler, with a fardle of lies? Beware what you doe,Fol. 36. a you ſaid euen nowe, Mendacem oportet eſſe memorem: A lyer muſte haue a good memorye.

The Philoſopher Ariſtotle ſaieth: Fumo & halitu carbonum, homines aggrauantur & plerun
