que exanimantur: De ſenſu & ſen • . Men are troobled with the ſmoke and breathing of coles, and oftē times ſtyfled. And ſo may yow with the ſmoke of vntruthes, ſmother of lies,
breathing of falſhodes be quicklye confounded.

Beſides theſe ſix contradictions yow mingle with the hiſtorie certaine notable lyes: for yow ſaye that the ſigne was not ſhewed from heauen to confirme Conſtantines faith, but to put him in aſſurance of the victorie, Luc. 5. which is very falſe. For it was as well ſhewed from heauen, firſt to bringe hym to the faith, and then confirme hym in it, as it was to put him in aſſurance of victorie.Lib 1. ca. 4 Conſider the ſtory. It is written in the Tripartite hiſtorie, that Cōſtātine deſirous to vanquiſhe and ouercome Maxentius, and delyuer the Romaynes frome his tyrannye, thought what God he might haue, to aide him in the warre: For he knewe, that the Gods which Diocletian did worſhipe, were able to doe nothing, and that his father contemning, the paganes relligion, lyued in much felicitie: And whiles he was in this meditation, he ſawe in his ſleepe the ſigne of the croſſe, placed very brighte in the elemēt, and angells ſaying vnto him, O Conſtantine in this ouercome. By this it apeareth that Conſtantine was yet neither Chriſtian nor earneſt Pagane. The Paganes Gods he deteſted, as impotēt, the Chriſtians lorde and God, he knewe to be omnipotent, yet God the ſonne crucified for them, he knewe not.

Nowe becauſe he ſhould knowe him, and beleue in him, and haue him for his ayde and ſuccour in the bataille, this ſigne was ſhewed him frome heauen: this miracle was wrought. And was not this M. Calf. to inſtructe hī and confirme hī in the faith?The end of miracles. Lib. 2. ca. 8. de ciuit. Dei. Capit. 62. quaeſt. ex nouo teſtamen. To what ende were all Chriſtes miracles, but to declare him ſelfe to be god, and to cōfirme mē in faith and beliefe of the ſame? Reade yow not in S. Auguſtine, that before the worlde beleued, miracles were neceſſarie, vt crederet mūdus, that the worlde mighte beleue? Haue yow not ſene this in ſentence him? Signes and vertues were done of the Apoſtles for that ende, that infidells mighte be allured to the faithe? And ſhall this ſigne be ſhewed from heauen not to inſtructe and confirme him the faithe? VVhat vanitie is this? too ſhameleſſe M. Calf. too ſhameleſſe, leaue it, or els yow ſhalbe but a vayne lyer. The principall end was to inſtructe him and confirme him in the faith, the ſecond to encourage him with hope of victorie, which yow might haue learned by
conſidering the circumſtance of the hiſtorie, and to what ende ſignes are ſhewed, and miracles wrought: But he that ſaide:3. Reg. 22. I wil goe foorthe and be a lying ſpirite in the mouth of all his prophetts, woulde not ſuffer yow ſo to doe.

And other lye yow make in recounting the ſhewing of the ſigne to Conſtantine a perſonall priuiledge. For a perſonall priuiledge paſſeth not the perſon, to whome it was geuen. It dieth with the perſon. Then if God woulde haue had this to haue bene a perſonal priuiledge, it ſhoulde neuer haue paſſed his perſon, but haue bene ſhewed onlye to Conſtantine, and ſeene of him onlye. It ſhoulde haue died with him, but many other did ſee it at that time, beſides Conſtantine as the ſtorie mentioneth.Lib. 1. cap. 4. Tripar. And Chriſten princes euer ſithens haue graued it in their flagges, portrayted it in their palaces, and made it in their foreheades, and continued it in their chappells, as experience teacheth.

Yf yow will haue it a perſonall priuiledge, becauſe Chriſte ſpake only to Conſtantine, and commaunded him to make that ſigne, by like reaſon yow may ſaye that Chriſte ſpeaking at his laſte ſupper to his diſciples onlye, and commaunding thē to doe thoſe thinges, that he did in remembrance, of him, gaue them but a perſonnall priuiledge. For he was alone with them in the parlour, he ſpake to none but to them, he ſaide to none but to them doe this in remembrance of me, and being perſonall it paſſed with their perſons. So euer ſithēs by yower diuinitie, there was none that had auctoritie to celebrate the memory of Chriſtes paſsion, ſo well you haue profited in Sathans ſchole.

A thirde lye yow make in ſaying that Conſtantine was newlye conuerted to the faith, before the apparitiō of the croſſe. Fol. 46. a. For as Socrates writeth, euen before the appearing of the ſigne He thought what God he might haue to helpe hī in battaille, which cogitation argueth that he was not cōuerted, to the faith: for faith is not to ſeke in what God the faithfull ſhall beleue,Lib. 9. ca. 9. hiſto. Eccle. nor of what God he ſhal haue ayde. And albeit Euſebius ſaieth, that whē he marched againſte Maxentius with his armye, he was a fauorer of Chriſtian relligion, (as ſome heathen Emperours were before)
and a worſhipper of the true God, as the Iewes are at this preſente, Yet not withſtanding he had not receaued the ſigne of our lordes paſsion, as the ſolemne manner is amongeſt vs, to bringe men firſte to Chriſte, and make them Chriſtians, wherupon the ſigne of the croſſe was ſhewed him in the Element, & ita coelitus inuitatus ad fidem, and ſo frome heauen inuited and called to the faith, he ſemethe to me no inferiour thē he was to whome it was ſaide Saul, Saul, why doſt thou perſecute me? By which yow ſee that he was called to the faith of Chriſt frō heauen,Acto. 22. which was by the apparition of the ſigne of the croſſe, and not before, as yow falſelye affirme.

Furder where yow interprete the wordes in hoc ſigno vince. ouerthrowe thine enemies in this ſigne, Fol 46. a Calf. Mart. that is to ſaye in his name, whome this figure repreſenteth, we require yow to proue this yower gloſe, either by ſome texte of ſcripture, or auctoritie of ſome auncient fathers. Yower bare aſſertion is to be counted lighter than a fether. Yower naked wordes noughte els but puffes of winde: otherwiſe yow for this preſumption ſhalbe taken either for a falſe gloſer, either a peruerſe corrupter and peruerter of Gods worde. In all ſcripture I beleue you ſhal not finde, ſignum, taken for Nomen, (that is to ſaye) this worde ſigne, for the name of God. Yf yow ſaye the name of God, is glorious, and adde furder, that whatſoeuer we aſke in his name, we ſhall obtaine, whatſoeuer is to be aſked of vs, muſte be aſked in his name, I graunte it, and all Chriſten men confeſſe, that there is no other name vnder heauen, by which we maye be ſaued, but the name of Chriſte, with all we ſay that our ſauiour Chriſt who made his holye name ſo glorious, and promiſed vs ſaluatiō, and all that we deſire, in his name, doth alſo ꝓmiſe in this place, victorie to Cōſtantine, in the ſigne of the croſſe. He ſaid not ouercome in my name,Chriſt ſaid not to Cōſtā tine, ouercome in my name but in this ſigne. but in hoc ſigno vince. Ouercome in this ſigne. He ſaid not, ouercome in his name, whome this ſigne repreſenteth, but in this ſigne which the element ſhewethe. And as he ꝓmiſed it, ſo he did ꝑforme it, in that ſigne he ouercame, his enemies and gotte the victorie. Not that the ſigne was of force, to fight, but that God gaue ſuch power to that ſigne where it was, that they ouerthrewe their enemies. For
proufe wherof, reade the ſtorye againe M. Calf.Lib. 1. cap 4. Tripat.

In Sozomemus yow ſhall finde thes wordes. Chriſte apeared to Conſtantine as he was a ſleepe with the ſigne, which he ſawe in the element, and commaunded that there ſhould be a figure of that ſigne made, quae auxilio foret, which ſhoulde be an ayde vnto him in the conflictes and ſkirmiſhes of his warres: Here I praye yow (ſir) who is antecedent to the relatyue, Quae, it is not, figuratio? then belike Chriſte woulde haue the ſigne and figure to be an ayde to the emperour in his warres, ouer and beſiders figuratum, the figured?

He would hym to ouercome in that ſigne ouer and beſides, his name whome that ſigne repreſented. And ſeing Chriſte willed him ouercome in that ſigne, and is able to geue ſufficient ſtrenght and power vnto it, and becauſe he promiſed it, woulde do it, ſhall we beleue the gloſe of yower idle heade, and diſcredite the wordes of Chriſtes mouthe and ſay, he bad him not ouercome in the ſigne, but in his name, whome that ſigne repreſenteth? No: Yf Chriſte had ment as yow imagine, it had bene as eaſye for him, to haue ſhewed his holy name, from heauen, as it was to ſhewe the ſigne of the croſſe, and as eaſy to commaunde the Emperour to write the name of Ieſus, and vſe that, as an ayde in warre, as it was to commaunde him to make the ſigne of the croſſe, and vſe that. But Chriſt did it not, not that he would not haue Conſtantine to putte his truſte and affiance in his name, or to looke for victorie of any other God, but of him, but that he woulde bring him to the faith, and declare the mightines of his power by the ſigne of the croſſe, vpō which he was crucified,Cōſtātine cauſed the ſigne of the croſſe to be paincted. Euſeb lib. 1 de vita Conſtant. Fol. 45 a Calf. Mart. which that it mighte be knowen to all the worlde, Conſtantine cauſed the ſigne of it, to be painted on a piller at his right hande with this inſcription. By this healthfull ſigne, a true token of vertue, I haue delyuered our citie from the yoke of the tyrant and made it free, which woordes you ſuppreſſe.

Againe ſir wheras yow ſay, that whatſoeuer it hath pleaſed God for his glories ſake at any time to do, muſt not be drawen for example to vs, VVill yow infer vpon it, that becauſe all thinges are not to be drawen for an example, therfore nothing
is to be drawen for an example vnto vs? As becauſe we can not faſte fourty dayes,Matt. 4. and 40. nightes, ſhall we not take example to faſte one day and one nighte? Or becauſe we cā not feede fyue thouſande with fyue barly lofes, and twoe fiſhes, ſhall we not take example to feede one or twoe poore Chriſtians?Ioan. 6. Or becauſe wee can not be ſo meeke, ſo patient, ſo hūble, ād ſo ready to geue our ſoules, for our flockes, as he was for the worlde, ſhall we not drawe vnto vs the exāples of his humilitie, and of his loue towardes vs? and learne by hī to be meke, patiēt, hūble, and readie to geue vp our ſelues, for his ſake? Or becauſe we cā not take exāple of his walkīg on the water,Matt 14. Luc. 8. to do the like, ſhall we not take example of his going to Iairus houſe to viſite the ſicke? Alas (good readers) what reaſon is there in this? Of whome ſhall we take example, if we take not example of God? who ſhalbe our patterne, if Chriſte be not? VVhome ſhall we followe, yf not hī in all thoſe thinges which are lawfull and poſsible for vs to followe? I truſte yower diuinitie will not deny this M. Calf. and if you do not deny it, then doth yower vniuerſalll propoſition what ſoeuer etc. make nothing againſte vs.Fol. 45. b For if ſome thinges that Chriſte did may be done, although all that he did may not be done, and examples drawen of ſome thinges vnto vs, albeit there can not be of all, there is no inconueniēce,Hovve Conſtantine vſed the croſſe. nor let, but that we may be bolde vpon the commaundement of Chriſt geuen to Conſtantine to make the ſigne of the croſſe and vſe it for an aide as he did, and drawe example vnto vs of that vertuous Emperour to make it in our foreheades, to ſet it vp in market places, to erecte it at our gates, to beare it in our handes, and honour it as he did.

Firſte Chriſte commaundeth nothing that is vnlaufull, and no other thing than the Chriſtians were commaunded of the holy Ghoſte by the bleſſed Apoſtles. Secondarily if his bleſſed will had ben, that this precept ſhould haue extended no furder than to Conſtātine, ſo many auncient, holy and lerned fathers woulde neuer ſo highly haue commended it, the generall councells directed by the holy Ghoſt, would neuer haue commaūded it, the Chriſtians in all ages, and all cuntries euer ſithens, ſhould
not without controlment, and threat of Gods diſpleaſure, haue continued it. VVherfore yow may be aſhamed to deceaue the ſimple people with ſuch pretenſed reaſons. And wheras yow haue ſaide nothing to any effect, to vaunte ſo cōfidētly, and ſay: VVhat preſidēt is this to preiudice my cauſe? Fol. 46. a As though yower fonde generall propoſition (but in dede particuler if malice had not made you blinde) forbidding vs to take example of God in ſome thinges, becauſe we may not take example of him in all,iiij. lies and ſix contradictions vttred in one ſtorie no preſidēt to preiudice M. Calfs. cauſe. 1. Tim. 1. Cap. 28. Prouer. 10 yower vaine gloſe in peruerting and altering Gods worde, yower iiij. lies, and ſix contradictions in repeating of one ſtory, were not a ſufficient preſident to preiudice yower cauſe, and diſcredit you for euer. Yower owne conſcience would cōdemne you in this caſe, vnleſſe you repelling conſcience, had made a ſhipwracke (as S. Paule ſaieth) about faith, and ſaid with thoſe Mynions, that which the prophet Eſai mentioneth: VVe haue put lying our hope, ād with lying we are defended. But beware, it is a brickle bridge to goe vpon, and an euill ſtaff to ſtay by. The VViſeman ſayeth: He that leaneth to lies, feadeth the windes, and the very ſelfe ſame man foloweth fleing birdes.

Here would I haue knitte vp the knott of Conſtantine,Contradictions. and paſſed to an other matter, but that I thought it good to put the reader in minde of certaine other cōtradictions, and an abſurde principle. The croſſe he ſaieth, is neceſſarie, and yet ſuperfluous, tolerable and yet impious. Neceſſarie to make Gentills thincke better of Chriſt, but ſuperfluous to put Chriſtians in remembraunce of Chriſt. Tolerable amonge them that came from infidelitie, but impious amongeſt them, that profeſſe Chriſtianitie, and that in reſpect of the abuſe? as though the abuſe could make a thing good of it ſelf, wicked and impious.

His abſurde principle is this: talking of ſuch extraordinarie meanes in which he accompteth the croſſe, he ſayeth:Fol. 46. b Calf. VVhatſoeuer our neede is through our owne defaulte, ſurely we ought not to haue them, that is to ſaye, theſe extraordinaries aydes: God is not pleaſed with them. VVhere is this in ſcripture?Mart. VVhat Prophet: VVhat Apoſtle, VVhat Euangeliſt, VVhat
councell, VVhat father euer taught this doctrine? VVhat reaſon is there in it? Yf we ſtande in nede of a thing, yea through our owne defaulte, ought we not to haue it? VVhat if a Ruffian quarreling with his companion be wounded, and ſo ſtande in nede of a ſurgion, ought he not to haue one? VVhat if a mā take a ſurfett, and ſtande in neede of a phiſitiōs counſell, ought he not to haue it? VVhat if yower ſelfe M. Calf. ſtoode in nede of a frē de to put you in remembraunce of yower dutie, ought you not to haue one? Yes verelie, and God wilbe nothing diſpleaſed with it, and ſo likewiſe in this caſe.

Charitie that knitteth all men togheter in one bodie with Chriſte willeth vs to do all that we can to edifie one an other.Epheſ 4. As apeareth by S. Paule, where he ſayeth: Chriſte hath geuen ſome Apoſtles, ſome Prophetes, ſome Euangeliſtes, ſome Paſtours, and Doctours to the conſummation of the ſaincts, into the worke of miniſtration to the edifying of the bodie of Chriſt. Seing then we be apoynted miniſters to edifie the bodie of Chriſte (that is to ſay all Chriſtians) we muſt omitte nothing that may appartaine vnto the edifying of them. VVherfor if they ſtand in neede of ſuch extraordinary meanes, as you M. Calf. mention, and may be edified by thē, they ought to haue them, and we to geue them. For we are apointed miniſters vnder Chriſte in aedificationem, 1. Cor. 14. to edifying, and all thinges muſt be done as S. Paule ſaieth to edifie. He him ſelfe vnderſtanding that the Corinthians could not receaue the myſteries of Chriſte,1. Cor. 3. but ſtoode in nede as yet of milde and ſweete doctrine, ſaieth: I gaue yow milke to drincke, and not harde meate, for as yet yow coulde not digeaſt it. Therby teaching vs to condeſcend to the infirmitie of our brethrē, and to do all that we can to edifie them. Our nature then being dull and heauye, and neding many helpes to prouoke it to the contemplation of heauēly thinges, and meditation of Chriſtes death and paſsion, we may vſe extraordinarie meanes to ſtirre vs vp the more, and bringe to memorie the merites of Chriſtes deathe. And ſeing amōgeſt all other meanes, the ſigne of the croſſe doth moſte liuely ſett Chriſt before our eies, as preching doth declare vnto the eares, there is no reaſon, but we may haue it, as God by the Apoſtles, Chriſte
in Conſtantine, the holy Ghoſt by the prelates of his churche, in 2. generall councells haue commaunded vs.

An other principle M. Calf. propoundeth vnto vs (good readers) fathred vpon Chriſoſtome Homi. 44. in 23.Fol. 46. b Matt. in opere im ꝑfecto. It is this.Calf. before the knowledge of God was in men it was reaſon that the pouer of God ſhould be knowen by the holynes of men, but nowe it is madneſſe. Mart. Here how faithfully he demeaneth him ſelfe, conſider I beſeche yow: firſt Chriſoſtome in all that Homilie hath no ſuch ſentēce, but amonge other thinges he ſaieth.good vvorkes neceſſary to ſaluation. An heretike doble the child of Hel. The chardge of interpreting ſcriptures cōmitted to Prieſtes To all men generally thes two are neceſſarye to ſaluation, true faith and good workes. Againe he ſayeth, he that goeth ouer to hereſies, is dooble the childe of hell, firſt becauſe he forſaketh the truth which he did holde. Secondarily becauſe he is become an enemy of truth. Beſides he ſaieth. Prieſtes are the key keepers to whome the chardge of teaching the worde of God, and interpretinge the ſcriptures is geuē, with many notable thinges, which M. Calf. could not or would not ſee, and conſider that, as he vſeth him for a witneſſe in ſome pointes, ſo he ſhould be preſſed to admit his teſtimonie in others, which would vtterly condemne him and all his. But what meaneth M. Calf. by this trowe you? Muſt not the power of God be knowen by the holines of men? VVil he be alwaies like him ſelfe, and deny the ſcripture? Doth not Chriſt ſay:Matt. 5. Sic luceat lux veſtra, lett yower lighte ſo ſhine before men, that they may ſee yower good workes, and glorifie yower father which is in heauē? doth not the holy ghoſte ſay vnto vs by S. Paule,1. Cor. 6. God glorificed by our good vvoortes. Glorifie and cary God in yower bodies? And if we muſt glorifie God by our good workes, and cary hī in our bodies by holines of life, muſt not his power be knowen by our good workes and holines? If M. Calf. denye this, I would faine learne of him, what it is to glorifie God, if it be not to make his omnipotency and mightie pouer knowē vnto all the worlde? But he will ſay,Calf. his ſecretary wrote euill, and the compoſitour ſette worſe, and the ouerſeer or Correctour did ouerſee it worſt of all. It is in the 24. Homilie of the ſame worke fathered vpon Chriſoſtome. Matt.

So is it alſo that the prieſtes, Put a weightie loode vpon them that come
to penance. Prieſtez inioyned penance. By which wordes and others in the ſame place, it may be proued, that prieſtes inioned mē penāce. VVhat ſayeth M. Calf. to that? Forſoothe Eraſmus affirmeth it vndoubtedlye to be none of Chriſoſtomes worke. Ah ſirrha, in one place and in one Homilie Chriſoſtome ſpake this, and he ſpake not that? what indifferency is this (good readers)? were it reaſon that he ſhould ſay, this is Chryſoſtomes ſaiyng, and yet ſay, that, that is not his ſaying, which he writeth in the ſame Homilie? I dare ſay you thinke not ſo: yet ſuch ſhiftes muſt proteſtants vſe to defend their hereſies. In dede I acknowledge that the auctour of that worke hath ſuch a ſaying, in that Homilie, and meaneth, that it is but madnes for men to ſeeke for miracles, and not to beleue the mightie worke, and dreadfull power of God, vnleſſe there be ſuch holynes in mē, that they worke ſuch miracles, and do ſuch cures as S. Paule did by the Napkins, and Partletts, that were ſent frome his bodye. But what is this agaīſt the Croſſe?M. Calfs. Similitude, Fol. 46. b Thincketh M. Calf. that this ſimilitude, As it is madneſſe to haue the power of God knowē by the holynes of mē, So the ſigne of the Croſſe is not only ſuperfluous, but alſo impious, will holde? It reſembleth no more the nature of a ſimilitude, than dothe an oxe of an elephant, ſauing that it hath the vſuall termes which euery bēchwhiſtler cā vſe. For a ſimilitude is a reſemblīg of one thīge to an other,VVhat is re
qui red in a Similitude. which muſt in ſome poīt be like, to that vnto which it is reſembled. It muſt cōtaine foure thīges, twoe that muſt be likened, and 2. wherin they muſt be likened. Let this be one for an exāple. As they greuouſly offende, who with poyſon infecte the cōmō fountayne, whēce al mē fet their water: So do they deſerue very euill of the cōmonweale, who do corrupt the prīce his minde with naughty coūſel. Here the commō fountaine, and princes minde are 2. thinges likened. The infecting of the fountaine with poyſon, and corrupting the princes minde with euill counſell are the thinges wherin they are likened. The reſembling of one to the other is good.

The foreſaid ſimilitude which M. Calf. ſeemeth to make of S. Chryſoſtomes wordes is a nowne heteroclite, maymed in twoe of his principle partes. Yf he had ſaid thus: As it is madneſſe
to haue the power of God knowē by the holines of men: So it is impious to haue his glorie ſett forthe by the croſſe, I would haue denied the ſecōd parte of this ſimilitude, and ſhewed reaſon of diuerſitie. But ſeing he vrgeth not ſo much, I wil vſe no more wordes then neede, only this I ſay, ſeing M. Calf. graunteth the ſigne of the croſſe to be not only tolerable, Fol 46. b but alſo neceſſarie, as Conſtantine vſed it, He may alſo graunte it to be not only tollerable, but alſo neceſſarie as Chriſtians nowe a daies vſe it. For we vſe it no otherwiſe than Conſtantine did.The Chriſtians vſe the croſſe no othervviſe thā Conſtātine did. He made the ſigne of the croſſe in his forehead, ſo doe we: he cauſed it to be paincted in a table: ſo doe we. He ſett it vp at his courte gate, ſo doe other Chriſtian princes in their palaces. He wrought it into his banner, vſed it in the warres: So do we into our flagges and enſignes. He ſette one of golde in the church vpon S. Paules tumbe, we ſett ſome of ſtone, timber and metall in churches, vpon the alters, in roode loftes, windowes, and ſo foorth. He did honour it callīg it: A ſinguler ſigne, and enſigne a tokē of much vertue and power, we reuerēce it with like epithetons, and titles of honour. To be ſhorte, VVe do vſe it as Conſtantine did vſe it, and no otherwiſe then Conſtantine vſed it. If the aduerſaries replie, and ſay that Conſtantine did neuer cap, nor knele, vnto the croſſe, lett thē proue that negatiue, by ſcripture, councel, or doctour: in this pointe I will ſtand with the beſt of them all, that no auncient writer, no famous hiſtoriographer, ſauoring of antiquitie, euer wrote, that the vertuous Emperour Conſtantine did not Cap, nor kneele, nor doe any other honour to the ſigne of the croſſe. VVhich negatiue when they proue, charing croſſe will ſay they lye, and this, till then.

Nowe to an other, M. Calfehill, perceauing that the aunciēt hiſtories make ſo often mētion of the croſſe ſhewed from heauen, that it can not be denied, but that it was a very true Croſſe, which was firſt made in Iulianus and the Iewes apparell,Lib. 5. ca. 50 Tripat. with a ſhooer of rayne, and afterward ſhewed from heauen, when they would haue builded the temple againe, gladly forgetteth his vaine aſſertion, that the ſigne of the croſſe was not prefigured in the lawe of nature, nor foreſhewen by the ſignes of
Moyſes lawe, nor denounced by the prophets, nor ſhewē from heauen in the time of grace, and as though he had neuer affirmed any ſuch thinge, paſſeth it away in ſilence, and findeth fault with the application, Fol. 48. b and yet geueth no cauſe why: but reſembleth me to a foole, that walketh in a nette, and to children that thinke they cā not be ſeene, whē their heades be hidde: which is as much to the purpoſe, as to proue a miniſter an honeſt man, ſome Ieſter would beginne to make a diſcourſe, of one that hath a heade like an ape, eies like an oule, eares like a Calf. A mouthe like a maſtyfe, teethe like a Tyger, and tongue like a dragon, and ſay no more, as this VViſeman doth.

That done, (finely as he imagined) fault is founde with a concluſion where I made none, but declared a cauſe, why God foreſhewed the ſigne of the croſſe by ſo many figures in the lawe of nature,VVhy the croſſe vvas prefigured. Moyſes, and the prophets, which was that we ſhould highly eſteeme the thing, which thoſe figures ſignified, and beleue that as thoſe figures wrought temporall benefites to the Iſraelites. So the truth (that is the croſſe it ſelfe) ſhall worke to vs, beleuing in Ieſus Chriſt, and hauing that ſigne printed in our foreheades, the like benefites etc. VVhen he heard this, as one ſet ſodenly in a chafe,Calf. Fol. 48 b he demandeth who tolde me, that the truth of thoſe figures was the croſſe it ſelfe? then how I proue that thoſe figures wrought temporall benefittes to the Iſraelittes?

Mart. Gene 2. Tēporall benefites vvrought to Iſraelites by the figures vvhich ſignified the croſſe. Gene. 48. Exod. 17. Ibidem.To coole that cholerike heate, I anſwer, Damaſcenus, Caſsiodorus, Cirillus, Ambroſius, Origenes Auguſtinus, Tertullian and Iuſtinus martir told me, that the truth of thoſe figures, was the Croſſe on which Chriſt died, and not only Chriſt him ſelfe. That they wrought to the Iſraelites temporall benefitts, I proue by the ſcripture. All that was lawfull for Adam to eate in paradiſe, wrought him temporall benefitte, before his fall. But the tree of life wes laufull for Adam to eate: ergo the tree of life wrought him temporall benefite. The arke of Noe preſerued him and his familie frome drowning. The bleſsing of Iacob made Ioſephs children increaſe into greate multitudes vpon the earthe, Moyſes rodd broughte water out of the rock in the wilderners, the
liftinge vp of Moyſes handes gotte thē the victorie ouer Amalech: The wood caſt into the riuer Marah made the water pleaſant and ſwete to drinck,Exod. 15. which was before very vnſavory and bitter. All theſe were figures of the croſſe, and the benefites tē porall wrought to the Iſraelits by the mightie power of God throughe them, as externall meanes, ergo by the figures of the croſſe tēporal benefites where wrought to the Iſraelites. Thus ſayeth the ſcripture ād holy worde of God.Calf. Fol 48. b But quoth M. Calf. yf they were cauſes of any good that came, they were cauſae ſtolidae, as Tullie calleth them, fooliſhe, meane, and inſtrumentall cawſes, and not efficient. Mart. But where doth Tullie tall them ſo M. Calf.? where doth he write, of Adam and the tree of life plāted in paradiſe? VVhere writeth he of Noes arke, Iacobs bleſsing, Moyſes rodde, ſtrekīg of the rock, lyfting vp af his hādes, the wood caſt into the ryuer Marah, or any ſuch? Tel vs for ſhame, where dothe he call them cauſas ſtolidas, foliſhe, meane and inſtrumental cauſes, and not efficient? Yf you be as cunning as ye bragge in Tullie, note the booke, quote the place, aſsigne the chapter? ſaue your poore honeſtie. VVe will not ceaſſe to call vpon you, vntill you tell vs, where Tullie calleth them, cauſas ſtolidas foliſh, meane and inſtrumental cauſes, and not efficiēt. VVhatſoeuer Tullie ſaieth of them: we are, ſure, that our Logicque taught vs ones, that omnes inſtrumentales cauſae ſunt in genere efficientium. All inſtrumental cauſes are in the nature and kinde of the efficient, and ſo were you as I ſuppoſe, before you lerned that Tullie called them, cauſas ſtolidas, The meanes by vvhich God vvrought benefittes to his people called, foliſh cauſes. foliſh cauſes. Note here good readers, the fruicte of hereſie, one that pretendeth to be a Chriſtian, out of Tullie findeth occaſion to controll Gods doinges. Becauſe he of his infinite mercy was the only efficient cauſe of all benefitts to the Iſraelites, and vſed the other as meanes and inſtruments to worke them by, M. Calf. lerneth of Tullie to calle thoſe meanes by which god wrought, Cauſas ſtolidas, fooliſh cauſes. Doth not Sathan ſhewe him ſelfe in his likneſſe here? Draweth he not well towarde a thinge called Atheiſme? See to what abſurditie the diuell will driue
him by diſputation,Horrible blaſphemie. he hath done no more allredy by his miniſter, but proued God, (which is horrible blaſphemie) a foole. Marke his reaſon. VVhoſoeuer worketh by fooliſhe cauſes or meanes, is a foole, but God wrought thoſe benefittes to the Iſraelites by fooliſh cauſes, ergo yow knowe what followeth. VVhich parte deny you M. Calf? all worldly wiſdome affirmeth the maior to be true, The minor is yower owne: the forme good: the concluſion muſt nedes followe. See you not to what abſurdities you fall, and profite apace in yower M. ſchole? who but you or one of yower profeſsion woulde haue fallen into ſuch horrible blaſphemy?
Hovve the nevve religion is mayntayned.
Arrogancie of heretikes. Can not yower doctrine be mainteyned with the ſcriptures denied, the councells diſauthoriſed, the fathers condēned, but muſt God be blaſphemed? Muſt the meanes by which he wrought benefites to his people be called: Stolidae cauſae, foliſh cauſes? O the arrogancie of heretikes. Frome cōtempt of men, they fall to blaſpheming of God, frome inuerting the ſenſe of his worde, they come to controlling of his wiſdome: with them the meanes that he worketh his benefites, be cauſae ſtolidae, fooliſhe cauſes. And becauſe M. Calf. is ſure of it, and proueth it out of Tullie, and yet ſheweth not where we ſhal finde it, men muſt beleue it. But that warrant is not ſufficiēt. Therfore be not deceaued (good readers) it is a lamentable caſe, VVhen a phraſe of Tullie muſt controll the doinges of God in diuinitie. A practiſe to be left to the heatheniſhe pagans, and not to be imitated of true Chriſtians: yet ſuch is the wiſdome of M. Calf. that to ſhifte the matter that he taketh in hāde, he ſticketh not to vſe it, and call the meanes wherby God woorketh, cauſas ſtolidas, foliſh cauſes.

Fol. 48. b Fol 49 a Calf.And where he ſayeth that becauſe I made no diſtinctiō of thoſe wordes which might be diuerſly takē, and ioyne the truthe and croſſe together, my meaninge is with couert ſpeache to deceaue the ſimple, and cauſe them to deriue the glory frome the truth, and tranffer it to a figure, to haue in reuerence the idle ſigne, Mart. and lett the thinge ſignified be forgotten, I woulde ſome good fellowe would tell him in my behalfe, that with
one breath he vttereth him ſelfe to haue an euill memorie, and a ſclanderous tongue. For in the beginning I made a diuiſion and diſtinction of that worde that mighte be diuerſly takē, and ſignified in what ſenſe I woulde haue it vnderſtoode. So that in other places, I neded not to vſe a vayne repetitiō of one thing: which yf M. Calf. remembred, why requireth he a newe diſtinction? Yf he did not, lett him goe to ſchole againe, and learne the arte memoratyue a litle better: or miſlike his witte for finding faulte where none can iuſtly be founde.

That his tongue is ſclanderous eche mā that hath eies may ſee. For by the whole diſcourſe of my treatiſe,M. Calfs. tongue ſclanderous. it may be ſeene that I require the ſigne of the Croſſe to be erected in churches, ſett vp in high wayes, had in priuate houſes,The cauſes vvhy I require the croſſe to be ſette vp. Fol. 49. b and printed in in mens foreheades, to make them remember Chriſte, and by often ſight of it, to be brought to the remembrance of his death, and memory of his paſsion, and ſo be ſtirred frome vice to vertue, frome the loue of the worlde, to the loue of God. Yet, as though he had crepte into my boſome, and ſearched the ſecrets of my heart, (which God only knoweth) he reporteth, that my meaninge is by couert ſpeache to deceaue the ſimple etc. and make them forgett Chriſte, which ſurmiſe is far vnſitting for one that profeſſeth Chriſtian charitie and ſinceritie of the goſpell, and very ſclanderous.

But like goſpell, like fruictes: where he biddeth mee,Fol. 49. a Marke Tertullians iudgement of the figures of the olde teſtament cō cerninge the Croſſe, I haue done it according to his aduertiſmēt and marked very well,M Calf. vnderſtadeth not Tertulliā. Lib. 3 aduerſ. Marcio. that wheras he ſtudieth to imitate Tullies phraſes, he vnderſtandeth not Tertullians ſenſe. For in the very ſentence which he alledgeth, praedicatio is not taken for preaching, but for predication, (that is foreſaying) as eche mā that conſidereth the circumſtance of the place, and noteth Tertullians ſtile, may eaſely ſee: for my parte becauſe the diſcuſsing of it is more curious, thā neceſſarie, I omitte it, and referr the iudgement of it to the learned. And returne to the examininge of the defaulte that he findeth with my application.

I ſaied the ſigne of the Croſſe was ſhewed Conſtantine in in his greate anxitie, to inſtruct vs that in al anxietie of minde and penſifnes of heart, the Croſſe of Chriſte ſhalbe our comforte,Calf. Fol. 49. b Mart. and the ſigne a meane to ouerthrowe our enemies. The firſt parte M. Calf. graunteth, the laſt he denieth, and aſketh where I finde it? As thoughe the very ſtory declaring that Chriſte commaunded the ſigne to be made, and vſed as a helpe, did not conuince, that, to all Chriſtians truſting in the merites of Chriſtes paſsion, it ſhoulde ſo be a meane to ouercome their ghoſtly enemies, as it was to Conſtantine to ouercome Maxentius, eſpecially whereas the Angells ſhewing the ſigne to Conſtantine ſaid, In hoc vince: Ouercome in this ſigne. But let vs heare M. Calfes reaſon why this may not be inferred vpon the ſtorie. He ſaieth:Calf. Mart. God hath more meanes of comforte than one, he deliuereth his that are in danger by diuerſe wayes. You take much paines to proue that which no man denieth, we graunte it. VVhat will you builde vpō this poſitiō againſt me? wil you ſay thus: Chriſte hath more meanes of comforte than one, and deliuereth his out of daunger by diuerſe wayes, ergo he deliuereth none by the ſigne of the croſſe, ergo the croſſe is no meanes of comforte? Yf you make this argument as you can make none other of this principle againſt myne aſſertion, I deny the conſequent, and bid you reſorte to the younge ſchollers, in the paruis ſchole, and conſult by what rule in Logicke that argumēt holdeth. And vpon conſultation with ſome lerned clerks in the facultie, I doubte not but you will ſay, deceptus perij miſer: I was deceaued poore man.

On like ſorte when that which you inferre vpon the apearing of God in a prieſtes attire to Alexander, and ſeruing of Paulinus in the habite of a gardiner ſhalbe examined, and proued to haue no liknes in a manner to the apparition of Conſtātine, and that you can not infer of them that we muſt haue the ſigne of a prieſt in his maſkinge garmentes, (for that is yowr ſcoffing terme) becauſe God apeared to Alexander in a prieſtes attire, Fol 49. b
or that we muſt haue a byſhope a gardiner, Fol. 51. a when priſoners muſt ſo be ranſomed, becauſe by Paulinus God deliuered ſome after a ſtrāge maner, You will ſay, I marked not the ſtory wel. I remembred not, that God ſaide to Conſtantine,
• n hoc vince, Ouercome in this ſigne, and ſaide nothing to Alexāder. I forgote that Chriſte apeared vnto Conſtātine the next night, and bidde him make the ſigne of the croſſe, and vſe it for a comforte and ayde in the warrs, and neuer willed Alexander to make any prieſtes apparell. It could not ſincke into my heade that Chriſten men bothe before that time, and euer ſithens vſed the ſigne of the croſſe, and had greate helpe by it, which they coulde neuer haue by a prieſtes apparell. And ſo when ſuite of lawe ſhalbe commenced againſt you, Caput quoniam ignorantes, muſt be your proctour, and illude all the action, with ſuch an exception.

Diogenes marueled muche at certayne grammarians that diligently inquired and ſearched out the miſeries of Vliſſes, Diogenes. and were ignorant of their owne. So may we iuſtly wonder at this curioſitie of M. Calf. who ſought out twoe longe hiſtories of Alexander and Paulinus, nothing to the purpoſe, and forgotte that which he had in hande of Conſtantine, of muche importance, and fitt for the purpoſe. For none but ſuch as lack wiſdome, would haue omitted to ſearch ſuch circumſtances as make againſte him, and thincke to bleare ſimple folkes eies with fanſies of his owne heade, coloured with the truth of twoe hiſtories.

Truth may by ſome outwarde ſhewe be coloured for a time, but it can not be hidde lōge. The Aſſe that had on the lions ſkin and woulde haue made his maſter afraide, was at lenght eſpied by his longe eares, and made ridiculous. But peraduenture, if M. Calf. were poſed of his ſuperintendēt, why he dallieth and trifleth, and vſeth ſuch vayne ſhiftes, that ech man may aſwell eſpy, as the good man eſpied his aſſe by his eares, I thincke he woulde anſwer as a fiſherman ſometimes cōtrolled for trooblinge the riuer,The fyſher Mās anſvver. and not ſuffring the neighbours to haue cleare water, anſwered: Niſi ſic fluuius perturbetur, me oportebit eſurientem mori. Vnleſſe the riuer be thus troobled, I muſt dye for hunger.
For certainly vnles he ſhoulde trooble the ryuer in ſuch ſorte, his eloquence were ſpent, and cauſe quite marred. The cleare water woulde quickly purge the filthy mudde that he ſtirreth. Marke and you ſhall ſee.

Lib. 5. cap. 50. Tripar. Sozomenus ſayeth, The ſigne of the croſſe made in Iulian and the Iewes apparell, did ſignifie after the interpretation of ſome, that the doctrine of the Chriſtians came frome God, and that all mē ought to be marked with the croſſe. M. Calf. troobleth the water here, and becauſe mē ſhoulde not beleue it,Calf. Fol. 51. b ſtirreth ſuch a mudde, as ſtincketh of follye a mile of. For he ſaieth: The croſſe noted Iulian and the Iewes to be ꝑſecutors, Mart. ergo it is neceſſary for vs to be noted as perſequutors. VVhere firſt it is to be noted that he vnderſtandeth not the hiſtorie. Iulian being a Chriſtian chaunged his relligion,Iulian a ſuperintendent and named him ſelfe a ſuperintendent of the Pagans, and cumminge into the temples of the paganes, did ſacrifice, and counſeled his ſubiectes to do the ſame. Now to declare that he had done very euill in forſaking his relligion, and ſacrificing to idolls, God ſhewed him twoe ſtrange and wonderfull thinges.Circa occaſum Pliadum, For when the vintinage was paſt, and all grapes gathered, the vines brought foorth newe grapes, and a ſhooer of rayne falling frome heauen made with euery droppe a ſigne of the croſſe in his ſouldiers apparell. Some ſaide the grapes growinge at ſuch vnſeaſonable time, ſignified that the Emperour ſhould be vndone, and his Empire of no longe continuance. And the croſſe did forſhewe that the doctrine of the Chriſtians came frome God,VVhat the croſſe ſignified vvhich vvas ſhevved to Iulian. Lib. 5. Tripar. cap. 50. Tripart. and that all men ought to deſigned with the croſſe, which interpretation to be true, tyme tried ſhortly after ſayethe Sozomenus. For he raigned but 3. yeares, and afterwarde, vnder Iouinian, and other Chriſtian Emperours the Chriſtian faith and relligion flooriſhed. By which you may perceaue, the cauſe of thoſe miracles ſhewed to Iulian, was to worke penaunce in him, and to make him returne vnto Chriſte, and obſerue that faith and relligion which by the ſigne of the croſſe was ſignified to be the true relligion that came frome heauen, and ſhould goe ouer the worlde: and not as M. Calf. fanſieth to note him to be a perſequutor.

He was in deede a blouddy Tyrante,Iulian not noted by the croſſe to be a perſequutor. and a terrible perſequutor as the ſtory teſtifieth, but that by the croſſe he was noted to be ſuch a one, all the diuinitie in M. Calfes brayne will neuer proue it. But if it had noted him to be a perſequutor: how doth this argument holde? The croſſe noted Iulian to be a perſequutor, ergo it is neceſſary for vs to be noted as perſequutors? Holdeth it not then tymes looſer, then his wauering heade, when he ietteth vp ād downe the ſtretes? Let the Lōdyners iudge, or iudge yower ſelfe by a like: The bearing of a fagotte before the croſſe in proceſsion, noted the bearer to be an heretike, ergo it is neceſſarie for all that beare faggotts to be noted as heretikes. And if there be good reaſon in the laſte, thincke that I haue done M. Calf. wronge in controlling the firſte.

Furder where he ſayeth:Fol. 51. b that none were maked but ſuch as had reneged their faithe, Yf he reſtrayneth his vniuerſall propoſition, to Iulian and his company, and that time, when they were marked, we graunte it to be trewe: Yf he meaneth it more generally, we vtterly deny it, as vayne, falſe, and moſt abſurde. For the Chriſtians in all ages were marked with the ſigne of the croſſe, as a token of their profeſsion and faith, only peculier and proper, to the Chriſtians, as I declared before.Fol. 51. b Thirdlye where he wiſheth that we may neuer haue occaſiō to be marked as Iulian was. Yf his wiſhe be, that we neuer haue like occaſion to renege our faith, it is godlye: Yf it be, that we ſhoulde not be marked as Iulian was with the croſſe, and when we haue forſaken God, be called to penaunce, by that, or ſome like viſible ſigne, by which it ſhall pleaſe him to ſhewe his mercye towardes vs, as he did to Iulian, if he had had grace to receaue it, it is moſte impious and vngodlye. For it is to wiſhe and praye that he maye not haue occaſion of grace miniſtred vnto him, to knowe him ſelfe, and returne to God.

Fourthly in ſaiyng,Fol. 51. b The croſſe alvvayes portēdeth goodneſſe that the croſſe doth not allwayes portende goodnes, he ſheweth much ignorance. For he ſemeth not to knowe that God being the only ſhewer of it frome heauen, and authour of all ſuch ſtrange fightes, and miracles worketh
all thinges to good to thoſe that loue him. The croſſe then, being the meane by which it pleaſed God to ſignifie vnto Iulian, that Chriſtes relligion, and faithe came from hauen, and that all men oughte to be ſigned with the Croſſe, coulde not, but portende vnto him greate goodnes, and haue wrought it in deede, yf he had not obdurated his owne harte like as Pharao did. Fiftelye I much maruell why he ſayeth,Fol. 51. b that the glittering ſigne of the Croſſe in the element, and Croſsinge of the Iewes cotes, was but a token of Gods wrath and vengeance, and that albeit it was ſignum Crucis ſalutaris, the ſigne of the healthfull croſſe, yet it was not healthfull to them etc. The croſſe ſhevved to Iulian vvas a token of the loue of God yf he could haue ſo conceaued it. Lib. 6. ca. 43 Tripar. For albeit it ſignified that God was angrie with their enterpriſe, yet it ſignified not that onlye, but alſo declared his eſpeciall loue in making them vnderſtande that he was God, whome their forefathers crucified, that his death being acknowledged, and faith in his paſsion cō ceaued they might turne vnto hym and be ſaued. And ſo of likelyhoode diuerſe were. For as the ſtory mentioneth, many cō ſidering that which happened, and fearing the plagues and ſtroke of God, returned home to their houſes, confeſsing hym to be God whome their fore fathers had nayled vpon the croſſe.

Againe that the croſſe otherwiſe healthfull, was not healthfull vnto them, the faulte was in their follye, that woulde not ſo demeane them ſelues that they might haue benefitte by it, and not in the croſſe, which through the vertue of Chriſtes paſſion, is healthfull to all that be not a ſtoppe, and occaſion of the contrary. Thus yow ſee (good readers) that bothe the examples brought for proufe that the ſigne of the croſſe was ſhewed from heauen in the time of grace, and alſo the auctorities of the fathers alleadged, to declare that it was foreſhewen by the figures of the lawe of nature, and Moyſes, and denounced by the prophetts, ſtande in their force, and are nothing impayred by M. Calfs. battrie, nor impugned by his bable.

VVherfore his dealīg in this caſe may be well compared to the deuiſe of a politike practiſer, knighte of the order of Macheuel, who vnderſtandinge that the proteſtantes were diſcomfited
in their rebellion againſte the kinge in Fraunce, gaue out letters to his frendes, that the prince had wonne the feilde, to comforte them for a time. And ſeing M. Calf. ſayeth: he coulde not ſee that the croſſe of Chriſte was prefigured in the figures of the olde teſtament, in like māner as Fauſtus the Manichee cried, that he could not finde any thing that apparteyned to the foreſhewing of Chriſte him ſelfe, yow may ſaye as S. Auguſtine did of Fauſtus. Quid autem mirum, ſi oculos habet, ad legendum, Fol. 41. b Lib 12 ca. 30. contra Fauſt. Manich. cor autem non habet ad intelligendum, qui poſitus ante oſtium dominici ſecreti, nō fide pietatis pulſat, ſed elatione impietatis inſultat. VVhat maruel is it, yf he hath eies to reade, and hath not a heart to vnderſtād, who placed before the doore of our lordes ſecrette, Knocketh not with the faith of pietie, but inſulteth with elation and pride of impietie.

div.head: THAT EVERY CHVRCH, CHAPPELL, AND ORATORIE ERECTED TO THE HONOVR AND SERVICE OF GOD, SHOVLD HAVE THE ſigne of the Croſſe. ARTICLE III.
div.p:
HEARD you neuer (good readers) of the famous-rouer Ropers companion, who hauing often a iury empaneled vpon him, did euer refuſe the foremā of the queſt, and founde ſome friuolous exception againſt him, becauſe his giltie conſcience knewe, that yf his verdict might be hearde, he ſhould be conuicted? The like parte pleyeth M. Calf. in this Article: and becauſe his conſcience accuſeth him of vilanie, and blaſphemous wordes againſt the croſſe of Chriſt, and by playne euidence ſeeth, that vnleſſe he finde ſome fooliſh ſhift, to illude the authoritie of the aunciēt fathers and generall councells, the worlde would condemne him, firſt he leyeth ſome vaine exceptions againſt Abdias, the Apoſtles companion, that ſawe, Chriſt here in earth, and afterward with ſuch ſclanderous wordes reuileth the doctours, and fathers of the ſecond councell of Nice, and the empreſſe Irene in whoſe time it was kept, that a man would thinke ſome furie of hell, had inflamed his ſpirite. VVith his exceptions, againſt Abdias he filleth much paper, to make a ſhewe of ſome truthe, but howe vayne they are, in parte I will declare, the reſt becauſe
they be but geſſes of an idle brayne,M. Calfs. exceptiōs againſt Abdias. Fol. 53 b Calf. Mart. Cap. 1. I will leaue to the iudgement of the indifferent readers. One exception brought to proue Abdias worke to be a legēd of lyes, is this: he reporteth that Mary the mother of Chriſte did make a vowe of chaſtitie. True it is he did ſo: we graunte it. And is this a ſtrange poynte in your diuinitie, and diſſonant from all godly lerning? VVhy it is the goſpell. M. Calf. S. Luke ſaieth: when the angel ſaied vnto our Ladie: Ecce concipies & paries filium: Behold thoue ſhalt conceaue and bring foorth a ſonne, She anſwered. Howe ſhall this be done, ſeing I knowe not man, which ſoothly ſhe would not haue ſaied, Lib de ſancta virg. cap 4. The doctours teach that our Ladie made a vovve chaſtitie. vnleſſe ſhe had vowed her ſelf before, a virgin to God, ſaieth: S. Auguſtine, but becauſe the māner of the Iſraelites as yet refuſeth this, ſhe was diſpouſed to a iuſt man, not ſuch a one as ſhoulde violentlie cary her away, but rather maintaine and defend that, which ſhe had vowed, againſt ſuch as would offer her violence. Howe be it alſo, yf ſhe had ſaied this onlie, howe ſhall this be done, and had not added furder, becauſe I knowe no man, ſhe would neuer haue aſked, howe ſhe being a woman, ſhould bring forth a ſonne, promiſed her, yf ſhe had maried to haue carnall companie with her huſband: She night haue ben commanded to remayne a virgin, S. Auguſtine. in whome the ſonne of God ſhould take the ſhape of a ſeruant, by miracle meete for it, but ſhe that ſhould be an example to all virgins, leſt ſhe alone ſhould be taken to be a virgin, which had deſerued to conceaue a ſonne without company of man, ſhe dedicated virginitie to God, whereas yet ſhe knewe not what ſhe ſhould conceaue, that in an earthly and mortall body, there might be imitation of heauenly lif • , voto non p •• cepto, amore eligendi, Our Ladie made a vovve of virginitie. non neceſsitate ſeruiendi, by vowe and not by commandement, by loue to choſe, and not by neceſsitie to ſerue. So Chriſt by his, being borne of the virgin Mary, which determyned with her ſelf to remayne a virgin, before ſhe knewe who ſhould be borne of her, had rather cōmend holy virginitie then commaunde it. Thus farre S. Auguſtine, who proueth by the very wordes of the ghoſpell that our Ladie made a vowe of chaſtitie, and yet M. Calf teacheth, that it is a ſtrange point, Fol. 53. b and diſſonant from all godly lerning.

Haue ye not a proper miniſter of him (good readers?) Beginneth he not pretely to practiſe after his maſters myniſtery, that
nowe euen in the ſpiring of his Apoſtaſie, dareth ſet out in print, to the viewe of the worlde, and ſight of the poſteritie, that a doctrine builded, vpon ſcripture and Ghoſpell of Ieſus Chriſt, is ſtrange and diſſonant from all godly learning? VVhat will he not venture here after, that beginneth ſo freaſhly? Diuerſe auncient fathers beſides S. Auguſtine,Ambroſe. Lib • . in Lucam. thought it no ſtrange doctrine. S. Ambroſe ſayeth vpon S. Luke, that in the virgin Mary, there was: Profeſsio virginitatis, A profeſsiō of virginitie: (that is to ſay) She profeſſed her ſelf to be a virgin. Agayne: Habes propoſitum, vides votum. Note this M. Calf. Ibidem Lib. 3. de Trinit. S. Hilarie. Thou haſt her purpoſe, thou ſeeſt her vowe. S. Hilarie ſayeth: The Angle ſaluteth Mary, and promiſeth, that ſhe, being a virgin, ſhould be mother of the ſonne of God Illa virginitatis ſuae conſcia, difficultate facti commouetur: She being witting of her owne virginitie, was moued with the difficultie of the fact, that is to ſay. She was troobled with thinking howe it ſhould come to paſſe.

Nowe vnleſſe ſhe had determyned, with her ſelf to kepe her virginitie, ſhe would neuer haue ben troobled with any ſuch thought. Nature taught her, that yf ſhe vſed the companie of man, ſhe might cōceaue. VVherefore in that ſhe was troobled with the ſalutation of the Angel, and thinking howe it might come to paſſe, that ſhe ſhould bring foorth a ſonne, it is euident, that ſhe made a vowe, to cōtinewe a perpetuall virgin, and neuer to knowe man.

S. Bede.S. Bede vpon S. Luke ſayeth: The virgin aſking howe this ſhould come to paſſe, Reuerently ſhewed foorth the purpoſe and intent of her minde, Hom 4. de virg. that is, that ſhe had determined to liue a virgins life. S. Bernard ſpeaking of thoſe wordes: Quomodo fiet iſtud, etc. Howe ſhall this be done,S. Bernard and ſo foorth, ſayeth: Our ladie doubted not of the fact: She requireth the meanes, and order howe it ſhalbe. For ſhe aſketh not whether this ſhalbe, but howe it ſhalbe, as if ſhe would ſay: Seing my lord God, witneſſe of my conſcience, knoweth, that his hand mayden hath made a vowe, not to haue knoweledg of any man, after what maner, after what order ſhall it pleaſe him to haue it done? Marke M. Calf. Yf I muſt breake my vowe, that I may bring foorth ſuch a ſonne, I will reioiſe of my ſonne, and be ſory for my vowe. Thus much S. Bernard. Nowe (gentle readers) yf it were a ſtrang poynt and diſſonāt from all good learning, Fol. 53. b as M. Calf.
ſayeth: To affirme that Mary mother of Chriſt, made a vowe of chaſtitie, then hath the auncient fathers S. Auguſtine, S. Ambroſe, S. Hilarie, S. Bede and S. Bernard, being all vertuous and godly men, well ſeene in the ſcriptures of God, and expoſitions of the olde interpreters, before thē, taught a ſtrange poynt and diſſonant from all godly lerning. Did S. Luke the Euangeliſt deceaue them, and vs in reporting the virgins anſwer to the angel in ſuch ſort as he did? It were blaſphemous ſo to thinke. And yf that were the virgins anſwer, then naturall reaſon doth inuincibly proue, that as theſe aunciēt fathers ſay, our Ladie made a vowe of chaſtitie. VVherefore there is no cauſe why M. Calf. for any ſuch ſaying ſhould diſcredite the auctoritie of Abdias.

An other exceptiō againſt Abdias is, that a church, Fol. 32. a. was builded at Epheſus and dedicated to S. Iohn in his life tyme, which may be proued falſe by a thouſand teſtimonies, ſayeth he, and yet of thoſe thouſand he bringeth not one, which ſignifieth that either he is a very pynching nygard, or els a paſsing Craker, or ſhameleſſe lier. VVherefore to purge him ſelf, let hyn ſhewe ſome of thoſe thouſand that ſaye: There was no church builded to S. Iohn at Epheſus in his life tyme.Fol. 52. a That it is derogation to the honour of God, and contrarie to the vſe of the primitiue church: He ſayeth it only, but bringeth neither ſentence out of ſcripture, nor teſtimonie of any father to proue it: and good cauſe why. For he had none to bring, that which he alleageth out of S. Auguſtine, maketh nothing againſt vs. For the catholihe church euer taught, and teacheth at this preſent,Churches builded principally to the honour of God. that euery church, chapell, and oratorie is builded immediatly and principally to God, and the ſeruice which therein is dewe to God only, is geuen to no creature, be he Angell, or Archangel or any other bleſſed Sainct in heauen. Mary, that churches, chapells and oratories at their dedication haue ben called by the name of S. Peter, S. Paule, S. Iohn, and S. Iames, or ſuch like, as it pleaſed the deuotion of them that firſt erected them, we teache it not only to be laufull, but alſo honorable to the glorie of God, and his ſainctes. Laufull, firſt becauſe no ſcripture nor
councell did euer inhibite it,No ſcripture nor councel forbiddeth churches to be builded in honour of Sainctes. Vide epi. tomē Cō cil. De eccleſiaſt. dog. cap. 73. They are heretiques and no Chriſtiās that thinke the bodies of of Saincts and holy reliques not to be honoured but condemne them as heretickes that did impugne it, as Euſtachius was condemned in the councell of Gangre the yere of our Lord 324. for contemning churches of martirs and chappells called by the name of ſainctes.

Secondarely, becauſe the fathers haue vſed, and the catholique church allowed it, and accōpt hī no Chriſtian that denyeth it. S. Auguſt. or whoſoeuer was auctour of the booke, De eccleſiaſticis dogmatibus, ſayeth: VVe beleaue that the bodies of ſainctes and eſpeciallie the reliques of the bleſſed martirs are moſte ſincerely to be honored, euē as membres of Chriſt, and that Churches called by their names, are to be gone vnto, with moſte godly affection and faithfull deuotion, as holy places dedicated to the ſeruice of God. Yf any man contrary and gayne ſay this ſentence, he is thought to be no Chriſtian, but as very an heretike as euer was Eunomius and Vigilātius. VVhere note briefly, that the holy fathers did not only build churches, and call them by the manes of ſaincts, but alſo perſuade thē ſelues that they ought to goe vnto thē with greate deuotion: and whoſoeuer did thinke that no ſownde doctrine, was accompted no Chriſten man, but an hereticke. VVhich being ſo, Alas in what predicamēt, ſhal we put M. Calf? By the determination of the councell of Gangre, and ſentence of S. Auguſtine, he muſt needes be an hereticke.

That it is honorable to the glorie of God and his ſainctes, I make this reaſon: what ſo euer God commāded to be done was honorable to him,To builde churches in honour of Sainctes, is honorable to God. and all his ſainctes: but God cōmanded churches, to be builded in the name of ſaincts, ergo it was honorable to God, and his ſainctes to builde churches in their names. The maior I thincke M. Calf. will not denie. The minor is proued by S. Ambroſe in the life of Geruaſius and Prothaſius, where he telleth, that in the lent he had a viſion, and becauſe he woulde be aſſured of it, he made his humble praïer to God, that yf it were an illuſion of the diuell, it might vaniſh away, yf it were a true viſion, it might appeare more perfectly. That done he augmented his faſt, the viſion apeared as it did before. The third night, his body being nowe worne with faſting, and he not ſleeping, but wondring at it, the viſion apeared vnto him againe: that is, to ſay, two youngemen in white apparell, and a third perſon which was like the bleſſed Apoſtle S. Paule, whoſe countenance he knewe by his picture,
who amongeſt other thinghs tolde him, that the younge men which he ſawe, were Geruaſius and Prothaſius, holy martirs of Chriſt. VVhoſe bodies thou ſhalt finde in the place where thou ſtandeſt and praieſt: thou ſhalt finde a cophine couered with earth, twelue foote vnder the grounde, S. Ambroſe cōmaū ded by God to build a church in the name of Geruaſius and Prothaſiꝰ. which cophine thou ſhalt take and lift vp on high, and builde a churche in their name. Thus much S. Ambroſe: the premiſſes thē being true, and the forme good, the concluſion muſt needes followe.

Here if M. Calf. will quarell, and ſaye, that it was S. Paule, that commanded the church to be builded in the name of Geruaſius and Prothaſius, and not God him ſelf, we will him to vnder ſtand, that as S. Paule being made an elect veſſell to preache the faith of Chriſt to the Gentills, did nothing but that which God and the holy Ghoſt willed him to doe: So being nowe a ſaincte in heauen, he neither doth, nor can do any thing, but that which it pleaſeth God to commāde him. VVherfore he may be aſhamed of his moſte blaſphemous aſſertion ſaying, that is a derogation to the honour of God.

VVhere he ſayeth:Calf. Fol. 52 b. It is contrary to the vſe of the primitiue church, and that all men agre that vntill the raigne of Conſtantine, there were no chapells nor oratories erected in honour of any ſainct, Mart. You may perceaue (good readers) frō what fountayne, he fetteth his doctrine, and that he trauayleth neither in the ſtudie of the eccleſiaſticall hiſtories, nor auncient fathers, but in ſuch halfpenny doctours, as haue written theſe later yeres, as Luther, Bucer, Caluin, Beza, Bullinger, Bale,P •• idoru • v •• g. cap. 6. de inuēt 〈◊〉 Churches builde 〈◊〉 hon ••• of Sa • nctes •• fore C ••
ſtant •••• tyme and the authour of the homilie againſt images, and Magdeburgenſes, and ſuch infamous friers and Apoſtatats. In Paris at this preſent in via Iacobea they haue an aūciēt churche builded by S. Deniſe and his companions in honour of S. Stephen, and becauſe they had the ſeruice there for a tyme in Greeke, they call it S. Eſtienne le Grec. Pius the tenth Pope after S. Peter, in the yere of our lord 155. as Pantaleon noteth dedicated a church to S. Prudentia. Calixtus or as ſome write Caliſtus the ſixthene Pope after S. Peter in the yere of our Lord 220. builded a church at Rome, beyond the ryuer Tibris in honour of our bleſſed Ladie. And all
theſe with many more which I could recken (were it not that I feare tediouſnes in ſo plaine a matter) were builded in honour of ſainctes,Polid. lib. 5. cap 6. de inuent. rerum. & li. 8. cap. 1. lōge before Conſtātyne was borne. VVhere is nowe M. Calfhills creditte become? VVhat truth is in his wordes? VVhat veritie in that bold aſſertion, VVhere he ſayeth, that it is contrary to the vſe of the primitiue churche, to build churches in the honour of ſainctes? Is it not turned into a vayne ſmothering ſmoke, and he taking vpō him to inſtruct other, as puines, and young ſchollers, proued to haue no ſight in antiquities, nor ſkill in thoſe authours, which fauoring his affection wrote the ſtorie of antiquitie, and mentioned this that I haue laſt recited? Iudge you (good readers) for my parte, I pittie his ignorance, and wiſhe him the ſpirite of humilitie, and vnderſtanding, that by the one he may knowe him ſelfe, and by the other lerne, howe by his newe M. and Apoſtatical doctours he is lurdely deceaued.

Fol 51. b Calf.An other exception againſt Abdias, is that he maketh S. Iohn to ſay: virtutum opes habere non poſſe qui voluerit diuitias habere terrenas: That he can not haue the riches of vertue, that will haue the riches of the earth. Mart. But yf this be a ſufficiēt reaſon to impugne ſo auncient a writer, and M. Calfhills witt, may be commēded for it, than to purchaſe like commendation, ſome pretie proteſtant may ſtart vp hereafter, and denie the Ghoſpell of S. Mathew,Matt. 19. and the Epiſtle of S. Paule to Timothe. For S. Mathew maketh Chriſt to ſay: It is eaſier for a camele to go through the eie of a needle, thā a riche mā to entre into te kingdō of heauē. S. Paule ſaieth:1. Tim 6. Qui volūt fieri diuites. etc. They that wil be riche fal into tētatiō, and ſnare of the deuill, and into many vnꝓfitable and hurtefull deſires which drowne me into perditiō, and deſtructiō. And are not theſe ſentēces, all one in effect, with that which Abdias attributeth to ſ. Iohn? he ſaieth they that will haue riches of the earth cā not haue the riches of vertue: S. Paule ſaieth, that they that will be riche fall into tētatiō and ſnare of the diuell. VVhat differēce is there betwene theſe two ſayinges? VVoulde not he haue riches, that deſireth to be riche? A wiſeman woulde thinke yeas, and yf it be ſo, then hath Abdias varied nothing
from the bleſſed Apoſtle S. Paule,The doctrine of Chriſt obiected as a fault to Abdias. Fol. 51. b nor doctrine of Chriſt in the ghoſpell: but M. Calfhils capacitie gaping after the riches of the worlde could not conceaue that, nor take the ſaying of Abdias in that ſenſe, in which the ſaying of Chriſt in Saint Mathewe, and S. Paule to Timothe is to be takē, but muſt make the ſimple people beleue that it accordeth not with the doctrine of Chriſt. VVherefor to oppoſe M. reader in this poynt of doctrine, tell vs ſir, dot not Chriſt teache contēpt of riches contēpt of the world and all inordinate willing and deſiring of earthly goods?1. Tim. 6. Sayeth he not by his Apoſtle, that they falle into the ſnare of the diuell, and many vnprofitable deſires, that will be riche? that is haue an inordinate deſire and vnbrideled will to be rych, an gett the goods of the worlde? Yf Chriſt taught this, then was it Chriſtes doctrine. Yf it were his doctrine, then that which Abdias attributeth to S. Iohn, varieth not frō Chriſtes doctrine. For take the wordes which your ſelf alleage, that he can not haue the ſubſtance of vertues, that will haue the ſubſtance of the earth, what is there here that accordeth not with Chriſtes doctrine? Haue you not the ſame termes in one that are in the other? Volunt in S. Paule, and voluerit in S. Iohn? and ſignifie they not bothe one thing? that is, an inordinate will, and deſire to haue the riches of the earth? And do not they that haue this inordinate will and deſire falle into the ſnare of the diuell, and many vnprofitable and hurtefull deſires, which drowne men into death and perdition? And whiles they are in the ſnare of the diuel and ſuch vnprofitable deſires that bring perdition, can they haue the ſubſtance of vertues? Speake M. Calf. This is the doctrine of Chriſt, this is the doctrine of the holy Ghoſt, in S. Paule. And this is the ſame that S. Iohn preached, and Abdias reported. And certes like as you ſir being ſick of an agewe cā not haue your health before the humour that is predominant, and matter of your ſicknes be al purged or cōſumed: Euen ſo the man that hath this inordinate will and deſire which the Apoſtles ſpeake of, can not haue the riches of vertues, before that lewed deſire and inordinate will be purged and cōſumed with the fyer of Gods worde, and loue of Chriſt, and he made a newe man in holynes and righteouſnes.
VVherfore I much maruel that you dirſt vēture to ſay, that the foreſaied ſentence of Abdias attributed to S. Iohn accordeth not with the doctrine of Chriſt. My ſelf will not condemne you of contrarying and gayneſaying the word of God, and doctrine of Chriſt in this caſe. Let your owne indifferent brothers iudge, howe litle you ſauour of any ſight in diuinitie for ſaying that thoſe wordes of Abdias accorded not with the doctrine of Chriſt. That the readers may vnderſtād howe fouly you haue corrupted Abdias, and left out a worde, and altered his meaning, I will examine the place.

He told there howe S. Iohn talking againſt riches, ſpake alſo of curing the ſicke of the palſey clenſing the lepers and caſting out of deuils, and afterward ſaied: Sed has virtutum opes habere non poſſunt, qui voluerint diuitias habere terrenas. But they can not haue theſe powers of vertues that will haue the ryches of the worlde: VVhere the Apoſtles meaning was that they could not haue the grace and vertue of curing the ſicke, and working of miracles, who inordinately deſired the riches of the earth, M. Calf. leaueth out craftelie, the worde (has) thoſe, and putteth it indefinitely, as though the Apoſtle ment, that they could haue no vertues at all, but this is playne couyn, woorſe than liegier demayne. Some mā woulde counte hī an aſſe, for leauīg out the worde (has) but I will not trooble his conſciēce. Let it be but a wilful ſcape, propre to heretickes.

The fourth exception is this: It is more then a miracle to mee that Abdias ſhould be ſuch an auncient writer, Calf. Fol 51. b mart. becauſe neither Irene, neither Euſebius, nor S. Hierome make mention of him. A great matter to be woundred at: a VViſeman woulde rather haue woundred howe it coulde be that three lerned mē, ſhoulde be able to write the whole hiſtories of thinges done longe before their tyme, and haue true notice of al that was done in all cuntries, townes, cities and villages, and omitte nothing, that was done. But M. Calfhills merueilous witte will neuer lacke ſtraunge thinges to woundre at. Yt is to be thought, yf M. Horne him ſelfe, as wiſe a man as he is, ſhould
tell him of VValtams Calf. that went nyne myle to ſucke a bul, it ſhould be more then a miracle vnto him.

The fift exception is that S. Iohn allowed the fact of Druſiana, whiche withdrewe her ſelf frō her huſbādes company. Calf. Fol. 51. q Mart. That is a falſe lye. For there is no mention in all that hiſtorie (where Abdias talketh of Druſiana) that S. Iohn allowed any ſuch fact of hers.Calf. Fol 52. a The ſixt that S. Iohn turned trees into gold, and made broken iewells whole againe. For they were fonde miracles, and had no apparaunce of truth (quoth M. Calf.Mart. As though the Apoſtle ꝓuoked there vnto to declare the mighty power of God, and ſtanding in hope to wynne a ſoule to Chriſte (as he did in deede) ſhould diſdayne to woorke ſuch a miracle to ſo good and end. Yf you had loked to the ſtorie M. Calf. and conſidered the circumſtances a litle better, you would not haue called them fonde miracles, and miracles that haue no apparance of truth. But we muſt beare with your boldnes. Yf you contynewe, we may fortune to heare, that the turning of Moyſes rod into a ſerpent,Exod. 7.4. Reg. 6. Ioan 2. the making of an hatchet ſwymme vpon the water, the going of Chriſt through the doores, the turning of water into wyne, ſhalbe counted fond miracles. For take away firſt the authoritie of the church that alloweth the ſcripture, as heretickes haue done, and thē the ſcripture it ſelf, as in parte they doe, and there is no more reaſon why they ſhould not ſtick to call theſe miracles, that I reherſe out of the ſcripture, fonde miracles, and miracles that haue no apparance of truthe, than there is why they ſhould ſay ſo of thoſe that Abdias referreth to S. Iohn. Thus you haue heard ſome of the fond exceptions that M. Calf. bringeth againſt that auncient father, and by theſe youe may iudge of the reſt.

Dionyſius Alexandrinus, an auncient, learned, and holy father, vnderſtanding that diuerſe condemned the Apocalypſe of S. Iohn, ſaied: I verelie dare not condemne, Euſeb lib. 7. cap 23. hiſto. and reiect the writing of this booke, eſpeciallie ſeing many of the brethren are of the ſame opinion with me, that it is S. Iohns: So modeſtie woulde haue re
qui red, that M. Calf. ſhould haue ſaied of Abdias, and becauſe many thinke it, to
be his worke in deede, eſpecially Lazius, and Sebaſtianus Munſterus a maſter of his, who were, at the finding of it, he ſhould not ſo contemptuouſly haue reiected it, and called the authour, a lyer, Fol. 51. b Fol. 53. b a landleaper, an authour of ſtraunge doctrine, contrarie to all godly learning: but you ſee what modeſtie is in proteſtants tongues, and reuerence in their heartes to antiquities. Euer ſythens frier Luther gaue example to contemne the ſcriptures, and eſpecially the Epiſtle of S. Iames, becauſe it made againſt his poſition of only faith, his diſciples haue not ſtickt to contēne doctours, councells, yea and the ſcripture it ſelfe, where it maketh againſt them. His other exceptions againſt Abdias, I omitt to avoyde tediouſnes, nowe yowe ſhall heare what he ſaieth againſt, the councells.

M. Calfs. anſvvers to the coū cells. Diſt 1. ca. Nemo. The councel of Orleance. Calf. Fol. 57. a Mart.I alleaged out of Iuo and Gratian his canon made in a councell kept at Orleans. Let no man build a churche before the biſſhop of that dioceſſe come and ſet vp a croſſe, to which, M. Calf. talking much in vaine, and ſo prouing euen as other principles of his religion be proued, that the Ring of the churche doore by the ſame reaſon is a piece of Gods ſeruice, with many like follies to no purpoſe, anſwereth thus in effect: In that decree order is taken for thinges neceſſarie before the churche be builded. But we require what is neceſſarie ſeruice in a churche hallowed. Yf wiſe men will iudg hym to be a very ignorant aduocate, who hauing his clients caſe geuen him in writing, and the copie alwaies lying before his eies, can neither conceaue, the meaning of it, nor yet propounde it in ſuch ordre, as it is geuē him, what ſhall we thinke of M. Calf? VVho taking vpon him to be aduocate for the proteſtants againſt the croſſe of Chriſt, neither vnderſtandeth the caſe which he hath to impugne, geuen him in print, and leyed before his eies in manifeſt termes, nor yet hath lerned to tel it in ſuche ordre, as it is geuen him? Donetur rude. In the beginning of this third article it is ſett foorth with charecters legible without ſpectacles, that euery church chapel, and oratorie, erected to the honour and ſeruice of God, ſhould haue the ſigne of the croſſe, yet this newe aduocate for the contrarie
parte, hauing viewed the matter ſubſtantially (as he thinketh) and hauing nothing to ſay againſt the canon, but forced to ſay, that the practiſe of the church was ſo then, leppeth out into a bye matter, and ſaieth:Fol. 57. a VVe do inquire what is neceſſary ſeruice in a church hallowed, and ſo for a a ſhift to deceaue the ſimple calleth the reader, very rudely from the ſtate of the matter, that is treated in the article. But that will not ſerue him. Euery mā that hath eies, ſeeth that our reaſoning is of the ſigne of the croſſe, and not of neceſſarie ſeruice in the churche. Neceſſarie ſeruice in a churche hallowed is matyns, maſſe, and euenſong, preaching and chriſtening, and ſuch like. Of this there was no worde mentioned. The ſigne of the croſſe erected and ſet vp there, is no neceſſarie poynt of this vocal and ordinarie ſeruice, no more then the couering of the booke and defke that holdeth hī is. VVherefore our freſhe aduocate may be thought not to haue had his wittes very ſobre when he ymagined to colour an euil cauſe with ſuch a bye trayne. So he ſay ſomwhat in apparance, for the tyme, he paſſeth not howe litle truth be founde in his tale, when it cometh to examinatiō. By his owne confeſsion a croſſe is neceſſarie according to that decree before the church be builded, afterward, when it is builded,A croſſe neceſſarie before the church be builded. Fol 57. a it is not neceſſarie: what reaſon is there in this? Yf there were only (as M. Calfhil ſaieth) a ciuil police in it, and no point of religion, why did that councell commaunde a croſſe ſpecially, before all other thinges, to be ſett vp there, and that by no priuate man, but by a biſhop? Let vs here a ſubſtantiall cauſe, of his pregnant witt. And he ſhalbe accompted to haue more wiſdome in that litle Calfes head of his, than that whole councell.Fol 57. a Calf. But to what purpoſe do we alleage councells? M. Calf. ſayeth if there were a moſt playne determination for the croſſe in this or any ſuch like councel, he is no more bounde to the authoritie therof, then we will be to the Engliſh Synodes, held in king Edwardes daies, and in the Quenes maieſties raigne that nowe is.

Here is a plaine puritaine, and notorious proteſtant.Mart. He ſheweth him ſelf in his likeneſſe. But (ſir) howe, and howe farre
you and euery man is bounde to obey the decrees of the prouinciall councells, I wil not diſpute. It requireth lōger tyme, yet this by the way, I will ſaye that youe are more bounde to obey that, thā we are either to obey the Synodes kept in king Edwardes daies, either yours in theſe later yeres. For firſt the Synodes in king Edwars tyme were by laufull authoritie, reuoked, and abrogated, and therefore binde no man to obey them. Theſe which you haue held of late,The proteſtants Synodes kept vvithout true biſſhops. are of no authoritie, nor worthy to be called Sinodes, but conſpiracies, cōuenticles, or aſſembles that had neuer a laufull and true biſhop in them. The councell at Orleaūce had thirtie and thre biſhops, laufully called, inſtituted and created. They kept them ſelues within the vnitie of the churche, ye like Apoſtatats haue forſakē it. Their decrees were to edifie, yours are to pluck downe. Looke then howe muche more, we ought to obey true biſhops, than falſe vſurpers, Chriſtians lyuing in the vnitie of the church, than renegates that haue for ſaken the church, men that deſire to edifie, than ſuch as labour to deſtroy: So much more ought we to followe that coū cell being but prouincial, than your Synodes being but ſchiſmaticall. The next Canon alleaged out of a councell kept at Toures,The coū cel of Toures. requiring, vt corpus Domini in altari, non in armario, ſed ſub crucis titulo componatur, That the body of our lord conſecrated vpon the aulter, be not repoſed and ſet in the reueſtrie, but vnder the roode, M. Calf. thinketh to illude which his foliſh cauills.Calf. Fol. 67. b Armarium, he ſaieth, may be well taken for a library, for a cloſet, or almerie, but no more for a reueſtrie than for a belfrie. Mart. And why ſo ſir, is not Armarium, properly a place, where any thīg is layed, as bookes, coates, houſhold ſtuffe and ſuch like? And doth not the reueſtrie, reſemble ſuch a place more properly then a belfrie.Fol. 57. b Your ſelf confeſſe it to be the fathers meaning, and yf it were the meaning of the councell, it was to much arrogancie in youe to condemne it, as foliſh, and exceſsiue folly to reproue them, who take the meaning of the authour, and ſticke not ſo preciſely to the bare letter.

S. Auguſtine reſoning againſt the Arrians contending earneſtly
the for worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 aſked,Epiſt 174 It is folly to contēd about the vvoord. vvhē vve knovve the thing Quid eſt contentioſius quā quū de re conſtat, certare de nomine? VVhat is more contentious the when there is plaine euidence for the thing, to contend vpon the name? In like maner we aſke you what more euidēt ſigne cā we haue of a brauling brabler, than ſuch manifeſt contention aboute a word, when we knowe the thing that is meant by the woorde: your owne freinde the hath augmēted Sir Thomas Eliots Dictionary, could haue tolde youe that armariū, is a place where bookes are layed, or other ſtuffe of houſhold, and by that yow might haue geſſed, that there is more affinitie betwixt, Armarium, Armariū. and a reueſtirie, than betwene Armarium and a belfrie. But yf it be your manner in reading, to daily aboute the woorde when you haue the true ſenſe of the authour, as you do here, certes I will not will euery of your hearers to gather a rodde for ſuch a reader, but deſire your tender harted damſell that would not willinglie haue you hurt, with a rodde, to gett a pecocks tayle, for feare of ſmart. VVhen I was at VVyncheſter, I taught my ſchollers euermore true ſignifications of their latin woordes, and when any came in conſtruction, that had diuerſe ſignifications, I expounded them, and when they tranſlated, I taught them to keepe the ſenſe, and meaning of the authour, although the proprietie of the worde ſtrictely taken, woulde ſcarce abide it. And for ſo doying I ſuppoſe none woulde thinke the vſher worthy of rodde, but ſuche a wiſe man as you are.Titulus crucis. As for the fault youe finde with the interpreting of Titulus crucis, for a roode, it is ſo childiſh that it is to be laughed at, rather then anſwered, but take it whether you will for a roode, or for the title of the croſſe, it doth manifeſtly conuince, that there was a croſſe in the church, which is the principal poynt that I tooke in I hand to proue in this Article.

VVhere you maruell that I woulde not rather expounde it for a pixe, than a roode, Fol. 57. b in good ſoothe I can not let ſo meruelous a monſtre to maruell at his owne ſhadowe if he pleaſe. VVhere you ſay,Calf. Ibidem. that you neuer heard afore this tyme that the ſacrament was reuerently kept vnder the Roode, that
the aulter refuſed, Mart. the roode ſhoulde be reuerenced. Surely it is no great maruell, for a man of ſo litle experience of foren countries, and ſo ſmal trauaile in reading the auncient fathers, and councells. But (ſir) you take the matter amiſſe. The wordes of the Canon do not tell you that the ſacrament was caried vp to the roode loft, but ſaied it was ſet, ſub crucis titulo, vnder the roode, or title of the croſſe. VVhich might be in an other place, beſides the roode loft. Againe if it had bene their meaning to haue it ſet in the roode loft, yet woulde it not followe, that therfore the aulter was refuſed,Diuerſe countries haue diuerſe places to keepe the bleſſed Sacrament. or thought no worthie place to keepe it. Diuerſe countries haue diuerſe places to kepe the bleſſed ſacrament: theſe lower partes of Germanie haue a place, beſides the aulter, builded of purpoſe very honorablie to reſerue it in, yet for al that they refuſe not the aulter, nor contemne it, as vnworthie for it, but take the other to be a more ſafe, and cōmodious place: other hanged it reuerently ouer the aulter, other kept it in the reueſtrie.

The councel of Chalcedō in Trullo.The next councell which I alleaged was the ſixt generall councell kept at Conſtantinople in Trullo. But M. Calf. could not finde any Canon in that councell that made for the croſſe, and no maruell. For he followed not the counſell of our ſauiour ſaying: Quaerite & inuenietis, Seeke and ye ſhall finde. In the ſumme of the councells gathered by the reuerend father Carranza, the 73. Canon of the ſixt generall councell is this. Seing the liuely croſſe doth ſhewe vnto vs that healthfull thīg (that is to ſay) the paſſiō of Chriſt, it behoueth vs to imploye all our ſtudie, that we may geue vnto it, that honour which is meete and conuenient. VVherefore we geuing adoration vnto it, with mynde, tongue and ſenſe, commaunde that the figures of the croſſe, whiche are made of ſome in the grownde, and pauiment, be taken away, leſt our triumphant ſigne of victorie, be iniuried by the treading of thoſe that paſſe and go that wayes. The iudgment of the ſixt general coūcel of the croſſe. This if M. Calf. woulde haue ſought, he myght haue founde, and noted, Firſt, that the croſſe by the iudgement of two hundred 27. fathers doth repreſent vnto vs the paſsiō of Chriſt.
