Secondely that they thought it their dutie to geue dewe honour vnto it. Thirdly that with mynde tongue and ſenſe, they gaue adoration vnto
it, that they called it neither idoll, nor ſigne of conqueſt againſt the Chriſtians, but a triumphant ſigne of victorie, for the Chriſtiās: Laſt of all becauſe they would not haue that holy ſigne to be trod vpō, and defiled with mens feete, they commaunded, that no ſigne of the croſſe ſhoulde be made vpō the grounde, or pauiment, and yf any were made, they willed it to be taken vp, and had away vnder payne of excommunicatiō. In ſuch honour and reuerence they had it in thoſe daies.

But if M. Calf. or any of his, reply, and ſay, that here is no mention made of any croſſe in the church, let him conſider the wordes of the councell well, firſt where they ſaye: Quum crux viuifica illud ſalutare nobis oſtendit: Seing the liuely croſſe ſheweth vnto vs that healthfull thing, it is manifeſt that there was a liuely croſſe to ſhewe them that healthfull thing: Secondarely, where they attribute adoration, vnto it, with mynde, tongue, and ſenſe, this worde ſenſe, declareth that they had a ſenſible croſſe, to whiche, they might ſhewe their reuerēce with their externall ſenſes. Againe the deuotion of the people, being ſuch that they would paynt it, or engraue it vpō the grounde, and pauyment, it is not to be thought, but that they had it in other places. And yf in other places, why not principally in the churche, VVhere they ſhoulde haue moſt occaſion to remembre Chriſt death and paſsion? and in remēbrāce of the great benefite purchaſed by the croſſe, honour and reuerence that holy ſigne? Laſt of all, the prohibition forbidding it to be made in the grounde and pauyment, doth euidently conuince, that it is lawfull to be made in other places. For a prohibition reſtrictiue, forbidding a thing to be done in this or that place, and no more, is a laufull permiſsiō for all other places, which are not namely included in that prohibition. For proufe whereof, I referre me, to M. Calfhils owne aduocate or lawyer, what ſo euer he be, ſo that he haue a litle more ſight in the lawe, thā the reader of Poules hath in diuinitie. Nowe yf it might haue pleaſed him to haue conſulted with his lerned counſell, he ſhould right well haue perceaued that the gatherers of the councells into a ſumme (whō he calleth patchers of ragged reliques)Fol. 57 b did not take the vj. councell
of Conſtantinople, for the vij. of Nice, nor that there was any ſlyght dealing in preſsing the authoritie, and not alleaging the wordes, the numbre of the canon was cited in the margent, the cauſe why it was brought, alleaged, and either of theſe cauſes, is ſufficient to excuſe me from all ſiniſtrous opiniōs of ſlight dealing.The ſeuēth general coucel at Nice. The fourth coūcel which I brought, was the ſeuent general coūcel kept at Nice againſt image breakers: but againſt theſe M. Calf. opponeth three other councells, one at Conſtantinople vnder Conſtantine the fift, Fol. 58. b another at Eliberie in Spayne nowe called Granata, the third at Franckford in Germanie.

The coū cel of Cō ſtātinople vnder • eo the fift no lauful coū cell.The firſt all the worlde knoweth to be no laufull councell, but a cōuenticle of heretikes, cōdemned by the catholike churche both in the councell of Franckford, kept in the tyme of Charles the great in Germanie, and alſo by the councell Laterane in Rome, to which the forſaied vertuous Emperour ſent twelue biſhops out of Fraūce. VVherefore that aſſemble at Cō ſtantinople being vnlaufull, the callers of it heretickes, the proceding inordinate, without their true head, it muſt followe that their decrees were vnlaufull, their reaſons ſchiſmatical, not foū ded vpon ſcripture, but wreſted to a wrong ſenſe after their maner, and therefore not worthie the anſwering.

As for the ſecond, who but bolde proteſtans dare affirme that about the ſame tyme when the councell of Conſtantinople was kept in Greece, this councell was kept at Eliberie or Granata in Spayne? It is to be ſeene in the actes of the coūcells and ſumme gathred by a lerned mā of Spayne, that it was kept in the tyme of Sylueſter in the yere of our lord 335. after the accōpte of their owne doctour Pantaleō, about the tyme of the firſt Nicene councell. And I maruell that M. reader, of Poules could not ſe it.Apoc. 22. But, he that is in filthynes, may growe in filthynes ſtill, he that is in ſuche groſſe ignorance, may be ignorant ſtill. M. Calfhills authour whome he followeth in this pointe, and of whome he borroweth the moſte of that whiche he infarced to no purpoſe into his booke, againſt images, and made no mention of him, in very deed readeth it ſo, in the Homilie againſt Images, fol. 37.
and ſo one blinde batfouler leading an other, they fall both into the myre of ignorāce. VVhereby you may ſee what aunciēt authours, M. reader ſtudieth moſt. As for the councell it ſelf, it decreed that A biſhop and prieſt might haue his ſiſter in his houſe, Canon 27 or daughter being a virgin, and profeſſed to God: but no other woman. VVhy is not this kept? VVhy haue they their nurceries? VVhy haue they theyr houſes deck with womans kirtelis, Caſſocks, and fardingalles that are no ſiſters nor ſpirituall daughtters,Cap 33. but carnall Concubines? It is decreed alſo, that Biſhops, prieſtes, Deacons and ſubdeacons, The proteſtats obſerue not the Canons of the coūcel of Eliber. being placed in the miniſtery ſhoulde abſtaine from their wiues, and not begett children, It is decreed that all that did ſo ſhould be thruſt out of their Clergie. VVherfore kepe ye not this Canon? why haue your coloured and votarie biſhops, pretenſed wiues? VVhy haue your friers, mounkes and lecherous prieſts their amorouſes in their armes? VVhy fill they the coūtrie which baſtardes? VVhy keepe they their benefices? VVhy deceaue they the poore people by purchaſing of landes and procuring of leaſes for their brattes? It is conuenient that thoſe decrees ſhoulde ſtand in force as wel as this, which ye alleage. The ſame fathers that made one, made the other, and at the ſame tyme in the ſame councell, and with the ſame ſpirite. VVherfore they ought to be credited a like. And ſeyng you vrge their authoritie, in one & refuſe it in an other, I might vſe your owne Rhetoricke and tel you that I am no more boūde to followe that coūcel in one canō, thā you ought to obey their determinatiō in the other,Cap. 36. This canō of the Elibertine councel ſpeaketh not agaīſt al images. Pictures vppon vvalles phibited only by this canō. but I will not deale ſo with you. The canō is good and maketh nothing agaīſt the catholike faith touching the vſe of images. This is the canō: Placuit picturas in Eccleſia eſſe nō debere, ne quod colitur aut adoratur, in parietibus depingatur: VVe decree that pictures ought not to be in the church, leſt that be paynted on the walles which is worſhipped and adored. VVhere note firſt that pictures only are prohibited by this decree, and not euery picture neither, but ſuche as were painted in walles. Secondarely that this prohibition is but particular for pictures on walles, and being ſuch, excludeth not other images, but rather permitteth them: for edictes prohibitorie, forbidding certaine caſes, permitte all that is
not ſpeciallie forbidden, if it be, eiuſdem generis & ſubiecti, of the ſame kinde and the ſame matter.

Thirdly that here is an euident proufe that pictures were then worſhipped. For this argument followeth neceſſarilie vpon thoſe wordes. That was worſhipped which was for bidden to be payncted in the walles: but pictures were forbidden to be payncted vpon the walles,Anſvver M. Calf. ergo pictures were worſhipped: the maior is proued by the later clauſe of the canon: Ne quod colitur aut adoratur in parietibus depingatur. That that be not payncted in walles, which is worſhipped and adored. For nothing can be payncted in the walle, but the image of ſome thing. Yf M. Calfhill ſay, that it is ment, that God which is adored and worſhipped, ſhoulde not be payncted in the waulles, he wilbe contrary to him ſelfe and doctrine of his owne councells, and doctours. For he and they teache, that neither God, neither Chriſt cā poſsibly be payncted. And yf it be ſo, then that which the councell ſaied in that canon, is worſhipped, and adored, is neither God nor Chriſte, but ſome thing that maybe payncted. VVherfore this impugner with his M. the authour of the image homilie, may ſtreeke this councell out of their bookes, and cry ſhame of their ignoraunce, for bringing that which proueth manifeſtly againſt them.

VVhy the coūcel of Eliberie, did forbid pictures in vvallesNowe why that councell did forbid pictures on walles, to help your vnderſtanding, ley downe your pecocks tayle, and diſdayne not to lerne a Lawyers poynt of an vſher of VVyncheſter, and ſtudient in Louayne. For the better vnderſtāding of a ſtatute or Canon, diuerſe circumſtances are to be conſidered. Amongeſt which for this wiche we haue nowe in hand,Circūſtā ces to ba cōſidered you muſt note, the place where it was made, the perſons that made it. The tyme when it was made, and the cauſe why it was made. They that made this decree were catholike biſſhops, and faithfull diſpēſers of Chriſtes myſteries, ſuch as knewe to geaue their people:Luc. 12. Their meaſure of wheate in tyme. The place where it was made, was Eliberye or Granata a citie in Spayne, whiche at that tyme, and longe after had many infidels and Paganes, that deſpited Chriſt, and his religion: and becauſe they were idolatours
them ſelues, thought the Chriſtians to committ idolatrie by hauing of images. The tyme when it was made, was when they feared perſecutiō, as apeareth by the 59. and 60. Canon of the ſame coūcell. The cauſe why it was made, was becauſe whē the Chriſtians by the tyrannie of Pagans and perſecution of infidels ſhould be forced to flee, and forſake their churches, they ſhould be driuē to leaue their pyctures in the walles to be mocked, ſcorned, and laughed at, by the infidells, to the great contempte of Chriſt and ſclander of the Chriſtians. Thes circumſtances conſidred no maruell, yf ſuch Catholike biſhops deſirous to winne the idolatrous to the faith of Chriſt, and ſtanding in feare daily of perſecution, and knowing that yf vpon the ſodayne they ſhoulde be forced to flee, the Pagans would pille their churches, and make their pictures left in the walles, a mocking game, as they did crucifie the image of Chriſt in Berythus, Athanaſ. de imag. Chriſt. Ephipha. epiſt ad 5. Synod. Conſt. to. 2. Concil. and ſtoned a croſſe in Tyrus, no maruell I ſay, yf for ſuch conſiderations ſuch holy fathers made ſuch a decree, and prohibited pictures on the walles in churches. At this preſent all catholike biſſhops vpon like occaſion woulde make the like. But what if thoſe fathers had no ſuch conſiderations, but did abſolutely forbidde pictures in the church? VVhat would it aduātage his cauſe? Dot he not remēbre that it was a prouincial Synode of xix. biſſhops,Fol. 88. a Marcell. Epiſt. 5. whoſe iuriſdiction ſtretched no furder than to their particuler prouinces? Doth he not remembre that when the tyme is chaunged, that which was well done before, may be chaunged according to S. Auguſtines rule which he him ſelf alleageth, in another place? Yf he doth not, it muſt be told hī, and furder ſignified, that pictures and images were not only receaued into churches in diuerſe other cuntries, but alſo permitted and commaunded by general councells, as by the councel of Nice vnder Adrian the firſt, by the councell of Rome vnder Gregorie the ſecond, and the councell of Franckforde vnder Adrian in the tyme of Charlemaigne. And ſeing by theſe generall councells the decree of that particuler Synode was abrogated by the aftercummers, according to Pope Stephens decree, and altered for the diuerſitie of tyme, as S. Auguſtine permitteth,
there is no reaſon why we ſhould be preſſed with the auctoritie of that Canon which was ones abrogated, and forced to preferre one prouincial Synode, before three general councells, and driuen more to eſteme the order of one prouince, than the authoritie of the vniuerſall church. VVherfor M. Calf. hath by no wayes, any vantage by the Elibertine councell.

Nowe as for the councell of Franckford held in the time of Charlemayn, it condemned not (as you falſlie reporte) the ſeuenth councel at Nice, but the falſe and forged Synode or Conuenticle of heretikes aſſembled at Conſtantinople, and all image breakers. The booke whiche you ſay, Carolus magnus, made againſt images,Fol 58 a vſque ad Fol. 78. a is a falſe forged tale, as you may ſee in the confutation of the Apologie Fol. 328. and all the long proceſſe of diſpute alleaged out of that booke, is not worthy ſo much creditte, as the tale of Robynwhode on wakefyld on a grene, and therfore neadeth no anſwer.

Fol. 78. ab Fol. 79 aThe ſclaunderous and ſpiteful wordes which you haue vſed againſt Irene and the councel of Nice, would neuer haue ben vttered, vnleſſe malice had hardened yower hearte, and hereſy blinded yower eies. For who but yow would declare, the bare facte of a prince to his reproufe and not tell the circumſtances? VVho would ſay the kinge exerciſed extreame Tyrāny againſt ſuch and ſuch perſons, and not declare the cauſes why? No man that meaneth vprightlye. For as the circumſtances and cauſes why thinges are done may aggrauate the indignitie of the facte: So may they either ſomewhat extenuate it, or alltogeather excuſe it.Fol. 78. b Calf. Twoe greate and haynouſe factes (as yow thincke) yow laye to Irenes chardge: One that ſhe burned Conſtantine the fifte his bones, after he was deade. An other that ſhe Scratched out her ſonnes Conſtantines eies, Mart. whiles he lyued, and berefte him of his empire, and life.

Cōſtātine the fyfte a vvicked emperour blaſphemie.But (ſir) why tolde you not the circumſtances and cauſes, which moued her to digge vpp Conſtantine the fifte his bones, and burne them? VVhy did yow not tell that he was a wicked Emperoure, and ſaide vnto his owne Patriarke Anaſtaſius, that
Chriſte the ſonne of God was not man, nor borne of the virgine Marye, otherwiſe then he was him ſelfe borne of his mother, called in like manner Marie? VVhy did yow not tell that when he was plagued morbe elephantico, and miſerablie tormented, he ſaied lying on his death bed, I am condemned to euerlaſting fire? Deſperation. VVhy did yow not tell that Irene vnderſtanding this, and exhorted by Theodorus then patriarke, digged vp his bodie and burnte it, and caſt the aſhes in the ſea? VVhy I ſay did yow not tell all this? And (which is not to be omitted) why did you not tell that the ſaide Conſtantine digged vp ſainctes bodies and caſt them into the ſea,Impietie. and cōpelled a gentlewoman of Bizance to digge vp her huſbandes bones after he had ben longe buried, and caſt them into the ſea, where theaues, murderers, and ſacrilegers were wonte to be caſte? VVere not all theſe circumſtances to be tolde? Yeas M. Calf. yf yow had delt faithfullie. But if thoſe circumſtāces had ben told, then ſhould all Chriſten men haue vnderſtoode that the iuſt iudgement of God, fell vpon that cruell tirāt, and Irene haue ben iudged to haue done nothing, but that which beſeemed a vertuouſe Empreſſe. But that was not for yower purpoſe, and therfore yow ſuppreſſed all the ſaide circumſtances, and to exaggerate the matter more cruelly made twoe foule lyes. For yow ſay.Fol. 78. a Calf.

This did the good daughter the defendour of images, becauſe her father whē as yet he lyued had broke thē in pieces. Mart. For neither Irene was his daughter, otherwiſe thē by mariage, and not properly to be called daughter,VVhy Irene burned Conſtantines bones. neither was his bodie digged vp and burnt, becauſe he broke and burnt images, but becauſe he denied the incarnation of Chriſte, and died in deſperation, ſayinge. Igni inextinguibili addictus ſum. I am condemned to euerlaſtinge fire.

The other facte which you lay to Irenes chardge is, that ſhe bereaued the Emperour of his crowne, and ſcratched out his eies, and murthered him, which were cruell factes I confeſſe: and as I denie it not, ſo will I not defende it. But ſir, why did you not tell vs, that when the ſaid Emperour had the gouernemēt
in his owne hāde, he put his owne mother in priſon, and that in ſubiectos immaniter ſaeuit. Cōſtātine Irenes ſonne a vvicked tyrāt. He waxed cruell and raged moſt vnmercifullie againſt his ſubiectes? VVhy did yow not tel that he puniſhed diuerſe men with ſtraunge kindes of tormentes, ād gouerned his empire tirānicallie? why told you not that he compelled his owne wife called Marie, to goe into religion and maried his maide? VVhy tolde yow not that he did put out his vncle Nicephorus eies, and cutte of Chriſtophorus and Nicephorus tongues, becauſe the ſouldiers woulde haue created the ſaid Nicephorus Emperour? VVhy tolde you not that he vſed like crueltie againſt many noble men, for which the whole citie of Conſtantinople, and the whole armie conſpired to depoſe him, and make a newe Emperour? VVhy I ſay did you not tell all this? was it not neceſſarie to be tolde? VVould any true meaning mā declare a facte to an others infamie, and conceale the circumſtances? No, I ſuppoſe, in ſuch weightie matters. But let it be yower ouerſight. VVhy did yow not according to yower promiſſe proue by ſcripture, councell, and aunciēt fathers that Irene was as you ſay a Iezabel, Calf. Fol. 78. b an Athalia, a woeman paſt all honeſtie, a woeman that peruerted lawfull counſel, that ſhe might goe a whooringe with her idolls ſtill, a woeman that became more ſauage than a wilde beaſte.

Mart. Prayſes geuen to Irene. Cuſpinia.The hiſtories geue her ſoueraigne praiſe, and greate titles of honour. Some ſaye ſhe was: A moſt godly woeman, more wiſe and politike in gouerning the ſtate, thā Leo and Conſtātin her father in lawe, notable as well for her bewtie, as for her holyneſſe and goodly qualities, a woeman of ſinguler wiſdome, and integritie, worthy to be eſtemed. Some ſaide ſhe was pijſsima imperatrix, Eutropius lib. 22. a moſt godly Empreſſe, and that ſhe tooke the Empire with her ſonne Conſtantine, glorioſe, diuinitus, honorably by the prouidence of God. As for her practiſes againſte her ſonne, Cuſpinianus ſayeth, That ſhe caſt him in priſon, and that afterward his eies were pluckte out, and where for anguiſh and ſorowe he died, vti mulier optima publicum bonum priuata charitati praeferret, that like a good woman ſhe might prefer the profite of the common weale, before her priuate loue. This
conſidered, it had bene reaſon that yow ſhoulde haue broughte ſome auncient father, ſome allowed hiſtoriographer, to haue confirmed yowr ſaying, and improued theſe and ſuch other as I haue brought, before you had fallen into ſuch a raging heate, of rayling without all conſideration of the circumſtances, and cauſes that moued her to do as ſhe did. But I perceaue the frenche prouerbe is true. Vn aſnè picque conuenient que il trotté. An Aſſe prict with the ſpurre muſt needes trotte.

Beſides when yow ſpoke of yower Councell of Conſtantinople aſſembled by Conſtantine the fifte,Fol 58. a ſonne to leo ſurnamed Iſauricus, why did yow not tell vs that the ſaide Leo that ſpoiled the churches, and broke downe images, was moued to doe it by twoe Iewes, Inchaunters, ſorcerers,Zonaras. To. 3. Annali VVhat māner of man he vvas that firſt did pluck dovvne images, and vvhat coūſellers he had for that purpoſe. Zona. To. 3. Annal. Zona. vt ſupra. Zona. 3. Annal. Cuſpinia. and cōiurers who promiſed I fitho prince of Arabia an Empire & longe life, if he would caſte the images of Chriſte and his bleſſed mother out of the churches, and fleing out of Arabia into Iſanria, ꝓmiſed the like to Leo, and aſked nothīg for their rewarde, niſi vt Nazareni er genitricis eius imagines tellerentur: but that the images of Chriſte, and his mother, might be taken awaye? VVhy did you not tell vs that the ſaid Leo promiſing theſe Iewiſh inchaunters to performe their requeſt, beganne warre againſte God, and with a terrible noyſe inuaded the holy images? VVhy did yow not tel that he depryued Germanus of his patriarkſhippe, and ordayned Anaſtaſius, becauſe he would not conſent vnto him for the plucking downe of images? VVhy did yow not tell vs that he ſet a princely palace on fire, and burnt goodly bookes, and twelue notable learned men mayntayned there to the furderaunce of learning, and furniſhinge the Emperour with graue and wiſe Counſelers, and all that was in the houſe, becauſe they would not aſſent vnto him for the deſtroying of images?

VVhy did yow not tell vs that he was an enemye of the Catholique faith, a ſacrileger, a bloud ſucker, a lyonlyke beaſte, couetous, impious, opinatiue againſt the equalitie of Chriſte, the ſonne of God, and true God with his father, an image breaker, and fighter againſt God? The hiſtories reporte theſe thinges and other wickedneſſe of him, as yow may ſee in Eutropius, Zonaras,
and Cuſpinian. This would haue bene tolde, that the people might haue vnderſtoode what manner of man he was that firſt in ſurch raginge ſorte pluckte downe images amongeſt Chriſtians,Leo Iſauricus coū ſellers that moued hym to pluck dovvne images. and what counſellers he had to exhorte him vnto it, to witte twoe Iewes and inchaūters, and what graue fathers he had that did dehorte him frome it, but a greate piece of your ſubtilitie and crafte ſhould haue bene deſcloſed by it. Therfore yow thoughte it not good to medle with it.

Eutropius lib. 21. A deſcriptiō of Cō ſtātine vnder vvhome M. Calfs. coū cel vvas kept againſt images.Againe why did yow not tell vs that Conſtantine the fift ſonne to Leo, was a more wicked mā than his father and a very forerunner of Antichriſte? VVhy did you not tell vs that he was called a perſequutor, an vnmercifull and moſt ſauage beaſte, allwayes cruell, of wilde and beaſtly manners, hurtefull, fearce, rude, a forſaker of God and his ſainctes, delited euen frome his youthe with magicke, inchaūtmēts, ſorcery, blouddy ſacrifices, calling vp of diuells, wantones, riote, and all inuentions that corrupte the ſoule?

VVhy did yow not tell vs that he ſo wallowed in all kinde of vice, that he was, non Chriſtianus, non Paganus, non Iudaeus, ſed colluuio quadum impietatis etc. Not a Chriſtian, not a pagane, not a Iewe, but a certayne lumpe and heape of impietie, lyke the beaſtes of Africa, which are reported to be borne with diuerſe ouhgely ſhapes, by reaſon that the beaſtes of diuerſe kindes do coople togeather?

VVhy did yow not tell vs that he betrayed many of his nobles, cutte of ſome of their heades, pickte out ſome of their eies, puniſhed diuerſe of his counſellers, murdered diuerſe religious men, burnte their houſes, prophaned their churches, ranſacked their Reueſtries, tooke away their Iewells, alienated their landes, and poſſeſsions, and for penaunce had thre wyues at ones? Al this is writtē of hī either in Eutropius, Zonaras, Sigiber te or Cuſpinian, and more, as neadful to be knowne as that which you heaped vp againſte Irene. And I beſeeke yow why was none of all this tolde? Belike yow feared that if ſo much ſhoulde haue bene vttred, men ſhoulde haue learned that they that gaue counſell to the pluckinge downe of images, were
runnagate Iewes, cōiurers, and practiſers with diuells:The emperours that plucked dovvne images The emperoures that followed their counſell, were Tirantes, perſequutors, māquellers, ſacrilegers, forerūners of Antichriſte, enemies of Chriſte, and the vileſt and moſt wickedſt men that profeſſinge Chriſt, euer ſate in that Empire, and ſo yower Conſtantinopolitane Councell againſt images, ſhould haue ben founde to be nothing but a conſpiracie, hatched of the diuell and his miniſters. But that was not Euangelicall ſimplicitie, nor Chriſtiā charitie. Truth ſhould not be concealed, nor the ignorant deceaued, with glorious wordes. VVell may a miniſter face out a lye for a tyme, but certainly tyme will diſcouer it, and reueale it to his vtter ſhame.

And as for yow M. Calf. ſeing yow like ſo well that Conſtā tinopolitane conſpiracie aſſembled by Conſtātine the fifte, that yow prefer it before the true and laufull councell, aſſembled at Nice, take heede leſt many thincke of yow, as they did in thoſe dayes of Conſtātine the fifte. Is it not a foule ouerſighte of yow to worthie that Councell of authoritie that was aſſembled by an enemie of Chriſtes faith, and religion? kept by heretical biſhoppes, who dertermined what pleaſed thē, and neither had the biſhope of Antioche, Alexandria, Hieruſalem, Lib. 4. ca. 9. Tripart. Lib. 5. cap. 29 Tripar. nor Rome preſent at their conuenticle? VVheras the order of the primityue churche was, and at this preſent is, that no councell ſhould be heald and reputed good and laufull, which the biſſhope of Rome did not confirme, and ratifie? Is it not a groſſe ignorance to affirme that Eutropius ſaieth there were 338. biſhoppes at that aſſemble, wheras he ſayeth.Lib. 22. The wicked Conſtantine gathered Iniquum concilium triginta octo epiſcoporum, a wicked Councell of thirtie and eighte biſſhopps againſte the holy and venerable images? For ſhame where was yower eie ſighte, when yow looked in Eutropius, or did you not looke in him at all, but ſpeake by the aduiſe of ſome learned brothers note booke? who for the worde (iniquum in Eutropius, wrote tercentum, Lib. 22. and made a ſtraunge Metamorphoſis,) yf yow did ſo, (vnleſſe he hath better euidence than I can yet ſe) he deceaued him ſelfe and yow bothe. For Eutropius printed at Baſile, by Frobenius, the yeare of our
lorde 1532. writeth thus. Conſtantinus impius contra ſanctas & venerabiles imagines concilium iniquum triginta octo Epiſcoporum congregauit. That is, wicked Conſtantine gathered a wicked councell of thirtie and eight biſſhoppes againſt the holy and venerable images. And albeit Sigibertus reporteth, that there were thre hūdred and thirtie, yet might yow haue better credited Eutropius, as more auncient and likelyer to knowe the truthe then he. And haue imagined that the printer mighte ſooner adde a figure of 3. to 30. than an other printe, iniquum, for tercētum, that is (wicked) for three hundred. But it was not for yower purpoſe.

VVherfor ſir, ſeinge yow will not tell the people what they were that firſte gaue councell that images ſhoulde be plucked downe, nor ſignifie what māner of mē they were that wroughte theſe troubles in Chriſtes Churche, to declare it breiflye (albeit the wiſer may ſee it by that which is declared alredie) yeat for the furder vnderſtādinge of the ſimpler, I will ley it downe playnlie, and truely, as euery man that will reade, Zonaras, Eutropius, Sigebertus, Suidas, and Cuſpinian of theſe Emperours liues may ſee.

The counſellers of plucking dovvne images.This firſt holy men that perſuaded the Chriſtians to throwe downe images, were twoe Iewes, bothe runnagates, inchaunters ſorcerers, and coniurers and practiſers with the deuil. And an other runnagat called Bezer who had forſaken his Chriſtianitie, and became a Iewe. Theſe were the counſelers. The Emperours that followed theſe counſellers were Leo Iſauricus, The emperours that follovved their coū ſel. Leo Iſauricus. Conſtantine the fifte, Leo the 4. and Conſtantine the ſixte. As for Leo Iſauricus, he was as yow heard before an enemye of the Catholique faith, a ſacrileger, a bloud ſucker, a Lyon like beaſte, couetous, impious, opinatiue againſte the godheade of Chriſte, an enemy of God: he depriued an holy patriarke and placed an heretike, he burnt a goodly and prīcely palace, with the bookes, iewells, ornamentes, and all the learned men that were within it.Cōſtātine the fyft. Conſtantine the fifte, ſonne to Leo, was many degrees worſe then his father, euen a verye forerunner of Antichriſte, as cruell a perſequutor of the Chriſtians, as Decius or any of the heathen Emperours was. He was of wilde and
beaſtly māners, a forſaker of God and his ſainctes, ſo fearce and rude that he was called a moſt vnmercifull and cruell beaſte, he delyted in wantones and riotte, he had great pleaſure in ſorcerie, magicke, and inchauntemētes, in blouddie ſacrifices, and callinge vp of diuells. He worſhipped Venus, Suidas. offred humane ſacrifices vnto her, and killed boyes for to pleaſe her. He betrayed his nobles, cutte of their heades, pickte out ſome of their eies, murdered diuerſe religiouſe men, and ſpoiled them. He digged vp ſainctes bodies, and hurlde them into the ſea. To be ſhorte, he was as ye hearde before, neither Chriſtiā, nor pagane, nor Iewe, but a certayne lumpe and heape of impietie, like the beaſtes of Africa, that are of diuerſe oughely ſhapes. Vnder this ſweete Emperour,Leo 4. M. Calfhills Councell of Conſtātinople was kepte againſt images, and God will. Leo, ſonne to this Cōſtātine, was as wicked a man as his father, and heire aſwell of his impietie, as of his empire. Conſtantine the ſixte his ſonne,Conſtantine 6. walked as his father did, and was a very tirante murdered his nobles, put his owne mother in priſon, forced his owne wife to enter into religion, pickte out his vnckle Nicephorus eies, cut of Chriſtophorus and Nicetas tongues, and did ſuch horrible and villanouſe actes, that the whole citie of Conſtantinople deteſted his crueltye, and ſoughte meanes to depoſe him. Theſe were the emperours that made the blouddye bickering againſt images, theſe were they that defaced the churces, of the Chriſtiās, and broke, and burnte the images of Chriſte, and his ſainctes. Theſe our proteſtantes followe, theſe they take for their preſident. Vnder one of theſe, yea vnder the vileſt of them all, was the conſpiracie of Conſtantinople kept by a fewe ſchiſmatical biſſhops contrarye to all order and lawe. And this they reuerence and prefer before the lawful councel of Nice.

Nowe whether they are to be followed, and their preſident imitated of any Chriſten man, I leaue it to the indifferent readers. In all good Chriſtian heartes, that can not be thought to tende any thing to the honour of God, which was deuiſed by Iewes that were inchanters, ſorcerers, and coniurers, and practiſers with the diuel, and put in practiſe by Tirantes, perſequutors,
enemies of God, and faith of Chriſte, as they were that broke and aboliſhed images.

As for the councell of Nice, that it was a lawfull generall Councell, ſummoned duelye and kept orderlye, and confirmed truly, as the eccleſiaſticall ordinaunce haue decreed, No mā denieth, but either he that is alltogether blinded with hereſie, or not traualed in readinge the hiſtories of the churche. He that hathe read no more but the talke of Paulus Patriarche of Conſtantinople vnto the Empreſſe Irene, and her nobles, and marked the ſadde and graue oratiō that Tharaſius that ſucceded him, made before this councell was kepte, can not choſe but ſaye it was, Sancta & vniuerſalis ſynodus. An holy and generall Synode. And ſo for all M. Calfs. Serpentine tongue we wil accepte it, vntil his Maſterſhipp proue by the ſcriptures, councels, and fathers that it was no general and lawful Coūcel. That which he fathereth vpon Carolus magnus, is as true as the booke againſt images, to witt nought, els but a very ſclaunder.

S. Ambro.VVhere, vpon S. Ambroſe wordes extolling the croſſe and making a compariſon betwene a church and a ſhip, where it is ſaied: As a church can not ſtand without a croſſe: Euen ſo a ſhip is weake without a maſt, I made this argumēt, That muſt needes be in the church, without which the church can not ſtād: But (as S. Ambroſe ſaieth) a church can not be without a croſſe: Therfore a croſſe muſt needes be in the church, M. Calfhil like a cūnīg carpenter, that knoweth a fyne ſleight to plucke downe churches, thinketh in deede that no churche can ſtād without a croſſe. Fol. 79. b Calf. For vnleſſe ye haue (quoth he) the croſſe beames, and croſſe pillers with one piece of tymber ſhutte into an other, which is the very ſigne of the croſſe, I can not tell howe the building can abide. Mart. Is not this a high point of ſkill in ſuch a maſter workman? Yf one had ben prentiſe x. yeares to Iohn Iumbler, this profounde paradoxe, might right well become his bald head, when his night capp is of. But I beſeke you ſir, is Crux Latin for a croſſe beame, and croſſe piller? Or was S. Ambroſe (a moſte eloquēt father in the iudgemēt of all lerned mē) ſo ignorant
and barbarous in your ſight that the knewe not what was Latin for a croſſe beame, or croſſe piller? Or yf he knewe it,Crux neuer taken for a croſſe beame nor croſſe piller. was his tongue ſo ſtuttring that he coulde not vtter the concept of his mynde? But muſt he neades take Crux, for a croſſe beame? Fye for ſhame? Conferre your Calepine, Looke on M. Copers dictionarie, ſearche the vocabularie that you lerned at Ludlowe conſult with the Cobler at Quene hiue, and vpon mature deliberation, Let vs heare their better aduiſe. That S. Ambroſe is not ſo to be vnderſtanded, al wiſe men ſee beſide your ſelfe.

In the ſame place he ſaieth: Arbor quaedam in naui, Serm. 55. S. Ambro. vvreſted. eſt crux in eccleſia. The croſſe in the churche is as it were a certaine tree in the ſhippe. The tree in a ſhipp (that is to ſay) the maſt, is not a croſſe beame, nor croſſe piller, ergo nor the croſſe in the church. Againe where ſtrayt vpon the ſimilitude he inferred theſe wordes: For by and by the deuil doth diſquiet it, and the winde doth ſquatte it. But where the ſigne of the croſſe is ſet vp, by and by both the iniquitie of the deuill is beaten backe, and the tempeſt of wynde appeaſed, it is manifeſt, that, ſignum Crucis, the ſigne of the croſſe, doth not ſignifie nor croſſe beame, nor croſſe ſayle. For the deuill is neither a fraied of a croſſe beame, nor wynde alayd with hoyſing vp the croſſe ſayle. The croſſe beame hath no force to driue away the iniquitie of the deuil,S. Amb • o. meaning far vvide from M. Calfs. fanſie. nor the croſſe ſaile power to alay the winde as the ſigne of the croſſe hath, of which S. Ambroſe ſpeaketh. VVherfore he muſt needes haue a farre other meaning thā that which our miniſter deuiſeth of a croſſe ſayle or maſt. And what other can it be, but that whiche he him ſelfe diſcourſeth of in thoſe ſermōs, the very ſigne of our croſſe, which throughe the merites of his paſsion hath ſuch vertue that it driueth away the iniquitie of the diuell, from the churche vpon the land, and aſſuaged the tempeſt of the winde vpon the ſeas. For the firſt you may take exāple of the church, preſerued from fier, by the ſigne of the croſſe in Nola, for the ſecond,Sir Ambro. Caue. ſir Ambroſe Caue on of the Quenes maieſties honorable coūcell, ſometymes knight of the Rhodes cā tell youe that by Rhodes there is a litle Ilād, ād in that a rode, for ſhippes, where no anker, nor cabel will hold the ſhip, vnleſſe the maryner make the ſigne of the croſſe ouer
the place where he caſteth his cable and pitcheth his ancker, this hath he reported to diuerſe men of worſhip, and as he loueht, the faith of a gentle man, and deſireth to be reputed for a faithfull knight, So I dare ſay he will not be a ſhamed to ſay againe, that which he hath ſo oftē ſaied before. Nowe ſir where you ſay,Calf. Fol. 80. my ignorance, or vnfaithfulnes is to apparant for fathering theſe wordes, yf a church lack a croſſe, by and by the diuel doth diſquiet it, and the winde ſquatte it, Vpon S. Ambroſe,

Mart.I muſt tell yow that your ſkill is very ſimple, yf you can not pyck that ſenſe almoſt worde, for word out of S. Ambroſe: and your rudeneſſe to apparant, yf you can not ſee that he talketh there of iiij. thinges, a churche and a ſhippe, the diuel and the wynde, the diuel for diſquieting the churche, the winde for ſquatting the ſhipp: Beſides I muſt tell you that you are to be noted of vnfaythefulnes in tranſlating the ſentēce of S. Ambroſe, alleaged in this place, as ſhal apeare whē I come to treate of your falſe interpretations and tranſlations. In the meane ſeaſon what meaneth your wiſdome,Calf. Fol. 80. b to ſay, that yf my opinion be true, we neede not feare the burning any more of Paules, make a croſſe on the ſteple and it ſhalbe faſe? Mart. Becauſe S. Ambroſe, and I vpon creditte of his worde ſaied, that a churche can not ſtand without a croſſe, will you with your logick, make vs ſay, that it can not be burned, yf it haue a croſſe? no M. Calfhil. All the witt in your head, and ſophiſtrie that you lerned, is not able to do it. VVe knowe when God vpon iuſt indignatiō will puniſh, nothing is worthy to ſtand in his ſight. VVherefor no meruell yf neither croſſe, neither policie of men could help that terrible fyer ſent from heauen, to declare the wrath of God, for polluting his church with your ſchiſmaticall ſeruice and horrible blaſphemie when by right order of the church the feaſt of corpus Chriſti, ſhould haue ben celebrate.

Calf. Fol 80. b A notable lie.VVhere you ſay that, twiſe whithin fiftie yeares the like plague happened in the moſte Catholik tyme, I muſt craue pardon, and ſay, Sir reuerence of your miniſtery, ye lye. For no cronicle
ſithens the church was firſt builded maketh mention that Paules ſteple was ſet a fier with lightning frō heauē and burnt downe to the battilments, and the whole bodie of the church with certayne yles cleane cōſumed, and the communion table burnt in the quier within the cōpaſſe of three or foure houres, on corpus Chriſti yeaue, as of late it was. VVherfore you may be a ſhamed of this lowde lye,Fol. 80. b to ſay that the like plague happened twiſe within the compaſſe of l. yeres. VVhere as it is not to be founde, that it happened ſo much as ones, thanked be God. In deede it was ones or twiſe ſett a fier, but quēched by the goodneſſe of God ſtrayt, without any great harme, and ones hapely by a morowe maſſe prieſt. VVhich I meruell why you did omitte to reporte. But you had rather aduenture your credit in facing a lie, thā by reporting the truth, ſay any good a of prieſt. God requit it you in that day.

Againſt Lactantius you ſay much to no effect.Fol 81. a Yf he can not confirme our doctrine ſo well as impugne others, as S. Hierome ſayeth, why do you alleage his words ſo thicke? Seing his workes be accompted by Gelaſius inter Apocripha, Ibidem. Heretikes accompte Lactatius vvoorkes inter Apocripha, and alleage them for their purpoſe. ſuch as may be read, an no doctrine grounded on, as you ſay, why do you and the authour of the image homilie, vſe his authoritie? There is not one authour of whome you borrowe more teſtimonies, but euil applied againſt images, than out of Lactantius, and is not this ſhame for yowe? The lawe ſaieth: Nemo debet conſequi beneficium ex eo quod nititur impugnare: No man ought to obtaine benefite of that which he endeuoreth to ouerthrowe. VVherefore ſeing you ouerthrowe the auctoritie of the witneſſe, which you bring, there is no reaſon why you ſhould take any aduauntage or helpe by his wordes. But what is it that hereticks will not doe? what corner that they will not ſeeke? what hole that they wil not prie, to eſpie ſome aparant colour to ouercaſt their euil fauored fantaſies? Lactātius when he ſeemeth to make for thē, is an aunciēt and approued father. VVhē he maketh againſt thē, then either his workes be accompted Apocripha, not ſownde ynough to builde any doctrine vpon, either vtterlie reiected
as none of his.Fol. 81. a Calf. As for exāple, his verſes vpon the paſsiō M. Calf. verelye ſuppoſeth to be none of his making, and is induced to thinke ſo for theſe three cauſes.M. Calfs. reaſons vvhy the verſes of the paſsiō be not Lactantius ovvne. Mart. Firſt S. Hierome making mention of all his writinges maketh no mention of this. Secondarely churches were ſcarcely builded in his time. Thirdly that it was a doctrine different frō that which he him ſelf taught, and was generallie receaued in his daies. But if any might be ſo bolde to aſke this croſſe crucifier howe he proueth, that S. Hierome made mention of all Lactantius workes, what could he ſay? Howe woulde he ſhift his hādes, and make it appeare that Lactantius wrote ſo many bookes, and no more? and that S. Hierome ſawe all thoſe bookes? It would grauel him. As euery mā beleaueth that S. Hierome deſirous of learning read much, and ſawe muche: So no wiſe man thinketh it poſsible, that he coulde read or ſee all that was written. VVherefore ſeing many thinges might eſcape his ſight, and come to knowledg many hundred yeares after, this is no ſufficient cauſe to ſay. S. Hierome maketh no mention of that booke, ergo it was none of Lactantius writing. No more than yf one would ſay, Iohn Fox maketh no mention in his Martyrloge that Crammer was pardoned for traiſon, and burned for hereſie, ergo it is not true that he was a traitour and an hereticke.

As for the ſecond cauſe, that churches were ſcarcely builded in Lactantius daies, it would haue proued a ſtark lye, yf he had not ſaied, ſcarcely. For that the Chriſtians had churches and places of praier, yea in the Apoſtles time and euer afterwarde albe it not ſo gorgiouſly builded, nor freely frequēted, as they haue ben ſithens the tyme of Conſtantine the great, apeareth both by the ſcripture,The Chriſtians had alvvayes churches. and eccleſiaſticall hiſtories, as in parte I haue proued before. S. Paule rebuking the Corinthians for eating and drinking in the churche, ſaied: Haue ye not houſes to eate and drinck in? Aut eccleſiam Dei contemnitis? Or do ye contēne the churche of God?1. Cor. 1. Cap. 14. In the ſaied epiſtle he ſaied it is ſhame for a woman to talke in the church, and talketh of the coming in of the idiote ād ſimple into the churche, which argueth that they
had then a churche, that is to ſay ſome place where they might pray, and to whiche men might reſorte. S. Hierome telleth that Cornelius houſe was made a churche.In vita Paulae.

Philo Iudaeus who lyued in the tyme of the Apoſtles, ſpeaking as Euſebius noteth, De eccleſiis, of the churches, which the Chriſtē men had at that tyme, writeth thus.Euſeb. lib. 2. cap. 17. hiſto. Eſt in ſingulis locis conſecrata orationi domꝰ. There is in euery place, a houſe hallowed to praier, which is called a monaſterie which in our tongue may ſignifie a companie of honeſt men, vnto which place,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Religious men and vvoemen in the time of the Apoſtles. Hymnes. Lib. 7 cap. 11. hiſto. Eccle. In inferiora altaris. Aulters. Libro 8. cap. 25. Fol. 81 b M. Calf. cōuinced by this ovvne vvordes. ſome ſeuering them ſelues from the world, leade a vertuous and chaſte life, and bring nothing into that place that apartayneth to meate and drinke, or other neceſſarie ſeruice of the bodie, but only the bookes of Moyſes, and volumes of the prophets and hymnes to ſerue God, and ſuch other things.

Euſebius declareth that whē in the perſecution of Valerian, at Caeſaraea a citie in Paleſtine, one Marinus ſhould be put to death, the biſhop toke him by the hand, and leed him, Ad eccleſiam, to the church, and there, with many woordes confirming him to the faith brought him to the inner parte of the aulter and animated him to martirdom. Again in the xxv. chapiter of the ſaied booke there is ſpeciall mention of a churche made in a manner by miracle. For at the praier of S. Dioniſe of Alexandria, a rocke was removed, and place made to builde a church. But what ſeek I furder proufe of this, ſeing, M. Calfhils owne woordes confeſsing that Diocletian hurled downe, and ſpoyled the temples of the Chriſtians, proue it euidently: for yf he ſpoiled their temples and hurled downe their churches in his tyme, then before his tyme, temples and churches were builded, and Chriſten mē ſerued God in them.

Beſides where he ſaieth,Calf. Fol. 85. b that the Chriſtians had their Oratories pluckt downe, and therfore had no leyſure nor libertie, to be at ſuch idle coſt, nor had tyme to make images of Chriſt, it maketh nothing to the purpoſe.Mart. For let it be vndoubtidly true that the perſequution vnder Diocletiā was ſo terrible that the Chriſtians, had neither libertie, nor leyſure to make images, wil M. Calf. inferre vpon it, ergo they could not looke
vpon thoſe which were made before? Ergo Lactantius, did not make thoſe verſes exhorting euery man to woorſhip the croſſe? Stragling argumēts No, I ſuppoſe, if he be in his wittes. Theſe argumēts ſtragle far, and wide from all good reaſon, much like as yf either an idle ſouldier would ſay: The enemie came ſo faſt and fierce vpon vs, that we could not runne to the armarie to fet newe weapō, ergo we could not fight with the olde: or a horſe leeche and Mountibanck, wolde reaſon thus: when Galene wrote his booke of phiſicke, none were ſicke, ergo the worke De ſanitate tuenda, is none of his. For as the ſouldier might fight well with his olde weapon, although he could not come to the Armarie for newe, and Galene write his boke de ſanitate tuenda, to inſtruct all that ſhould be ſycke afterward, although none were ſicke preſently: So albeit the Chriſtians were ſo perſequuted that they had no leyſure to make newe images, yet were they not ſo ſtraighted, but that they might behold the olde. And although the churches were throwē downe, and no croſſe nor Crucifixe left in them, nor Chriſtians then daring openly to worſhip them, yet might Lactantius make thoſe verſes to inſtruct other that ſhoulde come after, aſwell as thoſe that lyued preſently with him. And certes ſeing it apeareth by S. Hierome, that he had a grace in poetrie, and made other workes, carminibus Hexametris, De viris illuſtr. in long verſes, as theſe are, there is more cauſe why this coniecture ſhoulde be true, than that geſſe of M. Calfhils likely: eſpecially ſeing it hath paſſed theſe many yeares vnder his name vncontrolled, yea of Eraſmus, who was a profeſſed enemie to moſt of the auncient fathers workes, yf they had any euident and playne teſtimonie to conuince certayne truthes of the catholike faith againſt the heretike.

But as Lactantius liued vnder Diocletian when Churches, were throwen downe, ſo lyued he long vnder Conſtantine, when churches were a building,De viris illuſtr. Lactatius liued vnder Conſtantine. and dedicated his bokes of diuine inſtitutions, vnto that good Emperour, and as S. Hierome recordeth, taught his ſonne Chriſpus in Fraunce, where the Chriſtians lacked not churches at that tyme. For Conſtātine, by and by as ſone as the councell of Nice was ended, and his ſolemne
feaſt celebrated: Out of hand builded churches in all haſte, Socrat. lib. 2. cap. 18. Tripa. and did it in euery citie, and at the citie that of his name was called Conſtātinople. The firſt church he builded, was not at Hieruſalem in the xxx. yere of his raigne, as it pleaſeth M. Calfhill to lie for his vantage. But of that whē I come to talke of his lyes, this for the preſent I wil aduertiſe the readers that there is no reaſon why Lactantius verſes written of the paſsion ſhoulde be refuſed as none of his, becauſe he lyued vnder Diocletian, when churches were throwen downe. For (as I haue proued) he lyued in great fauour with Conſtantine as it may appere (becauſe he had his ſonne to teache) whē churches in all cities of the Emperours dominions were builded. VVherefor this croſſequareller may whiſſel for a newe reaſon: for his ſecond is nothing worth.

Touching the third cauſe,Calf. Fol. 81. a that this doctrine to worſhip the croſſe, is different from that which Lactantius taught, and was generally receaued in his daies, for a brief anſwer,Mart. we ſay it is very falſe. For he neuer taught that it was vnlaufull to bowe the knee to the ſigne of the croſſe: nor contrarie to the religion of Chriſt to worſhip it, in ſuche ſort and manner, as the Chriſtians doe. Reade his workes ouer and ouer, and you ſhall finde no clauſe, that condemneth this religion of the Chriſtians.Lactātius neuer reproued the vvoorſhipping of the croſſe. In deede he is very vehement, and that iuſtly in his bookes De falſa religione, againſt the gentills, who worſhipped ſtockes, and ſtones, the ſunne, and mone, the earth and ſea, and dead men, and women, as Iuppiter and Iuno for Gods. Their ſuperſtitiō and idolatrie, he conuinceth many waies, and proueth that God is not to be ſought for, in earthly thinges, but in heauen, as the whole chapiter alleaged doth manifeſtly declare, where it is ſaied,Libro 2. cap. 19. who ſoeuer endeuoreth to conſider the myſtery of man and to kepe the dignitie of his nature, let him raiſe vpp him ſelf from the earth, and when his mynd is lifted vp, let him lift vp his eies to heauē. Let him not ſeke God vnder his feete, nor plucke out of the place where he treadeth, that which he muſt adore, For what ſo euer is vnder mā, muſt of neceſsitie be inferiour to man. But God is greater than man, and therfore is aboue, and not beneath, not to be ſought, in this lowe and baſe region, but in the higheſt of all. VVherefor there is no doubt, but that there is no religion, where there is ſimulachrum.
A falſe and fayned image. Simulachrum. Nam ſi religio ex diuinis rebus eſt etc. For yf religion conſiste of Godly thinges, and there is no godly nor diuine thing, but in coeleſtibus: In heauenly thinges, then falſe and fayned images lacke religion, Lactātius ſpeaketh agaīſt the falſe and fayned images of the gētils. becauſe there can be no heauenly thing, in that which is made of the earth, which may apeare euidently to a wiſe man by the name it ſelfe. Quicquid enim ſimulatur id falſum ſit neceſſe eſt, etc. For what ſoeuer is counterfeted, that muſt nedes be falſe, and that can neuer take the name of truth, which by deceit and imitatiō, counterfeteth the truth, and ſo forth, By which it is manifeſt that he ſpeaketh of the groſſe, and idolatrous gentils, that could not lift vp theire heartes to heauē, and ſeeke God there: but had earthly cogitations, and thought the ſunne and moone, the earth, ſea, and the idols which they made, to be their God, and ſo worſhipped them: which to make more plainer, in the neyt chapiter of the ſame booke he ſaieth: Nowe then a great and harde portion of the worke which I tooke in hand, is diſpatched, vnleſſe I be deceaued, and the heauēlye maieſtie geuing me grace, and power to ſpeake, I haue driuen away the old canckred and feſtred errours.

VVherefore vnleſſe M. Calfhils Euangelicall ſpirite hath forced him to fanſie, that the Chriſtians worſhip the ſunne and moone, and dead ſtockes, and ſtones as God, and fett out of the earth, and place where their feete tread, the thing whiche they woorſhipp for God, and be fallen from Chriſtianitie to the olde canckerd and feſtered errours of the idolatrous gentils, he can neither ſay that the Chriſtians erre in woorſhipping the croſſe, nor that the doctrine of Lactantius in his treatiſe vppon the paſſion, is different from that whiche he him ſelfe teacheth. In his other bookes he forbiddeth vs to worſhip idols as the gentils did. In this he counſelleth vs to worſhip the croſſe of Chriſt as the Chriſtians doe, whiche to haue ben euermore laufull in Chriſts churche ſhall euidētly appeare, VVhen I come to talke of adoration in the tenth article.

As for theſe wordes: Carent ergo religione ſimulachra, quia nihil potest eſſe coeleſte in ea re quae fit ex terra, Falſe and forged images lacke religion, be cauſe there can be no heauenly thing in that which is made of earth, it is to be vnderſtand, that ſimulachrum
ſignifieth not as M. Calf. tranſlateth it euer image, but (as Lactantius him ſelf declareth and the Etimologie of the word geueth) a fayned or forged image, ſuch as the gentils images of Iupiter, Mercury, and Apollo were. In ſuche there is no religion, but much impietie. The images that Chriſtē men vſe in their churches are nor fayned, nor forged, but true images of Chriſt, and his bleſſed ſainctes, not honored as Gods, as the Gentils idols were, but vſed to repreſent vnto vs Chriſt and his ſainctes. And ſo farre foorth we do reuerence them and worſhip them, not for the lump of earth, maſſe of metall, or piece of tymber whereof the are faſhioned, but for their ſakes who by them are repreſented. Directing our hearts to the firſt ſamplers,Hovve Chriſten mē vvoorſhip the croſſe. and not fixing our myndes vpon the worke of the artificer, as theſe two verſes: Nam Deus eſt quod imago docet, ſed non Deus ipſa: Hanc videas, ſed mente colas quod cernis in ipſa, God it is that the Roode doth ſhewe, it ſelf no God, but woodde: See this with eie, but ſerue with minde that thereby is vnderſtode, vſed of the fathers of the Nicene councell do manifeſtly declare, and Damaſcene witneſſe, ſpeaking of the worſhipping of the croſſe. VVe adore alſo the figure of the lyuely and precious croſſe, albeit it be made of an other matter, no worſhipping the matter, for God forbid that, but the figure, as the ſigne of Chriſt. By which it is euident that in a thing made of earth, conſidered in his owne naure there is no religion. But in conſideratiō that it ſignifieth a holy thing, no Chriſten man can denie, but that there is ſuche religion in it, that it deſerueth honour and reuerēce of men for the thing ſignified. As for example man is made of earth: Conſider him in his owne nature, there is nothing in him, but a lumpe of clay, and maſſe of ſynne, not to be eſtemed. Conſider him as he is made to the image of God, indued with grace, and waſhed from ſynne in baptiſme by Chriſt, there is an heauenly thing in him worthy to be reuerenced. Yf this ſenſe pleaſe not M. Calfhils honour,M. Calfs reaſon agaīſt hym ſelf. let him reaſon thus with him ſelfe. There can be no heauenly thing in that whiche is made of earth, but I Sir Iames Calfhill am a thing made of earth, ergo there can be no heauenly thing in me, ergo I haue nor modeſtie nor ſhame, nor honeſty, nor truth, nor charitie
nor faith, no vertue, nor grace, nor any other heauenly gift that procedeth from God, an ſo by labouring to proue that Lactantius ſpake againſt the images of Chriſt and his ſaincts, haue ꝓued my ſelf no true mēbre of his church. As for the place of S. Auguſt. Crucis myſterio baſilicae dedicantur. Serm. 19. de Sāctis. Calf. Fol. 82. b Churches are dedicated with the ſigne of the croſſe, M. Calf. ſaieth, he ſpeaketh of no thing els, but of the myſterie of the croſſe, and not of the ſigne, as I ignorātly trāſlate it, Mart. where at I meruaill much. For ꝓteſtants were wounte to be ſo delited with ſignes, that rather thā they would lack a ſigne, they woulde cōtrolle Chriſt of impropre ſpeache and where he ſaied: This is my body, make hī by their interp̄tation ſay: this is not my body, but the ſigne of my body. Here ād in other places where mētiō is made of a ſigne, it muſt not be taken in that ſenſe, that the authours meane, and woords bere well ynough, but for the thīg it ſelf, ād that only and alone without the ſigne. VVhich can not be. For albeit the paſsion of Chriſt doth ſanctifie al thinges (which all Chriſtē men do confeſſe) yet is there no ſanctificatiō wrought by ordinarye courſe to man and the creatures of God,Hovve thinges are ſanctified. but by prayer and other externall meanes. As for example, It is the paſsiō of Chriſt that taketh away our ſynnes, but by the element of water and miniſterie of man in baptiſme. It is the paſsion of Chriſt that doth ſanctifie his creatures,1. Tim. 4. but, per verbū Dei & orationē, By the woorde of God and praier. It is the paſsion of Chriſt that halloweth and conſecrateth churches, but by his miniſter the Byſſhop, praying,In 1. Cor. 7. and making the ſigne of the croſſe, which is, as S. Ambroſe ſaieth: Quaedam ſanctificatio, A certayne ſanctification. For proufe where of, let vs examine a litle better, the place of S. Auguſtine.Serm. 19. de ſanctis. He ſaieth: Crucifixus noſter à morte refurrexit & coelos aſcendit, crucem nobis in memoriam ſuae paſsionis reliquit, crucem reliquit ad ſanitatem. Hoc ſignum praeſidium eſt amicis, etc. That is to ſay: Our ſauiour Chriſt crucified, roſe from death, and aſcended into heauen, he left vs the croſſe in remembrance of his paſsion, the croſſe he left to health, this ſigne is a ſafegard, to the frends, and a barre to the enemyes: with the myſterie of the croſſe, the font of Baptiſme is hallowed, with the ſigne of the ſame croſſe, they that are baptiſed receaue by impoſition of handes, the gifts of
grace, cum eiuſdem crucis charectere baſilica dedicantur, with the ſigne, or figure of the ſame croſſe, churches are dedicated, aulters conſecrated, the ſacraments of the aulter with the putting in betwene of our lordes woordes are made. By this ſelf ſame ſigne prieſtes and Deacons are promoted to holy orders. Thus farre S. Auguſtine: where it is to be noted, that this auncient father,Chriſt left vs the croſſe in remēbrance of his paſsion. ſaying that Chriſt left vs the croſſe in remembraunce of his paſsion, meaneth that Chriſt left vs a true ſigne and figure of his croſſe, otherwiſe we muſt condemne S. Auguſtine of barbariſme, and impropre ſpeache. For yf yow take, Crucem, in that place for the paſsion it ſelf, then muſt yow ſay, Chriſt left his paſsiō in remēbrance of his paſsiō, which we re ſluttiſh a figure to precede frō ſo lerned and eloquēt a father.

Neither can M. Calf. haue any aduantage to eſcape the force of this place by the next wordes following, Crucem reliquit ad ſanitatem, he leaft the croſſe to health, that is to ſay to worke health to men. For the very ſigne of the croſſe throughe the merites and vertue of Chriſtes paſsion, hath wrought health to many, as the hiſtories declare, and S. Auguſtine him ſelf wittneſſeth in his bookes de ciuitate Dei, Libro 22. cap. 8. where he telleth howe a gē tle woman called Innocentia, was cured of a Cancker in her breſt with the ſigne of the croſſe. Beſides the woordes. Hoc ſignum praeſidiū eſt amicis, This ſigne is a ſafegard to freneds and the reſt that follow, declare manifeſtly, that he ſpoke before of the ſigne of the croſſe. To expreſſe the ſame he vſeth theſe termes, ſignū, myſteriū, S. Auguſt. in this place ſpeaketh of the ſigne of the croſſe. character, Signe, myſterie, character, or figure. VVhereas yf he he had meant nothing but the paſsion, it had ben ſufficient to ſay: Cruce rudes cathechizantur, cruce fons regenerationis conſecratur, cruce baſilicae dedicantur, etc. The ignoraunt are thaught with the paſsion, the font of baptiſme is hallowed with the paſsion, churches are dedicated with the paſsiō. He woulde neuer haue vſed ſo many wordes. But he knewe bothe to be neceſſarie. The paſſion as the principall from whence all ſanctification and holynes cometh, the ſigne as an inſtrumēt by which is it deriued vnto vs, and to the thīg which is to be ſanctified. Therfore ſuppoſing all Chriſten men to be verely perſuaded of the firſt, he thought it expedient to commend the ſecond, that is to ſay, the
ſigne of the croſſe, by whiche the ſanctification ſpecified before is wrought.

Beſides, that the myſterie of the croſſe is taken in this place for the ſigne of the croſſe, it may well apeare by an other place of S. Auguſtin,De ſymb. ad Cathec. lib 2 ca. 1. Act. 1. where talking of thoſe that were Catechumeni, younge learners of their faith, he ſaieth as I mentioned before, ye are not yet borne againe by holy baptiſme, but ye are conceaued in the wombe of your holy mother the churche, by the ſigne of the croſſe. For here it is euident, that younge learners, called catechumeni, when they were taught the faith receaued a ſigne of the croſſe, and by that ſigne were adopted in to the numbre of Chriſtians, as the manner was in the primitiue churche, and by that taught howe Chriſt died, which thing S. Auguſtine meaneth here, by theſe wordes: Crucis myſterio rudes cathechizantur, the ignorant are taught with the myſterie of the croſſe. Yf this like not our aduerſaries vayne: Let him conſtrue it, and ſe howe it can ſerue his purpoſe. Calf. Rudes, The ignorant, cathechizātur, are taught myſterio, with the myſterie, crucis, of the croſſe. Mart. VVell, what ca • e is myſterio? Calf. The ablatiue caſe. Mart. why ſo? Calfhill. All verbes require an ablatiue caſe of the inſtrument, of the cauſe or of the maner of doing. Mart. Ah, well done Sir, I perceaue you haue not forgott all your grammer rules. By your rule then, myſterie, in that place ſignifieth, either an inſtrument wherwith they were taught, or the cauſe why they were taught, or the māner howe thei were taught: yf it be ſo, then can it in no wiſe ſignifie the paſsion it ſelf. Becauſe the paſsion is neither the inſtrument, where with they were taught, neither the cauſe why they were taught, nor the māner howe they were taught, but the very thing it ſelf which they were taught, and ſo brought to faith in Chriſt, and hope of eternall ſaluation, by his death.M Calf. cōuinced by his grā mer rules. Thus by his owne cōſtruction, you may perceaue (good readers) that he doth, but cauill and quarell and deceaue the ignorant with ſome ſhewe of woordes. Myſterium in that place of S. Auguſtine can not otherwiſe be taken in the iudgement of any lerned man, than for the ſigne of the croſſe: Neither am I to be accuſed of ignorance for tranſlating it ſo, ſeing the
authour him ſelf doth ſo take it, and reaſon conuince, that it can not be otherwiſe. Mary I muſt cōfeſſe an errour in the printer, who in this place hauing myſterio in his copie, but daſſhed a litle with a penne, and charactere written for it in the margent, ſet myſterio, for charactere, myſterie for charecter, and ſo altred S. Auguſtins wordes, as he hath done in an other place, for which, pardon woulde eſely be obtayned, yf it might be knowen with what difficultie bookes are printed of duitche mē that vnderſtād not our lāguadge. The wordes of S. Auguſtine are: cum eiuſdem crucis charactere baſilicae dedicantur, with the charecter or figure of the ſame croſſe Churches are dedicated.

VVhat is the charecter or figure of the croſſe? the paſsion of Chriſt as M. Calfhil imagineth? no: but one of the inſtruments with whiche churches are dedicated, in honour of Chriſt, to celebrate the memorie of his paſsiō, the very ſigne it ſelf, of which he talketh much in that ſermon. But to diſproue this, M. Calfhil vſeth this fonde reaſon.Fol. 82. b Calf. The ſigne of the croſſe is no ordinarie meane wherbie God vſeth to conferre health vppon the ſicke, ergo he hath not ordayned it to remayne in the churche for any remembraunce of his death and paſsion. Profoundely by S. Mary, and like a clerk,Mart. yf I were acquainted with euer a poynt maker in VValtam, I would requeſt him to geue this fine logiſoner, ſome halfpenny pointes, to tie his looſe arguments to gether. For vnleſſe they be better tied they will raū ge ſo farre, that they will ſhame that their M. for euer: Diogenes on a tyme meetīg a mynſtrell that made as good melodie as this miniſter, maketh argument, vſed this ſalutation vnto him, Salue galle, God morrowe cock, and when the minſtrell aſked, why he ſaluted him after that ſort, mary (quothe.Diogenes Laertius. Quia canens omnes excitas.

Becauſe with your mirry pyping you ſtirre vp all. So yf a man happely meete this our miniſtre early in the morning, he may put of his cappe gently, and ſay, Salue galle, God morrowe M. Cock, and yf he aſke a cauſe why, Diogenes anſwer may ſuffife, Quia omnes excitas, becauſe you ſtirre vs vp all to laughter
with your gay ſophiſtrie. It is muche like as yf one ſhould ſay. The bible is not and ordinarie meane whereby God vſeth to conferre healt vpon the ſicke,M. Calfs. reaſoning ergo God hath not ordayned it to be preached in the Churche for a declaratiō of his holy wil: and ſo proceding a litle furder negatiuely, denie and refuſe the ſcriptures with the Swenkfeldians. VVherefor good readers beware of this younker betyme, let him not deceaue yow any longer with vayne wordes: his reaſon hath no more truth nor ſequel in it, than that, whiche as youe ſee be is both impious and blaſphemours, and yet you ſee, howe he gloſeth it. He telleth a fayer tale that Chriſte,Calf. Fol 82. b left vs his wordes to put vs in mynde of his paſsion, and the poore and comfortleſſe Chriſtiās to feede our eies vpon: as for the Roode and crucifix, they may be compared to the gentils idols. Mart. Touching the firſt, no mā can denie, but that Chriſt hath left his wordes to excite vs. But what of that? will M. Calfhill inferre vpon it, ergo he hath left nothing els beſide his word, to put vs in mynde of his paſsion? All men can not reade, all men can not come to the church. All men can not here a ſermon, all men can not be in place where M. miniſter is at all tymes and all howres: and hath God ordayned nothing to put them in mynde of the paſsion of Chriſt? That were hard. Yf you ſay he hath ordained the poore and comfortleſſe Chriſtians to putte vs, that is as M. Calf. meaneth in his owne perſon, and his brothers, Archedeacons, and Chancellers, deanes and ſuperintēdents, Lordes and Ladies and other that are rich, in remembraunce of his death, what is ordayned for the poore, and cōfortleſſe them ſelues, that ſeldome come to churche, that heare ſermons very rare, that ſcarce haue a miniſter to preache vnto them in a yere? hath he prouided nothing for them? Did Chriſt take ſuch payne to redeme them, and nowe doth he forgett to prouide for them? No M. Calf. God hath ſpeciall care of all, and hath diuerſe waies and meanes beſides his worde, to put vs in remembrance of the death of our Saluiour Chriſte. Of which ſeing it hath pleaſed his diuine maieſtie to ordaine by generall councels (to whiche he promiſed
the aſsiſtance of his grace) and apoynted by the prelats of the churche (to whom he committed the chardg and gouernement of his flocke) the ſigne of the croſſe and images to be one, what impietie is there in you to liken them to the gētils idols, and iudg Chriſten men to be idolatours? Intollerable I aſſure you. The bleſſed martir Iuſtine ſayeth:Quaeſt. 149 Yf to ſuch impietie which opinion and imagination only breadeth talke and aſſertion be added, the impietie is made more greater. Yf it be both affirmed, and put out in writing, of neceſsitie ſuch vngodlynes compriſeth all malice and wickedneſſe.

Your digreſsion and wilde wandering talke,Fol. 83. a and places alleaged out of S. Auguſtine, make nothing againſt our images. All is ſpoken againſt the idols of the gentills, which we deteſt. In his daies Chriſten men had images, yea in the churches, as I haue declared in the preface, and proued M. Calf. both to miſconter, and alſo to falſifie S. Auguſtines wordes. VVherfore credit hym accordingly, and neuer thinke that ſo aūcient a father, and lerned biſſhop as S. Auguſtine was, coulde be ſo fondly affected, as he ymagineth againſt the vſe of the images of Chriſt and his ſaincts amongeſt Chriſtians in the churche.

To come to Paulinus, Fol. 84. a- Calf. Paulinus. our aduerſarie graunteth that a leuen hundred yeres a goe, the ſigne of the croſſe was erected in ſome churches, but he ſaieth, it ſuffiſeth not to ſay, Mart. this was once ſo, but proued it muſt be, that it was well ſo. The preſcription of a leuen hundred yeres, the vſe of Chriſten people, the authoritie of ſo aunciēt a father, as Paulinus was, will not ſerue to diſpute againſt heretickes: we muſt finde manifeſt and euident proufe, yea and that in the ſcripture, that they did well in hauing croſſes in the churches, or els it ſhall not preuaile, nor then neither: VVhat hardnes of heart and incredulitie is this? S. Bernard was wont to ſay, that it was: Imperfecti cordis, De praecepto & diſpēſatione 〈◊〉 . & infirmae voluntatis indicium ſtatuta ſeniorum curioſius diſcutere, etc. A token of an vnperfect heart, and weake will, to diſcuſſe ſomewhat curiouſly the ordināces of their elders, to ſticke at all that is inioyned, to require a reaſon of euery thīg and to ſuſpect euill of euery precept the cauſe whereof is not knowē, neither to obey willingly at any tyme, vnleſſe they heare, that which
happely pleaſe them, or playne reaſon or vndoubted authoritie, do euidently ſhewe, not to be otherwiſe lawfull and expedient. And certes ſo may we ſay of M. Calf. requiring proufe, that the aunciēt fathers did wel in gouerning the church of Chriſt committed vnto their chardge. But ſeing it pleaſeth him to haue it proued that it was well done, I will reaſon thus with him. Paulinus that hearing (as S. Hierome ſaieth) thoſe words of our ſauiour,Epiſt. ad Pauli. de inſtit. Mona • hi. yf thou wilt be perfect, ſell all that thou haſt, and followe me, turned words into workes and following the naked croſſe clymed vp the lader of Iacob, and reioiſed that he was poore, & puris manibus & candido pectore, & ſpiritu & operibus, with cleane hands, ſincere heart, both in ſpirite and all his workes, Paulinus (as S. Ambroſe ſaieth) nulli ſecundus, ſecond to none, Paulinus that gaue away all his goods, Libro 6. epiſt 36. ad Sabi. Quo impenſius Deo ſeruiret: that he might ſerue God more earneſtly, Paulinus Biſshop of Nola▪ copioſiſsimè Lib 1. cap 10. de ciuit▪ Dei. ſanctus, abundantly holy (as S. Auguſtine ſaieth) ſeaking God in ſimplicitie of his heart, Epiſt. 32. ad Pauli. ſentiens de illo in bonitate, & afferens ei claritatem et honorem, thinking of God in goodneſſe, and bringing vnto him glorie and honour,Epiſt. 34 Lib. 3. dial. cap. 1. VVhoſe breſt is ſuche an oracle of God, that we preſumed to haue anſwers geuen frō thence to the moſt babling queſtions, Paulinus (as S. Gregorie ſaieth) Vir domini, the mā of god, that gaue all that he had to poore and nedy captiues, This Paulinus, I ſay, ſo holy, ſo vertuous, and ſo learned a biſshop, ſet vp the ſigne of the croſſe in his churche at Nola, and deſired others by his letters to do the like, and no Catholike Biſshop or generall councell did euer finde fault with him, ergo it was wel done. Yf he denie this argumēt I proue it after this ſort? VVhatſoeuer any holy and lerned father, ſkilful in the ſcriptures of God, and right ſenſe of the ſame did at any tyme, and was neuer controlled of any catholique and lerned father for the doing of it, was wel done, and muſt ſo be taken. But Paulinus an holy and lerned biſhop etc. did ſet vp the ſigne of the croſſe in his church: and was neuer controlled of any lerned and catholique for it: Ergo it was wel done.De corona militis. Yf M. Calf. replie, and ſay, it was done without warrant of ſcripture or commandement from God, Let Tertullian anſwer, he ſaieth: Doeſt not thoue thinke it laufull for euery faithfull man to conceaue and ordaine, eſpeciallie that which is
agreable with God, whiche is expediēt for diſcipline and good order, which is profitable to ſaluation? ſeing our lord ſaieth? VVhy doe ye not iudge of your ſelues that which is good? etc. Yf that will not ſerue, Let S. Auguſt. anſwer, who in one place ſaieth thus:Lib. 50. homi. 49 I fully and wholy warne you of this. I require you, I commaunde you, the biſhop commaundeth you, Chriſt commaūdeth by me. In another place he ſaieth: God hath ſpoke by Angels, by Prophetes, by his owne mouth, In Pſal. 49 by his Apoſtles he him ſelf ſpeaketh by his faithfull ſeruants, by ſuch a ſimple man as I am he ſpeaketh, when I ſpeake the truth, he maketh a ſounde euery where, tangendo, modificando & inſpirando. By touching directing, and inſpiring their hearts. By which it is manifeſt that what ſoeuer is done, by the biſshops and faythfull diſpenſers of Chriſts myſteries in the vnitie of the churche to the honour of God, is done by God him ſelfe, who geueth his ſtewards commiſsion here in earth, to plant, and ſowe the ſeede of his Ghoſpell, and worke all things they cā, to the edifying of his body,Epheſ 4. which is the churche vntill we meete all in the vnitie of faith and knoweledg of the ſonne of God. So that M. Calf. neadeth no longer doubte, but that it was well done to ſett vpp the ſigne of the croſſe in the church, ſeing it was done by ſo lerned and holy a biſshop, and faithfull ſteward of Chriſt, as Paulinus was, who knowing his maiſters will in his ſcriptures, would neuer aduentred to haue ſet vp that ſigne, yf from the beginning of Geneſis to the laſt letter of the Apocalypſe, which he had oftentymes read, and profundely tryed) he coulde haue founde any precept, or clauſe that did fobid it.

VVhereas he chardgeth Paulinus, for commending a woman, Fol. 84. b. Calf. that ſeparated her ſelfe from her owne huſband vnder p̄tēce of religion, and citeth in the margēt the 3. epiſtle ad Aprium. I geue him to vnderſtand,Mart. that he fouly reporteth this holy father. In all his third Epiſtle, ad Aprium, there is no ſuch thing to be founde, but the cōtrary. VVhereby it apeareth,Paulinus ſclaundered. that M. Calfhil truſteth Melanchton, Luthers ſlaue to much, and would not remoue his eie from the booke whiche he made (de eccleſia) of the church, to the originall and epiſtle of Paulinus, where the very argument ſheweth, that he commendeth Apers wife, becauſe
ſhe abſtayned from wedlock woork, by the conſent of her huſband, according to S. Paules counſell.

In the epiſtle it ſelfe there be two notable places, that conuince this to be an open ſclander. The firſt is this: Benedicti vos domino etc. You are bleſſed of God, who made both one, hyding two in hym ſelfe, woorking miracles alone, who turneth not only ſoules, but affections, chaunging temporall things, into ſuch as are euerlaſting. Beholde, ye that were before one, mā and wife, are not nowe mā and wife, as ye were. You being the ſame, are not the ſame. As ye did not knowe Chriſt in fleaſh: So you do not knowe one an other according to the fleaſh. Haec mutatio dextrae excelſi. This change is of the right hand of the higheſt. The ſecond place is this: Non illam a propoſito tuo diſcors abiungit volūtas. No diſagreing will, doth ſeparate her from thy purpoſe. But (which is more maruell) one vniforme faith doth diuide her in woork, that is ioined in will. By which it is euident that Aper and his wife did very well agree together, and ſeparated them ſelues by mutual conſent, from carnal company. Aper entring into holy orders, and made a biſshop, his wife remayning in the ſtate ſhe was before, addreſsing her huſbands woordly things, and not refuſing his company, as M. Calf. falſlie affirmeth without mutual conſent vnder cloke of religion.

Fol. 84. bBeſides where he ſaieth that Paulinus affirmeth that the boke of the epiſtles which the Apoſtles wrote, layd vnto diſeaſes healed them, A lye fathred vpō Paulinus. and alleageth for it, his verſes, ad Cytherium, tracke him he that will and he ſhall take him in a lye, and well vnderſtand that he leaueth the goodly pleaſant ryuers, and fiſsheth in durtie puddells and ſtinking lakes. Firſt Paulinus there, ſpeaketh not in generall of the bookes of the Apoſtles epiſtles, but of the booke of S. Paules epiſtles only. Then he ſaieth not that they were layed vnto diſeaſes, but telleth howe one Martinianus, with other Chriſtians, being in danger of drowning, was preſerued by that boke, through the goodnes of God, who as he he gaue. S. Paule ones, all their lyues that were in the perill of death vpon the ſea, ſo he gaue Martinianus and his company at that tyme. But as for any one fillable of leying it vnto diſeaſes, it
is not there to be founde. VVherefore what credit ſhal we geue to this croſſe byter, who with a falſe ſclander and vaine lye, laboureth to diſcredit ſo auncient a father? Any more then to a ſclanderer and lyer? He that lyſteth to be deceaued may: he that leeketh to vnderſtād the truth will better trie, ere he truſt, yf he be wiſe.

Yf Paulinus had either commended Apre wifes, for ſeparating her ſelf from her huſband without mutual conſent, or affirmed that the bookes of the apoſtles epiſtles layed to deſeaſes healed them, yet ſhould the worde of God haue neuer the leſſe force, nor medicines be abhorred, nor men accōpted fooles for imitating of him, in ſetting vp the ſigne of the croſſe. For where a Doctour ſwarueth from ſcripture, no man ought to followe him: where he ſpeaketh not againſt the ſcripture, but tendeth to edifying, and hath the vſe of the churche and conſent of all Catholik Biſhops for that doctrine, therin whoſoeuer doth not followe him ſhalbe acompted but an arrogāt fole, Confidens in ſtultitia ſua, truſting in his owne folly.Prouer. 17

Nowe let vs conſider, what he ſaieth againſt Iuſtinians cō ſtitutions, and cuſtome of the Church. Firſt he ſaieth,Iuſtinianus. Calf. Fol. 84 b Fol 8 • . a Mart. that the order taken by Iuſtinians conſtitutions, That no man builde a churche, before the Biſhop hath conſecrated the place with praier, and ſet vp the ſigne of the croſſe, is but politique, as he anſwerd to the Synode kept at Orleance, and no matter of Religion. But let me aſke him this queſtion. Yf it were only a ciuil policie, why was it not done by a ciuil magiſtrate whom God hath ordayned to rule in politique matters ād ciuil affaires? Yf it were no matter of religion why is the biſhop required to be there? VVhy is he willed to hold vp his handes to heauen, to hallowe the place with praier? and to ſet vp a croſſe, more than any other thinge? Is it not the marke that ſigneth, Emperours and kinges, princes, and dukes and all that wilbe ſaued by chryſt, in the forhead? Is it not the marke and ſigne as Iuſtinian ſaieth) noſtrae ſalutis, of our ſaluation? No Chriſten man beleuing that our redemption was wrought vppon the croſſe, can thinke otherwiſe. The Biſhop then being religious for his perſon, the lyfting vp of his handes
praying, and conſecrating, pertayning to religion, why ſhould, the ſetting vp of the croſſe required to be done, as well as the reſt, and that with prayer and conſecration, which pertaine to religion, and by a biſhop who is religious, why I ſay ſhould it be politique only and no matter of religion? M. Calf. forgeteth his old logick rule, that ſaieth ſimilium idem eſt iudicium, of thinges that are like we muſt haue like iudgement. Yf he do ſo, yet I truſt he remembreth his grammer rule that teacheth him, that all that belong to one thing muſt be put in one caſe. The biſhop that dedicateth the churche is religious, the holding vp of his hands, and conſecraring with praier pertayne to religiō. Therfore the ſigne of the croſſe, which is one of the three thinges, that Iuſtinian requireth in dedicating of a churche, is a matter of religion, aſwell as the reſt, and not politique and ciuil, as our yoūge M. p̄tendeth: but put caſe that it appartayneth to the external policie of the church? May there any vnlaufull thīg be allowed, for the ſettīg foorth the policie of the church? No. But let that be pardoned. whye ſayeth he: that Iuſtinian liued in the tyme of great ignorance and barbaritie, Fol. 85. a. and enacted a thing contrary to truthe? Yf there were nothing els, the writing of the ciuil lawe,Iuſtinian lyued not in tyme of ignorance. might playnly conuince againſt him, that men of thoſe daies were neither ignorant, nor barbarous. It is ſo wittely conceaued, and ſo eloquently penned, that yf wiſdō were to be ſought, and eloquence loſt, they might be founde t •• re. In his tyme liued Priſcianus, a notable grāmarian. Procopius, a lerned hiſtoriographer, Arator, a diuine poet. Caſsiodorus a notable diuine, Benedictus, a vertuous and learned abbot. S. Medard, and Gildard both Biſhops and Brothers by one father, and mother,Vide Pantaleon. Doctiſsimi, very excenllently learned, Siluerius pietate & eruditione pollens, notable for Godlynes and lerning. In his time the fift generall councell was kept at Cōſtantinople againſt iiij. famous heretikes, Peter, Anthymus, Seuerus and Zoaras, to the which Epiphanius, biſhop of Tyrus, and other lerned Biſſhops vnder him ſent their learned epiſtles, by which it is eaſy to be perceaued that Iuſtinian lyued not in the tyme of ignorāce and barbaritie.

As for his lawes whether he enacted any thing cōtrary to
