a truth, let ſuch as haue authoritie iudge. They that are bounde to lyue according to the preſcript of lawes, muſt not ſit in iudgemēt of the equitie of the lawes. It is an euil cōmon weale, where euery theafe may ſay, the lawes of the lawfull prince are enacted conrrary to a truth. Yet ſuch is the audacitie of heretikes that whatſoeuer lawe liketh not their ligier and light braynes, they will ſay it is enacted contrary to a truth. But howe proue you M. Calfhill that this lawe of Iuſtinian is enacted cō trary to a truth? Hath Chriſt who is truth it ſelf, forbidden it? Hath the worde of God (which is infallibly true) inhibited it? Haue any Apoſtle or general councell ruled by the holy Ghoſt condemned it? Yf it be ſo open your ſecrets, and communicate them with vs. VVe reade the ſcriptures and can finde no ſuch inhibition. VVe turne ouer the councells, and can note no ſuch countermaunde. The dailie practiſe of the church aſsiſted, according to Chriſts promiſe with the holy Ghoſt, ſheweth vs the cōtrary. Pius the fourth of bleſſed memorie, building a churche in theſe later dayes, hallowed it him ſelf, and according to the order of the Canons, and this lawe of Iuſtinian ſet vp there: Venerabilem crucem, ſignum ſalutis noſtrae. A reuerend croſſe the ſigne of our ſaluation VVhich is a materiall croſſe, M. Calf. a croſſe in the fourth ſignification, of the which I promiſed to ſpeake. Looke to my diuiſion in the firſt Article, and yf you finde it ſo, then deceaue not the ſimple with inuerting my woordes. And ſeing you accompte, Iuſtiniās authoritie graue that calleth the croſſe, venerabilem, adorandam, & vere honorandam, reuerend, worthie to be adored, and truly worſhipped, and accompteth it, Signum ſalutis noſtrae: The ſigne of our ſaluation, thinke your owne head, but fantaſticall, and iudgement very light, for accompting it impious, and blaſphemous, and calling it an heatheniſh obſeruance, a magical inchauntmēt, and cōqueſt againſt Chriſtiās.

VVith all, conſider that you gayne nothing but ſhame to your ſelf: euery boy in the ſcholes can tell you, that, opponere non eſt ſoluere: An obiection far from the matter, is no anſwer. The conſtitution that you bring of Valens and Theodoſius, againſt the
lawe of Iuſtinian, Fol 85. a Valēs and Theodoſius. is borrowed out of the image homilie, and that which you attribute to Petrus Crinitus the homilie authour referreth to one Petrus Erinilus. In the which you are both groſſely deceaued, you for truſting Petrus Crinitus, as a receaued authour, who liued but of late yeres, and was of no fame, nor profounde lerning, but ſkilled in poynts of humanitie, like a pedāte of Italie: He for fathering that vpon an authour whoſe name is a well knowē as the mā in the mone. VVe may perceaue what narrow ſhiftes you ſeeke, when for a proufe of ſo auncient a lawe, you repaire to him that lyued in a maner, but yeſterday. Swete flowres be rare where nettels, are ſo made of. Good authours ſcant, where an humanitian, a ſcholemaſter, and a late writer is alleaged, for a receaued authour. Let me vſe your owne Rhethorick.No ſuch cōſtitutiō of Valens and Theodoſius to beſeene in amy auncient authour as M. Calf. allegeth. Yf Valens and Theodoſius, made ſuche a lawe what an ouerſight was it of Euſebius to ſuppreſſe it? VVhat an eſcape of Sozomenus and other hiſtoriographers, to forgett it? VVhat negligence in the fathers of Nice that could not eſpie it? what euil chaunce that it neuer came into the Code of Iuſtiniā with other Emperours cōſtitutiōs? In good ſooth he had neede to haue as many eies as Argus and then thouſand more, that ſhould finde that conſtitution, VVhiche was neuer made. The conſtitution that you cite out of Peter Crinite, hath no apparance of truth.Valēs and Thedoſius neuer liued to gether. Lib. 1 Ti. 8 Valens and Theodoſius the ſecond neuer raigned together, much leſſe made this conſtitutiō. The conſtitutiō which you meane was made by Theodoſius and Valentinian and is regiſtred in the Code of Iuſtinian in this ſort: Seing we haue a diligēt care to mayntayne the religion of God, in all poynts, we ſpecially cōmaunde that it be laufull for no man to engraue, or paynte the ſigne of our Sauiour Chriſt, either in the grownde or in flint, or in marble ſtones leyed vpon the grownde, but whatſoeuer croſſe is founde (ſo paynted or engraued (we cō maunde it to be taken away, and will hym to be ſeuerely puniſhed that ſhall attempte the contrary to our ordinances. Thus much Theodoſius, and Valentinian. And what hath M. Calf. gayned by this, but an opiniō of folly, that had rather truſt Peter Crinite, a late writer, than ſeeke to the original, and trye out the truth.

Now then ſeing we haue founde the true conſtitution, not
of Valens and Theodoſius, but of Theodoſius and Valētinian, let vs ſee whether it maketh not much for the honour of the croſſe. Firſt they call it: Signū ſaluatoris Chriſti, the ſigne of our ſauiour Chriſt. Yf it be his ſigne, thē is it honorable. For al that is his, is holy,The croſſe the ſigne of our ſauiour. and woorthy of all honour. Agayne yf it be the ſigne of our ſauiour Chriſt, thē is it nor magical inchauntement, nor cōiurers mace, nor helmet of hel, nor conqueſt againſt the Chriſtians, as M. Calf. ſaieth. For as there is no ſocietie betwene Chriſt and Belial, ſo is there no likeneſſe betwene thoſe thinges that appartayne to Chriſt and Belial. Beſides the good Emperours would not haue it trodde vpon. Nor vilanouſly abuſed, and therefore did forbid it to be printed vpon the grownde, and in forbidding that, they tought they ſhould mayntayne the religion of God. But M. Calf. and his cōpanious thīke the throwing of it downe and tredding it vnder their feete, and vilanous abuſing of it, to be a mayntenance of the religion of God, euen as the infidells and iewes thought they ſhould do God very acceptable ſeruice, yf the deſtroyed the faith, and religion of Chriſt. VVherein howe farre they are wide from the pietie and zeale of thoſe good Emperours, euery indifferēt mā may ſee: And note withall, that the ſcalding ſprite of ſcolding eloquēce,M. Calf • . phraſe. Fol. 85. b propre to proteſtants, came fiercely with ſome raging heate vpon M. Calf. when he thought to ſhift away the authoritie of the church by calling it, the Synagoge of Satan. That ſclaunderous terme is often in their writinges, but oftener in their mouthes.Fol. 85. b But tell vs O, ye Euangelicall brotherne that will admitte nothing but ſcripture, that brag vnto the people that you preach nothing, but the worde of the lord, and boldely ſay that you followe the auncient fathers of the primitiue church, tell vs, I ſay,Fol. 143. The commēdation vvhich the fathers geue the church of Rome. where finde you in all ſcripture, that the church of Rome is called the Synagog of Satan? VVhat auncient father doth ſo reporte of it? VVhat doctour of the primitiue church doth ſo terme it? I told you in my concluſion that by Ignatius (who lyued within an hundred and eleuen yeares next after Chriſt) the Churche of of Rome where Peter had his ſeate, was called, a church ſanctified,
and lightened with the will of God, preſident and chiefe in the nation of the Romans: worthie of God for faith, preeminence, bleſſedneſſe, and peace: foūded in the faith and loue of Chriſt: I tolde you out of S. Cypriā, that it is called the principall church, from whēce the prieſtly vnitie is ſprounge: out of Irenaeus, that it is the church to which all Chriſten mē muſt come for the mightier principalitie, and preeminēce. I told you out of S. Amb. that it is the houſe of God: out of Leo, that is a ſcholler of truth, an holy nation a prieſtly and princely citie, made by the holy ſeate of Peter the head of the world. I told you, out of Theodoritꝰ, that is the greateſt church, the moſt nobleſt church, and the church that hath the p̄ſidēceſhipp ouer all natiōs: out of the oration of Martinianus the Emperour and Lawes of Iuſtinian, that it is called, the Apoſtolicall throne, the countrie of lawes, the fountayne of prieſthode, Finde vs your termes that you geue to the church of Rome, in the fathers M. Calf? Fol. 85. b and head of all churches. VVhy beleaue ye not them? Yf ye wilbe children of the auncient fathers, why vary you in principall pointes, frō thoſe thinges that the fathers haue written? VVhy ſay you that euer ſythens, Sylueſters tyme whiche was in the yere of our lord 318. ſuch fylth of idolatrie and ſuperſtitiō hath flowed into the moſte partes of all Chriſtendome out of the ſynke of Rome that he neded as many eies as Argus, that ſhould haue eſpied any ſinceritie vntill the tyme that heretickes, and miſcreants began to reforme the decaid ſtate? Irenaeus calleth it Eccleſiam maximam, antiquiſsimam, omnibus cognitam, à glorioſiſsimis duobus Apoſtolis Petro & Paulo fundatam, Lib. 3. ca. 3. a greate church, a moſt auncient church, a church knowen to all, a church founded of the two glorious Apoſtles S. Peter and S. Paule. S. Cyprian ſaieth: It is the only church to which infidelitie could neuer haue acceſſe. Epiſt. ad Damaſ. And ſithēs Sylueſtres tyme, S. Hierome ſaid. The holy churche of Rome, which hath alwayes remayned vnſpotted, ſhall contynewe alwaies, God prouiding for it, and S. Peter helping, without the inſultation of heretikes, and perſiſt ſtedfaſte and immouable alwaies. Againe in the ſame epiſtle he ſaieth: The euil childe beīg baniſhed from the patrimonie, the authoritie of the fathers remayneth vncorrupt, with you only. Ibi ceſpite terra faecundo dominici ſeminis veritatem centeno fructu refert. There the grownde with her fertile ſoyle, doth bring foorth the truth of our lordes ſeede with an hundred
fold increaſe. S. Ambroſe ſaieth,Epiſt. ad Siricium Papa. Epiſt. 162. that the churche of Rome doth obſerue the faith of the Apoſtles vndefiled and without bleamiſh. S. Auguſtine ſaieth, that in the church of Rome, ſemper Apoſtolica cathedra viguit principatus. The principalitie of the Apoſtolike chaier hath alwayes floriſhed. The ſame father reckoning vp all the Biſhops of Rome from S. Peter vnto Anaſtaſius, Epiſt. 165. who was the ſixt Pope after Silueſter, ſaieth: Of al thoſe, there was: Nullus Donatiſta, neuer a Donatiſt, not one traitour. Nowe yf any of the ſixe, that S. Auguſtine reckoneth after Silueſter, had ſuffred idolatrie, and ſuperſtition, to flowe out of the Synke of Rome into the moſte partes of Chriſtendome (as you ſay) they had ben woorſe than Donatiſtes, worſe than traitours. But by S. Auguſtines iudgment there was no hereſie, nor traiſon in that ſee, much leſſe idolatrie, and ſuperſtition.

S. Bernard, ſaied, In the churche of Rome, fides non poteſt ſentire defectū: Epiſt. 190. ad Innocēt. Papa. faith can feele no defect. And with what face cā you ſay that theſe twelue hundred yeres and more, there was no ſinceritie in the churche of Rome, but idolatrie and ſuperſtition? Yf it be ſo howe was the promiſe of Chriſt made to S. Peter,Matt. 16. Matt. 28. that hell gates ſhoulde not preuaile againſt the church fulfilled? Howe hath Chriſt kept his couenaunt that ſaied. Behold I am with you all daies vntill the end of the world? Howe hath the holyghoſt of who me it was ſaied, Ille ſuggerei vobis omnia, & docebit omnem veritatem, Ioan. 14. Ioan. 16. he ſhall prompt vnto you all thinges, and teache you all truth, diſcardged his office? Howe are S. Paules words verified that ſaied, the churche is, columna & firmamētum veritatis, the piller and foundatiō of truth? 1. Tim. 3. Let vs haue your iudgmēt. For yf the moſte partes of all Chriſtēdome were frō the tyme of Silueſter twelue hūdred yeres in idolatrie and ſuperſtition, without any piece of ſinceritie, hel gates preuailed againſt Chriſtēdome, Chriſt was not faithful in his promiſe, the hoylyghoſt not carefull in his gouernement, S. Paule not wiſe in his woordes.

Yf you ſay, that Chriſt had his church remanyning in ſome countries not withſtanding the moſte partes of all Chriſtendome fell into idolatrie and ſuperſtition, we tell you that this is
playne againſt ſcripture. Chriſtes church is Catholik, and vniuerſall, diſperſed through out the whole world. It remayneth not in corners and coaſtes as hereſies doe. God promiſed Abrahā,Gene. 26. Pſal. 2. that in his ſeede all nations ſhould be bleſſed, he ſaieth to Chriſt aſke of me and I will geue thee nations for thy inheritaunce, and the ends of the world, for thy poſſeſsiō. Yf the the whole world is Chriſts poſſeſsion, and the whole world is his inheritaūce, his church muſt nedes be vniuerſall in the worlde, and not be ſhut vp in this or that corner. The Donatiſtes were in that hereſie, that the church whiche was ones vniuerſall, decayed and reſted with fewe in Afrike,In Pſal. 101. as you be nowe. But S. Auguſtine ſaied, they that ſay ſo, be not in that chuch. He accompteth their voice that ſay ſo, abhominable and deteſtable, full of preſumption and falſitie, bolſtred with no truth, lightned with no wiſdome, tempered with no witte, but vayne, raſh hedlong, and pernicious, as you may and ſee in the fortreſſe of faith, ſet foorth by M. Stapleton of late,Fol. 18. diſcuſſed at large.

Againe if Chriſt had a church in ſome corner al that tyme, you muſt tel vs where it was. The church of Chriſt is viſible, as a citie ſett vpon an hill, Matt. 5. Matt. 18. it can not be hid, men muſt reſorte vnto it. Chriſt willing vs to tell the churche yf occaſion ſo ſerued, meant that his churche ſhould be knowē. VVherefore yf twelue hū dred yeares and more, idolatrie and ſuperſtitiō flowed ſo into the moſt partes of Criſtēdome, Fol. 85. b that he neded as many eies (as Argus that ſhould haue eſpied any piece of ſinceritie, I woulde you and your fellowes would voucheſafe to vſe ſome honeſt conferēce, and vpō an vniforme accorde ſignifie vnto vs in writing,Diuerſe opiniōs amongeſt proteſtāts for the tyme vvhē the churche began to decay. Fol. 85. b Fol. 96. a. why and whē Chriſt loſt his churche, through out the worlde, and ſodenly began to haue it amōgeſt proteſtāts. As yet you are not agreed when Chriſtes Churche began to faile: you ſay here that ſythens Silueſters tyme, idolatrie and ſuperſtitiō flowed into moſte partes of Chriſtendome: In an other place, you ſay that within .cc. yeres after Chriſt many idle ceremonies, crept into the church, ād the ſimplicitie of Chriſts ordināce was refuſed. Luther ſaied the churche decaied after v. hū derd yeres, the M. of the martyrologe after a M. yeres, M. Iuel,
after ſix hūdred. So that as yet there is a great varietie betwene the goſpellers, whē the church begā to fayle. VVherefore ſeing my requeſt is reaſonable,Epiſt 161. ſuche as S. Auguſtine made to the Donatiſtes, let vs lerne of your wiſdomes when the churche fayled, where it hath ben ſythens, and howe it came thither, what Biſshops it had, and by what ſucceſsion it contynued. Tertullian required heretickes to ſhewe the begining of their churches, In preſcr. and declare the order of their biſshops, running ſo downe lineallye by ſucceſsion, that the firſt biſshop had one of the Apoſtles, or Apoſtolike men, Proue your ſucceſsiō M. Calf. ſhevve the begynnīg and continuance of your church. In Pſal 18 The Catholique church alvvayes viſible. Luc. 15. his authour and predeceſſour: as the churche of Smyrna had Polycarpe placed of S. Iohn, and the church of Rome S. Clemēt ordayned by S. Peter. The ſame muſt we require of yow. For Chriſt had euer more a viſible churche in earth. For God, ſaith S. Auguſt. Hath placed his tabernacle in the ſunne, that is his holy churche, he placed his Church is an open place, not in ſecret, not that it ſhould lurke in a corner, not that it ſhoulde be as it were ſecrete, leſt peraduenture, it might be as it were ſecret, as the conuenticles of heretikes are. He hath placed his tabernacle in the ſunne: why doſt thou o hereticke flee into darcknes? Art thou a Chriſten man? Here Chriſt. Art thou his ſeruāte? Here thy lord. Art thou his ſonne? Here thy father. A mēd, reuyue againe, let vs ſay of the, he was dead and is reuyued againe, he was loſt, and is founde agayne▪ Nowe yf you M. Calf. can ſhewe no ſuch church ſet vpon a mountayne, or placed in the ſunne, as I am ſure you can not, thinke this ſpokē to you, and be not aſhamed to lerne of S. Auguſtine, where he ſaieth againſt the Manichees, There be many thinges whiche keepe me iuſtly in the boſome of the catholike church. The conſent of all people and nations do kepe me: Cōt epiſt. Manich. cap. 4. the authoritie begonne with myracles, Nourriſhed with hope, encreaſed with charitie, and eſtabliſhed with antiquitie, doeth kepe me. The Catholique church euer preuayled againſt hereſie. The ſucceſsion of Biſhops from the ſeat of the Apoſtle S. Peter, to whome Chriſt cōmitted the feading of his ſheepe after his reſurrection, vntill this Biſshop that preſently poſſeſſeth the place, doth kepe me. Finallie the name of the Catholike Churche, doth kepe me, whiche hath only ſo preuailed againſt hereſies, that whereas all hereticks would be called Catholiks yet for all that, when a ſtranger aſketh where, or whether, he ſhall go to the Catholik Churche, none dareth ſhewe any Church or houſe. By which yow may ſee that the Churche of Rome, hath euer preuailed againſt hereſies,The ſucceſsion of biſſhops in the church of Rome. aſure bōde to ſtay mē in the Catholik church.
and that the ſucceſsion of Biſſhops in that Seate is a ſure bonde to ſtay men in the Catholik churche, and ſuch, as ſtayed S. Auguſtine him ſelfe at that preſent, who was long after Sylueſters tyme; and a man that knewe the ſcriptures to well, to be deceaued either with idololatrie, or ſuperſtition. VVherfore both you and your fellowe proteſtants muſt either denie, that Chriſt had any church theſe twelue hundred yeres, or recant your vilanous termes, and ſclanderous wordes, in ſaying that the churche of Rome, is the Synagog of Satan and ſynke of idolatrye and ſuperſtition. For as I proued out of the fathers, it is the only churche, that hath condemned all ſuperſtition, and idolatrie. It is the churche that hath euer preuailed agaīſt hereſie and ſhal neuer be ouer thowē, No, not by hell gates, and all the power of the deuill: or els denie your ſelues to be children, of the church and followers of the aūciēt fathers. For either they were deceaued, or ye be lyers. Beſides, that the churche, of Rome is the Catholique church or at the leaſt wiſe, the roote and mother of the Catholik church it apeareth by Cypriā, S. Ambr. S. Hierome,
Libro 4. Epiſt 2. Libro 4. epiſt 8. He that vvil be a Catholique muſt cōmunicate vvith the church of Rome.
In Orat. fu. de obit. fra.
Ad Dama •• . Au • ent. tit 4. and Iuſtinian. By S. Cyprian who ſaieth, to be with Cornelius (who was biſſhop of Rome) was to cōmunicate with the Catholike church: to allowe and firmely hold the cōmunitie of Corneliꝰ, was to hold and firmely kepe, the vnitie and Charitie of the Catholik Churche. S. Ambr. ſaieth, to be one of the Catholique Biſſhops is to agree with the churche of Rome. S. Hierome, telleth, that euery one that gathereth not with the biſshop of Rome ſcattreth. Iuſtiniā ſaieth, the Churche of Rome is mater omnium ſanctarū Eccleſiarū: The mother of all holy churches. VVherefore yf any church is to be followed, this is to be followed, yf any is to be obeyed, this is to be obeyed. Yf the tradition or cuſtome of any churche is to be kept, the tradition and cuſtome of the churche of Rome is to be kept.

Becauſe it neuer admitteh any cuſtome that is contrary either to reaſon, or truth, but condemneth then, that diſpiſe the truth and followe cuſtomes, as the eight diſtinction in the decres, doth playnly declare, and with all concludeth that when truth beareth with cuſtome, Cuſtome. Cap fruſtra diſt. 8 nothing ſhould be more firmely holden than cuſtome. Therfore yf M. Calf. would haue gayned any thing
by diſanulling their cuſtome, he ſhould haue proued firſt, that it is againſt either reaſon, or truth: and then haue alleaged the Canons againſt vs, for preſuming to build vpon cuſtome. But that paſſeth his capacitie:De bapt. cont. Donatiſt lib. 2. cap. 8. his Lōdon learning could not ſtreatch ſo far. S. Auguſtine talking of the cuſtome that the churche had to receaue them by impoſition of handes who had ben baptiſed of heretikes, beleaued that, that cuſtome came of the tradition of the Apoſtles. As many things are not founde in their writinges, neither in the councells of their aftercummers, yet for all that, becauſe they are kept through the vniuerſall churche, they are beleaued to haue bē delyured and cōmanded of none, but of the Apoſtles. Here I beſeek you mark, S. Auguſtins reaſon: he proueth that certayne things not written in ſcripture, nor determyned in councels, were beleaued to haue ben delyured, and cōmended of the Apoſtles,Thinges generally vſed beleaued to come frō the Apoſtles. De corona mil tis. becauſe they were vſed generallie in the Churche, which reaſon Tertullian alſo vſed long before. For ſpeaking of an old obſeruance he ſaieth, yf no ſcripture hath determyned this, certes cuſtome hath ſtrenghtned it, which vndoubtidly proceded out of tradition. For howe can a thing, be vſed, vnleſſe it were left firſt by tradition? So that it is to be vnderſtode, that yf there were neither ſcripture, nor councell, that made, for the vſe, and hauing of the ſigne of the croſſe, yet ſeing it hath bene generallie vſed in all Chriſtendome,Cuſtome. this twelue hundred yeres euer ſythens pope Silueſters ryme, by M. Calfhils owne confeſsion, this generall and auncient cuſtome, were a ſufficiēt argumēt to proue that it was delyured, an cōmended vnto the churche by the Apoſtles, neither againſt reaſon,In cōtradictorio Iud. cio. nor ſcripture. But thanks be to God beſides tradition, we haue Coū cells of the biſſhops and lawes of the Emperours whoſe authoritie is more weightier than can be blowen away with the belowing blaſt, of ſuch a quarrelling Calf.

As for his ſclandring the vertuous ladie Helena with ſuperſtition, I wil talke in the eight Article.Fol. 86. a As for his ſyniſtrous ſurmiſes that the Chriſtian Emperour Conſtantine woulde haue ſome piece of Gētilitie obſerued in building of churches, Fol. 86. b I counte as vayne. His tōgue is no ſlander. As for the reputing
the decrees of Silueſter, Donation of Conſtantine, apparation of Peter and Paule to be tales and impudēt lies, I do not meruel.Fol. 86 b Heretiks will denie the moſte vndoubtedſt truth, that is, yea the playne woordes of ſcripture it ſelf, if it make againſt them. as Luther denied the epiſtle of S. Paule to the Hebrues, S. Iames epiſtle and S. Iudes, and the Apocalipſe of S. Iohn.

As for his comparing Ionas Biſſhop of Orleaunce, a great learned man, that lyued eight hundred yeres ſythens, and more, vnto a netle, Fol. 87. a it is not rare, with proteſtants. No man is lerned, no man worthie of credit, yf he fauour not hereſie. VVherefore gentle readers ſith M. Calfhills coniectures againſt Abdias be but vayne, ſith his diſprouing of the authorities brought out of S, Ambroſe, Lactantius, Paulinus, and S. Auguſtine and generall councells is conuinced, to be but mere quarreling, ſith it is declared, that the catholique churche cā not be ſhutte vp in corners, but muſt be diſperſed, through out the woorld, contrary to his, and all the proteſtants prating, Sith all truth is proued to haue iſſued out of the church of Rome, as the vndoubted foūtayne of all true Chriſtianitie, Sith it is conuinced by vndoubted teſtimonies, that the churche of Rome is teacher of all truth, and enemie to all infidelitie, ſuperſtitition and idolatrie, Sith the cuſtome, to haue the ſigne of the croſſe in churches, chapels, and oratories, came firſt by tradition from the Apoſtles, and afterward was confirmed by generall councells, and lawes of Emperours, to haue ben vſed alwaies where true Chriſtianitie hath had his force, as you loue Chriſt crucified on the croſſe, be not aſhamed to haue the ſigne of his croſſe in your churches, chapels and oratories, and al other places what ſo euer they be deputed to Gods honour and ſeruice.

div.head: THAT THE SIGNE OF THE CROSSE WAS VSED IN ALL SACRAMENTS. etc. THE FOVRTH ARTICLE.
div.p: ALbeit you haue M. Calfhil battred like Solymās blouddy Baſſa, againſt the materiall croſſe of Chriſte, and vſed all violence that you can, to raſe it vp, and ley it flat vpon the grounde, yet may you ſee, that no ſhotte of yours haue pearced, but rebounded backe againe, and put the gunner in daunger. And as that triumphant ſigne of victorie ſtandeth, diſplayed vpō the walles, for all your force: So kepe I both watche and warde and flee not from the walles into any other caſtle, than I tooke my ſelfe vnto before. From thēce you ſhall neuer be able to driue me with all the fier you can make. I haue heard of ſome that carrying fier to miſchiue others, haue ben burned to aſshes them ſelues. VVherfore by my counſell you ſhall do well to take heede, howe you medle to much with fier. A litle ſparkle may kendle to a greate flame. And one in a caſtel is not fiered out but with long ſiedge and ſome perilous attempt. But let vs marke what flames of fier you make.

You acknowledge,Fol 87. Fol 88. • Calf. that the Chriſtians vſed croſsing to teſtifie their faith in deſpite of their maſters enemyes: And that vpon zeale and deuotion, the fathers admitted the ſigne of the croſſe into Gods ſeruice, as a laudable ceremonie, and whiſhed all men to vſe it. But you ſeeing ſome ſuperſtitions men to
abuſe it, and of a ceremonie make a neceſsitie, and noting that the people bend not their hartes, The Chriſtiās ſclā dered. to the conſideration of the heauenly myſterie, but defixe their eies, and repoſe their affiance in the earthly ſigne, were forced to refuſe it.

Mart.Here to omitte your falſe ſclandring the fathers for ſuperſtition and abuſe of the ſigne of the croſſe, and vniuſt cōdemning Chriſten people of forſaking God, and putting their affiance in a ſigne, becauſe you ſay you were forced to refuſe the ſigne, Let me aſke you firſt, who forced you to refuſe it, but your owne wilfulnes? Secondarely what are you? From what coaſtes come youe? VVho made your miniſtres in Chriſtes churche? VVho called you when youe ſtode idle in the market, Matt. 20. and ſent you into Gods vynearde? VVhat laufull biſshop gaue you auctoritie to preach and miniſtre the ſacraments? Let vs haue your euidēce and ſee, or els we will ſay vnto you with Tertulliā,De praeſct. putting in certayne names of our newe heretickes,Tertulliās queſtion applied to our miniſters. Anſvver ſires. for his old, what doe ye in my grownde, being no woorke men of myne? By what right doe ye cutt downe my wooddes M. Horne? By what authoritie doe you tranſuert and turne away my fountaynes M. Iuel? By what commiſsiō doe ye remoue my boundes M. Grindal? And all ye other miniſters why ſowe ye and feede ye here, at your pleaſure? It is my poſſeſsion, I haue poſſeſſed it long, I poſſeſſed it before you. I haue ſure euidence and originals euen from the lordes whoſe inheritance it was. I am the heyre of the Apoſtles. As they ordayned in their teſtament, as they cōmitted it to my chardge, as they adiured me, ſo I keepe it. As for you, they haue diſherited you alwayes as foreners and enemies. Yf you can not ſhewe your vocation to be laufull, according to Chriſtes inſtitution, and ordinance of his churche, then will it followe that you are no true miniſtres, and diſpenſers of his myſteries, nor prelates, that haue charge to rule Gods people, and therfore haue no authoritie to do what ye pleaſe, and refuſe what ye liſt. For he that can not make a lawe, can not refuſe a lawe that is made. The vſe of the ſigne of the croſſe then, being a tradition deryued from the Apoſtels, and generallie receaued in Chriſtes catholicke churche, and thinges receaued by tradition hauing as S. Hierome ſaieth: authoritatē ſcriptaelegis, Authoritie
of a written lawe,Aduerſus Luciferia. you cā not iuſtlie violate and breake this lawe, vnleſſe yow will ſet your ſelues wilfully againſt Chriſte, and the holy Ghoſt. For as S. Cyprian ſayeth:Serm. de Ablut. p •
dum. That is no leſſe ratified which the Apoſtles deliuered by the inſpiration of the holy Ghoſte, than that whiche Chriſte him ſelf delyuered.

The authoritie whiche you bring out of S. Auguſtine and S. Gregorye to proue that thinges ones receaued,Fol 88. a may for circumſtances of perſons, tyme or place, or other cōſiderations be chā ged, I admitte with all my heart:The proteſtāts haue no authoritie to make any eccleſiaſtical. lavves. and confeſſe that thinges ones receaued, may for circumſtances be changed, in ſuch ſort, and ſuch thinges as they meane. But by whome muſt they be altred and chaunged M. Calf.? of euery priuate man? No: but of thoſe that haue authoritie to make a lawe: and that authoritie lacke you and your cōgregatiō, who hauing no biſhops, cā make no Eccleſiaſticall lawes, nor abrogate the olde? yf you will preſſe vs with your Synodes, we will proue vnto you, that yf you had as may apoſtaticall biſhops, as you haue miniſtres and prieſts, it woulde avayle no more then a gooſe feather in the Tems, Seing the eccleſiaſticall rule commaundeth that no councels ſhould be kept contrary, or beſides the mynde of the biſshop of Rome, and Iulius the firſt writing for Athanaſius to the biſshops of the eaſt ſaieth vnto them, your rule nor hath, nor can haue, any force, Lib. 4. ca. 9. Tripart. No councell to be kept vvithout the cōſent of the Biſſhop of Rome. becauſe that councell was not kept of Catholik Biſshops, nor had a legat frō the churche of Rome, wheras the canons commaunde that councells ought not to be kept without his authoritie. VVherfore you condemne your ſelf and all your ſect of much arogancie, who being but priuate men, not called to the offices whiche you preſumptiouſly vſurpe, by any laufull meanes, nor hyred of any true gardiner, that hath the cuſtodie of Chriſtes vynearde, do take vpon you to refuſe the lawes that your forefathers made and Chriſten people haue hitherto obſerued.

VVhere you talke of compulſion and ſay,Fol. 88. •
that you were forced to refuſe that laudable ceremonye, It is well knowen that there was neuer violence vſed againſt any proteſtant to make him renie the Catholicke faith, or ſigne of the croſſe, and that you were not otherwiſe forced, than voluntate, by your owne
wilfulnes. But yf great violence had bene vſed to force youe vnto it, you ſhoulde rather haue ſuffred, all torments then haue broken the vnitie of the church, knowing, that it is more gloriouſe to ſuffre martirdome, Dionyſ. Alex. epi. ad Nouat. Euſeb. lib. 6. cap. 34. Cap. 27. de Spir. ſan. The reiecting of traditions a deſtroynig of Religion. that the church be not deuided, than that idols ſhould not with ſacrifice be honored. S. Baſile talking of Eccleſiaſticall inſtitutions written, and of certayne traditions and cuſtomes that are vſed amongeſt Chriſten men, and not written, numbred the ſigne of the croſſe for one, and ſaieth that there is like affection of pietie dewe vnto bothe, and ſuppoſeth that yf we caſt away ſuche cuſtoms, religion ſhall haue great detriment and loſſe, and the preaching of faith be brought to a naked name. VVhich being vndoubtedly true, euery man, that is deſirous to haue the Ghoſpell of Chriſte reuerenced, true religion maintained, and faith ſincerely preached, ſhould defend ſuch traditions and cuſtoms as the Apoſtles, and auncient fathers, did recommend vnto the churche, for maintenance of Chriſtes religion, and not be forced by a litle wilfulnes to refuſe them at their pleaſure, as M. Calfhil ſay they are.

Traditiōs muſt be obſerued. 2. Cap. 2.S. Paule commaunded the Theſſalonians to ſtand, and kepe the traditions whiche they had lerned either by his epiſtle or by his ſermōs and talke. And in them warneth vs to do the like. VVherbie we may perceaue that he woulde haue vs to be conſtant in obſeruing of traditions, and whatſoeuer pretence or colour Satan tranſfiguring him ſelf into the angel of light vſeth, to plucke vs from them, vnder the ſhadowe of ſuperſtition and other groſſe abuſes, we muſt not flee frō that which we receaued. For he crieth: State, tenete: Stand ſtoute, kepe faſt, let no violence force you, to refuſe that which is delyured vnto you. VVherfore I exhorte you M. Calfhil, to refuſe your fooliſh fanſie, and kepe traditiōs and cuſtomes, according to the counſell of S. Paule. And yf wilfulnes here to fore forced you to refuſe them, lett reaſon induce you nowe to imbrace them,Policarpe Epiſt. ad Epheſios. Origen. In expoſi. 1. ad Titū. Homi. 29. In Matt. that as that bleſſed martyr Polycarpe ſaied: VVe forſaking the vanities of many, and falſe doctrines, may returne to that word whiche was delyured vs from the beginning. Origē accompted him an hereticke that profeſſeth to beleaue Chriſte and beleaueth otherwiſe of the truth of the Chriſtian faith, than the tradition of the church hath defyned: and counſelled vs not go away: From the
firſte Eccleſiasticall tradition, nor beleaue otherwiſe then the churche of God, by ſucceſsion hath deliuered vnto vs. VVhiche counſell yf you could followe, you would not be ſuch a ſworne enemy to traditions, nor eſteme the eccleſiaſticall hiſtories, written by ſuch authours as all the worlde regarde and reuerēce, to be but tales: but to maintaine hereſie, traditions muſt be reiected as trifles, viſions as illuſions, fathers as fablers, hiſtories, as lies. VVhiche is lamentable, that ſo foule a bird ſhould vnplume ſo many, to feather her fylthy neaſte.

Yf the hiſtorie of Probianus be but a tale, M. Calf. and Sozomenus authour of it, no better thā a thefe, as you make hī, why hath it paſſed the iudgmēt, of ſo many, vnder the name of an eccleſiaſtical hiſtorie, which is a teſtimonie of things done in the church, & witnes of the truth?Sozomenus likened to a thefe. Fol. 89 a Caſsiodorꝰ the Senator in the p̄face before the Tripartite hiſtorie, ſaieth: that the eccleſiaſticall hiſtorie, written, mirabiliter as it were by miracle) by the three greke authours, Theodoretus, Sozomenus and Socrates, is ꝓued and tried to be very neceſſarie for all Chriſtians: and therfore, he biddeth euery mā read them boldly. For whoſoeuer ſo doth, ſhall haue great knowleg and cōmoditie by it. Theodoret he reckoneth for a reuerend biſhop, Sozomenus and Socrates for moſte eloquent, wiſe, and no doubte graue and lerned mē. VVherefore either he muſt reporte an vntruth, or you make a lye M. Calf. For yf the hiſtorie written as it were by miracle, be very neceſſarie, for all Chriſtians, then certaine it is that it cō ſiſted not of idle fables, and fabulous tales. For to what purpoſe ſhould tales be very neceſſary for all Chriſtiās. Yf it conſiſted not of tales, then can you with no more right condemne this ſtory of Probianus, for a tale, thā any other thing that the ſaied authour writeth. Yf Sozomenus be a light of the church and a moſte eloquent man, then haue you ſclaunderouſly, let your tō gue ſlippe, in reſembling him to a theefe, Calf. Fol 89 a that leaping ouer a pale leaueth a piece of his cloke behind him, and ſo paſſeth that we maye tracke him by the fote. Mart. But let vs conſider what a fyne bloude hownde ye are to tracke a theef by the fote. Sozomenus ſaieth, that the diuine power apeared to Probianus, becauſe he woulde
not worſhip the croſſe, Lib. 2. ca. 19. Trip. and ſhewed him the ſigne of the croſſe, whiche was vpon the aulter of the churhe, where he was, and made it playnly apere, that euer ſythens Chriſte was crucified, all thinges whiche were done for the commodity of man, were done by no meanes without the vertue of the holy croſſe; Fol 89 b Calf. nor of holy angells nor of good men. You ſay, either the collectour of this was a lyer, or I an euill applier. For quoth yowe, Angels can not make any material croſſe, ſuch as is ſet vp in Churches, nor myſticall, ſuch as men vſe to printe in their foreheades. For they haue no bodies to beare it, nor handes to make it. Mart. Gene. 32. VVorſhipfully ſir: Yf your ſenſes ſerue you no better, your noſe will ſoner be hyred to be ſome poore mans ſowe, than required to ſerue ſome gētle mans foſter for a bloud hownde to tracke a theefe Did not the angell wreſſell with Iacob, and breeke a ſynowe in his thighe? Did not the angells that came to Sodoma lodge with Loth, and eate and drinke in his houſe?Gene. 19. Did not the angell Raphael, that went with Tobias to Rages a citie of Medes, walke, eate, ſpeake, and receaue mony for Tobye? Looke the fifth, ſixth, ſeuenth, eight and ninth chapiter of Tobias: Did not the Angel take vp Abacuc by the heare, and carie him frō Iurie to Babilō? Looke to the fourthtene of Daniel. Did not the angel Gabriel when he was ſent to our Ladie in to Galilee in Nazareth, goe into her? Did he not ſalute her, with that ſwete ſalutatiō, Aue Maria, that the church vſeth in remēbrance of Chriſtes incarnation and honour of the bleſſed virgin? Did he not, talke with her, and whē his meſſage was done departed he not againe? Looke the firſt of S. Luke. Did not the angel come downe from heauen and rolle away the ſtone of Chriſtes ſepulchre and ſitte vpon him, and ſpeake to Mary Magdalene and the other Maries and willed thē not to feare? Looke to the 28. of Mathewe, and to be ſhort looke through out all the ſcripture, and you ſhall finde that where it pleaſeth God to do any thing for the commoditie of mā, by the miniſterie of his bleſſed angels, he ſuffred them to take the ſhape of our bodies, handes legges, tongue, and all, and to do ſuch corporall functiōs as apertayneth to any part or membre of the bodie. VVher for vnleſſe
ſome euill angel bewitched the ſenſes of your bodie and powers of your ſoule, I can not ſee what ſhoulde force you to diſgrace the truth of this ſtorie, becauſe angels haue no bodies, to beare the croſſe, nor handes to make it? Of ten hundred ſhiftes, this was the worſt: euery one that knoweth God to be omnipotent, can eaſely cōceaue, howe the angles may haue bodies and hands to worke the will and pleaſure of our lorde in earth, or to make a croſſe without hand or bodie.

Nowe ſir for my diſcharge that I am no fond applier (as it pleaſeth your worſhip to terme me) let the īdifferēt reader that vnderſtādeth the ſtorie, ād is able to weigh the circūſtāces of it, iudge. Probianus of a Pagā was made a Chriſtian, that is to ſay he beleaued in Chriſte, and hoped to be ſaued by his death vpō the croſſe,Lib. 2. cap. 19. Tripar. but he would not worſhip the cauſe of all our ſaluation (that is to ſay) the moſte holy croſſe: VVhat is this croſſe, which he would not worſhip? The paſsiō of Chriſte, as you ſaie? No: For he was a Chriſtiā, and being a Chriſtian, he did honour, reuerēce, adore, and loue the paſsion of Chriſte, and had the hope of his ſaluatiō repoſed in it. And whoſoeuer doth otherwiſe can not be a Chriſtian. VVherfore, the croſſe that he would not worſhip muſt be an other thing, than the paſsiō it ſelf. And what can it be but the very ſigne of the croſſe which all younge cōuerſes, were wonte to haue delyured vnto them, when they began to be Chriſtiās, and God ſhewed him by his diuine power in an holy viſion from heauen, ſtanding in the church, vpon the aulter, A croſſe ſtanding vpon the aulter is not the paſsion M. Calf. a place of great honour and reuerence, for the dredfull myſteries that there be offred. Nor haue you any aduantage, againſt me, becauſe S. Cyprian. S. Auguſtine and Chryſoſtome treating of the paſsion do vſe the terme Croſſe, when they meane the crucified. The ſame fathers very oftentymes in their woorkes vſe the ſame terme croſſe, when they meane the ſigne of the croſſe, as the lerned knowe right well, and you are driuen to confeſſe the like in this Article of Tertullian, Prudentius, and S. Hierome.Fol. 88. b

But notwithſtanding all the fathers: vſed the ſigne of the croſſe in miniſtration of Sacraments, Fol. 89. b and ſomtyme otherwiſe,
as M. Calfhil graunteth, yet it contenteth him not, but with a vehement ſpirite, and hote interrogatiō he maketh theſe demaundes.Fol. 89. b Fol. 90. a Calf. Shall we be reſtrained to that whereof ther is no precept in ſcripture, nor they thē ſelues yelde lawfull cauſe? Thinke you that they did attribute, ſo great vertue to the wagging of a finger, that the holy Ghoſte coulde be called downe, and the deuil driuen away by it? Thinke you that they woulde haue neglected, churches, refuſed ſacramentes, doubted of their health, yf the prieſt had not broken the ayer firſt, and with his holy hand, made an owerthwart ſigne?

To anſwer mildly becauſe his patience is ſome what brokē,Mart. and charitie chafed, I tell you (ſir) that yf you wilbe a Chriſtē mā, ād ſo reputed you muſt be reſtrayned, to what whereof there is no precept in expreſſe written ſcripture. As for example. There is no precepte in expreſſe written ſcripture that commaundeth you to beleaue that in the bleſſed Trinitie there be thre perſons and one God.VVe muſt be reſtrayned to that vvhereof there is no cō maundement in expreſſe ſcripture. Yet you muſt be reſtrained vnto it. There is no precept in expreſſe writtē ſcripture that the ſonne of God, is of equall fubſtāce with his father, that the bleſſed virgin Mary was the mother of God, that ſhe continued alwayes in virginitie, without the carnall companie of man, that the Saboth day refuſed, the ſounday ſhould be kept holie, that the ſacrament fhould be receaued faſting, that infants ſhould be baptiſed, that biſshops ſhould not practiſe iuriſdictiō in other mens Dioceſe; that the baptiſme of heretikes ſhould be auayleable. That there is a diſtinction of the bookes of ſcripture, ſome to be canonical, ſome Hagiographal, ſome Apocriphal. For thoſe and many more you haue no precept in expreſſe ſcripture writtē in the compaſſe of the Bible, yet you muſt be reſtrayned vnto them, maugre your beard, as nowe you are to ſquare capps, and prieſtes gowndes although there be no precept of them in ſcripture.

Touching your ſecond demaunde, it is moſte euident that as ſone as praier is duly made, and the name of God called vpon, and ſigne of the croſſe drawen wit the hand, the holie Ghoſte according to the promiſe of Chriſte cūmeth downe, and ſanctifieth
the giftes offred, and thinges brought to be conſecrated, vhatſoeuer Sacrament, or Sacramentall it is, and that the deuill is driuen away. As for the thirde, I verely beleaue that none of the olde fathers at that tyme did neglect the churches, refuſe the ſacraments, doubt of their health, yf the prieſt did omitt the ſigne of the croſſe in any ſacramēt or ceremonie: and the ſame opinion haue all true chriſtiās and catholickes in our age.Fol. 52. a My ſelfe tolde you in this article of my treatiſe, that the croſſe was vſed in celebration of Chriſtes ſacraments for two cauſes. The firſt is to put vs in remembraunce of our redemption by the croſſe. The ſecond to declare that all ſacramēts haue their vertue and effect of the merites of his paſsion? and ſaied furder, that albeit the auncient fathers taught,Yf the ſigne of the croſſe be omitted the ſacramēts lack not their vertue. and catholike churche commaunded, that the ſigne of the croſſe ſhould be vſed in all ſacraments, yet it is not their meaning, that any ſacrament lacketh his operation, effect, and vertue, yf or for neceſsitie, or by ouerſight, or by ignorance, the ſaied ſigne be omitted: But when of ſelf will and purpoſe the order of the churche is contemptuouſly broken, and the intention of the miniſtre euil, and faith worſe, as theirs is, who be Zuinglians, Caluiniſtes and ſuch like, there is no doubt, but that they offende the goodnes of God, and in omitting the ſigne of the croſſe, tranſgreſſe the ordinaunce of the holy Ghoſt, and tradition of the Apoſtles and auncient fathers. This ſir to take away matter of cauillation, I told you: there might you haue ſene it, yf you woulde haue taken paines to haue ſought it, and becauſe you might and would not, learne more good ye pieuiſh puine Iulianiſte, than ſo fondly to thinke,M. Calf. vnderſtandeth that vvhich he taketh i • hand to reproue. and falſly reporte, of another. Learne to vnderſtād the authour which you take in hand to reproue, before you ſett foorth your reprouf, leſt whiles you improue that which is not to be reproued, you proue your ſelf as wiſe as VVilliā VVittleſſe of VValtam. But becauſe you require me to examine the woordes of my authour, for my parte ſeing I am in your iudgement, but a puine, a younge ſcholler, Fol 90. •
one that hath not learned his leaſſon well, I will ioine a third perſon to be an vmpier in this cauſe betwene you and me, and becauſe you ſhall not ſuſpect him
as partiall, or refuſe him as to fauorable to papiſtrie, let it be one that careth as litle for papiſtrie, as for honeſtie: D. Cox or M. Grindal, yf you will: One, I paſſe not whiche. M. Grindal becauſe he is your Dioceſan, yf you pleaſe. VVel go to then. Martial.Serm. de paſsio. S. Cyprian ſaieth: VVhatſoeuer the handes bee which dip thoſe that come to baptiſme, whatſoeuer the breaſt is, out of which the holy wordes do procede, the authoritie of operation geueth effect to all ſacraments, in the ſigne of the croſſe. Here S. Cyprian teacheth that men haue authoritie by commiſsion from God, to make, and miniſter his ſacraments, and that in the figure, and ſigne of the croſſe,Fol. 90. a all ſacraments haue their effect. Calfhil: Yea ſirra, ſay you ſo? ſhewe the commandement, for the ſigne of the croſſe, yf ye will haue Cyprian to meane of it. Mart: I proued euen nowe, that yf you will be a Chriſten man, and wilbe reputed for one, you muſt be reſtrayned that whereof there is no precept in ſcripture written in the volume of the Bible. Yf you will haue it proued out of ſcripture writtē by the holy Ghoſt in the heartes of men, and not in leafes, of paper, and ſheepes ſkinne, looke in Tertullian and S. B •• ile, and other auncient fathers, that ſay it was a tradition and practiſe of the catholicke Churche.

Calf. VVhat talke you to me of traditiōs, cuſtomes and ſcriptures, writtē in mens heartes? yf it be not in Gods booke, away with it. Grindal. Grindal. O pacifie your ſelfe ſir Iames, for the lordes ſake. It muſt not be ſo. The Apoſtle S. Paule and his ſcholler Timothe exhorted men to kepe thoſe thinges, Act. 16. that were decreed of the Apoſtles, and elders that were in Hieruſalem. The ſaied Apoſtle willed the Theſſalonians to ſtand ſtoutely and kepe the traditions,
• Theſſ. 2. which they lerned either by his epiſtle or by worde of mouth: and in very deede yf we reiect traditions and cuſtomes,Cap. 27 de Spir. ſan. we ſhall bring (as S. Baſile ſaieth) the preaching of faith to a naked name, and neuer be able to mayntayne our owne religion. For we haue many thinges by cuſtome and tradition, of whiche we can ſhewe no precept. Calfhill. Calf. VVhie yf it pleaſe your ſuperintēdentſhip what ſhal we do? Yf we admitte the traditions of the Apoſtles, and auncient fathers, Grind. our religion will neuer be mayntained. Grindal.
Yf we condemne them, all the worlde will crye out vppon vs.Athanaſ. epiſt ad Afros de Ariminē ſi concil. For who will not hate them (ſaieth Athanaſius) that refuſe the conſtitutions, of the fathers, and prefer thoſe thinges that were made of l • te contentiouſly, and with great violence at Ariminum? Very fewe or none. Therfore ſober your ſelfe, ſir Iames: and go wiſely to woorke. Euery thing hath a tyme: Marre not al vpon a litle headynes and haſtie courrage. It can not be denied, but that men haue authoritie of operation from God (that is to ſay) commiſsion and authoritie, as miniſters, to worke and make his ſacraments.Men haue authoritie of operation. Matt. 28. Ioan. 20. The wordes of Chriſt are plaine: As my father ſent me: So do I ſend you: Therfore going foorth, teache all nations, baptiſing them, in the name of the father, and of the ſonne and of the holy Ghoſt: Receaue ye the holy Ghoſt, whoſe ſynnes ye remitt, are remitted them, do this in my remēbrance. Here you ſee commiſsion, and authoritie is geuen to baptiſe, to releeſe ſynne, to celebrate the ſupper of the lorde, and if according to this commiſsion one be baptiſed in water, in the name of the father, and of the ſonne, and of the holy Ghoſt, this Sacrament hath his effect. And yf he be not ſo baptiſed, by ordinarie courſe it hath no effect.

VVherfore it is not be denied, but that the authoritie of operation, that is to ſay, a man hauing authoritie to worke and make his ſacraments as gods miniſters, geueth after a fort effect to the ſacrament. For before the man doth his dutie commaunded by God, in that behalf, there is nothing done, when he hath ſpoken the wordes of Chriſte, Ego te baptiſo, I baptiſe thee and ſo foorth, then is the ſoule waſhed from his filth, then is remiſsion of ſynne, geuen, and then hath the ſacrament his full effect, and not before. Calf. Nay if pleaſe your ſuperintendentſhippe.De baptiſ. Chriſti. Fol. 90. b Remiſsiō of ſynnes geuen by Sacramēts. More Sacraments thā tvvo. Cyprian ſaieth, Chriſte came to baptiſme, not wanting a waſhing in whom there was no ſinne, but to the end that a continuall authoritie might be geuen to the Sacrament, and not accepting of perſons commend ſo great a woorke. For remiſſion of ſinnes, be it ether geuen by baptiſme, or by other ſacraments, properly appertayneth to holy ghoſt, and the priuiledg of this effect remayneth vnto him alone. As for the ſolemnitie
of wordes, and calling vpon the name of God, and ſignes attributed to the apoſtolicall inſtitutions through the miniſterie of the prieſts, they mak a viſible ſacrament, but the thing it ſelf, the holighoſte doth frame, and make, and to the viſible conſecrations, the authour of all goodnes, doth viſiblie put his hand. Here you ſee that the effect is geuen to the holieghoſt, and only to the holighoſte, whiche yow attribute either to the prieſt or to the ſigne of the croſſe. Grind. You talke as though you did not vnderſtand the ſcripture. No Chriſten mā doubteth, but that the holyghoſt is authour of all grace, and geueth effect to all ſacraments: but the holyghoſt hath put all thinges vnder a lawe, he worketh euery thing by a meane. And in ſcripture, the effect that is wrought by God, is attributed, in a ſorte to the mā that worketh,Thinges done by God, attributed to men. Acto. 28. although the holyghoſt be the principal and chief worker of all. For example when Publius father was cured, of his agewe and bluddye flix, the ſcripture ſaieth that, S. Paule ſanauit eum, healed him. Here the effect of healing; propre to God only is attributed to S. Paule, becauſe S. Paule was the meane by which God voucheſafed to confer health vppon him. In the ſecond chapiter of the Actes it is ſaied, many wounders and ſignes were done by the Apoſtles in Hieruſalem: Exod. 10. becauſe God did it, by them, as inſtruments, and meanes. In like manner becauſe the Biſhops and prieſtes being diſpenſers of Chriſtes myſteries, do either dippe the childe in the font, that muſt be baptiſed, or poure water vppon him, and celebrate the Supper of the lorde, and pronounce theſe holy wordes, and conſecrate according to the inſtitution of Chriſte, wherby remiſsion of ſinnes and life euerlaſting is geuen, this effect which God only geueth, is according to ſcripture, ſaied to be geuen by the biſshops and prieſts, in theſe ſacraments, as meanes, and theſe men as miniſtres, to giue remiſsion of ſinne and life euerlaſting by. So you may ſee that, S. Cyprian,The meaning of S. Cypriās place. ſaying that the holy ghoſte geueth effect to all ſacraments, meaneth that the holyghoſt is authour of all grace and geueth effecte to all ſacraments, immediatly by his abſolute power, and mediatly by the miniſtery of mā, whoſe ſeruice it hath pleaſed
his diuine maieſtie to vſe, as meanes to woorke, theſe effects to his people. Calf. what my lorde, S. Cyprian ſaieth remiſsion of ſinnes, Grind. Matt. 10. properly appertaineth to the holyghoſt and is dewe to hym only: So Chriſte ſaieth, It is not you that ſpeake, but the ſpirite of your father that ſpeaketh in you. Did not the Apoſtles, therfore ſpeake? I perceaue you vnderſtand not what you ſay, nor your owne authour neither. I tolde you that remiſsion of ſinnes appertayneth properly and only to the holyghoſt, immediate, immediatly. For he is the fountayne from whiche all grace floweth, he the authour from whom all vertue is deryued. But as euery fountayne diſperſeth his water by diuerſe waies to the vſe of man: So doth the holyghoſte diſperſe his grace by diuerſe meanes. And becauſe he doth it by externall meanes in ſacraments, thoſe externall meanes are ſaied to geue effect vnto his ſacraments.

That remiſsion of ſinnes is geuen by baptiſme, and other ſacraments, as externall meanes, S. Cypriā teſtifieth plainly, in the woordes that you alleaged. For he ſaieth: Remiſsion of ſinnes, De baptiſ. Chriſt. whether it be geuen by baptiſme or other Sacraments, proprely appartayneth to the holy Ghoſte. Here you may ſee that he acknowledgeth remiſsion of ſynnes, to be geuen by baptiſme, and other ſacramēts,Remiſsiō of ſynne is geuen by other ſacramēts beſides baptiſme. There is a viſible cō ſecration. Officialibus. There is a ſanctifica done of dutie. Calf. yet properly by the holy Ghoſt, and by them, as meanes. Beſides he talketh there of viſible cōſecrations and of ſanctifications done of dutie, and ſaieth that the authour of all goodnes doth put his hand inuiſiblye to thoſe viſible conſecrations, and the holy Ghoſte infuſe the fulnes of grace to thoſe ſanctifications, and perfet the thing of the Sacrament. VVherby you may vnderſtand, that there is a viſible miniſtery, and externall operation, by which the holy Ghoſt geueth the fulnes of his grace. Take away one, the other ceaſeth: vſe the viſible conſecratiō, and the inuiſible grace is graunted, through the omnipotencie of his worde that ordaineth it.

Calf. VVell may I graunte as your ſuperintendentſhippe haue proued, that after a ſorte the auctoritie of operation, geueth effect, to all Sacraments: but I can not be perſuaded, that S. Cyprian ſpeaketh here of a croſſe, as Martial fanſieth.
Martial:Mnrt. No ſir? you are very hard laſed and loth to beleaue. May it pleaſe you before you ſuperintēdent here, to cōſider the place of S. Cypriā: and for better vnderſtāding of it, call to remē brāce, a fewe wordes that wēt before? Talkīg there of the bloud of Chriſt, he ſaieth: It is of ſuch authoritie and power, that it doth not only fence the dore poſtes of Iſraell, The vertue of the croſſe. but euen the very, and only ſigne of that ſacrament, doth dryue away deuils, and the vertue of the hoy name, and marke of the bloud, is terrible to all wicked ſpirites, whereſoeuer it is ſeene. In brief, whatſoeuer the miniſtres of the ſacraments be, whatſoeuer the handes are that dip thoſe that come to baptiſme, whatſoeuer the breaſt is, out of which the holy wordes procede, the auctoritie of operation, geueth effect to all ſacraments in the figure of the croſſe, and the name whiche is aboue all names, being called vpon by the diſpenſers of the ſacraments doth all. Here I pray youe (ſir) what is the ſigne of the ſacrament that driueth away diuells? VVhat is the marke of the bloud that is terrible to wicked ſpirites?Calf. Calf. Marry the paſsion it ſelfe. Mart: VVe knowe that the paſsion of Chriſte is terrible to the deuill,Mart. Calf. and all wicked ſpirites, but is that S. Cyprians meaning only? Calf. VVhat ſhould he meane els? Mart. I will tell you: He ſpeaketh there of the paſsion of Chriſte,Mart. and to proue that it is of great vertue and power, able to dryue away diuels, he vſeth theſe reaſons. The ſigne of the ſacrament (that is the ſigne of the paſsion, for ſo is Sacramentum taken ſome tymes in S. Paule) driueth away deuils. Againe the vertue of his name and marke of his bloud is terrible to wicked ſprites, ergo much more the bloud it ſelfe.

Here the grater is proued, by the leſſe, the paſsion by the ſigne. As then the thing that is proued, muſt be diuerſe from that, by which it is proued: ſo in this place the ſigne of the Sacramēt, (that is the ſigne of the paſsion) and marke of the bloud muſt be diuerſe from that which was proued: otherwiſe S. Cypriā ſaied nothing, but proued one thing by it ſelf, which is abſurde. For a more familier exāple, yf one would ſay, my lorde Mayours mace borne in the ſtrete maketh malefactours afraied, ergo much more my lordes owne perſon, would you not think M. Calfhil that my lorde mayor were one thing and his mace an other?
Calf. yeas I would. Mart. ſo may you in this caſe. For it is al one. Calf. Nay, yet had I rather be croſſebitten than confeſſe that. Martial.Diogenes vvordes to the boy that caſt ſtones at the galloes. on a tyme Diogenes ſeing a beardleſſe bachiler caſting ſtones at a galloe tree, ſaied vnto him, Goe to ſirrha, In good faith, one day you will hitte the marke: So in good ſoothe to you ſir, that had rather caſt ſtones at the croſſe, and be croſſe bitten than confeſſe the truth, we may ſay, Take hede, ſir, one day yow will hitte marke.

The thirde reaſon that S. Cyprian maketh, for proufe of this (as you may ſee by the cōtinuing of his talke, by the aduerbe of ordre, and particle, Illatiue, denique, which ſignifieth that ſomthing followeth, appertayning to that whiche went before) is this,Authoritie of operation in the ſigne of the croſſe geueth effect to al Sacramēts The authoritie of operation in the ſigne of the croſſe geueth effect to all ſacraments, ergo much more the paſsion of Chriſte it ſelf. Here the vertue of the paſsion, is proued to be great by the figure of the croſſe. For be the diſpenſers of Chriſts Sacraments neuer ſo wicked, yet yf they call vpō the name of God, and make the ſigne of the croſſe, and woorke according to the authoritie of operation that is geuen them, and do as their commiſsiō chardgeth them, the ſacraments haue their full effect. Calf. VVhy ſir, Fol 90. b Fol. 91. a referre you the authoritie of operation to the prieſt, that maketh the croſſe with his thombe. Haue ye forgot that you learned out of S. Ambroſe, Aliud est elementum, aliud eſt conſecratio, aliud opus, aliud operatio. The elemēt is one thing and conſecration an other, the woork is one thing, and operation an other, The woorke is done by the prieſt, the operation by God. So S. Ambroſe ſaieth alſo, that the conſecration is. Non ſanat aqua niſi ſpiritus deſcenderit et aquam illam conſecrauerit. The water healeth not vnleſſe the holy Ghoſte come downe and cōſecrate the water. Fol 90. b. Fol. 91. a Mart. I am glad that at lenght I knowe who it is that made the propre dialogue in your booke betwene. C. and M. Before I ſtoode in doubt of it: becauſe. C. you knowe, ſtandeth for Calf. Cuckold, or Cuckow, as wel as for Calfhill, and M. for Martī, Mathewe or Mortimer, aſwel as
for Martiall: and I perſuaded my ſelf that M. Calf. would propounde no ſuch queſtions as C. did, and was ſure that Martial, would frame no ſuch anſwers as your naked M. imagyneth. But ſeing tyme trieth truth, and falſhode ſheweth it ſelfe, I wil deale with you accordingly. Nowe to your queſtiō. I haue not forgotten ſir that which I lerned out of S. Ambroſe. I remember it right well. He hath thoſe wordes: but not in that ſenſe whiche you take them, and that you may the better vnderſtand it, and the readers ſee howe you haue peruerted it, let vs conſider the place, and gather. S. Ambroſe meaning of his woords that goe before,S. Ambro. peruerted and come after.

Before, he ſpooke of Naaman the Syrian that was cured of his lepre by waſhing in the water of Iordane:De ſacra. lib. 1. ca 5. and aſking the queſtion what that ſhould ſignifie, he ſaied: vidiſti aquam. Sed nō aqua omnis ſanat, ſed aqua ſanat quae habet gratiam Chriſti. Aliud eſt elementum, aliud conſecratio, aliud opus, aliud operatio. Thou haſt ſeene the water, but all water doth not heale, but that water healeth, whiche hath the grace of Chriſt. The element, is one thing, the conſecration an other: the woorke one thing, the operatiō an other. Afterwarde declaring howe Chriſte came to S. Iohn to be baptiſed, and ſhewīg a cauſe why Chriſt went downe into the water, and then the holy Ghoſt came, he telleth that the forme and manner of our baptiſme, hath this obſeruatiō, that firſt the font muſt be hallowed (howe like you that M. Calf?) then he that is to be baptiſed, muſt go downe into the water. For as ſone as the prieſt cometh in, he maketh an exorciſme (howe like yowe that?) Secondarely he maketh an inuocation vpon the creature of water (what ſaye you to that) ād afterward he maketh praier, that the font may be hallowed, and the preſence of the euerlaſting Trinitie be there preſent. This leyed together you may ſee that in baptiſme, of which S. Ambroſe ſpoke in that place, there is water, there is exorciſme, there is inuocation ouer the water, there is praier to hallowe the font, and one to be waſhed in the font. So that S. Ambroſe by the element meaneth water, by conſecration, the inuocation of the name of God, and bleſſed Trinitie vpon the creature of water, to hallowe the font, and there to be preſent: by the worke he meaneth remiſsion of ſynne geuen by the
goodnes of God to hym that was baptiſed, by operatiō he meaneth the exorciſme, prayer, ablution, and acte of the prieſt, waſhing hym that was baptiſed. and this is the very meaning of S. Ambroſe. The worke that is wrought, to witte the remiſsion of ſynnes, is not as you fooliſh by imagine, done by the prieſt, Fol. 91. a The vvoorke in baptiſme done by God and not by the prieſte. but by God, to whome only and immediatly appertayneth remiſsion of ſynnes. It is the operation, that (is to ſay) the exorciſme, the act of ablution and waſshing, that is done by the prieſt, ād not the worke. For yf you ſay that the worke is done by the prieſte, and the operatiō by God, then do you preferre the prieſt before God. For in all the courſe of nature and grace, where beſides the operation there is a worke: Digni • s eſt opus operatione, the worke is woorthier than the operatiō, as the ende is woorthier thā the meanes, by which we come to the end. And if the worke be woorthier than the operatiō then is the worker of the ſaed worke woorthier than the operation by which it was wrought: and ſo by your frōtike fanſie, the prieſte more woorthier them God. See you not into what blaſphemie your groſſe ignorance bringeth you? Recant for ſhame, and geue to God that which is Gods, and to man that which appartayneth man. Let the worke in baptiſme, which is remiſsion of ſynnes, be geuen to God, whoſe properly it is: let the operation, which is the ſaying of praiers, making of exorciſme, hallowing the water, dipping the child, and whole acte of ablution, be the prieſtes whoſe miniſtery God vſeth in that worke. Likewiſe in S. Cyprian the authoritie of operation is not after your fanſie,Ibidem. the power of the holy Ghoſt. For authoritie of operation is a cōmiſſion, lycence, or grace, geuen to mā to worke. The holy Ghoſte is the authour that geueth this authoritie, commiſsion, licence, and grace. Authoritie of operation, remaineth in the partie that hath lawfully receaued it, be he neuer ſo vitious, the holy Ghoſt dwelleth in none by ſpeciall grace; that enormouſly ſynneth.

VVherfore yow did very euill when yow taught yower yoūg ſcholer,Fol. 9 • . that auctoritie of operation is the power of the holy Ghoſt. Not becauſe it is vntrue that the holy Ghoſt doth
ſanctifie, conſecrate, and worke euery thing inuiſiblye, but becauſe by this inuiſible ſanctification, conſecration and working of the holy Ghoſt, you labour to exclude the viſible ſanctification, cōſecration, and working of the prieſt, and ſo by one truth deſtroye another (that is) that the prieſt doth ſanctifie, cōſecrate, and worke. For as S. Ambroſe ſaieth: Thowe wēſt in, thowe ſaweſt the water, Lib. 1. de Sacram. cap. 5. thowe ſaweſt the prieſt, thowe ſaweſt the Leuites: Leſt ſome ſhould happely ſay, is this al? Yea verily it is all, it is trulye al, where all the whole innocencie, all the whole pietie, all the whole grace, and all the whole ſanctificatiō is. Thowe haſt ſeene all that thowe couldſt ſee with the eies of the bodie, or ſight of man. Thowe haſt not ſeene thoſe thinges, which are done and not ſeene. Thoſe thinges that are not ſeene, are much more greater. Becauſe thoſe thinges that are ſeene are temporal, thoſe thinges that are not ſeene, are eternal. By which you ſee that the prieſt ſanctifieth,2. Cor. 4. the prieſt conſecrateth, the prieſt worketh, and that that which the prieſt worketh, is all innocency, al pietie, al grace and al ſanctification.

Likewiſe in ſaying that the ſacraments haue their effect in the figure of the croſſe,Fol. 91. a that is as you ſay in Chriſte him ſelfe, you walke deceithfully, not becauſe it is vntrue thal all ſacraments haue their effect in Chriſte, and only by Chriſt, and merites of his paſsion, but becauſe you exclude the vſe of the ſigne, from the celebration of Chriſtes ſacraments, which the holy Ghoſt taught, and the catholicke churche receaued by tradition from the Apoſtles, as many auncient fathers wittneſſe, and is nowe generalie obſerued through all Chriſtēdome, where the corruption of hereſie, hath not entred, and ſhall preuaile and be vſed, maugre all hereſies and heretickes, in diſpite of the deuil. Grind. In deede (ſir Iames) we can not denie, but that the old fathers vſed the ſigne of the croſſe in all ſacraments. Iuſtinus Martyr, Apolog. 2 talking of the croſſe, biddeth vs viewe in our myndes, and conſider with reaſon, all things that are in the worlde, and ſee, whether ſine hac figura adminiſtrentur, they may be done without this ſigne. The very woordes of S. Cyprian, whiche you alleaged euen nowe out of his ſermon, De baptiſmo, declare no leſſe. Calf. I meruail, that your ſuperintendentſhip ſhould thinke ſo. Grind. do
you ſo ſir Iames? Conſtrue the woordes, that you alleaged.

Calf. Verborum ſolennitas, The ſolennitie of the wordes, Fol. 90. b & ſacri inuocatio nominis, and the calling vpon the name of God, &, and, ſigna, the ſignes, attributa, attributed, inſtitutio nibus Apoſtolicis, to the Apoſtolicall inſtitutions, ſacerdotum miniſterijs, through the miniſtery of the prieſts, celebrant, do make, viſible ſacramentum, the viſible ſacrament. Grind. In very deede you haue trāſlated it ſo, and ſet it out in your booke. But howe well your ſelf ſhal ſee. I pray you what caſe, is Inſtitutionibus in your conſtruction? Calf. The datiue caſe. Grind. Then ſignes were attributed to the apoſtolical inſtitutiōs. Calf. yea my lorde. Grind. what were thooſe ſignes and what were thoſe apoſtolicall inſtitutiōs ſir Iames? Calf. You oppoſe me hard, my lord: The ſignes are the viſible elements, the Apoſtolicall inſtitutiōs, are ſacramēts as I thinke. Grind. Ah ſirra, you haue deſerued not only to be had to S. Anthonies ſchole and layed ouer the forme, but to be brought to the conſiſtory and depriued of your leſſon, Archdeacōry, and all that, youe haue. You a preacher, and guide of the people, that can not tell of whoſe inſtitution, the ſacraments are? I had thought that Chriſte had inſtituted the ſacraments? yourſelf ſpeaking againſt the ſacramēt of holy orders,Fol. 104. a ſaied that neither angells nor men make a ſacrament, and are you driuen nowe to contrarie our owne ſaying, and tell vs that the inſtitutions of the Apoſtles (who were men) be ſacraments? By the faith of my body, I am aſhamed of you. Looke better vpon it, and conſtrue it ones againe. Calf. Verborū ſolēnitas, the ſolennitie of woordes, & ſacri nominis inuocatio, and the calling vpō the name of God, & ſigna and the ſignes attributa, attributed, inſtitutionibꝰ apoſtolicis, Signes attributed to the ſacraments by the inſtitution of the Apoſtles. by the apoſtolical īſtitutiōs, ſacerdotū miniſteriis, through the miniſterie of the prieſt, viſible, ſacramētū celebrāt make a viſible ſacramēt. Grindal. This is an other matter, by like then, beſides the ſolemnitie, of wordes, and calling vppon the name of Chriſt, there were certaine ſignes required, by the inſtitutions
of the Apoſtles, to be vſed by the miniſterie of prieſts, to the making of a Sacrament? Calf. It ſemeth ſo: Grin. VVhat were thoſe ſignes? the viſible elements, as you ſaied before? Calf. what will youe haue them be be (my lord)? Grind. Not viſible elements (ſir Iames): As the Apoſtles did not inſtitute the ſacraments: So did they not inſtitute the viſible elements, which are matters of Sacraments. But the ſignes which they inſtituted, were certaine rites, and ceremonies, for the dewe celebration of the ſacraments. And what were thoſe rites and ceremonies that they ordayned and inſtituted, I beſeke youe? VVere they not ſuch as the church hath euer ſithēs vſed? And of al thoſe what one hath more mention in their writings, thē the ſigne of the croſſe? I aſſure you none. VVherfore this cōtētious braule of yours, is not commendable. It geueth the Catholikes more aduātage, againſt vs, and maketh them more curious to ſeeke out antiquities, and the more antiquitie they finde, the more ſhall our noueltie decay. The VViſeman commandeth vs, not to ſtriue of that thing, which doeth not moleſt vs, and not to medle with many thinges. I wiſh you had followed his counſel:Eccle. 11. by your impertinent ſpeaches, you do nothing, but ſhewe the weaknes of our cauſe. To what purpoſe I pray you, is that fooliſh Dialogue that you make about the woordes of S. Cyprian? Is it not not all one to ſay, the authoritie of operation, geueth effect to all Sacraments in the figure of the croſſe, and the authoritie of operation in the figure of the croſſe geueth effect to all facraments? There is no difference in it at al. Serche wel and you ſhall finde it ſo. There are no points to diſtinct the partes of the ſentence, as you imagine. I haue conſulted diuerſe printes, and from the worde operationis they contynue it to the laſt, which is, effectum, without any point at all: and as far, as I can ſe by S. Cyprians drift in that place, thoſe woordes ſhoulde rather be gouerned of the verbe, than of any other worde that goeth before the verbe. For he proueth, that the vertue of the paſsion is great, by the ſigne and figure of the croſſe, and power that it hath, which could be to no purpoſe, yf he would haue theſe wordes in figura crucis, in the figure of the croſſe, to referred to the operatiō of authoritie that
went before, and not to the verbe largitur effectum, that followeth after.

Againe where you finde fault, with your aduerſarie, for ſtaying there, and not alleaging the other wordes, that followe, it argueth that you do but quarell. For it is preſuppoſed that euery Chriſtian man beleaueth, that in the celebration of the ſacraments, the name of God is ſpeciallie to be called vpon, and that his holy name (as S. Cyprian ſaieth) doth all thinges: To talke therfore of the inuocation, and calling vpon the name of God, whiche all men, do confeſſe, it was not to his purpoſe, but of the ſigne of the croſſe, VVhich yow and ſuch like denie. And ſeing he tooke thoſe wordes, that made ſpeciallie for his principal purpoſe, and omitted the other as loth to be tedious in ſpeaking of that which no man denieth, no wiſe man, woulde miſlike his doing therin, nor allowe, your ſuperfluous paynes,M. Calf. taketh much paynes to proue that vvhich no man denieth. in prouing out of S. Cyprian, that whiche the churche euer taught, and all Chriſten men hold at this preſent, that all things do ſtand and be brought to perfection, by the maieſtie of God, and truth of faith, and that ſacraments are not imperfect yf they lacke a croſſe, as the authour tolde you in the 52. leaf of his booke. VVhich being ſo,Eccle. 8. you ſhould haue abſtained from contention as the VViſe man ſaieth, and neuer haue contended in words, as S. Paule teacheth, knowing that: It is honour to a man, 2. Tim 2. Prouer. 20 who ſeparateth him ſelfe, from contention. The Catholickes will reporte of vs, that we paſſe not what we ſay, be it neuer ſo abſurd, and from the purpoſe, ſo we ſay ſomewhat for the preſent. They will ſay, as father Gregorie ſaied,Lib. 8. •• 2. M ••• l. that heretikes by their inquiſitions ſeeke not to attaine the truth, but to be victorers, that is to haue the laſt woord: And whiles they deſire to ſhewe them ſelues outwardly wiſe, inwardly they are tyed by foolly with the chaines of pride. VVherbie it cometh to paſſe, that they ſeeke matter of contention, and can not ſpeake peacebly of God, which is our peace: and of a matter of peace, become inuentours of contention and ſtrief. VVherfore deale more circunſpectly, be not ſo contentious. Yf I had bene of counſell with you before, or yf you had according to the Quenes maieſties iniunctions repayred to me for priuilege to the printing of your booke, yt ſhould
not thus haue paſſed. It had ben a thouſand tymes better for vs, yf it had ben ſuffred to paſſe away in ſilence, but nowe ſett a faier face vppon it, and lett it goe.

Here goode readers, you ſee the force of truth howe it preuaileth, and howe the enemy of truthe is confuted by him, that otherwiſe perſequuteth the truth. At the inſtant, when I tooke him to be arbiter, I ſuppoſe he had in his meditation, that verſe of Dauid: Pſal. 118. Num. 22. Et ne auferas de ore meo verbum veritatis vſquequaquè. O take not the woorde of truth vtterly from my mouth, and as Balam hyred to courſe, could not chooſe, but bleſſe: So M. Grindal profeſsing otherwiſe to mayntaine lyes, could not chooſe but in this caſe defend the truth. God be thanked for it. But to let M. Grind. take his eaſe, and retourne to M. Calf. another while, you ſhall vnderſtand good readers that he is forced to confeſſe,Fol 89. a The fathers vſed the ſigne of the croſſe in miniſtration of ſacraments that the auncient fathers vſed the ſigne of the croſſe in miniſtration of the Sacraments▪, and that a ceremonie wanted, yf the making of a croſſe wanted. VVhich being true, where is their great crake, that they haue reſtored the communion to the vſe of the primitiue churche? where is their vaunte that they followe the auncient fathers? Al is turned into a vayne bragge. By their owne confeſsion, in thoſe daies in celebrating the ſupper of our lorde, the ſigne of the croſſe was vſed, and in other ſacraments, nowe it is reiected with the ſacraments. They obſerued it for a godly ceremony, nowe it is contemned for groſſe idolatrie. Howe ſtāds this together? As right as the miniſtres badge in horne church yarde.Calf. Fol. • . b Mar •
▪ But M. Calf. ſaieth, that our ſacraments lacking the ſigne of the croſſe and that vſual ceremonie, be perfect not withſtanding. VVherein he is much to be commended for a iolye wiſe ſire,The ſigne of the croſſe but a ceremonie, yet not vvilfullie to be omitted. that affirmeth that, which no man denieth, and although the thing be tolde him ten tymes, yet wil not vnbutten his precious eares, to let in ſo litle a blaſt of holſome winde. Ones againe therfor I tell you M. Calf. that we confeſſe, that the ſigne of the croſſe is but a ceremonie, yet ſuch a ceremonie, that whoſoeuer doth wilfully omitt it, and contemptuouſly reiect it as ſuperſtitious, trāſgreſſeth the ordinance
of the holy Ghoſt, tradition of the Apoſtles, cuſtome of the church, and decrees of the fathers.

Furder we ſay, with S. Auguſtine that yf the ſigne of the croſſe lacke in the Sacraments, None of them is done rightlie, that is, according to the ſolēne, rite and ceremonie: And ſo, yow M. miniſter might haue conceaued, that I M. lawier did ſo take it, both by my woordes that went before, and by this alleaged here out of S. Auguſtine. And albeit the Engliſh woorde (rightly) being written ſo, for ritely,Fol. 52. a did miniſter you occaſion to thinke the contrarie, yet might the latin woord, rite: haue geuen you to vnderſtand, that it was ment of the ſolemnitie and not of the ſubſtance. But yf your will had followed your wit in this, your ſelf ſhould haue lacked woordes, your booke ſtuffe, the printer worke, and prentiſes matter of errour, which had ben a greate ouerſight.

Concerning your robbing the Sacraments, of their effect,Fol 92. a Auguſt in Ioa. T • ac. 40 & de Catacl. cap. 5. and attributing the ſame to faith only, and for proufe of it alleaging a place out of S. Auguſtine, wherein yow folowed your Sarum Solymam, who is anſwered by doctour Harding in his reiondre lately ſet forth, I ſay nothing but referre you to that. There ſhall you ſee it confuted to your ſhame. Your cauills againſt the viſion of Probianus and fanſie that angells can make no croſſes, becauſe they haue no handes, I anſwered before:Fol. 93. b likewiſe your braule aboute S. Auguſtines place for myſterie, and trifling againſt theſe woordes operationis Authoritas, out of S. Cyprian, I haue already cōfuted,Ibidem. only you ſay Chriſoſtome maketh nothīg for me, and bring no cauſe why. As long as your do ſoo: my yea, ſhalbe as good as your nay. But how lurdely yow deceaue, and are deceaued, the learned that haue S. Chriſoſtoms workes may ſee by conference of his places. For the vnlearned,Ho. 55. in 16. Matth. The croſſe a banner and enſigne of victorie. it may ſuffiſe that S. Chryſoſtome ſaieth, VVhen we are Chriſtened, when we are nouriſhed with the holye meate, when we are placed to be conſecrated in holy orders, that banner and enſigne of victorie alwaies aſsiſteth vs. I pray you good ſir, what was the enſigne of victorie, that Chriſoſtome ſpeaketh of, but the ſigne of the croſſe? The
paſsion, was the conqueſt, and victorie it ſelf, as S. Paule teſtifieth, and not the enſigne of victorie. The ſigne and the thing ſigned, be two thinges, in wiſe mens iudgmēt. Yf ſome drouſie dreame, haue made you dote, and thinke the contrarie, awake betyme, and ſtretch your lymmes or els we will ſay, God night M. Calf.

Fol. 94 aYour idle digreſsiō and blaſphemous woordes vttred in your raging heate, againſt the ceremonies vſed in the dedication of churches, I wittingly omit as loth to ſpend two leafes as yow haue done, in cōfuting not your reaſon, but your railing. For reaſon yow do not ſoberly, but rayle impudently, as your euangelicall māner is. VVherfore ſeing yow raile, where you ſhould reaſon, I thinke it not reaſon to enter any long diſcourſe of it, and reaſon againſt railing. The churche that vſeth thoſe ceremonies is of ſufficient authoritie to conuince the vſing of them to be laufull, and ſuch a piller and foundation of truth, that raile againſt it as long as ye liſt, you ſhall but vtter your malice and ſpend your breath in vaine and hurt it no more, than the bloyſtring winde, that beateth againſt the rocke.

I remēber when I was a ſcholler, I lerned a tale of an eluiſh angrie beaſt, called a weſell, that coming to a ſmythes ſhop and finding a fyle, did lick it, and gnawe it, vntil her tongue was raſed,M. Calfs. tongue like the vveſel, that gnavved the Smithes fyle. and the bloud dropping out of her mouthe: Yet ſhe made her ſelf mery ſo long, with licking and gnawing the fyle, thī king to get away ſomewhat of the yron, that ſhe had her tongue lickt of. So may you, M. Calf. licke, which your venemous tongue, gnawe with your Tigers teethe, the cetemonies of the church, and delite your ſelf in it: You ſhal hinder it no more, thā the eluiſh weſell did hurt the yrō fyle: and perchaūce by lickīg, licke out your owne tongue, before you diſgrace the churche, and ceremonies therein vſed. From railing, youe runne to your ſory refuge of denying. Being preſſed with th'authoritie of S. Dioniſe. S. Paules ſcholler, and biſhop of Athens, you haue no ſhift to elude it, but to denie the he heauēly and Eccleſiaſtical Hierarchie to be S.
