Dioniſes woorke, and call it a baſtard booke, vniuſtly fathered vpon him, which is a ſhift next the woorſe,
and moſt agreable, to your negatiue diuinitie,M. Calfs. reaſons againſt S. Dioniſe vvorkes anſvvered. and ablatiue doctrine. But as your impudence paſſeth honeſtie, in denying, ſo doth your folly ſhewe it ſelf planly in vttring the reaſons, that induced you to denie it. For who but ſuch a miniſter, as you, would ſay, Euſebius and S. Hierome made no mētion of S. Dionyſe heauenly and eccleſiaſticall hierarchie, ergo, he wrote no ſuch woorke? I tolde you before that it was poſsible that many thinges might eſcape Euſebius knowledg, and S. Hieromes alſo, cōcerning the hiſtorie of thinges done, before in diuerſe ages, diuerſe cuntries, and diuerſe Emperours dayes: and ſo I tell you againe. And for to inſtruct ſuch and olde Bachiler and yoūg reader of Engliſh diuinitie, I tell you here, that Origenes, Sophronius Archibiſhop of Hieruſalem, Gregorius Nazianzenus, Ignatius, Teſtimonies cited of S. Dioniſe by the auncient fathers. the thirde Archbiſshop of Anthioche, after S. Peter, do cite places out of his epiſtles, and hierarchies, as you may ſee in the epiſtle before his workes ſet foorth in Greeke by Morelius, the kings printer in Paris, the yere of our Lorde 1562.

Your other reaſon why that booke ſhould not be S. Dionyſe is this: He ſpeaketh of God fathers in his booke, but the vſe of God fathers was not inuented fourtye yeres after, Calf. Fol 95. b ergo that was not his woorke. The Minor you proue by Hyginus, that liued an hundred and fourthy yeares after Chriſte,Mart. The antiquitie of god fathers. and inſtituted, that at euery Chriſtening there ſhould be at the leſt on God father and one God mother: where the gentle reader may ſee, that that ceremonie vſed, in the churche, is not a late deuiſe, nor newe inuenton, but fouretene hundred yeres old. But be it that Higinꝰ Pope of Rome did firſt inſtitute in the weſt churche, that God fathers and God mothers, ſhoulde be preſent at baptiſme? what will you inferre vpon it M. Calf? VVill yow ſay this, Pope Higinus was the firſt that inſtituted godfathers and godmothers in the weſt church, ergo S. Dionyſe biſshop of Athens did not ſpeake of it nor thinke of it, xl. yeares before in Athens amongeſt the Grecians? Howe holdes this argument? VVhy ſpeake you not? Or tell vs the ſoner, or we will ſay that as yet, it hangs as farre wide, as Athens is from Rome. Conſider
it by a like. The Quenes maieſtie was the firſt that ordayned by act of Parliament, that euery man ſhoulde eate fiſh in her realme vpō weneſday, ergo the kings and biſshops of Italie, Fraunce and Spayne, yea and England too neuer thought nor ſpoke of the weneſdayes faſt before. Is not this paltrie? leaue it, leaue it, for ſhame.

Higinus borne in Athens. Higinus, being a Grecian, borne in Athens, where S. Dionyſe was biſshop, might knowe the orders and ceremonies which he had receaued of his maiſter S. Paule, and planted in his churche at Athēs, and knowing them might by his authoritie, being nowe biſshop of Rome commaunde the ſame order, and ceremonie to be vſed in the Latin church, not as firſt inuentour or inſtitutour, but as a newe reuiuer and recommender of olde ordinances and auncient ceremonies, like as holy Auguſtine, our Apoſtle, hauing commiſsion from S. Gregory, to choſe out of all churches,Diſt 12. ca. Nouit. thoſe things which were godly, religious, and honeſt, and delyured them to our forefathers to be obſerued, was not to be counted the firſt inuētour, inſtitutour, and ordayner of newe ceremonies, but a recōmender of old, ſuche as were vſed in other churches before. VVhich being vndoubtedly true, your reaſon ſerueth no more to infringe the authoritie of S. Dionyſe heauenly and eccleſiaſtical hierarchie, than the paryng of a nayle to battre the biſshops palace of Canterbury. Neither cā you haue any euaſion to eſcape and refuſe the ſigne of the croſſe, becauſe the auncient fathers repelled the traditions of their elders, Fol 96. a Calf. and after eſtabliſhed other of their owne, nor thinke that becauſe their example proueth no vſe Apoſtolike, or neceſsitie to haue ben in them, that their preſidēt authoriſeth you to diſanulle the other. Mart. For they were laufull biſshops, dulye called to that holy miniſterie. VVherfore as true ſhepeheards of Gods flocke, and faithfull diſpenſers of Chriſtes myſteries, they might by their authoritie alter and change, ſuch traditions, as according to the varietie of tyme, and diſpoſitiō of men, they vnderſtoode to be burdenous, and vnprofitable for the people. As in very deede the churche of Rome (mother and head of all churches)
hath altred diuerſe. But as for you whoe are but murtherers and theaues, falſe prophets, that runne before you were ſent, deceithfull woorkmen that were neuer hired, preſumptuous vſurpers that were neuer lawfully called, adulterous ymps that can proue their inheritaunce by no ſucceſsion, that is thre ſcore yeres olde, you I ſay haue no more authoritie to alter and change any ordinance,Our heretiques haue no auctoritie to chaunge the decrees of the aūciēt fathers. ſtatute, decree, tradition, or ceremonie of the churche vſed of the auncient fathers, than the foole of the midle temple hath to change the principles, and grownds of the common lawe. VVherefore you may wype that conceit and fanſie out of your head, and thinke it vndoubtedly true, as I ſaied before, that he that hath no authoritie to make a lawe, hath no authoritie to abrogate a lawe: and before you may preſume to alter and chā ge, by any preſident of theirs, who for theſe fiftene hūdred thre ſcore and fiue yeares can ſhewe their ſucceſsion from whence they came, proue your petrigrewe by lyneal diſcent, from that raſe, or els you ſhall preuaile nothing.

VVhere you tell me,Fol. 96. b Calf. that youe haue as good authoritie for hony, milke, and wyne to be reſtored in baptiſme, and communion to be geuen to children, as I haue for the croſſe, Yow deceaue your ſelfe and the ſimple reader. For, geuing of hony,Mart. mylke, and wyne in baptiſme, went out of vſe by diſcōtinuāce,The traditiō of the Apoſtles touching the ſigne of the croſſe, neuer altered. Fol 96. b▪ Calf. and geuing the communion to infants was laufully abrogated, and put out of vſe by the church of Rome, which you your ſelues are forced to followe. The traditiō for the vſe of the croſſe was neuer diſcontinued, neuer abrogated by that churche, nor euer taken away by any ordinarie and laufull authoritie: and therefore ſtādeth in his full force ſtill. VVhich ſeing you knewe right well, what vayne toy came into your head to argue deceitfully in this ſorte? Yf the ſigne of the croſſe hath ben vſed in baptiſme, and therfore is nowe to be had in reuerēce, then hony, milke, and wyne, ſhalbe reſtored, in baptiſme, and euery infant receaue the communion? For they were ones vſed? Yf you would haue dealed ſimply, and plainly,Mart. as one deſirous to furder truth, you ſhoulde haue tolde thē (according to your
owne knowledg) that hony, mylke, and wyne were diſcontinued, and communion vſed ones to be giuen to children in baptiſme laufully abrogated by the churche of Rome, but the vſe of the croſſe neuer. And then haue made your argumēt: but full wittely like a wiſe miniſter you knewe that yf you ſhould firſt haue opened thoſe particulers, and afterwarde haue made that reaſon, euery reſonable man would haue called for a bottel of hey to preſent, ſuche an vnreaſonable reader. And therfore you wrought more craftely. But as Salomon ſaieth: The deceithfull mā ſhall finde no gayne, Prouer. 12 his foote is taken in the ſnare which him ſelf layed. He ſhall fall downe in his owne deſtruction, and the ſimple ſhall poſſeſſe his goodes. Prouer. 28

VVhen you had done with this ſubtil deceit of yours, and by ſome ſecrete inſpiratiō vnderſtoode, that it would be eſpied, you thought it good to face out the matter, and fare like a bedlem, and raile ſo boyſterouſly, that no man ſhould withſtand the bitter blaſt that malice blewe from your bleſſed mouth: and therfore you haue diſgorged your ſtomacke of a foule deale of fylth: which I dare not repete, for feare of offending good Chriſtian eares. VVherfore to omitte the vilanous termes, and blaſphemous wordes which your virulent mouth, and ſerpentine tongue vttered againſt the ceremonies vſed in baptiſme, ſacrament of confirmation, chriſme, holy orders, and prieſts, for eight leaues together in your booke, becauſe they are to horrible to be repeted, and more meeter to be written of a Celſus, Porphirie, or Lucian, that diſpited the faith of Chriſte, and myſteries of the Chriſtians, than of a bachiler of diuinitie, that ſhoulde reuerēce them, and more worthie be heard of heathens, Turkes and painimes, than of ſuch as reuerence the name of Chriſte, and profeſſe their faith in baptiſme, where theſe ceremonies, and myſteries were vſed, let vs come to the principall poynt and talke ſoberly.

The cauſe whie you and yours ſtorme againſt thoſe holy ceremonies, and myſteries, is becauſe they be not mentioned in the written ſcripture. Is it not? Yf it be ſo, tell me I beſeeke you, dooth not the ſcripture ſay,Ioan. 20 that Ieſus did many things that were not
written. Doth not the Euangeliſt write,Ioan 21. All thinges that Chriſt did are not vvritten. Ioan. 16. that yf all thinges which Ieſus did, were written particularlie, the whole worlde were not able to receaue the bookes that ſhould be written? Did not Chriſt him ſelf tell his diſciples, I haue many thinges to ſay vnto you, but you can not beare them nowe? But when the ſprite of truth ſhall come, he ſhall teache you all truth? For he ſhall not ſpeake of him ſelf, but whatſoeuer he ſhall heare, he ſhall ſpeake, and declare vnto you, and tell you thoſe things that are to come? Is not this ſcripture M. Calf? And learne you not by this, that the Euangeliſts did not put in written ſcripture, all that Chriſte did? Lerne you not that Chriſt would not tell his diſciples many thinges, becauſe at that tyme they could not vnderſtand them? Learne you not that the holy Ghoſt ſhould teache them all truth, and ſhewe what was to come after? Lerne you not (I ſay) all this? Yf you haue lerned it, why require you authoritie of written ſcripture for all that Chriſt did? See you not by S. Iohn, that all that Chriſt did was not written? See you not that Chriſt left many thinges to be tolde of the holy Ghoſt?Anſvver M. Calf. and that according to Chriſtes bleſſed will the holy Ghoſte did tell his diſciples afterward thoſe thinges, which he had to tell them before, but left vntold, becauſe of their infirmitie? And I beſeeke your maiſterſhip where are thoſe thinges written that Chriſt had to tell his diſciples, and left to the holy Ghoſt to be tolde? VVhere are they I ſay, why ſpeake you not? In what Euangeliſt? In what Apoſtle ſhall we finde them? They were Chriſtes woordes: they were neceſſarie to our ſaluation: otherwiſe Chriſt would not haue ſpoken ſo carefully of them, nor haue put his diſciples in mynde of them, nor haue left them to be told by the holy Ghoſt? Let vs haue your aduiſe. VVhere ſhall we ſeke them? In the Euangeliſtes? they treate only of the doings of Chriſt before his paſsion and aſcenſiō. In the actes of the Apoſtles? Note vs the chapiter. In S. Paules epiſtles? Aſsigne vs the place. In the woorkes of S. Peter, Iames or Iude, Note the ſentence. In the epiſtles and reuelations of S. Iohn? Repete vs the woordes, and remembre well that youe finde, Multa, many things, Suche as none of the Euangeliſtes ſpecified, neither couertly, nor expreſſely. And when ye haue
founde them, proue vnto vs by expreſſe ſcripture, that they are thoſe, multa, that Chriſt had to tell his diſciples, and yet would not tell them, but lef them to the holy Ghoſt to be told.

Furder where S. Paule ſaieth to the Corinthiās: All other things will I diſpoſe when I come, 1. Cor. 11. The order that ſ. Paule preſcribed the Corītiās not foūde in ſcripture. 2. Cap. 2. Let vs vnderſtand of your wiſedom in what written ſcripture we ſhall finde thoſe diſpoſitions and orders of S. Paule. They are not to be neglected. Againe he willed the Theſſalonians to ſtand ſtoutely and kepe the traditiōs whiche they had learned, whether it were by epiſtle or by woorde of mouthe. Yf your learning haue founde what traditions, he commēded vnto them in his ſermons, and talke, ſhewe in what written ſcripture they are to be ſeene: help at a pynch, make a booke of the orders and diſpoſitiōs, that he left to the Corinthiās, and traditions which he willed the Theſſaloniās to kepe: bring out your written ſcriptures, and purchaſe your ſelfe immortall fame, by ſhewing that which neuer man yet coulde finde in the ſcripture. Yf you can finde no place in ſcripture, where they are written,No abſurditie to build a doctrine vpō traditiōs. and yet moſt certaine it is that certayne orders and traditions S. Paule left to be obſerued, thē thinke it no abſurde thing to beleaue more than is contayned in ſcripture, nor inconuenient to build a doctrine vpon the traditions of the Apoſtles vnwritten. But you will ſay, howe ſhall I knowe that theſe are the traditions of the Apoſtles? For anſwer, aſke your ſelf howe, a man ſhall knowe that the Ghoſpell of S. Mathewe, Marke Luke,The churche that approueth the vvritten ſcripture, approueth vnvvritten traditiōs. and Iohn, Actes of the Apoſtles, epiſtles of S. Paule and others, be canonical ſcripture? And yf you finde the authoritie of the churche to be a ſufficient reaſon to proue them to be ſcripture, and perceaue by dryft of reaſon, that you muſt take them to be ſcripture, becauſe the churche hath allowed and approued them for ſcripture: So thinke the authoritie of the churche to be ſufficient to proue thoſe to be traditions of the Apoſtles: and becauſe the catholicke church hath receaued thē, and vſed thē from tyme to tyme vntill this preſent day, thinke that euery Chriſten man that wilbe a member of the churche, muſt alſo receaue them, and vſe them as the churche commaūdeth. For as S. Baſile (talking of eccleſiaſticall ordinaunces writtē in ſcripture,
and others not written, but deliuered by tradition of the Apoſtles, in myſterie) ſaieth: Both haue like force to pietie, Cap. 27. de Spiritu ſancto. Traditiōs. and no man doth gayne ſay them, that hath any meane experience in the lawes of the church. But you haue gayne ſaied them M. Calf. ergo your ſkill in the lawes of the church is very ſimple.

And that it may clerely apeare to all the bretherne that boſte you ſo brauely, your ſelf geue plaine euidēce.M. Calf. ignorāt in the ſcripture. Firſt in ſaying that we delight in odde numbres as all inchaūters haue done of olde: next in denying the ſeuenfold grace of the holy Ghoſt: For yf you vnderſtode the ſcriptures, and knewe what myſteryes the holy Ghoſt had hid, and auncient fathers obſerued in numbres, and knewe, that we delight in thē no otherwiſe, than the church taught by the lerned Doctours, you would not haue founde fault with odde numbres, nor likened vs to inchaunters. But you ſpake according to your knowledg.Fol. 103 a b Aug lib 2. queſt. Euāg. cap. 6 The myſtery of Three. Et in Pſal. 49. Fyue. Auguſt in Pſal. 147. Seuen. In Pſal. 78 In Pſal. 118. Prouer 24 In the number of three, the bleſſed Trinitie, is ſignified, and the ſpirituall parte of man, becauſe we are commaūded to loue God, with all our heart, and with all our ſoule, and with al our minde. In the number of fiue, the continence of our fiue ſenſe is vnderſtode: becauſe, by them, as by fiue gates, thinges entre into the ſoule. And whoſoeuer doth not ſuffer corruption to entre, by the fiue gates vnto his ſoule, is rekoned amongeſt the fiue virgins, who ſignifie all faiethfull ſoules, that ſhall entre into the kingdome of God. By the numbre of ſeuen, Plenitudo ſignificari ſolet, fulnes is wounte to be ſignified ſaieth S. Auguſtine, be it either in reward, or in puniſhment. In another place he ſaieth: Numerus iſte ſolet eſſe vniuerſitatis indicium. This numbre is wonte to be a token of vniuerſalitie, as when Salomon ſaied: The iuſt man ſhall falle ſeuen tymes in a day, and riſe againe, he meaneth, that the iuſt man humbled all maner of waies neuer periſheth. For this phraſe: Septies cadet, he ſhal fal ſeuētymes, is put for al kinde of tribulation by which he is abaſed in the ſight of mā. Againe he ſaieth:Libr. 4. quaeſt ſup Nu. cap. 33 Eleazar was commaunded to ſpringle bloud ſeuen tymes towarde the face of the tabernacle of witnes, becauſe that numbre of ſeuen, pertaineth to ſpirituall clenſing. The ſeuen churches, ſeuen candleſticks, the ſeuen ſtarres, ſeauen ſeales, that S. Iohn ſpeaketh of in his reuelation, the ſeuen barly lofes that our ſauiour multiplied in the ghoſpel, the ſeuē waſhings of Naaman the Siriā, in the ryuer of Iordane,
Seuen pillers builded, by Salomon, be not without high and ſecrete myſteries,Vide Cypria. Ser. de ſpiri. ſancto. not ſuch as inchaunters and cōiurers vſe (as M. Calfhil pretendeth) but ſuch as it pleaſeth the holy Ghoſte to vſe, to expreſſe deepe and profounde ſecretes, to whō the ſcripture commendeth, and the churche knoweth this numbre of ſeuen to be dedicated. Auguſt. li. 5. cap 5 de geneſ ad liter. The like might be ſaied of fyftene, xxi. and diuerſe other odde Numbres, in whiche, yf we delight, we delight not as cōiurers, and inchaunters, as this quarreller ſaieth, but as true Chriſtians, that haue lerned,Aug lib. 1 cap 15 •
▪ quaeſt ſuper Gene. numbres to be very holy and full of myſteries in ſcriptures, which yf our ſir Iames diuinitie could haue foreſeene, although he denieth the ſeuen ſacraments, yet he would neuer haue denied the ſeuēfold grace of the holy Ghoſt, nor vpbrayed the papiſtes with corrupting, and falſifying the woorde of God, and ſet them ſo ſcornefully to ſchole,Fol 10 • . b M. Calf. ſetteth the Catholiques to ſchole, to tell ſeuen as Tom foole told his geeſe. in their olde age, to lerne to tell ſeuen, as Tom foole told his geeſe. But his clerckly ſkill could not direct his ſharpe ſight ſo far, nor make his rowling eies ſee the wood for trees.

To tell the ſeuen graces of the holy Ghoſt mētioned of Eſay was no longe labour. It might haue ben don without an auditour, or Tom foole, that told his mothers geeſe, but ſeing this good calculer in telling of ſeuen, miſſeth one, let vs recken together and make a ſcore, leſt for feare of forgetting, ſo great a numbre,Cap 11. Seuen gyftes of the holy ghoſt in Eſai. we be forced to begynne againe. The prophete Eſay ſaieth: There ſhall come foorth a rodde out of the rote of leſſe, and a flower ſhall ſpring vp out of his rote, and the ſpirite of our lord ſhall reſt vpon him, the ſprite of wiſdome, there is one. Kepe ſtore M. Calf. vnderſtanding, there is two, coūſel, there is three: ſtrenght, there is foure: knowledg, there is fiue: Godlynes, there is ſyxt: the feare of our lord, there is ſeuen: howe ſay you ſir? Haue you the iuſt numbre? Yf you haue not let vs call for ſome of the Quenes auditours, and tellers out of the exchecker, or yf they be to much incombred with odde reckominges, and old accompts, let vs finde ſome other to recken for vs. S. Clement,S. Clemēt Epiſt. ad Iul. & Iulia To. 1. concil. S. Cyprian, Origen, S. Chryſoſtome, S. Ambroſe, S. Hierome and S. Auguſtine, and ſee howe they reckon. S. Clement ſaieth: All men muſt haſte without delay, to be borne, againe, and ſigned of the biſshop, that is, receaue the ſeuenfold grace of the
holy Ghoſt, he kepeth iuſt tale. S. Cyprian ſayeth: By the benefite of this oyntment, both wiſdome, and vnderſtandinge is geuen vs frō God, Serm. de vnct. Chriſti. S. Cypria. counſel, and ſtrenght ſlydeth into vs from heauen, knoweledg, godlynes, and feare, by heauenly inſpirations are poured vpon vs: there is another telleth ſeuen. Origen in his thyrd homilie of ſeuen women, vpon Eſay the prophet, conſidred diligently,Origen. what women thoſe ſeuen were, and what was the ignomine which they ſuſtayned, and founde, that thoſe ſeuen woemen, were but one. For they were the ſpirite of God, and this one is ſeuen. For the ſpirite of God, is the ſpirite of wiſdome, and vnderſtanding, the ſpirite of counſell, and ſtrenght, the ſpirite of knowledg and godlynes, the ſpirite of the feare of our lorde: This wiſdome ſuſtayneth ignomine of many falſe wiſdomes, riſyng vp againſt it. This true vnderſtanding ſuſtayneth obloquie, of many great vnderſtādings. This great counſell is ſclaundred of many euill counſels: This ſtrenght is miſreported of another, which being no ſtrenght nor vertue, yet accompteth her ſelf a vertue. This knowledg abideth iniury, of a falſe pretenſed knowledg, which taketh away her name. This godlynes is vpbraied of that which vaūteth her ſelf to be godlynes, ād is in deede īpietie, ād inſtructiō of the vngodly. This feare ſuffreth vilanie of that which is thought to be feare. Here is another that keepeth iuſt reckoning and telleth ſeuen. Chryſoſt. ſaieth,Chriſoſt. Homil de ſanct & ado • ando ſpiritu. as S. Paule called the holy ghoſt, the ſpirite of life, the ſpirite of charitie, the ſpirite of vertue, the ſpirite of temperance, the ſpirite of promiſe, the ſpirite of faith, the ſpirite of mekenes, the ſpirite of adoption of of ſonnes: So the bleſſed prophete Eſai ſaith, A roote ſhall come foorth out of the roote of Ieſſe, and a flower ſpring out of it, and the ſpirite of God ſhal reſt vpon him. Here is the name of the nature of the ſpirite him ſelf: afterward folloe the giftes, the ſpirite of wiſedome, and vnderſtanding, the ſpirite of counſell, and ſtrēght, the ſpirite of knoweledg, Lib. 3. cap. 2 de ſacra. S. Ambro. Marke M. Calf. The holy Ghoſt is geuen at the inuocation of the prieſt. the ſpirite of Godlynes the ſpirite of the feare of our lorde. This auditour keepeth iuſt accō pte with the reſt, and findeth ſeuen. Come to S. Ambroſe, he ſaieth, The ſpirituall ſeale followeth, which you heard read this day, becauſe after baptiſme it remayneth that there be a perfection made, when at the inuocatiō of the prieſt, the holy ghoſt is infuſed. The ſpirite of wiſedome and vnderſtanding, the ſpirite of counſell, and ſtrenght, the ſpirite of knoweledge and godlynes, the ſpirite of the feare of God, ſeuen as it were graces of the holy Ghoſt. Here is an other, that miſſeth none of the
numbre.Cap. 11. S. Hiero. S. Hierome vpō Eſai, keepeth the ſame tale and ſaieth, It is to be noted that ſpirite of God, wiſdome, and vnderſtanding, counſell, and ſtrenght, knoweledge and godlynes, and feare of our lord (that is to ſay, the ſeuenth number, whiche are called in Zacharie ſeuen eies, in one ſtone, doth riſe out of the roote of leſſe, and ſo conſequently, out of the ſtocke of Dauid. Cap. 3.

S. Auguſt. Lib. 11. ca. cap. 31. Libro 12. cap. 15. In Pſal. 49Here is an other goeth iumpe with the reſt. S. Auguſtine in his woorke, de ciuitate Dei, in his booke againſt Fauſtus the Manichee, in his tteatiſe vpō the pſalme, and diuerſe other places of his woorkes keepeth the ſame reckōing, with al other chriſtiās, and maketh ſpecial mention of the ſeuenfolde grace of the holyghoſt. But what? In compariſon of our Sir Iames, and reſpect of the profounde knoweledg which his maſterſhippe hath gotten in diuinitie, they were euill auditours, not lerned to reckon ſeuē,Fol. 103. b they were falſifiers of ſcripture, nor experte in their textes, but very Tom fooles, ſcarce able to tel, their mothers geeſe. O pryde intollerable? what eare can heare, what heart can abide this Lucifers ſprite? Such aunciēt fathers, ſuch learned doctours ſuch wiſe biſshops, ſuche vertuous prelates to be ſclandred as falſifiers of ſcripture, to be reputed as vnſkilfull idiots, not able to tell ſeuen, to be eſtemed as ignorants, that muſt learne to tell ſeuen,An obiection. as tom foole tolde his mothers geeſe? VVhat ſpitefull malice and raging furie, is this? Satā authour of all lyes, to eſtabliſh his kingdom hath ſcarce a viler practiſe. But M. Calf. will ſay he followeth the truth of the Hebrue, and therfore finding no more, but ſix graces of the holy Ghoſt mētioned in that text, durſt boldly,Fol. 103. b preſume to terme vs falſifiers, and ſay there were but ſix, Fol. 103. b The anſvver. and returne the ſeuenth (which is godlynes) to vs, as our owne. For anſwer we ſay. S. Hierome, ten thouſand tymes better learned in the Hebrue tongue, than this prating parrat, and all the proteſtants, laboring for his life to tranſlate the old teſtament ſo faithfully according to the truth of the Hebrue text, as was poſsible, reckoneth vp ſeuē giftes of the holy Ghoſt, and pietie for one, which was to cumbrous for hereticks cumpany, and therefor no maruell, yf they caſt him out of the text, and
turne him ouer to Catholikes. Nowe yf he tranſlating the Bible according to the truth of the Hebrewe, becauſe the Iewes ſhould not inſult againſt the chriſtiās, ād ſay it was not ſo in the Hebrue, and haue the like ſtarting holes to flee vnto, whē they were preſt with ſcriptures, as ſome ſmattring Hebrue proteſtants haue nowe, did ſhuffle in one worde more in to the ſcripture than the true text had, he ſhould haue geuen the Iewes iuſt occaſiō to cauill, and him ſelf haue had greate grudge of cō ſcience for adding to the ſcriptures, contrary to Gods ordināce,The ſeptuagintes, reckon 7. graces of the holy Ghoſt. Oratio. • a • aenet. ad gentes. In vvhat eſtimatiō the fathers had the ſeptuagints. Lib. 3. cap. 25. Ireneus. Origen. Epiſt. ad Africa, vide Euſeb. li • . 6 cap. 23. hiſto. Cirill Hieroſ. Cathecheſi. 4 Chriſoſt. homi 5 in 1 Matth. S. Hiero. De doctri, Chriſt li. 2. cap. 15. S. Auguſt. which had bene too groſſe an ouerſight, for ſo wiſe, lerned, and godly aman, as S. Hierom was.

Againe the ſeptuagintes whom Ptolomeus king of Egipt had to Hieruſalem, to tranſlate the ſcripture into Greeke, being as Iuſtinus Martir recordeth, men of excellent wiſdome, well lerned in the Greke, and Hebrue tongue, tranſlating this place of Eſai, reckon vp theſe ſeuen graces of the holy Ghoſt, and pietie for one, which M. Calf. woulde haue caſt out. And that the worlde may vnderſtand, howe maliciouſly he ſclandreth the Catholiques with falſifying the ſcriptures, becauſe they followe S Hieromes tranſlation, and the ſeptuagints alſo in this, I will declare in what eſtimation the ſeptuagints, that tranſlated the olde teſtament, were with our forefathers. Irenaeus ſaieth: The ſcriptures were interpreted of the ſeuentie elders per aſpirationem Dei, by the inſpiratiō of God, and declareth in the end of the chapiter, that the ſelf ſame ſpirite, that did foretell in the Prophets, what and after what ſorte the coming of Chriſt ſhould be, did interprete very well in the elders, thoſe thinges which were well prophecied. Origen ſaieth: that only is to be counted true in ſcripture, which the ſeptuagints did tranſlate. Cyrillus Archbiſshop of Hieruſalem ſaieth: The interpretation of holy ſcripture was made of the holy Ghoſt. Chriſoſtom writeth thus: To make credit of a true tranſlation, the ſeptuagints are of right, worthier then all other.

S. Hierome in his prologue vpon the Paralippomenon, ſaieth: The ſeptuagints full with the holy Ghoſt, did tranſlate thoſe thinges which were true. S. Auguſtine hath thoſe woordes: The authoritie of the ſeuentie interpreters excelleth, touching the old teſtament. In all churches, of great learning and ſkill, they are ſaied to haue tranſlated with ſuch preſent
aſsiſtāce of the holy Ghoſt, that thoſe ſeuentie men had but one mouth. Hilarius, In Pſal. 2. S. Hilarie in pſal. 118 S. Luke. S. Paule. Orige. in epiſt. ad Rom lib. 10. cap. 15. counted their authoritie, Perfectā & religioſam: perfect and religious. To be ſhort, S. Luke, an holy Euangeliſt, both in his Ghoſpell, and Actes of the Apoſtles citeth teſtimonies out of the olde teſtament, according to the tranſlation of the ſeuentie interpreters, and not out of the Hebrewes. S. Paule an Hebrew borne and well ſeene in the lawe, kepeth the tranſlation of the 70. almoſte in all pointes. VVhich being ſo it followeth that neither they were deceaued in tranſlating this place of Eſai, nor we falſifiers in following thoſe lerned men, that interpreted the olde teſtament by the inſpiration of God, and aſsiſtance of the holy Ghoſte.

Yf this quarreller will yet ſay, they had no ſight in Hebrewe, he ſhall proue him ſelfe a ſtarke lyer and a very Tom foole. For they were (as I proued before out of Iuſtinus Martyr) very well lerned in Greke, and Hebrewe. If he ſay, their tranſlation was corrupted, I will not contend: but it was corrupted moſte (as the ſaied Iuſtinus reporteth) by the Iewes, whoſe ſpeciall purpoſe was to improue the myſterie of Chriſtes incarnation, and not the ſeuenfolde grace of the holy Ghoſt. Yf he ſay that S. Hierome founde fault with them, we will him to vnderſtand, that Ireneus, Origenes, Cyrillus, Auguſtinus, Hilarius, doe highly commend them, as men full of the holy Ghoſt. Yea S. Hierome him ſelfe, (as is a fore ſaied) who hauing the miſliking of the ſeptuagintes leyed to his chardg, as a fault by Ruffinus, Apolog. 2. cōt Ruff. ſaid for his purgation, non damno, non reprehendo Septuaginta, I reproue not, I condemne not the Septuagints: But I doe boldely preferre the Apoſtles before them all. VVhich places muſt haue a reconciliation, before he be proued to be enemie to the tranſlation of the Septuagints.M. Calfs. reaſon vvhy there ſhould not be ſeuen graces of the holy Ghoſt. Fol. 103. b Calf.

In the meane while heare M. Calf. his fine reaſon, why there ſhoulde not be ſeuē graces of the holy Ghoſt. He ſaieth, Other places attribute of diuerſe effectes, diuerſe other titles to the holy ghoſt, nor the faithfull are only partakers of thoſe which Eſay ſpeaketh of, but alſo of others, as chaſtitie, ſobrietie, truth holynes, whiche in like māner do flowe from the ſame ſpring.
To thruſt the power of Gods ſpirite, into ſuche a corner, that it ſhall haue but ſeuen holes to ſtart to, is to ſtraight a cōpaſse, and can not contayne him. By this he ſheweth him ſelf as wittles as the Tom foole that he ſpooke of euen nowe,Mart. that could not tell his mothers geeſe. For yf witt had ſerued, or Arithmeticke feyed, he might haue ſeene, that the leſſer numbre is alwaies included in the greater. As the marchant that hath ten pownde and a purſe, the famer that hath ten horſe and a carte, the parſon that hath ten kyne and a calf, hath ſeuen. And ſo vnderſtanding, that there be more giftes of the holy ghoſt than ſeuen, he ſhould neuer haue denied that there be ſeuen. Yf he fanſied, that by the ſeuenfold grace, we ſay therbe no more giftes of the holy Ghoſt but ſeuen, he ſheweth his head to be but a ſphere of fanſies, and voyde of all lerning. For yf he had ſpent but a ſmale tyme in diuinitie, he might well vnderſtand, that the fathers, by ſaying there be ſeuen graces of the holy Ghoſt, exclude not all beſides ſeuē. S. Ambroſe ſaieth: There be ſeuen graces of the holy Ghoſt, and all graces pertayne to the holy ghoſt: but theſe are as it were the chiefeſt, theſe are as it were the principalſt. Lib. 3 cap. 2. de ſacra. Cardinales principales. For what is ſo principal, as pietie? VVhat is ſo prīcipal as the knoweledg of God? VVhat is ſo prīcipal as the ſtrenght of God? VVhat is ſo prīcipal as the coūſel of God? VVhat is ſo principall as the feare of God? and ſo of the reſt. Yf thē theſe be the prīcipalſt, and chiefeſt graces of the holy Ghoſt? and all other are contayned in them, he that ſaieth there be ſeuen graces, meaneth not, that there be no more than ſeuen, but meaneth that in thoſe ſeuen all other are compriſed, as Chriſoſtome or the authour of imperfect woorke ioyned with hym teſtifieth, ſaying. As of Gods parte, albeit there be many ſpirites of power yet for all that, they are counted ſeuen, Cap. 11. Prouer 9. be cauſe out of thoſe ſeuen all ſpirites of vertue and power do procede, the which ſpirites, Eſai doth recken vp, and Salomon expreſſe in theſe woordes, wiſdome hath builded her a a houſe and put ſeuen pillers vnder it: So of the deuills parte, although there be many ſpirites of ſynne, yet they are ſaied to be ſeuen, Homil. 30 in 12. Mat. becauſe out of thoſe principall vices, all other vice and ſynne doth flowe.

Yf M. Calfhills wiſdome will ſay for excuſe that he did not
ſee ſo farre in theſe fathers, yet the note of ignorance ſhall ſticke on his cloke, as long as this his dounghil of blaſphemies, and lies ſhall remayne vnburnt. For out of Tullies offices, which he read being but a boy, he lerned that liberalitie, affabilitie, modeſtie, patience, and conſtancie, are counted vertues, and yet Cicero hī ſelf, with other phyloſophers ſay, there be but iiij. vertues, VVyſedome, Iuſtice, fortitude, and Temperance. VVhich might haue geuē him to vnderſtand, that they, in ſaying there be foure vertues, mynded not to exclude all other vertues beſids thoſe foure, but eſtemed thoſe iiii. as the chiefeſt and principalſt vertues, out of which, as out of foūtaynes, all other ſhould iſſue, and ſpring. And by that he might haue lerned to iudge of the ſeuen graces of holy Ghoſt. But his head was ſo infatuated, that he paſſed not what he ſaied, ſo he ſaied ſomewhat at the requeſt of this brethren to deface the Catholiks.

To procede, he trauaileth much to infringe the reaſons that I brought, to proue that the ſigne of the croſſe was vſed in conſecrating the body and bloud of Chriſt, in the ſacrifie of the Maſſe: and by the way like a venemous ſerpent ſpetteth out his poyſon, and blaſphemouſly calleth that dredful ſacrifice, nothīg els but the ſacrifice of the deuil. Fol. 106. a Blaſphemie. VVhiche is a phraſe, more meter, for a lymme of the deuil and tormenter in hell, than for a profeſſour of Chriſt, and preacher of the goſpel. For yf the true ſubſtance of Chriſts body an bloud were not there,Prayer and callīg vpon the name of God is no thīg vvith M. Calf. but a ſacrifice of the diuel. after conſecration, by the omnipotencie of his woordes pronounced by the prieſt, yet there is an oblatiō, and ſacrifice of thankes geuing and prayer made for all ſtates of men, yea with many of the ſame collectes, whiche of force, they them ſelues haue ben compelled to borrowe of the churche of Rome, which malitiouſly they do maligne. There is the epiſtle and goſpel. There is the very true woord of God. The name of Ieſus is called vpō: the praier of our lord ſaied, Gloria in excelſis, ꝓnoūced. The Crede repeted. The name of God, with thriſe repeting, Sāctus, holy, holy, holy, lorde God of ſabooth. And is this, nothing, but a ſacrifice of the deuil? O horrible blaſphemie? what daies are theſe? with heretiks euil, is good, ād good is euil. The deuill is God, and god is the deuil:
yf holy Polycarp was wounte to ſaye, when he heard any thing ſounding the diſhonour of God:Euſeb. lib. 5. cap. 20. hiſto. O mercifull God to what tyme haſt thou reſerued me, that I heare theſe thīgs? Howe much more iuſtely may we, that heare not only the body and bloud of Chriſte, but alſo the praiers of Chriſtians, that haue put on Chriſte in baptiſme, and that truſt to be ſaued by the merites of his paſsion to be reckoned nothing els but a ſacrifice of the deuil? O merciful God to what tyme haſt to reſerued vs? Yf the beaſt with ſeuen heads, and ten hornes, Apoc. 13. that opened his mouth into blaſphemie againſt God, to blaſpheme his name, and his tabernacle, and thoſe which dwel in heauen, were come into the woorld, what coulde he ſay more, to the diſhonour of God, and ſhame of the Chriſtians? To God, who being a ieloous God, a God that geueth the glorie of his name to none other, A God, that ſaied to his Prophete, that men ſhould offre in euery place from eaſt, to weſt, a pure and clene ſacrifice to his name, would ſuffer ſo many prieſts, and biſshops, to ſacrifice ſo many hundred yeres, in ſo many cuntries, in ſo many free cities, ſo many townes, and ſo many villages, to ſuch and oughely dragon, and monſtrous beaſt, as the deuil is? To man, that being redemed with the precious bloud of Chriſt, and made a member of his myſtical body, would forſake ſo mercifull a lorde, and louing father, and honour his deadly enemie, that wayteth for his diſtruction, and like a roring liō ſeketh to deuoure him, what I ſay, could he ſay more to the diſhonour of God? I aſſure you nothing. For it cōuinceth God to be vntrue of his promiſe, that ſaied in thy ſeede all nations ſhalbe bleſſed: and Chriſt vncarefull of his churche, which he ſo dearly ranſomed, and promiſed to aſſiſte with the preſence of the holy Ghoſte vntill his coming againe: which is the greateſt derogatiō to the glory of God that can be. VVherfore ſir vnleſſe you will ſay that Chriſt, ſaying behold I am with you all daies to the end of the world, Matt. vlt. failed in his promiſe, and ſent not the holy Ghoſt to teache thē all truth, (as he ſaied he would) or vnleſſe you will ſay, that the holy Ghoſte for this xv. hundred yeres, was idle in the churche, and ſuffred Chriſtes people that were incorporate into his myſticall body by baptiſme, to erre and offer their ſacrifices of praier, ād thākes
geuing, at the celebration of the heauenly myſteries done in remembrance of Chriſtes death, vnto the deuil, you can not ſay that the maſſe is nothīg els but the ſacrifice of the deuil. VVherfore you may be aſhamed, that ſo blaſphemous a woord paſſed your mouh. For yf you ſhould be narrowly examined whom you haue vpbraied, whō you haue blaſphemed, againſt whom you haue exalted your voice, and lifted vp your eies on high, it would appeare to be:4. Reg. 19. Cōtra ſanctū Iſrael? againſt the holy one of Iſrael.

As touching the principal pointe, you ſaye nothing to the purpoſe. For whereas I proued out of Albertus Magnus a lerned man that lyued iii. hundred yeres a goe, and was B. of Ratiſbone, that Chriſte in his laſt ſupper taking bred in his handes, Signo quodā manꝰ benedixit, did bleſſe it with a certayne ſigne of his hādes, and for proufe, that this woorde, benedicere, may be taken to bleſſe with the hand, brought certaine places of ſcripture, as that Iacob with his hāds bleſſed Ioſephes childrē, Geneſ. 48 Marc. 10 Luc. 14 Fol. 106 a Chriſt leyed his hādes vpō childrē, ād bleſſed thē, Chriſt lyfted vp his hāds and bleſſed his Apoſtles, and that cōſidered, aſked a reaſon of the proteſtāts, why we might not ſay that Chriſte inſtitutīg the ſacramēt of his body, ād bloud and taking bread into his hāds, and bleſsing it, lyfted vp his hāde and with a certaine ſigne of the croſſe bleſſed it, ſpecially, ſeing the auncient fathers do ſo often inſinuate the ſame, and the holy Ghoſt, directing the church in all her doyngs, hath euer allowed this maner of conſecration in that myſterie, and ſacrifice, to all this you anſwer not one woorde, but proue that which no man denieth, that benedicere, is to ſay well, to ſpeake well, and geue thankes, which is no more to my demaunde and queſtiō, than if one would ſay, to hym that aſketh why may not M. Calfhil, be a miniſtre and miniſtrel alſo, Hony is good meate for my lordes beares, and nuttes fyne ſeruice for Iack a napes.

Bleſsing geuen vvith the hande. Serm. de venerat. crucis.By conferring places of ſcripture, we lerne, that bleſsing is geuen with the hande. By S. Chriſoſtome we lerne that the ſigne of the croſſe (which can not be made but by the hand) is preſent euery where, whether the myſticall meate is to be receaued, or any thing els to be done. By S. Auguſtine, that with this ſigne of the croſſe which is expreſſed, with a light mouing of the hand, and calling vpon the name
of God, the body of our lord, and all other thinges that are ſanctified, are conſecrated. By the ſame father we lerne, that men make a croſſe in celebration of Chriſtes ſacraments. Tract. 118. in Ioan. Tit. 20. Panopl. Theſe Authorities not anſvvered by M. Calf. This queſtion not ſoluted. By Euthimius that a croſſe with the hād doth ſanctifie all thinges, to whiche it is put, as the water of baptiſme, the oyle and oyntmēt, the faces of the faithfull, the myſticall bread, and holy bloud. And all this I did put in my booke, and deſired our newe miniſtres to tell vs, howe all this could be done, vnleſſe it be, as the church vſeth, by lyfting vp the hād, and making the ſigne of the croſſe? but I haue no anſwer. M. Calf. that hath taken vpon him to anſwer, in the behalf of all the proteſtāts, anſwereth no worde, neither to this queſtiō, nor to theſe places of S. Chriſoſt. Aug. and Euthymiꝰ: whereby you may ꝑceaue that he anſwereth not directly to that which is propounded, but vſeth ſlyghtes to ſhyft matters, that the ignorant may contynue ſtill in errour.

But becauſe he braggeth ſo much of ſcripture, and thinketh no catholique to haue ſo much ſkill in them, as him ſelf, and and his maſters, let vs examine the places which he bringeth, and ſee, whether benedicere, ſignifieth nothing els, but to ſpeake well, and geue thankes. S. Mathewe ſaieth: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which woordes, you tell me, Yf I vnderſtand Greeke, be theſe, Ieſus taking the bread, Matt. 26. and geuing thankes, brake it. But I tell you, yf you interprete them ſo, you vnderſtand neither Greeke, nor the Euangeliſt. For to oppoſe you in your ſmale rules, be not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,Fol. 106. a participles of the ſecond and firſt Aoriſtes? And to what hath the firſt, and ſeconde Aoriſt reſpect in your Lexicon and grammer? to the ꝑſent, or to the perfecte tenſe? Yf to the ꝑfecte tenſe, then cā not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſignifie taking, nor 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſignifie geuing thankes, in the preſent tenſe. But 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 muſt reſpect the tyme paſt, and ſignifie, after he had taken, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , when he had geuen thanks. And ſo, yf you would nedes refuſe the old tranſlation, and followe the Greeke preciſely, you ſhould haue ſaid: Acceptum Ieſus panem fregit quum benedixiſſet, Ieſus broke the bread taken into his handes, after that he had bleſſed it. Or els this: Acceptum Ieſus panem & benedictum fregit, Ieſus brake the bread taken into his handes, and bleſſed it. VVhich kind of tranſlation,
by the participle of the preterperfecte tenſe, they that be more ſkilfull in Greeke than you or I, Sir Iames, take to be moſte apteſt to expreſſe the nature of the participles of the actiue Aoriſtes. But that ſenſe could not like your melancholy humor, becauſe it proueth that the bread was bleſſed of Chriſt, and cō uinceth that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ſignifieth more than ſpeaking well, and geuing thanks: which you like not.

In the woordes of S. Marke yow committe the like errour. For yow interprete 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 taking in the preſent tenſe, which ſignifieth, after that he had taken, in the preterperfect tenſe. But to the purpoſe. S. Marke ſaieth, Accepit Ieſus panem & benedicens fregit. Ieſus tooke bread, and geuing thankes brake it, after your tranſlation. Tell vs ſir to whom did Chriſt geue thankes in this place, to God the father? that apeareth not by ſcripture. For it is euident by the euāgeliſt S. Mark, that Ieſus tooke bread, bleſſed bread, and brake bread, as the Greeke Aoriſt 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 gouerning in that place an accuſatiue, doth playnly ſhewe. And whether it be gratiarum actio, aut benedictio, geuing of thankes, or bleſsing, it muſt aſwell be applied to the bread, as taking, and breaking. For Chriſt bleſt that which he tooke, and that whiche he tooke he brake, which is eaſy to he ſeene in S. Mathewe, who ioyneth thoſe woordes, taking bread, and bleſſing with a coniunction copulatiue, whiche ſheweth, that there is a likneſſe, betwene that whiche went before, and that whiche came after. But to end this cōtrouerſie, and put all out of doubt, S. Paule hath an euident place in his epiſtle to the Corinthians, where he ſaieth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ? The cup of bleſsīg which we do bleſſe, 1. Cor. 10. is it not a communication of the bloud of Chriſt? and the bread which we breake is it not a participation of the body of our lord? Becauſe, we being many, are one bread, and one body, all that be partakers of one bread and one cuppe? Here S. Paule referreth bleſsing to the cuppe, and geueth vs to vnderſtand that albeit the Euangeliſtes do not clerely expreſſe it, yet they meant that the bleſsing ſhoulde be alſo referred to the bread. Both the bread and the cuppe are of like holynes, bleſſed in the laſt ſupper and not thāked of Chriſt,
as our younge maſter miniſter by the Etymologie of his 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 woulde made ſuch as him ſelf beleaue. But to talke with him plainly, howe ſay you ſir,Fol. 107. a doth it euidently appeare by the woorde of God, to all reaſonable creatures that it is all one to bleſſe, and to giue thankes, as you teache in your booke? Yf it be ſo, conſtrue the woordes of S. Paule, and make a reaſonable man beleaue it. He ſaieth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ? Conſtrue it I beſeeke you in Greek, as it lyeth. Calf. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the cupp,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
of bleſsing,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for the which we geue thākes,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is it not,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the cōmunicatiō,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , of the bloud af Chriſt? Mart. Yea younge man, will you euer more falſifie the ſcripture? where finde you that particle (for) whiche you ſhufle in, to help your purpoſe? There is no ſuch woorde in the text. Conſtrue, it againe, and remembre, that, ô, in Greeke is the accuſatiue caſe, gouerned of the verbe, and anſwereth to the queſtion whom or what, Goe to be not afraied. Calf. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the cuppe, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , of bleſsing, ô, the which, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , we bleſſe, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is it not, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the communication, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , of the bloud of Chriſt?

Mart. VVel ſaied, I am glad that at lenght you can ſee the truth. By S. Paule then, it is playne, that we bleſſe the cuppe of benedictiō: and ſo plaine that you cā not ſay, we geue thākes the cupp of benediction, or we ſpeake well the cuppe of benediction. For that is an vnprope phraſe of ſpeache, nor yet, that we geue thankes to the cuppe of benediction. For thankes are due to God only, nor yet that we ſpeake well the cuppe of benediction, nor geue thankes only for the cuppe of benediction. For the woordes do not import ſo much, nor imploy that ſenſe,The bred and vvine bleſſed. but inferre a playne bleſsing of the bread and wyne. VVhereby, yf you be one of the reaſonable creatures that your ſelf mentioned euen nowe, you may ſee by the woorde of God, that to bleſſe, and geue thankes, is not all one. The very places of ſcripture which you alleage, proue againſt you. For when fiue lofes and two fiſhes mentioned in S. Mathewe, Marke and Luke,Matt. 14▪
were bleſſed, it is vnpropre, to ſay, that Chriſt ſayed, well bread, wel fiſhes,Marc. 6. Luc. 9. or gaue thankes to the bread, and thankes to the fiſhes, or for the fiſhes, but as S. Mathew ſaieth: He bleſſed and brake, what M. Calf? the bread forſoothe? S. Luke ſaieth: Benedixit illis, He bleſſed them.Marc. 8. Likewiſe S. Marke: Habebant paucos piſciculos & ipſos benedixit, They had a fewe fiſhes and he bleſſed them.

Here bleſsing is not thankes geuing, nor ſpeaking well, but a ſanctifying of thoſe creatures, a geuing a vertue and power vnto them to multiply, and increaſe, to ſet forth the glory of God in feeding ſo many perſons. Lykewiſe when Chriſt lyfted vp his handes, and bleſſed his diſciples, yow can not ſay, that Chriſt ſaied, well diſciples, nor that he gaue thākes to his diſciples. But benedixit eis, he bleſſed them, Perchaunce pouring into them a ſtrēght, which ſhould warde them, Theophilact. in 24. Lucae. vntill the coming of the holy Ghoſt. Perchaunce inſtructing vs, that when we go farre from home, we ſhould commēd the people vnder vs, to the bleſsing of God ſaieth Theophilact.

Thus youe ſee that bleſsing and thankes geuing is not all one. And albeit it followeth in S. Luke, that the Apoſtles came into Hieruſalem, benedicentes Dominum, prayſing God, yet ſhall bleſsing, and thankeſgeuing, be diuerſe, as long as there is man to bleſſe, or thinge to be bleſſed.

And becauſe you ſeeme to be ignorant, what bleſsing is, and cā not eſpie a differēce betwene, bleſsing, thāks geuing, and ſpeaking well, I will vpō hope that youe will bleſſe more oftener, thanke more frendlyer, and ſpeake more honeſtlyer, note what is bleſsing, thankeſgeuing, and ſpeaking well. Benedictio eſt ſancticationis traditio, Diſt 28. cap preſbiterum. Geneſ. 2. VVhat is bleſsing. bleſsing in that ſenſe that we talke of nowe, is a geuing of ſanctification, as when God bleſſed the ſeuenth day, he gaue a ſanctification to the ſeuenth daye, and made it holy, and would haue men, to ceaſſe from labour, and beaſtes from woorke, that his holy name might be honoured that day. Likewiſe when he bleſſed Noe and Abraham, and other patriarkes, he gaue them a ſanctification,Geneſ. 9. 1. Reg 9. and made them holy in his ſight. Samuel, bleſſed the ſacrifice and made it holy and meete to be offred vnto God: In the newe teſtament, the virgin mary was, benedicta in mulieribus, bleſſed amongeſt woemen, that is ſanctified
aboue al other woemen, made an holy and ſwete tabernacle to receaue the eternal ſonne of God. Chriſt in his laſt ſupper bleſſed bread, that is gaue it a ſanctification, and by the omnipotē cie of his woorde, made it his owne fleaſh, ſaying. This is my body, which ſhalbe geuen for you in remiſsion of ſynnes, and ſo likewiſe, of the cuppe, this is my bloud of the newe teſtament which ſhalbe ſhed for many in remiſsion of ſynnes. And that you may not thinke this to be my priuate opinion, diuerſe aunciēt fathers ſpeake notably of this ſanctification and conſecration of the outwarde elemēts and viſible creatures of bread and wyne, eſpecially Iuſtinus, Martir, S. Cypriā, S. Ambroſe, Euſebius Emiſenus, Apolog. 2. de coena domini. De ijs qui myſter. cap. 9. Homil. 5. de Paſch. Epiſt 59. queſt. 5. Thankes geuing. De gratia & gratitu. queſt. 106 and S. Aug. as al that are deſirous to ſeeke may finde in the places quoted in the margēt, which for feare of tediouſnes I omitt.

As for thankeſgeuing it is defyned, thus. Gratiarum actio eſt quaedam gratiae recompenſatio, that is to ſay, thankes geuing, is a certayne recompence, of grace, and benefit beſtowed vpon vs. As when the poore begger geueth the riche man thankes, for his almes, his thankes is a certaine recompence for his almes. In like maner when we giue our heart, our ſoule and mynde, to God, when we haue compaſsion of the poore, when we faſt, and pray, when we renewe the memory of his paſsion, when we ſet foorth the glorie of his name, and geue him high commendations, and ſoueraigne praiſes for the benfites of our creation, for the abundance of all things, appertaining to our ſuſtenance, for the kindes of things, for the varietie of tyme, yea for perſecution, aduerſitie, and trouble, and ſo foorth,Iuſt. Mar. Apol. 2. then geue we thankes to God, then do we ſo farre foorth as we may recompence, his goodnes towards vs, and after the benefite is beſtoued, geue thankes, and when the good turne is done, make recompence, and in conſideration of his merciful promiſe make hym debter vnto vs. For as maſter Calf. alleageth out of Chriſoſtome: Qui benedixerit debitorem illum facit maioris benedictionis: He that bleſſeth, and geueth thākes to God,Fol. 116. a Homil. 29 in 9. Gene. maketh him debter of a greater bleſsing. VVhich bleſsīg is no thākes geuīg M. Calf. For God geueth vs no thākes, we muſt geue thākes to him. And for our poore thākes, ꝑceding of a pure heart, he geueth vs an infinite
treaſure, that is the fruition of hym ſelf in glorie. By this we ſe that to geue thankes to God, is to recompence his goodnes, and benefites towards vs, ſo farre foorth as we may, by rendring our heartes, ſoules, and myndes, vnto him, and geuing him high commendations, and ſoueraigne praiſes for our creation, as is before ſaied: but that Chriſt in ſuche ſorte only, gaue thankes to God the father, at the inſtitution of his ſupper, the woordes of the Ghoſpell do not import, for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in S. Mathewe, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in S. Luke, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in S. Paule haue relation to the bread and wine,VVhat did Chriſt bleſſe in the ſupper M. Calf? Anſvver. and anſwer to the queſtion whom or what, as yf you woulde aſke what was it, that Chriſt tooke, what was it that Chriſt bleſt, your anſwer muſt be, he tooke bread, and he bleſſed bread, and not he thanked bread, or ſaied well bread, or gaue only thankes for the bread. Thankes in ſuch only ſort, as you proteſtāts meane, were geuē after ſupper, whē they ſange their hymne, and went vp into the mounte olyuet. And that you may not cauil, in ſaying that thankes were geuen after ſupper in ſuch only ſorte, as youe meane, I put you to vnderſtand, that we denie not, that Chriſt lyfting vp his eies to heauen gaue thankes to God the father before, to inſtruct vs, that before and after the celebratiō of the myſteries, we ſhould praiſe God, and geue him tankes, for his tender mercy towardes vs: but we ſay, that Chriſt beſides geuing of thankes, bleſt the bread, and gaue it a ſanctification, and made it holy, euen his owne body and bloud, and both by his example taught, and with his woorde commaunded vs to do the like whenſoeuer we would celebrate the memorie of his paſsion, that is, to take bread, and bleſſe it, and pronounce thoſe holy woordes, by which through the omnipotencie of his power, the viſible creatures are ſanctified, and hallowed and turned into the ſubſtance of his body and bloud.

He ment not only, that whē we came, to the myſteries of the lordes ſupper, we ſhhould bleſſe only, that is as M. Calfhils interpretation expoundeth it,Fol. 106. a Be thankefull for them. For which expoſition of his, becauſe he alleageth. S. Chriſoſtome, and wyl leth me, to ſet him againſt my Alberte, I will examyne the place
of that auncient father. And to the end you may the better vnderſtād his woords, I will note a place,In 1. Cor. cap 10 homil 24. Homi. 60. Chriſt doth ſanctifie the creatures of bred and vvine and chaū ge them. where he proueth that the creatures of bred and wyne were cōſecrated by Chriſte in the ſupper. In his Homilie to the people of Antioche, talking of the ſacrament he ſaieth, The woorkes ſet foorth, are not wrought by the vertue of man: he that then made them in that ſupper, maketh them alſo nowe. we kepe the place of miniſtres. It is chriſt him ſelf that doth ſanctifie them and chaunge them. Here he declareth, that Chriſt in the ſupper did more then geue thankes, he ſanctified the creatures, and changed them. And ſo muſt we that are his miniſtres doe. Yf you aſke into what he chaunged thoſe viſible creatures, S. Chriſoſtom ſhall tell you out of the ſame Homilie vpon the epiſtle to the Corinthians,Hom 24. in 1 Cor. cap. 10. The creatures of bred and vvine chaunged into the bodie of Chriſt. Marke M. Calf the bodie of Chriſte is ſeene vpō the aultor whence M. Calf. hath pickt his half ſentence. There he ſaieth, Chriſt gaue vs his fleſh, that we might be filled with it, by whiche he allured vs into a maruelous great loue of him. That fleaſh was Chriſts body. That body the wiſe men adored in the manger, But you do not ſee that in the manger, but in the aulter, not a woman holding in her armies, but a prieſt preſent, and the holy Ghoſt plentifully diffuſed vpon the ſacrifice there propoſed: neither doeſt thou ſee that ſimple body, but thou ſeeſt alſo his power, and knoweſt all the order and doing of it. Furder he ſaieth. If thou deſireſt bloud, do not ſpringle the alter of idolls with ſlaughter of brute beaſts, but ſpringle my aulter with my bloud. Quod eſt in calice id eſt quod a latere fluxit, & illius ſumus participes. That which is in the Chalice, is that which flowed out of his ſide, and of that we are, partakers. By whiche euery man that hath not his ſenſes corrupted with fanſies, may ſee, that the true body, ād bloud of Chriſt, are in the ſacrament, and that it is the true ſubſtance of his fleaſh into whiche the creatures of bread and wyne are chaunged.

This conſidered let vs ſee the place, that M. Calf. alleaged. And that Chryſoſtomes meaning may more clearly appeare, I will repete the woordes that go before, and come after. Streit vpō thoſe woordes of S. Paule, he ſaieth: VVhat ſaieſt thou O bleſſed Apoſtle Paule, when thou wilt aſ • onnie the hearers, and make mention of of the dredfull myſteries? Doeſt thou call that cup fearfull and full of dread, the cup of bleſsing? I do ſo in deede. For it is no ſmalle thing that is ſpoken.
Siquidem quum benedictionem dico, Euchariſtiam dico, & quum Euchariſtiam dico, omnem benignitatis Dei theſaurum aperio. For when I ſpeake of bleſsing, I ſpeake of thankes geuing, (as M. Calf. tranſlateth it) and when I ſpeake of thankes geuing, I open all the treaſure of the goodnes of God, and rehearſe thoſe great giftes of his. For with the cuppe we adde the vnſpeakeable benefites of God, and whatſoeuer we haue obtayned. So we come vnto him, we communicate with him, thanking him that he hath delyured man kinde, from errour, that whē we had no hope, and were wicked perſons, he admitted vs brothers, and companions vnto him ſelf. VVith theſe and ſuch other rendringes of thankes we come vnto him. Hitherto M. Calf. and as though he had founde a great proufe for his gay fanſie, he ſaieth:Fol. 106. b Here you ſee, what Chriſoſtom tooke bleſſing to be. It followeth a litle after in Chriſoſtome: The cuppe of bleſsing which we do bleſſe, is it not a cōmunication of the bloud of Chriſt? By theſe woordes ſpeciallie, VVhat S. Paule calleth the cuppe of bleſsing. he made him ſelf to be credited, and alſo to be dreaded. The ſenſe and meaning of thoſe wordes is this, that which is in the chalice, is that, which flowed from his ſyde, and of that we are partakers. He called it the cuppe of bleſsing, becauſe when we haue that cuppe before vs, with admiration and certayne honour of that vnſpeakeable gifte, we praiſe him, geuing him tankes that he ſhed his bloud, that we might not remaine in errour, but haue made vs partakers of it.

Thus Chriſoſtome there: Nowe gentle M. Calf. what meaneth Chriſoſtome by bleſsing? thankeſgeuing as you ſay? Yf it be ſo? Then thankes geuing is all the treaſure of the goodnes of God, thankes geuing is that which flowed out of the ſide of Chriſt, thankes geuing is the table of our Lord, thankes geuing, is animae noſtrae vis, The bleſſing that Chriſoſt. mentioneth in the Place alleaged by M. Calf nerui mentis, fiduciae vinculum, fundamentum, ſpes, ſalus, lux, vita noſtra. The ſtrenght of the ſoule, the ſynowes of the mynde, the bonde of faith, the foundation, our hope, our health, our light and our life. For benedictio, and euchariſtia, that S. Paule mentioned, haue all theſe properties applied vnto them in the very ſelf ſame place of Chriſoſtome. Read the whole chapiter and ſee: and after viewe of the place, let vs vnderſtand whether thankes geuing (which is an action of ours) neuer of it ſelf acceptable, in the ſight of God, for our vnworthines, can be compared to any of them. Yf after mature deliberation, you fynde it
not only great impietie and vngodlineſſe, but alſo curſed blaſphemie and abominatiō to conceaue any ſuch thing) thinke thē no vnreaſonahle men, that make a difference betwen bleſsing, and thankes geuing, and miſlike your raſhnes for alleaging, that out of Chriſoſtome whiche you vnderſtand not. The thankes geuing or Euchariſte, which he mentioned, is the body and bloud of Chriſt, called of S. Paule the cuppe of bleſsing, VVhat is Thankes geuing mentioned of Chriſoſt. becauſe, when we haue that cuppe before vs, we praiſe God with admiration, and honour, geuing thankes that he ſhed his bloud, for vs, and ſuffred vs not to remayne in errour. VVith that cuppe we remembre the vnſpeakeable benefits of God, we come vnto him, we communicate with him, and praiſe him, for redeming vs out of thrauldom. By this you ſee that firſt we muſt haue the cuppe of bleſsing before vs, and then geue thākes, not that we may not geue thanks without the cuppe, but becauſe our thankes geuing with that cuppe of bleſsing is a more acceptable ſacrifice in the ſight of God. VVherfore it behoueth vs to ſeeke, howe we may come by this cuppe of bleſsing. A meane muſt be had: yf it may be gotten by only thankes geuing, or by being thankefull, then euery man may make this cuppe of bleſsing. For euery man can geue thankes, at the myſteries of our lordes ſupper, and be thankefull for them: but yf none cā make that cuppe, but ſuch as be ſpeciallie called, to whō it was ſaied: Make this in my remembrance, it will followe that ſom ſpeciall thing is required, more than thankes geuing, as taking, bleſſing, and conſecrating, with thoſe wordes, which Chriſt ſpoke, when he inſtituted this ſacrament, and ſaied: Take, eate, this is my body: Drinke ye all of this, This is my bloud of the newe teſtament, which ſhalbe ſhed for many in remiſsion of ſynnes, which appartayneth not to all. As for ſpeaking well,Speaking vvel. it is either a geuing of gentle woordes in familiar talke, or a reporting wel of our euen Chriſtians, or a copious and eloquent ſetting foorth of an oratiō by voyce and geſture, or a teaching in right order. And none of al theſe was principally meant of our ſauiour Chriſt in his laſt ſupper.

To conclude therfore, ſeing I haue diſproued, M. Calfhils aſſertion, that by the nature of the woorde, the iudgment of the
Euangeliſts, and teſtimonie of S. Paule, to bleſſe and geue thankes is not all one thing, and declared that Chriſt in his laſt ſupper, did not only geue thākes, but bleſſe the bread and wine, and gaue them a ſanctification, and made them holy, that is, turned them in to the ſubſtāce of his body and bloud, and proued that bleſsing which Chriſoſtome ſpeaketh of,
• . Cap. 10. in the x. chapiter of S. Paule to the Corinthians is not our bare thākes geuing, but the very bloud of Chriſt it ſelf, and furder noted, that in celebration of Chriſts ſacramentes, there muſt be a conſecration, and ſanctification of the viſible creatures, by pronouncing the woordes of Chriſte, and calling vpō his holy name, and making the ſigne of the croſſe, which manner of conſecration the church lerned of Chriſt, and hath contynued euer ſithens, which cuſtome and vſe of the churche, S. Auguſtine thought a good way to vnderſtand the ſcripture, we may boldly ſay with that lerned father Albertus Magnus, that Chriſt bleſsing the bread, Signo quodam manus benedixit, Epiſt. 59. queſt. 5. ad Paul. Bleſt it with a certaine ſigne of the hand, and then pronounced theſe woordes, this is my body etc. and this interpretation of his, and aſſertion of myne, all the witte of M. Calfhils head, and lerning in his Engliſh Doctours, wil neuer be able to proue to be friuolous.

His iarring ſtill, like a blind harper vpon one ſtring, that it is not materiall, Calf. Fol. 107. a what rite or ceremonie was receaued after, and that it is not ſufficient to ſay, it was once ſo, but it muſt be proued that it was well, ſo, Mart. I haue anſwered before. And ſay furder here with S. Auguſt. that as we muſt do all that, which the authoritie of ſcripture commaundeth: So likewiſe, yf the catholik church through out all the woorlde doth vſe any of theſe rites, and ceremonies, we muſt alſo vſe them and do as the churche doth.Epiſt. 118. ad Ianua. Epiſt ad Pomp. For to reaſon whether this ſhould be done in ſuche ſorte, or no, it is a poynt of moſt inſolent madnes. The place of S. Cyprian, whiche he him ſelf alloweth, vnde eſt traditio etc. VVhence is this tradition, doth it deſcend from the writinges and commaūdements of his Apoſtles, maketh nothing againſt vs. For this rite and ceremonie of making the ſigne of the croſſe, came from the tradition of
the Apoſtles, and ſo conſequently from, their commaundemēt, as it is proued before. Yf you bid vs ſhewe ſcripture for it, we bid you ſhewe vs in what ſcripture all Chriſtes doinges,All the Apoſtles preched, but all their precepts are not vvritten, yet to be follovved. and al the Apoſtles cōmandemēts were written. All preached, all gaue commaundements, to the Chriſtians, where they preached, and yet haue we not writings of all. And becauſe al their commaundements were not written, ſhall we thinke that the commaundements whiche they gaue to their people, and they to their aftercummers ſucceſsiuely, by tradition vnto this preſent, are to be contemned? No. S. Paule commaundeth the contrary, and biddeth vs kepe traditions, that we lerned by his epiſtle and woorde of mouth S. Cyprian him ſelf vrgeth earneſtly the tradition of Chriſt, for mingling water with wyne:Libro 2. epiſt. 3. Serm. de vnctio. like wiſe the anoynting w • h Chriſme to be inſtituted, and yet neither this nor that tradition▪ is written, neither in the Euangeliſts, nor in the Actes of the Apoſtles, nor in any of their epiſtles. VVherby you may vnderſtand, that he aſking for tradition, aſked aſwell for ſuch as were vnwritten, and ſealed in the heartes of men, by the commandement of the Apoſtles, as for thoſe whiche were written i • the Euangeliſts, epiſtles, or Actes, of the Apoſtles.

VVherefore,Fol. 107. b in ſaying that S. Cyprian would not be bounde to admitte any thing which was not written in the Euangeliſtes, Actes, Epistles, or other writinges of the Apoſtles, S. Cypria. sclaundered. Heretikes denying traditions denie the ſcripture. Auguſt▪ epiſt. 118. you ſclāder that holy father, and deceaue the readers, with abuſing his authoritie, and wreſting his wordes. And whiles you will not be bounde to the obſeruance of traditions without proufe of ſcripture, denye the authoritie of ſcripture, which cō maundeth traditions to be kept, although they were delyured without ſcripture. You breake the ordinances of the Apoſtles, and determinations of generall councells, from whome all traditions generally vſed in the catholike churche are commended vnto vs. So litle paſſe you either for ſcripture, councells, or fathers, when they make againſt you.

But to procede: where I proued that the ſigne of the croſſe
is vſed in matrimonie, penaunce, and extreme vnction, becauſe they are ſacraments of the churche, which are made (as S. Auguſtine ſaieth) with the ſigne of the croſſe, M. Calf. hauing litle to ſay, findeth fault where none is, and ſaieth:Calf. Fol. 107. b I am abuſed in my owne conceit, for eſteming the ſigne of the croſſe, to be a thing of ſuch neceſsitie, as that the ſacraments can not be made without it. Mart. This for lacke of better ſtuffe he infarced, ones or twiſe in his booke before, but the oftener he repeteth it, the more is his ſhame. For all that haue eies to ſee, and eares to heare, and witte to iudge, may well perceaue that this is, a very cauillation. In all my treatiſe I mayntayne no ſuch poſition, but miſtruſting, leſt ſome malitious momes ſhoulde miſtake my meanīg, I put in a clauſe in the 52. leafe of my booke, to declare that no ſacrament lacked his operation, effect, and vertue, yf by negligence, or forgetfulnes the ſigne of the croſſe were omitted. And this quareller could not choſe, but ſee it before he came to this place, yf he were not blind or druncke with an haſty zeale to anſwer that, which came after, before he vnderſtoode what went before, which is a foule ſhame. VVhere ſuch practiſes are vſed, there is ſmale hope of vpright dealīg. That done he ſaieth, that I leaue out the calling vpon the name of God, Fol. 107. b as though Chriſten men taught that any ſacrament coulde be made with a bare ſigne, without the calling vpon the name of God, and pronouncing the woordes of Chriſt. The lawyer ſaieth, all that is ſpoken in the preface or beginninge, is preſuppoſed to be repeted in that which followeth. VVherfore, albeit in euery place, I put not in all the doctours woordes, nor talke particularly of the calling vpon the name of God, yet ſeing that was: Primum in intentione, firſt in intention, as I profeſſed in my preface, and ſo well knowen of all men, that he is an heathen that doubteth of it, a charitable reader, and good Chriſtian, would euer thinke that to be prīcipally vnderſtode: but we may lerne be this, what good opinion this our good aduerſarie cōceaueth of vs. VVhen he preacheth, and for one halfhower ſpeaketh againſt the Pope, for another againſt the Cardinalls, for another, againſt the enormities
of the clergie, for another, agaīft the ſtudiēts of Louayne, would he thinke any of his brothers wife, yf he ſaid, to his reproche. M. precher ſpoke neuer a woord of faith in all his ſermon, nor of the name of God? No: His charitie (I feare me) would be chafed with it. And yet he dealeth ſo with me: and becauſe I did not expreſſely talke of the calling vpon the name of God, he ſaieth, I leaue it out: and when he had left ſuch a ſiniſtrous ſuſpicion of that in his brethrers eares, he armed him ſelf and went in haſt to proue that matrimony, penaunce, and extreme vnction be no ſacraments, and whereas S. Ambroſe, Auguſtine, and Leo calle matrimonie, a ſacramēt, that maketh no matter, quoth M. Calf. For Ambroſe calleth the woordes, Fol. 108. a Calf. and woorkes of Chriſt a ſacrament. Auguſtine hath nothing more familiar in him than, Sacramenta ſcripturarum, the ſacraments of ſcriptures. VViſely by S. Mary, and like a clearke.Mart. I euer thought before this, that you had lerned, that ſacraments in their propre and true ſignification, (as the churche taketh them) be ſignes of an holy thing, that is of an inuiſible grace,VVhat ſignes Sacraments are. geuen of God in the viſible elements, and not naked ſignes only, but ſignes that are effectuous, ſignes, that contayne grace, and be the cauſe of grace, and bring to paſſe that which they ſignifie. Signes that put vs in remembrance of that which is paſt, preſent and to come, as baptiſme putteth vs in remembrance of the paſsion of Chriſt that is paſt, of preſent grace, that is remiſſion of ſynnes, geuen in that ſacrament and the glorie to com, to which we haue entrie by baptiſme, this I ſay, I though, you had lerned, and could haue iudged that in this ſenſe, S. Ambroſe, S. Auguſtine, and Leo take matrimonie to be a ſacrament, and not as the woorkes of Chriſt, and parables of ſcripture, be counted ſacraments: but I perceaue you are worſe, and worſe: eueryday more ignorant, than other. Euery ſacrament is a ſigne of an holy thing: but euery ſigne of an holy thing, is not a ſacrament. You forgett your rules of reciprocation. Albeit, Ariſtotle ſaied, euery horned beaſt lacketh teethe in the vpper iawe, yet you knowe right well, that whoſoeuer
lacketh teethe in the vpper iawe is not an horned beaſt. And ſo may you thinke of ſignes and ſacraments.

But that is not the matter that you ſticke ſo much vpon. You thinke if it be a ſacrament it muſt be a ſigne, ordayned of God for vs, Calf Fol 108. a to confirme our faith, and ſeale the promiſe of grace within vs. This is a ſtrange definition of a ſacramēt. I beſeeke you in what ſcripture,Mart. doctour, or councell, ſhall we finde it? Yf in none, then geue vs leaue, not to beleaue it. By this definition, we are like to haue neuer a ſacramēt left. For baptiſme was not principally ordained to confirme our faith, but to waſhe away our ſynnes, as S. Peter ſaied: Let euery one of you be baptiſed into remiſsion of ſynnes.Acto 2. For ſuch as were of age, it was neceſſary, that they ſhould (be confirmed in their faith, and beleaue in Chriſt before they were baptiſed, as it is written: He that beleueth and is baptiſed ſhalbe ſaued. As for infantes the faith of the church ſuffiſeth for them,Marc. 16. to baptiſme, to purge them frō originall ſynne. The ſacrament of the body and bloud of Chriſt, was inſtituted to be a meate and foode of the ſoule, in this warfare of ours, and before we can be partakers of it, we muſt not only be confirmed in faith, but alſo haue ſuch diſcretion and iudgment, which cometh not, but after certayne yeres, that we may be able, as S. Paule ſaieth,1. Cor. 11. to trie our ſelues, and examine our conſciences, whether we be worthie to be partakers of that holy meate, before we preſume to come to that dreadful table of our lorde. And more ſacraments then theſe the proteſtants do not acknoweledg. So whiles M. Calf. proueth Matrimonie to be no ſacrament, by his newe deuiſed definition coyned of Caluin in Geneua, M. Calf. of tvvo ſacraments, by his nevve definition leueth neuer a one. Fol. 108. b Calf. and of ſeuen cutteth of fyue, of two he hath left his fellowes newer a one, which is an euill kinde of Aritmeticke. Such diminutions make poore treaſures.

Another reaſon why Matrimonie ſhould be no ſacramēt, is this. VVe haue for baptiſme, who ſo euer beleaueth and is baptiſed ſhalbe ſaued: for the ſupper, Take, eate, this is my body, drincke ye all of this, this is my bloud, which is ſhed for many, for the remiſsion of ſynnes. But we haue not for matrimonie
take a wife, and thoue ſhalt be ſaued. Take a wife and thy ſynnes be forgeuen the, ergo matrimonie is no Sacrament. A propre reaſon, and meete for ſuche a reader.Mart. To anſwer briefly, I denie that argumēt: for it is not neceſſarie that euery ſacrament haue a promiſe of remiſsion of ſynnes, albeit ſome haue. Yf it may be ſhewed that it is a ſigne of inuiſible, grace,Euery ſacrament hath not a promiſe of remiſſion of ſynnes annexed. Ioan, 20. in ſuch ſorte as I ſaied before, it is ſufficient to conuince, that it is a ſament. But what yf Matrimonie had ſuch a promiſe annexed vnto it, woulde this old bachiler and younge miniſter, acknowledg it to be a Sacrament? No No: Penaunce hath an expreſſe promiſe of remiſsion of ſynnes, by Chriſt him ſelf, ſaying. Receaue ye the holy Ghoſt, whoſe ſynnes • e remytte are remytted them. Likewiſe extreme Vnction hath a promiſe of remiſsian of ſynnes, by the holy Ghoſt in the bleſſed apoſtle S. Iames, ſaying,Cap. 5. Penaunce and extreame vnctiō haue a promiſe of remiſsion of ſynnes, yet M. Calf denieth thē to be Satraments. Is any man ſicke amongeſt you, let him bring in the prieſts of the church, and let them pray ouer him, anoynting him with oyle, in the name of God: and the praier of faith ſhall heale the ſicke, and God ſhall eaſe him, and yf he be in ſynnes, they ſhalbe forgeuē him: yet amongeſt proteſtants they cā be no ſacraments. Their definition muſt ſtretch as farre, and be coarcted, as ſhort, as pleaſeth their fanſie: Yea rather, than they woulde confeſſe theſe ſacraments to be compriſed in that definition, which them ſelues make, they will ſend that to Geneua, and ſeeke an other in Gehenna. But let vs go forward.

A third reaſon they haue lerned of Caluin their brutiſh Baſſa vpon the wordes of S. Paule: who writing in Greke called it a myſtery and not a ſacrament. but as I anſwered in my treatiſe before, So I anſwer nowe againe, that baptiſme and the ſacrifice of the body and bloud of Chriſte, are called by diuerſe auncient fathers, myſteries, and yet notwithſtanding they be ſacramēts. For euery ſacrament is a myſterie, and this worde Sacrament and myſterie do not ſo farre differ, but that, that which is a myſterie, may alſo be a ſacrament. Mary euery myſterie, is not a ſacrament in the propre ſignificatiō: So that yf matrimonie muſt be no ſacrament, becauſe it is a myſterie, then baptiſme and the ſacrifice of the body and bloud of Chriſte be no ſacraments: for they are myſteries, and ſo we ſhall haue (as I ſaied) neuer a ſacrament
left ſhortly. Such is the drift of the deuil. To this anſwer, this quareller made no replye in the world, but thought it beſt to ſcoffe it out,Fol. 109. a and like a minſtrell make men laugh, with a mery mariadg ſolenniſed by the vicar of S. Fooles, betwene Maukyng and Daukin etc. M. Calfs. ſcoffe of Maukin and Daukin anſvvered. But yf Sir Iames, Calfhil, wilbe ſuch a calf ſtill, as to followe Caluin, then Calfhil, and Caluin, A Calf with a carrin, may daunce before Satin and like a dolt, and a dawkin, meete with Luther and his katrin, and ſimul & ſemel by the vicar of ſainct Folly, be maried to a furie, without ſacrament or myſterie.

The fourth reaſon why matrimonie ſhould be no ſacramēt is,Fol 109 a Calf. ſaieth he, becauſe it conferreth no grace. For he that is married, is not, in that reſpect more the childe of God, than yf he were vnmarried, he that is maried hath no peculier promiſes, that for his mariage ſake, his ſynnes are remitted him: and yet theſe are requiſite in a ſacramēt. For anſwer, I ſay, where I declared in my booke,Mart. that in matrimonie there is an inuiſible grace (that is to ſay) a gift of God, by which, they (that are maried) are made more ſtronger to ſuffer aduerſitie, more wiſer to inſtructe their children, and better able to reſiſte all corruption, and vnclenlynes, you ſhould (ſir) firſt haue diſproued theſe to be graces, and giftes of God, and than, haue ſaied, that in matrimonie, there is no inuiſible grace, geuen to the man and wife: but that was to hard meate for your ſucking teethe.Homi 20. in Geneſ▪ S. Chryſoſtome, counted it a great myſterie, and vnſpeakeable wiſdom, for a man to forſake his father that begotte hym, his mother that with payne brought hym into the world, Inuiſible grace geuen in the ſacramēt of matrimonie. and cleaue fast to a woman, which perchaunce he neuer ſawe before: and dare you ſay it is no grace? Againe euery honeſt man ſo tenderly loueth his wife, as his owne fleaſh, and ioyfully contenteth him ſelf with her company, all daies of his life, and departed his body to none other. Is this no grace? Beſides in all aduerſitie, he contynueth with her, in all ſicknes he cheriſheth her, and from all iniuries defendeth her, and ſo likewiſe the woman for her parte to the man. Is not this a ſpeciall gift of God? Yf it be geuen in matrimonie (as none haue that
ſpecially, but thoſe that are vnited together in matrimonie) why is there no grace conferred in matrimonie?

Furdermore, ſainct Paule ſaieth in this place,Heb. 13. that matrimonie is honorable in all thinges, and the bed vndefiled. In an other place: The womam ſhalbe ſaued by bringing foorth of children, 1. Tim. 2. yf they contynue in faith. Nowe yf matrimonie hath not a grace of God annexed, howe can the woman haue her ſaluation? Take away matrimonie, the act is vncleane, vſe it in matrimonie, as God hath ordayned, it hath his reward, and why? becauſe God hath geuen it his ſpeciall grace. To be ſhort, when God ioyned our firſt parentes together, the ſcripture ſaieth, benedixit illus Deus, ac dixit, Geneſ. 1. Creſcite & multiplicamini. God bleſſed them, and ſaied, increaſe and multiplie. VVhat was that? thankes geuing, prayſing or ſaying wel, according to your etimologie, M. Calf.? No: but Gods bleſsing, was a ſanctyfying of them, and geuing of a ſpirituall grace: whiche ceaſſed not in them, but flowed into all, to whome this precept of his increaſe and multiplie may extend. In S. Mathewe it is ſaied, whome God hath ioyned let no man ſeparate. Cap. 19. By whiche we may perrcaue that the man and wife, that come to gether in the feare of our lorde, are ioyned by God. And ſuch is his mercy, whom he ioyneth, he repleniſheth with his grace: wherbie it is euident that matrimonie hath an inuiſible grace of God annexed vnto it. But M. Calf ſaieth, he that is maried is no more the child of God in that reſpect than yf he were vnmaried. It is true: what then? Is Matrimonie therfore no ſacrament? or hath it no grace annexed vnto it? It followeth not.
