For like as yf the Quenes Maieſtie ſhoulde geue to the lorde mayor of Lōdon, an hūdred poundes by the yere, her liberalitie ſhould be alwaies counted a ſingular fauour, and ſpeciall grace albeit in that reſpect, he be no more the Quenes ſubiect than he was before: So is matrimonie an holy ſacramēt, although the maried is not in reſpect of his marriage more the childe of God than yf he were vnmaried. For as the prince extendeth not her liberalitie to the lord Maior, to make him more her ſubiect thā he was before, but to encoradge and able him, to do her grace better ſeruice, in that vocation: So God ordayned not this ſacrament
of matrimonie, to make the married man more the childe of God, than, when he mas vnmaried, but to able him by his grace to liue in that ſtate honeſtly, and ſerue to the increaſe and generation of children to the honour of God, ſo long as he woulde haue men to lyue vppon the earth.

Calf.Againe to proue that matrimonye is no ſacrament M. Calf. ſaieth, he that is maried hath no peculier promiſe, that for his mariadg ſake his ſynnes are remitted, and yet theſe thīges are required in a ſacramēt: Maat. where note good readears that he paſeth not what he ſayeth, ſo he blinde mens eies with ſome gay coloured wordes. For what if thoſe thīges be required in a ſacrament? ergo be they required in all ſacraments? It is no good argument. For albeit baptiſme hath a promiſe of remiſsion of ſinnes annexed vnto it, yet it is not neceſſarie that euery ſacramēt haue that ꝓmiſe. It is ſufficiēt that accordīg to their diuerſe effects,VVhere hath the ſupper of our lord a promiſe of remiſſiō of ſynnes M. Calf.? Ioan. 6. they haue diuerſe graces of the holy Ghoſt, alwaies following. Yf euery ſacrament hath a promiſe of remiſsion of ſinnes annexed, and that can not be a ſacrament, which hath not the promiſe of remiſsion of ſinnes annexed, what ſhall we ſay of the ſupper of our lord? VVhere will the proteſtants proue in all ſcripture that a promiſe of remiſsion of ſynnes is annexed to this ſacrament? Yf they tell vs out of S. Iohn: Yf a man eateth of this bread, he ſhall liue for euer, we will ſay vnto them out of S. Paule: He that eateth and drinketh vnworthely, eateth and drinketh his owne iudgement not diſcerning the body of our Lord. So that remiſsion of ſynnes is not promiſed to a man, becauſe he is made partaker of this ſacrament: his ſynnes muſte be remitted before, and he him ſelf in fauour with God, before he preſume to come, to this Sacrament, otherwiſe he ſhall not only not haue remiſsion of ſynnes, but he ſhall haue a terrible iudgement alſo, and greater heape of damnation. And if there be a remiſsion of ſynnes, thē is it a ſacrament propitiatorie,M. Calf. proueth the ſupper of our lord no ſacrament. contrary to your owne doctrine. Yf it be not, then haue you founde a ſacrament that hath no promiſſe, of remiſsion of ſynnes annexed vnto it, and ſo conſequently make it no ſacramēt. For yf that be no ſacramēt which hath no remiſsion of ſynne promiſed vnto it, as baptiſme hath,
certes, this can be no ſacrament: and ſo of two ſacraments by this reaſon the proteſtants will leaue them ſelues but one, and not that neither, yf their definition of a ſacrament may ſtād, as I ſaied before. Thus they faulle from errour to errour, from abſurditie to abſurditie, whiles they forſake the true determination of Chriſts catholicke churche.

As for the fiue abſurdities which M. Calf. hath noted in popiſh doctrine, touching matrimonie, I differre to ſpeake of thē here, only this I ſay, he hath as abſurdely demeaned him ſelf in treating of them as the aſſe did in his lyons ſkinne. In the laſt of them he ſclaundreth the church, and cōtrolleth that which neuer honeſt man thought woorthy of reprehenſion, and mayntayneth a notable errour, by which the whole ſtate of cōmon weales ſhalbe diſordred, that is, that a man may put away his wife for fornication and the woman refuſe her huſbād, Fol. 111. a Apoſitiō of M. Calf • cōtrary to ſcripture. Matt. 19. Vide Augu. de adulter. cōiug. ad Pollēt. 1. Cor. 7. vpon like cauſe, and yet marry an other: which is expreſſely againſt the Ghoſpell of Chriſt, and preaching of the holy Ghoſt. For Chriſt ſaieth: VVhoſoeuer forſaketh his wife, except it be for fornication, and marieth another, he cōmitteth adultrie: and he that marrieth the woman that is ſo forſaken committed adultrie. The holy ghoſt teacheth by S. Paule, that neither the man muſt forſake his wife, nor the wife go away from her huſband. Yf ſhe fortune to goe away from her huſband (which is neuer permitted, but in caſe of fornicacion) S. Paule willeth her: Manere innuptam aut reconciliari viro. To contynue vnmaried or els to be reconciled to her huſband: which being true, howe can he that deuorceth an adulterous perſon,He that putteth avvay an adulterous perſon cā not marry another vvhile ſhe lyueth. Acto. 10. marry another? S. Paule ſaieth yf the woman forſake her huſband (which ſhe can not do but fornication) ſhe is commaunded by god, either to remayne vnmarried, either to be recōciled to her huſband, and yf the woman being giltleſſe, and innocēt, is bounde by the lawe of God not to marry, yf ſhe forſake her huſband for fornication, ſhall not the man be bounde in like ſorte to contynue vnmarried, yf he put away his wife for like occaſion? Is God, Acceptor perſonarum? An acceptour of perſons? Shall the weaker and frayler veſſell be bounde to cōtynue vnmarried,
and ſhal the mā whome reaſon and wiſdome ſhoulde more rule, be ſet at libertie? No M. Calf: There is no reaſon in it. The lawe that bindeth one, bindeth the other. But we may ſee howe lewdly you wreſt the ſcriptures, to mayntaine the ſenſuall luſtes of ſome fleaſhlie brothers, but let vs go forward.

That you will haue penaunce, to be no ſacrament, that you followe Caluin and counte it blaſphemous ād abhominable to haue it called the ſecond table after ſhipwracke, Fol. 111. a and ſo conſequently the authour of that doctrine, a blaſphemous and an abhominable man,In cap. 3. Eſai. & epiſt. ad Demetri. who was no worſe, than S. Hierome, what ſhal I ſay? VVhen S. Hierome tranſlated the epiſtle of Epiphanius againſt images (as you thinke) and gaue no ſignification that he miſliked it, then S. Hierome was a Cardinall, and a ſainct Canoniſed, nowe he calleth penaunce the ſecond table after ſhipwrack,M. Calf. accōpteth S. Hiero. a blaſphemous and an abhominable man. he is a blaſphemous and abominable man. Alas ſir howe hath S. Hierome offended you, that you ſhould prefer Caluins iudgement, and your owne before his? Yf penaunce be not the only way and meane to raiſe vs vp againe, when we fall, after baptiſme, tell vs howe we ſhall riſe? VVe ſynne dailie, and therfore we muſt haue ſome meane to wype away our ſynnes, and reentre into fauour with God daily?Fol. 118. a Are we bounde to call our baptiſme to remembraunce, whenſoeuer we ſynne, that by the promiſe exhibited in baptiſme, the ſynfull ſoule may be refreſshed and penaunce out of it gathered, as you ſaye, thereby to exterminate the ſacrament of penaunce? VVhere is this in ſcripture? Yf it be neceſſarie to ſaluation, ſome Apoſtle or Euangeliſt muſt nedes haue ſpecified it after your doctrine?Some thinge neceſſarie to ſaluation not founde in ſcripture, by the proteſtants doctrine. Chriſt that ſo tenderly loued vs, the holy Ghoſt that ſo wiſely inſpired the Apoſtles, to inſtruct vs, would not omitte ſo neceſſarie a poynt of doctrine. Yf it be no where to be founde in ſcripture, and yet in the proteſtantes fanſies neceſſarie to ſaluation, then by their owne poſition, there is ſome thing neceſſarie to ſaluation, and yet not to be founde in ſcripture, but alas: Aſpis a vipera mutuatur venenum. Calfhil hath ſucked, this dragges out of Caluins drugges, as farre wide from all ſcripture, and reaſon, as
eaſt from weaſt, and North from South. God by the Prophet cried vnto the ſynfull people:Ioel. 2. Turne vnto me in weeping and wayling. Chriſt him ſelf cried: Do penaunce the kingdom of God is at hand. Matt 4. S. Iohn Baptiſt in like ſorte preached,Matt. 3. and willed vs to do the woorkes and fruictes of penaunce, and not to ſay we haue Abraham for our father. Likewiſe the Apoſtles cried: Poenitemini, repent. Acto. 3. Cap • . S. Iohn the Euangeliſt in his Apocalypſe, willed the angel of Epheſus to remember whence he fell and to do penaunce, and woorke the woorkes that he did firſt. And what is it to doe penaunce? to call our baptiſme to remembraunce, as M. Caluin and Calfhil ſaye, minding thereby to exterminate the ſacrament of penaunce? A propre definition nor founde in ſcripture, councel, nor auncient father, theſe fouretene hundred yeres, but wicked and heretical, and therefore worthie to be cōtemned, with the authours of it. Other thinges, you bring againſt this ſacrament.

As that abſolution ſhould be the ſacrament, Calf. Fo. 112▪ a. b and not penaunce, that confeſsion is to no purpoſe, that contrition of heart, ſuffiſeth to remiſsion of ſynne, that the churche ſhould teache that euery thefe, murderer, and adulterer hath cleare remiſsiō of his ſynnes although he neuer repent, that it requireth a viſible element, but ſo farre vnlike a diuine,Mart. and one that pretendeth ſkill in the fathers, that wiſemen, thinke it more meter to laughe at yow, than anſwer youe. To talke of all thoſe requireth a large treatiſe, whiche I omit becauſe it is not incident to my purpoſe. They that are deſirous to ſee it largely handled, may reade Hoſius confeſsion, and other late writers.

That whiche yow ſpeake of extreme Vnctiō,Fol. 113. a as that oyle cā not entre into the ſoule, Howe fond is it? Yow might aſwell require it to be proued that water entreth into the ſoule in baptiſme. For as remiſsion of ſynnes is geuen in baptiſme, as ſone as the water hath waſhed the body, and the miniſter pronounced Chriſts wordes: So is remiſsiō of ſuch ſynnes as Chriſt would haue remitted by vertue of this ſacramēt geuē, as ſone as the body is anoynted. Againe that prieſts anoynt euery ſicke body, Calf. Fol. 113. a. and none are the better, that biſshops (who are prieſts) haue not
commiſsion to caſt ont diuells, to cure diſeaſes, to cleanſe lepres and to rayſe the dead. That prieſts mocke the holy Ghoſt, and make the body the greſier for the graue, that we come not by our wills to the ſicke vntill the laſt gaſpe, that we admitt but one alone, or none but prieſts when the ſacrament is miniſtred, Mart. what vayne lyes be theſe? All that are of any experience can controlle yow of vntruth in al theſe, and diuerſe others as ſhall apeare hereafter?

Fol. 114 b Galf. Mart.VVhere you cōclude, that extreme vnctiō is no ſacramēt, becauſe it is not a ceremonie inſtituted of God, and delyuered vs, nor hath a promiſe of grace that concerneth vs, Let me aſke you this queſtion.Proteſtāts denying extreame vnctiō to be inſtituted of God, denie the holy Ghoſt to be God. Cap. 5. Is the holy Ghoſt God, or is he not? Yf he be God, then was this ſacrament and ceremonie of extreme Vnctiō inſtituted of God. For the holy Ghoſt infuſed plentifully vpon the Apoſtles, and ſpeaking nothing, but that whiche he heard of Chriſte, did ordayne by the bleſſed Apoſtle. S. Iames, that ſick mē ſhould be anoynted by the prieſt, and haue praier made ouer thē. Examine the woordes: S. Iames ſaieth, Is any man ſicke amō geſt you? Let him bring in the prieſts of the churche, and let them pray ouer him, anoynting him with oyle: Is not here a plaine inſtitution and ordinance of the holy Ghoſt? Is not inducat, let him bring in, the imperatiue mode, which biddeth and commaundeth? and doth not (orent) let them pray, ſignifie alſo a cōmandement? VVhat reaſon haue you to the cōtrarie? Shewe it yf youe cā. As for the promiſe of grace,A promiſe of grace. doth it not followe ſtreitwayes? And yf he be in ſynnes, they ſhalbe for geuen him? Is not remiſsioa of ſynnes a grace with you M. Calf? Be not theſe the woords of the holy ghoſt in the Apoſtle S. Iames? Yf yow acknoweledge them to be the woordes of the holy ghoſt, and cōfeſſe the holy ghoſt to be God and allowe remiſsion of ſynnes, to be an inuiſible grace of God, then muſt yow graunte, that extreme vnction is a ſacramēt inſtituted of God, and hath a promiſe of grace annexed vnto it?

Calf.Touching your fanſie that S. Iames woulde haue it to be tē porall, Mart. and not paſſe the preſent ſtate, we tell you, that the expreſſe commaundement of God, may not be illuded with ſuch
fond ſurmiſes. VVe haue it put indefinitely, as a precept to continue for euer, without all lymitation of tyme. Yf you will haue it but temporall, ſhewe vs the commadement? Shewe vs as good euidēce out of ſcripture againſt it, as we ſhewe you for it. Or yf you haue no ſcripture in ſtore, ſhewe vs ſome generall coūcell: ſome aunciēt father: ſome decre of the See Apoſtolik.

Yf yow can ſhewe none, (as I am aſſure you can not) why crake yow ſo impudently, that youe haue reaſon, Calf. and ſcripture for youe, Fol. 114. b with the lerned and ſounde determination of moe fathers of the churche, Mart. than were at the councell of Florence and Synode of Trent? Youe haue not alleadged ſo much as one councell, nor one father: nor haue any to alleage, but frier Luther that married Mouncke, and Caluin that louſie Lorrell, of Geneua, and ſuch Apoſtatats as haue followed thē and kept their cōſpiracies agaīſt the church and ſpoyled it, as apeareth in a litle oratiō, made agaīſt the inſurrectiōs and outrages of heretikes ād lately tranſlated in to Engliſh. VVherefore what ſhall p̄uaile? ſcripture, or no ſcripture? Gods woorde, or mens willes? True councells, or falſe cōſpiracies? holy fathers, or rennegate friers? Catholike biſhops, or violent vſurpers? fonde talke or ſadde proufe? Yf all the durtie termes which frier Luther vſed were leyed in a heape, and all the filthy woordes that baudy Bale diſgorged, were brought together, and all the vilanous phraſes, ſlanders, Tauntes, that Melanchtō, Illiricus, and Montanus, and all the rable of ſuche raging rufflers had oft in their mouthes, were conueyed with a gliſter pype into your rayling breaſte M. Calf., you ſhould neuer be able to diſgrace that honorable councell, which was kept of late in Trent. It was ſummoned by the head of Chriſts churche in earth.The coū cel of Trent. It was kept by true and laufull biſshops. It was aſsiſted by the Emperour, and mightieſt kinges in Chriſtendome. It was honored with the Legates, and Ambaſſadours of al catholike princes. The fathers there aſſembled out of Italie, France, Spaine, Portugalle, Pole, etc. Flādres, Brabant, Henalt and Artois, were lerned biſshops, well nigh to the numbre of 2. hundred, beſides many Doctours of Diuinitie,
and lawe, diuerſe of the ſocietie of Ieſus, generalls of all religions, men profoundly lerned in the depe pointes of Diuinitie, and not be witched,Fol. 115. a with the ſorcerie of Cyrce, nor called, to a trough of draffe, (as it pleaſeth ſuch a well nurtered gentleman to terme it) but required to come together to debate theſe controuerſies of religion for the ſtay of Chriſten people, and ſuppreſsion of hereſie, and being there aſſembled, they examined the growndes that all heretikes builde on, and tried them to the vtter moſte. And becauſe all proteſtants ſhould haue acceſſe thither, and diſpute freely, and propounde what they could, for mayntenāce of their newe religion,Safe conduicte offred the proteſtāts they gently required them to be preſent, they offred ſafe conduict to come, and go, to tarry, returne when they would? yet not one of all your ſect durſt apeare, and ſhewe his face, no, not your great idol of Geneua, and that as the worlde may well iudge conſcientia imbecillitatis, for conſcience of their owne imbecillitie and weaknes.

VVhen they could not procure any proteſtants thither to defend their poſitions, they aſsigned ſome, who after the manner of all ſcholes, ſhould diſpute for both partes, and after long and mature deliberation, they concluded by the aſsiſtaunce of the holy Ghoſt, whoſe preſence and grace Chriſt promiſed to al ſuch cōpanies, aſſembled in his holie name, the decrees which you ſee.Matt. 18. Amongeſt which this is one, that there be ſeuen Sacraments in Chriſts church, as Baptiſme, Confirmation, the Supper of our Lord,Seſsio 7. Can. 1. holy Orders, Matrimonie, Penaunce, and extreme Vnction. VVithal they accurſed all that defende and mayntayne the contrarie. VVhich curſe will light vpon you, make as light of it as you can. For Gods woordes muſt be true, ſpoken to Peter:Matt. 16. Quic quid ligaueris ſuper terram, erit ligatum & in coelis. VVhatſoeuer thou bindeſt in earth, ſhalbe bounde in heauen. They haue tyed you in the terrible band of excommunication vpon earth, doubt you neuer a deale, but ye are tyed. They are the body of Chriſtendome, the Pope is the heade: They both make one churche, and beſides this church, there is no other churche:Mat. 18. yf you heare not this churche, Chriſt ſaieth: You are an Heathen and Publican, and ſo conſequētly an heretike. VVherfore
in contemning the church, and diſpiſing the orders of generall councells, yf there were nothing els, you ſhewe your ſelues to be heretickes. In all ages and all cuntries hetetikes euer more, and none but heretikes, haue refuſed to yeld to the generall councells, quorū ſaluberrima in Eccleſiis est authoritas. VVhoſe authoritie is very holſome in the church, ſaieth S. Auguſtine.Auguſt. epiſt. 118. The Arriās refuſed the councel of Nice. The Macedoniās the coūcel of Conſtantinople. The Eutichians the councell of Chalcedon.None but heretiques refuſe general councells The place of Hilariꝰ lib. 8. de Trinit. applied to heretikes. Image breakers, the ſeuēth of Nice, and you the coūcels of Florēce, and Trent. VVherefore the ſaying of Hilarius, againſt Auxē tius, may welbe applied vnto you. For as he kept conuenticles againſt Hilarius, ſo do you againſt the church. As he called him hereticke, ſo do you the catholikes. As he purchaſſed him the diſpleaſure of noble men, ſo do you labour aſmuch as you cā, to bring vs in hatred, with the prince. As he deſpiſed the councell of Nice: So do you not only contemne the councel of Florence and Trent, but that of Nice alſo, and al other generall coū cells that were euer kept in ſuch poynts as they make againſt your errours. You haue reuyued diuerſe hereſies that they cō demned. Therfore, as he ſaied: Diabolus eſt quia Arrianus eſt, he is a deuil becauſe he is an Arrian: So we may ſay he is a diuell, becauſe he is a Caluinian. For as they contēned the churche, and rebelled againſt God: euē ſo do youe. That ſaying of Hilarius, many there are which fayning a faith, are not ſubiect to faith, and rather do apoynte them ſelues a faith, than receiue a faith: puffed vp with the ſenſe of much vanitie, whiles they ſauour thoſe thinges, as they liſt, and will not ſauour thoſe thinges that be true: whereas this is the truth of wiſdom, ſome tymes to ſauour thoſe things, which thoue wouldeſt not: but the talke of folly followeth this will wiſdome. For neceſſarie it is, fooliſhly to be vttred, that foliſhly is vnderſtode, That I ſay, may woorthely be returned vpon you, and all proteſtants.Heretikes fayne a faith vnto them ſelues. For you are they that fayne vnto your ſelues, a faith neuer heard of before Luther, and his diſciples began to ſpred it abrode, for his bellies ſake: becauſe he and his conuentual brothers could not be preachers of a pardon.

Yow are they that wilbe ſubiect to no faith, no not to your owne, made at Auguſta, by the arche heretiks and chief apoſtatats
of your religion. One faith muſt be preached at VVittenberg: an other at Zuriche an other at Lipſia, and other at Baſile, another at Geneua: ſo many Apoſtatats, ſo many Chriſtes, ſo many cities, ſo many faiths, ſo many cōgregations, ſo many goſpel. You are they that appoīt your ſelues a faith, ād receaue not that whiche your fathers receaued of their elders, and taught youe. You are they that are puffed vp with the ſenſe of humane vanity. You will beleaue no councels, nor auncient fathers. No man knoweth the ſcripture, no man hath the interpretation of the woord of God, no man hath the right ſenſe and meaning of the goſpell, and holy write, but you. The fathers were men and did erre, as men, youe are Sainctes and Angells: youe cā not erre, you cā not tred a wrye. The ſpirite doth ſo inſpire, that al that yow ſay is as true as ſteele and light of the goſpell. This is your opinion of your ſelues. As for the fathers, theſe thirtene hundred yeres, yow ſay they erred, they refuſed, the ſimplicitie of godds woorde: Fol. 96. a Chriſt had no church vntill a fewe renegate friers, and lecherous moūckes came and reſtored it againe. And whiles your heartes are infatuated with this arogācie, and pride, you ſauour what pleaſe your ſelues, and miſlike what ye liſt, you will not vnderſtande, thoſe thinges that be true, whiche is the occaſion that your talke is ſo fooliſh, your doctrine ſo diuerſe, and your preaching ſo diſſolute, and your writinges ſo ſclanderous, your bokes ſo blaſphemous.

As for the Catholiks they haue neither fayned nor made thē ſelues a faith, they contynue in that which they receaued of their forefathers, and can proue to come from Chriſt, by ſucceſſion, and lyneal deſcent, euen from S. Peter and Paule, to Pius the fyfth that ſitteth nowe by the mercifull prouidence of God in the Apoſtolike ſee of Rome. They be neither diſobedient to faith, nor to their laufull biſshops. They varye not in the principalle points of their religion and faith. In all churches, Cities, patriarkes, and biſshops, there is one vniforme concēt, through out the worlde, whereſoeuer Chriſtes, catholike church hath diſperſed her light. VVherfore, yf you will rightly apply Hilarius his woordes, and to good purpoſe, as he did, applie them to
heretikes, whoſe talke and peſtiferous doctrine, ſhould range and rage againſt the ſownde of Gods woorde:2. Tim. 2. And creepe like a canker, to the rote of the ſoule. Apply them as he did to ſuch as you are your ſelues: Homines mente peruerſi, & profeſsione fallaces, & ſpe inanes, & ſermone viperei. Mē corrupt in mynde, deceythfull in profeſsiō, vayne in hope, and adders in talke, men whiche force vs, of neceſsitie to gayne ſay your poſitions, becauſe vnder colour of religion, you teache the ſimple people (falſas doctrinas, & morbidas intelligentias, & corruptas voluptates. Lib. 8 de Trinit. in princip. •
Falſe doctrine lewde vnderſtanding and corrupt fanſies. For of ſuche, he ſpeaketh in the place whence you had thoſe woordes.

div.head: THAT THE APOSTLES AND FATHERS OF THE PRIMITIVE CHVRCHE BLESSED THEM SELVES, &c. THE FIFTH ARTICLE.
div.p:
IF it were graunted to be true that the Apoſtles and fathers of the primitiue churche did bleſſe them ſelues with the ſigne of the croſſe, and counſelled all Chriſten men to do the ſame, and that in thoſe daies a croſſe was ſet vp in euery place conuenient for it,Fol. 115. b M. Calf. ſuppoſeth that it woulde not hurt his cauſe: yet becauſe we ſhall vnderſtande that he, who
ſometymes came in ſilkes, veluetes, and great brauerie to Paules croſſe, when he was but a greene miniſter of this newe diuinitie, lacketh nowe no humilitie, he abaſeth him ſelfe to point-makers craft,Fol. 116. a M. Calfs. humilitie and taketh in hand the trying of three tagleſſe pointes, as he ſaieth. VVhich is a bolde enterpriſe of ſo younge a prentiſe, neuer broughte vpp in the facultie. His cunning will appere by his workmanſhip. The firſt pointe that he counteth tagleſſe is this. That the fathers of the primitiue churche bleſſed thē ſelues with the ſigne of the croſſe, for the terme of bleſsing (ſaieth he) is euill applied to the ſigninge in the forhead. Fol. 116. a Calf. For benedicere, to bleſſe, is to ſpeake well, and to lyue well. And that is the nature of the worde: in that ſenſe it hath bē taken of olde. Mart. Here is one euill pointe to begin with all. Crafte increaſeth dailie I ſee well. Yf to humilitie in abaſing him ſelfe to poyntmakers craft, he had ioyned ſimplicitie in ſtreatching out his leather, this poynt woulde haue ben ſtrōge ynough and lacked neuer a tagge. For benedicere, as I haue ꝓued before is ſtreatched furder,Article 4. Benedicere. 3. Reg 21. Iob 2. and applied to other ſignifications in the ſcripture, and doctours, than to thoſe three which maſter Calf. mentioneth. It was laied to Naboths chardge that benedixit Deum & Regem. Sathan, ſaied to God when he woulde furder plage Iob, Caſt thy hand vpon him, touche his face, and his fleſhe, and then thou ſhalt ſee, that, in faciem tuam benedicat tibi. VVhat is benedicere here, to ſpeake well, liue well, profeſſe well, as maſter Calf. ſaieth? No, it is quite contrary: to banne, to blaſpheme, and to curſe God.

It is written in Geneſis, that God benedixit diei ſeptimo. Dauid ſayeth:Geneſ. 2. Pſal. 84. Benedixiſti domine terram tuam. Howe ſhall this be Engliſhed? In which of the ſignifications that maſter Calf. deuiſed? Shall we ſay thus: God ſaied well to the ſeuenth day? Or thus, God profeſſed well to the ſeuenth day? or thus, God liued well to the ſeuenth day? or, God gaue thankes for the ſeuenth day? And ſo in the other, Shall we ſay, God ſpake well the earth? or God profeſſed well the earth? or God lyued well the the earth? or God gaue thankes for the earth? or what ſhall we ſay? Our newe poyntmaker ſaieth, that benedicere, is to ſpeake well,
profeſſe well, and lyue well, and ſtreatcheth his leather no furder, for feare of breaking in te midſt? ſhall we take his pointes? no, they be tagleſſe, and made of rotten calfs ſkinne. VVe muſt ſtretche it out a litle furder, and finde another ſignification for benedicere. Chriſt taking litle childrē in his armes,Marc. 10. Luc. 24. and leying his handes vpon them, benedicebat eos. Aſcending vp to heauen, in the ſight of his Apoſtles, lifting vp his hande benedixit eis. VVhat is benedicebat here? Shall we tranſlate it and ſay, Chriſt ſpoke wel the children, or Chriſt profeſſed wel the childrē, or Chriſt lyued well the children, or Chriſt gaue thankes for the children? and ſo likewiſe in the other? No: theſe are impropre ſpeaches, and phraſes not agreable to the letter, nor ſauoring of any good ſenſe in that place. VVherfore benedicere, muſt be ſtreatched on ynche furder to another ſignification, beſides maſter Calfhils, ſpeaking wel, lyuing wel, and profeſsing wel. And that is, Chriſt did bleſſe the children, Chriſt did bleſſe his Apoſtles, yea,Chriſt did bleſſe vvith his handes. Theophil. in 24. Luc. eleuatis manibus, with handes lifted vp) that is to ſay) Chriſt lifted vp his handes and bleſſed his Apoſtles: Perchaunce pouring (ſaieth Theophylact.) into them grace and ſtrenght that mighte garde them, vntill the holy Ghoſt came, perchaunce alſo inſtructing vs, that whē we go farre from home, we commend thoſe that are vnder our gouernement, to the heauenlie benediction. By which it is euident, that benedicere hath another ſignificatiō in the ſcripture, beſides to ſpeake well, profeſſe wel, ād liue wel, ād that is to bleſſe with the hād as Chriſt did. VVherfore he doth iniury to the eſtimatiō of his owne lerning to ſay, that this is a newe founde ſignification: Fol. 116. a and wrōge to thīke that we borowe this phraſe ād māner of ſpeach, either of olde mother Mawkin, or of a fooliſhe cuſtom. For benedicere, in this ſignification, is as olde as Iacob, who with his handes a croſſe bleſſed Ioſephs children, and as Autentick, as the Ghoſpell of S. Marke and Luke, who ſaied that Chriſt leyed his handes vpon children and bleſſed them, and lifting vp his hand bleſſed his Apoſtles.

But yf it had bene a common cuſtome to vſe that phraſe, and we had borrowed that manner of ſpeche of cuſtome, it is no point of wiſdome in M. Calf. to accōpte, that cuſtome fooliſhe; and holde them fooles that followe it. As wiſe as a man he is,
ſaied. we muſt ſpeake as the common ſorte doe, and thinke as the wiſe. And that cuſtome is to be followed, a better poete than he is diuine telleth vs, ſaying:
Multa renaſcentur quae iam cecidere, cadent
que ,
Quae nunc ſunt in honore vocabula, ſi volet vſus:
Quem penes arbitrium vis eſt & norma loquendi.
Many woordes that wythered be ſhall floriſh as the ſpring.
And ſuch as ſtand in high degree, vade as eche fayned thing.
Yf Lady Cuſtom doth ones take the exchange in to her hand.
For cuſtom hath a mould to make wordes currant in eche land.

VVherfore ſeing in this treatiſe I laboured to profite the multitude, whiche is miſerably deceaued by theſe newe miniſters, it was moſte neceſſary, for me to vſe the termes which commō vſe had made moſte familiar in their eares, and moſte liuely repreſented the thing it ſelfe vnto them. And albeit the olde fathers do not commonly vſe to ſay,To bleſſe vvith the croſſe. and ſigne hym ſelf vvith the croſſe is all one. benedicebant ſe ſigno crucis, they bleſſed them ſelues with the ſigne, but ſignabant ſe ſigno crucis, they marked them ſelues with the ſigne of the croſſe, yet do not I, very ill, (as M. Calf. ſaieth) in applyinge it, to the Apoſtles tyme and primitiue churche. For in effect they are all one, and as I may ſay, Synonima: For he that after the vſe of a Chriſten man, marketh him ſelf with the ſigne of the croſſe,Lib. 2. hiſtor. Apoſtolic. Lib. 3. bleſſeth him ſelf, and he that bleſſeth him ſelf, marketh him ſelf with the ſigne of the croſſe. VVherfore ſeinge Abdias reporteth that S. Paule crucis ſigno ſe muniens, arming him ſelfe with the ſigne of the croſſe, held out his necke to the hangemam, and that S. Andrew, ſingulis manus imponens & conſignans cruce, Lib. 5. leying his handes vppon euery one, and ſigning thē with the croſſe, ſuffred them to departe, and that S. Iohn, Armauit ſe ſigno crucis, Armed him ſelfe with the ſigne of the croſſe, no wiſe man can take it otherwiſe, than that they bleſſed them ſelues, with the ſigne of the croſſe, nor thinke contrary but that this croſſebiter is very quarreling, who knowing the thing to be one, will yet contentiouſlie iarre aboute the woorde. But like doctour, like Doctrine. He is alwaies denying the authoritie of the fathers, when he hath no cauille in ſtore to ſhift it away: but
ſeing he ſaith no more here againſt Abdias, than he did before, do ye credit him no more than ye did before. Semel malus ſemper praeſumitur malus, he that is ones euill, is p̄ſumed to be alwaies euil (ſaith the lawe,) vnleſſe the contrary be proued,Denying authorities M. Calfs beſt refuge. Fol. 116. b and that will not M. Calf. do. For lying ad denying muſt be his beſt defence, and Aiax ſhilde in this ſkyrmiſh. Euen in the laſt ſentence, Abdias was denyed, as a very lyer and forger of fables, nowe that wich is brought out of S. Clemēt, is refuſed as an authoritie that hath no credible authour to ſupporte it. Ibidem. So bring what ye can, either the authour ſhalbe refuſed, or his woorke denied.

As for S. Clement that he is an authour ſufficient to ſupporte him ſelf, and writer of the Apoſtles conſtitutions, the preface ſet before his worke, doth ſufficientlie proue to any reaſonable man, neither all the witte that M. Calf. hath, is able to conuince it of forgery: That he will not fullie beleaue S. Clemēt, Ibidem. becauſe he ſucceded not immediatlie, after S. Peter, according to his appointment, but ſuffred Linus and Cletus to occupie the roome before him, and ſcoffeth at his modeſtie in that behalfe, I meruail not. A leſſer cauſe than that, will make him beleaue, as a great many proteſtantes did, and let not to put in print, that S. Peter was neuer at Rome. But what matter is it yf he do not beleaue, nor fully, nor in parte? It hīdreth this cauſe no more thā the in credulitie of Caiphas, and lacke of faith in Pilate, did hinder the veritie of Chriſts incarnation in earth, an equalitie with his father in heauen. The Euangeliſtes them ſelues yf we take the bare letter do not agree exactely in the hower, that Chriſt ſuffred death. Yet being wel vnderſtode they agre both in the tyme, and the māner of it. So albeit all the fathers that haue written, do not agre of the manner and order of biſshops, that ſucceded S. Peter, yet the truth is confeſſed by all, and not withſtanding, S. Clement did of humilitie and modeſtie yelde the prerogatiue, to Linus and Cletus, whiles they lyued, yet do they acknowledg that S. Clement was ordained by S. Peter to be his ſucceſſour. As he that liſteth to ſee the truth of this, may reade, Damaſus of the biſshopes lifes and Baptiſt Platina that wrote of late.

VVhere M. Calf ſaieth that, the fact of S. Anthonie, S. Martin, Fol. 116. b and Donatus of Euoria Epiri, bleſsing them ſelues with the ſigne of the croſſe, being men of great holines and vertue, and ſo highe in fauour with God, that in their life tyme, they did many miracles,Fol. 117 a and the example of Paula a moſt godlie woman bee not preſidents to enforce imitation, it were to be wiſhed that ſome good phiſitiō, would feele his pulſe, ād trie his humour, that we might know of whome he woulde haue p̄ſidēts to be takē,Heb. 6. Examples of vertue to be takē of holymen. yf not of holie mē. S. Paule writing to the Hebrues, whyſſeth thē not be ſlouthful followers of thē, that ſhal inherite the ꝓmiſes. By which it is euident that the holy Ghoſt, woulde haue the examples of holie men to be followed, as directories to vertue, and as preſidents to force an imitation in godlines of life.

As for bleſsīg with the croſſe I did not teache, that the exāples of thoſe holie fathers did force an imitation, but only ſhewed that thy did ſo, and that it is lauful for vs by their exāples, being holy mē, and in great fauour with God, to bleſſe our ſelues, and vſe the ſigne of the croſſe, in temptations and other dangers, as thoſe holy fathers did, and that the cōtempt thereof is abhominable:Fol. 116. b And albeit it pleaſeth m. Calf. to terme thes hiſtories, but tales, and condemne S. Hierome, Sulpitius Seuerus and Sozomenus, as reporters of idle tales, and not writers of true hiſtories, yet I doubt not but the indifferent of his owne ſect, will blame his impudencie, for ſo iudging of ſuch lerned and renōmed writers.

Calf. Mart.VVhere he ſaieth: The deuill delited in the croſſe, and fayned him ſelfe to be a fraied of it, that the Eremite might runne to that ſory ſuccour, and men put more affiance in it, it is to childiſh for litle coknells that runne vp and downe the ſtreates,The diuel fayneth not feare at the ſight of the croſſe but feareth in deede. with tūbrells and rattles. That the deuill pretēdeth not feare, but is a frayd in deede at the ſight of the croſſe, I haued declared before, but furder to adde ſomwhat, when Iulian the Apoſtata had by vertue of that ſigne, dryuen the deuills away, the coniurer vnderſtanding it blamed him for it. And whereas Iulian for excuſe ſignified that he was in great feare, and woundred at the vertue of the croſſe, the ſorcerer ſaid vnto him: do not
thinke Sir, that they feared as you ſay, but they diſdained this ſigne rather, and ſo departed: The gentils as Lactantius telleth, perceauing that the Chriſtians, impoſito frontibus ſigno, putting the ſigne of the croſſe to their forheades, droue their Gods away from their ſacrifice, ſaied, that their Gods fled away, non metu, ſed odio: not for feare, Lactā. lib. 4. cap. 17. de vera ſapient. but for hatred. Maſter Calf. agreing with thē in one poynt, ſaieth: That the deuill fleeth not away at the ſight of the croſſe for feare, but whereas the coniurer ſaied that the deuill fled away for diſdaine, and the gentils ſaied that he fled away for hatred, he knowing more of his counſell then either the coniurer or gentils, ſaieth, that he fleeth away, as it were for loue or delight that he had in the croſſe, therby to allure men to vſe it:M. Calf. ſhevveth hym ſelf more priuie to the diuels counſel, than the coniurer or the gē tills. which is a ſtraunge caſe and much like to the comicall poetes fanſie, where he ſaieth: Credo quia miſera prae amore hunc excluſit foras. I ſuppoſe, poore woman ſhe ſhut him out of dores for loue. Yf one that loueth muſicke wel, and deliteth to heare mē ſinge, and play vppon muſicall inſtrumentes ſhoulde come in place, where there is a ſwete noiſe, and ſodēly runne away, whē the beſt melody is made, woulde any wiſe mā thinke that he ranne away for loue that he beareth to muſicke, or delight that he hath in muſicall inſtrumētes? No I ſuppoſe. Euery thing liketh to be where it loueth, and neuer fleeth that in which it deliteth. For it is naturall. VVherefore yf the deuill loued the ſigne of the croſſe, and delited to haue it made, as M. Calf. ſaieth,Fol. 117. a he would be ſtill where it is, and not alwaies flee away, when it is made, albeit he might ſometymes pretend a flight, to doe it, for a furder miſchieffe, but be he Iewe, be he Turke, be he a Iuliā, or be he a Iudas that maketh the croſſe, vnleſſe God geueth him vp to the deuill as a pray, the deuill fleeth away ſtill, whenſoeuer he ſeeth it, muche leſſe he maketh it (as this quarreller blaſphemouſlie reporteth, a cauſe of furder ſicknes, Fol. 117. a a ſtone of offence, a ſtumblinge blocke to fall at.

S. Anthony, of whom we talke, knowing the ſubtiltes and craftes of the deuill, and withſtanding them all,Fol. 117. a and ſo withſtanding them that he vpbraied, the wicked ſprites with their
weaknes againſt hym,Athan. in vita S. Anthonij. ſaied boldlie (as Athanaſius reporteth) vnto them all: Yf ye are able to do any thinge, yf our lorde hath geuen you power againſt me, beholde here I am, deuoure me, being graunted vnto you. Yf ye can not, why do ye labour in vaine? For the ſigne of the croſſe, and faith in our lorde is an inexpugnāble wall for vs. In the ſame place, in the very next ſentence it is writtē, that the deuills treathning many thinges againſt S. Anthony, did gnaſhe their teethe becauſe their temptations had no effect, but were made vaine illuſions. VVhere it is to be noted that the deuill tempted not S. Anthony to make the ſigne of the croſſe in his forhead. For yf he had don ſo, then had his temptations taken effect: but Athanaſius ſaieth, it was a great torment to the deuill that: No effect followed their temptation.

Yf M. Calf. wil not beleaue this ſaying of ſo lerned a father, Let hym beleaue the deuil hym ſelf, confeſsing the ſame. It ſo came to paſſe that certayne wicked ſprites were rayſed vp, and commaunded by a cōiurer, called Theodas, to tempt a young prince to the luſtes of the fleſh, but they preuayled not. VVhen the coniurer Theodas vnderſtode that, he ſaied vnto them. O ye weake and wretched caytiffes, Damaſce. in hiſtor. Barlaā & Ioſaphat. howe are ye ouercomed of one boye? The wicked ſprites forced by the power of God, made anſwer, againſt their will and ſaied: we were neither able to abyde, nor behold the power of Chriſt, and banner of his paſsion, which they call the croſſe. Illo enim ſigno rediuimus eneruati, etc. For we returned weakned with that ſigne, and all the princes of the ayer, and rulers of darkenes fleing away are burnt with it. Before the young man was perfitely ſigned with that ſigne, we cumming furiouſly vpon him did diſquet him. But as ſone as he had called Chriſt to his help, and armed him ſelf with the ſigne of the croſſe, he perſecuted vs with anger, and made vnto hym ſelf a moſt ſure defence. Here is a playne teſtimonie of the deuils, that they feare the ſigne of the croſſe, and are weakened with it, and forced to flee away at the ſight of it. And this they confeſſe not of them ſelues, thinking as M. Calf. doth to deceaue vs: but they cōfeſſed, diuina virtute compulſi: compelled by the power of God, they confeſſed it, inuiti againſt their wills, and that which they cōfeſſed was the truth. VVherfore it hath no apparance that the diuel deliteth in the ſigne of the croſſe, or fayneth hym ſelf to be a frayed of it,
but he is a frayed in deede, and trembleth, and quaketh at it, and fleeth away for very feare. But you ſee what a patrone the diuel hath. Martialis writeth that the croſſe is a buckler beating back the dartes of the enemie. S. Auguſtine that it is,Epiſt ad burde gal. Ser. 19. de ſanctis. Libro 4. cap. 12. Demonſt. cōt. Gent. a let or ſtaye againſt the enemies. Damaſcene that is, a ſigne that the deſtroier touche vs not. S. Chriſoſtome, that is, a deſtruction of the deuill, a bridle of wicked ſprites, and bitte for contrary powers. A ſigne of much bleſsinge, and a wall of all kind of ſecuritie, and yet M. Calf. is not aſhamed boldlie to aſſeuere, without authoritie, and reaſon that the deuill deliteth in the croſſe, and maketh it a cauſe of Sicknes, a ſtone, of offence, Fol. 117. a and ſtumblinge blocke to fall at.

Diogenes was wounte to ſay vnto him, that talked buſely of heauenlie matters: Quando de coelo veniſti? Ah Sirrha when came you from heauen. In like ſorte we may aſke of our aduerſarie, that talketh ſo certainly of the deuils practiſſes, Quando de inferis redijſti, when came yow from hell ſirrha? For none but ſuch as haue bene of priuie counſell in Sathans courte, can tell theſe ſecrets. The lerned fathers neuer knewe any ſuch practiſe of his: yet had they as many conflictes with him, and as much experience of his ſubtilties, as any in this later age. And that might M. Calf. well vnderſtand, yf he woulde haue reade the life of S. Anthony written by Athanaſius, and other auncient fathers. But he will not: and therfore what ſhall we ſay of him, but as S. Auguſtine ſaied of the like, Euill men ar enemyes to them ſelues, by not vnderſtanding howe they may liue well: not becauſe they can not, In Pſal. 35 but becauſe they will not. For it is one thing, when euery man endeuoureth to vnderſtand ſomwhat, and through infirmitie of the fleaſhe can not, and an other thing when the hearte of man dealeth ſomwhat frowardlie, againſt him ſelfe: in ſo much that he can not vnderſtand, that whiche he might vnderſtande, yf he had a good will, not becauſe it is harde, but becauſe wil is wilfull and againſt it.

VVhere he ſaieth, that not withſtanding, Fol 117. a Calf. yf in the doinges of elder age there were no ſuch offence, yet conſidering howe thinges in tyme haue growen to abuſe and ſuperſtition, ſuch as haue bene tolerably receaued, muſt nowe of right, and conſcience
be condemned, VVe tell him that yf thinges, good of their owne nature muſt be taken away and condemned, becauſe of the abuſe, we ſhall haue nothing left to our comfort in earth. Yron is abuſed to murder, fier to burning other mēs houſes,The thinkge that is good, muſt not be taken avvay for the abuſe. water to vnlaufull drowning, the name of Ieſus to ſorcery, the Pater noſter to witchcraft, and makinge payles go amilking as he told vs before) and nothing ſo holie but the wickednes of man doth prophane, and abuſe. Shall the thinges therefore, be taken away? No M. Calf. The abuſe ought to be amended, and the thing ſuffred to remaine. Or yf it be expedient to haue the thing it ſelf taken away, let it be done in ſuch ordre as it ought to be done, and of ſuch perſons as the decree of Stephen (which you your ſelfe mention) require, who are as I proued before the biſshops of Rome, to whom God hath geuen the chardge and gouernement of his church on earth. But where you ſay, that the croſſe hath ben abuſed, and ſhewe no euident proufe of it, we tell you that you moſt impudentlye belye, and ſclander the church of God, and therin ſhewe, that your conſcience (is cauteriata, feared with a hotte yron, and hath no ſenſe at all. Neuertheleſſe, yf any ſhuld abuſe it, the abuſe ſhould be taken away by lauful auctoritie, and yet the ſigne ſuffred to remayne.

Fol. 117. b The place of Epiphanius anſvvered.As for the place, cited out of the epiſtle which you ſay: Epiphanius wrote to the patriarke of Hieruſalem, and S. Hierome trāſlated, what yf we ſhoulde denie that Epiphanius wrote that epiſtle? VVhat yf we ſhould ſay it is not be founde in his Greke copies, and for a probable coniecture, and vehement preſumptiō tell you that all the biſshops in Grece, that were image breakers neuer alleaged any ſuch epiſtle of Epiphanius, which had ben a great, ouerſight, yf either the epiſtle had ben his, or the place ſo manifeſtlie oppugned the vſe of images, as you pretend? Yea furder, what yf we ſhoulde denie that S. Hierome did tranſlate the epiſtle, and ſay as you do for diſproufe of other authours, that the ſtile ſauoureth nothing of S. Hieroms eloquence? Howe would you be able to proue it, or iuſtifie this
worke, in which ye triumphe as though you had gotten the victorie? You haue no antiquite for it. You haue no other teſtimonie in all his woorkes, to proue that he miſliked the vſe of images. In all his bookes againſt hereſies, he accompteth the hauing of images to be no hereſie.

And where you ſay on the contrary ſide,Fol. 78. a that he diſcourſinge vpon the ſectes of hereſies accompteth them for none that cōdemned images, there is good cauſe why. For in his daies there were no heretikes, that condemned images. Image breakers were not then out of their ſhell. But yf they had, he being a lerned man, and ſkilfull in the ſcripture, both vnderſtanding that no text through out the Bible doth inhibite the hauing of images, and alſo knowing that from the Apoſtles tyme, Chriſten men had the images of Chriſt and his ſainctes, and the Catholique biſshops neuer inhibited the vſe of them, he I ſay woulde vndoubtdly haue reported them, as condemned for wicked and accurſed heretikes, that condemned the vſe of images, yf any ſuch had bene either in, or before his tyme.

In the ſeuenth councel of Nice euery mā that can reade and vnderſtand may ſee that not only images were in churches in Epiphanius tyme,Actio. 6. Nice. 2. A churche a builded in Epiphanius name and decked vvith images. but alſo that his diſciples builded a churche to God in his name, and adourned the ſame with images and pictures: which they woulde not haue done, yf either their maſter had taught them that it had ben hereſie, or the fathers, and biſhops of that age had iudged it derogatorie to Chriſtes religiō. VVhich being ſo, it is euident that Epiphanius did neither miſlike the hauing of images, nor write any thinge that improued that doctrine. But let this epiſtle which you brag ſo much of be Epiphanius owne writing, let the tranſlation be S. Hieroms? VVhat maketh it for you? VVill you ſay Epiphanius, cut a vayle: habēs imaginem quaſi Chriſti vel ſancti cuiuſdam, hauing the image as it were of Chriſt, or of ſome ſainct, ergo he was an enemy to the image of Chriſt, and his ſainctes (as you note in your margēt?) I thinke your wiſdome wilbe better aduiſed:Fol. 117. b or yf you muſt of neceſsitie ſay ſo, or els conclude nothing of that notable place of Epiphanius
againſt images, tell vs, howe holdeth this argument, My Lord chamberlyn coming into the chābre of p̄ſence, and finding one ſitting in the princes ſeate, vnder the clothe of eſtate, quaſi reginam, as it were the Quene, thruſteth him out, and putteth him in priſon, for his trayterous preſumption, ergo my Lord chamberlyn is an enemy to the true Quene that ſhould ſitte there in deede? Let vs haue your anſwer ſpeadelie. And yf you thinke this argument naught, So thinke of your owne. For they be both like.The vayle rent of Epiphaniꝰ had not the image nor of Chriſt nor any Saīct. The image that was in the vayle rent by Epiphanius was not a true image of Chriſt, nor of any ſainct. It was, quaſi imago Chriſti vel ſancti alicuius, as it were the image of Chriſt or ſome ſaincte. Perchaunce the image of Iuppiter, or Hercules, or ſome man that liued in thoſe daies, as it pleaſed the painter. Epiphanius, remembred not whoſe image it was, but ſure he was that it was not the image of Chriſte, or any ſainct, but, quaſi Chriſti vel alicuius ſancti, as it were the image of Chriſt, or ſome ſainct.

VVherfor in renting and tearing that falſe image, he did the dutie, of a learned, wiſe, and graue biſshop, as the lord chamberlyn did the parte of a true, faithful, and truſtie ſubiect. He was no more enemie to the true image of Chriſt and his ſainctes, thā the other was to his ſoueraigne ladie, and natural princeſſe. For as he thruſt the traytour out of the roiall ſeate, that p̄ſumed to fitte there, Quaſi regina, as it were the Quene: So did Epiphanius rēt the vayle that had, imaginem quaſi Chriſti, the image as it were of Chriſt: and not the image of Chriſt in deede. As he bore faithfull heart to his true ſoueraigne ladie: So did Epiphanius to the true images of Chriſt and his Sainctes, as I declared before, whiche the woorde Quaſi, as though, yf nothing els might haue made your wiſdome conceaue.

2 Cor. 6.S. Auguſtine to make his heares vnderſtand theſe woordes of S. Paule,In Pſal. 48 Quaſi triſtes, ſemper ante gaudentes, as it were euer ſad but alwaies mery, ſaieth: Our ſorowe hath alwaies, Quaſi, an as it were, our ioye hath not a, Quaſi, an as it were, becauſe it is in ſure hope. VVhy hath our ſorrowe a, Quaſi, an as it were? Becauſe it paſſeth away as ſleepe: Your charitie knoweth, he that telleth a dreame, addeth, Quaſi an as it were. Quaſi dicebam, quaſi loquebar, quaſi prandebam, quaſi equitabā
quaſi diſputabam, Totum quaſi, qui cum euigilauerit, non inuenit quod videbat. Quaſi the ſaurū inueneram dicit mēdicus, ſi quaſi non eſſet, mendicus non eſſet, ſed quia quaſi erat, mendicus eſt, I ſaied as it were. I ſpooke as it were, I dyned as it were, I ryd as it were, I diſputed as it were. All is as it were, becauſe when he awaketh, he fyndeth not that which he ſawe: the begger ſaieth, I founde, a treaſure as it were. Yf as it were, were not, he were no begger. But becauſe there is, an as it were, he is a begger. So to make you to vnderſtand this place of Epiphanius, we tell yow, Si quaſi nō eſſet, Chriſti imago fuiſſet, ſed quia quaſi erat Chriſti imago nō fuit, yf there had not ben, an as it were, it had bē the image of Chriſt, but becauſe there was an as it were, it was no image of Chriſt, and being no image of Chriſt, nor ſainct, Epiphanius did well in rē ting, and tearing it, and nothīg againſt the true images of Chriſt and his ſainctes. the contrary whereof is not to be ſeene in all his worke.

Concerninge S. Hieroms tranſlation, ſeing the whole epiſtle vnderſtoode according to Epiphanius mynde, contayneth no doctrine contrary to the Catholike faith, no maruell yf he tranſlated it out of Greke into Latin. He had ſuch an earneſt zeale, and deſire to profite the church of God, that he ſpared no paynes, neither to tranſlate out of Hebrewe, nor Greke. But yf there had bene any vnſounde doctrine in that epiſtle, his tranſlating doth not argue a liking. Many a good man may trāſlate a worke at his frendes requeſt, out of one language into another that cōtaineth not all to gither ſounde doctrine, and yet be farre and wyde from allowing that doctrine. S. Hierome him ſelf, and Ruffinus tranſlated diuerſe woorkes of Origens, yet do they not allowe thoſe errours, which are obiected againſt him. VVherefore, ſeing there is nothing in Epiphanius that maketh againſt the images of Chriſte, and his ſainctes, ſeing S. Hierome interpreting that epiſtle neuer founde fault with that place, ſeing the image breakers aſſembled in Conſtantinople, neuer eſpied that place, or yf they did eſpie it, thought it not worthie to be obiected againſt the hauing of images, ſeing the three hundred and fifthye Catholike biſshops aſſembled at Nice for diſcuſsing the controuerſie moued againſt images, affirmed plainlie that there
is nothing in Epiphanius, writinges that gayne ſaith the laudable manner of the churche for the vſe of images, your triumphe is loſt.Paula. Fol. 118. b The fact of Paula can not be ſet againſt, the fact of Epiphanius (as you would haue it). There is no cōtraritie in them. She did nothing but that which beſeemed a vertuous matrone. He no more than was ſitting for an holy biſshop.Ephiphanius. She made the ſigne of the croſſe in her forhead: So did he, and confeſſed that with the ſigne of the croſſe,Lib. 1 cōt. Hebr. 2. and holy water, inchauntements, and diuels are dryuen away. She proſtrated her ſelf before the image of the croſſe, he neuer cutte the vayle that had the image of Chriſt, or any Sainct vpon it. She being learned and taught of S. Hierome, did according to reaſon worſhip the croſſe, as S. Hierome him ſelfe did,Apol. 3. as you may ſe in his epiſtle to Marcellina, and in his Apologie againſt Ruffinus. He neuer condemned it, nor knewe any religion, or ſcripture to be contrary vnto it. Therefore I will ſtill vrge the fact of Paula, vntill you proue out of Epiphanius by better euidence then you haue ſhewed yet, that he would haue no croſſe, Fol. 119. a no crucifix, nor image in the church: And this is my iudgmēt of your place brought out of Epiphaniꝰ.

Calf.VVhere you tell me that I reckon a ſorte that vſed of deuotion to make the ſigne of the croſſe in their forheades, but make no mention of them that vſed it not, in zeale as good as they, Mart. and in numbre moe, I beleaue verelie that there was neuer Chriſten man, of pure zeale, and ſincere mynde, that euer refuſed to bleſſe him ſelf with the ſigne of the croſſe. Reade all the aūciēt fathers that euer wrote ſythēs Chriſtes incarnatiō, kepe your Calēder as warely as you cā, make as perfect a regiſter as poſsible may be, and yf you finde any of them, ſaye that this man,A Calender to be made of Chriſten men that refuſed to croſſe thē ſelues and this man was a perfect Chriſtian, as feruent in zeale, and as good as Epiphanius, S. Anthonie, S. Hiero. and S. Auguſtine and did refuſe to bleſſe him ſelf, or ſigne him ſelf with the croſſe, or make the ſigne of the croſſe in his forhead. Put him in your Calēder, and when you haue founde out a numbre, bring them to light, ſhewe them forth, as I haue done: name the authours that mention them, note the bokes, and chapiters where
we ſhall finde them, and we ſhall ſay, ye haue kept your promiſe. But before you haue founde many ſuch, boaſt not of a nū ber nor crake of antiquitie, leſt yf you finde none, (as I am ſure you ſhall not till you come to frontike Fox his lying Calender) ye be founde a iacke bragger, and vayne boaſter.

Your poſition, non viuendum exemplis, ſed legibus: mē muſt not liue by examples, but by lawes, which you ſay taketh place in religion yf any thing doth, is not all together true.Fol. 119. a And yf I ſhoulde require you to finde it in ſcripture, you would be long in ſeeking, and in the end returne the write and ſay,1. Tim. 4. The exā ples of holy men to be follovved. Cap. 2. Cap. 5. non comparet. S. Paule writing to Timothe, ſaied vnto him: Be an example of the faithfull, in word, and cōuerſation, in charitie, in faith, in chaſtitie. Likewiſe to Tite: In all thinges ſhewe thy ſelf an example of good woorkes. S. Iames biddeth vs take the prophetes for an example of ſuffring aduerſitie, and patience. To be ſhort, S. Peter ſaieth: Chriſt hath ſuffred for vs, leauing you an example that you followe his ſteppes. And I pray you M. Calf. to what end did the holy Ghoſte require Timothe and Tite to be an example of good woorkes to the faithfull, yf he woulde not haue the faithfull to take example of them and frame their life according? To what end hath Chriſt left vs an exāple, but that we ſhoulde followe his ſteppes, and frame our liues as nigh as we can to his? Yf only lawes muſt be followed, and not examples, why ſaied S. Paule: Lex iuſto non eſt poſita, 1. Tim. 1. ſed iniuſtis? The lawe is not made for the iuſt man, but for the vniuſt and diſobedient? Howe ſhall he lyue? muſt he not take example of Chriſt, and his Apoſtles, and other holy mē that trodde in the pathe of holynes before hym, and come by imitatiō as nigh vnto them as he may? Yf it be ſo, then is your aſſertion vayne, foliſh, and friuolous. For we muſt lyue in ſome caſes, as well by examples as by lawes. For where there is no expreſſe lawe there examples muſt preuayle.

The lawiers (of whom you borrowe this rule, altred at your pleaſure) ſay: Non exemplis iudicandum, ſed legibus: Men muſt not iudge by examples, but by lawes, yet where the caſe is not determyned, nor decided by the lawe, they allowe cuſtomes and
examples.Examples and cuſtome to be follovved l. de quibꝰ ff. de l. The cuſtō of the citie of Rome a refuge vvhere lavves fayle For proufe whereof, we haue this lawe. De quibus cauſis ſcriptis legibus non vtimur, id cuſtodiri oportet quod moribus & conſuetudine inductū eſt, etc. As for the cauſes, in which we haue no writtē lawes to vſe) that muſt be obſerued, which was brought in by cuſtom and maner: And yf in any thing that fortune to lacke, then that muſt be kept which is next, and like vnto it, Yf that apeare not, then the lawe which the citie of Rome vſed, muſt be obſerued. An auncient cuſtom is not vnworthely obſerued for a lawe: And this is the lawe, which is ſaied to be receaued by the cuſtom, and manner of thoſe, that vſe them.

Here is ordre taken that when there cometh a ſtraunge caſe for which there is no lawe written, it muſt be decided by cuſtō and manner, and for defect of cuſtom, the iudge muſt procede by likelyhodes, and yf they fayle, he muſt ſtād to the lawes and cuſtomes of the citie of Rome. By which you may learne that for many caſes there is no lawe written, and that when there is no lawe written, men muſt iudge according to cuſtom. And yf iuſtice can not be miniſtred, nor iudgement geuen in wordly matters, for certayne caſes, but by the cuſtomes, examples and preſidents of other that went before, ſurely in ſpiritual matters, where there is no expreſſe lawe in ſcripture, the churche of God can not be mayntayned, vnleſſe we followe the cuſtomes, and preſidents of other, and lyue as our holy fathers did before vs.

Luther your firſt father was ſo farre wyde from this fonde opinion of yours, that he ſaied, a prince might better rule by the inſtinct of nature,In cap. Babylo. epiſt ad Pragenſ. than by orders and lawes. And in diuerſe places of his workes, it appeareth that the would haue the libertie of the goſpel, to put away al princes lawes. In whiche although he meaneth as wickedly, as you do fondly, yet you being but an ympe of his braunche pretending vnitie in doctrine, ſhould not haue reuolted from that your Apoſtata, and vppon no grounde of ſcripture,Fol. 119. a doctour, or reaſon haue concluded that in religion we muſt not lyue by examples, but by lawes. For euery wiſe ſeeth, that where there is no lawe, the cuſtom, manner, preſidēts and examples of others muſt ſtand for lawes. But to what purpoſe would maſter Calf. thinke you (goode readers) haue this
his poſition take place? Forſoothe, that when he had concluded that we muſt no liue by examples, but by lawes, he might make ſimple ſoules beleaue, that they ought not followe the exā ples of their holy forefathers, in bleſsing them ſelues, but to haue the name of the lawe in their mouthes and do nothing leſſe thā that the lawe biddeth them to doe. And to bring that to paſſe ſee howe he vvrangleth.Calf.

The fathers taught other thinges more oft, and more earneſtlie, than the vſe of the croſſe. As Tertullian taught that it was a wickednes to faſt on the Sunday, or to pray on our knees. Beſides, in his tyme oblatiōs were made at birth daies. milke and honny was geuen to the children at chriſtenninge. In S. Auguſtines tyme, infants receaued the communion, Becauſe vve do not obſerue all theſe ceremonies that are out of vſe, M. M. Calf. vvil not keepe that vvhich is in vſe. Mart. 1. Cor. 11. By M. Calfs reaſon S. Peter and S. Paule muſt not be credited. and diuerſe ſuche ceremonies were cōmaunded, which are nowe abrogated, and becauſe we do not obſerue al thoſe ceremonies, that theſe and other fathers ſpecifie, they will not follow this that they ſpeake of the croſſe: which hath no reaſon. For yf the diſvſe of ſome ceremonies vſed of olde tyme for good purpoſes, doth derogate authoritie in al other from the fathers, that make mention of anye ceremonies, S. Paule muſt not be credited in apoynting order for the ſupper of our lorde, for he maketh mention of a ceremonie then vſed, that men ſhoulde not pray with their heades couered, nor women with their heades vncouered, which is nowe gone out of vſe. For men praye with night cappes, on their heads, and women come open faced to churche, and maydes in their heare, in ſome places, eſpeciallie when they be married. S. Peter, yea and all the Apoſtles muſt be diſauthoriſed. For they made a lawe that non ſhoulde eate bluddings, or ſtyfled meate: for it is nowe gone out of vſe, no man accompte them ſelues bounde to the obſeruance of it, thought the Apoſtles all together aſſembled did make that lawe. But be not deceaued, although the foreſaied ceremonies that S. Paule ſpoke of, be gone out of vſe, and the decree of Peter and the Apoſtles be broken, yet ſtandeth their authoritie full and perfect in the diſpenſatiō of Chriſtes myſteries, and euery man is bounde
to followe it, and ſo likewiſe in the fathers. For the church hath authoritie to abrogate ceremonies and lawes, for orders and diſcipline, as the diuerſitie of tyme, place, and men require.

And although one or two be altred, the reſt muſt not be contemned, becauſe the church hath not ſo decreed, which prerogatiue yf heretickes had,Heretikes haue no authoritie to alter ceremonies. their alteration and changing of ceremonies, had ſome colourable ſhewe of pietie, but ſeing they haue no church, no laufull biſshops, no duly called miniſtres, they ought not to alter the leſt rite, and ceremonie in Chriſtes church. But yf they woulde be as they pretend followers of Chriſt, they ſhoulde kepe the vnitie of his church, and not ſeeke occaſion to condemne all that is vſed, becauſe ſome thinges are diſuſed that in olde tyme were vſed.

VVere it reaſon in a common ſtate of a citie, for priuate men to alter this and that ſtatute, of the whole corporation at their pleaſure? Or were it reaſonable for ſome one citizen to ſay, he will not kepe this ſtatute, becauſe they kepe not another ſtatute, that was made an hundred yeres before, and nowe abrogated? or gone out of vſe? No, as wiſe men thinke: And yf it be not permiſsible, in a citie, much leſſe is it to be ſuffred in the church and whole bodie of Chriſtendome.

Furdermore, wheras, M. Calf. refuſeth, to beleaue, Tertullian, Ephrem,Fol. 119. b Fol. 120. a Fol. 120. b Chriſoſtome, S. Hierome, Auguſtine, Cyrillus, and Prudentius, and other fathers, becauſe they had their errours and imperfections, and like a wicked Cham diſcouererh that which he knoweth, againſt them, and for lacke of errours obiecteth vndoubted truthes againſt ſome of them (as ſhall appeare hereafter) and yet woulde be ſeene to reuerēce thē, it is to be thought that he is ſo buſied with his Geneuian doctours, that he hath not ſo much as viewed the treatiſe of Vincentius Lirinenſis, againſt hereſies. For yf he had, he might eaſely haue ſeene, howe and in what ſorte, we are bounde to followe the doctours: but becauſe the booke is ſo chardgable that he can not bye it, and ſo longe that he hath no leyſure to reade it, I will for his furder inſtruction declare his iudgemēt, which all the church followeth preſently in this caſe. He inſtructing a yoūge ſcholler to auoyde
hereſies, moueth certayne queſtions, and anſwereth them. One is this.

VVhat yf ſome newe infection ſekeeth to corrupt, not one litle parte only, Vincētius Linnenſis counſel againſt hereſie. but the whole churche? The catholicke (ſaieth he) muſt prouide that he ſticke to antiquitie, which can not altogether be ſeduced with any deceithfull nouelitie. An other queſtion is this: VVhat yf in antiquitie it ſelf, the errours of two or three men, or els of a citie or prouince be founde? Then he muſt procure that he preferre, the decrees of the vniuerſall church, which were generally receaued of olde tyme. The thirde queſtion is this: VVhat yf ſome ſuch queſtion riſe, that we can finde no antiquitie, Hovve the aūciēt fathers muſt be credited. nor decree of the vniuerſall church for it? Then he ſhall imploye all diligence that he may, to conſult and aſke the iudgment of the forefathers, and compare them together, thoſe eſpeciallie, who although they liued in diuerſe ages, and places, yet continuing in the vnitie and faith of the catholicke church, were good maſters and teachers, and whatſoeuer he knoweth, that not one or two, but all together with one conſent did holde, write, and teache, openly, commonly, and continually, let him vnderſtand, that he muſt without all doubtyng, or ſtaggering, beleaue that: And for more clearer euidence of the ſame, I will adde another ſentence of his. In the ſame woorke, he hath theſe woordes.

VVhen the rottenneſſe of any euill errour beginneth to breake out, and ſteale the wordes of the holie lawe, and expounde them craftely, and deceithfully to the mayntenance of it, ſoorth with (ſaieth he) the expoſitions of the forefathers are to be gathered to gether, for vnderſtanding of thoſe ſcriptures, by which, that what ſoeuer it is, that ſhall ſpring vp, The expoſitions of the fathers to be gathred for the vnderſtā ding of ſcripture. being newe, and therfore prophame, may both be diſcouered without circumſtā ce, and alſo condemned without all retractation and delay: but the expoſitions of thoſe fathers onlye are to be conferred, who liuing holily, teachinge wiſelie, and continuing ſtoutely in the faith, and vnitie of the Catholicke church, deſerued either to die faithfullie in Chriſte, or to be martired happely for Chriſte. VVhome not withſtanding we muſt creditte with this condition, that what ſoeuer either all, or the moſte parte haue affirmed, with one aſſent, playnly, commonly, and continuallie, as it were by an agreing councell of their maſters, by receauing, keeping, and deliuering, VVith vvhat cō ditiō vve muſt creditte the fathers. the ſame we receaue and followe, as moſte vndoubted, certaine, and true. And whatſoeuer, any man be he neuer ſo holy, be he biſshop, confeſſour,
or Martir, Priuate opinions muſt be reiected. ſhall preſume to mayntaine otherwiſe, than all the reſt do thinke, contrary to all other, that muſt be deuided from the authoritie of the common, publike, and generall ſentence, and be adnumbred amongeſt propre, ſecrete, and priuate opinions. Thus much Vincentius a zelous father, more than a thouſand yeres a goe. By whiche we vnderſtand that the doctrine whiche the holy fathers, or the moſte parte of them taught generallie with one conſent, is to be imbraced, and followed. And that if any of thē had any priuate opinion, cōtrary to the truth, whiche was generallie receaued, that is no cauſe why they ſhoulde not be receaued in other thinges, where they agree with the teſt.

Seing then in the matter of the croſſe, nor Tertulliā, nor any other Catholik authour varieth from the reſt of the fathers, nor teacheth any other thing than his elders delyured, and our forefathers taught euer ſithēs, playnly, cōmonly, and continuallie with one conſent and vmformitie, there is no cauſe why either he, or any other doctour ſhould be refuſed, becauſe they had other priuate opinions.Proteſtāts diſcredite the fathers. And certes where you refuſe to followe their iudgment, in ſuche matters as they all agree vpon with one accorde, and are receaued generally of the churche, ye diſcredite them, as men that knewe not the ſcripture, and true interpretation of the ſame, ye like a iudg ſitting magnificallye in your throne of arrogancie diſauthoriſe them, as ignorants that knewe not light from darcknes, veritie from hereſie, true religion frō vaine ſuperſtition: you iuſtifie your ſelues, and preferre your owne iudgments before theirs. Ye eſtabliſh your traditions, and diſtroye theirs. Ye make men beleue that they tranſgreſſed the commaundemēt of God, to bring in a cuſtome, and deuiſe of their owne. For the which you ſhall neuer lacke the ſhameful note of pride and ſingularitie. For Vincētius (of whome I ſpooke euen nowe) prouing that no man ought to contemne the holie and catholicke conſent of the bleſſed fathers by the place of S. Paule,1. Cor. 12. Epheſ. 4. where he ſaieth: God placed certaine in his churche, firſt Apoſtles, them Prophets, and then doctours, preachers, and paſtours to the edifying of the church vntill his coming againe, ſaith: VVhoſoeuer deſpiſeth theſe, placed and apoynted of God, in the church, as
the tymes and place required, agreing and conſenting together vppon one thing in Chriſt, he deſpiſeth not man, but God, He that deſpiſeth the fathers apoynted by God, deſpiſeth God. who is no authour of diſſenſion, but of peace, (that is to ſay) he is not God of him, which ſhrinketh away from the vnitie of conſent, but of ſuch as abide conſtant in the peace of vnitie and conſent.

VVherfore ſeing you are faultie, in refuſing the authoritie of the auncient fathers, in ſuch pointes as they with one vniforme cōſent agree vpō, no maruel yf ye be reputed heretikes and ſciſmatikes: Such as diſpiſe not men, but God, not the church, but Chriſte, whatſoeuer reaſon you and your fardle of fanſies, your patch of old errours, your packe of hereſie, and lumpe of lies,The Apologie of the nevve church of England. for a faier name called the Apologie of the churche of Englād, cā p̄tend for your ſchiſme and ſeparation. For one of the greateſt reaſons and cauſes which it pretēdeth for your going from the churche, is the wicked life of the gouernours and rulers. And whoſoeuer forſaketh the church for any ſuch conſiderations, violateth the commaundement of Chriſte, who telling his diſciples, that Scribes and Phariſees ſate vppon the chaire of Moyſes, ſaied: Matt. 23. VVhatſoeuer they ſhall ſay vnto youe, kepe all, and do all, but doe not as they doe.

VVere he not an euil ſouldier that being commaunded vpon paine of his princes diſpleaſure to ſerue vnder a capitayne, woulde forſake the cāpe becauſe his capitayne liueth vitiouſly? VVere he not an euill marriner that being in the midſt of the ſea woulde leape out of the ſhippe, becauſe the pilote or maſter is naught? were he not an euill citizen that being required to continue in the citie on peril of his life, would runne out becauſe the maiot and other officers lyue not as they ſhould? Ye as verely, and ſo are they that forſake the churche. For God being king of al kinges hath, placed diuerſe capitaynes in his churche (whiche is acies ordinata, Cant. 6. a battaile ſette in good aray) and a general ouer al. As long as we lyue in this warfare he hath required vs to obey theſe capitaynes. His churche is as a ſhip vpon the ſea,VVe muſt neuer forſake the church. a citie builded vpon a mountayne, he hath willed vs to contynue in that ſhippe as long as we are on the ſea, and remayne in the citie as longe as we wilbe citizens. And yf any be ſo wilful,
that he will runne from the campe, leape out of the ſhip, and for ſake the citie, beſides that, he breaketh his maſters commaundement, he falleth into the handes of his enemies, and putteth him ſelf in vndoubted dāger of drowning. For as S. Hierome ſaieth: Yf a man be not in the Arck of Noë, Epiſt ad Damaſ. VVhile the fludde rageth, he ſhalbe drowned. VVhich yf the maſter of the Apologie had conſidered, his reaſon might haue tolde him that the churche is not to be forſaken, for the euil life of the rulers.

The holy Martir S. Cypriā hauing to do with certaine that broke the vnitie of the church for the ſame cauſe that you do, ſaied vnto them:Libr. 3. epiſt. 3. Albeit there be cockell ſeene to be in the church, yet for all that, our faith and charitie ought not to be let, that becauſe we ſee cockell in the church, we ſhoulde departe from the churche. VVe muſte only labour that we may be good corne, that when the corne ſhall beginne to be leyd in our lordes barne, we may haue reward for our labour and paynes. By theſe wordes S. Cyprian kepeth vs in the houſe of God, by theſe woordes he may bring vs peaceablie to the catholicke peace and vnitie, ſaieth S. Auguſtine, Lib 2. cōt. Creſco. cap 30. that you being offended with other mens faultes, be they true or be they falſe, might not obiect ſuche greate miſchiefes againſt the church, fructifying and encreaſing in all the worlde with the ſcripture, that ye might not blame the wheate for the cockell, that ye might not for ſake the corne for the chaffe, that ye might not remayne without the great houſe for the foule and filthie veſſels. For ſo to do, it is, as the ſaid, S. Cyprian teſtifieth, VVhat it is to forſake the church. ſuperba obſtinatio, & ſacrilega preſumptio. A proude obſtinacie and a wicked preſumptiō: from which S. Auguſtine exhorteth vs, ſaying, when either by negligence of rulers either by ſome inexcuſable neceſsitie, either by priuie obreptions we finde euill men in the churche, whome by eccleſiaſticall diſcipline we can not correct, and puniſh, then let not that wicked and daungerous preſumption, De fide & oper. ca 5. by which we thinke that we ſhoulde be ſeparated from them, that we be not infected with their iniquities, Aug. ad Creſco. grain. lib. 3. cap. 3. come into our heartes. Yf thou deſireſt good corne, moorne in the trauell of the field, reioiſe in hope of the barne, ſuffre the euill, in the cōmunion of Chriſtes ſacramentes, leſt by breaking the nette before you come to the bankes ſide, you be that which you woulde not ſuffre. Thus both by reaſon, and authoritie of S. Cyprian, and S. Auguſtine you ſee, that no Chriſten man ſhoulde forſake the church for the wickednes
of the gouernours. Yf this cōtent you not, lerne of your owne deare dearling and maſter Iohn Caluin. In the 4. booke and fifte chapiter of his inſtitutions, he ſaieth.

p.q: Horrible are thoſe diſcriptiōs wherein Eſay, Hieremie, Ioel,Caluin. Abacuc, and the other Prophets do lament the ſicknes of the churche of Hieruſalem. In the common people, in the magiſtrate, in the prieſtes, all thīges were ſo corrupt, that Eſay doubted not to match Hieruſalem with Sodom and Gomorrha: religion was partlie deſpiſed, partly defiled. In their manners are cō mōly reported theftes extortiōs, breaches of faith, murders and like miſchiues, yet therfore the prophetes did neither erect to them ſelues newe churches, nor build newe altars on which they might haue ſeuerall ſacrifices, but whatſoeuer maner of men they were, yet becauſe they conſidered that God had left his worde with thē, and ordayned ceremonies, wherby he was there worſhipped, in the midſt of the aſſembly of the wicked, they helde vp pure hādes vnto him. Truly yf they had thought that they did gather any infection thereby, they woulde rather haue died an hundred tymes, then haue ſuffred them ſelues to be drawen there vnto. Therefore nothing withheld thē from departing, but deſire to the keeping of vnitie, but yf the prophetes thought it againſt conſcience to eſtrange thē ſelues from the church, for many and great wycked doinges, not of one nor two men, but in maner of the whole people, then we take to much vpon vs, yf we dare by and by departe from the communion of the church, where not al mens manners doe ſatisfie either oure iudgement, yea or the Chriſtian profeſsion.
p.note: No offēce greater tha ſchiſme. Libr. 2. epiſt. 1. Lib. 1. cōt. Donat. cap. 13. Tract. 6. in epiſt. Ioan ca. 4 In Pſal. 54

div.p:
Here your owne doctour, your owne patriarcke, and idoll of Geneua condemneth your preſumption for ſeparating your ſelues from the churche, for that cauſe whiche your Apologie moſte vehemently vrgeth. He had lerned out of S. Cyprian that there is no greater, offence, than to breake the vnitie of the churche, and eſpied in S. Auguſtine, that immaniſsimum eſt ſeparationis ſcelus. The fault of ſeparatiō is moſte haynous, and that he hath no charitie that breaketh vnitie, ād that he which forſaketh the vnitie of all nations and remayneth in a parte, Polluit teſtamentum
Chriſti, difileth the teſtament of Chriſte, yet he had not the grace to followe it. VVherefore his damnation is the greater. But you ſay,Calf. Fol. 121. a we are the enemyes of God, and his churche, and therefore you ſeparate your ſelues from vs, and ioyne with the churche of Chriſt. Mart. Theſe are ſwete woordes but ful of poiſon, yf all men that liue euil, be Gods enemies, thē are we and yow alſo gods enemies: for neither of vs lacke infirmities, and ſynnes. But yf they be Gods enemyes that knowe his will, and wilfullie breake it,VVho be Gods enemies properly. Matt. 13. Pſal. 65. Pſal. 73. Matt. 16. Ioan. 21. Matt. 18. Heretikes ſovve vpō the corne that the Apoſtles ſovved. that come after that his ſeede is ſowed, and ſowe cockel ouer it, that in the multitude of his power lye vnto him, that haue maligned ād done euil in his ſanctuarie, and blaſphemed his holie name, then are you the enemies of God. For you know that he gaue the keies of heauen to S. Peter, and made him chief of the Apoſtles, and ruler of his churche in earth, yet you wilfullie denie it. Ye knowe that euery Chriſten man is commaunded to heare the church, yet you contemne it. You knowe that the ſeede whiche was firſt ſowē, was the true ſeede of our lord, yet haue ye ſowed cockel ouer it, and taught that theſe thirtene hundred yeres mē, yea tht chief pillers of the church varied from the ſinceritie of the goſpell.

Lib. 4 cōt. Marcio.You knowe with Tertulliā, that that is trueſt whiche is firſt, that is firſt which was from the beginning, that was from the beginning which was delyured of the Apoſtles, and that was delyured of the Apoſtles, which was holie and well obſerued in their churches,Heretikes refuſe that vvhich vvas holy in the Apoſtles churches. yet the moſt part of thinges that were holy and obſerued in their churches you refuſe to followe. Youe knowe that Chriſte in his laſt ſupper ſaid, This is my body, This is my bloud, yet ye lye vnto hī, and to his, in the multitude of his pouer, & ſay it is not his body, it is not his bloud, but a ſigne of his bodie, ād a ſigne of his bloud only. You knowe that he went by his diuine power through the doores faſt ſhutte into his diſciples, Ioan. 20. Heretikes lye vnto God. yet in the multitude of his power, ye lye vnto him, and to his, and ſay, he went not in through the doores faſt ſhutte, but by a chincke, by a wycket, or ſome ſuch thing. Youe knowe that his ſanctuarie is an holy houſe and a place of praier, yet haue
ye plucket many a hundred downe to the grounde,Heretikes prophane and ſpoyle churches. turned diuerſe into ſtables and ſlaughter houſes, deſtroyed the aulters, broken the baptiſteries, and made it a place of deſolatiō. Ye knowe that God tempteth no man, to euil, yet ye write that he is authour of euil: and affirme that the treaſon of Iudas, and crueltie of Manlius was the woorke of God,Heretikes blaſpheme God. aſwell as the conuerſiō of S. Paule, whiche is horrible blaſphemie, and yet one of the leaſt, with whiche ye blaſpheme his holie name.

Yf youe were Gods frends, and ſo holie as ye pretend, ye woulde neuer haue done ſuch vilaine to his churche as ye do. But to let, all thoſe paſſe, and come to your ſeparatiō and ſchiſme, I will ſay vnto you with S. Auguſtine,In Pſal. 40 Si ad membra Chriſti pertines introeas ad caput etc. If thou appertaine to the membres of Chriſt goe into thy head: beare with the cockel, yf thou be wheate: beare with the chaffe, yf thou be good corne. Beare with euil fiſſhes within the nette, yf thou be a good fiſhe. VVhy didſt thou flee away before the tyme of wynnoīg? VVhy haſt thou pluckt vp good corne before the harueſt? why haſt thou brokē the nette, before thou cameſt to the bāckes ſide? Chriſt ſaith, ye ſhalbe my frēdes yf ye do thoſe thinges whiche I cōmaunde you.
