The end of his cō maūdemēt is charitie: yf thē you wilbe chriſtes frēdes,Ioan. 15. you muſt haue charitie, yf you haue charitie, you muſt haue vnitie, yf you haue vnitie you muſt haue one God, one faith, one baptiſme, and one church, and one chiefe head of that churche, and that one head muſt be S. Peters ſucceſſour, euen whome you ſo maliciouſly impugne the biſhop of Rome. For Chriſt (ſaieth S. Chryſoſtome) ſhed his bloud, that he might gather vnto him thoſe ſheepe, Quarum curam tum Petro tum ſucceſſoribus Petri committebat. Lib 2. de ſacerd. The charge of Chriſtes churche cōmitted to S. Peter and his ſucceſſours. Lib. 2. de conſid. ad Euge. The charge of whome he committed both to S. Peter and to S. Peters ſucceſſours.

And other ſucceſſours of S. Peter, that do cōtynewe, you can ſhewe none, but the biſshops of Rome, as both the ſucceſsion from Peter to Pius the fifth, doth plainly conuince, and S. Bernard writing to Eugenius doth manifeſtlie ſhewe. For he ſaieth: Goe to, let vs ſearche out more diligentlie as yet, who thou art, what perſon thou beareſt for the tyme in the churche of God: who art thou? Sacerdos magnus, ſummus Pontifex, Tu princeps epiſcoporū, tu haeres Apoſtolorū, etc.
A great prieſt: The biſſhop of Rome Peters ſuceſſour. an high biſshop, thou art thou art the chief of Biſshops: thou art the heire of the Apoſtles: Yf heire of the Apoſtles, ergo ſucceſſour of the Apoſtles, yf ſucceſſour of the Apoſtles, ergo indued with all the rightes, titles, and prerogatiues that his predeceſſours had. As Peter then was, ſo muſt his ſucceſſour be, aedificandae eccleſiae Tertull. de preſcri. petra: magnum fundamētum Eccleſiae, Origen. ho. 5 ſuper Exod. ſolidiſsima perta: Apoſtolorum princeps: Chriſo. ho 29. in epiſt. ad Rom. Anteſignamus, coripheus, Idē ho. 1. in epiſt. ad Rom. vertex, caput Auguſt. queſt. 75. ex nouo teſtam. eorum, caput Marcellꝰ epiſt. 1. & Chryſ. ho. 55. in Mat. totius eccleſiae, fidei Hippol. Oratio. de conſum. mundi. petra, firmamentum Ambro. in. 5. Luc. De queſt. noui & ve ter. teſta. queſt. 110. Shevve vs your church M. Calf. and proue your ſucceſsion. Auguſt in Pſal. 15. eccleſiae. The rock of the church that was to be builded: a great foundatiō of the church: a moſt ſounde and ſtronge rock: the prince of the Apoſtles: the chiefe capitayne, the head and toppe of all: the head of all the whole church, the rock of faith, and groūde piller of the church. VVherfore yf ye wilbe Chriſtes frendes (as ye pretend) haue charitie: kepe vnitie, loue his church: obey his officer, and vicar on earth, whom he hath made ruler of his churche. As for that church, which you call the church Chriſt, with which you flatter your ſelues, and ſay ye ioyne vnto, is no church, but a ſynagog of Satā, oftē ouerthrowē, and manytimes inuiſible, by your owne cōfeſsiō, a cōuēticle of Apoſtatats, ād cōſpiracie of libertines. For S. Augu. calleth the church that diſturbeth, the ordre begonne in S. Peter, and contynued by order of Biſshops ſucceding one after another to the preſent tyme, which was the order of the biſshops of Rome, Cathedram pestilentiae, the Chayer of peſtilence.

Yf your church be (as you make the ſimple beleaue) a catholike and vniuerſall church, diſperſed through out the worlde, ſhewe vs where it is nowe: and where it hath ben the fiftene hundred yeres: proue your ſucceſsion: name your biſshops. The church of Chriſt hath alwaies ben viſible, as a citie placed vpon an hill: It hath alwaies had (as he ordained) Apoſtles, Euangeliſtes, Doctours, and Paſtours: In ſole poſuit tabernaculum ſuum, hoc eſt ſanctam eccleſiam ſuam, etc. He hath placed his tabernacle in the ſunne, that is his holy church: he hath put it in an open place to be ſeene, and not in couert, and ſecret corners, not that it ſhould lye priuie, not that it ſhoulde be couered, that happely it might not be couered, as the conſpiracies and conuenticles of heretickes are. That we may knowe your churche ſhewe vs the tabernacle,
where it was placed as in the ſunne: Shewe vs the opē place where it was planted as in the light of the worlde, and yf ye can not (as moſte certaine it is you can not) then bragge no more that your church is catholike and vniuerſall. The churche of Rome founded of Chriſt by his bleſſed Apoſtles S. Peter and S. Paule, which we preſently followe,The churche of Rome alvvayes viſible, ād ſincere in faith. and are able to giue the name of euery biſshop that ſucceded in that ſee euerſithens, hath cōtinued in the light and face of the worlde, alwaies viſible, alwaies ſeene, alwaies reſorted vnto, alwaies vncorrupt both in doctrine of faith and doctrine touching māners, alwaies vndefiled, alwaies firme and ſtable in the faith, alwaies counted the head of the vniuerſall churche, alwaies mother of faith, and rocke, that hell gates coulde neuer breake. VVherfore ſir you neaded not require vs to make it a catholike churche, Fol. 121. b and a follower, and furtherer of true religion. It was proued before, and nowe for your furder inſtruction, I wil repete ſomwhat of it againe.

To be with Cornelius (who was biſſhop of Rome) idem eſt quod cum Eccleſia Catholica cōmunicare, Cip. lib. 4. epiſt. 2. is the very ſelfe ſame thing that it is to communicate with the Catholik churche. To allowe and firmely holde the communion of Cornelius, eſt catholicae Eccleſiae vnitatem, pariter & charitatem probare, & firmiter tenere, is to allowe and firmely hold both the vnitie and charitie of the Catholike churche. Libr. 4. epiſt. 8. To be one of the Catholike biſhops, eſt cum Eccleſia Romana conuenire, is to agree with the churche of Rome. S. Cyprian ſaieth, The churche of Rome hath bene, Ambroſ. de obitu fratris. Libr. 1. epiſt. 3. Lib 3 ca. 3 epiſt. ad Damaſ. and is the only Church to whiche infidelitie and vnfaithfulnes could neuer haue acceſſe. Irenaeus ſaieth, in the churche of Rome that tradition which came from the Apoſtles was alwaies kept. S. Hierome ſaith, Amongeſt the Romayns only, the authoritie of the fathers remayneth vncorrupt. Ibi ceſpite terra ſoecundo dominici ſeminis veritatem centeno fructu reſert, there the grounde with her fertile ſoyle, bringeth foorth the truthe of our lordes ſeede with an hundred folde increaſe. The churche of Rome the Catholique churche.

By this you might haue ſeene that the churche of Rome is the Catholike church, or at the leaſt the mother, rote, ſpring, and head of the Catholike church, neuer defiled with hereſie, idolatrie, ſuperſtition or any errour in matters of faith. But peraduē ture
you read not ſo farre. VVherfore in Gods name ſee it nowe, and yf you wilbe a membre of the Catholike churche, be with the chief biſhop of the Catholike church. Youe may lerne by S. Cyprian that the biſshop is in the churche, and the churche in the biſshop: Lib. 4. epiſt. 9. and that yf any man be not with the biſshop, he is not in the churche: and that they flatter them ſelues in vaine, who hauing not vnitie and peace with the prieſtes of God, creape vp, and beleaue that they ſecretly cō municate with ſome, wheras the church, which is one, and catholike, is not cutte, nor deuided. Yow may learne by S. Auguſtine that they who go from the whole to a parte, from the bodie to a wounde, from life, to a diuiſion, ſhall paſſe hence into the pitte of corruption: and that they that die in frowardnes, In Pſal. 54 and ſchiſme, ſhalbe humbled of God in damnatiō, becauſe they were aduaunced vp in diſſenſion? To be ſhort, you may learne that he crieth woe to them that hate the vnitie of the churche and make them ſelues partes in men, wherfore as ye tender your owne health,Tract. 12. in Ioan. reade and regard. And yf ye ſhall finde no vnitie nor perfect truth out of the churche of Rome, then returne againe frō whence ye departed, into the vnitie of the churche of Rome.

VVhere youe obiect againſt me, that ſpeaking of cuſtome, I make a lye and falſifie Tertullian, Fol. 123. a you muſt pardon me, yf I tell your maſterſhippe, ſir reuerēce according to your cuſtome you make a lye. Theſe are my woordes. Cuſtome increaſer, confirmer, and obſeruer of faith, taught vs this vſe of the Croſſe. His woordes out of whiche I gathred this poſition, in latin are theſe.De coro. militis. Harum & aliarum eiuſmodi diſciplinarum ſi legem expoſtules ſcripturarum, nulla legis traditio tibi praetendetur. Autrix conſuetudo, confirmatrix & fidei obſeruatrix. Yf thou require a lawe of ſcriptures for theſe and other obſeruāces, no traditiō of lawe ſhalbe pretēded vnto the. Cuſtome authour, cōfirmer, and obſeruer of faith ſhalbe pretēded vnto the. Theſe wordes finde I in Tertullian printed of Frobenius at Baſile in the yere of our lorde 1521. in the moneth of Iuly. The very ſame wordes finde I in Tertullian printed of Frobenius at Baſile in the yere of our lorde 1528. in Marche. And the very ſame may you finde in Tertulliā, yf it pleaſe your worſhippe to looke vppon any of the ſaid printes. VVherfore ſeing I followed my printed booke viewed by learned men before
it came to the prime, and receaued of learned men in the ſame ſenſe, in whiche it is alleaged, after it came from the printe, eſpecially out of Baſile where your religion raygneth, I am not to be coūted a falſifier of the authour, for alleagīg him as I finde hī in print, but you an infamous ſclāderer, for ſo reportīg of me before you had conſulted diuerſe printes, and impreſsions, and ſeene vpon what grounde I builded. But we may ſee that you are glad to take euery light occaſion to diſcredite vs, and ſhyft away the matter whiche ye take in hād to impugne. But it is a foule ſhift to make a lye, and ſclander your neyghbour.

Let your neweſt Baſile printe, and the laſt of Paris, reade that ſaying of Terrulliā in this ſorte: Harū & aliarū diſciplinarū ſi legem expoſtules ſcripturarū, nullā inuenies, traditio tibi praetēdetur autrix, cōſuetudo cōfirmatrix, et fides obſeruatrix: that is,For certayne ceremonies tradition and cuſtome ſuffiſe for ſcriptures. yf thou demaūde a lawe of ſcriptures for thoſe and other obſeruances, tradition ſhall be p̄tēded vnto the as authour, cuſtome cōfirmer, ād faith obſeruer of thē, it maketh quite againſt your poſitions, who will haue nothing but ſcripture. You ſee that tradition may be authour of a ceremonie in Chriſts churche. For ſo haue your newe printed booke, autrix, and not auctrix, authour and not increaſer. Howe be it yf we had not to do with wranglers, both might ſignifie one. You ſee that to the curious that aſke for ſcriptures,Good Chriſtians obſerue traditions. tradition and cuſtome are pretended, and that the faith of true Chriſtians obſerueth that, which tradition delyured and cuſtome confirmed.

You take much paines to proue that which no mā denieth,Fol. 123 b Fol. 123. a that traditions not written ſhould be reaſonable, and agreable to ſcripture, as though the Apoſtles and fathers after them, delyured any thīg by traditiō that was vnreaſonable, and cōtrary to ſcriptures: or the catholicke churche woulde maintaine any thīg, cōtrary to reaſon ād ſcripture. Again you would haue the vſe of the croſſe proued to be a reaſonable traditiō, Calf. Fol. 123. b agreable to God, furthering to diſcipline, and profitable to ſaluatiō, and then ye woulde yelde vnto it, Mart. but yf there had bene ſuch modeſtie, and honeſtie in you, as is required in an obedient childe,
you woulde neuer haue doubted, but that the Apoſtles hauing the holy Ghoſte, did all things agreable to God, furtherīg to diſcipline, and profitable to ſaluation, and conſonant to reaſon, albeit they gaue not preſently a reaſon why and wherfore they did it.Hom. cōt. Sabel. Tradition In 2 ad ad Theſſ. Hom. 4 VVhenſoeuer any traditiō might be alleaged, S. Baſile ſaied: Te pacatum reddat traditio. Let tradition make the quiet. S. Chryſoſtome ſaieth: Traditiō eſt, nihil quaeras amplius. It is a tradition, ſeeke for no more. VVherfore ſeing Tertullian and S. Baſile tell you that it is a tradition to vſe the ſigne of the croſſe, and bleſſe our ſelues with it, that might haue made you quiet, and taught you to beleaue that it was of God.

Leo an holy father was wounte to ſay, that it was not to be doubted but that euery thing which was retayned of the church into cuſtome of deuotion, came of the Apoſtles tradition, or doctrine of the holie Ghoſte. Serm. 2 de ieiunio. pētecoſt. The general cuſtomes of the Catholik church come frō the Apoſtles and doctrine of the holy ghoſt. Lib. 2. cap. 7 de bapt. cont Donatiſt. Likewiſe becauſe many ceremonies were vſed through out the vniuerſal church, and not ſounde in ſcripture, nor councell, S. Auguſtine thought that they were delyuered and commaunded of no other, but of the Apostles, and yf they being holy and lerned fathers, thought the vniuerſall cuſtome of the church a good cauſe, and ſufficiēt reaſon, to ꝓpue that the ceremonie vſed, was delyured of the Apoſtles, what wiſdome is there in your ſingular head to require other proufe for the traditiō of the croſſe, than the generall obſeruation and common cuſtom of the catholike churche? Are you wiſer or better ſeene in the ſcripture, or more zelous to ſet forth the honour of God then they were? No no M. Calf. There was, more wiſdome lerning, and deuotion in the meaneſt of them, than in all the proteſtants heades that euer were, or ſhalbe. VVherfore ſeing you knowe it to be a tradition, braule no more contentiouſly againſt it. Say with S. Baſile, Me pacatū reddet traditio. Tradition ſhall make me quiet. Say with Chryſoſtom: Traditio eſt nihil quaerā amplius. It is a tradition, I will ſeeke no furder. Say with Leo and S. Auguſtine, it is receaued into cuſtome of deuotion, and generall vſe through out the catholike churche, therfore it cometh from the tradition of the Apoſtles, and doctrine of the holy Ghoſt: ſo ſhall your ſelf be moſte at peace and quiet. The furder ye venture, the more ye
fall in danger. The diſtinction, which you make of thre kindes of traditions, that ſome are neceſſarie to be retayned of all Chriſtians as neceſſarilie inferred of the ſcripture, Fol. 124. a & b. Three kindes of traditiōs mē tioned by M. Calf. As that a woman in the congregation ſhoulde not be bare headed, that in the congregatiō ſhe ſhoulde kepe ſilēce, that the poore ſhould labour with their owne handes and get their lyuing, other direct contrary to the woorde, As Latin ſeruice, worſhipping of images, vowing of chaſtitie, and cōmunicating vnder one kinde, Other indifferent, neither vtterly repugnant to the woorde of God, neither neceſſarely inferred of it, ſo ſauoreth of ignorance that it is like to diſgrace the eſtimation of our lerning amongeſt the whotteſt puritanes in all London. For firſt to put you in remembrance of the greate vanitie made in the title of your booke, that the vanities of men ſhould diſproued by the vndoubted worde of God, and the dreames and dotages of others controlled by the godly fathers of the churche, and conſpiracies ouerthrowed by laufull councells, M. Calfs diſtinctiō of traditions not to be foū de in the fathers nor ſchole men. I beſeeke tell vs in what ſcripture, father, or councell you finde this diſtinction? VVe admitte all for ſcripture, that you reiect out of the Canon. Beſides S. Auguſtine, Ambroſe, Hierome, Gregorie, and other aunciēt fathers, we will receaue S. Thomas, Gaietan, Alexander de Ales, Martin de Magiſtris, Bonauenture, and all other ſchole men with their gloſes in this caſe, we will not refuſe the ſimpleſt prouinciall coūcell that was aſſembled by any lawfull biſshops theſe thirtene hundred yeres. Goe to therfore bring vs one text of ſcripture, one father, one councell, and canon, where this diſtinction is made. VVhy ſpeake you not? Are your ſcriptures ſo tied to the paper, that they can not be looſed? Are your fathers ſo to the leſſe that they can not ſpeake? Are your councells ſo conceaued that no canon cā appeare? VVhat a ſtraūge eaſe is this? Finde ſome for ſhame, let not all the worlde ſee that great crake of ſcriptures, fathers, and councells to be turned into a dreame dotage, and fanſie of your owne. Yf they do, you are ſhamed for euer. For either men will eſteme you,
but for an arrogant fole, for making ſuch a great brag, or a very idiot for ſo foliſhly exemplyfying your diſtinction. For what ignorant, but you woulde, ſay that theſe are traditions neceſſarilie inferred of the ſcripture, and ſo proued out of the ſcripture by S. Paule, that a woman ſhould not be bare headed in the churche? that in the congregation ſhe ſhoulde kepe ſilence?

That is neceſſarilie inferred of ſcripture which being not in expreſſe ſcripture is by drift of argument, and neceſſarie ſequele of reaſon,Inferred of ſcripture. 1. Cor. 11. inferred of ſome place of ſcripture. As for the tradition that woemen ſhould couer their heades in the church, it is taught in expreſſe woordes, and commaunded in S. Paule, and not inferred of any ſcripture. There is one lye: and if that place of S. Paule were not, there were no ſcripture in all the Bible to proue it.Fol. 124. b Againe where you ſay, that S. Paule did not obtrude this of his authoritie, but by the ſcripture proue it, there is another lye. For S. Paule brīgeth no text, nor ſentēce of ſcripture to proue it neceſſary that women ſhoulde be couered, in the churche: but as he was an apoſtle indued with the holy Ghoſte: So he gaue that precept.

Furder who but ſuch a blind batfouler, would ſay, that Latin ſeruice, woorſhipping of images, vowing of chaſtitie, and receauing vnder one kinde were direct cōtrary to the woorde of God? VVhereas there is no expreſſe precept of any one tō gue in ſcripture, nor any commaundement againſt images, vowing of chaſtitie, or receauing vnder one kinde. Laſt of all, who but ſuch a wiſe man would ſay: that in traditions of ſuch thinges as are indifferent, Fol. 124. b we muſt followe the ordre of the churche with a limitation, and not abſolutely?

Euery wiſe man knoweth that we ſhould not preſcribe order to the churche, but the churche preſcribe ordre vnto vs: we obey the church, and not the church obey vs. Your ſelf ſay within fewe,Fol 124. b lynes, that the churche muſt ſtill retayne her right, to be iudg and determiner of ſuch traditions, either to beare with them, or aboliſh them, as may beſt ſerue for edification.
Yf that be true, howe will you excuſe your ſelf of cōtradictiō? Yf the church hathe a right to be iudge and determiner of traditions, then the churche muſt ſee whether they be profitable, the churche muſt ſee whether they be to edificatiō, the church muſt ſee whether they be tollerable, and not we, I meane ſuch priuate men as you and I are. Yf the churche commande them, we muſt obey, yea abſolutely: and not with a limitation, vnleſſe for not obeying the churche, we wilbe alienated abſolutely without al lymitation from Chriſt,The churche muſt be obeyed abſolutely vvithout limitation. Matt. 18. and made of Chriſtiās heathens and publicanes. Chriſt, willeth him that heareth not the churche to be counted an heathen and Publican. But ſir in whiche of the three kindes of traditions, will you place thoſe that S. Baſile mentioneth, to witt, the ſigning and bleſsing of Chriſten men with the ſigne of the croſſe, praing towarde the eaſt, the woordes of inuocation whiles the Sacrament is ſhewed, hallowing the water of baptiſme, the oyle of inunction, and the man that is baptiſed? be they neceſſarely inferred vppon ſcripture or direct cōtrary to the worde of God? Or indifferent, neither repugnant to the worde, nor neceſſarely inferred of the worde? Seing our controuerſie was of the tradition of the croſſe ſpecially, whiche both Tertullian, and S. Baſile mention, reaſon would youe ſhould haue placed them in one of your three rancks, that we might by your good aduiſe haue knowen, whether it be a tradition or neceſſarely inferred vpon ſcripture, or direct contrary to the ſcripture, or indifferēt, nor repugnāt to ſcripture, nor neceſſarely inferred of ſcripture. But youe thought it not good for your purpoſe, leſt yf happely you had adumbred it amongeſt ſuch traditions as are indifferēt,Fol. 125. a The fathers accōpte the croſſe to be a tradition and yet M. Calf. vvil haue it to be none. your owne rule would haue forced you to retayne it, becauſe the churche hath taken order for it, and vniuerſally receaued it, through out all chriſtendome. VVherfore to aduoice that, youe ſay, that in this numbre we can not iuſtlely cōpriſe the croſſe: which is a ſtrange caſe. Tertullian, S. Baſile, Leo S. Auguſtine, aūciēt and lerned fathers, ād al the whole church of Chriſte take theſe and ſuche like traditions to be at the leaſt, thinges indifferent, and yet your wiſedome can not ſee, it. VVhence cometh
this? Of humilitie, or arrogancie? of modeſtie, or ſingularitie? Flater your ſelf as well as you can, S. Auguſtine) as I tolde youe before) counteth it not omly arrogancie, and ſingularitie, but inſolentiſsimam inſaniam, moſte proude madnes. Epiſt. 118.

VVhere youe ſay, that although of ſome fathers it hath bene accompted ſuch, Fol 125. a Calf. yet we muſt remembre that they did not alway builde golde and ſiluer, but ſomtymes hay and ſtuble vpon Chriſt (which wordes being meāt of manners you wreſt falſely to doctrine) and that euery thing whiche is p̄tended to be the fathers writīges, Mart. is not by and by theirs, I anſwer that albeit ſome fathers in ſearching reaſons to conuince Heretiks arguments had ſome priuate opinions, yet there is no reaſon why their authoritie ſhoulde be refuſed when they agree with all other fathers and biſshops of Chriſtes churche. Likewiſe albeit ſome falſe bookes, and baſtard babes haue ben fathered vpon ſome fathers, by baſtards, Apoſtatats and heetickes, yet is it not conuenient that therefore we ſhoulde condemne the true bokes and woorkes of the fathers, Or refuſe to followe the cuſtome of catholik churche. Therefore we ſay vnto you as S. Baſile hauing to do with ſuche a wicked heretike as you are, and almoſt in a like caſe,S. Baſile. Lib. 1 cōt. Euno. Reuerēce devve to the aūciēt fathers. ſaied ones. VVhat ſaieſt thou man? Shall we not giue more to antiquitie? Shall we not reuerence the multitude of Chriſten men, aſwell thoſe that liue preſentlie, as thoſe that lyued euer ſithens the Ghoſpell was preached? Shall we haue no regard of their dignitie who floriſshed in all ſpirituall grace, for whom thou haſt lately deuiſed this enuious way of impietie? But ſhutting the eies of our hearts, and abandoning the memorie of euery holy man, ſhall we yelde our mindes nowe quiet, and voyd of fanſies to thy ſophiſtrie and cauillation? Suerly thy power is great, yf thoſe thinges ſhall be at thy commandement which the deuill him ſelf with his manifold craft, could neuer attaine: For we being perſuaded of thee, ſhall preferre your wicked imaginations and thoughtes before the tradition of faith, which in all ages paſt, hath preuayled vnder moſte holy men, which were no ſafetye. VVherefore vtter all the vemine that you can againſt the fathers, of bleſſed memorie: turne vp their aſhes: diſcloſe their infirmities: ſhewe their errours, ſpend al the
eloquence that you haue againſt thē, you ſhal neuer hurt them, nor driue any Chriſten man from reuerencing that, which the churche hath allowed in them: Tradition ſhall make vs quiet. VVe will ſay with S. Baſile. Dominus it a docuit, Apoſtoli praedicauerunt, Hom. cōt. Sabell. patres obſeruauerunt, confirmauerunt martyres, ſufficiat dicere, ſic edoctus ſum. Our Lorde hath ſo taught: the Apoſtles haue ſo preached: the fathers haue ſo obſerued: the martyrs haue confirmed. As for you and yours we leaue with the Arians, who would not voucheſafe to compare any of the olde fathers to them ſelues, Lib. 1. cap. 14 Tripar. The pride of heretikes. nor to be equalled to the ſcholemaſters of whome they were inſtructed, nor thinke any mā comparable to them ſelues in meaſure of wiſdom, but imagined that they only were wiſe, they only had thoſe thinges reueled vnto them, which were knowen of no mā vnder the ſunne beſides. VVe leane you to Neſtorius, Lib. 12 ca. 4 Tripar. who hauing a litle eloquence, diſdained to reade the bookes of the olde interpreters, and thought him ſelf better then all. It ſhal ſuffice vs to ſay, we haue bene ſo taught.

Your long diſcourſe made to proue,Calf. Fol. 125. b that whatſoeuer hath ben delyuered, and otherwiſe eſtemed Apoſtolike, is not to be obſerued, that for diuerſitie of ceremonies men are not to be contemned, and that traditions varied often, Mart. to the end that you might not be contemned, for refuſall of the like, I haue anſwered before: and ſay furder, that there is nothing more reaſonable, than to haue euery thing diſſolued by the ſame meanes that it was tied: euery lawe to be abrogated by the ſame meanes that it was firſt ordayned. Seing then traditions were deliuered vnto the church by the Apoſtles, and biſshops, who had the diſpēſatiō of Chriſtes myſteries, it is reaſon that yf there be cauſe why they ſhould be abrogated and refuſed,Proue your churche to be Apoſtilike and Catholique and your vocation Lauful M. Calf. they ſhould be abrogated by the Apoſtles ſucceſſours, and biſshops, that haue the diſpenſation of Chriſtes myſteries, and gouernance of his churche committed vnto them. As for you, proue your churche to be Apoſtolike, and Catholike, your vocation to be lauful, that ye are rightlie accordīg to Chriſtes ordināce called to the diſpenſatiō of his myſteries, that you haue true biſshops in your churche, before you challeng vnto you, the alteration,
of any ordinance, tradition, or ceremonie in Chriſtes churche.

Hitherto I haue ſpoken of the two poynts which you like an euill point maker haue knockt long to make tagleſſe, and breake a ſunder: But thankes be to God the leather was ſo good and your hammer ſo vnhamſom that they be both whole yet. Nowe let vs ſe howe you tugge at the thirde pointe: videlicet, that a croſſe was ſet vp in euery place etc. To Martialis one of the 72. diſciples that ſaied: Crucem domini in mente, in ore & in ſigno tenete: Kepe the croſſe of our lorde in your mynde, in your mouth, and in a ſigne, Martialis vvorte denied and vvordes vvreſted. Fol. 127 a Calf. Mart. you ſaye nothing, to any purpoſe: but as the propertie of al heretikes is, denie his worke, and wreſte his woordes, and ſaye: VVe may haue the croſſe in a ſigne accordīg to Chriſtes woordes in his laſt ſupper, doe this as ofte as ye do it in remēbrance of me, though we haue not the ſigne of the croſſe.

Here it is to be noted, howe wittely this wiſeman diſſenteth from the reſt of his brethren. For whereas they ſay, that in the ſupper we haue the body of Chriſt in a ſigne, he to haue a ſinguler fanſie from all the reſt, will not reſt vppon that, but ſaieth, we may haue the croſſe at the ſupper, in a ſigne, to witte the paſsion of Chriſt in bread and wyne, whiche is but a newe deuiſed to ye, to ſhyft away an olde truth. Certaine it is that by the celebration of Chriſtes ſupper, we are put in remembraunce of Chriſtes paſsion. But becauſe it was done then, but priuilie in ſome ſecrete place, it is to be thought that the authour requiring vs to haue the croſſe of Chriſte in our myndes, in your mouthes and in a ſigne, meāt that, ſeing our mature is ſo dull and heauy, that we could not alwaies thinke and ſpeake of Chriſt, vnleſſe we had ſome externall meane to excite our memory, nor be euer at the ſupper to celebrate the remembrance of his paſsion, we ſhoulde haue the ſigne of the croſſe before our eies in our churches, houſes, parlours, chambres, high waies, and els where, that whetherſoeuer we turned nor face, the croſſe might be ſeene, and put vs in remembraunce of Chriſte. Certaine it is that Martialis was no ſignifier with Swinglius, nor meant that the ſupper of our lord is a naked ſigne. His woordes in the ſame
epiſtle teſtifie the contrary: for he ſaieth, That whiche the Iewes through enuie ſacrificed, thinking to aboliſh his name out of the earth, An aulter hallovved. An argument for the preſence of Chriſt in the Sacrament. we for our healths ſake, ſette foorth in the hallowed aulter. vpon whiche woordes we may buld this argument. That is vppon the hallowed aulter whiche the iewes crucified, but the iewes crucified Chriſtes true bodye, and not a naked ſigne of his bodye. Ergo his true bodie and no naked ſigne of his bodie is ſet vpon the aulter: whiche being true, it can not be, that he willing the Burdegalenſians to haue the croſſe in a ſigne, meant that they ſhoulde haue a ſigne of our lordes bodie at our lordes ſupper, but the ſigne of the croſſe in our churches, chambres, and high waies.

To the place of Athanaſius that ſaied: Crucis certe figuram ex duobus lignis componentes adoramus, we certes making the figure of the croſſe of two pieces of wood, do adore and woorſhip it, you anſwer nothīg, but as youe did before ſclanderouſlie reporte of me,Queſt. 38. ad Antio. that I falſified Tertullian: So with like impudēcie, and leſſe honeſtie you ſay here, that I falſyfie Athanaſius. Athanaſiꝰ not falſified. But what truth is in your woordes lett the readers iudge. I alleage the woordes ſimply and plainly as I finde them in the authour. Athanaſius printed at Lions in Melchior and Gaſpar Trechſels ſhoppe, the yere of our lord 1522, hath one and fourth ye queſtions to Antiochus, and in the anſwer to the 38. queſtion hath theſe wordes. Crucis certe figuram ex duobus lignis componentes adoramus, we certes making the figure of the croſſe of twoo pieces of wood, do adore and worſhip it. The ſame Athanaſius printed at Argentine, (a towne of our owne goſpel) in Marche the yere of our lorde 1522. by Knoblouch hath all the ſame queſtions to Antiochus, and the very ſame woordes in the anſwer to the 38. queſtion. Like wiſe the ſame Authour printed at Colonie the yere of our lorde 1548. in the printe houſe, of Melchior Moneſiany, readeth as before, as euery man that will take paines to looke in them, may ſee, and are leſſe to be ſuſpect, of corruptiō than your late Baſile print. VVhiche being vndoubtedlie true, iudge (good raders) whether I alleaging Athanaſius woordes as I founde them, in three diuerſe printed bookes, haue deſerued to be accuſed for a falſifier, or he condē ned
for a ſclaunderer, I for a lyer, or he for a falſe accuſer.

But to returne thoſe three lies vnto hī ſelf againe, youe ſhall vnderſtād that where he ſaith: that I ſuppreſſed a piece of Athanaſiꝰ, Fol. 127. b. ſaying of the ſpeare, reede and ſpōge, that thy are holy as the croſſe, whereas the authour ſaied, they are as holy as the croſſe, that is a lye of his. For I ſuppreſt it not, my written copie is yet able to ſhewe the contrary. In dede the printer hath omitted it, by ouerſight, but his negligence is not to be abuſed to my hinderance. In ſo ſmale a matter a gentle reader woulde haue borne with ſuch a ſcape, ſeing it was printed in a ſtraunge countrie, but ſeing he grateth ſo nigh, to ſpie a fault, you ſhall pardon me, yf hereafter I driue him to the printer for excuſe of ouerſights.

The vvoorde Adore. in Athanaſiꝰ text.VVhere he ſaieth: the woorde adore is not in the text, there is a falſe lye. For all the three printes which I alleaged before haue this woorde: Adoramus we do adore, and are better to be credited than his neweſt impreſsion. Againe in ſaying that there be not xxxix. queſtions, that is another lye. For yf he tell them, as tom foole tolde his geeſe,41 queſtions of Athanaſ. to Antio. he ſhall finde fourthy and one in the bookes of the ſaied printes, which yf it might haue pleaſed his maſterſhip to haue vievved with other circumſtances before he pronounced ſo raſh a ſentence, and condemned me of falſifying thoſe authours, this infamie had not rebounden backe vpon him. But let vs conſider the woordes, which he alleageth out of his neweſt printe.Queſt 16 ad Antio. Calf. Fol. 127 b They are theſe: Quare credentes omnes ad crucis imaginē cruces facimus, Lanceae verò ſanctae, aut arundinis, aut ſpongiae, figuras nullas conficimus, quum tamen haec tam ſint ſancta, quàm ipſa crux. Reſponſio: Figuram quidem crucis ex duobus lignis compingentes conficimus, vt ſi quis infidelium etc. VVhy do all beleauers make croſſes after the image of the croſſe, but make no figures nor likeneſſe of the ſpeare, the reede, or the ſponge, whereas not withſtanding, they are as holy as the croſſe it ſelf? The anſwer, we make in deede the figure of the croſſe by putting of two pieces of wood together, that yf any of the infidels reproue that in vs, that
we woorſhip wood, we may by ſeparating thoſe two pieces of wood, and taking away the ſigne of a croſſe, accompte them as vnprofitable wood, and perſuade the infidel, that we woorſhip not woodd, but crucis typum, the thing repreſented by the croſſe, quoth M. Calf. which in the ſpeare, ſpōge and reede, we neither cā do nor ſhewe. Mart. But what hath he adunataged his cauſe by this? Or what hath he hyndred myne? Is it not plaine, that all Chriſten men made croſſes to the likeneſſe of the croſſe of Chriſte? VVhat will he make of thoſe woordes omnes credentes? Al Chriſten men made croſſes. all beleauers? and conficimus figuram crucis ex duobus lignis? VVe make the figure of the croſſe, of two pieces of wood? Yf he conſtrue them, muſt he not ſay: All we Chriſten men make a figure of the croſſe of two pieces of wood? yeas I trowe, and that the yoūgeſt puine in Paules ſchole hauing learned, but Eſops fables of bayard and the Aſſe, the egle, and the Betell can tell him. Yf it be ſo, then haue we founde, that in Alexādria in Athanaſius tyme all Chriſten men made croſſes, like the croſſe of Chriſte, and that Athanaſius him ſelf archbiſshop of Alexandria was one of thoſe Chriſten men ſpite of M. Calfhils balde miniſters beard.

But (he ſaieth) there is not any word or half woord for woorſhipping. Calf. Fol. 127. b Mart. Veneror veneraris &c. is not latin to vvoorſhip vvith M. Calf. Athanaſiꝰ corrupted No ſir? Is not veneror veneraris etc. Latin in your Dictionarie to worſhip? And haue you not that woorde twiſe in the ſame ſentence? non veneremur lignum, ſed veneremur crucis typum? That we worſhip not the wood, but we worſhip the figure of the croſſe? O mercifull God what frontitck phrenſie inueigled your wittes that you durſt make ſo open a lye? and interpreting the authours woordes corrupt his ſenſe? Is typus crucis, the thing repreſented by the croſſe? or the figure of the croſſe? Examine the place better, call your wit to court, aſſemble your learned counſell, and make a cōference, of the brotherhode. Or yf it be to chardgable, for you to be at ſuch a coſt, conſult maſter Copers Dictionarie and ſee whether, typus be not Latin for a type, figure, ſhadowe, an example, a forme, a likenes, and Crux Latin for a croſſe? and when you haue put them both together, aſke ſom lerned man, whether typus crucis, be not a figure, a forme an example
and likenes of the croſſe, and not the thing figured by the croſſe. In the meane while we wilbe ſo bolde as to ſcore vp the three lyes,Three lies one for that you ſaied: there was no woorde no halfe woorde in that ſentēce for worſhipping. Another becauſe you ſay: Typus cruris ſignifieth the thing repreſented by the croſſe. makīg no differēce betwene the figure of the croſſe, and Chriſt hym ſelf. The third that you ſay the ſpeare ſponge and reede ſhould be aſwel woorſhipped as the croſſe. For the very wordes and meaning of the authour is againſt it. He ſaieth: we make croſſes, that yf the infidels woulde laye to our chardg that we woorſhip wood we might breake thoſe pieces of wood, and perſuade the infidel, that we woorſhip not the wood, but Typum crucis, the ſigne, forme, figure, and likenes of the croſſe, but we can neither do the like, nor ſhewe the like in the ſpeare, The ſpeare and the ſpōge not to be vvoorſhipped as the croſſe. An imitation of M. Calfs Rhethorique. Fol. 128. a. ſponge, and reede, and therfore we woorſhip it not as we do the croſſe, which is Athanaſius true meanīg, or els the queſtion propounded, remayneth as yet vnſoluted: which were abſurde to thinke.

VVherfore to vſe his owne Rhethorike: Ah ſee (good readers) with what a ſotte, we haue to do with all, that condemneth him of falſifying authours, who alleageth their woordes as he findeth them in their bookes of diuerſe printes, more auncient than his, and more likely to be true than his of the neweſt print? See with what a Calf. we are encōbred that vnderſtandeth not his owne boke, that falſlie tranſlateth the woordes of his authour, and maketh lyes as he liſt? And becauſe mē ſhould not thinke that the croſſes which Athanaſius and other Chriſtiās made in his tyme were ſet vp in priuate and publick places, aſketh,Fol. 128. a. whether any wyſe man when he hath a newe garment proclameth it in the market, or hange the counterfect of his frend vpon a pole to beſeene? And willeth vs as we iudg of one ſo to imagine of the other? VVhich hath nor witte, nor reaſon in it. For as euery wiſe man that maketh him a newe cote maketh it to were on his backe, and not to proclame in the market: So they that make croſſes, and images of ſainctes, and counterfectes of their frendes, make them becauſe they
ſhould be ſeene. To haue them ſeene is not to ley them vp in a cole houſe, but to ſet them in ſome open place, where they may be ſeene. And albeit, M. Calfhil, thinketh it a foule incōuenience, for a man to hang the counterfect of his frend vpon a pole to be ſeene, yet he can not deny, but that euery man that hath the counterfect of his frend, or hāgeth it vpon a nayle againſt ſome wall, or ſetteth it in ſome windoe, where he him ſelf and others may ſee it, and remēbre his frend. For that is the only end, why he maketh the counterfect of his frend.

To your brable aboute Serapis, I anſwered before: that may ſuffiſe. For the ſiniſtrous ſuſpicion and lewde ſurmiſe which of the fact of Tyrannus an heathen and idolatrous prieſt, you labour to rere, and leaue in mens heades of all Catholik prieſtes, of the newe lawe of Chriſte, and his goſpell, God that knoweth the ſecretes of all heartes, iudge you for it, and reward that malicious mynde of yours, who for the lewdnes of a fewe, ſclander the whole order: But where finde you, that any prieſt blamed laufull mariadg, as you ſay?Fol. 129. a. VVhere finde youe that they counte it a life diſſolute? VVhere finde you that they take it a ſatisfying of luſtes of the fleaſh? The places that you alleaged before in the fourth article when you ſpoke of matrimony out of Innocentius, and Syricius, ſpeake only of prieſts and deacons, that vowed chaſtity, and made a ſolemne promiſe to God,110. a b Diſtin. 82. cap. propo ſuiſti. Diſtin. 82. cap. qu • a. The mariadg of prieſts cō demned. that they woulde lyue a ſole and ſingle life: and for them to marry and breake their vowes, for them to take woemen, and vndoe their promiſe made to God, not only Innocentius, and Siricius and all other Catholick biſhops and prieſtes, but all godly lay men that are learned in the ſcripture, or otherwiſe zelous in the ſetting foorth of Gods honour, counte it, all to gether vnlauful, a life diſſolute, and ſatisfying of carnal luſtes, and that worthely. For both the woorde of God, decrees of Emperours, and ſtatutes of princes do condemne it for ſuch.

In our realme of England you haue a lawe againſt the vnlauful mariadg of prieſtes, ſtāding ſtill in his full force to all effectes at this preſent, which condemneth all your married mounkes, friers, and Apoſtatats of diſobedience to God, and their
prince for theire vnlawfull marriadgs. If youe haue no better proufe than theſe decrees of Innocentius, we may ſcore vp thre lyes more. For firſt we blame not lawfull marriadg, but the marriadg of prieſts, which is altogether vnlaufull. Secondarely we thinke it a life diſſolute in none,Thre lies. but in prieſts and ſuch as haue vowed chaſtitie. Thirdly we accompt it a ſatisfying of the fleaſh in none but in prieſts as before, and ſeing we eſteme it only vnlawfull in them, what honeſtie is there in youe to ſay indefinitely,Fol. 129. a that we blame lawfull marriadg? VVhat charitie to affirme that al we ſoole lyued prieſtes practiſe, al for the moſte parte adultrie? and vſe viler ſhyftes, than Saturnus, the idolatrous prieſt? howe proue youe it? howe iuſtifie yow it? what euidēce haue youe for it? yf you haue none in ſtore, find ſome I aduiſe you, the tyme may come whē you ſhal be dryuē to ſhewe your proufes.

Fol. 129. aYou appeale to my cōſciēce whether I knowe it to be ſo or no, and I anſwer before God, in my cōſcience I do not knowe it to be ſo, nor euer did. VVhatſoeuer enormitie or fault was ſeuerely puniſhed in VVyncheſter at my aboode there (as many were both by me, and their diſcrete, ſober, and vertuous ſchole maſter at that tyme, I proteſte before God, I knowe no other that taught them any euill, than he that teacheth men all wickednes and euill, that is Sathan the authour and deuiſer of all iniquitie and euil. For my owne behauiour there, I will ſay nothīg for auoyding of vanitie. Let the world iudge, and the ſchollers and their frendes, for whoſe ſakes, I tooke that tedious paynes of enducation wittneſſe, and ſay of me as they knowe.

Fol 129. aVVhere you threaten bluddely that you will vnripp the lifes of our popiſh doctours, and of our ſelues, I beſeeke you ſay what you can. VVhen all your venemous blaſtes are blowen, when all the poiſon of your ſerpētine tongue is ſpet out, when all the rancored malice, and feſtred hate of your euangelicall ſtomake is diſgorged, you ſhall hurt our cauſe no more, than other heretikes did the Catholicke faith, by like rayling and ſclaūdring the fathers in thoſe daies. And ſeing our ſauiour and
M. Chriſte was called a Samaritane, a man that had a diuel, Ioan. 8. Matt. 11. Act. 26. Act. 17. Iuſt. Mar. in Apol 2. a frend of Publicans, a wyne bibber, and S. Paule a madbrayne, a woorde ſower, a preacher of deuills, The Apoſtles dronckardes, the Chriſtiās that followed them, eaters of mens fleaſh, wicked adulterers, and curſed Atheiſts, and in other ages other ſclaunders haue bene raiſed vpon the catholikes, as S.Greg. Nazian. in Monod. Baſile was ſclaundred to haue had a woman in his chamber,Libr. 2. ca 24. Tripart. Euſtachius that he had a ſonne by an harlot,Euſeb. lib. 10. ca. 18. hiſt. Athanaſius that he rauiſhed a woman, cut ofIbidem. Arſenius arme, vſed ſorcery, ſtirred aLib. 4. ca. 17. Tri. ſedition in Alexandria, deceaued poore men ofLi. 4 c 19 Tripart. corne ſent from the Emperours, and burnt the holy bookes, and ſo likewiſe diuerſe other, certainly it ſhall nothing greaue vs to heare the heape of ſclaunders and venemous woordes that you ſhall falſely lay to your charge, and haue lerned of Martin Luther and frier Bale. That confortable ſaying of our ſauiour Chriſte: Beati eritis quum maledixerint vobis, mentientes propter me: Ye ſhall be happie, when they ſhall ſpeake euill of you, lying for my ſake, ſhall be our preſeruatiue againſt all our poiſon. Begynne whē ye will:Li. 4. ca. 24. Trip. he that ſhall feele hī ſelf giltie in cō ſcience, ſhall haue occaſion thereby to lament his ſinnes, and do the worthy fruictes of penaunce, and yf he take it patiently, haue merite by your miſchief.

As for my ſelf, when you haue ſaied all that you can, I truſt yf all the worlde turne into proteſtants, and they all refuſe me, yet he that ſhall iudge them and all the world, will receaue me, who as Chryſoſtome ſaieth, ſpeaketh theſe confortable woordes of the ſynner. Licet omnes homines, Matt. 5. Ho. 21. ad pop. Anti. licet daemones cum diabolo conſtituti ipſum accuſent de turpiſsimis & occultis criminibus, non reijcio, non abhominor, ſed ab accuſatoribus ipſum liberans, & ab iniquitate abſoluēs, ſic ad certamina duco. Albeit all men in the world, albeit all the ſprites with the deuill in hell, accuſe him of moſt fylthie and priuie faultes, I do not reiect him, I do not abhorre him, but delyuering him from his accuſers, and abſoluing him from iniquitie, I bring him in ſuch ſorte to fight. VVhen the woman accuſed of the Iewes to our ſauiour Chriſte for adultrie was rigorouſlie exacted to puniſhment after the lawes of Moyſes, Chriſte ſaied vnto them, let him that is without ſynne amongeſt you, caſt the firſt ſtone at her. Ioan 8. So ſay I to
you M. Calf. yf you thinke your ſelf faultleſſe, prepare your ſling, let flee your ſtones, our pauice is ready, and ſhield prepared, to receaue your ſtrokes.

In Pſal. 36 A cōfortable ſaying agaīſt the rayling of heretikes.Againſt that famous libel of yours come, I will deſire all Catholickes to arme them ſelues with patience. I will ſay vnto them, as S. Auguſtine ſaied to his people: Let them ſpeake againſt vs what they will. Let vs loue them againſt their wil. For we knowe dearelie beloued bretheren, we knowe their tongues. VVherefor let vs not be angrie with thē, haue patience as well as we haue. For they ſee that they haue no aduantadge in the cauſe, and they turne their tōgues againſt vs, and begyn to ſpeake euill of vs: many thinges which they knowe, many thinges which they do not knowe. Thoſe thinges that they knowe, are our offences paſt. For we haue bene, as the Apoſtle ſaieth, foliſh, and incredulous, and vnwilling to all good woorkes, we haue bene doting, and madding in peruerſe errour, we denye it not, and in aſmuche as we denie not our infirmitie paſt, ſo much do we praiſe God that hath pardoned it: and yf they reproue vs, do you contemne it.

In Pſal. 36 To M. Calf.And to you ſir with the ſame holy father I ſay: Quid ergo haeretice dimittis cauſam & is ad hominem? Quid enim ego ſum? Quid ſum? nunquid eccleſia catholica ego ſum? etc. VVhy doeſt thou o hereticke forſake the cauſe, and goe to the man? For what am I? Am I the Catholicke churche? Am I the heritage of Chriſte, diſperſed through out the world? It ſuffiſeth me that I am in it. Thou doeſt reproue my offences paſt: what greate thing doeſt thou? I am more ſeuere in my owne offences then thoue art. That which thou reproueſt, I haue condemned. O, would to God thou wouldeſt followe, that thy errour myght alſo at lenght be paſt. VVithall, to the reader I ſay out of the ſame father, Yf we be good men, we be wheate in the church: To the reader. Yf we be euill men we be chaffe in the churche, yet for all that, we go not from the flooer. Thou that fleeſt away with the winde of tēptation, what art thou? wheate? Yf thou were wheate, the winde ſhould not driue the frō the flooer. VVherefore by the place where thou art, agniſe and acknowledge what thou art. VVhat we are he knoweth to whom we make our mone.

Matt. 23. Of euil men it is ſaied, ſcribes & phariſees haue ſate vppon the chaire of Moyſes. Do what they ſay, but do not what they do: by whiche youe ſee, that in the chaire of Moyſes, for whiche the chaire of Chriſte ſucceded, euill
men ſitte, and yet for all that by ſaying well hurt not their hearers. VVherfore doeſt thou then forſake the chaier for euill men? O man Redi ad pacē, redi ad concordiam quae te non offendit, etc. Returne to vnitie, In Pſal. 36 returne to peace and concorde, which hath not offended the. Yf I ſay well, and do well, followe me. Yf I do not as I ſay, thou haſt the counſell of our ſauiour Chriſte, do as I ſay, but do not as I do. And for all this, go not away from the Catholick chaire, from the vnitie of the churche. Embrace the truth, who ſo euer ſpeake it. This I thought good to admoniſh the gentle reader out of S. Auguſtine, not becauſe my conſcience is witting of any of thoſe horrible and haynous crimes whiche that wicked Neroniſt by his lewde ſurmiſe woulde make men ſuſpect, but that thoue mayeſt vnderſtand that no Chriſtē man ought to diſcredite the truth, nor forſake the churche, for the lewdnes of the rulers and gourenours.

Nowe you ſhall ſee what a bone he geueth me to picke out of Chriſoſtome. VVhereas he ſpeaketh of houſes, marketts, Fol. 129. b Fol. 130. a Calf. wilderneſſes, high waies, ſeas, ſhippes, Garments, Parlours, walles windowes, armour, and ſuche other thinges, where the croſſe ſhoulde be, only he ſaieth not (quoth M. Calf.) that he croſſe was in the church. Reckoning vp ſo many, woulde he haue forgotten the chief, yf any ſuch ordre had bene receaued then? It is not credible. This is M. Calfhils bare bone,Matt. bare I ſay, becauſe it hath no honeſtie nor truth in it. For Chryſoſtome ſpeaketh in the very ſame place of the croſſe in the church, theſe are his woordes:In demōſt cōt. Genti. All men ſigne them ſelues often tymes with the croſſe, by printing of it in the nobleſt parte of our bodie. For it is figured and made dailie in our forheades. So it ſhineth in the holy table. So it ſhineth in the conſecrating and ordring of prieſts. So it ſhyneth againe with the bodie of Chriſt in the myſticall ſuppers.

This Chryſoſtome there, within three lynes, before the other woordes recited, by M. Calf.The croſſe in the church mētioned by S Chriſoſtome. And yf the croſſe were in the holie table was it not in the churche? VVhere was the holie table, but in the churche? In Chryſoſtoms tyme, Churches were not dentie. Euery citie had them honorablie adorned for the vſe of Gods ſeruice. Is it credible then that where he ſaieth, The croſſe
was in the holy table, in the body of Chriſte, in the myſticall ſuppers, that he ſaied, it was not, in the churche? VVhat reaſonable man would thinke ſo? None, but M. Calf. He that ſaieth this or that is, in the holy table, ſaieth that it is in the churche. For none or very fewe holie tables, were without the church at that tyme: but you ſee good people, what a ſtrong piller you haue to leane vnto, and what a wiſe miniſter to be your reader, that muſt face out ſo euident, ſo manifeſt and playne a truth with ſuch a ſhamefull lye.

Ser. 130. de Temp. de cruce & latro. Fol. 130 aYf his leſſons, and ſermons be no truer than his aſſertions in this booke, youe may harken longe, and heare many a lye before you ſhall heare any truth. VVherefore vnleſſe your eares, ytche with hearing lying vanities, ſpend no more tyme in hearīg ſuche vayne liers. His drift is naught els, but either with gay coloured woordes to blinde youe, or with deſtroying one truth with an other to deceaue youe.

VVhere S. Auguſtine ſaice: Before the croſſe was a name of condemnation, nowe it is made a matter of honour, before it ſtode in damnation of a curſe, nowe it it is ſet vp in occaſion of ſaluation, M. Calf. ſaieth: That S. Auguſtine ſpeaketh not here of a myſticall or material croſſe, but of the paſsion of Chriſte. VVherein with a lewde breath he maketh a loude lie, and yet in ſome thing telleth a true a tale. For that S. Auguſtine ſpeaketh there of the paſsion, it is true. That he ſpeaketh not of the material croſſe, it is moſte falſe. And that it may, the better appeare, iudge your ſelues. In this very place S. Auguſtine making a difference betwene the croſſe of the olde lawe, and the croſſe of the newe lawe, and comparing them together ſaieth,

The croſſe in the old lavve and the croſſe in the nevve lavveBefore (that is to ſay in the olde lawe, before the paſsion of Chriſte) the croſſe was a name of condemnation, but nowe (it) what is that (it) M. Calf? The Croſſe which was before the name of condemnation, is made a thing of honour. Before (it) that is to ſay the croſſe which was before a name of cōdemnation, ſtode in damnation of a curſe, to witt as a curſed ſigne of dānatiō, nowe it, what is that (it) M. Calf.? forſoth the croſſe that was before, the name of condemnation, is ſet vp in occaſion of ſaluation.
Yf then the croſſe which in the old lawe was a name of condemnation, and ſet as a curſed ſigne of damnation, was a material croſſe, certes the croſſe in the newe lawe, made a thing of honour, and erected in ſigne of ſaluatiō, muſt as S. Auguſtine there meaneth, be a materiall croſſe: and not only the paſsion. For otherwiſe his compariſon can not ſtand. And this my geſſe is more agreable to S. Auguſtines minde, than all the aſſurance, that M. Calf. hath to the contrary. VVherefore my collection, made of S. Auguſtines woordes, that as then the material croſſe was a name of ignominie, ſo nowe the material croſſe is a thing of honour, is not vayne, as M. Calf. ſaieth,Fol. 130. a. but his fanſie very fonde, who becauſe the ſcripture do not accompt the wood of which the gallowes was made accurſed, thinketh that in this place of S. Auguſtine, there is no materiall croſſe mentioned. VVherebie ye haue ſome triall of your miniſters witte, but ſuch witte, ſuch wiſdome, ſuch knowledg, ſuch aſſuraunce.

To another place of S. Auguſtine following immediatlie in my booke, where expreſſe mention is made alſo of an externall ſigne of the croſſe, he ſaieth not as much as one woorde. By like his lippes were tyed.Li. 3. de vita Conſtā. Likewiſe to the place of Euſebius who declared that Conſtātine the great, made the ſigne of the croſſe in his forhead, and paynted it in a table and ſett it vp on high at his courte gate, he ſaieth naught in effect,Fol. 130. b. but that he did repoſe no holynes in it, nor euer brought it into any of the churches, which he builded, and for proufe of it bringeth not ſo much as one woorde out of ſcripture, councel or auncient father as full gloriouſly he bragged in the firſt front of his booke. VVherfore ſith his ſight in the Greke is ſo ſlender, that he knoweth not howe to trāſlate the Aoriſts truly, ſith his ignorāce vnderſtādeth not the fathers writings, ſeing he refuſeth ceremonies, cuſtomes and traditions, which the Apoſtles deliured and cōmaūded, and the Catholike church hitherto neuer abrogated, nor he nor his are to be thought other then falſe Apoſtles, cōtēners of their ordinances, deſpiſers of their traditiōs, diſcrediters of the aunciēt fathers, and diſauthoriſers of their lerned woorkes, for all their glorious wordes and ſhameleſſe crakes.

div.head: THAT DIVERSE HOLY MEN, AND WOEMEN GOTTE THEM LITLE PIECES OF THE HOLY CROSSE, and incloſed them in gold, &c. THE SIXT ARTICLE.
div.p:
AGAINST this Article M. Calf. bringeth nothing worthie of anſwer. In the beginning he alleadgeth a mangled place of Tertullian,Fol. 131. a De velandis virg. to proue that Chriſt called not him ſelfe cuſtome, but truthe: againſt which no perſon, no ſpace of time, no maiſterſhipe of men, no priuiledge of cuntries can preſcribe: VVhich ſeing euery Chriſten mā graunteth, that idle allegation mighte well haue ben ſpared. In the nexte page he proueth that the fathers of the old and newe Teſtamēt, are not to be drawen alwaies for example, and for that he alleadgeth a place of S.Lib. 2. cōt. epiſt. Gaudētij ca. 23 Auguſtine, which in dede in the ſenſe that the authour meaneth is both godly and true. For diſputing there againſt the Donatiſts murdering thē ſelues, becauſe they would be Martirs, and defending their willfulnes by ſcripture, and the example of Razias that killed him ſelfe, becauſe he woulde not come into the handes of his enemies, that would murder hym, he ſayeth more largely, and otherwyſe than our M. miniſter hath recited. Non itaque debemus quicquid etiam Dei teſtimonio laudatos homines feciſſe legerimus, conſentiendo approbare, ſed conſiderando diſcernere,
adhibentes iudicium non ſane noſtrae authoritatis, ſed ſcripturarū diuinarum atque ſanctarum etc. VVe muſt not therfore allowe by conſent whatſoeuer we reade in ſcripture that men commended by God him ſelfe haue done, but we muſt diſcerne with diſcretion, not taking the iudgemēt of our authoritie, but of diuine and holy ſcripture, which doth not permitte vs neither to imitate, nor to commend, the factes of thoſe men, who in the ſcriptures haue good teſtimonie, yf any thinge were done otherwiſe than well of them, or not conuenient for this time: as you muſt not followe, nor commēd Razias that killed him ſelfe,2. Mac. 14. Dauid that committed murder, and adulterye, nor Salomō that departed his bodie to ſo many Concubines, nor Peter that denied his M. and ventered to waulke vpon the water, alhoughe eche of theſe men haue their ſpeciall commendation in ſcripture. And why muſt we not followe thoſe holy men? Becauſe in thoſe thinges they did naughte, and contrarie to ſcripture. And this is the meaning of S. Auguſtines rule, full wide God wott from M.No man to be forbidden to follovve the vertuous examples of the aūciēt fathers. Calfhills purpoſe. For if they, or any other man did any thing agreable to ſcripture, conuenient for the time, or profitable to edifying, no man is forbid to followe them. Yea it is againſt all reaſon that any man ſhoulde be inhibited to imitate thē. VVherfore vnleſſe this our aduerſarie and enemie of Chriſtes Croſſe, had firſt proued that Helena, Paulinus, Gregorius, who gotte litle pieces of the croſſe, and ſet them in gold or ſiluer, had done euil and againſt the expreſſe ſcripture, he ſhould neuer haue alleadged that place of S. Auguſtine. For as euery wiſe man knoweth that he ought not to followe the factes and miſdoings of the old and auncient men in euill: So no man is ſo ignorant,Hovve fa • forth examples may be follovved but vnderſtandeth that it is laufull for him to followe their examples in all workes of veritie, ſo far forthe as the time will ſerue, and their habilitye beare. But he had forgott that, and thought it ynough to ſaye: They had a zeale, but not according to knowledge, and call Helena ſuperſtitious, and S. Fol 132 a He • ena ſuperſtitious. S Gregorie fabulous. Gregorie and Nicephorus fabulous, vntill ſome good ſage father Bizias had tolde him, that S. Hierome reproued the hauing, and incloſing of pieces of the croſſe, and willed him to ſeeke for it in his commentaries vpon S. Mathewe. Then as though he had gotten a great
praye,Halfe a ſentence out of S. Hierom mangled & vvreſted. Matth. 23. in he layeth halfe ſentence of S. Hierome, and triumpheth as though he had wonne the fielde. But that you may ſee howe he mangleth the Doctour and wreaſteth him for his purpoſe, I will repete S. Hieroms wordes that goe before.

Expounding theſe wordes of the Ghoſpell, Dilatant enim philacteria ſua etc. For they ſette abroade their philacteries, or broode gardes of their cootes, and ſo forthe, he ſaieth. VVoe be vnto vs miſerable men to whome the faultes of the Phariſies are come. VVhen God had geuen the commaundements of the lawe by Moyſes, at the laſt he ſaid, Thou ſhalt tye them in thy hand, and they ſhalbe immoueable frrome thy eies, and this is his meaninge, let my commaundements be in thy handes, that they may be fulfilled in dede. Let them be before thy eies, that thou maiſt muſe on them day and nighte. The Phariſees not wel conſtruing this, wrote the x. commaundements in parchement, foolding them, and tying them in their foreheades, The phariſees vnder ſtode not Gods commaū dement. and making as it were a garlonde for their heades, that allwaies they might be moued before their eies, which the Indians, Perſians, Babylonians, do at this preſent: and he that hath this, is cownted religious amōgeſt the people, and ſo foorth, much in that ſenſe. At lēghte to come nere to our purpoſe, he ſayeth: Thoſe frontlettes, or filletts in which the precepts of the lawe were written they called philacteries, becauſe whoſoeuer had them, had them, as it were for a ſafegarde, or defence of them ſelues. VVhere the Phariſees vnderſtoode not that the commaundements were to be caried in the hearte, and not in the bodie. For otherwiſe ſtudies and cheſtes haue bookes, and haue not the knowledge of God. This doe ſuperſtitious woemen at this day with vs in litle Ghoſpells, and pieces of the Croſſe, which haue the zeale of God, but not according to knowledge, ſtrayning a knatt, and ſwallowing a camell.

The ſuperſtitious of the phariſees and vvomen that S. Hierō mētioned in a manner alone.Thus much S. Hierome complayning of the iniquitie of the time, and hipocriſie of men that doe in manner as the Phariſees did, gette the worde of God, beare it in their handes, and leye it in their windowes, but did not lodge it in their heartes. Furder as the Phariſees hauing the ſkirts and hems of their cotes leid with ſcripture, thought them ſelues defended ſufficiently with the bare characters, although they had none in their hartes: So in S. Hieroms tyme ſome ſuperſtitious woemē gotte lite Ghoſpells, and pieces of the croſſe, and as the Phariſees did (for ſo
ſaieth the text) Hoc faciunt, they do this, that is to ſay, hanged it aboute their necks, and thought them ſelues well armed with them, although they had not the inward faith in their myndes, as the Phariſees had not the commandements in their heartes. For which only S. Hierom calleth them ſuperſtitious, and women that haue a zeale, but not according to knowledge. He cō pareth not the pieces of the croſſe to the Phariſees philacteries. He thought it no fonde thing to be incloſed, caried about, or woorſhipped of any: for he him ſelf ſaieth:S. Hierom vvoorſhipped the croſſe. Apolog. 3. cōt. K • ff Incunabula • . VVhen will that day come that it ſhalbe laufull for vs to go into the denne of our ſauiour, to weepe in the ſepulchre of our lorde with the ſiſter, to weepe with the mother, and afterward to kiſſe or licke the wood of the croſſe? Again in another place he ſaieth: By and by I returned in all haſt to my Bethlehem, I adored the manger, and the ſwathling clothes of my ſauiour. By which it is manifeſt that S. Hierome thought it no fonde thing, nor to haue, nor to keepe, nor to worſhippe, nor to adore the ſigne of the croſſe. But he miſliked ſuche ſuperſtitious womē,In Maatt. 23. ho. 43. as had litle Ghoſpells and pieces of the croſſe, as the Phariſees had the commaundemēts in their philacteries, that is without fayth in their myndes, and good woorkes in their heartes. And ſo doth Chriſoſtome in the place alleaged. For he ſaieth: Howe can the Ghoſpels hanged aboute ones necke ſaue him, whereas being heard of ſome they profite them nothing? Again, where is the vertue of the Ghoſpell? In the figures of the lettres or in the vnderſtanding of the ſenſe? Yf it be in the ſigne of the lettres, then wel doeſt thou hange them aboute thy necke. Yf in the vnderſtanding, then woulde it profite more, repoſed in they hearte than hanged about thy necke.

By this it is euidēt that in his tyme,VVhat prieſtes Chriſoſtome rebuked. ſome prieſts were as full of hipocriſe as the Phariſees, and woulde hange the Ghoſpell aboute their neckes, and not haue it in their heartes, and haue a piece of Chriſtes coate ād heare thincking to be holpē more by that, than by the worthie receauing, of Chriſtes bodye. Thoſe Chryſoſtome blamed, thoſe he called foliſh prieſts: of them he ſaieth: O impietatem, O what impietie is this. He did not abſolutely condemne the hanging of Ghoſpels, pieces of Chriſtes cote, and heare about them, but he condemned their folly and hiprocriſie
in thinking more vertue to be in it than in true faith and the body of Chriſt it ſelf. VVhen two thinges are to be done, Chriſt ſaied:Mat. 23. Luc. 11. Haec oportet facere, illa non omittere. Theſe thinges you muſt do, and not omitte thoſe. On like yf either thoſe woemen that S. Hierome ſpoke of or theſe prieſts that S. Chryſoſtome mentioneth, would needes haue kept litle Ghoſpells, pieces of the croſſe,VVhy S. Hierom and Chriſoſtome rebuked thoſe that incloſed pieces of the croſſe &c. Fol. 132. b and reliques of our lordes cote, and heare, they ſhould not haue omitted the other which was the moſte chiefeſt and principalſt, that is, true faith and vertuous life: But becauſe they did ſo, and put to much affiance in thoſe outwarde thinges. S. Hierome and Chryſoſtome did reproue thē, not becauſe it was euill of it ſelf, but with ſuch a circunſtances as they vſed, moſte wicked, and intolerable.

Thus haue I layed downe all affection as you requeſted me, and ſpoke out my conſcience of theſe places of S. Hierome and Chryſoſtome, and ſhewed that they make nothing againſt me, nor condemne any errour of myne. For I mayntayne none, but aduouche moſte vndoubted truthes, whiche I haue receaued of the Catholik churche. S. Hierome a lerned man, hath nothing contrary to Helena,Fol. 133. a a ſilly womā, S. Hierome a receaued doctour hath nothing in this place againſt Nicephorus a ſuſpected writer, Ibidem. Ibidem. as youe ſay. S. Hierome a Cardinall hath nothing contrary to Paulinus a biſshop. S. Hierome a ſainct canoniſed, hath nothing contrary to Gregorie, a ſainct alſo canoniſed. Chriſoſtome alſo hath nothīg agaīſt the hauīg of ſuch pieces of the croſſe, as may well apeare by his woorke againſt the gentills, where he declareth that the Chriſtians in his daies were very deſirous to haue pieces of the croſſe, and for a great treaſure incloſed them in gold or ſiluer.

Fol. 133 a Calf. Mart.But quoth M. Calf. it is not to be thought that Chriſoſtome ſpooke that is a praiſe of the parties, but a practiſe of tyme. Full wiſely, God wotte, and like a profounde clerke, well ſeene in Chryſoſtome. In all his diſcourſe there, he doth ſo highly commend the vertue of the croſſe, ſo ofren repete it, and with ſuche woordes inculcate the ſame, that no wiſe man can ſee, but
that he ſpeaketh all that is ſpoken in cōmendation of the croſſe, as a praiſe of the parties that vſed it, and commended the fact to be laufull, and not only a practiſe of the tyme as he fanſieth.Chriſoſtome cōmē deth the hauing of croſſes incloſing of them in gold. The croſſe euery vvhere. For example, when he ſaied, This accurſed, this abhominable, this ſigne of extreme puniſhemennt (that is the croſſe) is made more briter than princes crownes and coronets, ſpoke he that as a practiſſe of the tyme, or a praiſe of the thing? ſpeake M. Calf. when he ſaied, euery man ſeketh the croſſe, we ſee it with princes, with ſubiectes, with men and womē, we may ſe the croſſe euery where, in houſes, market places, high wayes etc. All men ſo gredylie, take vnto them this wonderfull gift? Spoke he that for a practiſſe of the tyme only or praiſe of the parties? Anſwer Maſter Calf. when he ſaied,No Chriſten man aſhamed of the croſſe. This is a maruelous grace, no man is confounded, no man is aſhamed, thinking that it was a token of a curſed death, but all men are more adourned with it, than with princes crownes or ouches ſett with precious ſtone, or chaynes of Gold, and it is not only not ſhunned, but it is deſired, it is loued, all men are hoofull for it. Spoke the that as a practiſe of the time, only, or as a praiſe of the parties? when he ſaied to the gentil, Yf thou thinkeſt this to be nothing, but remayneſt impudent as yet, and ſetteſt they ſelf againſt the truth, and art blinde in the cleare light, learne by an other argumēt, what maner of thing this is and of what vertue. Tell me from whē ce cometh ſo great zeale, and care of it, that it is ſo deſired of all men, and worthier to be deſired thā al thinges? All Chriſten men deſire the croſſe. VVhy do all the worlde ſo earneſtly deſire to haue that wood in which the holy bodie of our lorde was ſette, in ſo muche that whoſoeuer haue a litle piece of it, incloſe it in gold, as well men as women: and make it meete for their neckes, by that rightlie honeſted, and honored, defended, and garded, although ſometymes it was the wood of condemnation? ſpoke he that as a practiſſe of the tyme only, and not as a praiſe of the parties, and for the laufulnes of the facte? Laye downe all affection and to condemne your owne errour, ſpeake out your conſcience, doth he not labour to proue vnto the pagane the vertue of the croſſe, becauſe al men did honour it, all men deſired it, all men were glad of it, yea all the world labored earneſtlie, to haue it, and when they had any piece of it incloſed in Gold, and kepte it as a treaſure, and though them ſelues honoured, and defended with it? And if their facte
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
had bene wicked, and the hauing of it a ſhame to the Chriſtians, woulde ſo eloquent a preacher, and writer as Chriſoſtome was, haue vſed no other reaſon, but ſuch as afterward (yf yower ſayinges were true) might turne him to perpetuall ſhame? Yf only ſome priuate men had vſed that of zeale (as you fanſie,) would ſo holie a father haue made ſo impudēt a lye? and ſaid, No man is aſhamed of it, No man is confounded with it, No man bluſheth at it? But all men deſire it, all men loue it, all men are gladde of it, all the world did earneſtly labour to haue it? No ſir, No: you take the marke amiſſe. The vertue of Chryſoſtome, and ſo impudent a lye can not ſtande together.

VVherfore vnleſſe yow haue ſome other ſhifte, yow may putte vp yower Pipes. This is too groſſe to ſaye. All the Chriſtians in thoſe dayes were will worſhippers. All the Chriſtians deſired willinglye and wittinglye that which turned to their ſhame. All the worlde was deceaued, and wandred in errours, vanities, and idle toyes. For it is playne that S. Chryſoſtome dothe not talke of the facte of a fewe priuate men, but of all the woorlde, yf Totus Orbis in yower Calepine be al the worlde. Other thinge there is none in all the Article, worthie of anſwere, but a fewe lyes, of whiche yow ſhal heare more hereafter.

div.head: THAT A CROSSE WAS BORNE AT THE SINGING OR SAYING OF THE LITANIE: &c. THE 7. ARTICLE.
div.p:
HERE vpon light occaſion M. Calf. maketh an extrauagant diſcourſe of litanies and proceſsions, and like a true man maketh three notable lyes one after another: One that proceſsiōs came firſt from gētilytie. Fol. 138. b Another that neuer Chriſten men vſed proceſsions before the Montaniſtes and Arrians, as he read. The third that Papiſtes degenerate from all good order. That proceſsions came from Gentilitie to the Chriſtiās,Ibidem. Fol. 139. a it is vtterly falſe. They came to vs from the traditions of the Apoſtles, and doctrine of the holy Ghoſt, ergo not from Gentilitie. The antecedent I proue after this ſorte.Proceſſiōs a tradition of the Apoſtles, and doctrine of the holy ghoſt. VVhatſoeuer is retayned of the church into cuſtome of deuotiō, cometh of the traditiō of the Apoſtles and doctrine of the holy ghoſt, but proceſsiōs haue bē retayned in the church into cuſtome of deuotiō, ergo they came frō the traditiō of the Apoſtles, and doctrine of the holy ghoſt. The Maior is Leo his poſitiō in his ſecōd ſermō of the faſt of Pentecoſt, and S. Auguſt. doctrine in his hundred and eightene epiſtle: the minor is, manifeſt by the aūciēt, and cōtinued practiſſe of the church vncōtrolled to this preſent:Al that come frō gentilitie muſt not be condē ned. which being true, the concluſion muſt of neceſsitie followe, that it came not from gentilitie, but from the firſt profeſſours of Chriſtianitie. but be it that proceſsion came, from Gentilitie: VVill M. Calfs witte, ſerue him to condemne it for that? Becauſe the liberall
ſciences came frō the gentills, and the lerned Philoſophers who did not woorſhip God, ſhall we cōdemne the liberall ſciences? Becauſe diuerſe policies and lawes came to vs from the Gentills, ſhall we condemne thoſe policies and lawes? That were pieuiſh policie and lawleſſe libertie. And yet ſo doe our newe maſters, and eſpecially this croſſebiter. For he ſaieth, images come from gentilitie, croſſes from gentilie, proceſsions from gentilie, ergo images croſſes, and proceſsions muſt be condemned: but howe fonde it is conſider by that I ſaied before.

The Manichees vpbraied the catholikes of olde, that they retayned many cuſtomes and manners of the Gentills, as this our good newe maſter miniſter doth vs at this preſent, but as S. Auguſtine anſwered thoſe wicked hereticks, ſo do we this pieuiſh proteſtant not knowing, what he ſaieth. Seing (ſaieth S. Auguſtine) the iuſt man liueth of faith, Lib 20 ca. 23 contra Fauſt. Ma. Rom 1. 1. Tim. 1. 1. Cor. 13. Diuerſitie of faith hope, and charitie, maketh a diuerſitie of māners and the end of the commandement is charitie out of a pure heart, good conſcience, and vnfayned faith, and thoſe three, faith, hope, and charitie remaine, to confirme the life of the faithfull, howe can it be, that he ſhould haue like manners and cuſtomes with any man that hath not theſe three faith, hope, and charitie like with him? For he that beleaueth otherwiſe, hopeth otherwiſe, and loueth otherwiſe, muſt neades lyue otherwiſe. And yf the vſe of certaine thinges be like betwene vs and the gentills, as of meate, drinke, houſes, garmēts, waſshings, marying and hauing of wiues, for them that will followe that kynd of life, begetting of children, bringing them vp, and purchaſing of landes for them, yet for all that, he vſeth theſe thinges far otherwiſe, that referreth the vſe of them, to another end, and he otherwiſe who for them geueth thankes to God, of whome he beleaueth no ſiniſtrous nor euill thing. For as you in your errour, whereas ye eate the ſame bread that other men do eate, and lyue with the ſame fruict and water, and are clothed with lynnen and wollen as other men are, and yet for all that, in theſe thinges eſteme not your life equall, not for eating and drinking any other thing, nor for hauing any other apparell, but by thinking and beleauing otherwiſe and referring theſe thinges to another end: So we bothe in thoſe thinges, and other which we take in like, do not lyue in like with the Gentills, referring the ſame thinges to one like end, but to the end of the commaundement of God, to charitie iſſuing out of a pure heart, good conſciēce, and vnfayned faith: from
which ſome men wandring, haue ben turned into vayne babling. In which you beare the bell, not ſeing nor conſidering, that in doing and hauing of like thinges, it is ſufficient only to make the life to be different, yf the faith be diuerſe. Thus much S. Auguſtine. So that yf we had receaued images, croſſes, and proceſsions of gentilitie, yet becauſe we vſe them otherwiſe than the gentills did, we referre them to another end thā they did, neither are we to be blamed, nor the thinges them ſelues condemned no more than liberall ſciences becauſe they come from the heathen Philoſophers, nor yet policies, and lawes, becauſe they came from the gentills.

That the Chriſtened neuer vſed proceſsions before the Montaniſtes, and Arians, Tertul. li. 2 ad vxor. Euſeb lib. 6 cap. 8. Eccleſiaſ. hiſtor. Ceremonies of the Chriſtiās in Tertulliās tyme. neither doth it apeare by Tertullian nor Euſebius in theſe places noted by M. Calfhill in the margent. Tertullian writing to his wife telleth her, (being a Chriſtē woman) that yf ſhe mary after his death with a gētil, ſhe ſhoud not obſerue the orders and ceremonies of the Chriſtiās, as their ſtations, faſtinges, viſitation of the ſick, meetings in the night, watching in the churche at Eſter, reſorting to our lordes banket, viſiting the priſonners, waſhing holy mens feete, kyſsing of the bretherene, and making the ſigne of the croſſe: but as for any ceremonie or odre of proceſsion or other that the Montaniſtes and their prophetiſſes vſed, he ſpeaketh not ſo much as one woorde. Euſebius in the 7. chapiter of the ſixt boke talketh of one Narciſſus, biſshop ſometyme of Hieruſalem, who at the ſolemne feaſt of eaſter,VVater turned in to Oyle by miracle to ſerue for light in the churche. whereas they lacked oyle for their lightes commaunded water to be filled and brought vnto him, and when the water was brought, orauit & benedixit aquam, he praied and bleſt the water, and when he had ſo done the water turned into oyle, and gaue a more clearer light, than euer it did before: this was done in the raigne of Seuerus, a hundred yeres before Arius began his hereſie. VVherfore vnleſſe, he had better prouf for this negatiue, we will enrroll him amongeſt the negatiue doctours of whom the common rule, Plus poteſt aſinus negare etc. may be truly verified.

Concerning the third lye that papiſts degenerate from all good order in proceſsion, (for ſo he meaneth there) you ſhal ſee
howe fond it is.Cap 33. The councell of Mentes, kept viij. hundred and thirtene yeres after Chriſt, made this decree. Our will is that the greater Litanie be obſerued of all Chriſtians three dayes: Sicut legendo reperimus, as by reading we fynd (whiche woordes, M. Calf. leaueth out) and our holy fathers ordayned, not ryding nor hauing precious garments on them, but bare foted, in ſack cloth, and aſhes, vnleſſe infirmitie do let. This Canon ſpeaketh of the proceſsion, whiche the fathers vſed in the rogatiō weeke before aſcenſion day,In cap. 7. 1. ad Cor. Proceſsiō in S. Ambroſe time. Cap. 29. Fol. 138. a betwene eaſter and witſontide: of whiche S. Ambroſe who liued in the yere of our lord 380. maketh mention calling them Dies proceſsionis, the dayes of proceſsion, and the firſt councell kept at Orleance, in the yere of our lorde 515. calling them Rogationes, Rogations, and yet M. Calfhil ſaieth we reade not of proceſsions, before Agapetus daies, in the yere of our lord 533. VVhereby you may ſee what a diligent ſtudient, and great reader he is.

In thoſe proceſsions riding, precious apparell, as well of men as women, Eccleſiaſticall, as ſecular, were forbidden. And the Canon was euer obſerued niſi infirmitas impedierit, vnleſſe infirmitie did lette: we ride not in proceſsion: we put not on our beſt apparell: we were no copes. VVherfore albeit in other ꝓceſsiōs at home in Cathedral churches on high daies, for more ſolennitie and honour of the feaſt, the churche vſeth copes, yet do we not degenerate from all good order, we do not contrary to that Canon. For that Canon inhibited riding and precious apparel in the rogation weeke, and not copes in other ſolemne and high feaſtes.VVomen Sclaundered. And yf ſome women haue for vayne glorie, and ambition contended to haue the higher place in proceſsion, yet euery woman and euery wife haue not ſtryued for it, nor ſhewed them ſelues ſo immodeſt and paſt all womāly ſhame, that they were ready to ſcratch one an other by the face, Fol. 139. a as M. Calf. ſaieth, for goīg next the croſſe. This lye might haue bē ſpared, It maketh nothing to the ſolēnitie of a proceſsiō. Although you ſclandered mē, yet ſo fyne a chambre knight and carpet gentleman, ſhould not haue ſlaundred euery woman, and euery wife, and made them litle better than madde furies, that for
a trifle wilbe ready to flee in their neighbours face: and ſcracthe out their eies. But youe may ſee in what follies he falleth, while he ſeketh to quarrel againſt the truth. And that not in one place or two, but generally in all his booke.

VVhere Sozomenus declared that the Catholiks paſſed the Arriās in nūbre of mē, and ſolēnitie of proceſsiō, and to ꝓoue that, ſaied, Argentea crucis ſigna vna cum cereis accenſis praecedebant eos, Before the Catholiks wēt two ſiluer croſſes, with tapers or torches burning, this wiſe marchant deuiſed an other folly: as where I tranſlated, Argentea crucis ſigna, two ſiluer croſſes, he ſaieth:Calf. Fol. 140. a Mart. Crucis ſigna, may be as well many ſiluer ſignes of the croſſe as one. Is not this an high poynt of newe diuinitie? wel ſir, whether you will haue it ſiluer ſignes of a croſſe, or ſiluer croſſes, muſt it not ſignifie more than one, I beſeeke you? Is it not the plurall numbre? And doth not the plural numbre ſignifie many? And yf it ſignifieth many, doth it not ſignifieth two at the leaſt? Anſwer M. Calf. Yf that be true thē in trāſlating Argētea crucis ſigna, two ſiluer croſſes,Fol. 141. a I did not (as you ſaye) make a lye. For in many two are cō priſed, and the geater number euer contayneth the leſſe: but let that ignorance be pardoned. VVhy trifle you ſtill? As though this were not follie ynough, to ridiculous for a cocknel with beane in a bladder, you faulle into a worſe then all the reſt.Fol. 139. b Fol. 240. a For you ſaie: Argētea crucis ſigna, be not ſiluer croſſes, nor ſiluer ſignes of a croſſe, but certayne croſſe pieces of ſiluer, a ſtaf torch, or pole to cary a creſſet.
