And for proufe of that,Eccleſia. hiſt. lib 6. cap. 8. alleage theſe woordes out of Socrates, excogitauerat argenteas cruces quibus erāt impoſitae cereae faces accenſae, and tranſlated them thus: He had deuiſed certaine croſſe pieces of ſiluer, where vpon were put burning tapers of waxe.

Is not here a fine piece of ſkill? Surely yf M. Cooper in augmenting. Sir. Tho. Eliot.Significations of this vvord Crux deuiſed by M. Calf. Fol. 7. b his dictionarie had called you to counſell, he ſhould haue lerned many ſignifications for this word Crux. which he hath wittingly omitted, as a gallowes, a magicall inchauntement, a ſorcerous mace, a conqueſt againſt Chriſtians, an helmet of hell, a croſſe beame, a croſſe piller, a candle
ſticke, a torche ſtaf, a pole that carrieth the creſſet, a croſſe piece. O what a fruictfull vayne and fertile ſoile, is this for ſo litle a calfs head? who would haue thought that ſuch a doctorlike miniſtre could haue fallen into ſuch doltiſh follie? To omitte all the reſt, is Crux (ſir) Latin, for a candleſticke, a torche pole, or croſſe piece? You promiſed that the vanities, dreames, dotages, Shevve vs your ſcriptures, coū cels and fathers M. Calf. and cōpiracies of men, ſhould be diſproued and controlled by vndoubted ſcriptures, holy fathers, and laufull councells. VVe muſt deſire your maſterſhip to ſhewe vs one ſentence out of ſcripture, one euidēce out of ſome holy father, one place out of ſome laufull councell, where Crux, is taken to be a candleſticke, a torche pole or a croſſe piece, or els your glorious title will conuince you to be but an egregious foole.

Yf your play ſchole play, you muſt not make your inſtance in the preſent, but let vs graunte you that libertie, doe Argenteae cruces, ſignifie croſſe pieces of ſiluer? VVhich is the woord that ſignifieth croſſe? VVhich is the word that ſignifieth piece, which is the woorde that ſignifieth ſiluer? Argentea ſignifieth of ſiluer, and Cux ſignifieth croſſe: where is piece, M. Calfhil? Howe patch you that on? Either do it finely, or your folly will ſo apeare, that all your fyneſſe with the beſt ſtitche that all the miniſter taylours haue in England, will not excuſe your groſſeneſſe. Crux Latin for a croſſe piece, a candelſticke, and torche pole? O the faith of God and man? VVhat a fine deuiſer is this? Al the grammarians, makers of Calepynes, obſeruers of phraſes, and noters of proprieties in woordes could neuer finde out theſe ſignifications, their wittes were to groſſe, their capacities to dulle their iudgements to blinde. Crux a croſſe piece a candle ſticke a torch pole? Doth any wiſe man thinke that M. Calf. meaneth as he writeth? Yf he do, I would gladly vnderſtand what authoritie and reaſon he hath for it. M. Calfhils is ſtarke naught. For yf thoſe croſſes were candleſticks, or croſſe pieces, for candels, becauſe candels were ſett on them, then in like manner muſt the gentlemans hand be a miewe for his hauke, his ſeruants backe a deſke to write, and the ladies bed be a kenell for her hounde,
becauſe the hauke is ſet vpon the gentlemans hand, the paper is layed ſomtymes vpon the ſeruants backe, and the litle hounde caſt vpon the ladies bed.

The croſſes that Chryſoſtome deuiſed, were (as Sozomenus and Socrates reporte) made of ſiluer, which argueth that they were not candelſticks, or croſſe pieces, for candles. Siluer was not ſo plentifull in thoſe daies, that men would make croſſe beames, croſſe pieces, torche ſtafes and candelſticks of it. Againe yf thoſe croſſes had ben made only to beare candels, and geue light in the night ſeaſon, what neded Chryſoſtome to deuiſe aboute the matter? VVas it ſo hard a matter in ſuch a great citie as Conſtantinople was, to haue lynkes, torches, and creſſets, to geue light? But muſt croſſes be turned into Candelſtickes? VVas there no mā to deuiſe that? No wiſemā beleaueth it M. Calf. VVherefore in ſo muche as Chryſoſt. deuiſed theſe croſſes of ſiluer, and made ſupplication to the empreſſe to beare the chardge, it is not ſo be preſuppoſed that making his ſupplication, to the empreſſe, he ſaied, as he muſt,A ſupplication to the Empreſſe. (yf your ſaying be true) yf it pleaſe your moſte excellēt Maieſtie, the Catholikes lacke Candelſtickes to beare their Candels in the night tyme, whē they ſhould go againſt the Arians, and ſinge the hymnes that I haue made for them. Therfore yf it pleaſe your moſte excellent Maieſtie, I haue deuiſed a way to make them candleſtickes, that is to ſay, I haue deuiſed that they ſhall haue ij. croſſe pieces of ſiluer, Fol. 140. b and ſet candels vpō them, that the lightes glymmering there vpō, might make a beautifull and goodly ſhewe. VVherfore my humble, ſute and requeſt to your moſte excellēt maieſtie is, that it may pleaſe you to beſtowe ſo much ſiluer vpon me, as may ſerue for the making of theſe candelſtickes, and croſſe pieces. VVere not this a worthy requeſt for ſo wiſe a biſshop as Chryſoſtom was? were it not a mete ſupplication to be made to ſuche a famous empreſſe as Eudoxia was? Yf that be not preſuppoſed to be true, then it is not to be thought that Cruces Argenteae, & argentea crucis ſigna, are croſſe pieces of ſiluer, or ſiluer ſignes of a croſſe piece, or candelſticks of ſyluer, or a torch pole. The woordes
beare it not, the ſenſe geue it not, the authours meane it not. To childiſhe is that fanſie, & to groſſe for a bacheler of diuinitie. Studie your Calepine beter, and reade M. Coopers dictionarie with more iudgemēt for ſhame, that mē may not cry, fye of your ignrāce, for takīg cruces argēteas, to be latin for croſſe pieces of ſiluer.

The Magdeburgenſes your owne doctours, proteſtants of the neweſt Relligion, neuer eſpied this ſhifte. But confeſſe playnly that Chriſoſtome vſed croſſes of ſiluer, and burning tapers, vt res abiret in ſuperſtitionem, The Magdeburgenſes againſt M. Calf. Centu. 5. cap. 6 pag. 650. Candells vvere ſet vpon the croſſes, ergo the croſſes vvere candel ſticks, it is no good argument M. Calf. that the thing might go into ſuperſtition: which was not like to procede of bearing croſſe pieces for candelſtickes. Yf you aſke me why candels were ſet vpon them, yf they were Croſſes, It may be anſwered, that Candells were ſet vpō them to geue light. And yet for all that they are neuer a whit the more to be reputed for croſſe pieces or Candelſticks. The butcher whē he killeth a Calfe, ſomtymes putteth his knife in his mouth, The ſcholler as he writeth ſometymes putteth his pēne in his eare, yeat neither is the butchers mouth a ſheate for his knife, nor the ſchollers eare a caſe for his penne. So is it in the croſſes that had Candles ſtickte, or ſet vpon them.

Sozomenus ſaide Argentea crucis ſigna vna cum cereis accenſis praecedebant eos. Siluer ſignes of a croſſe or two ſiluer croſſes went before them together with burning tapers. VVhich wordes ſeing I alleaged out of Sozomenus, it had bene reaſon that you ſhoulde haue anſwered them, and not oppoſed an other place out of Socrates, who although he ſayeth, tapers were ſet vpon the Croſſes, yeat he varieth not in the cheifeſt pointe frome the other: that ſaid they went together with the Croſſes. For both confeſſe that they were croſſes, and croſſes of ſiluer, not Candelſtickes or Croſſe pieces of ſiluer. But you thought in this night of darkneſſe to haue ſome aduantage by the glimmering light, of Socrates wordes, and make a goodly and bewtifull ſhewe: but thankes be to God, it is turned into a foule driſeling myſt, and vpleaſant ſauour of a ſtinking Candleſticke.

Fol 141. bNowe howe iuſtly he chardgeth me, with foure lyes, conſider I beſeeke, the (good reader). I ſaide they caried two ſiluer croſſes.Ibidem. That is a lye, (quoth M. Calf.) For there is no number
mentioned. Doth he not grate harde to make this a lye? Sozomenus ſayeth, Argētea Crucis ſigna precedebant eos. Siluer ſignes of a Croſſe or ſiluer croſſes wente before them. Socrates ſaieth, excogitabat argenteas cruces, He deuiſed ſiluer croſſes. Both ſigna & cruces, ſignes and croſſes, are the plurall numbre, which euer ſignifieth more than one, and when it compriſeth leaſt, it compriſeth twoe, yet becauſe I ſaid, there were two where no certayn number is mentioned, he accompteth it for a lye, wheras being in the plural numbre, it muſt ſignifie twoe at the leaſt: and ſeing he ſayeth that I make a lye where none is made,Lies returned vpon M. Calf. lett him goe which waye he will, we may returne it to him againe and ſaye that he is a lyer. Thē that they ſhoulde be caried in proceſsion. That is a lye, quoth M. Calf. For it was only in proceſſu, Ibidem. in their marching foreward. Is not this far ſought and fooliſhly brought, to conuince one of a lye? It was caried in proceſſu, ergo not in proceſsion? what Tom foole, that had witte to tell his mothers geeſe, woulde make ſuche a reaſon? Is not proceſſus, Proceſſus and proceſsio. and proceſsio all one? Doth not he that marcheth forwarde goe forwarde? and he that goeth forward, march forwarde? An highe matter in a lowe houſe. After that the Catholikes were marched forwarde, and gone forth, did they not goe ſtill the moſt parte of the nighte, vntill they mett with the Arrians? And all while they went, had they not the Croſſes with them? Reade the ſtory: and when you finde the cōtrarye, then ſaye it is a lye. In the meane ſeaſon ſeing they were caried in proceſſu, all the while they were goinge in proceſsiō, it is no lye for me to ſaye, that they were caried in proceſsion, but it is a lye for him that ſaide, they were not caried in proceſsion, becauſe it was in proceſſu, in the marching forwarde.

The thirde lye (as he reckoneth) is becauſe I ſaye the croſſes were caried in the churches, for it was in the ſtreats, Ibidem. quoth M. Calfhil. As though he that ſaide, The Croſſe was caried at a general proceſsion in Paules churche, made a lye, becauſe it was caried in the church yard, when proceſsiō was vſed. The croſſe was firſte caried in the church, and afterward in the ſtreates,
and then broughte into the church againe. And as the cleargie of Paules then beganne their proceſsion in the churche, and wente into the ſtreate, ſo it is moſt likely, that the catholiques in S. Chryſoſtomes time, repaired all together to the church, and there made their prayer firſt to God, and ſange their himnes, and frome thence wente with their croſſes into the ſtreates, ſinging the ſame. There is no mention that they repaired together to the biſshops palace, nor any one Catholiques houſe, and yeat together they came, and ſeing it is ſo, what other meter place could there be for it than the church? None as wiſe men thinke. The caſe thē ſtāding ſo, and my aſſertiō being probable, agreing to reaſon, I am not to be condemned of a lye, but he that imputeth it to me, muſt haue it reuolted to him ſelfe, and ſo is it where it ſhould be.

The fourth lye is, That they were caried as ours are in the day time. And this is a lye in deede, and a Notable lye, but none of myne: it is his owne: therefor I beſeche you lett hym haue it. In all my booke I haue no ſuch worde. Trye it, and you ſhal finde it. So while he hath laboured to controll an other of iiij. lyes, he is founde to be a vayne lyer him ſelfe, in euery one of the ſaied foure, beſides other hūdreds as ſhall apeare hereafter. To the foure mentioned before, he addeth twoe more in the Margent with great letters, becauſe euery man ſhal ſee thē. The one is,Fol. 141. a that the matter alleadged out of Sozomenus hiſtorie maketh nothinge for me. The ſecond that I gather this concluſion out of Sozomenus, that we muſt carye a candleſtick in ſteade of a Croſſe, in proceſsion, which I referr to the indifferent reader to iudge, whether they be twoe Notable lies or no.Fol. 142. a M. Calfs. reaſons againſt tapers in the church. Fol 141. b. The firſt. Cap. 34. My ſelfe hauinge to talke of other matters more neceſſarie, will not ſtande triflinge aboute it.

M. Calf. noteth in the Margent that there muſt be no tapers vpon the lordes table, becauſe a decre of a Councell called Elibertinum, generall (as he ſayeth, but prouinciall in deede), forbiddeth vs to lighte candles in the churche yarde in the daye time. The wordes of that prouinciall councell are theſe. Cereos
per diem placuit in caemiterio non incendi, It hath pleaſed vs, that tapers be not lighted in the day time, in the churche yard, here is no mētion of the church, nor lordes table. VVherfore it is to be ſene, that he meaneth not playnlye. For reaſon willeth that he that citeth a lawe, cite it trulye as it is, and not leaue out the chiefe parte of it. This Canon inhibited not tapers to be lighted in the church, nor vpon the lordes table, but in caemiterio, in the church yarde. This worde (churche yarde) M. Calf. ſuppreſſeth,The canō of the Elibert: councel falſely alleaged. and maketh the councell ſaye indefinitely, that we ſhoulde not lighte candles in the day time, quite contrary to the meaning and wordes of the councell.

An other reaſon why there ſhould be no tapers vpō the lordes table,The ſecōd he bringeth out of Lactantius, and begīneth with halfe a ſentence. For where deſcribing the ſuperſtition and vanitie of the Gentills, he ſaide, Mactant igitur opimas & pingues hoſtias Deo quaſi eſurienti, profundunt vina tanquam ſitienti, Lib. 6 cap. 2. de ve • o Cultu. accendunt lumina tanquam in tenebris agenti, etc. They kill the beſt and fatte ſacrifices to God, as though he were hungrie, they poure forth wine as though he were a thirſte, they light vp candels as though he dwelt in darcknes, the laſt woordes of this ſentence M. Calf. ſnatcheth, and letteth the other alone, which expounde the meaning of the authour. For Lactantius perceauing the groſſe and moſt abſurde errour of the Gentills who attributed to their Gods no heauenly, but an humane ſenſe, and thought that they needed meate, drincke, clothes, and light, as well as we did, reproued this fonde opinion, and fanſie of theirs, and ſeing God is authour of all light, thought it madnes in them to offer vp cādles and tapers to him pro munere, for a preſent, or gift,The gētils fanſie of their gods as though he lyued in darknes, and neded light. Nowe becauſe Lactantius accompted it a madnes to lighte candles and tapers to God in ſuch wicked ſorte, as the ſuperſtitious gentills did, our miniſters madde brayne ſerueth him to thinke it a madnes in vs to ſette tapers vpon the table of our lorde,Iſido li. 2. cap. 1. de Eccleſiaſ. officijs. who knowe God to be the authour and geuer of all light, and light not our cādles to God, as though he needed them, or as though he dwelt in darknes, but ad ſignum latriae demonſtrandum, etc. To declare a ſigne of the high
ſeruice and worſhip that we owe to God, VVhy the Chriſtiās light candels in the church. Ioan. 1. Fol. 141. b The fathers that make mē tion of lightes in the churche. that vnder the ſhadowe of that corporall light, that lighte may be repreſented, of whom it was ſaid, he was the true lighte, that lightnethe euery man that cometh into this worlde. In which ſenſe neither ſcripture, nor Councell, nor auncient father inhibite the lighting of tapers. And for imagining the Catholiques to thinck ſo of God, and light their candles in ſuch māner as the Gentills did, and haue no preſident for burning of tapers, but from the ſacrifices of Saturnus, it is an extreame madnes.

But let it be propre for heretikes. Let them be better ſeene in the ſacrifices of gentilitie, than ceremonies of Chriſtianitie. Let vs Chriſtians retayne lightes in the Church, of which we haue ſo euident recorde, and witneſſe, out ofLibro 6. cap. 7. Eccleſ. hiſt. Euſebius, 6. epiſt. ad orthodox. Athanaſius, Orat. 4. in paſch. Gregorie Nazianzene, S.Contra Vigilant. In epitap. paulae, Hierome,Ser. 7. de ſanctis. Auguſtine,3. Natal. S. Foelicis. Pauline andLibr. 2 cap. 1. de Eccleſia. officijs. Ieremie cap. 6. Fol. 142. b Iſidore. Let vs keepe that which the holy Ghoſt hath continued in the church thes many hundred yeres and confirmed by miracle. Let vs make no innouation to the great iniurie of the dead: but let vs tary in thoſe thinges which were determined of our forefathers, and neuer abrogated by the church. So ſhall we followe the counſell of the prophet, that cōmaunded vs to aſke of the old pathes, which is the good waye, and walke in the ſame. VVhere M. Calf. findeth fault that I ſaid, our heretickes nowe a dayes, will haue no croſſe at the ſinging of their lordes prayer, becauſe neither their lorde nor they can abide the ſighte of the croſſe, and thincketh that becauſe they haue no other lordes prayer than that which is written in the vi. of Mathewe, and xi. of Luke, I mighte as well haue ſaid at the lordes prayer, as at their lordes prayer, I wiſhe with all my hearte, that they had neither geuen me occaſion ſo to write, neither other men cauſe ſo to thincke: but ſeing they haue ſeparated them ſelues frome the church, and whoſoeuer is ſeparated from the churche,Cyprian. tract. de ſimpl. praelato. and ioyned to the adulterous and baſtarde church, is ſeparated from the promiſes of the church, and ſeing non pertinet ad praemia Chriſti, qui relinquit Eccleſiam Chriſti, alienus eſt, prophanus eſt, hoſtis est, he ꝑtayneth not to the rewardes of Chriſte,
who forſaketh the church of Chriſte, but is an alian,He is no Chriſtian that forſaketh the church. a prophane man, and an enemie, I could not but write as I did and call it their lordes prayer. For if Chriſt were their lorde in deede, and for firmely fixed in their heartes, as he is often in their mouthes, they would not forſake his church. For as S. Auguſtine ſayeth: Totus Chriſtus caput & corpus, caput ille ſaluator corporis qui aſcendit in coelum, corpus autem Eccleſia quae laborat in terra. In Pſal. 30 Conc. 1. The head and the bodie is whole Chriſte. He the ſauer of the bodie, who aſcended into heauen, is the heade. The church that trauaileth in the earthe, is the bodie, and a litle after that you may knowe (ſayeth he) quia vnus dicitur Chriſtus caput & corpus ſuum: That the heade and his bodie is called one Chriſte, he ſaide when he ſpake of mariade, They ſhalbe twoe in one fleſhe. Therfore nowe they are not twoe, but one fleſhe. And a litle afterwarde.

Fit ergo tanquam ex duobus vna quaedam perſona, ex capite, & corpore ex ſponſo et ſponſa etc. There is made therfore as it were one perſon of two, of the head and the bodie, of the bridgrome and the ſpouſe. For the prophet Eſaie commendeth the maruelous and excellent vnitie of this perſon. For Chriſt ſpeaking alſo in him, ſaied in way of prophecie. He hath tied a Miter vpon me, as it were a bridegrome, and adorned me as it were a ſpouſe, with pretious attire, he called him ſelfe the bridegrome, and her the ſpouſe, why did he call him ſelfe the bridegome, and her the ſpouſe, but becauſe they are twoe in one fleſhe. Yf they be twoe in one fleſhe, why not in one voyce. Let Chriſt therfore ſpeake, becauſe the church ſpeaketh in Chriſt, and Chriſt in the church, the bodie in the heade, and the heade in the bodie. And whoſoeuer ſeperateth him ſelfe frō the bodie, ſeparateth him ſelfe from the heade. VVhich ſeing heretikes haue done, although they bragge luſtely, and talke buſilye of Chriſt,Lib. 4. epiſto. 3. Reaſons out of S. Cyprian that our heretiques are not in the church. yeat are they not in dede true Chriſtians but traytours and Apoſtatats. For as S. Cyprian ſaith. Chriſtianus non eſt qui in Eccleſia non eſt. He is no Chriſtē mā, that is not in the church, but an alian, a prophane man, and an enemie.

But peraduenture ſome will ſaye, It is not ſufficient to tell vs that the our heretikes haue forſaken the churche of Chriſt, it muſt be proued. And but reaſon in good faith: herken therfore, and ſee howe I proue it out of S. Cyprian. He ſaieth. Quo modo
autem poteſt ei cum aliquo conuenire cui cum corpore ipſius eccleſiae, De ſimpl. Praelato. & cū vniuerſa fraternitate nō cōuenit? that is to ſaye, howe can he agree with any mā that agreeth not with the whole bodie of his churche, and with the vniuerſall brotherhoode? vpon thoſe wordes I reaſon thus: he that agreeth not with the whole bodie of Chriſtes church, and the vniuerſall brotherhode, is not in the church: but theſe heretikes do not agre with the whole bodie of Chriſtes church, nor with the vniuerſall brotherhode. For they agre not with Italie Fraunce, Spayne, portugall, Polonia, Bauarie, Burgundie, Brabant and Flaunders being in the church of Chriſt, nor with the biſhopps, prieſtes, and catholiques in theſe countries, and otherwiſe deſperſed, Ergo they are not in his church. An other reaſon out of the ſame father is this. Qui aduerſus ſacerdotes Chriſti facit, & ſe a cleri eius, vel plebis ſocietate ſecernit non eſt cum Chriſto: he that doth againſt the prieſtes of Chriſt, and ſeparate him ſelfe frome the ſocietie of his cleargie, and people, is not with Chriſte. But theſe our heretikes haue done againſt the prieſtes of Chriſt, and ſeparated them ſelues frome the ſocietie of his cleargie and people: Ergo they are not with Chriſt, and ſo conſequentlye not in the church.

That they haue done againſt Chriſtes prieſtes I proue by this reaſon out of S.Heretiques practiſſe agaīſt the prieſtes of Chriſt. Cypriā: Quiſquis contēptis epiſcopis, & Dei ſacerdotibus derelictis cōſtituere audet aliud altare, precē illicitis vocibus facere, dominicae hostiae veritatē per falſa ſacrificia prophanare, contra ſacerdotes Chriſti facit: that is, whoſouer cōtēneth the biſhops, and forſakīg the prieſts of God p̄ſumeth to ſet vp another aulter, to make an other prayer in an vnlawful tōgue, to ꝓphane the truth of our lordes ſacrifice, with falſe ſacrifices, doth againſt the prieſtes of God: but our heretiks haue p̄ſumed in deſpite of al the biſhops, and prieſtes of God, to ſet vp a newe aulter, yea rather to deſtroye al aultres, and ſet vp a newe ſkittiſh and whyrring table, neuer ſure ſettled in one place, but remoueable, from Corner to corner, from chauncell to Bellfrey: They haue preſumed to make an other kinde of prayer in an vnlaufull tongue, they haue preſumed to prophane the truth of our lordes ſacrifice, offred in the Maſſe as he commaunded, and the Catholike church hathe
euer taughte, for the quicke and the deade,The engliſh cō munion. by their ſingle communion, which is nothing, but a bare thanckes geuing, and naked ſigne with a piece of bread, and reading certayne places of ſcripture as it were an hiſtorie: Therefore they haue done againſt the prieſtes of God, and ſo be not in the church, but traitors to the churche, ſpurners againſt the ordinance of God, enemies of the aulters, rebelles againſt the ſacrifice of Chriſt, diſobedient ſeruantes, and wicked children.

Yf you denie the minor propoſitiō, and ſay that you haue not contemned the biſshops, and forſaken the prieſtes of God etc. yower owne doinges ſhall condemne you.The biſſhop of Rome cō temned. For firſt you haue contemned, and forſaken the biſshope of Rome Peters ſucceſſour and Chriſts vicare on earthe, the ruler of the houſe of God, the heire of the Apoſtles, the head of the vniuerſall churche, called to that vocation by God. You haue forſaken yower owne lawfull biſshops, and paſtours,Religion chaunged vvithout cōſent of the biſſhops. you haue altered the ſtate of religion without their conſent, you haue brought in a newe kinde of ſeruice, neuer heard of in the catholike church before yower dayes, and nowe too rare, for the whole ſtate of Chriſtendome, if it had pleaſed God not to ſuffre that horrible plague to lighte vpon vs. The caſe then ſtanding ſo, that you haue forſaken the church of Chriſte, for exijſtis, diſceſsiſtis. Ye haue gone out, ye haue departed awaye, it muſt nedes followe that ye are not Chriſtiās nor obedient ſeruants that haue Chriſte for their lorde, nor naturall children, that haue God for their father. For yf ye had Chriſt for yower lorde, ye would haue his ſpouſe for yower miſtreſſe. Yf you had God for yower father, ye would haue the church for yower mother. For Chriſt and his ſpouſe, is but one bodie, God and his churche one foundatiō, and piller of veritie.

Yf they will obiect that they acknowledge one God the father, one God the ſonne, one God the holie ghoſte, as wel as we doe, we anwſer them with S. Cyprian, That Core, Dathan, Libr. 1. epiſt. 6 ad Mag. and Abiron acknowledged one God with Moyſes and Aron, and liuing in the ſame lawe and relligion that they did, worſhipped God, which is to be adored and worſhipped, yet for all that, becauſe they paſſed their miniſterie and vocation, and chalenged vnto thē ſelues lycence to ſacrifice, Againſt
Aaron the high prieſt, they were ſtroken from heauen, and ſwallowed into the earth a lyue, and ſo may they. S. Auguſtine hath many notable ſayings in this ſenſe able to make any man that looketh for fauour with God aſtonnied and a fraied. In one place he ſaieth: Yf a man be ſeparated from the catholike churche, Epiſt 15. The vvrath of God hangeth ouer al ſchiſmatykes. He that breaketh the churche denieth Chriſt. Tract. • in epiſt Ioā. cap. 4. In Pſal. 10. He violateth the temple of God that breaketh vnitie. although he thinke him ſelfe to liue commendably, for this only fault, that he is ſeparated frō Chriſtianitie, he hath not life, but the wrath of God hangeth ouer him. In another place he ſaieth: He denieth Chriſt to become in fleaſh, that breaketh the church, which he aſſembled. In another place he ſaieth: He breaketh the tēple of God that breaketh vnitie, for he holdeth not the head by which the body and head is ioyned and cōpacted together. God is in his holy church which conſiſteth of many mēbres, doing euery one his dutie in their vocatiō, which he breaketh, VVhoſoeuer is ſeparated frō the catholike ſocietie. A terrible caſe. ād worthy to be cōſidered of al that haue fallen into ſchiſme, that they may ſee in what miſerable ſtate they ſtand.

As for vs, we are not to be counted Apoſtatats, we haue not forſaken our faith, we keepe that which we receaued from the beginning. Non exiuimus, non diſceſsimus, manſimus apud eos qui fuerunt ex nobis. VVe haue not gone out: we haue not flitted away: we haue remayned with them, who were of vs: we haue not broken the vnitie of his churche, but as the churche hath euer taught, ſo we hold: we refuſe not the lordes prayer, but your ſchiſmaticall ſeruice, your ſingle communion, and Geneuian lordes prayer commonly called doctour Coxes, Pater noſter with ſuch additions, as are neither to be founde in the vi. of Mathewe, nor xi. of S. Luke, this we deteſt, this is not of God. This is not of Chriſt. This is not of the holy Ghoſt, but of your fanſies, your dottages, and your dreames.

Nowe as concerning your other imagination, that Luther ſhould be no heretick, Calf. becauſe Ephrem ſaied: the croſſe is an expeller of hereſie. For that he is alwaies pictured ful deuoutely kneling before the croſſe, Fol 143. a. and no Papist had the ſigne of the croſſe in more reuerence thā he, Mart. you muſt reſtrayne your poſition, or fall into a lye. For he hath not alwaies ben portrayted kneeling
full deuoutely before a croſſe. My ſelf haue ſene his picture without any croſſe, before him: and many mo beſides, that trauaile into Germanie.Luther and his nonne payncted together. In ſome places ye may ſee in ſteede of a croſſe his ſwete heart dame Katerin bore a nonne of Nemeck and amorouſe of VVittemberge, pictured with him: but yf it were ſo, for you to gather of the painters fanſie an argument of no hereſie in Luther, was a maruelous policie, much like the deuiſe of the knight of the order. For your witte, yf you were ioyned in commiſsion with him, we ſhould haue a pack full of policies able to be compared with Macheuell. But yf a man ſhould oppoſe you, howe would your maſterſhip proue that no catholicke had the ſigne of the croſſe in more reuerēce than Luther? Surely very hardly: yf you can, ſaue your ſmall honeſtie, from an impudent lye: and in your next reply make ſome demonſtration of it. In the meane tyme it ſhall runne with the reſt: for as frier Luther was an enemy to all good religion, and ceremonies of the church, ſo was he alſo to images and the ſigne of the croſſe,Luther an enemie to the croſſe and images. and where he blamed Caroloſtadius archedeacon of VVittenberge for plucking downe of images in his abſence, it was not for that he miſliked, the doying of it, but becauſe he was not the principall authour of it.

That ſaying of holy Ephrem: Crux eſt haereſium expulſatrix, The croſſe is an expeller of hereſie, is true in his ſenſe. For it bringeth to all that can abide the ſight of it, and haue holy meditations of Chriſtes paſsion, ſuch thoughtes of humilitie, and obedience, that ſingularitie can haue no place, nor pride preuaile. Yf the diuell tempt any with rebellion, againſt the churche, by ſight of that it cometh or at the leſt it may come the ſoner to his mynde: Howe Chriſt was obedient to his father euen to death, Good thoughtes may come to our mindes by 〈◊〉 of 〈◊〉 croſſe. 〈◊〉 2. 1. Cor. 2. yea death of the croſſe. Yf he tempt him with vayne glorie, and would make him conceaue ſuch opinion of hym ſelf, that he paſſeth all other in knoweledg, and learning, by ſight of the croſſe, the humilitie of Chriſt ſo cometh ſo to his mynde, that he reſiſteth the temptation, and ſaieth: I thincke my ſelf to knowe nothing, but Ieſus Chriſt and him crucified: and in very deede yf Luther had locked vpon the croſſe in ſuch ſorte, hereſie that cometh of ſingularit e
and pride could neuer haue preuailed againſt him and his. For it woulde haue taught him humilitie and obedience, mothers of all vertue: but that the deuill could not a bide. And therefore made him runne out of his cloyſter and diſobey the generall of his order, contemne the Popes Legate, ſet naught by the Emperour, and rayle moſt wickedly againſt the biſshop and ſee of Rome, and to fall to great diſorder as the ſequele hath tried.

Touching Iuſtinians conſtitution for croſſes to be borne at the ſinging or ſaying of the litanie, M. Calfhil thinketh him ſelf not bounde to followe his order in religion, Fol. 143. a but in ciuil caſes, and ſome matters of correction: vt quod pederastis virilia confeſtim exſecari voluit, he doth gladly admitteth, and we do not refuſe. Other conſtitutions he hath alſo in ciuil caſes and matters of correction,Iuſtinians lavves of correctiō. as that euery man that contracteth any vnlawfull marriadg contrary to the lawe of nature, ſhoulde leeſe all his goods and dignities, and he ſent into baniſhment, and be bodely puniſhed, yf he were a poore knawe: what ſay your maried monukes to that? That the blaſphemous man ſhould be put to death, howe do you ſanfie that? That the houſes where hereticks kepe their conuenticles ſhould be confiſcated and appropriated to the churche, howe like you that M. Calf? and the heretickes them ſelues abide the puniſhement of the lawe, what ſay you that?Cōſti. 109. Item that hereticks ſhoulde beare no office in the common weale. Admitte ye that? And that we ſhould not be ignorant who be heretickes, he ſaieth: All they be heretikes that be not membres of the holy catholike, and Apoſtolike churche of God, in which all holy biſshops and patriarkes of the world, VVho be heretickes and the biſshops vnder them preache the Apoſtolike faith and tradition.

But theſe cōſtitutiōs are to ſharpe, and therfore M, Calfhi did wiſey in admitting Iuſtinians lawes but in ſome ciuil caſes and matters of correction. For he knewe, yf all were admitted he and his ſhould be condemned. Yf lyke libertie might be permitted euery where, and eche man refuſe the lawes of the Emperours, and princes, and be iudged by none, but ſuch as it pleaſeth him to admitte, and vnderſtand at his owne pleaſure, murders, rouers, churche robers, lechers, heretiks and pirats had purchaſed
them ſelues greate priuiledg, and the vertuous and godly great dāmage and hinderaunce. VVherfore it muſt not be ſo. Euery mā may not admitte, and refuſe what him liſteth: lawes ones eſtabliſhed muſt haue their force, vnleſſe by like authoritie they be abrogated, or otherwiſe growen out of vſe. And albeit the lawes of Iuſtiniā, binde not vs in England in all poynts becauſe they were neuer generallie receaued, in our realme being an Iland and kingdom of it ſelf, yet doe they declare the vſe and manner of all Chriſtendome in his tyme, and condēne all hereticks of vanitie, in condemning the whole world, and bragging that they followe the primitiue churche, and craking of antiquitie: whereas in this point, all the world may ſee that they ſwarue from the vſe of the primitiue churche and all antiquitie.

Nowe to come to holy Auguſtine our Apoſtle, M. Calf.Auguſtin. our Apoſtle. becauſe he will not acknowledg that we Engliſh men receaued our faith and religion from Rome, and S. Gregorie Biſhop of that ſee, by Auguſtine and his companions,Fol. 143. a. b. Calf. telleth vs that euer ſythens the tyme of Eleutherius of Rome and Lucius of England, Chriſtianitie hath bē receaued, and neuer fayled amō geſt vs: and that Ethelbert king of kent was meetely well inſtructed in the faith by a good wife, that came out of Fraunce and a faithfull hiſshop that attended vpon her.

Howe ſo euer it be yf it came from Eleutherius in king Lucius daies, it came frō Rome. For Eleutherius was pope of Rome.Mart. Yf it came be Ethelberts wife, ād the faithful biſshop that was ſent with her out of Fraunce, it came from Rome.M Calf. forced to confeſſe that vve receaued our faith frō Rome For Fraunce receaued the faith from Rome, and the Frenche kinges daughter and biſshop that attēded vpon her, coming out of Fraunce had no other faith, nor laboured to plant any other faith than they receaued from Rome. So which way ſo euer he turneth, the truth forceth him to ſay that we receaued our faith frō Rome.

But albeit the Brittons receaued the faith in king Lucius daies, and Ethelbert heard of the Chriſtian religion by his wife, that came out of Fraunce, yet is there no olde hiſtorie that mentioneth
that thoſe partes of England which king Ethelbert and other poſſeſſed in that tyme, generally receaued and profeſſed the faith of Chriſt, before Auguſtine came from Rome. S. Bede teſtifieth that when he and his companions came to the king in the ile of Tenede,King Ethelberts vvoordes to S Auguſtine our Apoſtle. Lib. 1. ca. 25. hiſto. Angl. Cap. 26. Fol. 143. b he ſaied vnto them, Youe geue vs faire woordes and promiſes: but yet for that they are ſtraunge, and vnknowen vnto me, I can not raſhly aſſent vnto them, forſaking that auncient religion which this long time both I and my people haue obſerued. By which it appeareth that nor the king, nor his people were inſtructed in the faith of Chriſt before Auguſtine came and preched. In the next chapiter Bede ſaieth: They began to expreſſe the very Apoſtolike order of lyuing of the primitiue church, ſeruing God in cōtinual praying, watching, and preaching the woord of life, to as many as they could. And yf they did followe the order of the primitiue church, and preche the worde of life, they did not plāt ſuperſtitiō in place of idolatry, as M. Calf. ſaieth: For the woord of life is not ſuperſtition, M. Calf. nor the order of the primitiue church a way to induce mē vnto it, and the woorde of life they did preache and obſerue the order of the primitiue churche, as Bede ſaieth, more worthy of credit than ten hundred Galfrides.

Ibidem.That holy Auguſtine ſhould labour of an ambitious proude heart to peruert true religion, it is a malitious ſclaunder. For he was a man of an humble, and meeke ſpirite, far from al haftines and pride. His doinges witneſſe, and ſtories teſtifie, that his coming was to plant true religion, and not to peruert any. All that you haue to obiect againſt him is that he required ſubiectiō of the mounkes of Bangor, Auguſtines requeſtes, to the mounkes of Bangor thought vnlauful by M. Calf. that he would haue inioyned them to be come ſeruitors in preching of the Ghoſpell, to their mortall enemies the Saxons, and that he would haue them kepe Eſter as the churche of Rome did, and vſe their ceremonies in miniſtration of baptiſme. Nowe whether he that requireth theſe things of others, myndeth to peruert true religion, it is eaſie to be iudged. Yf thoſe ſeuen biſshops, with their archebiſshop and mounkes of Bangor had ben faithful, and learned prelats (as you ſay) they would haue conſidered, as reaſon and lerning
taught them, that the church of Rome was the rote and mother of all churches, ſythens the Apoſtles tyme: and that the biſhop of that ſee, is head and chief gouernour vniuerſally ouer all churches, and that Auguſtine being apoynted and ſent, as a Legate from that ſee, required their obedience to that head and chief biſshop, and not vnto him ſelf, as you maye ſee in S. Bede:Libr. 1. cap 27. and that conſidered, knowing that humilitie is a godly vertue, and obedience a ſwete ſacrifice, it had ben their dutie rather mekely to haue yelded, than ſtubbornly to haue reſiſted. S. Auguſtine in this behalf, did but his dutie, as a faithfull ambaſſadour, would do for his prince in like caſe. And they in repyning ſhewed very litle loue to vnitie and charitie, and leſt of all to perfect Chriſtianitie, when they refuſed to be ſeruitours in preching the Ghoſpell to their mortall enemies the Saxons. For Alas what true Chriſten man, knowing that Chriſt hath commaunded vs, to loue our enemies, and that he him ſelf loued vs ſo tenderly, when we were his enemies, that he gaue him ſelf to death vpō the croſſe for vs, will refuſe the preching of his ghoſpell to a whole nation, becauſe they are his enemies?1. Cor. 1 • . Charitie is patient: gentle, it enuieth not: it doth nothing wickedly: it is not puft vp, it is not ambitious, it ſeketh not her owne commoditie: it is not prouoked: it thinketh not euill: it reioiſeth not ouer iniquitie: It is glad with the truth, and ſuffreth all thinges. and certes yf there had ben any ſparcle of Chriſtian charitie in thoſe men,Litle pietie or Charitie in the mounke of Bangor that M. Calf. prayſeth ſo much. Iacob. 5. they would neuer haue refuſed to preche the Ghoſpell, to the whole nation vnder pretence of enemitie, knowing that he that maketh a ſynner turne away from the errour of his way, ſhall ſaue his ſoule from death, and couereth a multitude of ſynnes. VVherfore in refuſing this condition (yf there were nothing els) they ſhewed them ſelues nor faithfull, nor lerned prelates, nor ſcarce good Chriſtians. And yf you had deuiſed an argument to make an inuectiue againſt them, you could haue inuented no better than this.

As for the keeping of Eſter, and baptiſing after the manner of the churche of Rome, yf they were but trifles (as you ſay) then were they very triflers that would reſiſt the authoritie of that churche, from which they receaued their faith, in trifles. Yf
they were matters of greate importāce,Euſeb lib. 5 cap 23. hiſto. Nicepho. lib. 4 c 22 then were they not louers of vnitie nor deſirous to followe orders receaued by general and ꝓuincial coūcels, vnder Victor at Rome, vnder Narciſſus at Hieruſalē vnder Irenaeꝰ in Fraūce, vnder Palmas in Pōtus, vnder Bachilus at Corinth, ād other biſshops in other cūtries: but declared them ſelues willinger to followe the ſchiſmatikes of the Eaſt, than Rome, Afrike, Italie, Egipte, Spayne, Fraunce, Lybia, Cilicia, and all other Catholike churches of the weſt. VVhich ſauored litle of the ſpirite of God.

Fol 143. b Calf.That Ethelbert ſhould ſtirre vp Ethelfrede, and the Saxō kinges againſt the Brittons, and moūkes of Bangor, partly in Auſtens quarrel, and partly of an olde grugge of his owne, It hath no colour of truth,Mart. yea it is a moſt ſclanderous lye. For Ethelbert being conuerted from idolatrie, and Chriſtened, did ſeeke,Beda lib 1 cap. 32. Eccleſiaſt. hiſt Ang. and maintayne the honour of God, as appeareth by the Epiſtle of S. Gregory ſent vnto him. And would he ſeeking and mayntayning the honour of God, either bare malice and rancour in his heart, or ſtirre idolaters againſt the religious that had profeſſed Chriſt? It is not credible. S. Bede reporteth that they were plagued by the ſecrete woorking of Gods iudgment, becauſe they refuſed and deſpiſed the holſome counſell of perpetuall life,Lib 2 ca. 2 hiſt. Ang. offred vnto them, which is more likelyer, than Galfrides tale. And if it might haue ſtode with the reuerence of your woorſhip and honour of your perſon to haue beleaued a receaued authour, before an vnlerned frier, and remembred what is ſpoken in commendation of Auguſtine, by S. Gregorie him ſelf you would neuer haue iudged him to be ambitious, nor haue imputed the murder of thoſe moūkes, to his ambitiō, who died long before that murder was committed. But authoritie preuaileth litle with youe, I perceaue. He that ſpeaketh woorſt of the Catholiks, is credited before the beſt, that writeth the true hiſtories. It ſhould not be ſo. The auncienter and worthier eche writer is, So ought his credit to be be preferred amongeſt the wiſe.

VVhere you note in the margent, that we differ from Auguſtine
the mounke in ceremonies, becauſe, Fol 144. b Calf. he brought but a bare croſſe, and we haue not only a croſſe, but alſo a crucifix graued thereon, he carried a picture paincted in a table, we haue the ſame carued and imboſſed, Mart. I maruel that youe are not aſhamed, to infarce ſuch childiſh toyes in your writīges. VVhat yf their croſſe had no image of Chriſt graued on it? VVhat yf they coming a thouſand miles and more brought but a litle table with the image of Chriſt paincted in it? VVill it followe that they miſliked croſſes hauing the image of Chriſt engraued? or allowed not images carued and imboſſed? your lodgick faileth, yf youe thinke that a good conſequent. Yf a man ſhould ſay, youe, and your felloe proteſtants differre from the Apoſtles, and being demaunded why, Anſwered: The Apoſtles forſoke al that they had, youe kepe al that youe haue,The proteſtats varie frō the Apoſtles. they wēt bare fote ād in ſheepes ſkynnes, you go ſome in buſkīs, ſome in great britches, ſome in wooſteades, ſome in chamletts, ſome in ſilkes, ſome in vnſhorne veluet, they had no benefices, nor prebendes, youe haue both benefices, and prebends, ſome foure, ſome fyue and ſo foorth: They went from citie to citie a foote, yf you goe from citie to citie, moſt commonly you ride: whē they went to any towne to preche, they receaued no mony for ſermons, you vnleſſe you may haue mony, in ſome places will make no ſermons, yea ye do obtrude your ſelues to haue the prefermēt of funeral ſermons and ſuch like. They required no beneuolence of their clergie, you, or at the leſt, ſome of you haue required beneuolēces of the clergie, they faſted often, you very ſeldome, they praied deuoutely, you very coldly, they lodged hardly, you very delicately, they lyued continently, you very licentiouſly, yf I ſay a man ſhould make ſuch an anſwer, to the ſaid queſtion, would you not recken him but a Calf. Ye as I dare ſay: And ſo do we you for the other.

It is manifeſt that the church in thoſe daies, had images, engraued, carued, and emboſſed, and as we receaued the faith from the churche of Rome: So in tyme, we receaued images alſo with the church of Rome. And although he brought none that
were carued nor imboſſed,Auguſtine neuer miſliked carued and emboſſed images. yet doth it not argue that he condemned thoſe that were carued and emboſſed. In all his prechings, in all the ſtorie that Bede mentioneth, there is no woord that imployeth any diſcontētatiō or miſliking with carued and emboſſed images. VVherefore you may ſcrape out that note, and note in your margent that yow and yours differ, from the Apoſtles aſwel in manners as in tyme. For this is more meater for that place.

Fol. 144. Calf.VVhere you ſay, that yf Auguſtins fact coming to thē that neuer heard of Chriſt and bringing a croſſe, and image of Chriſt, to feede them, that lending him their eares, he might inſtruct their heartes, might he excuſed by the ſtate and condition of the countrie, yet can not we in our croſſe carying haue the like pretence, and therefore ought not to vſe the like example, Mart. I maruell that you forgotte to proue it by ſcripture, councell or auncient father, according to the large promiſe of your glorious title in the beginning of your boke. Your bare aſſertiō deſerueth no credit. Yf I ſhould deſire you to make good this argument. S. Auguſtine coming to an idolatrous nation that neuer heard of Chriſt, had a good pretēce to vſe the croſſe and image of Chriſt, but the papiſts in their croſſe carying haue not the like pretence, ergo they ought not to vſe the like example, it ſhould be a long tyme before you would iuſtifie it. Yf one ſhould ſay we haue not occaſion, to vſe like diligence in preaching as he vſed, for the conuerſion of infidels to the faith, Ergo, we ought no vſe the like example of diligence in preaching, for the preſeruing of Chriſten mē in the faith, you would thinke it no ſounde reaſon. The like ſentence may you geue of your owne.Hovve S. Auguſtine vſed the croſſe and hovve vve vſe it. For they are like. S. Auguſtine vſed it as a meane to bring infidels to the faith, we to kepe Chriſtians in the faith, he ta wynne mens heartes by ſight of it, we to contynewe theſe that are wōne in perpetuall memorie of it: he to bring mē from idolatrie, we to keepe them out of idolatrie. He to make them fixe their myndes on Chriſt that neuer heard of Chriſt: we to make them that haue fixed their heartes in Chriſt, neuer to remoue
their thoughtes from Chriſt. VVherfore albeit we haue not (thankes be to God) like pretence to vſe the croſſe, as S. Auguſtine did, yet is there no inconuenience, nor let, but that we may followe his example, and vſe it, as he did. The lacke of like pretence may not inferre a neceſsitie to refuſe old receaued faſhions and cuſtomes.

An other poſition of yours, is that the popiſhe litanie, Calf. Fol. 145. a virgin Mary pray for vs is idolatroꝰ, but where be your ſcriptures councells and fathers to proue it?Mart. Forgotte you your promiſe ſo ſone? That was a foule ouerſight. Hereafter or promiſe leſſe, or performe more. Yf you can ſay no more for it, than Luther Caluin, and the Magdeburgenſes haue done, you may go lay vp your harp with blynd Browne. All the wiſdome in your head will neuer proue it to be againſt ſcripture, councell, or auncient father.

Your applying that ſaying of Tertullian Vos religioſi, Fol. 145. a Calf. etc. you deuoute perſons ſeke for ſaluation where it is not to be founde, ye aſke it of thē that cā not geue it, omitting hym in whoſe handes it is, nor contēt with this, ye beate downe thoſe Chriſtians which knowe to aſke health, which alſo be able to obtaine it, Mart. becauſe they knowe howe to aſke it etc. to the Chriſtians, which he ſpoke by an ironie to the Gentils,Hovve vve ſeeke ayde of Saincts. is very ſclanderous and falſe. For we ſeeke for ſaluation no where, but of God, where it is to be founde. VVe aſke it of none, but of him that is able to geue it: we omitte not him in whoſe handes it is. VVe ſay not Mary haue mercy vpon vs: Peter deliuer vs, Paule heare vs, but lord haue mercy vpon vs, deliuer vs o Chriſt,The holy fathers prayed to Sainctes. Ser. de lau dibꝰ Mart. here vs o moſte mercifull father. VVhen we ſay Mary pray for vs, Peter pray for vs, Paule pray for vs, we ſeeke not ayde of Mary, Peter, and Paule, but of God, by meane of their praiers, and in ſo doing we haue the examples of the holy fathers to ſupporte vs. Holy Ephrē praied in this ſorte to the holy martyrs:De laudibus Paule. O ye moſte bleſſed men, o ye moſte glorious martyrs of God, help me miſerable man with your praier. S. Hierome praied thus to Paula when ſhe was deade: Fare well o Paula, and with they praiers, help the old age of him
that loued the. S. Auguſtine praied to all ſainctes in this manner: Orate omnia agmina ſanctorum & vniuerſi coetus beatorum, Lib. medita. cap. 24. etc. O all ye companyes of ſainctes and vniuerſall feloweſhip of the bleſſed pray that we aſsiſted wit your prayers and merites may deſerue to com to the hauen of ſaluation, with a whole ſhippe, and ſounde marchandiſe. Prudentius praied to S. Laurence in this wiſe:Lib. de coro. Mart. O thou honorable and worthy ſeruant of Chriſt, here a rude poet confeſsing the offences of his heart. Beſides this, we haue the piller and foundation of truth, the catholicke church (I meane) to ſupporte vs. She hath taught vs to pray in this wiſe,The catholique churche teacheth vs to pray to Saīctes. Mary mother of God pray for vs, Peter pray for vs, Paule pray for vs, O all ye bleſſed companies of ſaincts pray for vs. By which we lerne that it is no derogation, to the honour of God ſo to pray. They were, all holy and lerned men well ſeene in the ſcriptures and true interpretation of thē, they were in life and conuerſation godly and vertuous, not letting the feare of God departe from their eies: yf it had ben againſt ſcripture, by their great learning they would haue eſpied it, and yf they had once eſpied it, for feare of Gods diſpleaſure, they woulde neuer haue vſed it, nor the Catholicke churche theſe many hundred yeres continued it.

Yf I wiſt ye were ignorant, that ſainctes lyuing in immortall glorie in heauen pray for vs, beſides thoſe places recited, I would recite for your ſake certaine out of S.Lib. 1. epiſt. 1. de habi. virg. Cyprian,Serm. de 40. Mart. Baſile,Ho. 41 in Geneſ. In Pſal. 50 homil. 2. In Matth. hom. 27. Chryſoſtome,Lib 22. de ciuit. Dei cap. 9 & 10. Tract. 84. in Ioan. Lib. 4. ca. 28. diuin. inſtitut. Calf. Mart. Auguſtine, and diuerſe others, but yf you be as, you would ſeeme, expert or conuerſant in the auncient fathers, you finde this mentioned ſo oft, that you neede not an Eubulus, to put you in mynde of it.

VVhere you ſay that Papiſts are ſuperſtitious, becauſe Lactantius, writing againſt the Gentills, called them ſuperſtitious, who kept the memorie of the deade, and worſhipped their fathers images, as their houſhold Gods, and honored the deade in ſteede of Gods, we tell you, that we Papiſts keeping the memory of the bleſſed virgin Mary, Peter and Paule, and calling vpon them and prayng to them and other ſainctes, do not retayne the memory of the dead nor call vpon the dead,
nor pray vnto the dead. Mary is a lyue, Peter is a lyue, Paule is a lyue, and all the holy ſaincts be a lyue.Matt. 22. Luc. 20. Remembre you not that God is the God of Abraham, Iſaac, and Iacob? He is not the God of the dead but of the lyue, for all lyue vnto him? Yy you do, why ſay you that we ratayning the bleſſed memorie of Sainctes, retayne the memory of the dead? Is not the bleſſed virgin Mary in heauen? Is not Peter in heauen? It not Paule in heauen? Are not all the ſaincts and bleſſed martirs in heauen? And be they that are in heauē with God, dead with you M. Calf?Blaſphemie. VVhat horrible blaſpheme is this? VVhere is your ſight in ſcripture, non eſt Deus mortuorum, ſed viuorum, he is not God of the dead, but of the lyuing? Could you being a reader dailie occupied in ſcripture forget ſo manifeſt a place, and remembre to ſclaunder your neighbour, with no leſſe crime thā ſuperſtitiō? Alas what ouerſight was that? VVhile you laboured to proue vs ſuperſtitious, with the gentills, you haue ſhewed your ſelf more ſclaunderous, and fooliſh than many of the wicked heathēs: in ſo much that we may in maner ſay with the Prophete Ezechiele:Cap. 18. becauſe he hath ſclaundred, and done iniury to his brother, and wrought wickedneſſe in the midſt of the people, behold he is dead in his owne iniquitie. You are taken in the trappe that you layed for another.Fol. 146. a

The other note in the next Margent, That the materiall croſſe is no enſigne of Chriſt, hath ſimple proufe. The ſentence alleaged out of Carolus magnus booke againſt images is none of his: or yf it be, ſhewe vs ſome councell or auncient father, or allowed writer that fathered that booke vpon that worthie Emperour. Yf you cā not, deceaue not your ſelf, and the worlde with a falſe fable. Let it be Eliphili the man in the mones booke, made by Caluin or Illyricus or ſome ſuch pieuiſh proteſtant, and printed the firſt tyme ſo ſuſpiciouſly without any printer mentioned, either in the beginning or in the end, and without mention of the place where it was firſt founde, that euery man of meane experience may well ſee, it was none of his. But to procede,Acto. 4. Nica • . 2. M. Calfhil vnderſtanding that the place alleaged out of the ſeuenth general councell, proued plainly, that
proceſsion with the croſſe was vſed in Caeſarea a notable citie of Paleſtine, had no ſhift to put it away, but was driuen to runne to a common place,Calf. and ſay that a ſuperſtitious inſtrumēt was meeteſt to ſerue ſuche a ſuperſtitious effect: but that the croſſe ſhoulde be a ſuperſtitious inſtrument,Mart. or the tranſlating of reliques a like effect he proueth not, according to his promiſe, neither by ſcripture councell, nor auncient father, but ſaieth, that Moyſes bodie was buried in a vally by an angell no man knoweth where: Calf. Fol. 146. b Fol. 147. a and that yf the tranſlating of dead bodies had made either for the glorie of God, or commoditie of man, the reliques of ſuch a one as Moyſes was, ſhould not haue bē hidden. Mart. And that he proueth not neither, nor is able yf he would. For what yf Moiſes was the greateſt of all prophets,The not tranſlatīg of Moyſes bones, no cauſe, vvhy the tranſlating of other ſainctes bodies ſhould not be permitted. Exod. 33. Rom. 9. faithfull in all God • houſe, to whom God ſpoke mouth to mouth? was it neceſſarie therfore that his body, ſhoulde be ſhryned or his bones caried in proceſsion, or Chapel erected for him? Or becauſe it pleaſed not God to haue his bones tranſlated, was not the tranſlating of other holy Martirs bones, for the glory of God and cōmoditie of man? what reaſon is this? did not God ſay, Miſerebor cui voluero, & clemēs ero in quē mihi placuerit? I will haue mercy vpon whome I liſt, and be gentle to whome it pleaſeth me? declaring that yf it be his bleſſed will to haue this or that done, it ſhalbe done, and yf it be not his wil, it ſhal not be done? He loued Iacob and hated Eſau, was there therfore iniquitie with God? No: God forbid: In like maner it was not Gods pleaſure that Moyſes body ſhoulde be reueled and tranſlated, as S. Peters and S. Paules and other apoſtles and martirs were. Is the trāſlating of Saincts bodies therfore,Rom 9. nor for the honour of God, nor commoditie of man? VVhat reaſon is there in this? hath not the potmaker as S. Paule ſaieth, power to make one veſſel, to honour and an other for reꝓche? May he not transferre Peters bones, and let Moyſes alone? May he not make Paules bodie to be honored, and Ioſephs obſcured? S. Stephēs ſhrined, and Samuels interred? I thinck you will not denie it. And yf he being lorde of all may do it, as it pleaſeth his wiſdom beſt, then is the letting of one obſcure and vnknowen
no cauſe why the trāſlating of an other ſhould be either agaīſt the glory of God or the commoditie of man.

Vigilantius a famous heretike was in like errour,Our heretiques agree vvith Vigilātiꝰ. that reliques of ſainctes, and tranſlating their bodies, was not ſitting for the glorye of God, and therfore he accompted ſuch as worſhipped their reliques, or tranſlated them, ſuperſtitious and wicked. But S Hierome ſaide vnto hī.Hier. cōt. Vigilant. Yf they are wicked and vngodlye who worſhip the reliques of Martirs, then is Conſtantine the Emperour wicked and vngodlye, who tranſlated the holie reliques of S. Andrew, S. Luke and Timothe to Conſtantinople, at which the diuells rore, and the inhabiters of Vigilantius do confeſſe that they feele their preſence? The diuels cry at the preſence of Saīctes reliques. And nowe alſo is Arcadius who tranſlated the bones of Samuel a longe time after out of iurie, into Thracia, to be counted a wicked and vngodly man. All biſhopes are not only not to be counted wicked and vngodlye, but very fooles, who haue caried in a ſilken clothe, and golden caſe, a vile thing, and diſſolued Aſhes. The people of all the churches that mette the holy reliques, and receaued them with ſuch greate ioye, as though they ſawe the prophet preſent and alyue, were very fooles: which is very abſurde to ſay or thincke.

Euſebius reporteth that the Chriſtians gathered vp Policarpes burnt bones, and laied them vp, precioſiſsimis gemmis chariora, Lib 4 cap. 15. hiſto. & omni auro probabiliora per ignem facta, more dearer then the moſt preciouſe pearles that were, and made by the fire more pure than all gold. And if it had bene neither for the glory of God, nor for the commoditie of man, would the Chriſtians amonge the mideſt of the gētills either haue begged Policarpe his bodie, either haue gathered vp his bones: or haue thoughte them more pretious than the moſt pretious pearles that were? It is not credible.Calf.

And where M. Calf. thincketh that they made a right good excuſe, that denying the bodie of Polycarpe, ſaide it ſhould not be deliuered, Ne Chriſto relicto hunc. colere inciperent, leaſt Chriſte forſaken, they ſhould beginne to ſerue him, Mart. You may vnderſtande good people that he hath ſuch malice againſt the church, and ſuch deſpite againſt the reuerend ceremonies
of the Chriſtians,The Policie of the diuel cō mēded by M. Calf. and reliques of ſainctes, that he had rather cōmend the policie of the diuell, and practiſe of the Iewes, then thincke reuerendly with Chriſtes catholique church of ſainctes, and their reliques. For the excuſe why Polycarpus bodie ſhould not be deliuered to the Chriſtians to be buried, was deuiſed by the diuell, and made by the wicked Iewes, enemies to Chriſte, and all Chriſtian religion: and yet his wiſdome thincketh they made a righte good excuſe: as thoughe there were any goodnes in the diuell, or hope that he and his ſhoulde meane well to the Chriſtians.The excuſe vvhich M. Calf. thinketh right good deuiſed by the diuel and vttred by the Ievves. That you may thincke this no fayned matter, and trie more ſpedilie what ſpirite ruleth in him, I will tell you what Euſebius ſayeth of this matter, in the fourth booke, and xv. chapiter of his eccleſiaſticall hiſtorie. VVhē Polycarpus was thruſte through with a ſworde, he ſaieth: Ille aemulus totius boni, & aduerſarius iuſtorum, poſtquam vidit, etc. That enuier of all goodnes and enemie of all iuſte men, after he ſawe that he was crowned bothe for the glorie of martirdome, and vertues of his notable life, and had got the rewardes of immortalitie by deathe, he beganne to doe as much as he coulde, Polycarpe crovvned for good vvorkes. that no man ſhould geue the Chriſtians his reliques to buriall, yf they deſired them. VVherupō Nicetas Herods father, and brother to Dalcas, were earneſtly prouoked to goe vnto the iudge, and deſire him that he woulde not geue the bodie to be buried, leaſt peraduēture (quothe he) the Chriſtians forſaking him that is crucified, Nicetas Herodes father. begynne to woorſhipe this man. Theſe are Euſebius woordes.

Here you ſee playnly, that the graue counſeler, and polityke practiſer, who laboured that Polycarps bodie ſhould no be buried, was Sathan, the enemie of all goodnes and good men. You ſee that the promoter of the cauſe, that went to the iudge and required that it mighte not be buried, was a wicked Iewe, yea herodes father. And yeat M. Calf. yower reader and preacher, thincketh this a right good excuſe. Are not yow happie that heare him preache with auctoritie, that thincketh that right good that was deuiſed by the diuell, enemye of all goodnes, and practiſed by a Iewe that maligneth Chriſte and all Chriſtians? May ye not reioyce that yow haue ſuch a guide to directe yower ſoules? VVhat ſhalbe euil with him, if the diuells
counſell be good? VVhat ſhalbe vnholye if the Iewes requeſtes againſt the Chriſtiās be holye? VVhat ſhalbe refuſed if their aduiſe be admitted? horrible is it to thincke. Beware therfore good people in tyme, trye the ſpirites that preache, 1. Ioan. 4. whether they be of God or no. And if you finde that there is no communicatiō betwene lighte, and darcknes, God and Baal, Chriſte and the diuel, you may ſee that there is litle grace of the holie ghoſt,Litle grace in hym that thinketh the diuels coū ſel againſt the Chriſtiās right good. The diuel cā not abide the reliques of Saincts. Hom. 5. ad pop. Antioch. ho. 5 de beato Iob. De S. Babila. or ſparkle of Gods ſpirite in him, that likethe the diuells coūſell, and thinketh that right good for the Chriſtians, which the ſworne and deadly enemies of Chriſte gaue in deſpite of the Chriſtians.

But all this is becauſe he wil not allowe the hauing of Sayntes reliques. And no maruell. For the diuell him ſelf can not abide them, as S. Hierome ſpecified before, and S. Chriſoſtome playnly affirmeth, ſayīg. I would be in thoſe places where the chaynes remayne, and ſee the fetters, which the diuells feare, and tremble at, and Angells reuerēce. Yf I were diſbourdened of Eccleſiaſticall cares, and had a ſtronge bodye, I woulde not refuſe to take a pilgrymage, that I mighte ſee the chaynes and pryſon where S. Paule was boūde. In an other place he ſaieth. Such is the power of Saynctes, that the diuells can not abide the Shadowes and clothes of them that are alyue, and as for thē that are dead, they feare their tombes. VVhoſoeuer is deſirous to ſee more of Saynctes reliques, let him reade Chriſoſtomes oration vpon the Martir Babilas, his commentaries vpon S. Paules epiſtles at the beginning:Epiſt. 85 S. Ambroſe,de ciuit. Dei lib. 22 cap. 8. Serm. 256. de temp. Auguſtine,Hom. de S Bladina Euſebius Emiſſenus,Serm de S Barlaā Mart. & in Conc. Ma mertis mart. Baſill, and all the auncient fathers of the church. There ſhall he finde ſuch euidēt proufes and auctoririties for the holye reliques of Sainctes, that vnleſſe he wilbe blinde, and wander after ſuch as thīcke the coūſell of the diuel, that ca not abide the tōbes of the Apoſtles, ād reliques of Sainctes, to be righte good, as M. Calf. doth, he cā not choſe but acknowledge that they are of greate vertue and pouer, by the goodnes of God and merites of Ieſus Chriſt whoſe croſſe they caried, ād whoſe faythe they ꝓfeſſed. VVherfore ſeing M. Calfs. deuiſe, ſayīg that the croſſe ſignifieth a cādelſticke, a creſſet, a torche pole, ād torche ſtaffe, is ꝓued to be fooliſh and phantaſticall, ſeing the lawes of Iuſtinian dedeclare the vſe of all Chriſtendome in his tyme, and although
they binde not euery mā, as Emperours lawes, yet they ſhewe what the order of Chriſtes church was at that tyme, which ſithēs by cuſtome is growē into a lawe, Seīg the facte of S. Auguſtine cominge in with a croſſe, and featching in the reliques of Anaſtaſius with a croſſe in like māner, declare that Chriſten men in thoſe dayes vſed the croſſe in proceſsion, it remayneth that my proufes for hauing a croſſe at the ſinging and ſaying of litanies be ſufficient, and conuince, that ſeing it was the vſe of the primitiue churche, continued vntill our tyme without any laufull interruption, and neuer abrogated by any generall councel, or decree of the head biſshop of Chriſtes catholique churche, we Chriſten men deſirous to lyue in obedience, and followe the ſtepps of the forefathers of the primitiue church, ought to continewe the ſame order in ſynging or ſaying our litanie, and praye for all eſtates of men, and eſpeciallie for the chiefe gouernour of his churche, vt dominus conſeruet eum, viuificet eum, & beatum faciat eum in terra, Pſal 40. & non tradat eum in animam inimicorum eius. That our lord may preſerue hym, geue hym longe life, and make hym happy in the earth, and not delyuer hym to the power and will of his enemies.

div.head: THAT MANY STRAVNGE AND WONDERFVLL MIRACLES VVERE VVROVGHTE BY THE ſigne of the Croſſe. THE EIGHT ARTICLE.
div.p:
THAT M. Calf. thinketh,Fol. 148. b miracles wroughte in theſe latter dayes to haue ben wroughte ofter by the power of the diuell, than by the ſpirite of God, it is no newe thing to be woū dred at (good readers) it hath ben an olde ſurmiſe of heathēs and heretikes. The Iewes obiected to our Sauiour Chriſte that in Beelzebub prince of the diuells he did caſt out diuells. Matt. 12. The Paganes ſaid that he wrought his miracles by magicke and inchauntements.Augu. ſer. 11. de verbis domini in Mat. Idem li. 21 cap 8. de ciuit. Dei. In Praefa. Inſti. ad Franciſ. Gall. Reg. Fol. 149. a Calf. The heathens attributed thoſe ſtraunge thinges that were done by the merites of ſainctes, to ſorcery. Caluine a wicked Apoſtata crieth that the miracles of ſainctes are friuolous, ridiculous, vayne and falſe lies, done by Sathan that transfigureth him ſelfe into the angell of light. In like manner doth M. Calf. here: and furder openly proteſt, that vnleſſe I will admitte that witches and wiſſerds muſt be conſulted, that Berecinthia, Eſculapius, Hercules, and Proſerpina, diuels, or wicked ſpirites in hell muſt haue ſacrifice, becauſe by the diuell they haue done miracles, he will not graunte the ſigne of the croſſe to be admitted for any miracle, that hath
bene wrought by it. Mart. M. Calf. like to Pharao. For which I may well compare him to Pharao who would not beleaue the true miracles wrought of God by his ſeruātes, Moyſes and Aarō, becauſe he vnderſtoode that his ſorcerers and wiſſerders of Egipte were able to doe the like by incantations and inchauntmentes.

The miracles that were done by the croſſe (as I haue alleadged) were not done of late yeares,Miracles done by the ſigne of the croſſe, done by the povver of God. nor by inchauntementes, nor by ſorcerie, nor by the power of the diuell. They were done by the power of God, more than a thouſande yeares agoe: for breuities ſake, conſider but twoe of them with me. VVhen Helena had founde the croſſe, it was leyed vpon a gentlewoman in Hieruſalē that had bene lōge ſicke. As ſone as it touched her, ſhe recouered, and was made hole. Macarius biſshop of Hieruſalem, an holy ād vertuous mā, to diſcern which was our lordes croſſe, willed all three to be brought vnto him,Ruff lib. 1 ca. 7. & 8. and ſaid: God ſhall reueale it vnto vs. In his prayer he ſaide: Tu domine oſtende. Shewe thou O lorde which was the croſſe, that ſerued to the glory of Chriſte, that is, on which chriſt died. She at the touch of our lordes croſſe being reuiued, began to magnifie the power of God. This was a great miracle wroughte by the the power of God, at the touche of his croſſe. The enemies can not denye it.

Paulinus in 10. Natali. Foelicis.Furder at Nola, when the religious houſe was ſett on fyre, Chriſte preſerued it miraculouſlye, and therfore Paulinus required his people to geue thanckes to Chriſte, and praiſes to allmightie God. The meane wherby Chriſt wrought that miracle, was a ſplinter of his croſſe, heald in the fire by the biſshope. He ſaide him ſelfe: Nec mea vox aut dextra illum, ſed vis crucis ignem terruit. Neither my voyce, neither my hande, but the power of the croſſe made the fire ceaſe: By which it is euident that the ſaide miracle was wrought of Chriſte by a piece of his croſſe. Beſides, the woman that Epiphanius ſpeaketh of,Lib. 1. hereſ 30. Lib. 22. ca. 8. de ciuit. Dei. was ayded by the ſigne of the croſſe, and faith. Innocentia that S. Auguſtine mentioneth, receaued health by the ſigne of the croſſe, ād both theſe miracles were wrought of God by the meanes of his croſſe.

Epiphanius ſayeth playnly: The woman receaued health, by the ſigne of the croſſe and faith. S. Auguſtine ſayeth that Innocentia was admoniſhed
in her ſleape, to make the ſigne of the croſſe vpon her breaſte, and that ſhe was not warned ſo to doe of any euil angel,Innocētia cōmaunded of God to make the ſigne of the croſſe. but of God him ſelfe, it is eaſy to be gathered by S. Auguſtine. She was, foemi na religioſiſsima, a moſt godlie woman. She turned her ſelf to god with prayer in her extreame neceſsitie, and whiles ſhe prayed, ſhe was hearde, and cōmaūded to make the ſigne of the croſſe, but by whome I pray you? By the diuell, or ſome euill angell? No: S. Auguſtine ſayeth: She turned her ſelfe to God, ſhe prayed to God, and conforted ſhe was, but by whome M. Calf? By the diuel? That were ſtraunge, that God ſhould forſake the godlie, and the diuell healpe. Chriſte not heare whē we call, as he promiſed, and the diuel be readie to heare, and do good, before we call.

This caſe then ſtāding ſo,M. Calf. cā no more refuſe the croſſe thā Chriſtes doctrine becauſe vvounders haue ben done by coniurers. Ioan. 14. that theſe miracles were wrought through the almightie pouer of God by the croſſe, ſhould any man refuſe the croſſe, becauſe he findeth in prophane hiſtories and other authours falſe wounders, illuſiōs, and ſignes wrought by the diuel and his angells? by Sorcerers and witches? There is no reaſon in it, vnleſſe we wil forſake our faith, and beleaue none of Chriſtes doctrine confirmed with miracles, becauſe we reade that the Sorcerers of Egipte, Simon Magus, and other inchaunters haue wroughte greate wounders by helpe of the diuell. Chriſt him ſelfe did many miracles whiles he lyued on earthe: and told his diſciples that he that beleaued in him ſhoulde do thoſe workes, that Chriſte did. And according to this promiſſe of Chriſte, not only the Apoſtles haue wrought more miracles than be expreſſed in the ſcripture or actes of the Apoſtles, but diuerſe holie men haue done ſtraunge thinges, as are reported vnto vs in olde hiſtories, and auncient monumentes of the fathers.

Nowe yf we in this latter age, ſhall not beleaue thoſe miracles that were done of olde tyme, becauſe the like to outwarde ſhewe may be done by the diuell, either we muſt be driuen to ſaye that ſithens the Apoſtles tyme,Abſurdities. there were no good men in earth that had faith in Chriſt or if they had faith, that Chriſte did not kepe his promiſe, and geue them power to worke miracles: or if Chriſte gaue them power to worke miracles, that
the old hiſtories and auncient fathers reporte vnto vs the dedes of diuells and ſorcerers, for miracles of Sainctes and holy men. For certayne it is that miracles were done at the firſt planting of Chriſtes faith in all nations, and the name of God glorified by wonderfull ſtrange thinges, and ſome notice made of holy men in writinge for the benefit of the poſteritie.

Yf they muſt nowe be but tales, idle fables, and illuſions of the diuel, ād wicked workes of ſorcerers (as M. Calf. lewdly ſurmiſeth) Alas in what in what caſe are we? whome ſhall we beleue? The auncient fathers that ſaid, they were true miracles, or newe frontick proteſtantes that ſay they are falſe illuſions? The fathers that ſaid the were done by the power of God? or proteteſtantes that ſaye they were done by the power of the diuell? The fathers that ſaye they were done by holie men? or frontike and Bedlem miniſters that thincke they were done by wicked ſorcerers? Yf we wil followe God we muſt beleaue our elders, for he ſayeth:Deut. 32. God vvilleth vs beleaue our elders. Aſke thy father, and he ſhall ſhewe the, aſke thy elders and they ſhal tell thee. And when God biddeth me aſke my father doth he not bidd me beleaue my father? when he biddethe me aſke my elders? dothe he not bidd me beleaue my elders? yes verelye. VVherfore ſeing Ruffinus, Epiphanius, Paulinus, and Saint Auguſtine tell vs expreſſelye, that theſe miracles of the croſſe were done by God, and Sulpitius Seuerus, Euſebius, Sozomenus, Oroſius, and Eutropius reporte the like of other, yf we wil followe the commaundement of God, and beleaue our forefathers, and throughlye perſwade our ſelues that Chriſte accordinge to his promiſſe gaue thoſe that did beleaue, power to worke miracles, we muſte (I ſay) thinke that theſe miracles which they haue reported vnto vs were true myracles wrough by God, and not falſe illuſions ſhewed by Sathan, eſpeciallie ſeing the church who hath auctoritie to diſcerne true miracles frome falſe, hathe allowed theſe recordes for true, and cōdēned none of the ſaide miracles as falſe. Neither hathe M. Calf. any ſcripture, coūcel, or aunciēt father that teacheth hī to diſcredite true miracles wroughte by God, becauſe ſome falſe wounders and illuſions are wrought by the diuell, or not to admitte
the ſigne of the croſſe, by which God hath done miracles becauſe Sorcerers, wiſſerders and witches by ſome inchauntmentes haue done ſtraunge thinges.2. Theſſ. 2. Fol. 150 a

That which he alleadgeth out of S. Paule that the wicked man ſhalbe reuealed, whoſe cominge is by the working of Sathan, with all power and ſignes, and lying wonders, is to be referred to Antichriſte, in the latter end of the worlde, before whoſe coming (ſaieth S. Paule) there ſhalbe diſceſsio, a goinge awaye, a ſeparation from Chriſte, and the vnitie of his churche and See of Rome. The miracles that Epiphanius, Paulinus, Ruffine, and S. Auguſtine ſpeake of, were done in the primitiue churche withī foure hūdred yeares after Chriſte. The other place of ſcripture brought out of S. Math.Cap. 7. Fol. 150. a that many ſhall ſaye in the latter daye, Lorde, lorde, haue we not prophecied in thy name, haue we not done many miracles, Ho 25. in 7. Matt. Faith only doth not Iuſtifie. etc. proueth as S. Chryſoſtome ſayeth that, Fides abſque operū ſanctitate nihil valet, etc. Faith without holynes of workes auayleth nothing, and that not only faith, but neither the working of miracles it ſelfe ſhall profit him, yf he doe them without poſſeſsions of vertues, and that neither faith, neither miracles ſhal helpe yf good life aſsiſt not. It declareth alſo that euill men do miracles by the gifte of God, which they receaued to the edifyng of Chriſtians and furdering the Ghoſpell: and as Sacraments lacke not their vertue and effecte, becauſe they are miniſtred by euil men, ſo miracles done to the honour of God lacke not auctoritie, although they be done by the wicked.

The wordes of S. Auguſtine, Si Angeli etc. Lib 10 de ciuit Dei cap. 16. Yf angells require ſacrifice to be done vnto them, and worke ſignes with all, and contrary wiſe ſome other teſtifie that ſacrifice muſt only be made to God, and yet do no miracles, we muſt beleue theſe and not them, thoſe I ſay make nothing againſte me, for they ſpeake of ſuch as would derogate honour from God, we talke of miracles done to the honour of God, and commaunded by God him ſelfe. M. Calf. ſhould firſte haue proued that miracles wrought by the ſigne of the croſſe, and catholiques of olde, were as greate derogation to Gods honour and glorie, as the requeſt of an angell, deſiring ſacrifice to be done vnto him, before he had obiected this ſaying of S. Auguſtine,
or the other ſpokē againſt the Manichees,Fol. 150. b a curſed kinde of heretickes, who if they had ben able to haue done miracles, would haue done thē to the deſtroying of Chriſtes faith, ād his Ghoſpell, and not to furder any truth, or glorifie God. For it runneth againſt ſuch, and not againſt vs.

Fol 190 bVVhere he ſayeth: that wicked ſprites lurke in ſhrines, in Roodes, in croſſes, and images, tell him to his face (good readers) that yf he had any ſighte in the olde fathers he woulde neuer vtter ſo fonde and blaſphemous a lye.Ho 7. de Natiuit. Machab. Chryſoſtome telleth vs, that diuells and wicked ſpirites which are in deede the capitaines and maſters of theaues, where they ſee the hodies of glorious martirs ſhryned, runne away by and by, Lib. vno cōt gētill. and flee for feare from that place. Againe he writeth that when the bodie of Babilas was brought to Daphnis where Pithius Apollo, gaue oracles, out of a greate idoll, He made the diuel dumbe, and impotent, not able to do any thing in the worlde: and at lenght,The diuels feare the reliques of Sainctes. Hom. 55. in Matt. Queſt. 38 ad Anthioch. Daemonem ipſum exegit, Droue away the deuill him ſelf. For ſuche is the power of ſaincts, that the diuels cānot abide ſo much as the ſhadowes, and garments of thoſe that are a lyue, and feare the ſhrynes of thoſe that are dead.

Beſides for the croſſe he ſaieth that the diuell fleeth away whenſoeuer he ſee it: and ſo doth Athanaſius and diuerſe other fathers, as I haue declared before, which yf M. Calf. had fore ſeene, he woulde neuer haue ben ſo impudent as to haue made ſo vayne an aſſertiō and blaſphemous a lye. But we muſt beare with him: his great zeale infatuateth his litle witte. In deede S. Cyprian talking of the vanitie of idols writeth:Tract. de vanitate idolorum That diuels were in pillers and images of their falſe gods, and that being there, they gaue oracles, and inwrapped truthes in falſities, diſquieted mē in their ſleepe, diſtorted their membres, tooke away their health, and ſuch like.

Nor Shryns nor rodes, nor croſſes mētioned in S. Cyprian.As for ſhrynes, roodes, or croſſes, or woorking miracles, S. Cyprian ſpeaketh not ſo much as one worde, but to your confuſiō that thinke, our myracles to be wrought by the power of the diuell, he ſaieth of thoſe wicked ſpirites that lurked in idols: Theſe wicked ſprites adiured by the lyuing God, yelde by and by to vs, and goe away and departe out of the poſſeſſed bodies. Ye may ſee them yeld ſecretly, at our voyce and prayer, to be burned with fire, to crye out, to lamēt,
to vaniſh away, as the faith of the patiēt helpeth, or grace of the man that cureth, doth aſpire. In like manner Athanaſius declareth,Lib. 2. de Incar. that before Chriſt came, the diuells did much moleſt and trouble men with diuerſe phantaſies and ſights, and tooke vp for a dwelling place, fountaynes, ryuers, ſtocks, and ſtones, and by vayne ſlyghtes deceaued the ſimple,
• iuels driuē avvay by the ſigne of the croſſe. but when Chriſt was ones come, their pompe periſhed: for man vſing only the ſigne of the croſſe, driueth away all their ſubtilitie. And for more euident proufe of the vertue of the croſſe, he ſaieth: Let him come hither that ſeeketh to learne experiēce of theſe thinges, to wit, of the diuels pompe, of deceith of inchauntment, and wounders of ſorcery, The vertue of the croſſe. vtatur ſigno vt illi dicunt ridiculae crucis: Let him vſe the ſigne of the fooliſh croſſe (as they ſay) naming only Chriſt, he ſhall ſee the diuels to be put to flight by it, ſootheſaying to ceaſe, magike and poyſoning deſtroyed. Yf the diuels feare the croſſe and be put to flight, and dryuen away with the croſſe,Our miracles not to be aſcribed to Satan and vvitches. then do they not lurke in croſſes: if magike, inchauntemēts and ſorcery be diſtroyed by the croſſe, and good men calling vpon Chriſt, and his holy name, then are not their miracles, to be aſcribed, to the woorking of Satan, witches, and wiſſers.

Athanaſius to proue that miracles were not done by a dead man, as the Gentills cauilled, vſed this reaſon:Vertues vvrought by the ſigne of the croſſe. Yf by the ſigne of the croſſe all magicall arte is driuen away, all poyſoning is taken away, all idols forſaken, all ſenſuall pleaſure ſtayed, and all men made looke vp from earth to heauen, VVho can ſay that Chriſt doing ſuch things, is but a dead man? In like manner may I ſay, yf the diuels and wicked ſprites tremble and quake at the ſhrynes of martirs, yf they complaine of their preſence, flee away at the ſight of the croſſe, and vaniſh away when it is in preſence, who can thinke that they lurke in ſhrynes, croſſes, or images? VVho can thinke that miracles wrought by the ſigne of the croſſe were wrought by the diuell? None but ſuch as haue forſaken the churche and muſt ſeeke vyle ſhiftes to colour hereſie, and furder the worke of the diuell.
