As for this poſition of his,Fol 150 a Calf. That it is not a ſufficiēt proufe to make a thing good, to ſay that miracles were wrought by it,Mart. I would fayne learne what he meaneth by this woorde (make:) yf he taketh it to make, as the poticary maketh his confectiō,
ād goldſmith a ring I wil not cōtend:True miracles done by a thing, declare the thing to be good. Matt. 9 Luc. 6. Mar 8. Act 19. Euſe. li. 7. cap 14 hiſtor lib. 6. cap 41. Tripart. but if by that worde (make) he meaneth to declare cōſider with me a while gentle reader, howe litle truth it hath. Chriſt wrought miracles by his diuine power in earth: were not thoſe miracles a ſufficiēt ꝓufe to make vs beleaue, that his power was of God? The hem of Chriſts coate cured a womā of a bluddy flix. VVas it not a ſufficiēt proufe to make vs beleaue, that the hē of Chriſts cote was holy? S. Paules Napkins healed diſeaſes, was not that healing a ſufficiēt ꝓufe to make vs thīke that thoſe napkīs, had a vertue by touchīg his body? the herbe that growed at the foote of our ſauiours image in Caeſarea Philippi, did many ſtraunge cures, in ſo much that it was called medicamētum omnium paſsionum & aegritudinum, a medicine of all paſsions and ſores: was it not a ſufficient proufe to declare that herbe to be good?

In like maner God wrought diuerſe miracles, by the coates, napkins,Auguſt. lib. 22. Cap 8. de ciuit. Dei. Fol. 150 a Calf. M Calfs miracles. aſhes of martirs, and ſigne of his croſſe, Is not this a ſufficient proufe to decare that the coates, napkins, and aſhes of Martirs and ſigne of the croſſe be good? No quoth M. Calf. God doth abhorre adultrie, yet by the act of it, he ſuffreth a miracle to be done etc. God is offended with theft, yet doth he ſuffer ſtollen bread to feede vs, whiche is only the power of his ſecret and miraculous working, Nowe yf you gather, that the vſe of the croſſe is comendable, becauſe of myracles done, by the ſame reaſon the adulterer and theefe may defende and mayntaine their vnlaufull doinges, becauſe as greate or greater myracles are wrought by them.

Mart.Is not this a worthye Paradox for ſo profounde a diuine? But in what, ſcripture councell or father doth he reade that a miracle is wrought by adulterie and ſtollen bread? Is the begetting of a child either in laufull matrimonye (which God ordayneth) either in adulterie (which he abhorreth) or the feeding of a man with ſtollen bread any more myraculous than all other ordinarie and common workes of nature are? Be they not both done by the common courſe of nature ſuch as in all ages, in all countries haue ben done from the beginning, and may contynue
to the worlds end? Yes verely: ād yet no miracles, otherwiſe then the generation of all other creatures, and the feading of birds in the ayre, and beaſts in the field. VVhen I ſpoke of miracles, I ſpoke of ſuch as were farre paſsing the capacitie of mā, and commō courſe of nature. I ſpoke of ſuch as were wrought by the mightie power of God contrary to all nature, as the examples may particularly declare. And M. Calf. to make ſilly ſoules beleaue that a thing is not commendable becauſe of Miracles done by it, varieth groſſely in his anſwer.Fol. 150. a Hovve M. Calf. varieth in his anſvver. For where euery wiſe man ſhould frame his anſwer, to the queſtiō, and reaſonne, Secundū ſubiectā materiā, according to the matter that is treated, he fleeth from that: and where mention was made of miracles done aboue the common courſe of nature, he telleth vs of ſuch as were done by the commō courſe of nature. And where mention was made of miracles done through the mightie power of God, to his honour and glorie by the croſſe, he telleth vs of myracles done by adulterie and theft to his great diſhonour, which is extra oleas, farre wide frō the purpoſe God knoweth.

Myracles done through the omnipotencie of God for the aduauncement of his glorie, are a ſufficiēt proufe, to declare that the thing by which (as a meane) thoſe myracles were done is comendable, as I proued before.Miracles done by heretikes not able to cō mend a thing. VVounders and ſignes done by adulterers, and theues, by ſorcerers, and inchaunters, by heretiks and Apoſtatats, to the diſhonour of God, and ſubuerſion of his faith, ſeeme they neuer ſo great, are not able to make the thing commendable, whereby they woorke their miracles. Neither can the adulterer and thefe defend thier vnlaufull doings, becauſe great miracles by wrought by them, as we can defende the croſſe becauſe miracles were wrought by it, vnleſſe they or ſome newe diuine for them, can proue, that adulterie and theft is as good as the croſſe of Chriſt,Three reaſons of M. Calfs vvhy mirac •• s • ake not for the croſſe. or that the adulterers and theues were commaunded to committe adulterie and theft, as we can ſhewe that men and women were commaunded to vſe the croſſe, and wrought in deede true myracles by it. VVhiche ſeing youe denie, and bring three reaſons why myracles make not for the croſſe, I will firſt examyne your reaſons, and
then conſider your anſwers to the authorities, that proue miracles to haue bene wroughte by the ſigne of croſſe.

Before you bringe your thre reaſons you aſke this queſtion, why the durte of the ſtreate (ſeing Chriſt wrought a miracle by it) ſhould not as wel be honoured as the croſſe of the aulter? A queſtiō of M. Calfs. Fol. 151. a To which a briefe anſwere may ſerue: It is a durtie queſtion, mete for a durtie diuine.The anſvver. The croſſe was an inſtrumēt by which all the worlde was ſaued, the durte a meane by which one only mā was healed. The Croſſe a lyuely repreſentation of Chriſtes deathe. The durte but a memorie of one mans health. The croſſe effectuous euer ſithens. The durte neuer effectuous but then. The croſſe commaūded of God to be made and vſed, by diuers reuelations from heauē. The durt neuer mentioned to any ſuch purpoſe, nor of God, angell, nor man. The like may be ſaide to that which you talke of Moyſes buſhe,Fol. 158. a. b. Aarons rood, the wood of Marach, the braſen Serpent, the water out of the rocke, Gedeons fleeſe, Sampſons Iawe bone, Elias Cloke, Naamans waſhing, the hem of Chriſtes garmēt, the ſhadowe of S. Peter, Napkins of S. Paule, and ſuch like.

Fol. 151. a The firſt reaſon. Calf.The firſte of yower reaſons is made by this interrogation, why ſhould not ſuch external meanes as Chriſte and his Apoſtles vſed, and the ſcripture mentioneth, be had in admiration, rather then the idle deuiſe of man, of the which there is no lawfull preſident, Yf any externall meanes wherby ſtraunge wonders haue come to paſſe, Mart. be to be had in admiration? For anſwere we ſay, that it is moſt reaſonable that all ſuch externall meanes as Chriſte and his Apoſtles vſed, and the ſcripture mentioneth be had in admiration ſo far forthe as is behofull for vs, rather than the idle deuiſe of man wherof there is no laufull preſident. And with all we tell you that the croſſe is no idle deuiſe of man,The croſſe no idle deuiſe of man. but a doctrine of the holy Ghoſte, and tradition of the Apoſtles. For which we haue laufull preſidents and ſufficient recorde. This to yower interrogation ſett out for a reaſon may ſuffiſe▪ vntill you confirme by ſcriptures councells, and fathers, that the croſſe is an idle deuiſe of man, wherof there is
no laufull preſident. The ſecōd reaſon is this:Fol. 151. a The 2. reaſon. Calf. Yf miracles were done by the ſigne of the croſſe, yet were they not done only by the ſigne of the croſſe, and therfore the croſſe onely ſhould not according (to my treatiſe) without the reſt be magnified. In deede M. Calf. Chriſt worketh all miracles:Mart. Chriſte healed the ſicke woman at Hieruſalem: Chriſt preſerued the faire damſell frome rape in Syciria: Chriſt preſerued the religiouſe houſe from burninge in Nola: Chriſte healed Innocentia of her cancker in Carthage: but quibus medijs, by what meanes? by faith, prayer, and ſigne of the Croſſe: and as I finde the ſtories in the authours ſo doe I reporte thē in my treatiſe, and not ſay they were done as you falſely imagine, by the croſſe only, without Chriſte and faith in his paſsion, nor conclude that the Croſſe without the reſt ſhould be magnified, as you heatheniſhly imagine, and make ſely ſoules beleaue.

The thirde reaſon is this.Fol. 151. a The 3. reaſon. Calf. Yf it were true that ſuch miracles were done by the ſigne of the croſſe, yet this can be no reaſon why the croſſe ſhould nowe be had in eſtimation, vnleſſe you will haue all meanes and inſtrumentes of wounders heretofore wroughte, as the hem of Chriſtes garment, the ſpetle and the claye, the ſhadowe of Peter, and Napkins of S. Paule to be likewiſe honoured and eſtemed of vs? Mart. Yf you had proued by ſcripture, councel, or father, that we can not worſhip the croſſe and honour it, vnleſſe we honour and worſhip the hem of Chriſtes, garment, ſpetle, and claye, Shadowe of S. Peter, and Napkins of S. Paule, this laſt reaſon of yowers, ſhould haue had ſome colour of reaſon, but ſeing you aſſeuere it only without any reaſon, I will counte it, but a vayne aſſertion.A capitayne may be revvarded although euery ſouldier be not revvarded. I beſeeke you may not a capitaine that hath gotten a great victorie be rewarded of his prince vnleſſe all the pety capitaynes and ſouldiers be rewarded alſo? May not the Maior of London be priuiledged to weare a coller of golde, vnleſſe euery citizen be licenſed to weare the like? May not ſome whote puritanes of the newe clergie be diſpenſed with for wearing of a longe gowne, ſquare cap, and ſattē tippet, vnleſſe al be diſpēſed with all? I thinck you
will gladly ſubſcribe to theſe: and if the foreſaid be laufull, why may not the croſſe of Chriſte be honoured,The croſſe may be vvoorſhipped although other inſtruments of Chriſtes death be not vvoorſhipped. worſhipped, and eſtemed, vnleſſe all other meanes and inſtruments heretofore wroughte, be eſtemed of vs? Shewe yower reaſon to the contrary in yower nexte replye. In the meane tyme vnderſtand that we honour, worſhip, and eſteme the croſſe, as the chiefe and principall inſtrument of our redemptiō, becauſe of all other it doth moſt lyuely ſette before our eies, the death and paſsion of Chriſte. The hem of Chriſtes garment, ſpetle, and clay, yf we had them, we would honour, worſhip, and eſteme them, for his ſake whoſe pretiouſe body they touched. And as a true louier will highly eſteme a ring, napkin, or other iewell ſent from his louier, be it neuer ſo ſmale: So would we for the loue that we beare to Chriſt, for his infinite mercy towardes vs, both highly eſteme the very durt that he touched, yf we might happely come by it, and for his ſake reuerence S. Peters ſhaddowe, S. Paules parletts, and S. Stephens bones, and all other ſainctes reliques, becauſe they were Gods frends, and moſt ſpeciallie his croſſe. Nowe to your anſwers againſt the authorities that proue miracles to haue ben wrought by the ſigne of the croſſe. And firſt for the vertue of the Ladie Helena, what meane you to diminiſh her credit, and impaire her good name as much as in you lieth,Fol. 151. b by calling her a concubine to Conſtance? haue you not reade, that it is: Impium morderee mortuos? A wicked and vngodly parte to bite the dead? The Poete Horace could haue tolde you,Lib. 1. ſer. ſatyr 4. that abſentem, qui rodit amicum hic niger eſt, hunc tu Romane caueto, he is a man without al honeſtie, that gnaweth and biteth at his frend that is abſent, o thou that art a Romayne and true gentle man, beware of this man: he doth not onely bite at his frends that are abſent, but at Gods frendes lyuing with glorie, in heauen.Fol 101. b Fol. 103. a Sainctes ſclaundered. Fabian an holy martyr he calleth infamous, S. Cypriā, proude and blaſphemous. Helena ſuperſtitious, and concubine to Conſtance. If this thing were true, is not this a parte of curſed Cham? Yf a man ſhould bring a fact of S. Peter, S. Paule, Mary Magdalene, king Dauid, or Salomon to confirme a truth, were
it the dutie of a Chriſtē mā to ſay (by your leaue) S. Peter was a traitour? S. Paule a perſecutor? Mary Magdalene a harlott? Dauida mā kyller, & adulterer? Salomō a fornicatour? & keper of cō cubines? No. God that ſuffred thē to fall, rayſed them vp againe, and made them glorious in his ſight. And whome hath glorified we muſt not diſcredite, in ſuch thinges as they did after penance done for their ſynnes, when they were in fauour with God, when they were waſshed, when they were ſanctified, 1. Cor 6. The vertue of Lady Helena when they were iuſtified in the name of our lord Ieſus Chriſt, and ſpiritie of our Lord God. As for ladie Helena, the hiſtories and auncient fathers ſay, that ſhe was a woemanAmbro. de olitu Theod. Sanctae memoriae Ruff. in lib. 1 cap. 7. hiſto. incomparabilis fide, & religione animi, & magnificentia ſingulari, religioſa foemina, Paulinus epiſt 11. ad Seuerum. fidelis mulier, regina venerabilis, ſpiritum ſanctum per affectum pium meruit, foemina virtutibus omnibus Suidas. ornatiſsima, of holy memory, pearleſſe for faith and deuotion of minde, and ſingular magnificence and liberalitie, a holy matrone, a faithefull woeman that deſerued to haue the holy Ghoſte, throughe her good affection, a woeman plentifully adourned with all kinde of vertue, not ſuperſtitious (as it pleaſeth maiſter Calf. to ſay, nor gaddīg) as he ſpitefully ſaith, to Hieruſalem on pilgrimage of a ſinguler fantaſie, but going of great deuotion inſpired of God.

S. Ambroſe ſaieth: Inſudit ei ſpiritus vt lignum quereret, De obitu Theod. The holy ghoſt moued Helena to go to Hieruſalem. Epiſt 11. ad Seuer. certam indaginem ſpiritus ſanctus inſpirat, lignum infuſo ſibi ſpiritu reuelauit. The holy ghoſte did put into her heart to ſeeke the wood, The holy ghoſte doth inſpire that diligent ſearche vnto her, by the holy ghoſte, with which ſhe was inſpired, ſhe founde out the wood. Paulinus writeth, that ſhe obtayned of her ſonne to purge the places, and builde a church where our Sauiour Chriſte had trodd, diuino inſpirita conſilio, inſpired by the counſell of God, and when ſhe was at Hieruſalem, and by diligent inquiſition aduertiſed of the place, ſhe ſet mē a digging, vrgente ſine dubio conceptae reuelations inſtinctu, Ibidem. the inſtincte of the conceaued reuelation vndoubtely driuing her thervnto. Ruffinus ſayeth that, ſhe admoniſhed by reuelation frome God, went to Hieruſalē, Lib. 1. cap. 7 hiſto. and founde thre croſſes when ſhe came to the place, reuealed vnto he by ſome heauenly token or viſion. Macarius in his praier declareth
that in thes latter dayes, God inſpired the hearte of his hande mayden to ſeeke that bleſſed wood of the croſſe.

Nowe iudge good readers, whether the ladie Helena Conſtantines mother called a woemā of bleſſed memorye, pearleſſe for faith, deuotiō, and liberalitie, a womā bothe holy and faithfull, adorned plentifully with all kinde of vertues, and indued with the holy ghoſte, is to be eſtemed otherwiſe than vertuous? Iudge whether ſhe whoſe hearte God inſpired, whome the holie ghoſte admoniſhed and warned by viſions frome heauen to goe to Hieruſalem, and ſeeke the croſſe of Chriſte, is to be counted ſuperſtitiouſe, dryuen by woemaniſhe curioſitie, or fooliſhe zeale, as M. Calf. ſaieth? Iudge whether this yower newe miniſter hathe dealed either charitablie towardes the dead, that to blemiſhe her good name and impaire her credit, callethe her a concubine? or faithfullie to yow that are alyue, who calleth her ſuperſtitiouſe, whome the bleſſed and holy fathers S. Ambroſe, Paulinus, Ruffinus, Macarius, and Suidas teſtifie to haue bene inſpired with the holy ghoſte, and commaunded of God to ſeeke the croſſe as ſhe did? An honeſt mā hauing ſuch playne and euident teſtimonies out of ſo many, ſo auncient, and ſo holy fathets, for the honeſtie of that vertuous ladie, beſides the iudgement of the churche, that ſhe is a bleſſed Saincte in heauen, would neuer ſo impudently haue aſſured him ſelfe, that ſhe was ſuperſtitious, nor confidently haue auouched it to his readers with out ſufficient proufe. But yow may ſee what rotten ſtakes yow ſticke vnto.

He promiſed that the vanities of men ſhould be diſproued in this anſwer, by the vndoubted worde of God, true and godly fathers, ad laufull councells, but where is the worde of God? where are the godlie fathers? where is the lawfull councell that ſaye,M Calfs. impudē cie. Helena was ſuperſtitious? See yow not howe he deceaueth yow, and for ſcriptures, councells, and fathers, obtrudeth his owne impudent, vayne and arrogant aſſertions? See yow not that contrary to the euident teſtimonies of ſo many auncient and holy fathers, he iuſtifieth him ſelfe, to maintayne his
hereſie? Yf yow beleaue not me, ye that haue eies, ſee, and reade: ye that haue eares, harkē and learne. The places are quoted: the bookes eaſy to be had. And as yow finde his aſſertion true, in this caſe, ſo beleaue him in others. For my parte ſeinge his heart is ſo malitiouſe, his mouth ſo venemous, his penne ſo ſclaū derous, that he ſpareth not the bleſſed ſaynctes in heauen, I litle eſteme the boiſterous blaſtes of his ſpitefull breath, whatſoeuer wordes of reproche, either he hath, or ſhall breathe out againſt me, or any Catholique hereafter.

Furthermore where to deface Helena, he telleth yow out of S. Ambroſe, that ſhe was a woeman brought vp in as hoſtrie, Fol. 151. b Yf it might haue pleaſed him to haue dealed faithfully, he might alſo haue reported the woordes that followe in S. Ambroſe He ſayeth,De obitu Theodotij S. Ambroſes cōmē dation of Helena. She was a good hoſtrie woeman that ſoughte ſo diligently the maunger where our ſauiour was borne. A good hoſtrie woeman that knewe right well the maiſter of the hoſtrie, that cured his woundes, that was wounded of theaues. A good hoſtrie woemā that paſſed not to be reputed durte to wynne Chriſte, and therfore Chriſte aduaunced her from an hoſtrie to an Empire. But if all this ſhould haue ben reported with the reſt, it ſhoulde haue conuinced him a ſhamefull lyer, and proued Helena to haue ben vertuous, and not ſuperſtitious, and an honorable ladie, albeit ſhe lyued ſome tymes in a poore hoſtrie. As for his chardgyīg me with belying Euſebius, becauſe it was noted in the margent of my booke Euſebius libro 10. cap. 7. & 8. Eccleſiaſticae hiſtoriae, and Euſebius hathe not the ſtorye, but Ruffinus in his firſte booke and ſeuenth Chapiter, In deede I muſt confeſſe an ouerſighte in the printer for ſetting Euſebius for Ruffinus: But is this a ſhamefull lye with you M. Calf? and worthie ſo bitter a note in the margent? Yf yow will adiudge it ſo, let it be ſo: and be not angrie if yow be ſerued with the ſame meaſure agayne. I ſhall haue place to diſcourſe of yower lyes in tyme, and then lette the indifferent reader iudge betwene vs who is the moſt ſhamefull lyer.

Yower long wendleſſe aboute the varitie of the tyme in the hiſtorie,Fol. 153 a. b Fol. 152. a for the inuention of the croſſe maketh a man almoſt breathleſſe to reade it, and ſpend much labour to litle profit. For
what yf authours varie in the circumſtāce of tyme, and yet agre in the principall? Are they by and by to be diſcredited as reporters of vntruthes? or diſauthoriſed as full of repugnancie and contradiction as youer marginall note ſignifieth?Fol. 153. a Marc. 15. That were ynough to cōdemne the Ghoſpell of Chriſte. S. Marke ſayeth: The Iewes crucified Chriſte hora tertia, at the thirde houre. S. Iohn ſayeth:Cap. 19. It was the preparing daye of Eaſter, aboute the ſixte houre, and Pilate ſaid to the Iewes, beholde yower kinge: They cried away with him, awaye with him, Crucifie him. Pilate ſayd, vnto them, ſhall I crucifie yower kinge? The hye prieſtes anſwered, we haue no kinge, but Ceſar: Then he deliuered him to them to be crucified. And they tooke Ieſus and lead him awaye, and he bare his croſſe, etc. By which it apeareth that it was aboute the ſixte houre that Chriſte was condemned of Pylate, and deliuered to the Iewes to be crucified.Authours not to be diſcredited for a litle aparant diuerſitie in tyme. Cap. 17. And ſhall we nowe becauſe of this varietie in time, ſaye there is a repugnancie and cōtradictiō in the Goſpel? Shall we refuſe S. Marke and followe S. Iohn? or refuſe S. Iohn and followe S. Marke? or ſuſpecte them bothe, becauſe they agree not in the houre of Chriſts paſsiō? No M. Calf. To varie apparātly in time and agree vpō the thīg amō ge diuines, is no ſufficiēt cauſe to diſproue the truth. S. Mathewe writing of the trāsfiguratiō of Chriſte in the mounte ſayeth: and after ſixe dayes Ieſus toke Peter, Iames and Iohn his brother, and led them into a hie hill and was trāsfigured before them. S. Luke ſayeth: It chaunched allmoſte eighte dayes after, etc. Here in theſe wordes ſeemeth alſo an apparant varietie in tyme, but an accorde and agrement in the thing: and ſhall we for a litle apparant diuerſitie of tyme, which may be gathered by the bare wordes) diſauthoriſe the Ghoſpell? God forbid. It were Iewiſh follie. So albeit ſome ſaye that the croſſe was founde when Euſebius gouerned the churche of Rome, other ſome in Sylueſters popedome, yet do they all agree in the conſequent, that is was founde by Helena, by the inſpiration of the holy Ghoſte, and reuelation frome heauen. And this being agreed vpō by all wryters that diſcourſe of antiquities, and affaires of the church, what foliſhe curioſitie, or curious follye is it to beate aboute the buſhe, and hūt after houres, dayes, yeares, & for a litle diuerſitie of time cōdēne a true ſtorye.

But peraduenture M. Calf. vnderſtanding by ſome aduocate of his, that teſtes ſingulares non faciunt plenam probationē, Cap. cum dilectus ex de elect. Panor c. bonae memoriae, ex. de elect. and that they are, ſingulares that agree not in tyme, becauſe they that depoſe of diuerſe tymes, depoſe of diuerſe factes, and for a full proufe twoe muſt depoſe of one facte, thought he ſhoulde improue the truth of the hiſtorie, if he could ſhewe that the authours that wittneſſe it, did not agree in tyme. But yf he or his lawier had any ſuch fanſie, they were both deceaued. For in hiſtoriographers there is another conſideration, than in witnes.The caſe of an hiſtoriagrapher and vvitnes far diuerſe Bart. & dd. in l 1. ver. Celſus ait ff. ſi certū Petat. For the lawe geueth credit to an hiſtorie thought one onely wrote it, ſuch credit I meane as the authour commonly in all cuntries deſerueth, els no hiſtorie were laufull, except twoe men at one tyme wrote it, yea and nothing, but that they ſawe both togeather at ones. Yf another come and write, that it was not done, he that is of better credit is beleaued, but yf he write that it was done, as the firſte writer did, but differeth in tyme, it is to be beleaued the more, that it was done. For bothe agree in that: but nowe there is a greater doubte in deede of the tyme, then if the laſt had helde his peace.

Therfore we muſt beleaue him that is of greater authoritie, touching the tyme. Item him that bringeth beſt reaſon.VVhen authours varie in tyme vvi • h is beſt to be credited. Item him that lyued nearer the tyme when the thinge was done. Item where publique regeſters or other writers proue one tyme rather then another, with ſuch other circumſtances: which I would teache M. Calf. for his learning, yf he would be my ſcholler in lawe, as longe as he hath ben Caluines in hereſie. But yf no ſuch circumſtāces could be founde, yet muſt not we conclude, that the thinge was not done, but rather confeſſe the cō trarie: and ſtande ſtill in doubte of the time, neuer diſcrediting the authours for errīg in tyme, but rather excuſing them as the lawe doth, eſpecially in reporting thinges of antiquitie, the knowledge of the preciſe tyme wherof, can not be eaſely gotten: Quia labilis eſt hominum memoria circa tempus. Mans memorie fayleth oft in the • uſt tyme. Becauſe the memorie of man is ſlipper aboute the tyme.

In ſome caſes the lawe is content, contrary to common rules, in wittneſſes to haue teſtimonie de auditu alieno, of the heare
ſay, of other men: As yf he ſay, I knowe he boughte that houſe for an hundred yeares agoe, becauſe I heard my grandfather ſay ſo, this wittnes proueth. And if that be true, howe much more ſhall we beare with an hiſtoriographer in forgetting, or miſreporting the time, when there is no doubte of the thinge done? As for example, it is manifeſt that VViat with a greate company of the euangelicall brethren rebelled againſt their ſoueraigne lady and Quene: it is certayne that he came to Ludgate, and when he could not haue it opened, departed thence, and was apprehended and after a tyme beheaded, lyke a traytour. Nowe if one would write the hiſtorie of this rebelliō, and ſaye he came to Ludgate the 4. of Maye, ād another writing the ſame, ſay he came the xij. of Marche, ſhould this varietie of time proue a contradiction in the the thing, and argue that VViat ſtirred no rebellion at all? Or ſhould men an hūdred yeares hereafter ſaye that bothe thoſe writers were to be diſcredited? To ſchole ſir Iames to ſchole: yow had nede begynne yower A.B. C. againe, yf your ſecret ſtore, be not better furniſhed, than that which youer freaſh pedlers pack ſheweth at the toppe: But perhapes you will ſaye, the apparant contradiction in the Euangeliſtes is recōciled by S. Auguſtine, and others, but this it not. It is true. I graunte: but if I had yower ſpirite, and would ſaye: The doctours were but men, they had their errours, they varied frome the ſimplicitie of the Ghoſpell, and vrge the bare texte, and wordes of the Ghoſpell, and beleaue nothing that is alleadged, becauſe it is not in the written ſcripture, what had yower maiſterſhip to ſaye? Howe ſhould the places be reconciled? Let vs haue yower iudgement, and hereafter as occaſion ſerueth, I will ſend you myne, for the reconciliation of ſuch authours, as varie aboute the tyme of finding the Croſſe.

Fol. 152. bFurthermore your brable about that ſaying of Ruffinus: Titulus non ſatis euidenter dominici prodebat ſigna patibuli: The title did not ſhewe euidentlye the ſigne of our lordes gibbot, And this of S. Ambroſe: Titulo crux patuit ſalutaris, By the title, the healthfull croſſe was knowen, is to no purpoſe. VVhē you haue al ſaide a
ſimple Logitian will proue vnto you, that in thoſe twoe ſayinges there is no cōtradictiō. And where I ſaye in my treatiſe,Fol. 99. b that neither by the title that Pilate ſet vp in Hebrue, Greke, or Latine, neither by any other meanes they could diſcerne which was the croſſe that bare our ſauiour, I meane they could not diſcerne it by any ordinary meanes, ſatis euidenter, euidētly ynough, as Ruffinus ſayeth: And this comment for feare of yower groſſe cauillation I make, that in youer next replye you may not haue ſuch idle extrauagants and vayne digreſsions.

Yower lewde and ſhamefull lye that no ſhip or hulke of greateſt burden is able to cary the pieces of the holye croſſe, Fol 153. b A Shameful lye. yf they were gathered together, I remitte to the maiſter of the game to ſtand your frend for the whetſtone. The talke of the nayles wherwith all Chriſte was crucified,Caluin. I omitte as impertinēt. The diſprouing of Caluine I referre to learned in Fraūce, where his adulteries, his ſacriledges, his murder, leyed to his charge by Seruetus, his treaſons, his extorſions, and tyrannie, and lowſie euill are better knowen.Calf. VVhere you ſay of the miracle done at Nola by the croſſe, and reported by Paulinus, that miracles were not made to eſtabliſh a worſhipping or hauing of a croſſe, but to confirme a faith in the crucified, and teach vs not to do the like, but to beleaue the lyke, Mart. The one we graunte: the other we denye: we graunte that they were done to confirme a faith in the crucified, we deny that they were not done to eſtabliſhe a worſhippīg ād hauīg of the croſſe, and deſire you to proue it according to yower promiſſe, by ſcriptures, councells, and holy fathers.Fol 155. a Miracles that teache vs to beleue the like, teache vs ſometymes to do the like, yf vve may.

In that you ſaye, they teache vs not to doe the like, but to beleaue the like, I pray you tell me, Doth not he that teacheth one to beleaue that almes couerethe ſynnes, teache him alſo, to geue almes? Doth not he that teacheth one to beleaue, that by worthy receauing the Sacrament he receaueth life euerlaſting, teache him alſo to receaue the Sacrament? Dothe not he that teacheth one to beleaue that by baptiſme he ſhall haue remiſſion of ſynne, teache him alſo that he muſt be baptiſed? In like
manner, yf miracles done by the croſſe teache vs to beleaue the like, that is that the like may be done by the croſſe, through the mightie poure of Chriſte, do they not teache vs, when like occaſion ſerue to doe the like yf we may? And yf it pleaſeth God to haue his glorie ſhewed by like miracles vnto vs, as he did at that tyme to Paulinꝰ in Nola, by his croſſe, is it not reaſon that we ſhould cōceaue a ſtrong faith and aſſured hope in Chriſtes mercie, and venture to doe the like? And if we may venture to doe the like,Paulinus kept and reuerēced the croſſe. why may we not haue ſuch a piece of the croſſe as he had to doe the like? Let vs haue yower aduiſe: he was an holy man, and learned biſshop: he keapte it: he reuerenced it: he worſhipped it, and made a ſingular iewell and preciouſe treaſure of it. Yf you tel vs that there is more feare of idolatrie nowe, than there was then, youer owne wordes ſhall conuince you of vntruthe. For you ſaye we haue the Ghoſpell amongeſt vs more commonly than they had, and the truthe more ſincerely preached thā it was in thoſe dayes. And where that is, there is leſſe feare of idolatrie.

Fol. 155. aVVhere you ſaye that I haue heaped vp many tales, as that a woman, was preſerued frome rape and withcraſte by the croſſe etc. I would maruell why yow are not aſhamed to cal true hiſtories tales,True hiſtories counted tales. and iudge Epiphaniꝰ, Palladiꝰ, S. Auguſt. Sozome ne, Sulpitiꝰ, & Oſorius to be tellers of tales, rather thā reporters of true hiſtories, ſauīg that, I perceaue, you are paſt ſhame, ād moſt ſhamefully contēne the fathers, where they make againſt yow. But with the indifferent I truſt the foreſaide authours ſhall haue their worthy credit and you yower iuſt deſerte. As for your affirmation that thoſe miracles proue not my cauſe, becauſe (as yow ſaye) It is no good reaſon, Fol. 155. a to ſay, The ſigne of the croſſe hath done this or that miracle, ergo the ſigne of the croſſe muſt be ſet vp and honoured, we reiecte as friuolous, nakedly aſſeuered and nothing proued. VVhen accordinge to promiſe yow bringe ſcriptures, councells and holy fathers to diſproue it, then ſhall yow haue an other anſwer. In the meane time we tell you that it is a ſufficient teſtimonie to cōuince againſt all he
retikes, that it ſhould not be hackte, hewed and contemptuouſlye abuſed. And that yow may not rūne at ryot and hūte after owles in the midde daye,VVhat M. Calf hath to proue in his next booke. we tell yow that the thinge which yow muſt proue in your replie, is that miracles wrought of holy men, by the ſigne of the croſſe, at the commaundement of God, as ſome of thoſe were, to the comforte of his people, and glorie of his holiee name, is not a ſufficient reaſon to proue that the ſigne of the croſſe ſhoud be had, keapt, ſette vp, and honoured.

In the examining of it, yow ſhall diſcouer youre owne follie, and ſee that albeit miracles done by heretikes, Sorcerers, Nigromancers and deuills, are to be reiected with the doctrines, and poſitions, which they would confirme with fayned miracles, yet miracles wrought by good men, to confirme the doctrine and faith of the Chriſtians, are not to be contemned, nor the doctrine and faith refuſed, which God confirmed with thoſe miracles. That conſidered, yow ſhall furder ſee that it was ſome phrontike furie or diueliſh ſpirite that made yow ſay, that yow would not only haue to ſigne of the croſſe, Fol. 157. b A ſtrange fanſie meete for a nevve brother. but the ſigne of the diuell, yf miracles may commend a thing. VVas not the faith of Chriſt commended by miracles, and ſo commended that vnleſſe he had done thoſe miracles, the gentills woulde not haue beleaued? And will you becauſe miracles did commended the faith of Chriſt, haue not only the faith of Chriſte, but the faithe of the diuell? what a ſtraunge fanſye is this in yower Euangelicall minde?Ioan. 10 & 14. Chriſte willed the Iewes to beleaue his workes, yf they would not beleaue his wordes: and will yow not beleaue them becauſe miracles did commend them? I neuer heard of Chriſten man that in like caſe ſaid,Fol 157. b we may haue as wel the ſigne of the diuell, or any ſigne of idols, as the ſigne of the croſſe. And certes vnleſſe the diuel had poſſeſſed your heart, this blaſphemie would neuer haue ben vttred.

You tel vs howe in the raygne of Tarquine the proude, Fol. 157. b the image of madnes hāged before mēs dores deliuered the houſehold frō al dāgers: It is very like that madnes it ſelfe, hath taken
her flight from all thoſe doores, and lighted vpon ſuch a pale faced miniſter as yow are, and dryueth you to eſteme the ſigne of an idoll and diuel, as well as the ſigne of the croſſe: for remedie whereof the worſt that I wiſhe you, is ſome holy, and lerned exorciſt from Italie,An exorciſt for M. Calf. or Spayne, that is able with praier, and other meanes that the church vſeth, to expell that ſprite of madnes that poſſeſſeth your heart.

To the place of Epiphanius, that ſaied: A gentle woman bleſſed her ſelf in the name of Chriſt, becauſe ſhe was a Chriſtian, and was preſerued, you ſay, that the ſigne of the croſſe was no cauſe of her preſeruation, Fol. 155. b but wittneſſe of her faith that did preſerue her. But howe vaine it is that you ſay: Let the reader iudge of Epiphanius owne woordes.Lib 1 To. 2. hereſ. 30 He ſaieth: Per ſignaculum Chriſti & fidē mulier auxilium percepit, etc. By the ſigne of Chriſt and faith, the woman receaued help: neither did the force of the inchauntement auayle, where the name of Chriſt, and ſigne of the croſſe was. VVhat doe theſe woordes, the woman receaued helpe by the ſigne of Chriſt and faith ſignifie? Do they not ſignifie that by them, the woman was preſerued?A vvomā holpen by the croſſe. Conſtrue it M. Calf. and tell me what is percipere auxilium per ſignaculū Chriſti? to receaue help by the ſigne of Chriſt (which is the croſſe as apeareth by the wordes that followe) yf it be not to be preſerued by the ſigne of the croſſe? And yf ſhe receaued helpe by the croſſe, was not the croſſe one cauſe of her preſeruation, one I ſay, becauſe the paſsion and goodneſſe of Chriſt was the principall, and faith and the croſſe the meane by which ſhe was preſerued?

Yf the croſſe were no ſuch cauſe, why doth the authour ioyne: Signaculum Chriſti & fidem? The ſigne of Chriſt and faith together with a coniunction copulatiue? Is that in vayne? His ſkill is very ſimple that thinketh ſo. Nor doe I ſay, that the ſigne alone did preſerue, the woman (as M. Calfhil imagineth) but ioyne the croſſe and faith together, as Epiphanius doth, and ſay, by the ſigne of the croſſe of Chriſt, and faith, the woman receaued help. But let vs ſee howe M. Calf. proueth that the ſigne of the croſſe was but a witneſſe, of her faith that did preſerue her. Epiphanius (ſaieth
he) teſtifieth this, for he ſaieth: Signauit ſe in nomen Chriſti, Calf. vt quae Chriſtiana eſſet, ſhe ſigned her ſelf into the profeſsion and name, of Chriſt, as who was a Chriſtian woman. Mart. But is not this good readers a newe deuiſed trāſlation? to ſay,M. Calf. a fyne trā ſlatour. Signauit ſe in nomen Chriſti. She ſigned her ſelf in to the profeſsion and name of Chriſt, as who was a Chriſtian woman? The gentle woman was a Chriſten woman long before ſhe came into the bath, as our ſir Iames confeſſeth here: and did not there beginne to ſigne her ſelf into the profeſsion and name of Chriſt: but becauſe ſhe was a Chriſten woman (as Epiphanius ſaieth) before, and knewe that the Chriſtiās vſed the ſigne of the croſſe, againſt all tēptations, therfore ſhe ſigned her ſelf in the name of Chriſt, and not as M. Calf. fooliſhly trāſlateth it, into the profeſsiō and name of Chriſt. For that ſigning was paſt. She had profeſſed the faith and name of Chriſt in baptiſme, there ſhe was ſigned into the profeſsion, and name of Chriſte. Here ſhe did but ſigne her ſelfe in the name of Chriſte, and in that ſhewed her ſelfe a Chriſten woman, and made not a newe profeſsion.

VVhere yow ſaye,Calf. Fol. 155. b The end why God vſed this miracle was to ſhewe the vertue of beleefe in Chriſte, and to conuerte an heathen man, that could not ſee the ſecret faith, that ſo preuayled agaiſt inchauntment, and therfore ſtode in nede of an outwarde ſigne, Mart. I maruel much why yow labour buſelie to deceaue yower readers, and deſtroye one truthe by an other, and ſeparate, that which Epiphanius knitteth togeather with a copulatiue? He ſayeth, The force of inchauntement preuailed not, where the name of Chriſt and ſigne of the Croſſe was, This copulatiue (ād) declareth that faith in this caſe preuailed not without the ſigne of the croſſe, but that by the ſigne of the croſſe,The ſigne of the croſſe concurred vvith faith. and faith together the myracle was wrought. And albeit faith be able to reſiſte the force of incantation without the croſſe, yet it pleaſed not God ſo to diſpoſe it at that time, but made the ſigne of the croſſe concurre with faith, both to delyuer the gentlewoman from violence, and alſo to conuerte the gentill to the faith. For Epiphanius ſayeth in dede, hoc tertium inſtructionis ad fidem opus Ioſepho
contigit. This thirde worke of inſtruction happened to Ioſeph to bringe him to the faith: which fewe wordes howe falſely M. Calf. hath tranſlated, ſhall apeare when I come to treate of his falſe tranſlations.

In the meane tyme we deſire to learne of his wiſdome, why God wrought that miracle by the ſigne of the croſſe rather thā by any other externall meane? And whereas God notwithſtanding preaching vſed the ſigne of the croſſe to conuert an infidell, I would gladlye vnderſtande, why we that are Chriſtiās may not vſe, notwithſtanding preaching, the ſigne of the croſſe, to keape thoſe in memorye and meditation of Chriſtes paſſion,Ioſephus vſed the ſigne of the croſſe. Ibidem. who are conuerted alreadye? This Ioſephus of whome we talke being made afterward a perfect Chriſtē mā, vſed the ſygne of the Croſſe, and reuerēced it. For as Epiphanius reporteth, the Iewes by incantations went aboute to hinder his buildinges: ād ſo wroughte by their ſorcery, that his wood would not burne to make lyme, and brick. Of which when he was aduertiſed, he went to the place, and commaunded water to be brought thither,VVater bleſſed vvith the ſigne of the croſſe. and when it was brought: Magna voce crucis ſignaculum proprio ſuo digito vaſi impoſuit, etc. with a greate voyce he made the ſigne of the croſſe vpon the veſſell with his owne finger, and whē he had called vpō the name of Ieſus, he ſaied: In the name of Ieſus of Nazareth whome my fathers haue crucified, and all theirs, who ſtande here aboute, let there be vertue in this water to the deſtruction of all inchauntmentes and ſorcery, Vertue in vvater bleſſed vvith the ſigne of the croſſe againſt inchauntements. which theſe men haue made, and ſtrenght of power to make the fire burne, to perfit the houſe of God. And ſo he tooke the water, into his hande, and ſprinckled euery keele with parte of the water, and the inchauntments were diſſolued, and the fire made burne. VVhich done the very heathens acknowledged, that he was onely God, that helped the Chriſtians. Conſtantinus after he was conuerted, notwithſtanding he had much preaching, vſed the croſſe, and ſo haue all good Chriſtians that were conuerted to the faith, and ſo oughte we, vnleſſe we will degenerate from them.

Fol. 155. b Calf.VVhere you ſay, that the outwarde facte by which the inwarde puritie is notified needed not nowe to be the ſigne of
the croſſe, ſince we lyue not amonge Turkes and Sarazins, but all men without it, knowe of whome we holde, in whome we do beleaue, I woulde fayne learne howe a Portugalle,Mart. or one of the newe conuerted Ilandes of India coming by chaunce in to England, of which he neuer heard before,Hovve may one of the nevve Indians knovve that vve hold of Chriſt M. Calf? and ſeing nor aulters, nor images, nor roode in the church, nor croſſe in the ſtreate, nor high wayes, and none to bleſſe thē ſelues with the croſſe in the forheade, fayne would I learne (I ſaye) howe this man ſhould knowe of whome we holde, and in whome we beleaue? VVill you haue him harken to yower preachers? He can not vnderſtande them. VVill you haue him inquire of marchantes or ſome learned men? VVhat yf neither the marchant nor the learned man vnderſtande his language, neither he haue any ſighte in the lerned tongues? VVhat ſhall he do thē? But departe as ignorant as he came, and thincke that he hath bene rather in a coaſte of iurie thā in a lande that profeſſeth Chriſtianitie. And albeit we dwell not (bleſſed be God) amongeſte Turkes or Sarazins, but amongeſt Chriſtians, yeat becauſe ſtraungers of all countries haue acceſſe into our realme, and happely ſome may come out of Grece, Conſtantinople, Iurie and India to our coaſtes, we ſhoulde both to make vs thincke oftener of the paſsiō, and alſo to ſignifie our faith vnto the heathens, haue the ſigne of the croſſe in churches, chapells, and high wayes, and by the outwarde ſigne make them vnderſtand of whome we holde, and in whome we beleaue, ſeing by preaching we can not.

Thus your anſwer to Epiphanius is confuted, and by this you may learne, neuer to builde yower owne fanſie, vpō an holy fathers authoritie, and wreaſt it to a ſenſe which neither the plaine wordes of the texte, neither the circumſtance of the place can infer. I thincke a man ſhould haue much to doe with yow, yf yow could ſhewe any ſuch euident places out the fathers, that there were no myracles done by the croſſe, and that we ought in no caſe to haue the croſſe. In al the reſt that followeth I ſee nothīg worthe the anſwering, but certayne ſclaunders, ād lyes, of which I will ſpeake hereafter. Now to the Ninthe Article.

div.head: VVHAT COMMODITIE EVERY CHRISTEN MAN HATH, OR MAY HAVE BY THE SIGNE of the Croſſe. THE NINTHE ARTICLE.
div.p:
IN THE beginning of this Article this our croſſe quareller ſir Iames, fareth as a man ſick of a peſtilent feuer. For as he throughe the abundance of the cholerike humour, doth lothe the ſauour and taſte of holſome meates: So this man throughe the corruption of hereſie not only lotheth, but alſo refuſeth the authorities of the ſeuenth generall Councell, and condemneth their doinges,Auguſtin. epiſt. 118. quorū ſaluberrima eſt authoritas, whoſe authoritie is moſt holſome: and that he might ſeme to doe it, with authoritie, he taketh example of S. Ambroſe, who ſaide of the councell heald at Ariminum, Fol. 163. b Illud ego concilium exhorreo, that councell I do vtterly abhorre. But howe euill he imitateth S. Ambroſe,The coū cel of Ariminū a priuate and vvicked councel. iudge (good readers) The councell keapte at Ariminū was a priuate councell, vnlaufully aſſembled by heretikes, without the authoritie of the biſshop of Rome cōtrarie to the greate generall councell of Nice, and neuer confirmed. It made Chriſte the ſoone of God a creature, which the gentills and Iewes did eaſely acknowledge. Sainct Ambroſe a catholique biſshope, acknowledging obedience and ſubiection to the Popes holines, and a follower of the decrees of the Nicene councell, vnderſtā ding
that, ſaide like a ſtoute prelate: Illud ego cōcilium exhorreo, that councel I do vtterly abhorre.The 2. coūcel of Nice a general and Lauful councel. The councel keapt at Nice againſt image breakers, was a generall councell kept by Catholiques, laufully called and duly confirmed. It apeaſed the greate ſchiſme, that image breakers had rayſed againſt the churche many yeares. It decreed nothing againſt Chriſte and his holy ſcriptures, as the other did.

VVherfore if M. Calf. would haue imitated S. Ambroſe, he ſhould firſt haue proued that to haue ben a priuate Synode keapt of heretikes, vnlaufully aſſembled and neuer duly confirmed. He ſhould haue ſhewed that the fathers there decreed thinges cōtrary to ſcripture, and derogatorye to Chriſte. Otherwiſe there is no more likenes in the caſe, nor reaſon why he ſhould ſaye with ſainct Ambroſe: Illud ego concilium exhorreo, I vtterly abhorre that councell, thā there is cauſe why the thefe condemned at the Kinges bench for felony, ſhoulde ſaye to the 〈◊〉 , my lordes, as that worthy gentleman my maiſter, tal
••
〈◊〉 of the tumultes and ſedition in Northfolke, ſaide, I vtterly abhorre that tree of reformation: So do I vtterly abhorre this place of iudgement, and with all my harte refuſe this authoritie, and condemne the verdit of theſe twelue men, and ſentēce of this iudge. For as capitaines Keetes tree of reformation was a conuenticle of rebelles, ſo was the councel of Ariminum, a conſpiracie of heretikes. As that was againſt their laufull Prince: So was this againſt the true church. As that was againſt the commaundement of Chriſt: So was this to the diſhonour of God. VVherfore M. Calf. could not take example of S. Ambroſes facte in abhorring the councell of Ariminum, to refuſe and condemne the ſecond councell of Nice, vnleſſe with the Ariminians he wilbe an Arrian, and forſake the councel of Nice. Or with the thefe forſake the laufull Iuſtices, becauſe the good gentleman his maiſter abhorred the practiſe of rebelles.

But let vs heare what he ſayeth againſt them. VVhere Germanus a lerned father, and worthy biſshop of Conſtantinople ſaied, The images of holy men are a lyuely deſcription of their ſtouteneſſe, Actio. 4. Nice. 2. a repreſentation of their vertues, a diſpenſation of grace geuen them, etc.
It was (quoth M Calf.Fol. 1642 Calf.) a vayne allegation of Germanus: for I beſeeche you (ſayeth he) what ſtoutenes and vertue is deſcribed, what holynes and grace is diſpenſed by them? when the ſainctes were alyue, their vertues could not be diſcerned, with eie, they reſted in their minde, their propre ſubiecte. And ſhall they nowe beſeene in their dead images, which haue neither minde neither ſenſe, to hold thē? This is as iuſt as Germaines lipps: Mart. It was not for naught that Tertulian did forbid diſputation with heretikes, bringe what you can, either they will falſely wreſt it, or ſhamefully deny it. For proufe wherof we neede not ſeeke far: In this very thinge we haue experience of bothe in our ſir Iames. He denieth not only the ſaying of a learned biſshope, but alſo the auctoritie of a generall councell.Fol. 163. b Fol. 164. a The decrees of the one he calleth impudēt vanities, and the ſaying of the other a vayne allegation. VVhich howe ſitting it is for ſo younge a diuine, and ſimple miniſter, yow that are men of wiſdome iudge.

His wreaſting Germanus wordes is ſo ſhameleſſe, that vnleſſe with hereſie he had put on impudēcy, his pale face would bluſh to heare it. That you may better vnderſtand his forgery, conſider that holy biſshopes wordes, he ſaide: The images of holy men are a lyuely deſcription of their ſtouteneſſe, Germanus vvoordes vvreſted. and a repreſentation of holy vertue, and deſpēſation of grace, geuē vnto them. Nowe cometh our ſir Iames, and aſketh what holynes and grace is diſpenſed by thē? As though the authour meaned that images of ſainctes were a diſpenſation of holynes, and grace, which is abſurd and contrary to his minde. For he meaneth as the very wordes do importe, that images of ſainctes do deſcribe vnto vs the ſtoutenes of holy men,VVhat images repreſent vnto vs. and repreſent the holy vertue and grace that God diſpenſed vnto them. As for example, the image of S. Peter martired vpon the croſſe, the image of S. Paule beheaded with the ſworde, the image of S. Stephen ſtoned, Bartholomewe fleied. S. Laurence broyled and diuerſe ſuch, do repreſent vnto vs, that holde of Chriſte, their ſtoutenes in contemning deathe, their patience in ſuffringe tormentes, and grace that they had to perſeuere
conſtāt in the faith and loue of Chriſte vntill the end. Here is no mention that grace is diſpenſed by images:M. Calf. falſely trā ſlateth Germanꝰ vvoordes. nor Germanus ſayth (as M. Calf. falſely trāſlateth) that an image is a diſpēſation of holynes, but ſanctae virtutis et diſpēſationis figuratio, a figuryng or rep̄ſentatiō of holy vertue, and diſpēſatiō (that is) of grace geuē vnto the ſaincts. The worde diſpenſatiō which Germanꝰ vſed in the genitiue caſe, Calf. turneth into the nominatiue caſe, which is forſoothe no falſitie nor vnhoneſt dealing amōgeſt heretikes. And wheras the authour ſaid: An image is a repreſentation of diſpenſation. This falſe quarreler ſayeth: an image is a diſpenſation of holynes. And as though he had dealed honeſtly, aſketh this pieuiſh queſtiō, what holynes is diſpenſed by them? and ſheweth hym ſelf as wiſe as VValtams caulfe.

His reaſon that followeth, ſauoreth of the ſame paſture. For he ſaieth: the vertues of Saīctes could not be diſcerned with eye, Calf. They reſted in the minde their propre ſubiect, ergo they could not be ſeene in their dead images, which haue no ſenſe to hold them: Here the antecedent is ſtarke falſe?Mart. For albeit the minde is the propre ſubiect of vertue, yet doth it not ſo cloſely kepe it ſelf there, but that ſome tymes it ſheweth forth her fruictes. Faithe the chiefeſt vertue in a Chriſten man is ſhewed by good woorkes. The Apoſtle S. Iames ſaid,Faith ſhevved by Good vvoorkes Cap. 2. oſtendam tibi ex operibus fidem meam, I will ſhewe the my faith by good workes. S. Peter commaundeth vs to labour to make our vocation knowen by our good workes. And this would neither S. Iames haue ſaid, nor S. Peter haue commaunded,2. Petr. 1. yf our faith and vertue might not be knowen by the outwarde workes. But ſeing it is ſo, that faith and all other vertues may be ſhewed forthe by good workes, although they reſt in the minde as their propre ſubiecte, it ſtandeth with reaſon that they may be ſet ſoorth to the eie, by images. As the obedience of Abraham, and redines to offer his ſonne Iſaac at Gods commandement, may be and is ſet foorth by pictures: likewiſe the conſtancie of the Apoſtles, and patience of Martirs, and charitie of all, may in like ſorte be ſett foorth.

Yf M. Calf. denie this, let vs aſke him howe it cometh to
paſſe, that albeit the faith and other vertues reſt in the mynde as their propre ſubiect, yet they may be ſet foorth by ynck and paper, as the faith and holynes of the Apoſtles, is ſet foorth in the actes,Yf the vertue of ſainctes may be ſet foorth in ynck and paper, vvhy not in pictures? anſvver M. Calf. Ser. de 40. Mart. Noble faicts ſet foorth by pictures. and auncient hiſtories? Yf he finde, that by yncke and paper they may be ſet foorth to the carnall eie, to be reade, and by reading conueyed in to the mynde, Let him geue a good reaſon out of ſcripture, councel, and auncient father, why a picture cā not ſet a thinge foorth to our eies, and by outwarde ſight conueye it vnto the minde. S. Baſile commending the fourthy Martirs, tolde his people, that he would endeuour to ſett forth their noble actes to them all, quemadmodum in pictura, as it were in a picture. For both writers of hiſtories and alſo payncters do ſet forth very lyuely noble feates of armes: the one by eloquence, the other by garniſhing and ſetting it foorthe by tables: both ſtirring many to imitate the like valiantnes, and cowrage. For whatſoeuer the vtteraunce of the hiſtorye proueth by induction, the ſame dothe a ſtill picture ſett forthe by imitation.

But what yf in waye of reaſoning, we graunted M. Calf. his antecedent, that the vertues of Saynctes could not be diſcerned with eie, for that they reſted in the minde, their propre ſubiecte? Howe dothe this conſequēt followe, Ergo they could not be ſene in their dead images, which haue neither minde, nor ſenſe, to holde them? As iuſt as Germaynes lipps. May not all London laugh at it, and thincke they haue a pieuiſh miniſter for a learned reader?A propre reaſon for a nevve miniſter. Conſider his reaſon I beſeche yow. In effect he ſaieth thus. Deade images of Saynctes haue no minde, nor ſenſe, to holde their vertues, ergo their vertues can not be ſene of mē that haue witts, and ſenſe to beholde them. Is not this true dealing, and a token of profounde learning? Might not one by a like argument proue that we can not ſee the power of Chriſte, and vertue of the Apoſtles,M Calfs reaſon cō demneth the ſcripture as vvel as images. in ſcripture? how ſay yow to this argument? The yncke and paper wherin the ſcripture is written haue no minde nor ſenſe, to holde the poure of Chriſte, and vertue of the Apoſtles, Ergo the power of Chriſte, and of the Apoſtles cā not be ſene in the ſcripture? Yf M. Calfhils be good this is good. For they are bothe like. And yf yow will ſay with him that the vertues of Sayntes cā not be ſene in images, becauſe
images haue no mynde nor ſenſe to hold them, yow muſt ſaye in like ſort that we can not ſee the power of Chriſte and vertue of the Apoſtles in ſcripture, becauſe the paper and yncke, haue no minde nor ſenſe, to hold thē. And by like reaſon as he cō demneth images, condemne the ſcripture.

But be not deceaued. As by reading the ſcripture written in yncke and paper, the hearte conceaueth the power of Chriſte, and vertue of his Apoſtles: So by ſeing images of Saynctes made of inſenſible thinges, the minde conceaueth the vertue of Saynctes. And as the eare by hearing, geueth vnderſtandinge to the ſoule: So the eie by ſeing doth geue light to the mī de. VVherby it cometh to paſſe that althoughe images haue nor minde, nor ſenſe to hold the vertues of Saynctes, yeat we that haue mindes, witte, reaſon, and ſenſe, may beholde the vertues of Saynctes in images, and glorifie God for them. But to procede.

VVhē I ſee an image gorgeouſlye decked, with ſpeare, ſworde, Fol. 164. a or booke in the hād, an other with a boxe or babe ī her armes, Fol. 164. a what reaſon can tell me whether Mars or S. Georg, Venus, or the virgī mother of Chriſt be erected, quoth M. Calf?Mart. Forſoth yf yow be a Chriſten man, and lyue amongeſt Chriſtians, and haue any reaſon in your head, it may tell yow that euer ſithens Chriſte conquered the diuell, the Chriſtians haue forſaken all idolls, of Mars, Venus, Apollo, and ſuch like:Idols deſtroyed by the Chriſtiās. and vtterly deſtroyed them, as the prophetes did foretell, and ſuffred none to remayne amongeſt them. It might furder tell you that the Chriſtians neither haue nor can abide to haue any other image to be honored in the churche than the image of Chriſt and his ſainctes. VVhiche being true, and none ſo ſimple amongeſt the Chriſtians, but is wel aſſured of that, litle reaſon might ſerue to make you to thinke that, whē you ſee an image with a ſword, or child in the armes, it is nor Mars nor Venus, nor Mercurie, nor Momus, vnleſſe by hereſie you haue bē made ſo very a Mome, that you knowe not amongeſt whom you dwell nor of whome you hold.Fol. 146. b

It is a great argument of yours that images teache pride,
auarice, Fol. 165. b wantonneſſe and nothing els. And for proufe of it you bring the example of Cherea in Terence, and Venus Gnidia in Lucian, two worthy Doctours to confirme ſuch a truth. Scriptures, councells and fathers fayled, when theſe were thought worthie to be alleaged. But I pray you ſir what yf ſome wanton maydens lerne of the image of Mary Magdalene, the luſtes of vanitie, Fol. 164. b what yf the couetous mā ſeing an image faire gilded, wiſh it in his purſe? what yf the careleſſe and deſperat man thinke with himſelf, Fol. 174▪ b what ſhame is it for me to hang, ſeing our God was ſo ſerued? Ibidem. VVhat cō conſequution is this M. Calf. Some may haue euil thoughtes by ſight of images, Ergo images muſt not be ſuffred. Gene. 19. Gene. 30. Oſee 1. Mat 25. Luc. 19. Matt. 18. VVhat yf all this were true, what will you inferre vpon it? Shall images thefore be condēned and thought vnlawfull? Then by your wiſdome we ſhall ſhortly condemne the ſcripture: VVanton maydens hearing the chapiter reade where it is declared howe Loths two daughters made their father drunke, and went to bed vnto him, may lerne ſome lewde luſtes of vanitie, euill women hearing howe Rachel gaue Iacob her huſband leue to begette children of his mayden Balam, may haue wicked imaginations: Men hearing howe the Patriarkes had diuerſe wiues, may thinke that laufull for them. Some hearing thoſe wordes that God ſpoke to his Prophete Oſee: Goe thy way, take a harlot to thy wife, and beget children of fornicatiō, may thinke wickedly of cōmitting fornication. Some hearing that Chriſt ſaied to the ſeruant: Thou ſhouldeſt haue put my mony to the banke that I returning might haue receaued it with vſurie, will imagine that it is laufull to geue mony to vſurye. Some hearing that he ſaied: Yf I thy eie offend thee, pick hym out, yf thy hand or fote be offence vnto the, cutte them of, and caſt them from the, may take occaſion, as ſome haue done, to māgle them ſelues and cutte of their membres. And ſo all wicked men may take occaſiō of ſome other places of ſcripture to be naught and like the ſpider turne all into poyſon, as our ſir Iames doth. Shall the ſcripture therfore be contemned, and thought vnlaufull? Shall all men be forbid to reade it, becauſe ſome take occaſion of hurt by it? No: there is no reaſon, why the lewdnes of a fewe ſhoulde preiudice a multitude, and the iniquitie of ſome
lewdly diſpoſed, imbarre the cōmoditie of many well affectioned. As therfore the ſcripture is not to be reiected becauſe wicked men by certayne hiſtories, and textes miſunderſtode may take occaſion of euill: So are not images to be condemned becauſe wanton maydes and couetous perſons conceaue light affections at the ſight of them. Many haue holy meditatiōs and great commodities by them, and more good men and women by ſight of Mary Magdalene payncted mornefully,Mary Magdalene not vvant only paīcted. and not wantonly (as you ſay) take occaſion to repent for their ſynnes, and lament their wantonneſſe paſt, than to fall into the luſtes of vanitie. More by ſeeing the gilded images, thinke of the ioies of heauen, and bliſſe that they haue there, than of hauing it in their purſe. More ſeeing Chriſte hanging on the Croſſe, thanke him, for his paſsing loue towardes vs, than thinke hanging no ſhame, becauſe their lorde and maſter was hanged: and they for the lewdnes of a fewe that are naught, are not to be bereued of a commoditie that doth turne them to good.

The examples of Ezechias, Ioſias, and Salomon, Fol. 164. b Fol. 165. a The fact of Ezechias deſtroying the ſerpēt maketh not agaīſt our images. 4. Reg. 18. are brought to no purpoſe againſt images amōgeſt Chriſtians. The cauſe why Ezechias deſtroyed the braſen Serpent, is declared in the text: Siquidem, vſque ad illud tempus filij Iſrael adolebant ei incenſum. For vntill that day the childrē of Iſrael did offer inceſe to it. And in deede, the people of Iſraell being very prone to idolatrie, did oftentymes offende the goodneſſe of God with their wickedneſſe and abhomination, which the vertuous prince Ezechias vnderſtanding did deſtroye the braſen Serpent. Amongeſt vs that are Chriſtians, there is no ſuch miſtruſt of idolatrie. No man knoweth the ſecrets of an others heart, nor is able to ſay, this man or that man cōmitteth idolatrie, or burneth incenſe to idols, as the Iſraelites did. VVherfore the fact of Ezechias is vnfytly alleaged, againſt images. The lawe ſaieth: Ceſſante ratione legis ceſſat & ipſa lex. The reaſon of the lawe ceaſsing, the lawe it ſelf ceaſſeth. Seing them there is no idolatrie, committed, as there was in his tyme, ſeing the people direct their heartes, and offer their praiers to God, and whēſoeuer they ſet their eies on the image, they haue their mnydes in heauē with God, the deſtroying that
Ezechias vſed, ſhould alſo ceaſſe, and no image nowe be throwē downe, vnleſſe there were like apparant cauſe of idolatrie, as there was in Ezechias and Ioſias raigne. For whoſe fact alſo this anſwer for auoyding tediouſnes ſhall ſuffiſe.

Fol. 165. 3. Reg. 11. Salomon not abuſed by images but by vvomen.As for Salomon, he was not, (as M. Calf. ſaieth, contrarie to the woord of God) abuſed by images. The text ſaieth, Auerterūt mulieres cor eius, deprauatum eſt cor eius per mulieres, vt ſequeretur deos alienos, women turned away his heart: by womē his heart was corrupted, that he followed ſtrange Gods, as yow for hauing and pleaſing of your woemen, are brought to hereſie. To theſe woemen he was inueigled, Ardentiſsimo amore, with moſt hote and feruent loue. That he was abuſed by images, or by ſuffring his wā ton paramours, to bring their idols into his court, the ſcripture maketh no mention. The liuely images of his paramours the wanton continaunces of his concubines and niceneſſe of his ladies, were the Idolls that corrupted him, and not the images whiche he knewe, to be but ſtockes and ſtones. And albeit he was permitted to like his owne luſtes, and followe ſtrange Gods, which were but ſtockes and ſtones, yet wil it not followe that he was peruerted, and abuſed by thoſe ſtones. The ſcripture muſt be true, deprauatū eſt cor eiꝰ ꝑ mulieres, his heart was depraued by women to followe ſtrange Gods, and not by any affectiō to falſe images, to followe idolls. Yf you thinck this true, then tel, your miniſter that he hath made a foule and ſhamefully lye. Yf you thinke him an honeſt man, not withſtanding this ſhamefull lying, and cōtrarying the ſcriptures, all wiſe men may thinke,2. Tim. 4. that the tyme is come of which, S. Paule ſpoke to Timothe: There ſhalbe a tyme, when they ſhall not abide holſome doctrine, but hauing ytching eares, ſhall heape vnto them ſelues maſters after their owne deſire, and turne away theire hearing from truth, and turne to fables.

Fol. 168. a Calf.VVhere he alleageth this place out of S. Chriſoſtome, Animo deſperato, nihil peius, etc. nothing is woorſe than a deſperate mynde. Although he ſee ſignes, Although miracles be wrought, yet he ſtandeth ſtill in the ſame ſelf will frowardnes, Mart. to proue that obſtinate ſynners haue ſmale or no conforte by
the croſſe, ye ſhall vnderſtād good readers, that S. Chryſoſtome ſpeaketh, there of the Iewes that crucified Chriſt,Hom. 54. in 8. Ioan. and of ſuch hard harted and obdurated men, as Pharao was. Amongeſt them Chriſt wrought a great number of miracles. In his paſsion he leyed them flatte vpon the grounde, and tooke away their ſight, and yet they (that is to ſay the Iewes) did not beleaue. Nowe becauſe the Iewes were obſtinate in their wickedneſſe, ād would not beleaue, although they ſawe ſignes and miracles, is there any honeſtie in this maiſter miniſter to referre that to the Chriſtians that was ſpoken of the wicked Iewes? and to ſay they who haue receaued the faith of Chriſt, being nowe eſtraunged by abundance of impietie and ſynne, can not by ſignes and miracles, and ſight of the croſſe be turned to Chriſt againe, becauſe the Iewes, that crucified Chriſt, and Pharao that of malice and hardnes of heart,Lerne M. Calf. to make a difference vvhen an authour ſpeaketh of a ievve and vvhē he ſpeaketh of a Chriſtiā. oppoſed him ſelf againſt God, could not be conuerted by miracles and ſignes? The caſe is farre different betwene a Iewe and a Chriſtian, a Pharao and a faithfull. The one knoweth that by Chriſt he may haue ſaluation, the other ſuppoſed it a vayne illuſion. The Chriſtian vnderſtandeth that Chriſt, will receaue him to mercy yf he turne vnto him. The Iewe can not conceaue that there is any ſuch Chriſt to haue mercie vpon him. Therefore no maruell yf ſmale comforte ariſe to the like that S. Cryſoſt. ſpoke of, that is the Iewes and Pharaonites, when the croſſe, is brought vnto thē. For they neuer beleued in Chriſt crucified. But being brought to a Chriſtiā (of whō we talke and not of Iewes, and Pharaonites M. Calf.Comfort to Chriſtians by ſight of the croſſe.) there may riſe great cōfort vnto him. For by the ſight of it, he may come into remembrance of the paſsion of Chriſt, and conſider, that as he died for ſynners, ſo he wil ſaue ſynners, yf they turne vnto him, and repent, and fal into ſuch holy meditations as I declared in my treatiſe.

Neither doth this authoritie, and example brought out of S. Chryſoſtome condemne me, as M. Calfhil ſuppoſeth,Fol 116. a but ſheweth him, to be groſſe, and ignorant, that can not ſee, when an authour ſpeaketh of a Iewe, and a Chriſtian, of an infidel,Fol. 168 a and faithfull: and declare that his lying ſprite paſſeth not what he writeth, ſo he may colour his craft for a tyme. Or yf this be not
euidence ynough, marcke what a ſhamefull lye followeth ſtrayte vpon the backe of this?A ſhameful lie. Fol. 168. a Calf. (Athanaſius ſayeth he:) In the place by you alleaged howe the wounted affections be taken out of harlotts heartes, murderers kepe their weapon no longer, fearefull men conceaue courage, barbarous men lay away all immanitie, doth not aſcribe the effects to the croſſe, but wholly and ſolely to the faith of Chriſt? Mart. Nowe whether this be a moſte impudent and ſhamefull lye, iudge your ſelues. Athanaſius wordes be theſe: VVho hath ſo taken out of mens heartes their wounte affections, that harlotts would lyue chaſte, murderers kepe their weapons no longer? Fearefull men conceaue courage? who hath perſuaded barbarous people, and other nations, to ley away all immanitie in their owne cuntrie, The vertue of the croſſe. and muſe only vpon quietnes and peace? niſi Chriſti fides & ſignaculum crucis? But the faith of Chriſt and ſigne of the croſſe? And is it not plaine that he ſaieth here, The faith of Chriſt and ſigne of the croſſe tooke the wounted affections out of mens heartes? The faith of Chriſt and ſigne of the croſſe made harlotts lyue chaſt? the faith of Chriſt, ād ſigne of the croſſe made murderers, caſt away their weapon, and the fearefull conceaue courage, and the barbarous ley away their immanitie? And in ſaying that the faith of Chriſt and ſigne of the croſſe made all this, doth he not aſcribe all theſe effectes to the faith of Chriſt and ſigne of the croſſe? And yf it be ſo, then doth he not aſcribe thoſe effectes, VVholly and ſolely to the faith of Chriſt, but to the faith of Chriſt and ſigne of the croſſe together, not that faith is vnable, to do it, without the croſſe, but becauſe we might vnderſtand that God would haue the ſigne of the croſſe, concurre with faith, and worke the ſaied effectes by faith and the ſigne of the croſſe, to confounde the gentills that imagined Chriſt, to be but a dead man, and wrought vs no benefit by his croſſe.

M. Calf. his fanſie, ſaying that Athanaſiꝰ ioyned the ſigne of the croſſe to faith, that the one might be teſtified by the other, hath no ſure grownde to ſtay vpon. He hath according to his promiſe, alleaged nor ſcripture, nor councell, nor father to proue his geſſe. It is manifeſt to all that wil reade the whole diſcourſe,
which Athanaſius maketh there, that he talketh muche of the vertue and power of the ſigne of the croſſe,Athanaſiꝰ ſpeaketh much of the vertue of the ſigne of the croſſe. as that it driueth away diuels and deſtroyeth inchauntments and ſorcery, as I haue ſpecified before, and for declaration that it hath further power and ſtrenght to the benefite of Chriſtians, he aſcribeth the aforeſaid effectes to faith and the ſigne of the croſſe together: for ſo ſignifie his woordes: Fides Chriſti & ſignaculum crucis. The faith of Chriſt and ſigne of the croſſe. And albeit it be graunted to be true that M. Calfhil ſaieth, that the manner of that tyme, was for the chriſtians by this kinde of ſigne to ſhewe their profeſsion, being conuerſant amongeſt, infidels, yet doth it not proue that the aforeſaied effectes be aſcribed wholly and ſolely to faith. For by that ſigne, they might both teſtifie, their faith, and with faith in the merites of Chriſtes paſsion, and that ſigne of the croſſe, haue the effectes afore ſaied wrought, as Athanaſius plainly declared, when he ſaied, who taught all theſe thinges, niſi Chriſti fides & ſignaculum crucis? But the faith of Chriſt and ſigne of the croſſe? VVhich being true, I can not ſee with what face M. Calf. could, ſay that Athanaſius in that place aſcribed thoſe effectes wholly and ſolely to the faith of Chriſt makīg faith and the croſſe varie as it were, and not able to concurre on with the other, vnleſſe he had determined to out face the truth wholly and ſolely with lies.

As he hath faced this: So hath he made an other,The Pariſiens approue not Eraſmus Cenſure &c. Fol. 172. b that the Pariſiens, that is the facultie of diuines commonly, called the doctours of Sorbon in Paris, approued the iudgment and cēſure of Eraſmus, denying the booke, de viſitatione infirmorum to be S. Auguſtines woorke. For there is no woord, nor ſillable there that maketh mention that the ſaied cenſure ſet before the worke was approued by the Pariſiens, except M. Calfhils wiſdome will ſay, it was printed at Paris, ergo it was allowed by the Pariſiens.

Nor content with this, to ſhewe more feates of his arte, he fayneth of S. Cyrill that he hauing to do with Iulian the Apoſtata
(who entwited the Chriſtians for hauing, and ſetting vp of croſſes before their doores) did excuſe the order of the Chriſtians in his tyme, and couer their fault, Fol. 172. b Fol. 173. a which is an impudēt lie For Cyrillus acknowlegeth no fault in the order of the Chriſtians of his tyme,Cyrillus acknovvlegeth no fault in the Chriſtians for making of croſſes, and therefore excuſeth it not Libr. 6. cōt. Iulia. for making and ſetting vp of croſſes, and therefore neither excuſed them, nor couered any faulte of theirs. He was ſo farre from all ſuche imaginations, and thinking it a fault to haue, or make the ſigne of the croſſe vpon, either their doores, or for heades, that whereas Iulian ſaied that they were wretches that made croſſes, he ſaied: Abſque labore demonſtrabimus eiuſmodi ſermones à malis cogitationibus profectos, extremam ſapere imperitiam, we will proue without any greate trauayle, that theſe wordes coming of wicked thoughtes, ſauour of extreme ignoraunce. And ſo reckoning the benefites of Chriſtes paſsion he ſayeth: Haec omnia recordari nos facit ſalutare lignum. The healthfull woodde doth make vs remembre all theſe thinges. Furder he ſayeth: VVe make the croſſe of the precious wodde in remembraunce of all goodnes and vertue.

Nowe yf Cyrillus a lerned biſshop iudged the talke of Iulian the Apoſtata agreing with our heretiks, for vpbraydīg the catholikes with hauing and makīg the ſigne of the croſſe, to ꝓcede of wicked thoughtes, & ſauour of extreme ignorāce, it is not to be p̄ſuppoſed that he thought it a fault in the Chriſtiās to haue thē neither iudged it a wicked thought in an other to reꝓue the hauing of thē. But would rather haue takē it as an aduertiſmēt, to warne the chriſtiās to forſake it, leſt they ſhould be an offēce ād ſclaūder to the Ghoſpel. But in al his workes there is no ſentēce to declare that he exhorted the Chriſtians to leaue the making and ſetting vp of croſſes before their doores. But the contrary apeareth very euidently in this place. For he ſayeth with greate indignatiō to that wicked Apoſtata. Lib. 6. cōt. Iulia. The croſſe bringeth vs in remēbrāce of al goodnes. VVilt thou, that we caſt away the wood that bringeth vs in remembrance of all goodnes, and ſet forth thy toyes to women and children? No, we will not. Herepon I make this reaſon. VVhere there is no faulte, there neadeth no excuſe: There was no faulte (in Cirillus iudgement) to make the ſigne of the croſſe. Therfore it neded not to be excuſed, as a faulte.
Yf any wrangling heretike denie the ſeconde propoſition, lett him conſider Cyrillus wordes alleaged before: and if he hath cō mon ſenſe, he can not chooſe but proue it ſufficientlye out of that place: To auoyde teſdiouſnes I leaue it to the indifferent readers deduction,Notes of M. Calfs. cōſidered. and by the way conſider certayne notes that M. Calf. hath gathered out of an other place, of Cyrill in the ſame booke againſt Iulian. As for example.

VVhere Cyrillus ſaide that Numa king of the Romaynes builded certayne temples in the which nullum erat ſimulachrum, there was no falſe or forged image, The firſt Note. Fol. 173. becauſe he learned of Pithagoras that God lacketh forme and ſhape, he maketh this note in the margēt, Cyrillus alloweth no images in churches, and maketh this argument. There can be no likenes of God made, therfore not of Chriſte vnleſſe we denye him to be God? Corcerning the firſt, conſider howe wiſely it is inferred vpon that holy fathers wordes. Cyril telleth vs that Numa a good kinge (as Iulian ſaide) had no forged and fayned images, in his temples, ergo Cirill alloweth no true images of Saynctes in churches. Is not this beggerly logicke,A like argumēt to M. Calfs. and pelting diuinitie? Conſider it by a like. The prophetes and Apoſtles tell vs, that the gētills had no true māner of worſhipping the true God in their tēples, Ergo the prophets allowed not the true worſhipping of God in Chriſtiā churches. That Cyrill did not diſalowe images in the church, it apeareth firſt by his earneſt replie againſt Iulian that vpbrayded the Chriſtiās with hauing the ſigne of the croſſe, and thoughte it an extreame ignorance, to thincke it vnlawfull to haue the croſſe. Next by his not reprouing neither the fathers that were before his tyme, neither thoſe that lyued in his tyme, for ſuffering images in churches.

S. Baſile before his tyme allowed images in the churche, as apeareth in his ſermon vpō Barlaam the martir. There he crieth to the painters in this ſorte. Goe to nowe, S. Baſile allovveth images in churches. o ye notable paincters of noble faictes, ſett forth with yower arte the mutilate image of this capitaine, making him noble with the coloures of yower induſtrie, whome I haue ſomewhat obſcurely deſcribed and crowned. I will departe as ouercommed with the image which yow make of the cōflictes and victories of the martir.
I will reioyce that by yower dexteritie and fyneneſſe I am conquered with ſuch victorie. And in the ſame booke, in the end he ſayeth: Pingatur in tabula vna, et certaminū agonotheta Chriſtus: Let Chriſte the healper of thoſe conflictes and victories be paincted alſo in a table with him, to whome be glorie worlde without end, Amen. Thus much S. Baſile, and would he haue required them to paincte the image of the martir, and our ſauiour Chriſte, yf it had bene vnlaufull to haue the images of martirs and Chriſte in the churche? VVoulde he haue deſired it in his ſermone before the face of all the people, in the open audiēce, and ſhewe him ſelfe to reioyce in it, yf it had bene againſt Gods commaundement? No: His knowledge in the ſcriptures was greater, and zeale to the honour of God more feruenter, than that either he could be ignorant in ſuch a matter, or woulde be willfull to committe ſuch an offence.

Athanaſiꝰ allovveth images in churches.Likewiſe Athanaſius allowed images before Cyrillus tyme, as apeareth in the ſtorye, which he declareth of the image of Chriſte crucified at Berithus. There he ſayeth: The faithfull Chriſtiās and diſciples of Chriſte were warned of the holy Ghoſte to departe frome Hieruſalem, and to goe to the kingedome of Agrippa, twoe yeares before Titus and Veſpaſianus deſtroyed the citie: Qui egreſsi ab vrbe, omnia quae ad cultum noſtrae religionis vel fidei pertinere videbantur ſecum auferentes, in has regiones tranſtulerunt. Quo tempore etiam icona cum caeteris rebus eccleſiasticis deportata vſ
que bodie in Syria permanſit. VVho departing from the citie, taking away with them all thinges that ſemed to apertayne vnto our religion or faith, tranſported them into theſe cūtries. At what tyme alſo this image being caried awaye with other thinges of the churche, hath contynued vnto this preſent daye, in Syria. Here it is to be ſene euidētlye that in thoſe daies, euen at the beginninge, images were adnumbred amōgeſt thoſe thinges that appartayned ad cultum noſtrae religionis, to the furniſhing and ſettinge forthe of our religion, & cum caeteris rebus eccleſiaſticis, with other thinges of the churche.Oratio. in laudes Theodor Mart. Gregorius Niſſenus, In mira. S. Stepha. Euodius, In Felice Paulinus. De conſenſu. Euā gel. lib. 1 cap 10. Libr 22. cōt Fauſt. Manich. cap 73. S. Auguſtine,In Caſſian. Prudentius, or in Cyrill ••
tyme, or very litle before his tyme, ſpeake in like manner of images amongeſt Chriſten men. And yf Cyrill had diſalowed images in churches, either he woulde haue reproued the fathers
that before his dayes, or thoſe that lyued in his dayes, and had images in their churches, but no ſuch thinge apeareth in all his woorkes. VVherfore M. Calf. can not iuſtely ſaye that Cyrill alloweth no images in the church.

The other argument that we can make no image of Chriſte vnleſſe we will denye him to be God,The 2. Note. becauſe God lacketh forme and ſhape, is as vayne as the firſte, and ſo ſimple that M. Calf. is dryuen to featche a proufe for it, out of an heathen philoſopher in ſteade of ſcripture, councell, and auncient father. Chriſte our Sauiour, God and man, taking vpon him the nature and ſhape of man lyued here on earthe and died on the croſſe like a man. And ſeing it pleaſed his infinite Maieſtie to apeare vnto vs in the forme and ſhape of man, I woulde gladly ſee M. Calfhils ſcriptures, councells, doctours, and fathers that proue we can not paincte the image of Chriſte as man, vnleſſe we wil deny him to be God? VVe eſteeme not his owne aſſertion, neither the doctrine of Ely Phiſi, nor ſanſie of the Magdeburges ſo highly that it ſhall be worthied of authoritye for ſcripture, councell, or doctour. Howe fond this ſanſie is, I haue ſufficiently declared in the preface.

An other note is, that if the croſſe was vſed in Cyrills tyme, The. 3. Note. yet there was no picture vpon it. And that is but his geſſe. Yf it were denied, he would hardely proue it. Laſt of al,Fol. 173. b The 4. Note. that he condemneth the fooliſh ſuperſtition of Chriſtians in geuing worſe names vnto their churches, then he did to the Temples of his idols. For he called them all the Temples of faith geuing therby the glorye to God. VVheras we call them S. Iohns churche, S. Maries churche, and ſuche other like. This note is ſo fyne that all men may note him for a very Calf. that noted it.Nor Numa nor his vvritings can cōdē ne vs for building of churches. Numa Pompilius was the next kinge to Romulus who lyued many hundred yeares before Chriſte, and neuer dreamed of Chriſte nor the Chriſtians, and therfore could not condemne them of ſuperſtition. Yf he ſay his monumentes and writinges condemne vs, albeit him ſelfe did not, I anſwere, the writinges of none can condemne vs in matters of religiō, but theirs whome
we are bounde to followe, as the ſcriptures, councells, fathers, and prelates of the churche. VVe take not our religion of Numa, nor learne of him, and the gentills the manner of buildinge or dedicatinge churches. Chriſte is our Maiſter, vnder him the biſſhops and prelates of his churche are our ſpirituall fathers and guides: Of them we muſt learne our faith, of them we muſt take inſtruction howe to honour God and ſerue him. They haue builded churches and called them by the name, of S. Peter, Paule, Iohn, and Marie, Stephē and ſuche like, and yet were neuer condemned of any for ſuperſtitious, but of heretikes.
