Athanaſius writeth that after the greate miracle was wroughte by the image which the Iewes crucified, the Metropolitane of Siria being requeſted by thoſe that were conuerted and baptiſed, conuerted their Sinagoge into a churche, and conſecrated it in the honour of the ſauiour of the worlde. Afterwarde beīg required to conuerte other Synagoges and hallowe them in honore quorundam beatorum Martirū, Lib. de paſsion. imag. in the honour of certayne bleſſed Martirs, Dei iuuauime fretus cuncta expleuit deuotus, hauing confidence in the helpe of God, he fulfilled al that they required of him like a good deuoute man. Here the good Metropolitane that dedicated churches in the honour of Martirs, is not called ſuperſtitious, but deuoute, not allured with fooliſhe zeale, but inſpired with an holy ſpirite. And if it were of any accōpted (as M. Calf. imagineth) a fooliſhe ſuperſtition of the Chriſtians, to builde churches in honour of ſainctes, ād cal thē their names, why dothe he not laſhe out his ſcriptures, brīge in the coūcells, ād ꝓue it by the holy fathers? Thincketh he that it is a ſufficiēt diſcharge of his gloriouſe promiſe, to bringe, in ſo weightie a matter, againſt the Chriſtians the only authoritie of an heathen, infidel, ād one that neuer knewe chriſte, ſuch as Numa and Pythagoras were? No, we haue to many examples to the contrary, of elder age. And to many preſidentes of holy men ſithens, and authorities of councells and fathers to maintayne it. And if M. Calf. were as wel conuerſant in S. Ambroſe, S. Auguſtine, Hierome, Gregory, and other auncient fathers, and writers of Eccleſiaſticall
hiſtories, as he is in his Eſopes fables and in his newe peltinge doctours, he woulde be aſhamed that euer he let ſuch a fonde ſentence, eſcape his mouthe. For in S. Ambroſe he ſhall finde a churche called by the name of Geruaſius, Libr. 10. epiſt. 85. Lib. 22. de ciuit. Dei cap. 8. Ibidem. cap. 10. Cōt Vigilant. ad Ripa. Lib. 3. dialog. ca. 26. and Protaſius, and another of S. Fauſta, an other of S. Felix, ād Nabor. In S. Auguſt. a memorye of S. Stephē, and aulters in honour of Martirs. In S. Hierome, baſilicas Apoſtolorum Prophetarum, & Martirum, churches of the Apoſtles, Prophetes and Martirs. In Gregorie a church called by the name of S. Paule, and ſo in all other writers and hiſtoriagraphers allmoſt as thicke as haile.

And certes ſuch holy fathers, ſuch learned doctours, ſuch famouſe writers, ſuch true hiſtoriographers could haue diſcerned true religion frome vayne ſuperſtitiō. And if they had thought it only a will worſhip or ſeruice vnacceptable to God, they would neuer ſo willingly, ſo gladly, and ſo deuoutely haue dedicated thoſe churches, and called thē by the name of Saynctes. Thus much of his notes: where it is to be noted that he had rather followe Numa Pōpiliꝰ, that raigned ouer the Romaynes, thē the holy ghoſte that gouerned the holy fathers: heathēs and philoſophers, thā Chriſtiās, and true Catholike doctours. As for his negatiue argumētes, Paule ſayeth, not, Quaecū
que picta ſunt, Fol. 166. a. ſed quecun
que ſcripta ſunt, what ſo euer thinges are payncted, but what thinges ſoeuer are writtē, are writtē for our inſtructiō, Paule ſaieth not that by images or gaſinge ſtockes, but throughe patiēce and cōforte of the ſcriptures, we may haue hope, Paule ſaieth not all pictures, but al ſcripture inſpired of God is profitable to teache, to reproue, to inſtructe, that the man of God may be ꝑfect, ergo images and pictures be not profitable to teache, ergo Images and pictures be to no vſe, I leaue, with a greate many more, to the logiſioners and determiners in the ſcholes. The meaneſt and ſympleſt of thē al knoweth, that nothing can be truly concluded of negatiues. Certaine lyes and ſclaunders are contayned in this Article, and as yet not touched. Ye ſhall heare of them in their place. Nowe to the tenth Article.

div.head: THE ADORATION AND WOORSHIP OF THE CROSSE ALLOVVED BY THE AVNcient fathers. THE TENTH ARTICLE.
div.p:
IF YOV craked leſſe maſter Calf. in the ouerthrowing fundations that are to ſtronge for your weakenes, and did lay foorth before the face of the worlde weightier proufes, men would thinke their labour better beſtowed in reading your writinges. But you are ſo full of crakes, and no deedes, that you do men greate wronge to troble them, with ſo many woordes without ſubſtance of matter. Parturiunt montes: The hills trauaill, as though they laye in child bedde, but after long expectation of a fayre baby, out cometh a foule and fooliſh mouſe from the hills ſyde, that geueth all that ſee it occaſion of laughter.Calf. Fol. 175. a. b. You ſay: it had hen reaſon that I ſhould haue proued an adoration of the croſſe by ſome teſtimonie of ſcripture, which in Gods matters only and ſufficiently do take order. Mart. Proteſtāts proue not al their doctrine out of ſcripture. As though God had ſo tyed hym ſelf to the written lettre of the ſcripture, that nothing can be taken for truth, but that which is had in written ſcripture. It is no where founde in written ſcripture that baptiſme miniſtred by an heretike after the manner of the catholike church ſhould be allowable: yet the church alloweth it. Philip Melanchton an old
frend and maiſter of yours hauing to proue the baptiſme of infants againſt the Anabaptiſtes, Article 10 was compelled to alleage the cuſtome of the vniuerſall church, becauſe he had no expreſſe ſcripture for it. Frier Luther your greate idoll denied S. Paules epiſtle to the Hebrues, and S. Iames and S. Iudes epiſtles to be ſcripture. Yf a man ſhould require you to proue by ſcripture that thoſe epiſtles are no ſcripture, I thinke you would be as voyd of al ſcripture to cōfute your maiſters aſſertiō, as you would haue the world thinke that we are for the adoration of the croſſe.

In your late Synode you made a diſtinction of the bokes of ſcripture. Some ye call Agiographall, ſome Apocriphall, ſome Canonicall: but are you or they able to proue this diſtinctiō by any expreſſe teſtimonie of ſcripture? Tūble and toſſe the Byble, ſearch your wittes, aſke counſel of the ſuperintendents, and let vs haue your reſolutiō. You may ſtudie as many yeres as VValtams Calf went miles, and proue your ſelf as wiſe as he, before you finde it there. You ſay:Fol. 175. b I ſawe the ſcripture direct againſt me. But howe could I ſee that, ſeing the catholicke churche by whoſe only tradition and authoritie we haue receaued the ſcripture is euidently and plainly with me.

Touching the ignorant paynter that drewe a cock euil fauoredly, and commaunded his boye, Ibidem. The paincters Cock to keepe the quick cockes away to couer his fault, it could neuer come in better tyme. For you are the ignorāt paynters that haue drawē an euil fauored cock, that is, a newe platte of religiō,Promotours ſent to the hauens to keepe out the catholique bookes. depending of hereſie and lies. And becauſe certayne of our bokes do lyuely ſet foorth the truth, and vnplume the fylthy feathers of your euil fauored cock, you haue ſent abrode your ſpies, our promotours, your ſearchers and your miniſters, that none of the lyuely cockes ſhould be brought into the realme to crowe againſt your euil fauored paynted cock.

VVhere to ſhift away the authoritie of the fathers that ſpeake for the adoration of the croſſe, you ſay,Fol. 175. b they haue ouerſhotte themſelues in termes, I beſeeke your maſterſhip tel vs, were thoſe auncient fathers, Athanaſius, Chryſoſtomus, Lactantius, Auguſtinus,
Paulinus, Damaſcenus, and the fathers of the ſixth general councell in Conſtantinople, ſo ignorant that they could not tell howe to vſe their termes? VVere they ſo vnwary of their wordes, that in a matter of great weight, wherein yf they ſhould ouerſhote them ſelues in termes they might trayne the people to idolatrie, they would ſpeake they knewe not what, and geue other occaſion by following their geſſe to roue far from all godlynes? The fathers to vviſe to ouerſhote thē ſelues in their termes. No M. Calf. Their wiſdome was greater, and lerning more ſounder, than ſo fondely to ouerſhote them ſelues in termes. But howe do you proue this wicked ſclaunder that you lay to their chardge? By Gods euident and playne commaundement? Take heede, you promiſe no more than you are able to performe.

Calf. Fol. 175. bBefore you bring foorth Gods euident, and playne cōmaundement, you ſay: Yf I had ꝓceded according to the rule of ſkil, I ſhould haue ſhewed what adoration and woorſhip is, and then haue applied it to the croſſe. Mart. Euery terme is not to be defyned, As though a mā were bounde by the phantaſticall rule of your vnſkilful ſkill, to define euery terme that falleth in talke: and nothing were preſuppoſed to be knowen amonge Chriſten men. You haue talked in your boke of God, but in all your talke where haue you defyned what God is? You haue talked of the diuel, but where haue you defined what the diuel is? Yf you ſhould preſuppoſe nothing in talke as knowen, but would be ſo preciſe in your vnſkilful ſkil, that nothing ſhould eſcape vndefyned, whē would you make an end of any matter which you take in hāde to debate? Neuer whiles you lyue: But ſeing the rule of your vnſkilfull ſkill doth ſo leade you to define euery thing before you can procede, and to preſuppoſe that the woord of adoratiō and woorſhip were not knowen amonge good Chriſten men, before you made your deductiō out of the Hebrewe and Greke, and deſcribe it, by bowing downe, proſtrating your ſelfe, or by bowing he knee, and putting of the cappe, which you ſay, can in no ſenſe be geuē to an image or to a ſenſebeſſe thing, At this tyme as I am well contented with the former parte touching
your explication of adoration and woorſhippe: Euen ſo do I much maruel that you being ſo often in the courte doe not forbid men to put of their cappes to the Quenes Maieſties cloth of eſtate, which is both a ſenſeleſſe thing, and a dead creature? Can you that are of ſo hotte a ſpirite of reformation, hold your peace, and ſee ſuch idolatrie cōmitted (yf your owne rule be true?By M. Calfs rule no man may put of his cappe to the Cloth of eſtate &c.) Yf you were euer ſerued with a priuie ſeale, or ſtoode by when other were ſerued, I thinke either you did put of your cappe, or ſee other that did. Yf it be idolatrie, why haue you done it your ſelf? VVhy haue you not preched againſt it? Cā you finde faulte with them that putte of their cappes to the croſſe, and fynde none with them that put of their cappes, whē they receaue the Quenes Maieſties lettres, which are as ſenſeleſſe as the croſſe? I pray you good ſir be as fauorable maiſter to the croſſe on which our ſauiour Chriſt died for vs all, as you are to the cloth of eſtate or the priuie ſeale, or the Quenes Maieſties lettres, which are neuer able to be the inſtruments wherby any ſuch benefitt may be wrought vnto vs.

In the rehearſall of Gods euident and playne commaundement out of Exodus, Cap. 20. I maruell much that you did not rehearſe the former parte which doth vtterly forbidd (as ſome of yow were wōt to preache) the hauing of any grauē woork or ſimilitude, which is in heauen aboue or in earth beneath, or in the water vnder the earth? VVhy ſpooke you not againſt paynting, imbrodering, and ſilke woorkes? peraduenture the Quenes Maieſties arriſes, noble mens armes, and gentle mens recogniſances, of dragons, egles, owles, horſes, fawkons, dogges, Apes and ſuch lyke ſtayed your penne. Or perchaunce your wyues amorours image, ꝑſuaded you to allowe the hauing of ſuch images, and ſearch a gentle interpretations of Gods playne and euident commaundement. Yf the caſe ſtand ſo,Gods commaundement in Exod. toucheth not our images. then let vs deſire your clarkſhip with as good reaſon to ſearch out ſome gentle vnderſtanding in the ſecond part of the ſaid commaundement, at the old auncient fathers requeſt, who ſawe right well that al the places that yow alleage, agaīſt vs, touched not the images allowed by the Catholique church, but are all referred againſt,
the idols of the gentils. VVhich being ſo, reaſon would, that you ſhould haue proued that the places of ſcripture which you alleag, had vtterly forbidden the images of Chriſt and his ſaincts: Then had they ben to ſome purpoſe. But becauſe that paſſed your capacitie, you did as wiſely in omitting it, as you did foliſhly in alleaging ſcriptures to the to the purpoſes they ſerued not.

The images agaīſt vvhich the ꝓphetes crie Eſa. 46. Eſa. 2. Num. 22. Oſee. 10. Amos. 5. Cap. 7.The idols of the gentills againſt whome the prophetes do ſo earneſtly write, are no where founde in all ſcripture to be the images of Chriſt, and his ſaincts: But the images of Bel and Nabo, and the images of Molewarpes, and reremiſe, and the images of Baal, the images of Moloch, and Remphan, whereof S. Stephē ſpeketh in the actes. Theſe and ſuch other are the idols, and images againſt which the prophets ſpeake: And do not you thinke M. Calf. that S Ambroſe, Auguſtine, Hierome, Epiphanius, Chryſostomus, Damaſcenus, Caſsiodorus, Euthymius, and other fathers did vnderſtande what the prophets ment by the idols againſt which they crie, as wel as you, or rather better than you? Your arrogancie is greate, yet I thinke you will not imagine your ſelf able to match with theſe men. Yf you do, we can but lamēt the arrogancie, and fonde opinion conceaued of our owne wit, litle lerning, and leſſe diſcretion.

S. Ambro. De obitu Theodoſ.S. Ambroſe doth witneſſe, that Helena lyfted vp the croſſe in the head of kinges, that the croſſe of Chriſt ſhould be adored in kinges. Howe like yow this ſaying of S. Ambroſe? Becauſe he ſaied, the croſſe ſhould be adored, will yow ſay, he ouerſhotſ hym ſelf in his termes? S. Auguſtine. yf yow do, what will you ſay to S. Auguſtine vpō whoſe authoritie euill vnderſtoode yow grownde many of your hereſies? He taking of the croſſe howe honorablye it was placed in the forheads of Chriſten men, hath thoſe woordes. There was nothing at that tyme more intolerable in the fleſh, there is nothing nowe more glorious in the forhead: what keepeth he for his faithfull ſeruant that gaue ſuch honour to his puniſhmēt? Finally it is not nowe vſed amongeſt the Romanes in puniſhing the condēned. For where the croſſe of our lorde was honored men thought that the giltie perſon ſhould haue ben honored, Tract. 36. in Ioan. In Pſal. 36 yf he were put to death vpon the croſſe. Howe like yow this? S. Auguſtine teacheth that Chriſt made his croſſe honorable
and that the Romanes honoured it, and forbore the puniſhing of malefactours vpon the croſſe becauſe the people for the honour whych they did beare vnto the croſſe, were likely for the croſſe his ſake to honour theaues and murderers, yf they were put to death vpon the croſſe. Yf you ſpare him, as I truſt you will reuerēce his age, lerning, and plentifull graces of God in hym, I truſt you wilbe as good M. to S. Hier. who was ſomewhat elder, and very well lerned in termes, Latin, Greke and Hebrue,S. Hierom and not laye to his chardg that he ouerſhotte him ſelf in termes. He writeth of the graue and ſadde matrone Paula in this ſort. She went aboute to euery place with ſo great and feruent deſire, that ſhe would not depart from the firſt places,
In epitaphio Paulae. Pilgrimage.
A croſſe. Adoratiō before the croſſe.
ſaue that ſhe made haſte to goe to the reſt, and ſhe lying proſtrate before the croſſe, (awake M. Calf.) as though ſhe had ſeene Chriſt hanging vpon the croſſe, ſhe did adore. She hauing entred into the ſepulchre did kyſſe the ſtone of reſurrection, and the very place where our ſauiours bodie did lye, ſhe licked, and kyſſed with her faithfull mouth. Hitherto S. Hierome.

Here yow heare of Paula his pilgrimage, from one holy place to another, yowe heare there was a croſſe, and howe ſhe laye ꝓſtrate before the croſſe, and made adoratiō as though ſhe had ſeene Chriſt hanging there before her face. VVhat wil M. Calf. obiect againſt theſe three auncient fathers? VVill he cal thē idolaters? That were to groſſe. VVill he ſay they ouerſhotte them ſelues in termes, as he ſaied of Chriſoſtome, Athanaſe, S. Baſile and the reſt? That were to arrogant? VVhat ſhalbe his refuge then, yf one ſay vnto hym, he may woorſhip and honour the croſſe as theſe and other holy men did? Forſooth he wil ſay, auoyde Satan. By which you may note howe fynely he can apply ſcripture. Chriſt ſpoke thoſe woordes to the diuell.Scripture finely applied. And can any wiſe man thinke that the croſſe which S. Hierome, S. Ambroſe, S. Auguſtine, and other fathers, whome I mentioned before, would haue to be honoured ſhould be ſo odious to a Chriſten mā, that it ſhould be as greate horrour to falle downe before it, as it is to falle downe before the diuel? No ſuerly, except it be our ſir Iames, who is not aſhamed to ſay, that the holy fathers did ouerſhote them ſelues in termes, and yet is ſo
blinde him ſelf that he knoweth not howe to vſe his termes. For writing in ꝓſe,Fol. 176. b he talketh of a wooden tree, as though there were ſuch difference of matter in trees, that vnleſſe he had put in that epitheton, we ſhould haue imagined that he had ſpoken of ſome horned graff and or leadē tree. But you may ſee his witte.

Nowe let vs marke howe wiſely he wringeth the ſcripture that our Sauiour alleaged againſt the diuell to be vnderſtode of the croſſe: he ſayeth: It is written, Thou ſhalt woorſhip thy lord thy God, Matt. 4. Calf. Fol. 176. a and hym only ſhalt thowe ſerue. Nowe woorſhippe and ſeruice ſo ioyntly do concurre together, that the one can not be without the other. Yf only we muſt ſerue God, hym only we muſt woorſhip. It is true ſir, what cōclude you of this? That wee may not woorſhip the croſſe?Mart. By M. Calfs rule vve muſt not honour nor ſerue our parents. Eccle. 3. VVhat meane you to imagine ſuch ſophiſtical arguments as theſe are? I muſt honour none but God, whome I muſt ſerue, ergo by your wiſe rule, I muſt neither honour my father, mother, nor ſerue thē. And yet the ſcripture biddeth me doe bothe, and maketh the honour of my father and mother agree with the honour of God without any repugnancie. He that feareth God, doth honour his parēts, and ſerue thē that begatte hym, as Lordes. Nowe M. Calf. as the only ſeruice that men owe to God doth not repugne againſt the ſeruice that good children owe to their parents, and as the honour dewe to God doth not impugne the honour dewe vnto our parents, but bothe may ſtand: Euen ſo the honour that is dewe vnto God, is nothing contrary to the honour that is done vnto the croſſe. Yf M. Calfs wiſdome had proued that there is as greate contrarietie betwene Chriſt and his croſſe, as there is betwene God and the diuel, then he might haue concluded his purpoſe, ſomewhat likely out of that place of ſcripture alleaged againſt the diuell. But S. Ambroſe, S. Hierome, and S. Auguſtine haue leyed ſuch a beetel in his way, that he ſhall haue a knock in the head like a Calf. yf he attempt it.

Yf a man would denie that principle of his, that ſeruiſe and woorſhip doe ſo concurre together that one can not be without the other, and require hym to proue it by ſcripture, councell,
or doctour, Article. 9. I thinke he would be founde for all his luſty hotte bedlem ſprite, as deuoyd of all authoritie and reaſon, as an Aſſe is to ſeeke of a good amble. Might not a man lay to his chardg out of his owne declaration of adoratiō and woorſhip,I may vvoorſhip hym, vvhom I do not ſerue. that I may bowe my knee or put of my cappe to diuerſe men, whome I purpoſe neuer to ſerue? And becauſe woorſhip conſiſteth, in part, of bowing the knee or puttīg of the cappe, proue that ſeruiſe and woorſhip do not ſo concurre together, but that one may be without the other? The common courſe of our life declareth it. VVe muſt ſerue God only, I graūte: that is we muſt ſerue no other God but hī, nor any other before hī, or abowe hī or contrary to him. But he hath not proued,God only to be ſerued, and hovve. that the croſſe hath ben taken of any for God, nor that the adoration and woorſhippe of it, is a thing contrary to the ſeruiſe of God: nor ſhalbe able as long, as S. Ambroſe, Hierome, Auguſtine, and other holy fathers ſay the contrary. This argument being rotten before it came out of the ſhell, he fleeth to another as childiſhly as though he had forgot the rules of his vnſkilfull ſkill. Thus he ſaieth.

In the epiſtle to the Hebrewes S. Paule proueth Chriſt more excellent than the angells, becauſe they woorſhip Chriſt. Heb. 1. Fol. 176. a An addition not in S. Paule VVhich I graunte: but then he addeth vpon his owne hed, but they are not woorſhipped againe. For it is not in S. Paules epiſtle that the angells are not woorſhipped againe. And there he pleyeth a caſt of ligier demayne to bleare the ignorants eies. Yf he meaneth, that angells woorſhippe Chriſt, and that Chriſt doth not woorſhip thē agayne, as in ſome ſenſe it is true, euen ſo it maketh nothing to his purpoſe to ſubuert the adoration of the croſſe. For what kinde of reaſoning call ye this? The angells woorſhippe Chriſt, but Chriſt doth not worſhippe thē agayne,A fine reaſon. acknowledging them to be his equals or ſuperiours: Ergo we may not woorſhip an angel? where was this ſophiſtrie lerned? at VValtam belike. And as though he had made ſure woorke, foorth he goeth, yf angells haue not this adoration, what adoration M. Calf? Meane you that Chriſt doth not adore them?
If it be ſo, then as it is very true: So is it farre from the purpoſe. If you meane that we muſt not exhibite this adoration which is only propre to God to any angel,Angels not forbidden in S. Paule to be vvoorſhipped, as Chriſtē men do vvoorſhip thē. that is true, but as farre wide from this purpoſe, as the other. If you meane that S. Paule ſaieth: VVe ought to geue no kinde of adoration to angells, that is falſe, and no where founde in that epiſtle of S. Paule. VVhich you muſt make good, or ells you cā not not procede with this argument againſt the adoratiō of the croſſe, by taking away the adoratiō of angels, which is not mētioned in S. Paule to the He brues. VVherfore you may put that argumēt in your purſe. It will not followe: Yf angells haue not this adoratiō, ſhall a vile ſtock, Fol. 176. a or a cold canckred, corrupte piece of metalle haue it? Therefore what talke you of a vile ſtock, or a cold, canckred corrupte piece of metal? Our reaſoning is of the adoration of the croſſe, and not of a vile ſtock, nor corrupt metall, be it canckred or cold. Damaſcene maketh a playne difference, betwene the matter, be it metall or wood, and the ſigne of the croſſe. VVhy are you ſo ignorant to take the one for the other?Lib. 4. ca. 12. de fide. VVhy make you ſuch a fonde argument: VVe may not adore the metall nor wood, ergo we may not adore the ſigne of the croſſe? which is in the metall or wood? The ſigne of the croſſe vvoorſhipped, and not the matter vvhereof it is made. Knowe your folly by Damaſcene: VVe adore, ſaieth he, the figure of the precious and the life working croſſe, though it be made of another matter, not woorſhipping the matter for God forbid that, but the figure as the ſigne of Chriſt. Hitherto Damaſcene: by whome you may lerne to make a difference betwene the wood and the ſigne, the metall and the figure, and leaue to range like a lauiſh hounde that knoweth not his game. The catholiques, when the figure is blurred out, or the image broken, paſſe as litle for the wood and the cold canckred corrupte metall, as the moſt ſpritiſh puritane and pieuiſh proteſtant that lyueth.

Act. 10. The fact of S. Peter. lifting vp CorneliusThe facte of S. Peter lyfting vp Cornelius that fell at his feete and woorſhipped hym, ſaying: Riſe vp, for I my ſelf am a man, maketh nothing againſt me. For both S. Peter might doe that of humilitie toward Cornelius who was placed in good auctoritie,
geuing him to vnderſtand, Article 10 that as he ſawe him that was his maſter ſent of God, litle paſſe for any ſuch glorie of the worlde, euen ſo he ſhould in the whole trade oſ his life vſe humilitie, and not eſteme the honour and glorie that might be geuē him.Auguſt de praedeſt. ſanct. lib. • cap 7. 1. Cor. 4. Furder he might doe it to inſtruct Cornelius, who was but yet very younge in the faith, and had but a litle glimpſe of it, that he ſhould yeld no other kinde of honour to hym, than was dewe to the miniſter of God, and faithfull diſpenſer of God his myſteries, not taking the miniſters to be the principal workers and geuers of grace, but as the delyuerers of thoſe holy myſteries, which he receaued at Gods hande. For although S. Peter ſpoke thoſe wordes, for the better inſtruction of Cornelius (who had alredy done his adoration both inwardely in heart, and outwardely in bodely geſture by falling downe at his feete, no doubt without all idolatrie by the ſpecial ayde of God, who would not ſuffre hym at his firſt cumming to Chriſtianitie to committe idolatrie, whoſe prayers and almes deedes he had ſo well allowed before), yet did he neuer reproue him for doing that acte of adoration, as M. Calf falſely ſayeth, nor euer refuſed to haue the honour, as a thing vnlauful, that was dewe by the very ſaying of our ſauiour Chriſt vnto hym as an Apoſtle.Matt. 10. For Chriſt ſaid, he that receaueth you, receaueth me, and he that deſpiſeth you deſpiſeth me. God is honored, God is deſpiſed, God is loued, God is perſequuted in his ſeruants.Pri. Reg. 20. 3. Reg 1. Dauid ſuffred Abigail, and Nathā the prophet to adore hym.

Furder to make the matter more playne, that M. Calf. may ſee his blindeneſſe. VVe haue examples in the old teſtamēt, that Abigail adored Dauid lying proſtrate at his feete, intreating for her huſbands pardon. Nathan the prophet lying groueling on the grownde adored king Dauid alſo. And yf this kinde of adoration had ben idolatrie, neither would ſo good a king as Dauid was, prayſed of God him ſelf, haue ſuffred Abigail to haue fallen flatte to the grownde, neither the Propher Nathan to haue adored hym. Seing then this adoration that Cornelius did, was no idolatrie, there is no cauſe why S. Peter might not haue ſuffred it to be done vnto him as Dauid fuffred it to be done vnto him by Abigail and Nathan the prophet.

Apoc. 19. & 22. The places of the Apocalipſe, make not agaīſt the adoratiō of the croſſe.Touching the places of the Apocalypſe, where the angel refuſed to be woorſhipped, whē the Euāgeliſt fel downe at his feete, yf we ſhould followe the notable declaration of worſhip and adoration which he made in the beginning of this Article, the Euangeliſt had done his adoratiō, before the Angel did forbid him. For he ſaieth: Cecidi, I fell downe, I proſtrated my ſelf, before his feete. By which it apeareth that the adoration was actually done, yf by M. Calfs declaration, it conſiſteth only in the proſtration of the bodie, bowing of the knee, or putting of the cappe. And yf the adoration was actually done, gone, and paſt, howe could the angel forbid it? It foloweth in the text vt adorarem, that I might adore, ergo notwithſtanding the proſtration of the bodie, and falling downe at the angells fete, the adoration was not done, and ſo conſequētly it appeareth that adoration ſtādeth not only in the bowing or proſtrating the body,VVhat vvoorſhip the angel did forbid the Euangeliſt. but may be ſeparated, as this text importeth. The angel forbade the Euāgeliſt to geue hym woorſhip, not that worſhip which was dewe vnto him as to an angel, but he would none of that abſolute woorſhip and adoration which is dewe to God only. Therfore he told the Euāgeliſt, who might haue ben deceaued in taking hym to be God hym ſelf, and ſo might haue geuē the adoration dewe to God, to the angel, that he was but a ſeruant of God, as the Euangeliſt was.

But what of al this? Becauſe angells refuſed to be adored and woorſhipped as God, ſhall we refuſe to geue that honour and woorſhippe that may be geuen to an angell, or any other creature, as the image that repreſenreth vnto me Chriſt, and the croſſe that leyeth before myne eies the merites of his paſsion? By what reaſon can M. Calf. make this good? Suerly I knowe not. Yf he bringeth it to the ſcholes, he ſhal ſoner haue the noyſe of a gooſe, than prayſe of a ſcholler for it. VVe may licence hym like a lord in his owne dūgehill, to call the image of Chriſt, a foule block, Fol. 176. a b. Blaſphemie. a vile ſtock, a cold, canckred, corrupt piece of metal, a poſte forbidden to be made, accurſed to be vſed, a dumbe God, and a dead diuel, and vſe ſuch fyne eloquence, as he hath
lerned of Martin Luther and frier Bale: and of a luſtie courage,Article 9. and vayne ſingularitie to preferre him ſelf, before S. Ambroſe, S. Auguſtine, S. Hierome, S. Gregorie, and other fathers of the church,The images of angels, oxē, Lions and ſuch like in Salomōs temple, and the tabercle by the apoyntment of God. VVhat adoration is geuē to images. who commend images and the woorſhip of them vnto vs. But vntill he anſwer to the Cherubins that God commaunded Moyſes to make to couer the propitiatorie, to the braſen ſerpent, to the Lions, oxen and other images in Salomons temple, which are as farre againſt the commaundement, as the cruciſix, the croſſe, and the image of Chriſt, I will neuer acknowledg that the ſcriptures are againſt me. Naye as long as he, and his, do neither anſwer the places which we bring out of ſcriptures, and fathers, nor proue that the whole catholike churche hath erred in admitting images into the churche, and worſhipping them, Dulia, with a meane and reuerent kinde of adoration and honour, ſuch as hath ben geuen to creatures, and we commonly geue one to another, I will boldely ſay, and ſtoutely affirme that the ſcriptures are with me: and proue it as neede ſhall require. but to procede.

He findeth fault with the ſeuen auctorities, which I alleaged out of the fathers and councells for the adoration of the croſſe, and in effect ſaieth nothing more than he ſaied before. VVherfore you ſhall expect no other anſwer than I made before: Yf it may pleaſe you to loke back to that which went before, you ſhall ſee euery one of his cauills to the ſaid places detected. VVhere he ſaieth that I brought but ſeuen auctorities in all, Fol. 176. b I muſt tell his worſhip that I brought not thoſe ſeuen auctorities only, becauſe I had no more to bring,The ſeuē tene auctorities brought by M. Calf examined. but becauſe I was loth to cumbre the readers with moe auctorities than was neceſſarie. Yf the auoyding of tediouſnes hinder me not, He may before I make and end, heare more auctorities perhaps, than will ſtand with his honeſtie. He braggeth hard of ſeuentene for ſeuen, that my blinde ignorance, or willfull obſtinacie may the more apeare, as he ſaieth.

And S. Clemēt is the firſt which he alleageth.S Clemēt ſpeaketh no vvord agaīſt the croſſe and images of Sainctes. But where doth S. Clement ſpeake againſt the image of Chriſt, and the croſſe, M.
Calf. or any other image vſed in the church? Yf you bring me not that in expreſſe termes out of S. Clement, or ſo frame your argument out of his auctoritie that men may as wel ſee that he ſpake againſt the croſſe, as he did againſt the idols of gentilitie, you ſhall bring nothing againſt me and the Catholikes. VVe condemne and abhorre as well as you, all the idols of gentilitie, which the paynims toke to be very Gods, geuing that adoratiō of ſupreme dominiō vnto them, which is due only to God him ſelf, as apereth a litle before, in the ſame place of S. Clement which yow alleage. For they againſt whome S. Peter ſpeaketh, confeſſed by way of talke, that there was one God lorde of all: but thy would needes haue diuerſe other gods alſo, that ſhould haue equall honour with hym, and rule the worlde vnder him, as the Emperour hath diuerſe, Officers, Lieutenants, Conſulls, Tribunes and ſuch like. Againſt whome S. Peter reaſoneth by their owne example, of the Emperour and his officers.

Yow (ſaye quoth he) that God is compared to the Emperour, and that al the other Gods may be compared to his iudges, and other officers: keepe thē the example of Ceſar the Emperour, Lib. 5. recog. S. Peters talke to the gētils. which your ſelues haue ſet foorth, ād knowe ye, that as it is not laufull to geaue Caeſars name to any of his iudges, officers, and lieutenants, otherwiſe as wel he that taketh it vpon him, as they that do geue it, ſhalbe put to death: Euen ſo touching this matter, your dutie is to vnderſtand, that yf any do geue the name of God, to any other beſides hym, and the other do alſo take it vpon hym, they ſhall haue one condemnatiō and death much woorſe than Caeſars officers. For he that pleyeth the traytour againſt Caeſar, ſuffreth but temporall death: but be that committeth treaſon againſt the one only true God, ſhal ſuffer paynes eternal. And wel worthy becauſe he hath ſhamefully agaīſt alright abuſed the ſinguler name of God that can be verified but in one: although this worde God, The vvoord God abuſed tēdeth to the iniurie of God hym ſelf. be not the name of God, but a woord which is geuen men for the while as it were, for his name, which not withſtanding as I ſaied, where it is ſpitefully vſed, tendeth to very iniurie of his very true name. Hitherto S. Clemēt of S. Peters talke. Nowe M. Calf. yow may open your eies, and ſee that here is no worde againſt the croſſe, againſt the image of Chriſt and holy ſanctes, but only agaīſt the idols of gentilitie, which the Paynims adored and honoured as
very Gods, and ſaid that ſuch were rulers of the worlde vnder God.

Their idols had in them ſelues nor any diuine power nor repreſented any thing that had any ſuch diuine power, or excellencie aboue the common creatures, yea they were woorſe thā the baſeſt creatures of all, becauſe the diuels gaue their oracles out of them to deceaue the people. They woorſhipped, Apis the oxe, the goate, the ſerpent, Ibis the foule of Egipt, oynions,The idols of the gentils agaīſt vvhich S. Clement ſpake. priuies, fyeſtes, fartes, the ague: ād of euery one of theſe they made a God, and gaue thē no leſſe honour than they ſhould haue geuen to God hym ſelf. Againſt the honour that is geuen to theſe you may bring in S. Clemēts authoritie: but againſt the honour that is geuen to the croſſe of Chriſt, at the which the diuels doe tremble, againſt the image of Chriſt ſet vp, in part, to condemne the Manichees hereſie that denied Chriſt his incarnation and humanitie, againſt the picture of our bleſſed lady his mother and other ſaincts, againſt the image of Chriſtes owne face that he gaue to Veronica, and ſent to king Abgarus, there is not ſo much as one woord in S. Clement: but this is there, that this woord God is not the very propre name of God. For there is no one woord, nor all the woordes of honour in al the world able to expreſſe the very propre name of God, but he ſaieth: It is geuen men for the while for his name: And yf it be ſpitefully abuſed, it tendeth to the iniurie of his true name.

Yf then by S. Clemēt, this woord (God) be not the propre name of God, but a name delyured for the tyme to the dull capacitie of men that are not able to vnderſtand his very true name, and yet the abuſing of this woord (God) which is but a ſenſible woorde to the eare, as the image is a ſenſible worke to the eie, tendeth to the iniurie of God his true and propre name, why did not M. Calf. and his cumpanye perceaue that the abuſing of the croſſe of Chriſt,The abuſing of the croſſe tendeth to the deſpite of Chriſt. in the image where his bodie rent and torne for our redemption is repreſented vnto vs, tendeth as well to the deſpite of Chriſt, as the abuſing the word (God) tendeth to the iniurie of God his true and propre name? May there be ſpite done in woordes that we heare, and can there be none done in thinges ſubiectes to the eie? I thinke M. Calf. is not ſo farre
paſt al grace, but when he precheth he putteth of his cappe, and the people make courteſie, when he nameth the ſwete name of Ieſus Chriſt, and yet the name of Ieſus that is named at ſermōs, or written in bookes is not Ieſus him ſelf,As our eares cal vpō vs to bovve our knees at the name of Ieſus So doe the eies at the ſight of the crucifix. Galat. 3. but his name, and a woord that vaniſheth into the ayre as ſone as it is ſpoken. And yf we may doe honour to the name of Ieſus, which is but a ſoū de rebownding in their ayer, and not Ieſus hym ſelf, by bowing the knee, and putting of the cappe, why ſhould we not honour the image of Chriſt, and ſigne of his croſſe, by which his bitter paſsion is repreſented vnto our eies. S. Paule writing to the Galathians, ſaieth, that Chriſte was paynted before their eies. For ſo doth Eraſmus tranſlate the Greke woord, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ante depictus, paincted before, as the woorde doth beare and ſignifie. Yf then our eares doe call vpon vs to bowe our knees, and adore the name of Ieſus, when it is pronounced, becauſe S. Paule ſaied that euery knee ſhould bowe in that name, Philip. 2. VVhy ſhould not our eies cal vpon vs to bowe downe our knees, and adore the crucifix and image of Chriſt, who as S. Paule ſaieth is paincted and crucified before our eies.

Out of this place of S. Paule, let it be taken howeſoeuer M. Calf. will, either he muſt ſay that the crucifix was verily painted before the Galathians eies repreſenting the paſsiō and murthering of Chriſt as lyuely, as it was in a māner done malitiouſly by the Iewes, or els S. Paule muſt meane that they caried the image of the croſſe, and howe Chriſte his bodie was rent and torne in their mindes alwayes. And yf it were laufull for them to haue the image of Chriſtes bitter paſsion ſuffred vpon the croſſe, alwayes in their mindes as painted before their eies, why is it not as laufull to haue that image paynted in a fayre table to be repreſented vnto our bodely eies, as it is to carry the image of Chriſtes croſſe in our mindes? Speake M. Calf? Anſwer yf you can? VVill you allowe the hauing of the image of Chriſtes croſſe within our ſoule, where yf it be an euill thing, it will do more harme? and will you inhabite the hauing of the ſelf ſame image to be repreſented to our bodely eies? VVhere yf it be euil, it may doe you leſſe harme?

The commō order of nature planted for the vnderſtanding of thinges by God his ſpecial prouidence in man,Lerning cometh by the ſenſes. hath ſo his begynning of the ſenſes, eſpecially of the ſight and of the hearing, that no ma ſhould euer vnderſtand, or conceaue ought in the inward part of his ſoule, but the firſt occaſion thereof riſeth (as Ariſtotel and other lerned philoſophers ſay) of the very ſenſes.Their intēt that take avvay ſenſible thinges, that moue deuotion. And they that goe aboute to take away the ſenſible thinges that moue men to deuotion by the eies and the eares, do nought els, but reproue the common order, that God hath planted in mans creation to come to learning, and doe the beſt they cā to make al chriſtē mē beleaue, they haue ſoules without bodies, and ſeeme to paſſe litle vpon the article of reſurection.

Your laſt iniunctions take order that all the people ſhould kneele at the receauing of the communion after your ſchiſmaticall order: and yet according to your doctrine,Kneeling at the cō munion. there is no trāſſubſtantiatiō, of the bread and wyne into the bodie and blud of our ſauiour Chriſt. To whome do ye kneele? to the bread ād wyne? that were idolatrie, by your declaration of adoration and worſhip out of Hebrue and Greeke. Doth the bread and wyne which yow ſee, put yow in minde to kneele to Ieſus Chriſt?Chriſten men may kneele before the croſſe as vvel as before bred and vvyne at the engliſh cōmuniō. Yf that be your anſwer, why may not Chriſtē people kneele before the croſſe, and therby be admoniſhed to render their adoration and worſhip to Ieſus Chriſt, as yow are by bread and wyne? Search the croked corners of your witte M. Calf. and when you haue put of your braſen face let vs haue a true anſwer. And ſeing S. Clement talketh there of the idols of the gentills, geue vs a good cauſe why you do liken the images that repreſent the triumphes of Chriſt and his Sainctes vnto ſuch idols.

VVe reade in the ſcripture that holy men, iudges, and magiſtrates, were called Dij Gods, by participation and reſembling God his authoritie in the execution of their office. But that the idols of the gentils or they that were repreſented by them, were euer called by that honorable name, to their prayſe as the other are, it is no where to be ſeene. But Dij gentium daemonia, the Gods of the gentills are diuels. VVherfere to conclude concerning this place S. Clemēt, we do abhorre both the Aegiptiās and
their dumbe beaſts which they made their Gods, ſetling their adoration in them. VVe defye their oxe, their gote, their ſerpent, their Ibis, their cat, their dogge, and all their idols: and all thoſe that worſhippe the thinges that neuer lyued,Chriſten men haue not to doe vvith the images that S. Clement talketh of. making the perfect end and full reſting place of their adoration in them: And yf you be ignorant, we tell you that we haue nothing to do with thoſe idols that S. Clement mentioneth, we doe not worſhip them, we doe not adore them, we doe not reuerence them. Furder we tel you, that it is to childiſh a practiſſe, and foliſh toye, to bring that againſt our images, and woorſhipping of them which was ſpoken of the gentills idols, which they woorſhipped as Gods.

VVhere you bring another place of S. Clement declaring that the diuel ſayeth by the mouth of other. VVe to the woorſhippe of the inuiſible God woorſhippe the viſible images. Calf. And this is moſt certaynly falſe, for yf ye will truly woorſhip God his image, ye ſhould being beneficial to mā, woorſhip the true image of man in hym, I tell you as I told you before, that S. Clement ſpeaketh thereof the Gentills idols,Mart. ſuch as the church neuer vſed. VVho did euer ſet vp a drawght, a iakes, a fart, a fyeſte,Images of idolatrie mētioned by S. Clement. a cat, a dogge, a ſerpent, an oxe or a Calf. to be woorſhipped? Such are the images of idolatrie againſt whome S. Clements place ſerueth, and not the images of Chriſt and his ſaincts. Therefore you did wel to bid the reader marke, that S. Clements place proueth, that it procedeth of the ſuggeſtion of the diuell, that men for Gods honour will woorſhip, ſuch images: And in myne opinion you ſhall doe wiſely to call vpō all thoſe that ſet their delite vpon bely chere, and make that their God, as ſome of the Egiptians did, of whome S. Clement ſpeaketh, and haue vnleaded many a church and pilled many a poore man, to mayntayne that, and haue made fyne galeries, trymme priuies, ād braue iakes for ſuch purpoſes as the Egiptiās did, and tell thē that S. Clemēt ſpeaketh againſt them, for ſeruing ſo foule a god, or thinking that by honoring ſuch fayre images of ſuch ſluttiſh offices, they honour the inuiſible God.

Amonge other thinges which you kepe in England yet not reformed, one is to take, an othe vpon a booke. Article 10 VVherein you are very liberal, before you are deſired.Svvearing a kind of adoration Nowe you knowe that to ſweare is a playne acte of adoration, whether it be geuen by ſimple conteſtation, or by execration for the delyuering of ſome creature to the maledictiō of God, yf the thinge be founde otherwiſe than is conteyned in the othe. Here I muſt aſke you, why you doe exhibite to God this high and excellēt kinde of ſeruiſe and adoration, by a materiall boke, which the printer printed, or the ſcriuener wrote in paper or parchment? Yf you may exhibite the high acte of adoration by an oth vpō a boke, which is a dūbe, viſible, and ſenſeleſſe thing, why may not we as wel exhibite to Chriſt the high acte of adoratiō, and thankes geuing for his benefites geuen vs by his death on the croſſe, by caſting our eies vpon his image, where the dulleſt man that is,Adoratiō may be geuē to God by ſight of an images, as vvel as by taking an othe vpō a boke. yf he be a Chriſten man may liuely ſee in the twincle of an eie what torments our ſauiour Chriſt ſuffred for vs? Haue you any better reaſon to ſaue hym from idolatrie that taketh an othe vpon a dumbe viſible, and ſenſeleſſe booke, than we can rendre for him that kneeleth before the crucifix? No. Looke what ſhyft you can make for the booke, the ſame will we make for the crucifix: loke what defectes you laye to the crucifix, the ſame we will laye to your booke.

S. Clemēt as harde as in your opiniō he maketh againſt images,Lib. 5. recog. graūteth in playne termes that we may woorſhip the image of God in man: and yf we may woorſhip the true image of God in man,The image of God vvoorſhipped in man. then I truſt you will graunte that the true image of God is in mā, and that we may worſhippe that image by ſome external acte of the bodie, and that the external acte with which we ſhall worſhippe that image is no idolatrie. And yf you graūte this, what reaſon is there why you ſhould not graū te, that we ſeing the image of Chriſt, and his ſainctes, and thereby calling, to remēbrance that they were men, and in the ſhape of men vpon the earth, indued with the lyuely image of God, may not with ſome external act worſhippe them, and cōmitte no idolatrie in worſhipping God, and his lyuely image in them?
Let vs haue a reaſon at your next replye. In the meane time the gentle reader may both vnderſtand, that this place of S. Clemēt maketh nothing againſt the images of Chriſt and his croſſe, and alſo perceaue that your cauillations againſt the croſſe are but vayne and foliſh, and by this ſufficiently diſcried.

The reſt of the old fathers which you alleage, ſpeake nothing in expreſſe woordes nor againſt the croſſe, nor againſt the images of holy ſainctes. Nor there is any thing whereby it may be ſubſtantially gathered, that they boore any ſuch hatred to the croſſe, as you doe beare the worlde in hand. The images that they ſpeake againſt are the idols vſed of the gentils, as the place of Clement of Alexandria doth declare,The images agaīſt vvhich the ſathers ſpeake. and not the croſſe and crucifixe. They were the images of Diana, of Iſis, Pluto, Mercurius, Bacchus, Serapis, Caſtor, Pollux, Hercules, Oſiris, Ganimedes, Iuppiter, Iuno, Cupido, Venus, Saturnus, Neptune, Ceres, Proſerpina, and ſuch like idols. Of theſe the fathers ſpeake. Maſter Calf. for his life can not finde one place againſt the croſſe and image of Chriſt, doe the beſt he cā. Therfore the wordes of Clemēt aſking whether they be not monſtruous men that woorſhippe ſtones, Clemens Alexandrinus. muſt be vnderſtode of thoſe idols, and thoſe Gentills that woorſhipped them as Gods, as apeareth by the wordes that followe. And though you maſter Calf. blinded with pride, and hereſie, can not ſee what the croſſe is better thā a ſtone, yet as long as Damaſcene and other fathers of the church do put ſo playne a differēce (as I told you before) betwixt the ſigne and the metall, the figure and the matter, I truſt euery good Chriſten mā, will ſee it to be much better than a ſtone, in reſpect of hym whoſe ſigne and figure it beareth. As for the ſtones that Clement ſpeaketh of, what they are I haue told you alredye, and whoſoeuer worſhippe ſuch, they are mō ſtruous in deede.VVoordes ſhufled in, that be not in the authour. Fol. 177. b But as for our images, you ſhall neuer proue to be ſuch, as longe as you lyue: and ſeing Clement ſpeaketh not of them what honeſtie is there in you to ſhufle in theſe wordes croſſes and crucifixes, amōge his, where as he hath no ſuch woord? VVhat honeſtie is there in you, that repetīg thoſe wordes that followe corrupted the authour and left out ſome of his wordes, and where he ſaied: Adorant autem hij qui deos faciunt, non
deos & daemones, They who make goods do not woorſhip Gods and diuels etc, VVhy left you out theſe woordes, qui deos faciunt? they that make Gods? why vſed yow ſuch vile corruption? Thought you that the boke ſhould not be conferred, and the place conſidered?

Yf you did, we pittie your follie and as Clement had compaſsion vpon the gentills that were ſo mad as to honour ſenſeleſſe thinges, with diuine honour dewe to God: So haue we cō paſsion of your blindeneſſe, ignorance, and malice, that imagine the Chriſtiās to geue diuine honour to ſenſeleſſe things, and woorſhip idols as gentills did. As for the places of Irenaeus, Ireneus Tertulliā. and Tertullian, they haue nothing to your purpoſe but that which is contayned in the cōmaundemēt Exod. 20. they are anſwered in the preface.

The place of S. Cyprian would haue expounded it ſelf,S. Cypriā. yf you had not as a falſe heretike corrupted the place, and left out his woordes. For whereas ſpeakīg agaīſt the gētills that woorſhipped their idols as Gods, he ſaid, Quid te ad falſos deos humilias et inclinas? why doeſt thou hūble and bowe they ſelf to falſe Gods? yow becauſe the ſimple ſhould not ſee that S. Cyprian ſpoke of thoſe that woorſhipped idols, and falſe images as Gods, leaue them out, and inferre your owne fanſie, that to bowe, to kneele, Fol. 178 b Calf. to ſhewe any ſigne of reuerence to an earthly counterfeict▪ is contrary to nature and againſt the dignitie of our creation, and a wicked worſhip. And yf that be ſimplie true,Mart. thē by your doctrine it is contrary to nature, and againſt the dignitie of our creation, and a wicked woorſhip,By M. Calfs doctrine it is cōtrary to nature to ſhevve any reuerence to the cloth of eſtate &c. Fol. 179. a to put of our cappes to the cloth of eſtate: for there is an earthly counterfeict of a lyon, a dragon, a greyhounde, and flower de Luice. Then it is contrary to nature, and againſt the dignitie of our creation, and a wicked woorſhip to ſhewe any ſigne of reuerence when we receaue the princes lettres or brode ſeale. For there is an earthly counterfeict of an horſe, and a harneſt man, of a prince of a ſepter of a ſwoorde. And yf you thinke it true, preach it at the court.

Your illation vpon Origens woordes, That whatſoeuer our
mīdes are, our bodies muſt not bowe to any croſſe or creature, is as foliſh as the other. For who but yow would ſay, we may not worſhip the idol of Iuppiter, Iuno, Venꝰ: Ergo we may not worſhip the image of Chriſt. VVe may not bowe our knees, nor put of our cappes, to the images of Mercurie, Ceres, Proſerpina, and ſuch like, Ergo we may not bowe our knees nor put of our cappes to the croſſe of Chriſt? May not a man put of his cappe to his frēde,Origen ſpeaketh againſt the gētils idols. hūble his bodie to his better, geue reuerēce to the cloth of eſtate, bowe the knee to the prīce, and kneele at your cūmuniō, whatſoeuer his minde be? This is a ſtraunge poſitiō, worthy to be preached at the court. Or yf that place be terrible for ſo malepert a miniſter, you may goe to the ale benche, and tel thē that king Dauid did ſtarke naught when he ſuffred Abigail to lye proſtrate before hym. And yf your Euāgelicall ſprite wil ſerue yow, tell thē, the prophete Nathan was an idolatour becauſe he bowed his bodie to Dauid: tell them that Iacob that bowed his bodie to Eſau committed idolatrie, tell thē that they that kneele downe and aſke their fathers bleſsing, humble their bodies to the prince, and kneele at the cōmunion do naught. For what ſoeuer our mindes are, our bodies muſt not bowe to any croſſe or creature. As for the woorſhipping that Origen mentioneth there, we condemne and euer did. And vnleſſe you were malitiouſly ſet, you would neuer alleage it. Doe yow not ſee that he ſpeaketh there of the gentils idols, and woorſhipping and adoring thē? And ſeing we neuer had to doe, nor euer allowed thē, or any woorſhip done vnto them, why doe yow bring his authoritie in that point againſt vs? Yf yow lack better ſtuff holde your peace for ſhame. Origen ſpeaketh there no more againſt the croſſe of Chriſt, than he doth againſt a Calfs. head in a mans bodie or an oxe tayle in an aſſes face.

ArnobiusThe like may ſaied of Arnobius, and all that you bring out of hym. For as the title of his booke geueth, he ſpeaketh all to gether againſt the gentills, with whome we haue no communion: vnleſſe you will compare Chriſtians to gentills and our images,Fol. 82. a Lib. 8. cōt. gentes. to their idols: which you cā not. Before, in the 3. article, yow brought this place out of Arnobius, Cruces nec colinus nec optamus,
we neither woorſhip croſſes nor wiſhe for them: but yf I ſhould denie them to be Arnobius wordes, and require proufe of them, and authoritie that Arnobius made eight bookes againſt the Gentills, you would neuer iuſtifie it: But I willl not contēde aboute it. I allowe the woordes, and tell you as Arnobius ſaieth, that we neither worſhip, nor wiſh for croſſes, in ſuch ſort as the Gentils did. VVe make no Gods of them: we acknowledge no diuine power in them: we honour them not as Gods, like as the Gentills did their idols: and therefor in that ſenſe that Arnobius ſpoke thoſe woordes, we ſay alſo that we neither worſhip nor wyſh for croſſes.

VVhere you ſay that you will deale no furder with Arnobius, and affirme,Calf. that all his eight bokes contayne nothing els but confutation of our image hereſie, and croſſe ſhame, In myne opiniō, as you doe wiſely to deale no furder with him,Mart. becauſe he maketh nothing for your purpoſe: So you lye ſhamefully, when you ſay that his eight bookes contayne nothing els, but the confutatiō of our image hereſie and croſſe ſhame. For firſt we haue no image hereſie, nor croſſe ſhame.The doctrine of the croſſe no hereſie The doctrine of images that we teache is catholique, and good, founded vpō the Prophetes and Apoſtles and Ieſus Chriſt, the corner ſtone, who is one bodie with his ſpouſe the church. And whatſoeuer he ſpeaketh by her mouth,The croſſe no ſhame to Chriſtians. he ſpeaketh in his owne perſon. The croſſe is no ſhame of ours, but of Gentills, heretikes and heathens. It is our honour, glorie, and triumphe. And we deſire to lyue no longer than we may ſaye with S. Paule: God forbid that I glorie in any thing, but in the croſſe of our lorde Ieſus Chriſt.

As for Lactantius, Lactātius. what opinion he had of the croſſe of Chriſt I declared before. This place that you alleage here, ſpeaketh of the Gentills that feared them, whoſe counterfectes they had in ſtocks and ſtones, and could not lyft vp their eies to heauen, and conſider the creatour of heauē and earth, and lorde of all. Therfore he quarrelled with thē, becauſe they would looke to ſtockes, ſtones, and waulles, and not lyft vp their eies to hea ••• . And yf you knewe any ſuch amongeſt the Chriſtian, the •• might
you haue iuſtely alleaged this place of Lactantius againſt them, but yf you did not, then are you, but an heatheniſh quareller againſt the Chriſtians, and one that could not followe Lactantius counſell, and lyfte vp your eies to heauen, and conſider howe vou are fallen, from humilitie to pride, from truth to hereſie, from honeſtie to impudencie, from heauen to hel, from God to the diuell. From God by forſaking the vnitie of his catholique church, to the diuell by furdering his policies, and impugning the religion of Chriſt, and his churche. In which this ſaying of Lactantius: Flecte genu, lignum
que crucis venerabile adora, Bowe downe thy knee and woorſhipp the reuerend wood of the croſſe, ſhal be admitted whē all your hereſies ſhall haue their ouerthrowe, and be condemned with their authours: and that adoratiō and worſhipp which we geue to the ſigne of the croſſe ſhall ſtand, when all the woorſhip of the gentils idols that Lactantius ſpeaketh of ſhalbe confounded, and the idols of hereſie mens imaginations, and fanſies ſhall be deſtroyed.

It vvas neither abſurde nor impious for Lactā tius to coūſel the Chriſtiās to bovve to the croſſe.VVherfore to end with Lactantius, it is neither abſurde nor impious (as you ſay M. Calf.) to condemne the Gentills for turning their eies to ſtockes and ſtones, and charging the Chriſtiās to bowe the knee to the reuerend wood of the croſſe. For the Gentills reſted, their thoughts in their idols and could not lyfte their eies no higher. The Chriſtians lyfted vp their heartes to God, and would not reſte there as the Gentils did, but by that were ſtirred more often to fixe their mindes in heauen. The Gentills feared their idols as though they had ſome diuine power: The Chriſtians knewe the images to be voyde of ſenſe, which differēce betwene the Gentills, and Chriſtians, ſeing Lactantius being a profounde lerned man knewe right wel, there is no reaſon, but that he might right well condemne the Gentills for turning their eies to earthly creatures, and charge the Chriſtians to bowe their knees to the ſigne of the croſſe, and yet be neither abſurde nor impious.

AthanaſiꝰConcerning Athanaſius, what his opinion was for the woorſhipping of the croſſe, I haue alſo in parte declared before. For this preſent place,Fol. 180. a where M. Calf. ſaieth that, in his ſermon cō tra
Idola, againſt idols, he hath nothing more frequent than that ſuch honour to creatures is accurſed, I beleaue it and allowe it right wel: and confeſſe with Athanaſius, that all honour done to creatures, as Gods, in ſuch ſort as the Gentills did honour to their idols is accurſed, abhorred, and deteſted. But that we Chriſten mē doe, or euer did any ſuch honour to creatures, none but Gentills, Turkes, and Iewes, and ſuch as fauour their religion, and followe accurſed, abhorred, and deteſted hereſies, will euer ſaye: but becauſe we ſhould not thinke that thoſe ſermons of Athanaſius, cōcerne the Gentills idolls, Calf. Fol 180. a and touche not our images, maſter Calf. will come nere and go to the nature of the woorde generall adoration. And as one not fully awaked out of his drowſie dreame,Mart. he layeth foorth a place of Athanaſius againſt the Arrians,Serm. 3. not vnderſtanding that the ſaied father both in other places and alſo in the ſame place geueth hym a foule falle.One creature may adore another after a ſort. For taking the woord Adoration in his nature generall, he confeſſeth that one creature may adore another, when he ſaieth that ſuch as are of ſeruile cōdition doe adore their lordes and maſters: but Athanaſius drifte againſt the Arriās is, to proue that the Angells doe not only adore our ſauiour Chriſt, for the greter glorie they ſee hym in, for then it would followe that all other inferiour creatures would bowe downe them ſelues in that kinde of adoratiō to their ſuperiours, which they doe not, but that the Angells doe their adoration to Chriſt, as vnto God who knoweth no ſuperior nor equall. And in this kinde of adoration, Solius eſt numinis adorari. Adoratiō devve to God. It appartayneth to the only Godhead to be adored. None muſt be acknoweledged to haue ſupreme dominion but he, none honoured as lorde and God but he.

But what maketh this againſt the croſſe? Is this a wiſe argument trowe you? Chriſten men may not make the perfect end, and ful reſting place of their adoration in the viſible croſſe, ergo they may in no caſe put of their cappes, nor bowe their bodies to the croſſe? or this? God only muſt be adored as Lord, and ſupreme gouernour of all: Ergo I muſt not adore my prince, by
kneeling vnto her grace, by bowing my bodie or putting of my cap to her cloth of eſtate? Yf they be naught, you may eaſely ſee that you haue gayned nothīg by alleaging Athanaſius againſt the ſuperſtition of the Gentills or hereſie of the Arrians to impugne the croſſe. Yf Athanaſius had taken the croſſe to be ſo vile a thing as he toke the idols of the Gentils, he woulde neuer haue reported ſo honorablie of the image of Chriſt, that Nicomedus made, and Iewes crucified in Berithus as he did. As for his woordes in his queſtions to Antiochus I tell you againe, you ſhall finde them there in his ſort:Serm. de imagine. Queſt. 39. Epiphaniꝰ Crucis figuram ex duobus lignis componentes adoramus, we making a figure of the croſſe of twoe pieces of wood, do adore it, as I declared before.

The woordes of Epiphanius which you reherſe after a miſerable kinde of māgling neither declaring vpon what occaſiō he ſpoke them, nor to what end he wrote thē, might be anſwered in fewe: to witte, That he condemneth thoſe in that place that forſoke the lyuing God, and woorſhipped his creatures as God, and ſpeaketh no worde againſt the Chriſtians, who acknowledg hym, feare him, and ſerue no creature as God, but him, nor woorſhippe the image of Chriſt or ſigne of his croſſe with any ſuch honour as is dewe only to hym. But that your ignorāce ād malice may apere, I will declare the circumſtāces that you haue omitted,Heretikes deſpiſers of our Lady. Lib. 3. To. 2. cōt. Antidocomari. her. 78. and ſhewe what Epiphanius ment in that place. There were certayne heretikes called Antidicomarianites, that bore ſuch malice to the bleſſed virgin Mary, that to diminiſh the honour and glorie that God gaue her, ſaied: She had carnal copulation with Ioſeph after Chriſt was borne: at the which hereſie Epiphanius marueleth conſidering therin, howe buſye men are to ſeeke out thinges not neceſſary, ſhewing therin their greate folly in leauing out thinges neceſſarye, falling for lack of faith to blaſphemie, and to deface as he ſaieth the ſaincts honour: which hereſie being no leſſe malitious againſt the bleſſed virgin than yours is, who were wont contemptuouſly to compare her to a ſaffron bagge, Epiphanius refuteth by diuerſe other women, who were neuer called to that honour that the bleſſed virgin was, and yet becauſe they had ones promiſed to keepe their chaſtitie
for Gods ſake, they neuer broke their promiſe, as diuerſe Apoſtatats, mounkes, friers, and prieſtes doe in theſe dayes.Virginitie vovved and kept. Lib. 3. To. 2. cont. Collyria. hereſ. 79. For yf they that promiſed chaſtitie, kept it vnto their dying daye, howe much more ought we to beleaue that our bleſſed Ladie, ſayeth he, who was called to greater honour, and kept in her heart all the woordes that euer Chriſt ſpoke, kept her ſelf a virgin all dayes of her life?

Another hereſie there was which by vndiſcreete zeale, and vnbridled affection toward the virgin, gaue that honour vnto her which was neither meete nor cōuenient. For certayne women toke vpon them at a ſolemne tyme of the yere to ſet forth a ſquare chayer or chariot, couered with lynen cloth ſpread abrode, and there to ſet foorth brede, and make a ſacrifice of it, in nomen Mariae, in the name or honour of Mary, and ſo afterward all that were preſent toke part of it. Epiphanius for confutatiō of this hereſie, wherin womē toke vpō thē to doe ſacrifice vſeth a long proceſſe declaring that it was neuer allowed that women ſhould doe ſacrifice nor in the old teſtament, nor in the newe, Hovve cā they then be heads of the churche? nor doe any ordinarie acte in the church of God. For yf there had ben (ſaieth he) any commaundement, that a woman ſhould make ſacrifice to God, or execute any ordinarie or regular acte, or office in the church, it ſhould haue ben more reaſon that Marie mother of Chriſt, ſhould haue done ſacrifice to God. But it pleaſed God to geue her no ſuch authoritie, no not ſo much as to baptiſe. For then would he haue choſen rather to haue ben baptiſed of her than of S. Iohn. Theſe women then in taking vpon them authoritie to ſacrifice, did quite contrary to the lawe of God, as Epiphanius ſaieth, wherein he choketh both Luthers hereſie,Luthers hereſie cō demned. and yours that ſaye: Euery woman and gyrle are prieſtes, and haue as good auctoritie to doe ſacrifice as the prieſte.

Another poynt, wherein thoſe woomen offended was in that they offered vp ſacrifice to the virgin Marie without al cō ſideration, purpoſing to make her a God as Epiphanius ſaieth in his epiſtle to the Arabiās, doing ſacrifice vnto her in bread as vnto God, which is wicked and abhominable, becauſe many were deceaued, not (ſaieth he) becauſe the holy ſainctes are cauſe that theſe women are thus deceaued, but becauſe their thoughtes neuer quieted them ſelues, But would be ouerthrowen by wickdnes. For whether the holy
virgin be dead and buried her ſleeping is in honour, her death in chaſtitie, and her crowne in virginitie. Or whether ſhe were takē vp, as it is writtē, The ſwoord ſhal paſſe through her ſoule, her glorie is amōg the Martirs, ād her holy bodie by whome light ſprāge vnto the worlde in prayſe, or whether ſhe taried. For nothing is vnpoſsible to God, who doth all thinges that pleaſe hym: her end is knowen to no man. It is not conuenient to worſhippe ſainctes more thā is meete. But we ought to honour their lorde. Let the errour therefor of the deceaued, and of the deceauers make ones an end. For Marie is neither God, nor hath her bodie from heauen, but by cōception wrought by man and woman, according to promiſe diſpoſed as Iſaac. And no man may offer ſacrifice to her name, for therby he deſtroieth his owne ſoule.No ſacrifice to be done to the virgin Mary. And on the other ſide no man may rayle at her, diſhonoring and defacing the holy virgin, God forbid that, for ſhe neuer knewe carnall copulation neither after, nor before the byrth of our ſauiour. Hitherto Epiphanius.

By theſe places of this old father, men may knowe yf they lyſte, that neither he in al reſpectes condemned images, nor the honour geuen to ſaincts: But in that only reſpect that woemen did ſacrifice that had no authoritie at all, and that they did offer vp ſacrifice to the virgin as to God, which kinde of adoration by ſacrifice,Epiphaniꝰ cōtēt that our Lady be honored. is dewe to none but to God onlye. Touching the worſhip to be done to the virgin, he is wel contented that ſhe be honoured like a Martir, and her holy bodie to be honoured with prayſes. Nowe to come to the very poynt, as he wllleth al men to refrayne rayling at the virgin: Euen ſo he willeth all men to refrayne the doing of ſacrifice vnto her appartayning only to God, and forbiddeth the images that were ſet vp for that ſacrifice, or to her, as though ſhe were God. VVherevpon in the ſame place that M. Calf alleageth againſt images, he ſaieth In very dede the bodie of Marie was holy, yet for all that it was no God. In very deede the virgin was a virgin and honored, but not geuen vs to be adored, The adoration that Epiphaniꝰ meaneth. but ſhe adoring him which was borne of her fleſh touching fleſh. And in this kinde of adoratiō by ſacrifice Epiphanius might right well procede with proufe that neither Elias nor, Iohn, nor the
virgin, nor the angells are to be adored, nor any other mortall creature or ſeene with eie, or conceaued in heart, or expreſſed by images, yf it be aduaunced to be in degree as high as God. For it were as badde as the fornicatiō of an harlot, that offreth her ſelf equally to be abuſed of many, yf any would be ſo madde as to erect any image of a mortall creature, that the thing therby repreſented, ſhould be adored with ſacrifice as God. This is the right meaning of Epiphanius, nothing againſt the image of Chriſt or any ſainct, as they are vſed amongeſt vs, and allowed in the catholike church, as may apeare by diuerſe ſentē ces of his, and this amōge the reſt. Sit in honore Maria, Let Mary be in honour, that is, let Mary be honoured. Let the father, and the ſonne and the holy Ghoſt be adored, No mā may (after this ſort) adore Mary. This myſterie is dewe only to God, nor the angels do take ſuch a glorification.

Now (ſir) yf yow had marked theſe and other places of Epiphanius, and compared them together, you might ſone haue ſeene that it made nothing for your purpoſe, to alleage this place. For here yow may ſee that a woman can offer vp no ſacrifice to God, and yet I think you can not finde in all the ſcripture but that a woman may offer ſpiritual and inwarde ſacrifices.Some external ſacrifice. Therfore it muſt followe that there is ſome externall ſacrifice in the church, which women may not offer, for lack of authoritie, which ouerthroweth your hereſie that denie the ſacrifice of Chriſtes bodie and bloud to be offred in the Maſſe.No vvoman cā be head or gouernour of the church. And where he ſaieth that no woman may execute any ordinarie office in the church, there is another of your articles ouerthrowen, that No womā cā be head or ſupreame gouernour of the church, be cauſe ſhe can not ſpeake in the church, nor execute any regular or ordinary office in the church. But this liked you nothing, and therfore no maruel yf yow did not ſo ſoone eſpie it.

At the ſecond councell of Nice, certayne heretikes alleged Epiphanius againſt images. But as the councell did anſwer then, that the booke was none of his, but ſome Manichees, that abhorred images (as yow doe) Euen ſo doth one Epiphanius in the ſame councel clere this elder Epiphanius to be none of them that
abhorred images. Touching the later place of Epiphanius which you alleage: Non dominabitur nobis antiquus error, etc. The old errour ſhall not preuaile ouer vs, to leaue the lyuig, and worſhip thoſe thinges which are made of hym, for they haue worſhipped the creature beſides the creatour, and became fooles, VVherin he alludeth to the place of S. Paules epiſtle to the Romans,Cap. 1. the younger Epiphanius anſwereth you playnly, that it is to be vnderſtode to be writen againſt the idols of the Gentils. For as much as the Apoſtle ſpeaketh there, of the images of fleing thinges, of foure footed beaſtes, of ſerpents, and creping wormes, and not a woord againſt the image of Chriſt, and his ſaincts as the Chriſtians vſe. VVhich being ſo, what wiſdome was it for you to cite hym, who beſides that he proueth an externall ſacrifice, and that no woman can be head of the church, ſpeaketh alſo for the croſſe and maketh againſt you?Epiphaniꝰ againſt M. Calf. De vitis propheta. For Hieremie the prophete (ſaieth he) prophecing of the ſecond cumming of Chriſt, ſayeth in this manner. Et hoc aduentus indicium ipſius erit, quando gentes vniuerſae ligno ſupplicabunt. And this ſhalbe a token of his cumming, when all nations ſhall make their ſupplicatiōs to wood. Here of force you muſt confeſſe that either all nations doe well, to kneele before the the croſſe, and making their prayers there to God, or els graūte that the croſſe of wood, wherunto all nations ſhall make their ſupplications, can be no good token of Chriſt his coming. Or yf the prophete by the wood ſhould meane the matter it ſelf, then were it an errour of gentilitie, from which Chriſt by coming into the worlde delyured al nations. VVherfore the wood which the prophete ſpeaketh of, muſt nedes be the ſigne of the croſſe, before which all nations that woorſhippe Chriſt, make their ſupplications to God.

S. Ambro.VVhere S. Ambroſe ſaieth of Helena, that: Regem adorauit, non lignum, She adored the king and not the wood, becauſe it is an errour of the Gentills, and a vanitie of the wicked, It is to be vnderſtode that ſhe adored not the wood as the gentils did: but ſhe did bowe her bodie, and proſtrate her ſelf deuoutely before the croſſe, and worſhip that which was repreſented vnto the eies of her heart by the croſſe, that is the king that redemed vs vpon the croſſe.
S. Ambroſe meaneth not that it was vnlaufull either to humble the bodie, or to bowe the knee, or to put of the cappe, or ſhewe ſuch reuerence as the Chriſtians doe vnto the croſſe. He ſaieth in the ſame oration, that Helena (as I ſaied before) lyfted vp the croſſe in the head of kinges, vt crux Chriſti in regibus adoretur, that the croſſe of Chriſt might be adored in kinges. He ſaieth: Ferro pedum eius reges inclinantur. Reges adorant, Crux remedium immortalitatis, Sacramentū ſalutis. & • otiniani diuinitatem eius negant? Kinges are bowed to the yron of his feete. Kinges doe adore it, and doe the Fontinians denie his diuinitie? He ſaieth: Ecce clauus in honore eſt. Behold the nayle is in honour. He ſayeth: Helena haſtened to touch, remedium immortalitatis: The remedie of immortalitie: ſhe feared to tread vpon ſacramentum ſalutis, the ſigne of our ſaluation. By which it is euidently ſeene, that S. Ambroſe alloweth a kinde of adoration, honour, and reuerēce to the croſſe, and nayles of Chriſt, albeit he declareth that Helena did not worſhippe the wood of the croſſe, as the errour of the Gētills, and impietie of the wicked had forced diuerſe to adore their moſt accurſed idols. Yea as it apeareth in the actes of the Nicene councell, he with other fathers of the church, hath a playne teſtimonie for the adoration of the croſſe. For he ſaieth: Nunquid quum diuiuitatem & carnem adoramus, Chriſtum diuidimus? Actio. 2. Nicae. 2. The croſſe adored and Chriſt therfor not diuided. S Hierome. The images that he ſpooke againſt. Num quādo in eo & diuinam imaginem & crucem adoramus, ipſum partimur? Abſit. VVhen we adore the diuinitie and fleſh of Chriſt, do we diuide Chriſt? VVhē we adore in him both his diuine image, and croſſe, do we ſeparate hym? God forbid: So that as you ſee, M. Calf. hath no aduantage by S. Ambroſe: for he maketh cleane againſt hym. The next doctour that M. Calf. bringeth for his purpoſe againſt vs, is S Hierome vpon the third of Daniel, where howe he deceaueth the readers note I beſeeke you. S. Hierome talketh there of Nabuchodonoſars Gods, and the golden image that he would haue to be adored, and ſaieth: That the woorſhippers of God ſhould not adore that image. Furder he ſaieth, that the iudges and princes of the world, which adore the pillers and images of Emperours, may vnderſtande, that they do that which the three children refuſing to doe, pleaſed God. Then he inferreth theſe wordes that maſter Calf. alleageth: Notanda eſt proprietas, etc. The proprietie of the
woordes is to be noted, that Gods are worſhipped, and an image adored, whereof neither is conuenient to the ſeruantes of God. By which wordes S. Hierome declareth that it is incōuenient for the ſeruāts of God to worſhippe falſe Gods, with the gētils and Iewes, and the goldē image of Nabuchodonaſar, with the iudges and princes of the earth. As for the croſſe and image of Chriſt or any ſainct,No vvord in S. Hierome agaīſt vvorſhipping of the croſſe. S. Hierome ſpeaketh not ſo much as one worde, neither in that chapiter, nor in the 6. and tēth of Ieremie, to which M. Calf. referreth vs, to ſee playnly, that no woorſhip nor adoratiō ſhould be geuē to ſo vile a thinge as the croſſe is.

Howe vile a thing ſo euer the croſſe ſemeth to you, it forceth not. That S. Hierome would haue adoratiō and reuerēce geuen vnto it,Adoratiō of the croſſe allovved by S. Hierom and to ſuch earthly thinges, that putte vs in remembrance of Chriſte, and his ſainctes, he declareth vpon the 98. Pſalme, where he ſaieth: There be diuerſe opinions aboute this foote ſtoole, but the prophete taketh it here for our lordes bodie in which the maieſtie of the Godhead ſtandeth, as vpon a fote ſtole. VVhich that it ſhould be adored, the Apoſtles declared at his aſcenſion vp to heauen, when they returned adoring vnto Hieruſalem. Theſe alſo are to be referred to our Lordes croſſe, Acto. 1. and to his holy ſoule. Here S. Hierome taketh the foote ſtoole which the Prophete Dauid willed vs to worſhippe to be our Lordes bodie, his croſſe, and his ſoule, and willeth them to be adored and worſhipped. In another place he ſaieth: I returned by and by as faſt as I could to my Bethlehem, Apol. 3. cōt. Ruff. adoraui praeſepe & incunabula Saluatoris. I adored the maunger, and ſwathlinge clothes of our ſauiour. And yf he did adore (as he ſaieth) the maunger and poore clothes that Chriſt was wrapped in, is it likely that he founde faulte with them that worſhipped the croſſe on which he was crucified? Not in wiſe mens iudgments I ſuppoſe. But M. Calf. hath purchaſſed a placket to make them ſay what he liſteth, and to turne that to the Chriſtiās, which they ſpoke againſt the heathens, paynims, Iewes and their idols.

VVhere S. Auguſtine ſpeaketh againſt idolaters and the idols of Iuppiter, S. Auguſtine. Iuno, Venus, Ceres, Bachus, and not one worde againſt the croſſe or any image of Sainctes, he abuſeth that holy fathers authoritie,
and maketh the ſimple beleue that he ſpeaketh againſt the croſſe of Chriſt, and adoration of it, which is very fond and vayne. But what S. Auguſtine thought touching the reſpectiue re adoration of the croſſe, I haue declared before. VVhere M. Calf. ſaieth,Fol. 186. b Chryſoſtome. Ioan. 11. that Chryſoſtome in any woorke of his diſſenteh not from the reſt, tell hym that as Cayphas ſaying, It is expedient that one die for the people, ſayed true, and truer than he was ware: So in this caſe, he ſayeth true, and truer than him ſelf wiſt, but not in the ſenſe that he imagineth. For Chryſoſtome in very deede in al his workes diſſenteth from none of the fathers in this poynt. But as they all cōdemned the Gentills idols, and wicked worſhippe done vnto them: So doth he. As they ſpoke nothing againſt the adoration of the croſſe in ſuch ſenſe as the Chriſtians adore it: So doth he ſay, not one woord. But both telleth vs, howe Chriſten men did bleſſe them ſelues, and woorſhippe the croſſe, and alſo geueth teſtimonie by his writings that he exhorted his people to worſhippe the croſſe.

For the firſt, talking of a foliſh cuſtome that ſome had to dawke their childrens heads with durte thinking therby to preſerue them from witchraft, he ſaied,Hom. 12. in 1 ad Corinth. Chriſoſtome allovveth the adoration of the croſſe. It is to be lamented that this ignominie, preuayleth amongeſt them, quicrucem adorant: who adore the croſſe, and communicate the ſecrets myſteries. Therfore he wil led them to leaue it, and to teache their children to bleſſe them ſelues with the croſſe. And yf the children were not of age able to do it, he willed the parents to do it for them, For the ſecond, that he exhorted all his people to worſhip the croſſe, it apeareth by his ſermon made de veneratione crucis of the woorſhipping of the croſſe. There he ſaieth, Becauſe this daye, is apoynted to the woorſhipping of the precious croſſe, come hether, Let vs with feare and deſyre embrace it. By theſe playne woordes out of his commentaries vpon. S. Paule to the Corinthians, and out his ſermon tranſlated trulie after the Greeke copye, and not after frier Periōs fanſie (as M. Calf. ſuppoſeth) it is euident that his people did adore, and worſhippe the croſſe, and he hym ſelf allowed and commended that adoration and worſhippe which they did vnto the croſſe.

This ſaying of his. Adorare creaturae, adorari non creaturae, ſed domini
eſt. To adore belongeth to a creature: to be adored belongeth to no creature, but to hī that is lord of the creature, is true in the ſenſe that Chriſo. there meaneth: for expoūdīg thoſe wordes of the goſpel,Ioan. 4. vos adoratis ꝙ neſcitis, etc. Ye woorſhip that which you knowe not, but we worſhip that which we knowe, he talketh there howe both the māner and place which the iewes and gentils had to worſhip God, ſhould be altered, ād chaūged, ād god worſhipped in ſpirite ād truthe. And in that ſort no creature muſt be worſhipped but worſhip, no creature be adored, but adore his creatour and lorde,Cyrillus. Lib. 2. ca. 1 both as Chriſoſto. here, and Cyril in his bokes of treaſure and al other Chriſten mē acknowledg. But that abſolute and perfect kinde of adoration with which God muſt be adored, and woorſhipped only, will not let but that creatures may be adored as creatures, otherwiſe howe will M. Calf. iuſtifie this argument, I muſt adore and worſhip God only, Ergo I muſt not humble my bodie, put of my cappe, bowe my knee nor ſhewe any reuerence or to my prince, or to her letters, or to her cloth of eſtate? Yf he thinke that an vnlaufull argument then muſt he confeſſe that neither Chriſoſtome, nor Cyrill, make any thing for his purpoſe. For the adoration which they ſpeake of, is the high and abſolute adoration dewe only to God, and not that which one creature may geue vnto another.
