And this anſwer may ſuffiſe for the places which he bringeth out of S. Gregorie.S Gregorie. For the adoration which he forbideth to be done to images, is the abſolute adoratiō dewe vnto God, ād no other as you may ſee by that wich I haue declared in the preface, and by his whole epiſtle to Secundinus.Libr. 7. epiſt. 53. For there it is declared, that he kneeled and proſtrated hym ſelf before the image of Chriſt not as before the diuinitie it ſelf, but as before an image that repreſented Chriſt, God and man whome he adored.

Alfonſus. Fol 181. aNowe to Alfonſus de Caſtro: He reporteth (ſaieth M. Calf.) that one Claudius, biſshop of Taurino forbadde al in his iuriſdiction the adoration and woorſhip of our Lordes croſſe. True it is he doth ſo. But is there al that Alfonſus ſaieth M. Calf? Doth he not tell you that the ſayd Claudius was an heretike? and declare that the prohibiting of adoration to our lordes croſſe
was an hereſie? Yes verily, and why did you omitte that ſir? Could you ſo ſubtillie ſee the one, and be blinde in the other? Could you alleage a workeman of our occupation (as you terme hym) and could you not ſee the iugler of your owne occupation? That was not wel ſpied of you. Your caſe is miſerable when you muſt alleage accurſed heretikes to defend your Euā gelicall doctrine. Your Claudius was a wicked heretike, he endeuoured to rayſe not only the hereſie againſt the worſhipping of images, but alſo, the hereſie of Vigilantius, and Euſtatius. Yf you diſcredite it, ſee what Ionas biſshop of Orleance hath written againſt him. My ſelf wil ſay no more, but that it is an euil cauſe that hath no better pillers to mayntaye it, than canckred heretikes, amongeſt whome Alphonſus diſcourſing of hereſies reckoneth M. Calfhils Claudius: and condemneth his inhibiting the people to worſhip the croſſe of Chriſt, to be a wicked hereſie, and ſo ſheweth his opinion concerning the adoration of the croſſe, that yf M. Calf. had diligently viewed it, he would neuer haue numbred hym amongeſt ſuch doctours as prohibite the worſhipping of the croſſe. For there he doth playnly approue it, and in another worke of his moſt euidently declare, that it is the diuel that maketh mē deſtroye the croſſe of Chriſt,Lib 1. cap. 16. de iuſta punitione hereticor. and images of ſainctes. For talking of certaine duties that the diuell requireth of ſome lewde perſons that committe them ſelues vnto hym, he ſaieth: He that is ready to profeſſe this arte, when he is brought before the diuell, muſt denie his baptiſme, A precept of the diuels to deſtroye images. and forſake all the principles of Chriſtes faith: He muſt contemne all the ſacraments of the church. He muſt throwe downe the croſſe, and image of the bleſſed virgin, and all holy ſainctes, and tredde thē vnder his feete, and beware that he call not vpon the name of God nor make the ſigne of the croſſe, becauſe he can not abyde it, but fleeth away at the ſight of it. But either M. reader had not reade ſo farre, or els he was not diſpoſed to vtter Alfonſus opinion truly, leſt the people ſhould vnderſtand that it is a counſel and precept of the diuel to deſtroye the images of ſainctes, and prohibite mē to make the ſigne of the croſſe: but there is litle ſinceritie in ſuch dealing. As for the booke which you aſcribe to Carolus Magnus, it is but a fonde fable, as I
declared before. Your opprobrious wordes calling the ſecond Nicene councell a doltiſh conſpiracie diſſembling at Nice, Fol. 182 a declare that you are but an arrogant, doltiſh, and diſſembling, foole. For you venture to condemne that which all the catholike church hath allowed to be a ſounde, lerned, holy, and general councell. Theſe ſeuentene auctorities thus recited, he draweth to a concluſion, and before he entreth to it, he ſaieth in his owne perſon:Calf. Thus haue I ſleightly paſt ouer not al that I could recite, but as many as I though expedient for clere diſproufe of your vngodly purpoſe, Mart. and where he thought to haue a triūphe, as though the field were wōne, he hath loſt the victorie, and cōfeſſed ſo much agaīſt hym ſelf as would in any court in England condemne hym of extreme folly. For he ſaieth: He hath ſleightly paſſed ouer theſe authours, M. Calfs ſlighte dealing. and ſo in deede he hath both ſleightly, and craftely: nor weighing their woordes perfitely, nor conſidering the circumſtances narrowly, nor comparing what they ſaied in other places wiſely, not putting a difference betwene the image of Chriſt and idols of Gentilitie. To ſleightly God woott, for the weight of the matter and inſtruction of the reader. But ſuch ſleight dealing is not vnwounte to ſuch ſleight heretikes, that vſe all the ſleightes they can to deceue the ſimple people: and certes vnleſſe M. Calf. had ben wilful in contempt of antiquitie, ſingular in his owne fanſie, puffed with vayne glorie, impudent in forging of lyes, and careleſſe in deceauing the reader, he would neuer ſo ſleightly haue paſſed ouer ſo many fathers, and reported neuer a one of their ſayings in the true and propre ſenſe that they meāt. But let it be his ſleight.

VVhy findeth he fault with me for acknowledgīg the adoration and worſhip which the fathers gaue vnto the croſſe to be an inferiour kinde of reuerence, ſuch as may be geuen to creatures? May not euery man be beſt interpreter of his owne meaning? Thought he that when the fathers ſpoke of the adoration and worſhip of the croſſe, they did not vnderſtand what adoration and worſhip was dewe vnto God as creatour
and lord of al? and what was dewe to the croſſe as a creature and ſigne of health vnto vs al? Thought he becauſe the perfect, & abſolute adoratiō and worſhip, by which we ſerue god only acknowleging hī to be ſupreme lord, and gouernour of al, only woorthy to be adored in ſpirite and truthe, that there is no adoration, no worſhip, no inferiour reuerence dewe vnto creatures, as to our prince, to our parents, to our elders, to the croſſe of Chriſt? Yf he doe, he is fouly deceaued. For that we may geuē a kinde of adoration, worſhip reuerence, and honour to creatures by humbling the bodie, bowing the knee, putting of the cappe, kyſsing and ſuch like, I haue declared both here and in the preface. Yf M. Calf. knewe this, what phrēſie forced him, to accompte them bablers, who made their diſtinctiō, betwene 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ? that is ſeruice dewe to God,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . and ſeruice dewe to man? They are both gathred out of ſcripture, and vſed of no worſe doctour than S. Auguſtine, expreſſing by the one, adoration, worſhip, ſeruice, and honour dewe only to God,Libr. 15. cōt. Fauſt. Manich. cap. 10. & lib. 10. Cap 1. de ciuit. Dei. Calf. Fol. 183. b Mart. and by the other, adoration, worſhip, ſeruice, and honour dewe vnto man or any other creatures.

Thought he with a fonde and doltiſh tale of? woe horſes put in one ſtable, to eate at one rack, and reache to one maunger, not ſerued yet a like, becauſe they haue a barre betwixt them, to ſcoffe out the matter, ād irride the holy fathers that vſed that diſtinction? That was not Chriſtian like, nor miniſterlike. No bedlem in his furie could haue ſpoken more vnreuerently. For the one parte of his tale of two horſes ſet at one manger, he applieth, to the adoration of God, and the other to the adoratiō of the croſſe, which applicatiō is blaſphemous. But you ſee howe M. Calf. improuing the croſſe, and adoration of it, is driuen to runne to Iewes, to Turkes, to coniurers, to idols of Gentills, to heretikes, to horſes, to ſtables, to mangers, and rackes, for defence of his hereſie, and yet all will not ſerue: The diſtinction of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſtādeth ſounde and good, and the maynteners of it as wiſe and lerned fathers, and not vayne and doltiſh bablers as this our ſir Iames imagineth. And yf he had ben
ſo wiſe as he maketh hym ſelf, he might haue ſene it in our common life. VVe bowe our bodies to our prince, we kneele vnto her grace, we put of our cappes to her cloth of eſtate, and at the receit of her brode ſeale, and this bowing, kneeling, putting of the cappe, is a kīde of adoratiō (as hym ſelf proueth) out of Greke and Hebrewe, but this adoration is not done vnto the prince as to God,kneelīg to the prince is no idolatrie, M. Calf, and yet a kinde of adoration. and yet it is a kinde of adoration. VVherefore as it muſt be different from that which is dewe vnto God: So it muſt haue a different terme to be knowen by: and ſeing no Latin worde doth ſo wel expreſſe it, as the Greke, our forefathers haue called it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and therin in the iudgment of all lerned men did right wel, and were neuer cōtrolled of any vntill our younge maſter ſir Iames that will turne al vpſi downe ventred to call them bablers. But that will not ſerue his turne, nor ſaue his honeſtie.

Yf M. Calf. ſhould tel a ſimple man, that hath but a meane witte, that this is the image of Chriſt, he would knowe by and by that the honour which he vſeth in kneeling before the image, may not haue his full reſt, and principall end in the image, but in our ſauiour Chriſt, repreſented by the image, and not worſhip the material image in the church, but Chriſt, his mercifull lord and ſauiour in heauen. VVherefore to conclude ſeing the ſeuentene authorities that M. Calf. alleageth, ſpeake either againſt the idols of Gentills, and wicked worſhip done vnto them as Gods, or of the perfect and abſolute adoration which may be geuen to no other, but vnto God only, and vtter not one woorde againſt the images of the Chriſtians, and the inferiour adoration,VVordes vſed of the fathers to declare that they vvoorſhipped the ſigne of the croſſe. reuerence, and woorſhip that may be geuen to them as to the creatures of God, there is no cauſe why any Chriſten man ſhould beleaue his ſeuentene witnes, that ſpeake nothing for hym, before the ſeuen that in euident, playne, and expreſſe wordes, iuſtifie this cauſe that I haue in hand, or thinke that S. Baſile, Athanaſius, Chryſostomus, Lactantius, Paulinus, Augustinus, Damaſcenus, and the fathers of the ſixt generall councell of Conſtantinople in Trullo, vſing theſe wordes, honorare, adorare, venerari, veneratione dignū arbitrari, honorem habere, adorationem
tribuere: To honour, to adore, to worſhip, to thinke woorthy of woorſhip, to geue honour, to attribute adoration, to declare a kinde of adoration, honour and worſhippe dewe vnto the croſſe, were liers and idolaters, mē that ouerſhot thē ſelues in termes, or meant better than they wrote. Becauſe the right woorſhipful M. Calf. mounted into the hill of pride, and ſette in the ſeate of ſingularitie, with out all honeſtie, reaſon, or ſhame, hath condemned them for ſuch.

VVhere he noteth theſe woordes in the Margēt of his boke,Fol. 183. b A ſtrange proufe that no man may feare idolatrie in a papiſte, knowe ye good readers, that vnleſſe that ſtrange witte of his, had ben eſtranged with ſtrāge fanſies, and idle toyes, he would neuer haue thought the reaſon that I made for it to be a ſtrange proufe. To the end you may vnderſtand it, and his ſtrange capacitie conceaue it, I will bring it into a fillogiſtical argument. It is this.No man ought to iudge euil of another. &c. No man ought by the Lawe of God to iudge euil by any curious ſurmiſes or ſuſpicious fanſies of any Chriſten man that is baptiſed, and beleaueth in one God for doing of any acte that is commonly prayſed and allowred of many as well done, vnleſſe the cōtrary be proued. But to kneele downe in the church before a croſſe, to put of our cappes, and bowe the bodie, is an acte that is commonly prayſed, and allowed of many, videlicet of the whole Catholique church, as well done: Ergo no man ought to iudg euill by any curious ſurmiſe, or ſuſpicious fanſie, of a Chriſten man kneeling before a croſſe, and thinke that he committeth idolatrie. The Maior dependeth of the lawe of God. Nolite iudicare. Iudg not, Matth 7. and yow ſhall not be iudged. The Minor is euident by the practiſſe of the Catholique church, and proued by authorities brought before out of the old fathers, Grekes and Latins. The argument is good: ergo the cō cluſion, that you may not iudg men idolaters by curious ſurmiſes, or ſuſpicious fanſies vntil the contrary be moſt euidently proued, muſt needes be true. And yf we may not iudg euill of them, then may we not thinke euill of them. And yf we may not thinke euill of them, then may we not feare when we ſee them kneeling before a croſſe, and proſtrate before the crucifixe
that they cōmitte idolatrie. For yf we be Chriſtiās, and knowe them to be Chriſtians then muſt we thinke of them like Chriſtians, and not ſuſpect and feare the woorſt, like Antichriſtians. Charitas non cogitat malum: 1. Cor. 13. Charitie thinketh not euil.

VVhere you labour M. Calf. to proue by force of my argumēt that all proteſtants be good Chriſtians, I wiſhe with all my heart that you would proue it true in deede,Fol. 184. a by ſome fruictes of penaunce worthy of Chriſtians. But as longe as you continewe in your Apoſtaſie, like obſtinate heretikes out of the vnitie of the church, you will neuer be able to proue your ſelues good Chriſtians. Tertullian maketh this argument: Hereticus eſt, ergo non est Chriſtianus. De preſcr. Tract. de ſimpl. prae lat. & li. 4. epiſt 2. Contra Auxent. He is an heretike, ergo he is no Chriſtian. Sainct Cyprian maketh the like: Eſt ſegregatus ab Eccleſia: He is ſeparated from the church. Ergo prophanus eſt, alienus eſt, hoſtis eſt, therfore he is prophane man, he is an alien, he is an enemy. S. Hilarie maketh this argument: Arrianus eſt, ergo diabolus eſt. He is an Arrian, ergo he is a diuel. The ſcripture maketh this argumēt: Nō audit Eccleſiā, ergo eſt Ethnicus & Publicanus. He heareth not the church, Ergo he is a Heathen and a Publicane. VVherfore for all the fayre crakes of your Chriſtianitie, the truth will trie, that you be no true Chriſtians and by conſequent haue not lerned effectually that commaundement to haue no other God but hym, nor to beleaue in any other God but in hym, nor to ſerue any other God but hym.

Secōdarely where you ſay, that we are to blame in deming amiſſe of proteſtants, Fol. 184. a VVe iudge not euil of heretikes for doing any acte allovved by the churche in ſuch ſort as they ſhould. vnderſtand I beſeeke you, that we iudge not euill, nor deeme amiſſe of you, vpō any curious ſurmiſes or ſuſpicious fanſies, for any acte that the catholike church hath allowed, as it hath allowed the adoration and worſhippe of the croſſe. Yf we did, we did very euill: but your tongues vtter ſuch blaſphemies, your hādes, write ſuch hereſies, your ſelues practiſſe ſuch vilanies, and ſhewe ſuch affinitie in your doings with the old canckred, corrupt, and wormeaten heretikes, that all Chriſtian realmes not infected with your corruption, may accompte you for ſuch. And ſeing we haue euidence of your factes, we do not amiſſe in iudging of you, as we doe.

Thirdly where you ſay, that all Chriſtians (by force of my reaſon) can not ſynne, Let vs vnderſtād of your worſhip, howe this argument holdeth, Chriſten men that haue but one God, beleaue but in one God, and ſerue, but one God, contynuing Chriſten men can not committe idolatrie, ergo they can not otherwiſe ſynne. And yf you finde that the groſſe and wicked idolatrie of the Gentills that woorſhipped ſtockes and ſtones, which we talke of, was taken away by Chriſt, and ſo taken away that euery Chriſten man knoweth it, and abhorreth it,Idolatrie taken avvay by Chriſt. moſt of all other faultes, you may wel thinke that albeit ſynne may otherwiſe, by frailtie raygne in vs for a tyme, yet idolatrie can not entre into our heartes, eſpecially that groſſe idolatrie of the Gētills to worſhip ſtocks and ſtones. I told you before that the Chriſtiās ſaied to the Iewes, thinking that they would forſake Chriſt, and woorſhip Polycarpe, as you doe that we will forſake God and woorſhippe ſtocks and ſtones:The anſvver of the Chriſtians to the Ievves. Euſeb. lib. 4. cap. 15. hiſto. The wreched men knowe not, that we can neuer forſake Chriſt who ſuffred death for the ſaluation of the whole worlde, nor woorſhippe any other. And the ſame I tell you nowe agayne, and geue you the ſame cauſe that they did, the Iewes: Quoniam verum Deum & qui ſolus colendus ſit nouerimus, Becauſe we knowe the true, God and hym who is only to be woorſhipped, and loue and worſhip the martirs, as the diſciples of our lorde, etc. VVherfore notwithſtanding after Chriſtendom and faith receaued, many be murtherers, theaues, adulterers, and ſuch enormous ſynners, Yet no true Chriſtian that hath receaued the faith, can falle to the groſſe idolatrie of the Gentills, and forſake the true and lyuing God, and for hym woorſhip a ſtock and ſtone. So that it bideth ſtill for all M. Calfs blinde reaſon, that there cā be no feare or miſtruſt of idolatrie in Chriſtē men adoring and woorſhipping the croſſe. And that they doe moſt wickedly in affirming vs to be idolatours. For they iudge of our heartes, they iudge of our mindes, they iudge of our inwarde thoughtes, which no man can doe, but God only, that knoweth the ſecrets of all hearres.

VVhere you ſay that God is not contented yf a man inwardelyFol. 184. b Calf.
with heart acknowledg hym, but alſo ſeuerely doth exact, that by our outward ꝓfeſsiō we teſtifie to the world, that his diſciples we are: for vpō none other conditiō but this, he doth admittevs into the ſocietie and felowſhip of his kīgdom, Mart. I maruel that you did not remēbre your poſitiō and doctrine of only faith. For yf only faith iuſtifieth, and good workes helpe nothīg to our iuſtificatiō and ſaluatiō, thē doth not god ſeuerely exacte that we teſtifie by outwarde profeſsiō, that we are his diſciples. For that we cā not do but by good workes.M. Calf. condemneth his ovvne doctrine of only faith And yf God admittevs into the feloſhip and ſocietie of his kīgdome vpō no other cōdition, but this, that is, except we teſtifie to the world by our outwarde profeſsion, (that is by our good workes) that we are his diſciples (for to profeſſe Chriſt is a good woorke) then vnleſſe we do good woorkes we ſhall not come into heauen, haue we neuer ſo much faith, able to transfer mountaynes, and force vs to geue our bodies to the fire to be burnt. VVherefore my counſell is that ſeing God admitteth vs into the feloſhip ād ſocietie of his, kingdome vpon none other condition but this, that we teſtifie our faith by outward profeſsion which can not be but by good workes, that you leaue your preching of only faith, and falle to good woorkes. For vpon none other conditiō God will admitte yow into the ſocietie of his kingdome.

VVhere yow ſay that there is no true faith before God, but the ſame engendreth a true confeſsion before men, I cā not ſee to what purpoſe yow bring it againſt me in this matter. A man might caſt a beetle in your waye out of S. Iohns ghoſpell, where it is ſaied,Cap. 12. A faith and yet no cōfeſſion before men. Many of the chiefe rulers beleued in hym. Here is a true faith: but for the phariſees they did not confeſse hym that they might not be caſt out of their Synagog. Here is no confeſsion. So yow haue a true faith, vnleſſe yow will ſay the ſcripture is falſe, and yet it engendred no confeſsion before men. But, put caſe it be true, what maketh it againſt me? Doe not we confeſſe our faith before men that we profeſſe inwardly to God? Let our workes trie.

Fol. 185. aConcerning the twoo kindes of idolatrie which yow mention, as I denie them not: So am I glad to heare that yow doe
confeſſe once in your life that there are two kindes of honour dewe vnto God, One ſpiritual reſting in the heart:Tvvo kindes of idolatrie. Tvvo kindes of honour devve vnto God. Another corporall conſiſting in outward geſture. Certes yf there be a corporall honour dewe vnto God, we may thinke that God not withſtanding he is a ſpirite, is delited when we honour hym by the corporall ſeruice and geſture of our bodie: and that our kneeling, knocking, holdīg vp the handes, yea before an image, doe nothing abaſe our eſtate, nor ſhewe vs to be any others ſeruāts thā Ieſus Chriſt that redemed vs, and hath brought our holy fathers to his kingdome in heauē, that kneeled, and held vp the hādes, yea before images in his church in earth. But Calf. ſaieth that becauſe we kneele we knock, and hold vp the handes before an image, we defile our bodies with ſacriledg, Calf. Fol. 185. a. we attaynt thē with idolatrie, we haue thē ſubiecte to the diuells ſeruice. Here are bloudie woordes. But where are the ſcriptures,Mart. councels, and fathers to proue this? yea where is any reaſon to make this his argument good? we kneele we knock, we hold, vp our hāds before an image: ergo we defile our bodies with ſacrilegd and attaynt them with idolatrie, and make them ſubiect to the diuells ſeruice? Yf kneeling, knocking, and holding vp the handes yea before an image, be a ſufficient cauſe, to proue mē idolaters, howe wil he excuſe him ſelf, and his bretherne that kneele before the prince, kneele before bred and wyne at the communion table, and peraduenture vpon remorſe of conſcience knock their breaſts with the publicane? howe will he excuſe them that in Cathedral and pariſh churches,Proteſtāts knele before images, and creatures. hold vp their handes, and turne vp the eie, yea before the images in the glaſſe windoes, when they here the name of Ieſus, or pray with the miniſter? Howe will he excuſe the prentiſes, and dentye dames, that at Poules croſſe, hold vp their handes, and turne vp their face to the element, and when the precher talking againſt the papiſtes, ſaieth, the Lord confounde them, anſwer Amen? They kneele before creatures, they hold vp their hands before images, they lifte vp their eies to wardes the ſunne and elemente: and yf M. Calfs. ſophiſtrie be true, they delfie their bodies
with ſacriledg, they attaynt them with idolatrie, they haue them ſubiect to the diuels ſeruice.

The excuſe that M. Calf. maketh for his bretherne ſerueth for the Catholiques.Yf he excuſe his bretherne from groſſe idolatrie, becauſe their intent is good, and mindes are in heauē, although their bodies bowe in earth, the ſame excuſe ſhall ſerue for vs. Four our intent is good: our mindes are in heauen with God: our knees bowe to hym: our handes are lifted vp to hym, our breaſtes are knock to teſtifie a compunctiō of our heart, for offending him, and to ſtirre vs to more deuotion, and ſorowe for our ſynnes. VVe ſette not our adoration in the image: but in the repreſented by the image. VVe adore not the image, as it is an earthly thing, but we adore it, for that it repreſenteth vnto vs Chriſt or his ſaincts.

Furder, where M. Calf. ſaieth, that God his eternall will, requireth, and reaſon conuinceth that we with bodely ſeruice ſhould glorifie and honour hym, and affirmeth corporall honour to conſiſte in outward geſture, Fol. 185. a either he muſt acknowledg, that God is glorified and honoured by kneeling, knocking holding vp the hādes, yea yf it be before images (for whereſoeuer any kneele, knock, or hold vp the handes, he muſt doe it before ſome viſible creature, for the which he may be as wel ſuſpected of idolatrie, as for kneling, knocking or holding vp the handes, before an image), Or els he muſt declare in what other outwarde geſture the corporall honour, wherewith we muſt glorifie God, doth conſiſte. For ſome there muſt needes be, and fewe beſides theſe he will finde that ſhall like hym.

Fol 185. a Outvvard thinges condēned by proteſtants.Outwarde ceremonies he calleth maſking and externall pompe. Comely apparel is compted the ragges of Rome, and God thought to be ſo delited in broode hattes, turky gowndes, rownde cappes, long beardes, polde heades, barreld breaches, pinckt buſkins, and courtlike ruffes, that it is an high offence to forſake them, and obey the prince and Metropolitane that haue commaunded them to be no more vſed of the miniſtrie. Faſting from meates to puniſh the bodie is litle eſtemed: chaſtitie is thought vnpoſsible: and the vowing of it an ordinance
of the diuell: the ſetting vp of images before our bodely eies, to ſtirre the minde to remembre Chriſt, is an heathniſh obſeruāce, praying is lippe labour, ryſing at midnight, voluntary, beggerye, going in vile, and baſe apparel, viſiting holy places, going on pelgrimage, be ordināces of the diuel: becking, bowīg, nodding, and ſuch like, tende to the obſeruance of ſome part of the lawe, as he ſayeth, and ſo by their ordring of the matter, we ſhal haue litle outwarde geſture left for the bodely honour of God.

To diſproue our kneeling and bowing before the croſſe: M.Fol. 185. b Calf. ſayeth, God to expreſſe the peculiar note of his faithfull ſeruāts, ſaieth of them, that they bowed not the knee to Baal. But what is this to the croſſe? Haue I not ſhewed a playne difference betwene, the croſſe and images of the Chriſtians and Baal, and other ſuch idols of the Gentills? Doe not the doctours of the church allowe the one, and cry out vpon the other? Yf he could cite any ſuch ſentēce out of any catholike writer, that alloweth the kneeling before Baal, as I haue for kneeling before the croſſe, he might match the croſſe and Baal together, but he can not, nor all his, be their malice neuer ſo greate. He ſaieth: it is the peculiar note of Gods ſeruātes, not to bowe their knee to Baal. Yf he meaneth the idol that the ſcripture calleth Baal, howe many theues, murderers whoormoūgers, extorſioners,A madde peculiar note to knovve a Chriſtian. vſurers, cōiurers, ſorcerers, heretikes, harlottes, church robbers, poyſoners, and Apoſtatats are there amonge you that neuer kneeled to that idol Baal? And yet yf your rule be true, that not to bowe the knee to Baal, be the peculiar note, that God expreſſeth to be the marke of his faithful ſeauāts, all thoſe that I mē tioned before, by your peculiar note muſt be taken for Gods faithfull ſeruantes. For they neuer bowed their knees to Baal. And then haue you done them wronge to puniſh them: But deceaue not your ſelf, and the ſimple M. Calf. It is one thinge to be a note of Gods ſeruants, and another to be the peculiar note of Gods faithfull ſeruants. The peculiar note of Gods faithfull conſiſteth not altogether in negatiues, as this doth. It hath ſome affirmatiues, but your negatiue religion muſt ſtand vpon negatiues,
and denie you to haue any peculiar note of Gods faithfull ſeruants.

M. Calfs rule to diſcerne an idolater.By our capping, knocking, kneeling, and other outwarde geſture, and adoration, he maketh a ſure rule to diſcerne a mere idolater. VVill he then neuer geue vs leaue to put of our cappes, to knock, to bowe, to kneele? Or is it poſsible for vs in any open or ſecret place to ſhewe any kinde of adoration by like geſture, though there be no croſſe, nor image before vs? Yf it be poſsible where there is no image, why ſhould it not be poſsible where there is an image?

Yf the curious heretikes will ſuſpect euill, they may ſay, that men kneling in their naked churches, at the communion table, kneele, bowe, and cappe, to the bread and wyne, to the walls, to the glaſe windoes, to the formes, to the tables, to the ſunne, to the moone, and practiſe M. Calfs rule, to diſcerne and trie them mere idolaters. Did M. Calf. neuer put of his cappe, kneele downe vpon the grownde, and aſke his fathers bleſſing? If he did, ſhall we by his owne rule diſcerne hym and trie hym a mere idolater? I would fayne lerne his anſwer.

Eſa. 45.Agayne, euery man putteth of his cappe, when he taketh an othe vpō a boke. And the taking of an oth rightly, vpon a boke is an high adoratiō of God, as apeareth by his owne wordes ſet before, in the place of Eſai, which he hym ſelf alleageth: Viuo ego, mihi flectetur omne genu, & omnis lingua iurabit mihi. I lyue ſaieth the Lord. Euery knee ſhall bowe to me, and euery tongue ſhall ſwere to me. And yf ſwearing be taken by the prophete Eſai, to be as high an adoration of God, as kneeling is, why doth he and his bretherne ſuffer the people rather to ſweare vpon a booke with their capps in their handes, which is a corporal thing, ſubiecte to many caſualties of corruption, than to kneele before the croſſe in doing of their adoration to God? Let hym anſwer yf he can.

Fol. 185. b A lye. But I wil haue neither good nor badde adiudged by geſture, quoth M. Calf. Either let hym tell me where I ſay ſo, or I will ſay, though it be to the derogation of his honorable perſon, that
he lieth, I neuer ſaid it, nor was of any other minde, nor in writīg nor in ſaying, but that he that would kneele and doe his adoration to the idol of Baal, Iuppiter, Venus, Iuno, or any ſuch rather than to our ſauiour Chriſt, before his croſſe, might by that external acte and outwarde geſture be diſcerned to be an idolater. The doing of our adoration to Chriſt before the croſſe, is not of that nature, and therefor the thing being lawfull, you doe but ſhewe your ſuſpicious head, and malitious nature to iudge any that doth it, a mere idolater. My ſaying was that there could be no feare or myſtruſt of idolatrie in Chriſtē men worſhipping and adoring the croſſe. And whē I ſpoke of Chriſten men, I meant ſuch, as loue God,No feare of idolatrie in true Chriſten men. ſerue God and woorſhip hym in ſpirite and truth, as other Chriſten men doe. And theſe you can not diſcerne to be idolaters by their kneeling, knockīg, cappīg, bowīg, or any ſuch outward geſture. Id potes quod iure potes, you cā doe that which you may doe by the lawe. And that which you may not doe by the lawe, you can not doe. VVherfore ſeing Gods lawe doth forbidde you to iudge of other, as longe as they doe that which is laufull, and doe as other Chriſtē men do, and haue done before them, you can not iudg them to be idolaters by any outwarde geſture and acte of theirs.

Twoe excuſes you make for vs of very goodwill no doubt: one,Calf. Fol. 185. b A lie. Fol. 186 a Mart. that we knowe the image or Croſſe to be but a piece of metal. etc. Another that we affirme that an image or a croſſe is nothing. But where is the licence, where is the proxye that auctoriſed you to make thoſe excuſes for vs? ſhewe your mandatū or yf you cā not, ſhewe vs howe it cā ſtād that the croſſe can be a piece of metal, and yet be nothīg? Is a piece of metal nothīg? Cā mē bye and ſel nothing? Metal is bought ād ſold, ād yf the croſſe metal were nothīg, howe were the poore goldſmithes deceaued that bought many a ſiluer croſſe? Did they bye nothing? ād geue greate ſummes of monie for nothīg? Loke out thoſe bedlēs I beſeeke you, that ſay, a croſſe is nothīg:No bedlē ſaieth, A croſſe is nothing. we neuer told you that a croſſe is nothīg nor euer wil. You would gladly make vs ſay of the croſſe, as S. Pauld ſaied in his owne perſon, and not in the perſon of the Corīth. (as you ſay) of an idol, Scimus quia idolū
nihil eſt, we knowe that an idol is nothing. Becauſe as Origen ſaieth,Orig. ho. 8. in 20. Geneſ. it repreſenteth nothing that euer was or ſhalbe in nature, as a horſe head ioyned to a Mans armes, and a ſnakes tayle in one bodie or ſuch like. But no man without horrible blaſphemie can ſay ſo of the croſſe M. Calf. It repreſenteth the paſsion of Chriſt that was ſome what, truly done here in earth. It repreſenteth Chriſt that had a true, and naturall bodie, vnleſſe yow wilbe come a Manichee, and ſay there was neuer no ſuch in nature as Chriſt was: and therfore you can not wreſt S. Paules place to proue your purpoſe, nor match it with the ſacrifices that were done to idols,No Chriſtē ſo ſimple but knovveth vvhat is meant by the croſſe. as you would gladly. But it paſſeth your ſkill, nor all the witte in your head is able to proue that any Chriſten man is ſo ſimple that he will deeme any greate vertue to be in the bare ſigne cōſidered as, a piece of wood or metal not withſtāding he ſeeth wiſe men geue adoratiō vnto it. God be thāked the people are ſufficiētly inſtructed to knowe a differēce betwene an image and the repreſented by the image, betwene the croſſe, ād the crucified. Yea I beleaue there be none that haue meane naturall wittes, that will thinke as you imagine, or haue ſuch a fiction that yf the bodie called the heart vnto accompt, A fictiō of M. Calfs. Fol. 186. a the heart ſhould be cōdēned of miſgouernemēt in the chaūcerie. For the heart calleth the bodie to accōpt, ād ſitteth in iudgmēt of his doings, as the worthier ād excellēter part in mā, ād condēneth the bodie of diſobediēce. As for the bodie it hath no iuriſdiction, nor ſuperioritie ouer the heart, and therfore cā not call the heart to an accōpt. Yf you haue ſuch affiāce in the cauſe that you thinke the heart ſhould be cōdēned by the bodie of miſgouernemēt in the chaūcery, I beſeke you ꝓpoūde theſe queſtiōs to the lerned of that court:Queſtions to be propounded by M. Calf in the chauncery. whether the bodie gouerth the heart, or the hearte gouerneth the bodie. Itē, whether the bodie calleth the heart to an accompt, or the heart calleth the bodie to an accompt. Itē whether, the bodie condemneth the heart, or the heart condē neth the bodie. And when you haue their reſolutions, trie furder whether the euidence of a Chriſten mās fact, kneling, knocking, holding vp his handes in the church, or els where, yea before the croſſe, or any other image, make as yow ſay, a ſufficient
probatiō of idolatrie, and is to good a witneſſe of a miſdemeaning minde.

Agayne for your furder inſtructiō, lerne howe this argumēt holdeth. Chriſten men kneele, knock, and hold vp their handes in churches before the croſſe of Chriſt, and image of his ſaincts: ergo they are idolaters, and haue miſdemeaning mindes. If by lerning, and conſcience it be examined in the chauncerie and founde to be full of ignorance and folly, then may you thinke your ſelf to be an ignorant foole for talking ſo abſurdely and iudging ſo raſhly. In king Ezechias matter yf I had ben aduocate to impugne his deede, for breaking the braſen ſerpēt,Of Ezechias fact breaking the braſen ſerpent. I would neuer haue tried the caſe of iniuſtice againſt hym. I would never haue diſallowed his doing. For Ezechias was able to make iuſt proufe of a crime. He was able to conuince them of idolatrie both by their deedes, and alſo by their owne wordes. The ſcripture ſaieth:4. Reg. 18. The people burnt incenſe vnto the braſen ſerpent vntill that preſent tyme. VVhich God had forbidden, they made them ſelues images, woods, groues, an did ſacrifice after the māner of the Gentills, fecerunt
que verba peſsima irritantes dominum, 4. Reg. 17 and they ſpoke moſt wicked wordes, prouoking God: and that not priuilie, but verbis nō tectis, in playne and euidēt wordes. They were ſo prone to idolatrie, that they worſhipped the idols of the paynimes, and kept it not pryuie in heart, but ſaied opēly: Sequamur deos alienos, Let vs followe ſtraunge Gods: Hij ſunt Dij tui Iſrael. Thes are thy gods o Iſrael: And by this you may vnderſtād that Ezechias had manifeſt proufe of their idolatrie, both by worde and deede, and ſeing he ſawe ſo much euidence of their wickednes, and had beſides this, the ſecret inſtruction of God, that he ſhould not feare to breake that braſen ſerpent, there nedeth no lawier to defende his fact: It defendeth it ſelf ſufficiently.

Marry as for you (ſir) what like euidēce haue you of any facte or idolatrous deede in any chriſtiā?No euidē ce of any idolatrous fact in true Chriſtiās. VVho did euer burne incēſe to an image, as vnto God? VVho euer ſayed: Sequamur deos alienos? Let vs followe ſtraūge Gods? VVho euer ſaied to any croſſe, crucifix, or image, Ecce dij tui Iſrael? Behold thy Gods o Iſrael? Speake, thowe accuſer of thy bretherne, thowe condemner of
the Chriſtians, thowe iudger of other mens ſeruants. Speake for ſhame. VVhat Chriſtian euer beleaued ſo? Either make an inſtance, or we will condēne the for this raſh iudgment, and miſdeming of Chriſtians, and ſay that thowe doeſt, vſe the fact of Ezechias to no purpoſe againſt vs.

Daniels cōpaniōs.Touching Daniels cōpanions, yf they had feed you, or me, or any aduocate beſides, whatſoeuer you or any other could ſay for them, they ſhould haue ben accuſed of idolatrie, Yf they had bowed their knee, to the image, which the king commaunded them to worſhip. For it was a mere wicked idol, taken and reputed for God, and worſhipped for God. To ſuch no man boweth the knee, but with ſuſpitiō of idolatrie. But that the croſſe or crucifixe is, or hath ben taken, for ſuch, and as vnlaufull to be worſhipped, as that was, you ſhould firſt haue proued, and thē triūphed: but becauſe you knewe your weaknes in that behalf, you vſe a common ſophiſtication called, Petitio principij, and like a foliſh ſophiſter you preſuppoſe, that to be proued, which you were neuer able to proue, nor ſhalbe as longe as ſcriptures, councells, fathers, reaſon, and common ſenſe ſhalbe of any authoritie with men. To procede, I ſaied.

VVhen you ſee men praying, in my poore iudgment it is a good conſequent to ſay: They be Chriſten men. Therfore they ſerue God in ſpirite and truthe:Calf. Fol. 186. b This is a poore iudgment, quoth M. Calf. that becauſe god is worſhipped in ſpirite and in truth therfor mē falling before a piece of wood, knocking the breaſt, and holding vp the handes, may not in any wiſe be thought idolaters. Mart. But howe poore his iudgmēt and honeſtie alſo is, iudge, I beſeeke you. I talked of men that were baptiſed in Chriſt, and beleaued in God, and ſerued hym in ſpirite and truth, and ſaied, whenſoeuer they pray, whereſoeuer they kneele, whatſoeuer geſtures they vſe, they geue al honour and prayſe to god. Nowe cometh M. Calf. and ſpeaketh indefinitely of mē, which may be referred to Heathens, Pagans, Turkes, infidels, and ſuch like as wel as to Chriſtians, and becauſe men, that is to ſay ſome men, as Turkes, Iewes, Heathēs, Pagans, infidels, may be iudged
to be idolaters by kneeling, knocking, or holding vp their handes to any of their idols, he concludeth againſt vs, that Chriſten men may for like geſture before the croſſe of Chriſt and his image, be adiudged for ſuch. But that is a vile furmiſe and moſt wicked ſuſpicion contrary to the commaundement of God, ſaying, iudg not, and ye ſhall not be iudged. VVherfore becauſe M.A vile furmiſe and vvicked ſuſpicion. Calf. taketh vātage of that which I ſpoke in waye of humilitie, I wil nowe therfore ſtoutely ſay vnto him, ſir, whē you ſee mē, that is to ſay, men that are baptiſed, mē that beleue in god, praying, yea before any image, and holding vp their hādes and knocking their bereaſts, it is a good cōſequēt to ſay:A good Cōſequēt They be Chriſtē men, ergo they ſerue God in ſpirite and truth: and we may not iudg the contrary. For we can not entre into their heartes, and mindes where God is ſerued. VVe can not cōdēne thē for their outwarde geſtures by which they geue their corporall honour to God. Trie this in the courte of Chauncery, where conſciēce is examined, where you thinke the bodie wil cōdēne the heart of miſgouernement. And yf it be not founde a good argument, returne it to me, and I wil iuſtifie it. In the meane tyme we tell you, that wicked ſurmiſes and vayne ſuſpicions are contrary to the ghoſpell. Furder we neuer ſought by Roodes and images to plante any opinion of holynes and diuinitie to reſt in dead thinges. But as we haue knowen God, ſo haue we glorified him, ſo haue we ben thankeful vnto him, and not become vayne in our imaginatiōs, we haue not had our heartes ful of darknes, cōcerning the knoweledg of the only true, and almightye God.The adoration of the croſſe ſtandeth vvith the glorie of God. VVe haue not geuen the glorie of his name to other. The worſhip and adoratiō which we exacte to be geuen to the croſſe, ſtādeth with the glorie of his name, as wel as your kneeling at the cō munion table, your putting of your cappe to the cloth of eſtate, your vayling the bōnet to the prīces lettres, your bowīg your bodies to the Quenes maieſtie, your kiſsing of the booke when you take an othe, and ſuch reuerēces that may be done to creatures ſtand with the glorie of God. VVherefore in chardging vs with idolatrie, or any diſhonour to God in this behalf, you ſhewe more malice than reaſon, and declare that your tongue
is more ſclaunderous, than your heart is wiſe.

Calf. Fol 187. aDrawing towards an end, you ſay: Thus haue I anſwered your ten Articles vſing more woordes in diſprouf of them, than the cauſe requireth, or any man of indifferency, would loke for at my handes. Mart. But howe wel you haue anſwered, let the indifferent that reade this examination of your anſwer iudge ſincerely. In deede I acknowledg that you haue vſed more woordes in diſproufe of them, thā the cauſe requireth or any man of indifferencie would loke for at your handes. For the cauſe being a moſt certane and vndoubted truth, ſuch as hath contynued in all ages amongeſt Chriſten men, euer ſithens the Apoſtles tyme, all faithfull men that loue the croſſe of Chriſt ſhould embrace the ſigne of their ſaluation, and neither reuile it nor blaſphemouſly abuſe it, nor vtter any woordes to the diſproufe of it. No man of indifferencie looked for at your handes, that you ſhould liken the croſſe of Chriſt, to a gallowes, to the helmet of hell, and to the coniurers Mace, No man of indifferencie loked,No man of indifferencie loked for ſuch ſtuff of M. Calf. that you ſhould call it, a Magical inchauntement, am heathniſh obſeruance, a ſuperſtition of gentills, or conqueſt againſt Chriſtians, No man of indifferēcie loked that yow ſhould ſay: it was a dumbe God, a dead diuel, a ſcholemaſter of errour, and impietie, and God in the Roodelofte. No man of indifferencie loked that you ſhould ſo falſely wreſt and corrupte the ſcriptures, ſo vntrulye alleage, and mangle the fathers, ſo fondly reiecte and contemne the auncient doctours, ſo malitiouſly reporte of holy ſaincts, biſshops, Emperours, and empreſſes, and ſo conremptuoſly condemne and abhorre the generall councells, and preferre an aſſemble of moſt wicked and accurſed heretikes before them. No man of indifferencie loked for ſo many extrauagant and idle diſcourſes, ſo many impudent blaſphemous, and ſclaunderous lies, ſo many falſe allegations, ſo many euil tranſlations, and ſo many fooliſh contradictions, as you haue vttred in this your anſwer as ſhall particularly hereafter apeare.

And becauſe you will cōtynewe like your ſelf, euē in the very end you make an impudēt lye to helpe your credit. For you ſay,An impudent lie. Calf. Fol 187. a that you haue turned ouer leafe by leaſe, and peruſed eche lyne and woorde that had any reaſon in it, annexing a ſufficient and the ſame abundant confutation of it. VVhich is moſt falſe.Mart. As for the ſufficiencie of your cōfutation, Let the readers iudg. As for the turning ouer of leafe by leafe, and peruſing eche woord that had any reaſon in it,VVel nigh thirthy places vnanſvverd. it ſhall apeare that you haue omitted well nigh thirtye places alleaged out of Clement, Tertullian, S. Cyprian, Cornelius, Melchiades, Origen, Chriſoſtome, Cyrill, Socrates, Theodoretus, Sozomenus, S. Ambroſe, S. Auguſt. S. Hierome, Euſebius, Leo and Euthymius, who were lerned men and like to haue reaſon in their ſayings, and annexed no confutation vnto them at all, much leſſe any that was ſufficient and abundant.

My concluſion in deede you deale not withall, I blame yow not. It is to hard meate your for weake teethe. Yf it be but an heape of lyes and ſclaunders (as yow ſaye) it had ben more for your honeſtie to anſwer them,My cōcluſion not touched. than with ſilence to paſſe thē ouer. But you ſawe more weight and pith in it, than you and all yours are able to improue with like authoritie or reaſon. And therefore yow thought it beſt to anſwer with ſilence. But that ſilence we take for confeſsion. For whoſoeuer keepeth ſilence when he ſhould ſpeake, the matter wherto he ſhould anſwer tending to his preiudice or hurt, ſemeth to conſent.

Thus haue I examined the chiefe poynts and effect of your anſwere, to the treatiſe of the croſſe, and ſo diſcouered your corruptions, errours, and falſities, that eche man may ſee the weaknes of your cauſe, and perceaue manifeſtly that the cauſe which I toke in hand ſtandeth too faſt to be battred with your feeble aſſaultes. VVherfore I deſire the gentle reader to doe no more but reade and regarde, and iudge indifferently, and beware of theſe deceithfull workemen, and lying lippes. And whereas M. Calf. hath determined yf his ſleight dealing and ſhameleſſe lies ſhould be detected by me, and ſet in print to the vie we of the worlde, to contemne ſuch a lewde aduerſarie, Fol. 187. b and
geue place to other that with more freedome of ſpeache, and derogation to their perſons might anſwer accordingly, my requeſt is, that ſome frend of his tell hym politikely, that, ſeing he ſuſtayneth ſuch and honorable perſonage, it ſhall be greate derogatiō to his perſon to geue ouer this quarrell to another that hath neither ſuch impudencie to denie the aun •• nt fathers, nor ſuch immodeſtie to abhorre generall councells, nor ſuch vnhoneſtie to falſifie and wreaſt the ſcriptures, nor ſuch ſleightes to abuſe the doctours, nor ſuch inuentions to ſhyft away truthes, nor ſuch gloſes to colour lyes, nor ſuch ſclaunderous wordes to rayle againſt biſhops, princes, and ſainctes, nor ſuch vilanous termes to inueigh againſt Chriſtes church and his ſacramēts. For yf it be not workemanly done, it ſhalbe greate derogation to his perſon. But ſeing he hath determined to contemne me as a lewde aduerſarie, and for feare leſt it ſhould be a derogation to his perſon, ſaieth he will not anſwer that which I ſhall put in print, I require hym to auouche that which he hym ſelf hath ſetfoorth in print, and proue thoſe his parodoxes, poſitions and aſſertions, by the playne and vndoubted worde of God, by the true and godly fathers of the church, and by laufull councells, prouinciall or generall, which I haue gathered out of his boke, and ſet in the beginning of this boke, or els being conuinced with the force of truth, acknowledg them to be impious and blaſphemous, contrary to the playne and vndoubted woord of God, contrary to the true and holy fathers of the church, contrary to the determination of prouincial and general councells, and confeſſe his ouerſights, errours, and hereſies, and in humilitie of heart and meakenes of ſpirite, embrace the truth, and returne to the vnitie of Chriſtes catholike churche, and doe the worthy fruictes of penance for his wicked abhominations, and horrible blaſphemies, which God graunte, Amen.

q.l: Non meliora meis, ſed quae pro tempore noſti,
Impius impertis: exegi, hijs vtere mecum.
